HEADLINE: Diplomacy Fails to End Store Boycott In Flatbush

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
Little but the seasons have changed in front of the Korean-owned Family Red Apple grocery store in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
The black-led boycott of the store that began last winter has stretched bitterly -and effectively - into the summer, with no resolution in sight, despite lawsuits, court orders and quiet efforts by the Dinkins administration to mediate the conflict.
''The city can't do anything about this,'' a demonstrator said this weekend outside the nearly deserted store on Church Avenue. ''This is in the hands of the people.'' A few feet away, picketers stood behind a police barricade, as they have done almost every day for close to six months, chanting, ''Boycott! Boycott!'' Their presence and their voices are as much a part of the street scene now as the sound of traffic. 
''Things stand more or less where they were when this all started,'' said Richard A. Izzo, the lawyer for the store owner. ''Business is very sparse. As far as I can see, the city has done nothing to resolve this.''
 
Trying Quiet Diplomacy
The New York City Commission on Human Rights is leading the efforts of the Dinkins administration to end the conflict, which began after a confrontation between a black shopper and store employees. The commission has tried quiet diplomacy, speeches by the Mayor and public forums, but so far nothing has worked.
In the meantime, administration officials have begun working on ways to avoid future boycotts, by examining what Dennis deLeon, the city's Human Rights Commissioner, said is the underlying cause of the dispute: a lack of economic opportunity for all.
Demonstrators have complained about a paucity of black-owned businesses in the area, and the commission is studying lending practices as well as ways to improve relations between customers and owners.
At the same time, a fact-finding team appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins, which includes blacks and Koreans, is looking into the cause of the boycott.
''There are no magic wands or 30-second agendas,'' said Robert F. Sherman, the director of the commission's community relations institute. ''It's a tricky situation.''
At the core of the boycott remains the sharply disputed confrontation last January between the black shopper, Giselaine Felissaint, and store employees.
Mrs. Felissaint, a Haitian immigrant, contends that she was assaulted by three employees on Jan. 18 during an argument over a purchase. The employees deny the charge, and say that she became unruly after being asked to pay for some items.
 
Manager Is Charged
The demonstrators have demanded that the three men be arrested and that the store close because of the incident and because of what they said was a history of poor treatment of black customers by store management. A second Korean-owned store across the street is also being boycotted.
The demands have not changed even though the manager of the Family Red Apple, Pong Ok Jang, 32 years old, was charged with assault on July 7. Patrick Clark, a spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney's Office, said it appeared that no one else would be charged in the incident, but said ''the investigation is continuing.''
George Dames, a boycott leader, said: ''The stores have become a symbol of what has happened across this city in terms of the lack of recognizing the humanity of black people. It was not an isolated incident. And people are realizing that it doesn't have to be tolerated.''
Mr. deLeon said his office tried to convince Mrs. Felissaint to seek to end the boycott, but she has refused, pending the outcome of the criminal case. She has also sued the store's owner, Bong Jae Jang.
Mr. deLeon said the city then sought to have the leaders of the Haitian community ask for an end to the boycott, an effort that failed, partly because the boycott has taken on a life of its own, independent of Mrs. Felissaint.
 
'Grass Roots Style of Protest'
The commissioner said his staff has talked with 50 black and Korean neighborhood advocates, clergy and business leaders, and dozens of other Flatbush residents were interviewed by the fact finding team during a public forum last month. The black leaders of the boycott are a diverse group, making negotiations difficult, he said.
''It's a very grass-roots style of protest,'' Mr. Sherman said. ''Word spreads by word of mouth and identifying a single leader is difficult. There are a number of leaders and the landscape is always shifting.''
Mrs. Felissaint's lawyer, Colin A. Moore, said that the boycott ''has become a political movement'' in which the ''boycotters are fighting for respect for black people.''
But Mr. Moore said he did not think closing the stores would resolve long-term problems at the root of the conflict and the others that have erupted in the city between various immigrant and ethnic groups over the years.
''Nobody wins if the store leaves,'' he said. ''All you have is an empty store. The attitudes don't change. But ending the boycott right now should not be the objective. The objective should be removing the root causes: disrespect, economic powerlessness and a criminal justice system that is not there to assist the black community.'' Meanwhile, the boycott drags on. On June 27, Justice Gerald S. Held of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn ordered the police to enforce an injunction he issued in May against the picketers. But the city has appealed the order, saying that the police should be allowed to use discretion.
Not everyone in the neighborhood supports the boycott. This weekend, the picketers were defied by occasional shoppers, who were heckled, sometimes with humor and sometimes with harshness.
 
Tension, Attention Fading
''I'm suprised at you, sister,'' a man told a woman as she left the store. ''You are hurting my heart.'' She stared at him and said, ''I'm ashamed of you.''
Once in recent weeks, an elderly woman approached the barricade and distributed religious fliers.
''You have to forgive,'' she said. ''We've been forgiving for 400 years,'' a young man said. ''They attack one black woman, they attack them all.''
Racial slurs have been exchanged on both sides. But in recent weeks, tensions, the number of picketers and media attention have all decreased.
The boycott has continued to draw ''outsiders,'' from a Roman Catholic priest from Harlem, who supports the boycotters, to followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who support the store.
 
'A Lot of Integrity'
Charles Jenkins, the director of one of the rights commission's Brooklyn offices, has monitored the boycott from the beginning, visiting the picket line and talking with both sides.
''I never thought it would last this long,'' he said. ''There is a lot of integrity on the part of the demonstrators. They believe what they're doing is right. They're not looking for money. They're not looking to be bought off. They believe it's a correct issue and they're going to dig in and fight.''
Mr. Izzo laughed at that portrayal and said a few boycotters have intimidated the largely black neighborhood of immigrants. One of their motives, he said, is ''pure and simple racism.''
''I don't mean the residents of the community are racists,'' he said. ''I mean the organizers of the boycott.''
Mr. Dames responded that there are many Korean-owned stores in the area that are not being boycotted. ''Racism has nothing to do with this,'' he said. It's a question of respect.''

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Unexpected Shift In a Labor Rate

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
AN era might be ending, unexpectedly. Americans have been jumping into the labor force in ever-increasing numbers since the 1960's, so that today about 66.4 percent of the working-age population holds jobs or seeks them. The problem is that the labor participation rate, as it is called, was the same 66.4 percent a year ago. Having risen year after year, it might finally be leveling off -and just when the Labor Department and many economists did not expect it to be.
The labor participation rate is not an easily grasped concept. Although it is calculated monthly along with the unemployment rate, the latter attracts much more attention. That probably should not be the case, for the rate at which people enter the labor force determines how many end up unemployed. And right now, the leveling off of labor participation is probably creating an unemployment rate that is artificially low at 5.2 percent. 
''With labor participation leveling off, it is easier to keep the unemployment rate down,'' said Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. And, of course, a low civilian unemployment rate - it declined in June from May's 5.3 percent - might make the American economy seem to be stronger than it actually is.
The reason for this false impression lies in the difficulty in distinguishing between jobless people inside and outside the labor force. The Labor Department uses a monthly survey of 60,000 households, representative of the population, to determine the difference. If someone of working age reports having a job or actively looking for one, then that person is counted as a participant in the labor force. As of June, there were 126.5 million participants, with 6.4 million of them unemployed.
But if the answer comes back that a jobless person is not looking for work, then that person is excluded from the labor force, no matter what the reason for not seeking work. The common reasons include being in school, at home raising kids, in early retirement or unlikely to find an appropriate job. Currently, 63.1 million working-age people are outside the labor force. And surprisingly, the fastest-growing contingent is young, 16 to 24 years old.
By the laws of demographics, they should not be the dropouts but the leaders in making the labor participation rate rise in the 1990's. Women over 25 had led the rise since the late 1960's, driving the rate from 59 percent to today's 66.4 percent as they converted in huge numbers from homemakers to wage earners. And now the young people should take over. They are fewer in number than the ''baby boom'' generation, so a greater percentage of these 16-to-24-year-olds should be drawn into the labor force to fill all the job slots.
Partly in expectation of this shift, the Labor Department had projected that the overall labor participation rate would continue to rise, reaching 69 percent in the year 2000. Instead, this upward movement is being held in check, above all by the 16-to-19-year-olds, whose participation rate has plunged more than three percentage points since January, to 52.9 percent. The participation rate of the 20-to-24-year-olds is also down over the last seven months, by one percentage point. Meanwhile, older groups are all holding their own, and the rate for women 25 and over has edged up again.
What is happening to the young people? No one knows yet, but labor economists offer possible explanations. One is that the wages paid to young people have fallen by more than 20 percent over the last 15 years, when adjusted for inflation, and young people are not willing to work at low pay, unless the jobs lead to promotions. Too many do not.
''Young people are more willing to live with their parents than they were 20 years ago,'' said Richard Freeman, a Harvard economist. ''If you are able to earn only $5 or $6 an hour, you are more likely to get by living with your parents, rather than enter the labor force.''
Another explanation is that young people are dropping out because a sluggish American economy is creating fewer and fewer new jobs for them. Similar weak job creation flattened the overall labor participation rate during recessions in the early 1980's and mid-1970's.
A flaw in this explanation is that the nation is not considered to be in a recession today, although the growth of the economy is weak.
Whatever the causes, a labor participation rate that is no longer rising might have a silver lining. When the economy does become strong again, business will have a pool of idle workers to draw into jobs as production rises, without having to bid up wages unduly, some economists reason.
And maybe Americans would be better off if labor participation declined a bit. After all, it is higher than in other industrial countries, except Sweden. ''I would look positively at a leveling off,'' Mr. Freeman said. ''We certainly don't want 100 percent of the population working.''

HEADLINE: World Farm Subsidies in Trade-Talk Spotlight

BYLINE: By DAVID ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
When international trade talks reconvene in Geneva on July 23, the negotiators will resume their long-stalled discussions of agriculture subsidies.
That in itself was probably the main accomplishment of the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial countries in Houston last week. The attention paid to farm policy by the leaders of the richest countries in the world, who rarely focus on so mundane a topic, gave the deadlocked trade talks the political impetus that had been missing.
But the countries themselves are little closer to a resolution of their differences on the issue, and many officials and leading economists here and in Europe question whether the gaps can be bridged before the current round of trade talks ends in December. 
''The proof of the pudding of what was done in Houston will be in the tasting in Geneva,'' said Jeffrey J. Schott, an economist who specializes in trade policy at the Institute for International Economics, a private research organization.
''So far,'' he added in an interview, ''none of the sides have changed their positions.''
All seven industrial countries at the summit - the United States, Canada, Britain, France, West Germany, Italy and Japan - subsidize farmers to one degree or another with tariffs and quotas on imports, export supports and internal price supports.
For example, the United States has import quotas on sugar, peanuts and dairy products and makes price-support payments to growers of many crops. Europe subsidizes its farmers to a much greater extent, and rice imports are prohibited altogether in Japan.
These barriers distort the world market for foods and feed grains. The world price for sugar is about 10 cents a pound, for example. But it costs five times that much in American supermarkets and even more in Europe, mainly because inexpensive imports are blocked and sugar producers are guaranteed a high price by their governments.
As a result, developing countries, which have little to sell but agriculture products, have trouble entering the world markets and gaining the resources they need for their economies to grow.
President Bush pushed his counterparts in Houston on the issue, he said, because his trade advisers had convinced him that the trade negotiations would break down if the industrial countries did not agree at least to cut their farm subsidies if not abolish them.
''Agriculture is the underpinning of the whole round,'' said William E. Brock, a special trade representative in the Reagan Administration, who was in Houston as a private consultant to lobby for change. ''Half the countries in the world will take a walk if agriculture is not part of the agreement.''
 
Crucial Issues at Stake
If the talks collapse, the industrial countries will not get a settlement on issues that are of primary importance to them: freedom for banks and insurance companies to open branches in developing countries, overseas markets for services like telecommunications, construction and engineering, and standards to protect intellectual property. American officials calculate, for example, that American businesses lose $50 billion a year to piracy of trademarks, patents and copyrights.
If the trade talks are successful, said Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, ''there will be an economic renaissance for the 21st century.'' If they fail, she added, ''the world will have dangerously decreased economic prosperity.''
Still, the European countries, as much as they would gain from more open markets for their manufactured products and services, have been reluctant to relinquish their farm subsidies. And the Bush Administration could never sell Congress and American farmers on cutting subsidies as long as they are prevalent elsewhere.
 
Europe's Social Farm Policy
The Common Agriculture Policy, which governs the European Community on the issue, maintains high domestic prices for farm products with quotas and tariffs. That leads to more production than Europe can consume. The surplus is dumped on the world market, and export supports are paid to farmers to compensate them for the lower world price.
Farmers are a potent political force in the 12 countries of the community, which has more than 10 million farmers, compared with only two million in the United States. Moreover, the Europeans consider their farm policies to be social and ecological policies as well as economic ones.
''I've been in your cities,'' a European official told an American reporter, ''and I don't want our cities to get like that, crowded with all the people who have moved off the farms. We don't have plains and prairies and deserts like you. Our farms are our countryside.''
 
Efficiency Another Factor
The Europeans have another reason to resist lowering their subsidies. Their farms are much less efficient than those in the United States and Canada, and they would not prove competitive in a free market. If controls were lifted, the European official said, ''our farmers would go bust.''
Perhaps the most inefficient farms are in Bavaria, where the farmers are an important part of the political coalition of the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl. He is facing a crucial election in December, just as the trade talks will be winding up.
The summit leaders agreed that their countries would make ''substantial progressive reductions'' in their farm supports. But their final communique as a whole was evasive and left to the Geneva negotiators the central questions of how large and how fast the reductions would be made.
Optimists read the summit agreement to mean that the United States has relinquished its position that all subsidies should be abolished according to a specific timetable and that the Europeans have conceded that some reduction in supports is necessary.

HEADLINE: Discussions Are Held On Fast Data Network

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The International Business Machines Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation and officials at a group of Michigan universities have quietly begun discussions with the Federal Government about creating a nonprofit company that would operate a high-speed computer network that could one day reach every home in the country.
Some competitors worry that I.B.M. and MCI will gain an inside track in the race to build such a network, which is expected to replace the various specialized but much slower networks in use today.
 
Similar to Highway System
The proposed network would function like the nation's interstate highway system, carrying not just computer data but television images, telephone conversations and other forms of communication.
Just as the highway system created economic activity everywhere it was built in the 1950's, the computer network is expected to create businesses that take advantage of its technology. 
The proposed network is thus seen as a significant business opportunity. Traffic on the National Science Foundation Network, or Nsfnet, a specialized network started three years ago by I.B.M., MCI and the Michigan universities, is increasing by 25 percent a month.
I.B.M. and the Washington-based MCI say their motivation is to make the United States stronger. But their proposal is raising complex issues like who will operate the data networks and how they will be financed. A number of corporations, including computer manufacturers, regional telephone operating companies and providers of long-distance telephone service are eager to participate in developing high-speed networks.
The discussions with the Government center on the network's management, whether by the Government or private corporations, as well as its structure.
 
Essential to Competitiveness
Many industry executives and public officials view the networks as essential to promoting industrial competitiveness in areas ranging from broadcasting to scientific research.
I.B.M., MCI and the universities quietly sent a proposal to Government officials urging that they set up a nonprofit corporation to operate a national network that would carry data at more than 700 times the speed of today's fastest networks.
Some competitors in the computer and communications businesses are concerned that creating a corporation involving I.B.M. and MCI might stifle small commercial operations that have begun providing network services regionally.
''The regional computer networks are very uptight about this,'' said one computer industry executive, who spoke last week on the condition that he not be identified. ''They are very scared about this issue.''
 
Other Efforts Under Way
The initiative by the three organizations, which are joined in a partnership operating the National Science Foundation Network, is one of several being explored to design and deploy high-speed computer networks.
A bill pending in Congress introduced by Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, would create financing for developing a high-speed computer network called the National Research and Education Network to link the nation's supercomputer centers.
A consortium effort, organized by the Corporation for National Research Initiatives, a nonprofit research organization based in Reston, Va., has also drawn together corporations, universities and Government agencies to experiment with computer hardware and software that can transmit data at extraordinarily high speeds.
I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., insisted that it was not trying to pre-empt other efforts to develop advanced computer networks.
''Nsfnet has been so successful that we're struggling to determine this kind of growth,'' said Allan H. Weis, I.B.M.'s vice president of engineering and scientific computing. ''We want to make sure that there is consensus. If we did something and it was structured improperly, it could hurt the growth of the network.''
 
Motivations Questioned
But others are puzzled about I.B.M.'s motivations for proposing a separate corporation to control the operation of data superhighways when advanced development of the systems is just beginning.
''It is still a wide-open question of how to structure a future network,'' said Fred J. Howlett, the division manager for high-speed data networks at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. ''The legislative momentum behind funding a high-speed computer network is strong right now. If there is any indication that corporations might go ahead without Government support, it wouldn't be helpful to the legislative effort.''
I.B.M. has a significant advantage in the emerging computer network market because of its early investment in Nsfnet, a number of industry executives said. And several suggested that the company might be considering computer networks as a future market for expansion.
 
Concerns From Success
The issue has generated concern in part because of the tremendous success of Nsfnet, which is the backbone of a nationwide scientific, educational and commercial network known as Internet. The network now has several million users and consists of more than 60,000 large and small computers. It carries more than 3.2 billion packets of data each month, officials at the National Science Foundation said.
Nsfnet is also cited as a example of how a small amount of Federal financing can have a tremendous effect.

HEADLINE: Corrections Detroit Set For Talks With U.A.W.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 15

 BODY:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about negotiations between the Big Three auto companies and the United Automobile Workers referred incorrectly to the union membership of workers at United States plants owned wholly or partly by Japanese car makers. At some plants, hourly workers are indeed represented by the United Automobile Workers. Also, a chart with the article misstated the average hourly wage paid last year to workers at Honda of America. It was $15.32, including 77 cents for profit-sharing.
Contract negotiations between the Big Three auto makers and the United Automobile Workers union, which have historically been fractious, show signs of being much tamer this year. But the apparent calm may be deceiving.
Both sides in the bargaining, which opens on Wednesday, concede that they have less leverage than ever to wrench painful economic concessions from one another or to force a big work stoppage. An important reason is that their common adversary, the Japanese auto industry, grows more formidable by the day and would undoubtedly gain ground as a result of protracted labor strife. 
Moreover, labor and management have been trying to cooperate more. One example is innovative factory-floor programs that give hourly workers more responsibility and turn foremen into coaches. The bitterness engendered by a long national strike could undermine such efforts.
 
'Maturing' of the Process
''It's quieter this year, and I think it would be fair to say that this might be because of a maturing of the negotiating process,'' said a member of the U.A.W. staff who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
''Normally at this time you'd see the union demanding job security, and the companies would be saying they were in big trouble,'' said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. ''The two sides would be screaming at each other.''
Nevertheless, Stephen P. Yokich, U.A.W. vice president, has been quoted in local newspapers as saying: ''It's easy to strike. It's getting a settlement that's hard.''
Experts point out that a strike might still occur when the current contract expires on Sept. 14, particularly if talks snag on the important unresolved issues of health-care costs and job security.
The auto makers desperately want to reduce the cost of health benefits, which has grown into the single biggest expense in building cars and trucks. The union wants to halt the loss of jobs caused by the shutdown of underused plants, especially at the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation. To the extent the U.A.W. cannot stop the loss of jobs, it wants the auto makers to improve the financial umbrella for those who are laid off. Since 1987, G.M. has spent more than $600 million on jobless benefits for workers who have permanently lost their jobs.
 
Big Three Pay More
Dan Luria, a fellow at the Industrial Technology Institute, a research group in Ann Arbor, Mich., predicted that a new three-year contract covering nearly 500,000 United States auto workers at G.M., the Ford Motor Company and Chrysler would give workers a wage increase in the first year and lump-sum bounses in the second and third years. The raise may mean an increase in auto workers' salaries of 15 percent to 20 percent over three years, he said. The 500,000 workers are about half of the U.A.W.'s overall membership, which also includes workers at non-Big Three parts plants and aerospace and farm equipment companies.
Currently, auto workers at the Big Three have a higher average hourly base wage than those at Japanese car plants in the United States, according to Harbour & Associates, a consulting firm based in Troy, Mich. Hourly workers at the Japanese ''transplants'' are not covered by the U.A.W. contract.
Workers averaged $15.94 an hour at G.M. in 1989, $15.73 at Chrysler and $15.48 at Ford, compared with $15.16 at the Mazda Motor Corporation's United States operations, $14.95 at the Toyota Motor Company, $14.55 at the Honda Motor Company and $14.23 at the Nissan Motor Company. The Japanese car makers also have an advantage in productivity. Whereas G.M. averaged 4.99 workers per car per day, for example, Nissan averaged 2.94.
The union will try to resist demands by the auto makers that workers be forced to pay higher deductibles on their medical insurance and to begin to pay a percentage of their medical bills beyond the deductible, Mr. Luria said. Instead, the union may be willing to accept rules that encourage members to join health maintenance organizations and preferred-provider organizations, in which doctors and hospitals provide care at a lower price.
More militant union members, known as the New Directions movement, have been less active since recent local elections in which many of their candidates were defeated. 50% Chance Seen for Strike The industry has not had a protracted strike since a seven-week walkout against G.M. in 1970. The U.A.W. staged a short walkout against several G.M. plants in 1984. Edward J. Sullivan, an economist for the WEFA Group, rates the chance of a strike at about 50 percent.
''Existing job-security measures are viewed as inadequate protection against the structural changes facing the industry,'' Mr. Sullivan said, referring to the rise in the past five years of American-based auto plants owned by Japanese car companies.
In a poll in the spring by The Detroit Free Press, more than 50 percent of auto workers said their top priority was ''strong job guarantees and outsourcing restrictions.'' Outsourcing is the practice of subcontracting some manufacturing work to foreign and domestic factories with lower labor costs. More than half those polled said they had been saving money in the event of a strike.
The negotiating process will work this way: Beginning on Wednesday, negotiators for the union will meet separately with negotiators for each of the Big Three in talks that will last through August. Close to Labor Day top union executives will pick one of the auto makers as its ''target'' and attempt to negotiate a master contract with that company by the Sept. 14 expiration date of the current contract.
Ford's chairman, Harold A. Poling, said early this year that he would not mind if Ford was chosen as the target; that way Ford negotiators could structure an agreement that would favor their interests. Ford, which has very little unused capacity, might be quite willing to agree to strong job-security provisions in return for concessions on health-care costs.
If an agreement is reached, the master contract will be taken to each of the other auto makers. But this ''patterned bargaining'' could break down if the other auto makers demand special concessions that acknowledge their competitive position. Chrysler has said that its weaker financial position requires that it have a contract different from G.M.'s and Ford's.
If agreements are not reached, union members may walk out or there may be a short contract extension in hopes of averting a strike.
 
Need to Be Competitive
In the contract signed with the U.A.W. in 1987, G.M. agreed not to shut any plants permanently, although it was allowed to idle plants indefinitely if sales were slow. A short time later G.M. began ''idling'' big assembly plants, and few people expect that they will reopen. G.M.'s move exposed a loophole in the contract, but it also made clear the reality that auto makers cannot continue to build cars for which there are no customers.
Ultimately, company and union leaders realize that the only way to keep members working will be to sell more cars and trucks, which means being more competitive with Japanese auto makers. The Japanese companies in the first six months of 1990 captured a record 28 percent of the new-car market in the United States, up from 24 percent a year ago.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Little Change Expected for Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The bond market, which has so far this summer received help from both the President of the United States and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, may have a more difficult time finding new friends in the weeks ahead. But without further assistance, credit market analysts said, interest rates were not likely to decline much from current levels, and might even rise.
''I am not totally bearish, but we have had a good move'' in rates, said Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. ''Right now the market is very vulnerable to any bad news. To improve further we need further evidence of a weak economy or a budget deal out of Congress.'' 
Bad news has indeed been a fairly scarce commodity lately, and has been especially rare when it bears a Washington dateline.
 
Statements Welcomed
In late June President Bush encouraged the credit markets by forswearing a long-standing pledge not to seek tax increases as a way of securing a substantive package to cut the Federal budget deficit.
The strong suggestion last Thursday by the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, that the central bank was prepared to ease credit conditions -a hint that apparently became reality the following day - was equally welcome. In view of the Fed's fabled reticence in disclosing its intentions, Mr. Greenspan's remarks were in some respects even more surprising than the President's flip-flop on taxes.
Mr. Greenspan's comments on Fed policy, in Congressional testimony, was ''one of the most unusual ways the central bank has eased in postwar history,'' said Alan Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company.
 
Funds Rate Down to 8 Percent
The easing move, which analysts said had pushed the target for the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market down to 8 percent from 8.25 percent, helped to push short-term rates down sharply and caused bond yields to ease.
On the strength of the Fed's move, yields on the 8 3/8 percent two-year Treasury notes fell by more than 25 basis points during the week, to 8.10 percent late Friday. Bond yields also fell, but not as much: by the end of last week the Treasury's benchmark 8 3/4 percent bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.44 percent, compared with 8.50 percent on July 6.
Despite the decline in market rates, reaction to the easing move bore a strange resemblance to what happened in late December, the last time the Fed eased policy. Now, as then, gold prices rose sharply in response to the rate decline, and the dollar weakened.
 
Higher Than in Early July
And while long-term interest rates fell last week, they still remain higher than they were in early July, when the market was expecting an easing move by the Fed.
''The market's response to the Fed's move has been less than overwhelmingly enthusiastic,'' said John Lonski, a senior economist at Moody's Investors Service Inc. In part, Mr. Lonski and others said that traders might view the Fed's decision to ease credit as being politically induced, which could weaken the central bank's credibility as an inflation fighter.
In the near term, however, the Fed's slight easing move is not likely to help stimulate the economy, nor rekindle inflation, the analysts said. In fact, barring any further sign of an economic slowdown or progress on the Federal budget, the easing step taken last week is likely to be a one-time event rather than the first in a series of moves.
''For the time being, the Fed will stop here,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''And as a result I am not so sure that bond yields will drop any lower than they are right now.''
Even though Mr. Greenspan cited a tightening of credit by financial institutions as a reason for the Fed move, the analysts said the drop in the Federal funds rate was not likely to persuade banks to lower their prime lending rate, which has remained at 10 percent since early January.
 
Pressure on Banks Cited
''Banks are under exceptional earnings pressure, and have every incentive to maintain margins right now,'' said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh.
Mr. Sinai of the Boston Company said that ''banks will take as long as possible before they lower rates.''
Aside from monitoring developments on the budget front, the main focus this week will probably be on Mr. Greenspan's semiannual review of the economy and monetary policy to be given Congress. Aside from amplifying the reasons for the Fed's easing last week, some analysts said they were hopeful Mr. Greenspan would provide some sign of how the central bank might respond if Congress puts together a budget package that cuts the deficit by roughly $50 billion.
A variety of economic statistics are also scheduled to be released, the most important of which are the consumer price data for June, which are expected on Wednesday. In advance of the report, most Wall Street analysts are forecasting a rise in the Consumer Price Index of a modest two-tenths of a percent for June, due in large part to continued softness in energy prices.
Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, most forecasters see a June rise in the index of three-tenths of a point, following a similar increase in May.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;
For Networks, the Punch Line Is a Bigger Bottom Line

BYLINE: By Bill Carter

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
THE sound stages are being re-activated here this week as production begins on the fall season's television series. And the large majority of those stages will be filled with people telling jokes.
In television these days, there's no business like the ho-ho business. Comedy will dominate prime-time television in the coming season as never before. The three networks and Fox Broadcasting will offer 20 new comedy shows this fall, adding to schedules already crowded with situation comedies. 
Of the 93 entertainment programs (not counting news, sports or movies) in prime time next fall, 50 will be comedies. NBC will have a record 16 half-hour comedy shows. ABC will have 14 and Fox and CBS will each have 10.
Many forces are driving the comedy explosion, which is led by the fundamental popularity of the genre. Nine of the 10 top-rated series last season were half-hour comedies.
Comedy is proliferating all over television. Cable channels from MTV to ESPN are including some form of comedy. The pay-cable channels, like HBO and Showtime, recognizing that they can no longer depend as heavily on movies, have upgraded their commitments to comedy.
Steve Hewitt, the senior vice president of original programming for Showtime, said his network had all but abandoned special music programs for comedy. ''A totally unknown stand-up comic gets triple the rating on our service that we get even for a major music star, such as Barry Manilow,'' he said.
And Warren Littlefield, senior vice president of programming for NBC, said: ''We don't need social scientists to tell us the entire country is stressed out. The country is dying for laughs.''
About the only place where comedy does not seem to be thriving is on the two cable comedy channels introduced this year. So far, neither HBO's Comedy Channel nor MTV's HA! channel is offered on enough cable systems to attract any attention.
Good ratings always translate to good business in the television industry, but comedies are appealing for several other economic reasons. The most important: Comedies drive the domestic syndication business.
For years, hourlong dramatic shows have largely been a bust in syndication, but comedies continue to sell well, sometimes spectacularly. Hundreds of millions of dollars in sales have been racked up by ''The Cosby Show'' and ''Cheers.'' But even mediocre comedies, like ''Webster'' and ''Gimme a Break,'' have made large profits in syndication.
For the networks, which cannot share in the profits from syndication, comedies make economic sense because they hold their audiences so much better than hourlong dramas in reruns, when the commercial time is pure profit.
''In a year-round business, comedies make much better sense,'' Mr. Littlefield said.
Viewers are clearly far more willing to laugh at ''Murphy Brown'' a second time than watch ''Jake and the Fatman'' solve a mystery again.
Comedies also tend to attract the audiences that advertisers most want to reach - younger, urban viewers.
''History tells us that the network that dominates in comedy wins in both network ratings and demographics,'' Mr. Littlefield said.
The demographic strength of comedies has been a key to the success of Fox, which widened its audience by more than 70 percent over the last year largely on the appeal of its hit comedies, ''Married . . . With Children,'' ''In Living Color'' and ''The Simpsons.''
Indeed, Fox has made the coming season's boldest scheduling maneuver by deciding to take on NBC's perennial leader, Bill Cosby, with the phenomenonal upstart Bart Simpson. The move makes sense financially. There are advertising advantages for ''The Simpsons'' in the Thursday-at-8 time period that are not available in the time period it will be leaving, Sundays at 8:30.
Movie advertising has become a growing and increasingly lucrative category for the national networks. Film studios now rely more heavily than ever before on television advertising to introduce expensive movies. The most important night in movie advertising is Thursday, because most films open on Friday.
On Thursday nights during the last few years, NBC's enormously potent lineup, including ''Cosby,'' ''Cheers'' and ''L.A. Law,'' often seemed like one long series of coming attractions.
So, as successful as Fox has been, it has not been a major factor in that movie advertising bounty - until now. ''The Simpsons,'' with an audience profile that skews young and hip (in other words, the movie audience) is the ideal vehicle for Thursday night advertising.
Fox executives said last week that the opportunity to snatch some of that heavy Thursday movie advertising was a ''serendipitous'' coincidence in their audacious decision to move ''The Simpsons.''
Considering that Fox also owns a movie studio that advertises on Thursday nights, that sounds like a lot of serendipity to swallow.
But the Fox executives delightedly acknowledged that ad sales to the movie studios on coming episodes of ''The Simpsons'' went extremely well this summer - almost as well as sales of Bart Simpson T-shirts.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''The Simpsons'' are leading Fox Broadcasting's charge into the lucrative market for movie advertising on Thursday nights. (Fox Broadcasting)

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Promise of Yalta: Redeemed at Last?

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 16

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's acceptance of NATO membership for a united Germany brings the West closer to achieving the failed promises of Yalta in February 1945 for freedom, democracy and self-determination for all of Central and Eastern Europe.
Now, as then, it could not have happened without the Soviet leader. After the conference at the Crimean resort in 1945, Stalin drove home the gains of Soviet troops on the battlefield and brought half of Europe under Communist rule. Now, his successor has released it, agreeing to withdraw 350,000 soldiers from East Germany over the next three to four years. 
''It looks as if the key step has been taken,'' said an aide to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher after Mr. Gorbachev and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said at a news conference in another Soviet resort today that they had made the breakthrough, though he pointed out that all the British Government knew today came from news reports.
 
Stranger Than Fiction
But truth in East-West relations these days is often stranger than fiction, and so far predictions of how Europe and NATO are to be shaped have required frequent revision as deeds recently held impossible and unthinkable are routinely carried out.
For example, Mr. Gorbachev agreed last week to accept NATO's invitation to come to the lion's den and address them in Brussels. Starting July 1, a NATO member nation, West Germany, has been paying - and will pay 1.25 billion marks ($780 million) by the end of December - for the Soviet Union to station its troops on German territory, and will continue doing so for a transitional period that could last for several years.
When it ends, Soviet troops will withdraw from the eastern part of Germany. But American and presumably French and British forces - fewer than the 362,000 from these countries that were in West Germany at the end of last year - are to remain when East and West Germany reduce their combined armed forces from 667,000 to 370,000.
The United States, Britain and France have ritually supported the goal of German unification for 40 years. But the German-Soviet agreement brings closer the day when unification begins to bite - that is, when the Western allies and the Soviets will have to hand back to the Germans the residual claims on sovereignty, occupation rights and control over Berlin's affairs that they have exercised since the war's end.
By agreeing to German membership in NATO, Mr. Gorbachev is making a historic gamble, one driven by forces of history, politics and internal economic contradictions that may have outrun his ability to control them. He is also relying on the declaration by the NATO leaders at the London summit meeting this month that their alliance, created when the wartime community of Soviet and Western interests collapsed, means his country no harm and will work together with Moscow to insure a lasting peace.
But the West, too, has made a gamble - on the loyalty and commitment to Western democratic values of the Germans, who they believe will be led by Chancellor Kohl after unification and all-German elections on Dec. 2. Mr. Kohl's NATO allies left to him the negotiations with Mr. Gorbachev on what ceiling to impose on the armed forces of a united Germany. Today, with Mr. Gorbachev in the Caucasian resort of Zheleznovodsk, Mr. Kohl named a figure of 370,000, far below the existing strength of the West German forces alone, at 494,000. Pending fuller disclosure and examination of the fine print of the Soviet-German accord, reactions from other European capitals today were guarded. ''Germany's membership in our alliance will increase stability for all,'' a NATO spokesman in Brussels said.
 
Little Surprise
A well-placed French official said he was not surprised by the Soviet move, because Bonn, which he said had been urged on by Washington, had made a significant concession to Moscow by agreeing to set a limit on the armed forces of a united Germany.
Among the things that European policy makers and diplomats said they were not sure Mr. Kohl and Mr. Gorbachev had solved were the conditions of the transitional arrangements governing the status of the Soviet forces in East Germany pending their withdrawal. Mr. Kohl said that no nuclear arms or foreign troops should be based on the territory of eastern Germany.
''He probably means forever,'' a NATO diplomat in Brussels said today, ''but we have only said that we would consider that for the transition period.''
Another unknown was what kind of economic help Mr. Kohl promised Mr. Gorbachev to help his plans for economic change, now mired in chaos, indecision and bureaucratic resistance. Mr. Kohl sought but did not get Western agreement to provide loans and money, though he got approval to go ahead with his own plans for at least $3.5 billion in payments and loan guarantees this year.
Soviet agreement to German membership in NATO should bring progress in the six-power negotiations on the external implications of unification that resume in Paris on Tuesday. At those talks, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and his counterparts from Britain, France and the Soviet Union will meet with the foreign ministers of the two German states to discuss the remaining obstacles.
This time they have also invited a Polish representative who is expected to press Warsaw's demand that the wartime allies keep some of their residual rights in Germany until the united German nation ratifies a formal treaty renouncing any intention of altering the border with Poland. The two German Parliaments jointly agreed last month to negotiate such a treaty.
 
Ending Occupation Rights
Finally, the allies will have to end their occupation rights in Berlin, replacing them as the Western powers have already in West Germany with bilateral pacts on the status of forces. Since the war, for example, no West German-owned airline has had the right to fly out of West Berlin, and the routes have been monopolized by British, French and American companies, some with German minority partners.
The biggest remaining obstacle to German unity is successful conclusion of an agreement between Washington and Moscow on reducing conventional forces in Central Europe, a goal that should be made much easier by agreement on a German troop figure.
The conventional force talks in Vienna have been going slowly recently, British officials say. But if the talks now proceed to a American-Soviet conclusion, they can move rapidly to discuss limits on other European countries' forces, and allow the ''two plus four'' talks to report to the 35-nation summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe scheduled in Paris on Nov. 19-21.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: AIRCRAFT COMPANY TO CUT 17,000 JOBS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 16

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it would eliminate as many as 17,000 jobs, or nearly 13 percent of its work force. The cutbacks represent the most striking example of the economic effect of declining Pentagon spending and the intense competition in the commercial aircraft business.
McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military contractor and the No. 2 builder of jetliners behind the Boeing Company, is facing the cancellation of several of its largest combat aircraft programs, including the F-15 fighter, and a cut in orders on other programs, like the Air Force's C-17 transport.
But analysts said McDonnell Douglas had aggravated the problems of a declining military budget by mishandling many programs. It has encountered severe cost overruns and schedule delays, for example, on both the C-17 and the Navy's new A-12 attack plane. Moreover, the company has long struggled unsuccessfully to make a profit in the commercial aircraft business, despite a healthy backlog of orders from airlines. 
Although the layoffs at McDonnell Douglas are attributable as much to the problems in the company's commercial business as to the bleak outlook for its military programs, the company's action fits a pattern of steady cutbacks in the aerospace and military contracting industries. With the exception of Boeing, whose commercial aircraft business is booming, virtually every company has seen its profits tumble, and even Boeing announced recently that it would eliminate 5,600 jobs this year because of a downturn in its military business.
Under pressure to trim the Federal budget deficit, Congress has been cutting the Pentagon budget for the past several years. Much deeper cuts are expected because of the reduction in the Soviet military threat.
The Grumman Corporation has eliminated 6,000 jobs in recent years, to about 27,600, with cuts of 7,400 jobs on Long Island offset by some growth in other regions. The Lockheed Corporation has reduced its work force this year by 5,500, to 77,000, with most of the cuts in California and Georgia. And the Northrop Corporation expects to have cut 5,500 by the end of this year, mostly in California.
McDonnell Douglas said it would lay off 9,000 workers in Southern California, including 8,000 at its plant in Long Beach, where it builds its commercial aircraft and the Air Force's C-17. The job loss in Long Beach will be about 1,000 greater than the company had previously said it expected there by the end of the year.
The company said it would cut another 4,500 jobs in St. Louis, where the company is based and where it builds military aircraft like the F-15 fighter. In Arizona, where the company builds military helicopters, 800 jobs will be lost. Another 1,000 jobs would be cut in 25 other states where the company has operations. Attrition and other cuts could bring the total work force reduction to 17,000 by the end of the year, the company said.
 
Smaller Cut Possible
The company also said, however, that the job cuts might total as few as 14,000, or about 11 percent of the work force. McDonnell Douglas has 131,000 full-time employees plus more than 4,000 contract workers.
McDonnell Douglas said several weeks ago that it was developing a plan to cut $700 million in expenses to survive in both the commercial and military markets, and workers have been anticipating widespread layoffs since then. Barbara Anderson, a spokeswoman for the company, said the layoffs would fall most heavily on ''indirect'' workers, or those not directly involved in the design and manufacture of the company's planes and other products, and would include both white-collar and hourly employees.
''We tried to do everything else,'' John F. McDonnell, the company's chairman, said at a news conference in St. Louis. ''But in the final analysis we had to come to this.''
 
Profit Problems
McDonnell Douglas's problems in the commercial jetliner business go back for decades. Although the company's sales have always been brisk, it has never been able to keep costs low enough and its production line operating quickly enough to turn a consistent profit. It sold its DC-10 jetliner for two decades without making any significant profit on it, said Lawrence M. Harris, an analyst at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. in Los Angeles. The company has pinned much of its hope for the future on its new MD-11, a 325-seat jumbo jet, which should be delivered to airlines starting late this year or early 1991.
The layoffs are sure to be an economic shock to the communities where McDonnell Douglas does business, especially in St. Louis and in Long Beach, where the Douglas Aircraft division is the largest employer. The company said it would offer resume services, job fairs and counseling to workers who lose their jobs.
Layoffs of the scale announced today are certain to increase pressure in Congress and on the state and local level for funding to retrain workers who lose jobs in military-related fields and to encourage large and small contractors to explore new markets. But Congress is not likely to begin restoring funds to programs like the F-15 or McDonnell Douglas's AH-64 helicopter or the AV-8B Marine Corps jet, all of which are likely to be canceled in coming years, Congressional aides said today.
Outside the gates of the sprawling Douglas Aircraft plant in Long Beach today, employees seemed resigned to coping with the company's problems. Asked what he might do if he lost his job, one engineer on the company's new MD-11 commercial jetliner, replied with one word: ''Boeing.'' The engineer, who declined to give his name, said he had already sent a resume to Boeing, which is based in Seattle, and has hired thousands of workers from California in recent years.
But a Boeing spokesman said that employment in the company's commercial aircraft division was dropping slightly and that the company was no longer hiring large numbers.

HEADLINE: F.C.C. ACTS TO CUT RATES UP TO 50% ON CALLS ABROAD

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission, concerned that the cost of providing international telephone service has been falling far faster than the prices that callers pay, has begun an effort to force down rates by up to 50 percent within three years.
The agency has concluded that action is needed because telephone monopolies in nations other than the United States are keeping international rates high even as improvements in technology and operating efficiency have sharply reduced the cost of providing service. For example, while operators are no longer needed for most international calls, rates are still based on such expenses.
 
Payments Could Be Limited
The F.C.C. says that under a program it proposed last Thursday, American consumers could save several billion dollars a year.
Under this program, the agency would encourage foreign telephone companies to reduce their charges. It could limit payments from the United States to those that refuse to cooperate. 
''We certainly don't want to become unwitting handmaidens to a regimen that does not allow price changes,'' said Alfred C. Sikes, the chairman of the F.C.C.
But the F.C.C. effort will probably be opposed vigorously by foreign governments, which charge high rates for international telephone service to subsidize domestic phone calls and other services. Less ambitious efforts by the United States to reduce international telephone charges have met strong resistance abroad, said Earl S. Barbely, the director of telecommunications and information standards at the State Department.
International rates are set through negotiations between American and foreign telephone companies. The companies agree on one price to pay each other for receiving international calls. American companies, for example, pay 78 cents a minute to Deutsche Bundespost, the state-owned German company, for calls from the United States to West Germany, and the German company pays the same for calls made from Germany.
But the F.C.C. thinks the agreed-upon prices have not fallen nearly as much as the cost of handling calls. It wants prices to come down so that American carriers can charge their customers less.
 
German Charges a Problem
Telephone traffic between the United States and West Germany offers a good example of what troubles the F.C.C. American long-distance carriers charge as little as 62 cents a minute for calls to West Germany. Deutsche Bundespost, on the other hand, charges $1.91 a minute, and that does not include 32 cents a minute in taxes. The American carriers, which are competing with each other to offer the lowest rates, can ill afford to raise their rates. Their state-owned German counterpart, with no competition, charges whatever it pleases.
But even the 62 cents a minute that the American carriers charge may be twice the cost of handling the call. The problem, as the F.C.C. views it, is that agreements with foreign telephone companies have been based for decades on the much higher costs of operator-assisted calls. Even though they now offer direct-dial service, American carriers continue to make to foreign phone companies payments equal to half the inflated cost of operator-assisted calls. In the German example, they pay the German phone company half of $1.56, or 78 cents a minute.
 
Losing Money on the Calls
In short, the American long-distance companies are losing up to 16 cents a minute on such calls. They are able to sustain these losses because they receive 78 cents a minute from Deutsche Bundespost on calls made from West Germany. If the amount they had to pay the foreign company declined, so could their rates.
Given the disparities in rates, people in the United States spent 367 million minutes on calls to West Germany in 1988, while people in West Germany spent only 166 million minutes on calls to the United States, said Gregory C. Staple, a Washington lawyer and author of a recent study on international telephone rates sponsored by the International Institute of Communications in London.
The result, according to the F.C.C., was that American telephone companies paid $153 million in 1988 to the Deutsche Bundespost because it received 201 million minutes more of calls than it sent.
Reductions in the prices telephone companies pay each other could shrink the nation's annual trade deficit in telephone service, which was $2.4 billion last year and one of the fastest-growing components of the United States trade deficit.
The F.C.C. program, distributed for public comment last Thursday, would permit the agency for the first time to limit payments by American carriers to foreign partners that refuse to cooperate in reducing rates. It would also guarantee nearly automatic approval by the Federal agency of any international rate reductions under existing agreements, and make easier the approval of new agreements with rules that reduce international rates.
The comment period will probably last through November, after which the commission will amend its proposal if necessary and vote on whether to adopt it, said William J. Kirsch, the F.C.C.'s senior attorney for international issues. The Federal agency's five commissioners usually adopt proposed programs because they oversee the drafting of proposals.
Mr. Sikes said the prospects for similar changes overseas were good because the British regulatory authorities, the European Community and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development were all investigating whether current practices might be anti-competitive and represented improper trade restraints. A recent series of articles on international rates in The Financial Times, the British newspaper, has influenced policy makers in Europe and made them more receptive to the long-standing American position of encouraging competition, he said.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has favored F.C.C. intervention to cut international payments because the number of its outbound calls is double that of its inbound calls, so a cut in payments reduces the company's costs by more than it reduces revenues, said Thomas R. Luciano, the deputy director of international settlements for A.T.&T. The company has also found that international telephone traffic from the United States is more affected by price than other countries' traffic, so that reduced prices dramatically raise volume and may increase A.T.&T.'s revenues, Mr. Luciano said.
A.T.&T.'s competitors have also supported change.
But the existing system has drawn few complaints overseas because it benefits consumers at the expense of businesses, which account for two-thirds of all international calls, Mr. Barbely said. Few countries relish the prospect of raising the price of, say, stamps to reduce the telephone bills of multinational corporations, he added. Foreign countries have considerably slowed efforts by the United States Government since the early 1960's to introduce more competitive practices to international telecommunications.
''Every time we did this, we got yelled at by the rest of the world for stealing some of their revenues,'' Mr. Barbely said.
Indeed, high international telephone rates have been an unintentional form of American foreign aid for years. About $1.5 billion of the American trade deficit in telephone services consists of net cash payments to the state-owned telephone companies of developing countries, many of which sorely need American dollars to pay for imports and other expenses. $10 Billion in Profits The existing system has led to annual profits of as much as $10 billion for the world's telephone companies, on annual revenues from international traffic of $30 billion, Mr. Staple said.
One country that has reduced prices sharply under American pressure is Japan. The average price of a call from Japan to the United States has dropped by 80 percent in the last 10 years, and has been cheaper than the average call from the United States to Japan for nearly two years, said Toyokazu Kawaguchi, the assistant director of the Washington office of the Kokusai Denshin Denwa Company, the main Japanese provider of international telephone service.
But the United States ran a $91.4 million telephone service deficit with Japan in 1988, the F.C.C. said. The deficits continue because Japanese businesses and individuals gather and send back large quantities of information from the United States, while Americans collect much less information in Japan, Mr. Kawaguchi said.

HEADLINE: Bush Scraps Intelligence Board, Appointing a New Panel of 6

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
President Bush today scrapped the White House's 15-member advisory board on intelligence issues and replaced it with a 6-member panel composed largely of veteran intelligence officials and scientists.
Mr. Bush named as chairman of the new group John G. Tower, the former Republican Senator from Texas, who lost a bruising political battle in 1989 to be confirmed by the Senate as Secretary of Defense. Mr. Tower's new position does not require Senate confirmation.
The President's action, which had been expected, removes from the board a number of political conservatives and people outside the intelligence community who had been appointed by President Reagan. 
The new board retains the same broad mandate to advise the White House on ways to improve the quality of intelligence, but some outside experts have said they expect it to focus on how the nation's espionage agencies can adapt to a future in which other national security issues rival the Soviet Union as targets.
 
Retired Admiral Appointed
Mr. Bush named as vice chairman of the board Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, retired, a former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence and head of the National Security Agency, the espionage agency in charge of electronic eavesdropping. Other members are Lew Allen Jr., vice president of the California Institute of Technology and National Security Agency director from 1973 to 1978; Dr. William J. Perry, a former deputy director of research and engineering at the Pentagon, who is now a private businessman in Menlo Park, Calif.; John M. Deutch, a physical engineering professor and provost at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and William G. Hyland, editor of Foreign Affairs magazine.
Mr. Tower, now a private consultant in Dallas, currently holds a seat on the intelligence panel. The others appointed, all for two years, are newcomers to the board.
During Mr. Reagan's tenure, the intelligence panel was an active and, on occasion, a much-resented watchdog over the intelligence establishment, issuing critical reports on such lapses as the defection to Moscow of a former Central Intelligence Agency employee, Edward Lee Howard, in 1985. But it was all but moribund under Mr. Bush.
Administration officials have said that Mr. Bush considered the panel too unwieldy and was considering abolishing it, as had President Carter, but that he was persuaded to reconsider by the panel's departing chairwoman, Anne L. Armstrong, and by his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft.
 
Turbulent Time Foreseen
The new appointments suggest that the board will become much more of a force in setting intelligence policy during what promises to be a turbulent time for American espionage.
After several years of robust growth, Federal spending for intelligence is falling, and may drop more rapidly as the threat of a military confrontation with the Soviet Union recedes. But at the same time, the agencies face an array of costly new demands, including monitoring Soviet compliance with several new arms-control treaties, collecting more information on world trade and threats to American economic security, and increasing its collection of intelligence on developing nations' nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs.
Mr. Tower was Mr. Bush's first nominee for Defense Secretary, but the Senate rejected him after a bitter battle that revolved around accusations that he had a drinking problem. Mr. Tower denied that he had ever been an alcoholic and at one point pledged that he would not consume any alcoholic beverages while Secretary of Defense.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
The German-NATO Drama: 9 Fateful Months

 BODY:
Oct. 7, 1989: Gorbachev, visiting East Germany on its 40th anniversary, declares to Eric Honecker, the longtime, hard-line leader: ''Life punishes those who delay.''
Oct. 18, 1989: As pressures for reform in East Germany increase, Mr. Honecker steps down. His successor, Egon Krenz, supports limited reforms. 
Nov. 9, 1989: The breaching of the Berlin Wall begins as it becomes known that East German curbs on travel are ending. Throngs of East Germans cross to West Berlin, and most return to East Berlin. On the next day, East German soldiers begin tearing down sections of the wall.
Nov. 15, 1989: Gorbachev declares that German unification ''is not a matter of topical politics.'' Even discussing it, he says, is interfering in the internal affairs of the Germans.
Feb. 13, 1990: At an East-West meeting of foreign ministers in Ottawa, the four major World War II Allies - the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union - and East Germany and West Germany agreed on a framework for negotiating the reunification of Germany, which was divided in 1945.
First, the two Germanys are to discuss domestic aspects of unification. Then they are to meet with the four Allies on security matters - notably the question of whether a reunited Germany would be in NATO, as West Germany and its allies wish, or would be neutral, the preference of East Germany and the Soviet Union. Asked whether a united Germany could belong to NATO, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union shrugs.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
As Bush Hails Decision, Many See Bonn Gaining

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
President Bush today hailed the Soviet Union's decision to accept a united Germany as a member of NATO, describing it as an act of statesmanship. He said the move resulted, at least in part, from measures adopted by the alliance at its meeting in London 10 days ago.
''We think this solution is in the best interests of all the countries of Europe, including the Soviet Union,'' he said in a written statement.
But officials of the Bush Administration and others in Washington were keenly aware of the symbolism in the fact that the agreement was worked out by Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a meeting in the Caucusus, albeit along lines that the United States had strongly endorsed, with Mr. Bush more than 5,000 miles away. 
Not only were Mr. Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other American policy-makers remote from the scene of the action; Mr. Baker, at least, was taken completely by surprise, learning of today's developments from news accounts when his plane stopped for refueling at Shannon Airport in Ireland. For weeks, he and his staff had said they expected no break in the German impasse until the fall.
 
A More Felicitous Forum
A senior figure in the Administration, who spoke on condition of anonymity, conceded that ''it would have been much nicer if the deal Gorbachev and Kohl seem to have struck could have been announced when all the major powers were represented, but that doesn't change the fact that we got what we wanted - a unified Germany in NATO.''
Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, a major Democratic spokesman on foreign affairs, said: ''This makes it clearer than ever that the Germans are leading Western policy toward the Soviet Union. I'm not saying that it's George Bush's fault, and I'm not saying that we have become a non-power.
''But this is an example of the new multi-polar world that's going to make us learn a new meaning for the word 'consult.' These days it doesn't mean us going to Europe and telling them what to do. The constraints are largely economic. We haven't solved our fiscal problems, we need to borrow money, and you can't say to your creditors, 'this is what you're going to do.' ''
With the decline of the Warsaw Pact and the approach of reunification, Germany appears poised to become an even greater economic power than it already is, and Japan, a world economic power, is starting to flex its political muscles, too.
 
Quayle Is Upbeat
At a luncheon with reporters and editors of The New York Times, Vice President Dan Quayle emphasized the positive, asserting that President Bush had been ''way out front'' on the German question and declaring that ''relations are at an all-time high between Germany and the United States.''
While few diplomats or analysts would question either assertion, the new closeness of the two nations has given Mr. Kohl a more-or-less free hand to set the timetable and some of the terms for German unification, and granted him a much larger role among world leaders.
''The transformation is quite phenomenal,'' said a Republican Senator who asked not to be quoted by name. ''Kohl used to come here as a kind of supplicant, but now he comes into a room up here and senior people defer to him. He's polite and good-humored, of course, but he dominates conversations.''
German unification was to have taken place on the terms worked out in the ''two plus four'' negotiations, involving the two Germanys plus the Allied powers of World War II - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. That arrangement was to have constituted Moscow's veto, or Washington's, if the pace seemed too fast or the conditions too onerous.
But Mr. Gorbachev said today that four-power rights would lapse when Germany was reunited, and many diplomats here said the two plus four talks had been rendered all but moot.
''Not even a fig leaf is left'' to conceal the idea that West Germany has essentially negotiated its own terms, a West European Ambassador here said.
Zbigniew Brzezinski, who served as national security adviser under President Carter, said that while ''this is clearly the final act of Soviet accommodation to the new realities,'' Mr. Gorbachev ''may be giving ground so that he can partly recoup later'' by insisting that all foreign troops, not just Soviet ones, leave the soil of Germany.
''My instinct is that precisely that question will arise, certainly before 1995,'' Mr. Brzezinski said.
There is now broad support in Washington for the idea that the United States must push hard for the rapid integration of Europe - in economic, political, military and other spheres -to make Germany's triumphs Europe's triumphs and avoid any backlash against German economic power.
Under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Britain has resisted an accelerated timetable for European integration, with Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd restating British reservations about a single currency and a central European bank only last weekend. That could mean a further loosening of the old special relationship between London and Washington in the coming months.
''This is an alliance victory,'' the West European ambassador said. ''It is a Bush victory. The United States must not lose its nerve now, with these signs of German strength, and pause to reconsider things. It must play the game to the end, not back off, and not give anyone any reason to suspect that this is a German-Soviet deal of which the United States secretly disapproves.''
