HEADLINE: Facing Grim Data on Young Males, Blacks Grope for Ways to End Blight

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 13

 BODY:
Ronald Taylor, a black sociologist at the University of Connecticut, went back to the old neighborhood in Hartford the other day for the first time in years and was jolted by the sight of young men hanging out and selling drugs on once-familiar streets.
''I was frightened,'' he said. ''And I was embarrassed that I was frightened. These men are my own people, and I don't recognize them.''
Recent studies show that the situation is even bleaker than the one that shook Professor Taylor. It is a situation that inner-city residents know all too well: the United States is rapidly losing much of a generation of young black men to drugs, homicide and prison. 
Black men are several times more likely to be victims of homicide than any other demographic group, and they finish last in virtually every socioeconomic category, from the high school dropout rate to unemployment. A study in February found that more college-age black men - nearly one in four -are in prison or on parole than are in college.
 
Responses to Alarm
Alarmed by numbers like that, Professor Taylor and about 200 other scholars, ministers and community workers from across the country gathered here this week for a conference to exchange research and ideas on the problems of black men in America and to lay the groundwork for an organization dedicated to research and advocacy work for black men.
While this was billed as the first such nationwide gathering, a flurry of other meetings on the topic in recent months has brought together hundreds of people in places like Harlem, where a conference at the Apollo Theater was carried live on a black radio station in New York, and Atlanta, where Morehouse College, a leading black men's college, last spring created both a research institute and scholarly journal on the subject. At its national convention in Los Angeles last week, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People conducted a workshop called ''The Endangered Black Male.''
''Black men are coming together, and when they talk about the problems, yes, it's very personal,'' said Dr. Alvin Poussaint, a psychiatrist at Harvard Medical School and a consultant to the national conference here. ''This is a social movement to deal with social ills. It has gotten more and more momentum as the statistics have gotten worse.''
 
'Outside Our Experiences'
Black scholars, many of whom have spent their careers studying the topic individually, said they found themselves frustrated and overwhelmed as they discussed the twin plagues of crack dealing and black-on-black crime that have ravaged so many inner-city neighborhoods.
''It's hard for even the black community to comprehend,'' Professor Taylor said. ''It's outside our experiences. We know how to deal with poverty, oppression and discrimination, but the world seems to have changed rather dramatically. People are trying to figure out what the hell to do.''
A principal reason for the conference was to create a clearinghouse for the study of the nation's 14 million black males. Conferees, envisioning an advocacy and research organization that would shape public policy and sponsor annual symposiums like this one, named the group the National Coalition of African American Men and chose as its provisional chairman Dr. Richard Majors, a psychologist at Harvard Medical School and one of the conference organizers.
Outlining the coalition's mission, Dr. Majors said, ''There is a lot of ignorance, myths and stereotypes about black men. The bottom line is not only educating the public but empowering and improving the lives of black men.''
 
'We're Victims, Too'
Women, a distinct minority at the conference here, said they were drawn to the sessions out of fear for their loved ones and a shared sense of vulnerability. ''If a black man is in prison, on the street corner or dead from drugs, we're victims, too,'' said Dr. Gloria Alibaruho, a sociologist and consultant at Morehouse. ''We're without husbands, brothers and sons.''
Discussions that started out addressing a socioeconomic problem often turned into personal testimonies as participants shared stories of the countless small insults that come with being black men in largely white America.
Arthur Fletcher, chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission, told the group, ''At 64 years old and after 40 years of fairly solid achievement, I can still walk into a conference and they're surprised that I can contribute to the discussion.''
In dealings with the police and the criminal justice system, the scholars said they felt a sense of oneness with the black men who occupy a disproportionate share of the nation's prison cells.
''We're overrepresented as offenders and as victims,'' said Jon R. Gray, a black circuit court judge in Jackson County, Mo., who presided over one session. ''It tears me apart. The problems have long since festered. I'm becoming more and more cynical.''
 
The Path to Prison
Marc Mauer, author of the study that found that a fourth of black males between the ages of 20 and 29 are in prison or on parole, gave one explanation of how they get there.
''There may be a black or Hispanic man looking disheveled on the street, who has been drinking,'' said Mr. Mauer, one of the few white speakers at the conference. ''It is much more likely that the black or Hispanic man will be arrested for drunk and disorderly conduct than a white man in a three-piece suit who, instead of being arrested, might get a ride home. This leads to the disparities we see down the line.''
During one crowded session, about 150 scholars in suits and ties and cardigans shook their heads and whispered knowingly to one another as Don Jackson, a black former sergeant in the Hawthorne, Calif., police department, described what he said were the perceptions of many white police officers.
''Almost everyone in this room looks like a criminal to police officers so inclined,'' Mr. Jackson said. ''That's the kind of training they get.''
Ida R. Mukenge, a sociologist and associate dean at the Morehouse, said that black academics and others had been focusing on the plight of black males for some years but that it was only recently that funding for such work had become available from foundations and government and that the news media had grown interested in the subject ''It is true that there are a lot of groups and people working in this area,'' Dr. Mukenge said, ''but I'm not concerned about the effort being too diffuse. There is enough work to be done and enough points to be attacked.''
 
Work at Morehouse
Dr. Mukenge is executive director of the school's Morehouse Research Institute, which was established in 1988 to focus on problems facing black males and to analyze Government policies and programs directed at black men. The institute, which held its first conference in March, is intended to help black organizations and others take better advantage of the current attention on the problems of black males, she said.
Out of the meetings here came several possible routes to reversing the grim statistics, and few of them were revolutionary. Many in attendance called for pressure on the Federal Government to make dealing with the plight of poor blacks a priority and to change welfare and economic policies that they said undermine the black family. Others urged changes in the criminal justice system like alternative sentences to avoid sending nonviolent offenders to crowded prisons.
If there was a consensus, it was one of self-help. In hallway conversations and in seminars, people called for alternative, African-oriented schools to give black boys a sense of black history and self-esteem before they get pulled into an abyss of drugs and crime.
''We've got to stop waiting for white folks to put us in their history books,'' said Jacob Gordon, a professor of African American Studies at the University of Kansas and an organizer of the conference. ''The Jews have done a good job of this. We've got to create Afrocentric academies and create our own history books.''
Other recommendations included parent-training programs for young blacks, mentor programs to pair middle-class professional blacks with inner-city youth and changing attitudes in lower-class black neighborhoods.
''For too long we have tolerated too many of our boys making the passage from boyhood to manhood by defining manhood as sexual promiscuity, toughness and thrill seeking,'' said William Oliver, a professor of criminal justice at the University of Delaware. ''In the lower-class black community, there's almost a Wild West mentality. We're not saying there isn't a role for government, but ultimately we've got to save ourselves.''

PUB-DATE: July 17, 1990

LENGTH: 916 words

HEADLINE: Estimate on Deficit Is Raised Sharply

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Apparently trying to generate an atmosphere of crisis, the Bush Administration sharply raised its official estimate of the Federal deficit in the next fiscal year today and predicted dire consequences from automatic spending cuts if a budget agreement with Congress is not reached.
''If those negotiations fail, it will have major implications for virtually everything the Federal Government touches,'' said Richard G. Darman, the budget director.
He said that without an agreement, the across-the-board reductions required by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law would cause, among other things, a halving of military forces, the closing of many air traffic-control installations, the end of meat inspection for nearly five months, a halt in new cleanups of toxic waste sites and cancellation of vaccinations against childhood diseases for one million children.
Nonetheless, Mr. Darman, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said at a news conference that the Administration would accept the automatic cuts if Congress did not approve a budget that met President Bush's approval. 
 
Talks Expected to Resume
Administration officials and Congressional leaders have been meeting on the budget since May but have not made substantial headway in deciding what to cut or which taxes to raise. They are expected to resume bargaining later this week.
Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, said today that the talks were close to deadlocked, but the top Republican on the panel, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, said progress was being made.
Today's new estimate of the deficit, and a less optimistic economic forecast, did not differ substantially from material made public last month, after Mr. Darman presented it to Congressional negotiators.
But the documentation of the effects of across-the-board spending cuts, which was not required until late next month, and the harsh language the officials used seemed to be calculated not only to increase pressure on Congress but to stir public anxiety. Vice President Dan Quayle said in an interview with The New York Times today that the purpose was to have a ''sobering-up effect'' on many lawmakers.
 
The Bailout Factor
The Administration projected that without changes in taxes or spending, the deficit for the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1, would be $168.8 billion, not counting spending for the savings and loan bailout, and that it would rise to $231.4 billion with the bailout funds.
That is about $10 billion higher than the unofficial estimate Mr. Darman gave Congress last month and far above the $100.5 billion official estimate the President sent Congress in January.
The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, which is supposed to reduce the deficit in annual increments, sets a deficit target of $64 billion for the next fiscal year. If the target is missed by more than $10 billion, automatic cuts are required in almost all programs except Social Security and grants to poor people, like welfare and food stamps.
Even excluding the savings and loan cleanup, the target would be exceeded by more than $100 billion, today's figures show. Mr. Darman said that would mean a reduction of 38.4 percent in domestic programs and 25.1 percent or 41.3 percent in each military program, depending on whether the President exercised his option to exclude military personnel from the cutback.
 
From High to Low
The President and the Congressional leaders want to exclude the savings and loan program from the budget-balancing law's calculations. Most analysts believe that would be justified, since the program makes the annual deficit appear artificially large in some years and artificially low in others. In the early years of the bailout, the Government will spend billions of additional dollars to buy the property of failed savings institutions. In later years, much of that money will be redeemed when the property is sold.
Congress could avoid across-the-board spending cuts by raising the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law's target. But the Administration officials suggested that the President would veto such a measure.
Mr. Darman and the other officials blamed what they characterized as an irresponsible, intransigent Congress for the size of the deficit and the lack of progress in negotiations.
 
Economy Shows Weakness
Mr. Darman and Mr. Boskin also noted that the economy had been weaker than expected, producing less revenue, and that higher interest rates required more spending to pay bondholders.
The Administration is now projecting that the economy will grow by 2.2 percent in the calendar year 1990 and 2.9 percent in 1991, compared with January projections of 2.4 percent and 3.2 percent. It is predicting that consumer prices will rise by 4.8 percent in 1990 and 4.1 percent in 1991, compared with the January forecast of 3.9 percent and 4 percent.
At the Capitol, Democrats accused the Administration of not having leveled with the public until now about the severity of the deficit problem. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said the staggering effect of a huge across-the-board spending cut was ''what we've been saying since January.''
Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said he welcomed today's announcement because ''one problem in the negotiations has been the lack of a sense of crisis.''

HEADLINE: Bill on Farm Spending Meeting Stiff Opposition

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The 1990 farm bill, which heads toward the floor of both the Senate and the House this week, is meeting unaccustomed opposition from the Bush Administration and from newly aroused city and suburban legislators who seek to cut or redirect large Federal subsidies to agriculture.
The Secretary of Agriculture, Clayton Yeutter, said today in a letter to the Senate that he would recommend that President Bush veto the bill if its cost was not reduced.
The basic spending levels of the final bill, the Government's farm blueprint for the next five years, have been drawn in the committees, and floor action to alter them significantly seemed unlikely, people in Congress and the farm industry said.
The farm program, continuing the essential thrust that began with its reworking in 1985, is to cost the Treasury a bit more than $10 billion a year in the first half of the 1990's, about the same as the past three years. Drought, by raising market prices, could reduce Federal payments, while bumper crops could raise them. 
 
'The Bill Is Excessive'
In a 13-page letter to the President of the Senate, Vice President Dan Quayle, Mr. Yeutter said: ''From a budget standpoint, the cost of the bill is excessive. The bill authorizes appropriations for a number of new programs and authorities which could result in over $3 billion of additional outlays.''
The Senate is expected to begin debate on the farm bill this week. The House bill is to reach the Rules Committee this week, with floor action planned for next week.
Senator Patrick Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee, said in response to Mr. Yeutter's letter that the Administration was trying to kill the farm bill so it could free its hand in international trade talks intended to cut agriculture subsidies around the world.
 
'Cooked Up New Numbers'
Mr. Leahy said the Administration had ''cooked up new numbers'' in estimating the bill's effect on the budget, The Associated Press reported. ''The Administration's veto threat is a thinly veiled effort to kill the farm bill so the Administration can cut a back-room deal in Geneva, out of sight from American farmers.''
Mr. Yeutter's letter did not mention the trade talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade being conducted in Geneva.
The threat of a veto showed that a third group that wants to alter the farm bill, farm-state Democrats, faces a daunting task as they revive efforts to increase support for agriculture.
Those Democrats face the opposition not only of the Administration but also of some members of Congress who are trying to break the traditional farm-state monopoly of the legislation on behalf of consumers and taxpayers.
The main challenge is being mounted by a group of about 20 House members headed by Representatives Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, and Dick Armey, a Republican from the Dallas area.
 
Seeking an Income Limit
Contending that the 1985 farm bill skewed payments toward the wealthy, with less than 4 percent of farmers now collecting 40 percent of the benefits, Mr. Schumer said the coalition sought to apply an income limit in all programs. Federal support would be denied those with adjusted gross incomes exceeding $100,000, a move that would save $900 million a year.
Individual members will also try to abolish specific supports like those for sugar, peanuts, honey, wool and mohair. Another goal is to reduce export subsidies.
Representative Schumer takes some heart from recent House action attaching an income limit to a water bill but acknowledges his forces face an uphill fight to overhaul a system that provides so much direct income to farmers. ''This is the first time the ag bill has been challenged,'' he said.
In the Senate, there is less eagerness to cut farm programs because every member has some farmers as constituents. Most of the rebels are in a small group of so-called prairie populist Democrats who are unhappy with a bill that would freeze most subsidy levels while failing to produce a policy that would distinguish them from Republicans for this fall's elections.
Mark Ulven, a legislative assistant to Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said this group would seek to raise target prices for at least some portion of a farmer's harvest and might also revive an effort that failed in committee to tie prices to the Consumer Price Index.
Yet he acknowledges that at a time of general budget constraints this is a long-odds proposition. ''The climate is much different than it was in 1985, when the farm economy was still crippled by recession,'' Mr. Ulven said. ''The entire mood is shifting.''

HEADLINE: MacArthur Grants Are Awarded to 36

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago, widening the range of its coveted annual awards to gifted people, named a juggler, a photographer and a preserver of disappearing varieties of seeds among its 36 winners of fellowships yesterday.
While some of this year's winners are well known, including the author and critic Susan Sontag, others are aspiring but unknown artists or young scientists, and a number are rural or urban community organizers.
All will receive awards from $150,000 to $375,000 over five years and can spend the money as they choose. The amounts are determined by the winners' ages, with the youngest receiving smaller sums.
The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation created the fellowships in 1981, saying it wanted to free ''exceptionally gifted individuals'' from economic constraints to develop their potential. The awards are frequently called the ''genius awards.'' Recipients are recommended by 100 anonymous nominators, recruited around the country to serve for a year, and their selections are reviewed by a panel of 13 experts. The foundation does not accept applications or recommendations from other sources. 
''The creative person is at the heart of a society's capacity to improve the human condition,'' said Adele Simmons, the foundation's president. ''By supporting these fellows, working in a wide range of fields, the foundation means to honor creative persons everywhere.''
These are the fellows named by the foundation:
 
John Christian Bailar 3d, 57 years old, professor of epidemiology and biostatistics at the McGill University School of Medicine in Montreal. A consultant to The New England Journal of Medicine, he is a specialist in verifying scientific data.
 
Martha Clarke, 46, a choreographer who lives in Sherman, Conn. She has combined dance, drama and mime in her productions, which include ''The Garden of Earthly Delights.''
 
Jacques d'Amboise, 55, a choreographer. He is the founder and artistic director of the National Dance Institute in New York, which conducts classes for 3,000 students in 75 public schools, and author of the book ''Teaching the Magic of Dance.''
 
Guy Davenport, 62, professor of literature at the University of Kentucky. He writes fiction and essays and is the author of 15 books, including ''The Geography of the Imagination.''
 
Lisa Delpit, 38, a specialist in literacy development and in education dealing with different cultural groups. She has studied and worked in Alaska and New Guinea and in urban schools in the United States and is senior research associate at the Institute for Urban Research at Morgan State University in Baltimore.
 
John C. Eaton, 55, professor of music and composition at Indiana University. His operas include ''The Cry of Clytemnestra'' and ''The Tempest.''
 
Paul R. Ehrlich, 58, Bing Professor of Population Studies and professor of biological sciences at Stanford University. He is the co-author of ''The Population Explosion,'' published this year, which underscored the population and environmental crises.
 
Charlotte J. Erickson, 66, a British historian whose specialty is immigration. She is the Paul Mellon Professor of American History at Cambridge University and wrote research works following European migrations to the United States.
 
Lee Friedlander, 55, an independent photographer whose work has been exhibited in major museums in the United States and abroad.
Recipient of three Guggenheim awards, he lives in New York and last year published ''Like a One-Eyed Cat.''
 
Margaret Joan Geller, 42, professor of astronomy at Harvard University. She is a senior scientist at the Smithsonian Institution.
 
Jorie Graham, 39, poet and professor at the University of Iowa Writers Workshop and author of ''Hybrids of Plants and of Ghosts'' and ''The End of Beauty.''
 
Patricia Hampl, 44, writer of poetry and prose.
She is a Guggenheim Award winner and a professor at the University of Minnesota whose works include an opera libretto, ''Claire de Lune.''
 
John Hollander, 60, poet and literary critic, the A. Bartlett Giamatti Professor of English at Yale University. He is co-editor of ''The Oxford Anthology of English Literature'' and has written texts for contemporary composers.
 
Thomas Cleveland Holt, 47, professor of American and Caribbean history at the University of Chicago. He wrote ''Black over White:
Negro Political Leadership in South Carolina During Reconstruction.''
 
David Kazhdan, 44, mathematician who taught at Moscow University from 1969 to 1975. He is now a professor of mathematics at Harvard University.
 
Calvin R. King, 37, a farmer. He is founder and director of the Arkansas Land and Farm Development Corporation, which seeks to stem the loss of black-owned farmland and the decline in small farms in Arkansas by helping owners secure credit and technical help.
 
M. A. R. Koehl, 41, professor of zoology at the University of California. She is one of the few scientists applying engineering principles to the study of major biological processes.
 
Nancy Kopell, 47, professor of mathematics at Boston University. She uses mathematical analysis to reveal principles of biological organization.
 
Michael Moschen, 35, a juggler and longtime student of the dance, whose performances include experiments with objects, materials and body motions. He lives in New York.
 
Gary Paul Nabhan, 38, an agricultural botanist who co-founded Native Seeds/Search, an organization dedicated to perpetuating the plants and knowledge needed to preserve indigenous food and fibers in Southwestern United States. He is assistant director for research and collections at the Desert Botanical Garden in Phoenix. His books include ''Gathering the Desert.''
 
Sherry B. Ortner, 48, professor of anthropology at the University of Michigan. Her books include ''High Religion: A Cultural and Political History of Sherpa Buddhism.''
 
Otis Pitts Jr., 48, a former police officer. He is president of Tacolcy Economic Development Corporation in Miami, which works to improve conditions in the Liberty City area by stimulating business development and increasing jobs and housing.
 
Yvonne Rainer, 55, a former choreographer and now a film director living in New York. Her films include ''Lives of Performers'' and ''The Man who Envied Women.''
 
Michael S. Schudson, 43, specialist in media and its effect on public and private life in the United States. He is professor of sociology and chairman of the department of communications at the University of California at San Diego and wrote the book ''Advertising: The Uneasy Persuasion.''
 
Rebecca J. Scott, 39, associate professor of history at the University of Michigan and a specialist in slave emancipation in the Americas. She wrote the book ''Slave Emancipation in Cuba: The Transition to Free Labor, 1860-1899.''
 
Marc Shell, 43, a literary critic and head of the department of comparative literature at the University of Massachusetts. His recent work includes ''The End of Kinship.''
 
Susan Sontag, 57, writer, critic and film maker living in New York. She has produced novels, essays, plays and short stories in a career spanning more than two decades. Her latest nonfiction book is ''AIDS and Its Metaphors.''
 
Richard Stallman, 37, a computer programmer.
He is the founder of the Free Software Foundation, which advocates making software available to everyone.
 
Guy Tudor, 55, an illustrator of wildlife and researcher who lives in New York. He is a self-trained ornithologist who has published field guides on South American birds and is producing a four-volume work in this field.
 
Maria Varela, 50, a regional planner working in rural communities in the Southwest and head of Rural Resources, a New Mexico development organization. She was co-founder of Ganadas del Valle, a sheep-ranching and weaving cooperative in Los Ojos, N.M.
 
Gregory Vlastos, 82, retired professor of philosophy at the University of California. He is a specialist in ancient Greek philosophy.
 
Kent Whealy, 44, co-director of the Seed Savers Exchange of Decorah, Iowa, which he founded with his wife, Diane, to preserve ''heirloom'' vegetable varieties.
 
Eric Wolf, 67, professor of anthropology at Lehman College of the City University of New York. He is the author of ''Europe and the People Without History.''
 
Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, 53, a physician and director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group. He is co-author of ''Pills That Don't Work: A Consumers' and Doctors' Guide to over 600 Prescription Drugs that Lack Evidence of Effectiveness.''
 
Robert L. Woodson, 53, founder and president of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise in Washington, which helps poor people seek their own solutions to community problems like housing shortages, unemployment, crime and family conflicts.
 
Jose Fernando Zalaquett, 48, chairman of the Chilean section of Amnesty International's board of directors, an advocate for human rights.

HEADLINE: Vision Becomes Reality for Europe

 BODY:
President Gorbachev yesterday showed great courage in accepting a unified Germany in NATO. And Chancellor Kohl of West Germany demonstrated high statesmanship in agreeing to limit the future all-German army to troop levels below those now possessed by West Germany alone, and to grant credits to Germany's longtime adversary.
This arrangement will help to assure two critical goals: A united Germany will not feel strong and alone, and the Soviet Union will not feel threatened and isolated. These constitute the essential building blocks of a stable and peaceful Europe. 
Leaders often show realism by not trying to hold back the wave of history, or sometimes by riding it. But statesmen go further and recognize where history is heading and smooth the way, at times at great political risk to themselves.
As East Germans rushed westward, Mr. Kohl seized the moment to press for unification, though some Western leaders criticized him. Mr. Gorbachev had the wisdom not to resist, though many of his comrades condemn him. But important accommodations by both men and help from NATO leaders, especially President Bush, now allow an end to Germany's postwar division.
Mr. Gorbachev agreed to restore full sovereignty to a unified Germany, including the right to choose its own allies. And he said he'd pull out the 380,000 Soviet troops that remain in East Germany within four years. In return, Mr. Kohl said he'd cut all-German troop levels to 370,000 from the combined West German total of 480,000 and the East German complement of 135,000. He also pledged to forgo German nuclear capability.
The Chancellor promised as well to provide substantial credits to Moscow. The White House dismisses those credits as a bribe for Soviet withdrawal. But a parlous Soviet domestic scene could jeopardize the transition to a stable and secure Europe.
While Washington plays down this economic dimension of European security, it understands the military and political facets. Mr. Bush led the way in NATO 10 days ago in forging a vision of Europe, whole and free, from the Atlantic to the Urals.
Now Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Kohl have found the way to begin transforming that farsighted vision into reality. They have agreed to what was unimaginable less than a year ago: a united Germany anchored in NATO and a united Germany that does not threaten the Soviet Union.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: No to a Balanced Budget Amendment

 BODY:
The balanced budget amendment that the House will vote on today is impractical, unenforceable and wouldn't end Federal deficits. But it would litter the Constitution with a vacuous promise, and invite greater cynicism in budget-making.
Deficits are arbitrarily defined and easily manipulated. Achieving a specific level, like zero, has no special economic significance. And trying to hit that target could play havoc with valuable Federal programs and a declining economy that might need deficit spending. 
Yes, Congress should keep deficits from spiraling upward. But there is no immediate crisis, and the deficit - compared with the size of the economy - has already been cut in half under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law. More needs to be done. The prudent way is to amend Gramm-Rudman to make it work better, not spoil the precious Constitution in a quixotic search for a quick fix.
The proposed amendment would require a three-fifths vote in both houses to run a deficit. That, say the sponsors, would provide the flexibility to run deficits when they are needed but stymie unnecessary borrowing. But nowhere does the amendment come to grips with political reality. Evasion would be simple. Congress could move programs ''off budget,'' like funds for the savings and loan crisis.
The amendment also would require Congress and the President to agree on revenue and expenditure estimates. But politicians have a common interest in fudging such projections and pretending to pass a balanced budget. The amendment's only safeguard against self-serving projections is the proposed three-fifths vote to raise the debt ceiling. That way legislators eventually would be forced to confront the issue. Yet garnering enough votes would be easy since to vote otherwise would bring the Government to a screeching halt.
As for states that have balanced budget amendments, they also have separate capital accounts. That allows them to borrow money for long-term investments in infrastructure. There is no separate capital account in the Federal budget. So a requirement to balance the budget would create a horrific incentive for Congress to avoid costly investments in railroads, education and research.
Congress has been unable to make the Gramm-Rudman budget law work fully as intended. But amending it to plug loopholes would be far easier, and better, than drafting a skimpily worded constitutional amendment.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Lower Landfill Fees Will Cost New York Plenty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The New York City Board of Estimate, in its preliminary decision to reduce the fees charged private carters who remove recyclables before dumping at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island (news article, June 27), is seeking a short-term fiscal gain at the price of long-term economic losses at the Fresh Kills landfill.
There is no valid reason to subsidize private carters to motivate them to recycle; Mayor David N. Dinkins's administration has authority under Local Law 19 to require recycling of commercial collections, but has delayed action. The administration's motive is apparently the short-term gain of approximately $17 million in the 1991 fiscal year from more dumping at the lower fee. But this imposes a high-run cost associated with the accelerated depletion of the capacity at Fresh Kills.
Extending the useful life of the Fresh Kills landfill is a crucial element in any coherent solid-waste-management strategy. The Dinkins administration should not be remembered for its failure to protect New York City from the costly, and potentially overwhelming, problem of disposing of its waste when the Fresh Kills landfill is full.
The Dinkins administration can slow the depletion of the landfill by accelerating recycling, taking more aggressive waste-reduction measures and building new incineration plants. Specifically, the administration should issue regulations requiring commercial recycling and should raise, rather than lower, the tipping fees as recommended in the Citizens Budget Commission report issued in January, ''The State of the Uniformed Services.''
 
BUD H. GIBBS, Chairman
Municipal Services Committee
Citizens Budget Commission
 New York, July 3, 1990

HEADLINE: Education Consumers Should Have a Choice;
Still Far to Go

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''School Vouchers: Dangerous Claptrap'' (Op-Ed, June 29), Bill Honig presents a myopic view of school reform in California.
Contrary to Mr. Honig's internal measurements, California schools are not yet making the grade. At Pacific Telesis each year, we test thousands of candidates for entry-level jobs. Fifty-six percent fail to pass what amounts to about a junior-high level equivalency test.
Our experience is consistent with that of other members of the California Business Roundtable, an organization of the 75 largest private employers in the state.
While our schools are ailing, it is imprudent to dismiss a proposal from an institution like Brookings without thorough debate and consideration on its merits. It is premature to claim that all necessary reforms are in place and working in California.
California needs better performance-based student assessment techniques. We need to create affiliations between businesses and schools that help students smoothly from the classroom to a career. We need better teacher training and certification, and increased pay for those reaching professional status. We need more technology integrated into curriculum and administration. We need more parental involvement and a society that puts a premium on quality education.
I'm not wedded to the voucher plan proposed by John Chubb (of Brookings) and Terry Moe (Stanford), but I am committed to seeing some form of choice become part of educational reform. Perhaps progress has been slight in California, but the real issue for those who depend on the quality of our school system to compete in our global economy is how far we have left to go.
 
SAM GINN
San Francisco, July 3, 1990
 The writer, chairman and chief executive officer of Pacific Telesis Group, heads the California Business Roundtable's education task force.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
L'Etat, C'Est Moi

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

 BODY:
During the cold war the United States often supported undemocratic governments in the third world on the ground that they were pro-Western. Now that the cold war is over, and won, what should this country do when a third-world government we have favored turns nasty?
The question is raised in intriguing form by what is happening these days in Kenya. President Daniel arap Moi is cracking down hard on all who criticize his one-party state. Lawyers, journalists and politicians have been detained for speaking in favor of multiparty democracy - or defending the rights of those who do. 
Kenya has for decades been a, perhaps the, Washington favorite among African countries. While others tried various forms of Socialism, Kenya had a capitalist economy. It was also seen as a Western bulwark when the Soviet Union interested itself nearby in the Horn of Africa.
Kenya is the largest recipient of U.S. aid in sub-Saharan Africa. The Bush Administration has it down for $53 million in the next fiscal year.
President Moi has always been an authoritarian figure, but he has become increasingly intolerant of opposition. He reacted angrily this winter to public criticism over the unexplained death of the Foreign Minister, Robert Ouko, whose charred body was found in the countryside.
Early this month prominent Government critics were taken into indefinite detention without charge. Among them were two former Cabinet ministers, Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia, who have called for multiparty democracy. Mr. Matiba's home was attacked last month by 15 men armed with clubs and machetes; his wife's skull was fractured.
Another detainee is the editor of The Nairobi Law Monthly, Gitobu Imanyara. Mr. Imanyara visited the United States not long ago and spoke with human rights groups about the situation in Kenya. In the three years of his magazine's existence, it has become the leading voice for free speech and due process of law. But it has now been effectively silenced, because anyone selling it is arrested.
The police have also cracked down on what they call ''subversive music.'' They have arrested dozens of people for selling or listening to audio tapes with messages in favor of democracy. One of the tapes, referring to the murdered Foreign Minister, was called ''Who Killed Dr. Ouko?''
Few Americans will know the people detained or brutalized in Kenya. But the pattern of tyranny is familiar. As in so many other places, a leader has begun to lose public confidence because of economic and other failures - symbolized by the massive shantytowns near rich neighborhoods of Nairobi. He has met grievances by brutal measures to hold onto power.
What should the United States do in those circumstances? The U.S. Ambassador to Kenya, Smith Hempstone, has given an uncommonly forthright answer to the question. He has spoken out against one-party rule and said the United States will favor African countries that move toward multiparty democracy. For that, Mr. Hempstone was denounced by a newspaper in an editorial headed, ''Shut Up, Mr. Ambassador.''
Last week a prominent Kenyan human rights lawyer, Gibson Kamau Kuria, sought refuge from the police in the U.S. Embassy. Mr. Hempstone took him in and succeeded in arranging for him to go to London.
What remains to be seen is whether Washington will support its Ambassador. On July 5, the day after the political arrests in Kenya, the Defense Department signed an aid agreement for $5 million in arms to Kenya. If the Bush Administration is serious about backing up Mr. Hempstone, it will surely stop that agreement.
The developments in Kenya show that there should be no ideological division in this country now on issues of human rights. Ambassador Hempstone, a former newspaper columnist, is a conservative. I think liberals will agree with him that America's voice should be heard when governments we have supported act tyrannically.
The Kenya case also makes a point about the universality of human rights standards. Americans who have been engaged in the effort to bring democracy to South Africa should take the same view in Kenya. The campaign against apartheid is also a campaign for a free political system, justice, no detention without trial.
U.S. aid now goes to many brutal regimes, from Guatemala to Zaire. Why should it, when the cold war reasons are gone? Human rights must play a larger part in our decisions on whom to help, and Kenya is a good place to start defining the terms.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
All-Natural Food For the Dog Who Has It All

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: WESTPORT, CONN.

 BODY:
''It's Shelbie's birthday?'' asked Jordana Bloom, petting a customer at her gourmet health-food store. ''It's your birthday, Shelbie? Did you tell Jeannette it's Shelbie's birthday?'' Jeanette Champsaur, star saleswoman at Lick Your Chops, was up front finishing a high-protein, high-fiber order for a new customer, Wizzy Wig. ''Shelbie's three?'' asked Ms. Bloom, petting the customer some more. ''Let's get her birthday gifts started.'' Would Shelbie like a freshly baked whole wheat biscuit with carobs? Perhaps some imported New Zealand mutton for Shelbie? ''Jeanette, it's Shelbie's birthday!''
''Oh, this is the birthday dog?'' said Mrs. Champsaur, smiling at Shelbie, a midget version of Lassie. 
Meanwhile, Ms. Bloom had news for Wizzy Wig. ''This is our Lick Your Chops health club membership,'' she said. ''You did get one?''
''No,'' said Wizzy Wig's owner, Vicki Vance. ''No, I didn't know about the health club.'' When it comes to the gourmet pet-health-food industry, there's so much important going on that it's hard keeping track of new developments. ''I'm starting a bird section this fall,'' said Susan Goldstein, who opened her first Lick Your Chops store a decade ago and now oversees six in the Northeast. ''I have a bird. I feel I understand his needs. We'll be coming out with a new bird product. It's still in the R-and-D stage.''
The nation may or may not be in recession, but in well-to-do suburbs like Westport, the philosophy remains ''You are what your dog eats,'' and there are plenty willing to pay three times more for all-natural dog food. Supermarket dog food? ''Garbage!'' said Tirzah Barrett. ''Junk! You open a can, it's something you wouldn't eat. This is all natural. I always buy the best food for my dog.
Let's get you a warm cookie,'' she said to Kuulei, her poodle.
 
Next door to Ann
Taylor on Main Street here, the shop smells like a bakery and looks like a cafe.
Indeed, recently an elderly couple came in and asked for the special senior food, New Zealand mutton and rice. ''They didn't realize,'' said Mrs. Champsaur, ''it was for senior dogs.''
''Excuse me, where are the quackers?'' asked Chris Yanik. She meant the dog cookies shaped like ducks and made of whole organic eggs, Vermont cheese, rye flour, herbs and virgin olive oil. ''Gone?'' She picked peanut butter bones, carrot canes, banana spice, 10 for $6.65. ''That's cheap,'' she said. ''My dog loves the products and I love my dog and that's basically it.''
Ms. Bloom, a Dartmouth graduate, has little patience for those who question dog health food. ''It's easy to dismiss as frivolous,'' she says, ''but it's not. This is a mission. There's a lot of meaning to what we're doing. We're converting customers and animals.''
As the founder, Ms. Goldstein often says herself, ''Our belief is animals should have life force foods. Our meats are U.S.D.A. inspected and meet human standards. All the lamb is from New Zealand, the only place that guarantees there's no pesticides on the grazing land.'' When she started, she'd sell ingredients, so owners could cook homemade meals.
''I'd recommend a butcher, suggest fresh steamed chicken dishes.'' She was surprised not everyone had her dedication. ''Our clients didn't want to cook up meals.'' It's hard after a full day at the office to cook the dog dinner. ''It is,'' said Ms. Goldstein, ''It is.'' And that is why she she now offers 50 Lick Your Chops items.
It gets more complicated. ''We were the first to recognize you have to go beyond all natural,'' she said. ''We really interface with the animal person, we really dialogue.''
To upsurge interfacing, they started Pet of the Month and Birthday clubs. ''Out of control,'' said Ms. Bloom. ''We need a whole birthday staff for dogs and cats.'' They get 200 nominees for each Pet of the Month. ''Pierre's a very smart dog and understands many words,'' read one. ''Pierre is well known in our town.''
Westporters from a young age learn to want the best for their dogs. James Pechi, 8, comes in the shop daily for his dog, Princess. ''He takes the $3 his mother gives him to get pizza and soda for lunch and spends it on his dog,'' said Ms. Bloom. ''We worry about him, but he says, 'It's O.K., I'm not hungry.''
''Excuse me, can I help you,'' said Ms. Bloom. It was Elizabeth Nelson, who needed tangle-free shampoo for her dog, Rumple.
''We have exactly what you're looking for, don't move,'' said Ms. Bloom, going to the back to get it. While Ms. Nelson waited she and Rumple socialized with a bichon frise named Brinkley. Gourmet pet-food shops attract a nice breed. Ms. Nelson paid for the shampoo and a peanut butter star for Rumple, and before leaving, she bent down and kissed Brinkley good-bye.

HEADLINE: Lowlands Low No More As S.I. Favors Swamps

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Not so long ago, wetlands were considered disease-harboring nuisances -in other words, swamps.
On Staten Island, like elsewhere, wetlands were routinely filled and built on, used as dumping grounds for car wrecks and construction debris or converted for agriculture. Now, many Staten Island residents are fighting to preserve the borough's remaining wetlands, asserting that they have both environmental and great economic value.
Continued filling of freshwater wetlands for development may lead to much more flooding in southern Staten Island - already a flood-prone area -and require spending at least $1 billion to build storm sewers to duplicate the wetlands' natural storage ability, New York City environmental officials say. 
In addition, Staten Island, the least-developed borough, is the only part of the city where there are significant opportunities to preserve open space.
 
Many Landowners Dislike Label
And the island's 2,000 acres of freshwater wetlands, the largest concentration in the city, provide some of the increasingly rare habitat for birds to rest during migration along the Atlantic seaboard. The wetlands range in size from Outerbridge Pond, which is less than an acre, to the 242-acre Oakwood Beach wetland on the south shore.
But many Staten Island property owners say that by designating their land as wetland, the state has drastically reduced its value and made it almost impossible to sell. Owners of wetlands need a hard-to-obtain state permit to build.
As a result, they are demanding government compensation for their land, a sum that could reach a total of $400 million, according to a state estimate. At stake are more than 7,000 parcels owned by several thousand people.
''We want to preserve wetlands as much as anybody,'' said Daniel L. Master, representing the Staten Island Board of Realtors at a recent state hearing on wetlands. ''But basically we want people's property rights upheld.''
 
State Considers Some Filling
The conflict has been boiling for several years. It recently got hotter when a state draft of an environmental impact statement proposed allowing degraded wetlands on Staten Island to be filled and used for building, if ones in better condition are preserved.
Environmentalists assert that that ''trading-off'' approach flies in the face of the state's policy of no net loss of wetlands, and is a sellout to Staten Island developers. Even the most degraded wetlands are useful, and can be at least partly restored by nature if left undisturbed, they say.
If the state permits the approach in Staten Island, the environmentalists say, it could be applied to other parts of the state where development pressures are strong.
''If wetlands are traded off and built upon, every Staten Islander will suffer, struggling with overcrowed schools, roads, transportation, services,'' said Ellen O'Flaherty Pratt, a member of Protectors of Pine Oak Woods, a local environmental group. The group supports government purchase of the wetlands, she said, but thinks the estimated $400 million price tag is exaggerated.
A spokesman for the regional office of the state Department of Environmental Conservation, William Hewitt, said the proposal could be modified or eliminated before the environmental impact statement is made final.
 
Using Wetlands as Storm Sewers
Much of southern Staten Island lacks storm sewers. The city is trying to avoid spending at least $1 billion on such systems by using existing wetlands to collect storm water. The Bluebelt project, as it is called, involves five separate wetlands systems consisting of many properties in the southern part of the island.
The city supports a no-net-loss policy for Staten Island wetlands, said Albert F. Appleton, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner. But this ''doesn't necessarily require us to save every last postage-stamp-size wetlands,'' he said. ''My concern is with the overall function of the storm system.''
Wetlands, which are most often moist or swampy lands, offer vital habitat to fish, birds and other wildlife. They also provide flood control by leaving places for rainwater to collect. Wetlands also help to purify water by slowing it down before it reaches the sea, giving time for solids to sink and subjecting organic pollutants to microbes in the mud.
Only about half of Staten Island's 4,000 acres of freshwater wetlands found by the first Dutch and English settlers remain. Those that have not been drained and cleared for agriculture or filled in for urban uses have been degraded, to some extent, by the increasing stormwater runoff from paved areas and by urban contamination.
 
Owners Fear Crushing of Values
Broad debate over the future of Staten Island's freshwater wetlands dates to 1976, when the Department of Environmental Conservation began compiling an inventory. A 1975 state law regulates wetlands larger than 12.4 acres, although smaller parcels may be included if deemed of unusual local importance.
By 1981, about 600 acres had been identified. Based on public comment about wetlands that had been missed, the department produced another map in 1986 more than doubling the total acreage. A final map in September 1987 designated about 2,000 acres of wetlands, of which 800 are privately owned, mostly in small lots.
The 1986 designations upset many property owners. They argued that the market value of their land had been crushed; some said they had purchased property after 1981 without any idea that the land would later be considered wetland.
Their views received a sympathetic hearing in Albany. The Legislature gave the Freshwater Wetlands Appeals Board, an existing five-member body, the authority to hear Staten Island landowners' grievances. Owners whose property was not included in the original 1981 mapping could seek a reversal of the designation or dispensation for hardship. In some cases, that could mean permission to build. What Is a Hardship? Environmental groups say the appeals board has become a tool of developers in the two years it has been issuing decisions. And the Department of Environmental Conservation is fighting the board in court over what should be considered a hardship.
Of 175 appeals filed, two-thirds are still pending. Of the few cases decided, about half have gone in favor of the landowners, said Maxine Spierer, a board member from Staten Island.
Ms. Spierer denied the board favored building over conservation. ''Nobody is going to be 100 percent happy with our decisions,'' she said.
What might make many owners happy is if the state or city bought their wetlands. Mr. Appleton said the city is ''giving that very serious consideration'' for holders of ecologically important lands, particularly smaller property owners.
But there was ''less intention,'' Mr. Appleton said, of compensating real-estate speculators and professionals who he said should have known what they were getting into when they bought property after the state's 1981 wetlands designations.
Mr. Appleton's words might be some comfort to Dan Carone, a part owner of a Staten Island travel agency, who said he paid $48,000 for a 100-by-110-foot lot in Annadale in January 1986.
A few months later, the state told him his property was a wetland, Mr. Carone said. He continues to pay several hundred dollars a year in taxes on the property, which he had intended for his retirement home, said Mr. Carone, 53 years old.
''Give me what I paid for the property,'' he said. ''Just get me out of this mess.''

HEADLINE: 'Smart, Driven' Woman Overcomes Reluctance

BYLINE: By M. A. FARBER

 BODY:
The lithe, blond woman known as the Central Park jogger surrendered yesterday some of the privacy she has coveted since the night when she was dragged off a running path in the park and nearly beaten to death.
So intense has been the jogger's desire to preserve her anonymity and, as a friend said, ''simply get on with her life,'' that she only recently, and reluctantly, decided to testify against those accused of raping her - an option largely left to her by the Manhattan District Attorney's office, which is prosecuting the case and could have subpoenaed her.
''She was not happy with the world seeing that she's not 100 percent,'' said an acquaintance in whom the 30-year-old woman has confided.
The attack on the jogger - and, in separate incidents that night, on other people in the park - was one of the most widely publicized crimes of the 1980's. Some saw, in the jogger's case, the random but pervasive violence in big city life. Others saw the particular vulnerability of women. Because she is white and the defendants are black, some saw a racial element in the case, whether in the attack itself or in the vigorous prosecution of the defendants. 
 
Spoke Expecting Her to Die
In the days following the April 1989 attack on the investment banker, when doctors indicated she might die or be left with considerable brain damage, much was written and broadcast of a personal nature about her.
As doctors at Metropolitan Hospital in East Harlem, where she was initially treated, responded to requests from information about the victim's injuries and progress, as John Cardinal O'Connor visited and Frank Sinatra sent roses and thousands of ordinary people offered their sympathies, the victim's family and employer, friends and former teachers helped reconstruct a life that was both grand and ordinary.
Born in Bergen County, N.J., she had moved as a girl to Upper St. Clair, Pa., a bucolic Pittsburgh suburb, where her father, now retired, was a senior manager with Westinghouse and where both he and his wife were members of the local school board. An accomplished ballet dancer, the young woman went to Wellesley College, where she was active in the Catholic student center and helped organize a nutritional program for battered women. By graduation in 1982, she had won the economics department's top student prize, earned a Phi Beta Kappa key and was nominated for a Rhodes Scholarship.
 
Brilliant, and No Cheerleader
''She was brilliant, probably one of the top four or five students of the decade,'' recalled Len M. Nichols, chairman of Wellesley's economics department. ''She had the ability to ask the question that she wanted to ask and that was far advanced for her age and the other students didn't resent that.''
''I call that diplomatic skills, but she wasn't a bubbly cheerleader type,'' Professor Nichols said. After two years with a management consulting firm in Boston - and a summer working for the State Department at the American Embassy in Zimbabwe - she enrolled in the Yale School of Management, where, in 1986, she received a master's degree in business and international relations. She joined Salomon Brothers as an associate investment banker in the corporate finance department and, by 1988, was a junior member of the firm's fast-paced energy and natural resources group.
For some time she shared a two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment on East 75th Street with a Salomon employee she had met in a training class, Patrick Garrett. By early last year, however, she had subleased a cooperative on East 83d Street that she was considering buying.
 
Vegetarian and Maybe Anorexic
A vegetarian who was much concerned about fitness, the woman, who carried about 90 pounds on a five-foot-five-inch frame and was once diagnosed as possibly anorexic, was a compulsive runner, at least since her days at Wellesley. It was commonplace for her to run four to six miles at once, or even, on weekends, to run to work on Wall Street and back home.
Friends who have known the woman over the years have described her as extremely competitive, temperate, occasionally stubborn but demanding of herself, generous and, when time permitted, fun-loving.
''She was - she is - real dedicated at achieving what she wanted; she's what I'd call quietly aggressive,'' a former classmate at Yale, who asked not to be identified, said yesterday. ''I wouldn't be surprised if she ended up at a place like the World Bank.''
The attack on her in Central Park -she was, according to some of the defendants' statements, tied up, raped repeatedly and beaten on the head and body with a brick, a lead pipe and rocks - occurred between 9 and 10 P.M. But, for her, running even at that hour, alone and in an all-but-deserted area of the park, was not unprecedented.
 
Offered to Help Prosecutors
The victim - whose survival has been ascribed in part to her strong will - was treated for seven weeks at Metropolitan Hospital, where she was discovered to have no memory of the attack. During the latter part of her stay at Metropolitan, she understood for the first time the reason for her hospitalization. She offered her assistance to the District Attorney's office.
By the time she was transferred in June, 1989 to Gaylord Hospital, a medical rehabilitation center in Wallingford, Conn., much of the public interest in the case had shifted to the sometimes conflicting accounts of the defendants and to the question of their admissibility in court. In mid-November, when the jogger was released from Gaylord, the hospital issued a statement saying that her further recovery was ''highly dependent'' on the privacy accorded her. Assuring that privacy has since become the passionate objective of her family and of those who work with her or know her socially.
 
'Works a Full Day'
The jogger has not spoken to reporters and her parents declined to be interviewed for this article. Her two brothers, a lawyer in Hartford and a prosecutor in Dallas, did not return messages left at their offices.
''She wants anonymity, especially since she got out of the hospital and resumed her life,'' said Lisa Borowitz, a spokeswoman for Salomon Brothers, where the jogger returned to work in late November and was promoted to vice president in corporate finance in January. ''Her focus now is still on the recovery process. She just wants to continue along with her game plan.''
Ms. Borowitz said the woman ''works a full day,'' although fewer than the extended hours that were customary for her before the attack. Telephone calls made to her through the firm's switchboard - apparently whether business-related or not - are routed to Ms. Borowitz's office in ''corporate communications.''
Ms. Borowitz declined to describe the kind of work the jogger is now doing at Salomon Brothers, or to say whether she dealt directly with clients. Nearly each day the victim takes a break for rehabilitation - particularly, it is understood, for deficits related to stress and speed, and for double-vision. Despite the reservations of friends, she is again living alone, this time in an apartment near the financial district. And, with friends or colleagues, she is back to running, as much as five miles a day.
Not in Central Park.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Wynn Waits for Woes to Settle

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER

 BODY:
Whether or not the contractual dispute between Don King, the promoter, and James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, is settled out of court, Steve Wynn still has problems.
In his suit, King named Wynn, the owner of the Mirage in Las Vegas, Nev., as a defendant and accused him of wrongfully interfering with his contract.
But as much as the case put Wynn in jeopardy in the courtroom, it continues to hamstring him in his ability to convert his $32 million purse bid for Douglas's title defense against Evander Holyfield on Sept. 21 into a reality.
''The industry talk is that Wynn hasn't a dime of coverage on his $32 million, because the closed circuit and pay-per-view people won't do anything until the trial is over or a settlement is reached,'' said one boxing insider. 
Lou Falcigno, a closed-circuit exhibitor who recently allied with other exhibitors to form a pay-per-view organization, said neither he nor his exhibitors had put up money to secure closed-circuit rights.
Wynn, however, said: ''We haven't asked for anything from them. We're selling it direct to cable operators.''
Asked whether any pay-per-view systems had advanced him money, Wynn said, ''It's not a proper thing to discuss.''
But Falcigno said, ''Historically, the pay-per-view guys are even less inclined than closed-circuit exhibitors to put up money.''
Falcigno said that because the trial has frozen Wynn in place, Wynn needs more lead time to mount a successful promotion.
''You need easily three months to do a fight correctly,'' Falcigno said.
Then, referring to the Mike Tyson-Alex Stewart match Sept. 22 on Home Box Office, he added: ''The fact that there's a free show the next night doesn't help either. Because where are the boxing reporters going to be? Some of them will be in Atlantic City for Tyson-Stewart and won't be writing in advance of Wynn's fight.''
Falcigno said that if Wynn holds to his Sept. 21 date, he is going to have ''serious problems'' - problems Wynn apparently recognizes.
But so far Wynn hasn't been able to persuade the Holyfield camp to agree to the date he prefers, Oct. 25.
''We're not moving the date a month ahead,'' said Shelly Finkel, an adviser to Holyfield. ''Why should we? They're the ones that went to court. They're the ones that caused the problem. We're ready to fight on Sept. 21.''
Falcigno said he can't imagine Holyfield's promoter, Dan Duva, not giving Wynn the lead time that is an economic necessity.
''It wouldn't do him any good to have his fighter part of a failed promotion,'' said Falcigno of Duva. ''People would say, 'Holyfield can't sell any tickets.' I doubt Dan wants that.''
Wynn appears to think the problem will be resolved.
''We have the right to ask for an extension for cause, and we'll get it,'' he said. ''The trial is the reason we need to reschedule.''
But Duva doesn't share Wynn's opinion.
''Wynn wants to use the trial as an excuse,'' he said. ''He could have been working on the promotion. It's an internal Mirage problem because I don't think they know what to do. The Mirage has talked about Oct. 3, Oct. 19 or Oct. 25 as a new date. The later dates are completely unacceptable. We have no percentage of the upside revenues, so what's the difference?''
''Our objective,'' said Duva, ''is to win the fight. Evander's chances increase the earlier the fight, because he's in shape right now.''
 
Options for Foreman
A compromise is in the works to keep George Foreman as part of the doubleheader co-featuring Tyson against Stewart in Atlantic City on Sept. 22.
Foreman, who was resisting HBO's dictate that he fight Francesco Damiani, the World Boxing Organization heavyweight champion, in a 10-round non-title fight, has been offered the option of a different opponent, possibly Wimpy Halstead. Foreman will probably accept it.
Ron Weathers, Foreman's adviser, said that while Foreman would receive less than the $2- to $2.5 million he was to get for fighting Damiani, the $1.2- to $1.6 million for boxing Halstead, or a reasonable facsimile, likely would satisfy him.
Foreman has a tuneup bout against Ken Lakusta on July 31 in Edmonton, Alberta, and Weathers is looking into a bout against Jean Chanet, the European champion, at Wembley Stadium in London later this year.
As for Damiani, don't be surprised if Foreman ends up fighting him on prime-time network television in November. If the bout does happen, on ABC, it would be for that W.B.O. title that HBO would rather he not pursue - not after the cable service spent $22 million to unify the heavyweight division.
 
Showtime Intrigue
Negotiations are heating up for a Showtime doubleheader of Michael Moorer (W.B.O. light-heavyweight champion) vs. Charles Williams (I.B.F. light-heavyweight champion), and Thomas Hearns (W.B.O. supermiddleweight champion) vs. Juan Gimenez. But that card would lead to more intriguing future bouts: Virgil Hill (W.B.A champion) vs. the winner of Moorer-Williams, with Hearns to fight the winner of that bout.

HEADLINE: Aggression in Men: Hormone Levels Are a Key

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
WHEN men are domineering and intensely competitive, it may be just another case of raging hormones, specifically the male sex hormone testosterone, researchers say.
Scientists have long linked abnormally high levels of testosterone to an unusually early involvement with sex and drug use and to certain violent crimes, like particularly vicious rapes. But now a series of new findings show that high testosterone levels play a role in the normal urge for the upper hand.
Those men who are most likely to try to dominate in a social situation, be it in a prison yard or a board room, are likely to have higher testosterone levels than their peers, new data show.
Scientists caution against placing too much stock in the importance of hormones like testosterone in human affairs, since so many other factors, from childhood experiences to social status, shape the expression of a given behavior like dominance or competitiveness. 
''This doesn't mean that people can't be dominant or aggressive without high testosterone,'' said Dr. Robert Rose, a psychiatrist at the University of Minnesota medical school. ''A woman, of course, can be as competitive as a man, even though her testosterone levels are much lower.''
Scientists emphasize that the effects of hormones on human behavior are small relative to social and psychological factors, showing up most clearly in studies of large numbers of people. And Dr. Rose is among a group of scientists who are skeptical that the hormone is a strong and direct cause of specific human behavior. He cites a series of studies, most involving small numbers of people, that have posted contradictory findings.
''In animals behavior like mating, nesting and aggression is much more tightly linked to hormones than is true in humans,'' Dr. Rose said. ''In humans hormones only set the stage, while social factors determine if and how they are expressed.''
Still, a growing body of new evidence portrays a distinct role for testosterone among men jockeying for power.
High testosterone levels have long been known to typify the dominant males in groups of primates like baboons, and in unusual groups of men like prison inmates and hospitalized psychiatric patients. But the recent research has found the same differences in men who seek social dominance in normal realms of life.
''Hormonal secretions create a propensity for certain behaviors,'' Dr. Rose said. ''Testosterone seems most strongly linked to competitiveness and dominance.''
The findings apply only to men. After puberty, testosterone levels in men are about 10 times higher than in women.
''The highest testosterone level in women tends to fall within the low range for men, so that the hormone is a far greater factor for men than women,'' said Dr. Richard Udry, head of a center for population study at the University of North Carolina, who is studying the effects of testosterone on sexuality. But researchers agree with Dr. Rose that other factors can make women just as competitive as men.
The newest and strongest evidence about the effect of testosterone comes from a study of 1,706 men in the Boston area, aged 39 to 70. The men were selected at random as part of a larger study on aging. Those who agreed to participate were interviewed in their homes and given psychological tests, and blood samples were taken.
Those who had higher levels of testosterone and related hormones had a personality profile that researchers described as ''dominant with some aggressive behavior.''
''The picture we get is of a man who attempts to influence and control other people, who expresses his opinions forcefully and his anger freely, and who dominates social interactions,'' said John B. McKinlay, a psychologist at the New England Research Institute in Watertown, Mass., who was on the research team.
The study, which will be published in Psychosomatic Medicine, is considered significant because it is the first to examine so many randomly chosen men. Most studies of testosterone in humans have been on small numbers in select populations, like prison inmates.
Other studies, Dr. McKinlay noted, have found that men high in the trait of social dominance tend to rise to positions of leadership in business and other organizations. But for many others, some traits associated with testosterone present an obstacle to success.
Exactly how a man's high testosterone level is expressed depends in part on his social class, another new study has found. For men of lower social and economic status, it is likely to show up as a readiness for fights, a history of minor crimes, and chronic trouble with parents, teachers and peers in childhood. But that is not true at higher social and economic rungs, where the display of dominance is more subdued, researchers say.
 
Study of Vietnam Veterans
The findings are from data collected by the Federal Centers for Disease Control from 4,462 Vietnam veterans who were studied starting in 1985 to assess long-term effects of military service. The men's social and economic standing was rated as high if they fell into the top half of the United States population in both income and education level, and low if they fell into the bottom half.
An analysis of data on their testosterone levels was reported in the current issue of Psychological Science by James Dabbs Jr., a psychologist at Georgia State University.
''The overall picture among the high-testosterone men is one of delinquency, substance abuse and a tendency toward excess,'' Dr. Dabbs said. ''They have more trouble with people like teachers while they are growing up, have more sexual partners, are more likely to have gone AWOL in the service and to have used hard drugs. But that was so mainly for men who had low income and little education.''
There is disagreement over the social effect of testosterone on high status men. Dr. McKinlay sees these results from the study of veterans as dovetailing with his own on testosterone and social dominance, with high status men having different outlets for their impulse to dominate.
''How hormone levels are expressed depends on social factors,'' he said. ''You can drive a fast car instead of stealing them, for instance. Social dominance could be channeled into organizational leadership if you have the opportunities.''
 
An Obstacle for Some
On the other hand, Dr. Dabbs believes that many men with high testosterone levels are too impatient and aggressive to find their ways to positions of responsible leadership. Men with the highest testosterone levels were two and a half times more likely to be low-status as high.
The traits of some men with high testosterone may not suit them to rising in organizations where cooperation and consensus are valued, Dr. Dabbs noted. He cited other studies showing that among rapists, high levels are found in those who committed the most vicious attacks, and that among young men, schoolyard bullies have high levels of the hormone.
''Those successful in the business world use the machinery of social power, and many men with high testosterone may not be patient or docile enough to learn that mastery,'' he Dabbs said. ''They'd rather be out doing something physical. They're showoffs and swaggerers, anti-social and selfish.''
In a comparison of men in occupations ranging from the ministry, medicine and college professors to actors, football players and firemen, Dr. Dabbs found that testosterone levels correlated with certain vocations. Ministers were low in the hormone, while actors and football players had the highest levels. That study will be published in The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology.
''I was surprised that actors had such high levels,'' Dr. Dabbs said. ''But I found that among the Vietnam veterans, those who described themselves as entertainers also had high testosterone. There is a certain renegade quality to acting as a career.''
Dr. Dabbs is now studying lawyers to see if those specializing in litigation have higher testosterone levels than lawyers who do not fight it out in court.
In a series of other recent findings, fluctuations in testosterone levels in the 20 to 30 percent range have been found to reflect competitive triumphs and defeats. While most studies have focused on testosterone's influence in causing traits, these studies suggest that the hormone may be sensitive to the ups and downs of competition.
For instance, in one study the testosterone levels of the six members of the University of Nebraska varsity tennis team were monitored before and after six meets.
Players with the highest testosterone levels before each match were the most ''psyched,'' feeling optimistic about the match. Afterward, testosterone levels rose in those who won. How well the players felt they performed was also strongly related to the hormone levels: the better the player evaluated his own performance, the higher the level.
''There is a link between triumph and testosterone levels, which possibly could account for the momentum of a losing or winning streak,'' said Alan Mazur, a sociologist at Syracuse University who was an author of the study. The results were published in Hormone and Behavior in 1989.
 
Triumph and Humiliation
In the same vein, an earlier study by Dr. Mazur showed rises in the testosterone levels of men in the hours after being awarded their M.D. degrees. And, conversely, research by Dr. Rose found that testosterone levels fell in men going through harassment during the first few weeks of officers' candidate school.
Dr. Mazur sees testosterone at play in the small contests that establish pecking orders among men in social life. ''The sporting contest is an analog for any social competition,'' he said. ''It needn't be physical. We've found the same hormone changes in chess matches.''
''Finding your place in the hierarchy is a basic part of primate life, and testosterone is tightly linked to the outcome of battles for dominance in other species,'' he added. ''In humans, of course, face-to-face dominance is highly symbolic. I'd guess that any meaningful elevation of status would raise testosterone levels, and a blow to your status would lower them, though it hasn't been measured yet.''
