HEADLINE: Applause, Confusion On RJR Debt

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
Prices of some RJR Nabisco ''junk bonds'' soared - though not to expected levels - in heavy trading yesterday, as a $6.9 billion refinancing plan was generally well received by Wall Street.
Traders in both the equity and debt markets, however, said they were somewhat confused by the refinancing and did not fully understand its effect on RJR. Prices of RJR warrants dropped 37.5 cents, to $7, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts attributed the drop to the announcement that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which acquired RJR in early 1989, had paid $6.25 a share for new RJR stock, raising questions among traders about the actual value of the equity of the privately held company.
As part of the refinancing plan disclosed late Sunday, Kohlberg, Kravis invested more cash in RJR Nabisco and announced details of bond buyback plan. 
 
'Larger Equity Cushion'
Analysts welcomed the plan, saying it greatly strengthened RJR Nabisco's balance sheet. Investors said that the plan appeared to benefit both bondholders and Kolhberg, Kravis.
''This is a company that now has a larger equity cushion and a less burdensome debt profile,'' said Edward P. Mally, a junk bond analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc.
Investors said that the program somewhat enhanced the Wall Street image of Kohlberg, Kravis. To complete the 1989 buyout, the firm used some junk bonds with a ''reset'' feature that required RJR to establish a fixed interest rate intended to make the bonds trade at their full value.
The reset feature has created problems, because declines in the prices of the bonds require that a higher interest rate be established at the time of the resetting to make the prices rise back to 100 cents on the dollar.
Earlier this year, many investors expressed doubts about whether RJR or Kohlberg, Kravis could pay off the debts.
 
'Buys Them Credibility'
The official terms of the refinancing have altered some investors' opinions of the buyout firm's strategy for solving the problems of its highly leveraged companies. ''I don't think there's any question that it buys them credibility,'' said Robert S. Dow, portfolio manager of the Lord Abbett Bond Debenture Fund in New York.
Henry R. Kravis, a founder of the buyout firm, said yesterday that he believed the refinancing would benefit bondholders, stockholders and employees of RJR Nabisco. ''We think it is a very attractive package,'' he said.
Trading in some of the company's junk bonds was huge, traders said. One trader estimated that $500 million of the two most active issues changed hands.
The refinancing included these actions:
* RJR reset the interest rate on two issues of junk bonds, with a market value of more than $7 billion.
* Kohlberg, Kravis transferred $1.7 billion in new equity to RJR.
* RJR notified the banks that packaged its new loans that it would begin drawing the $2.2 billion tomorrow.
While the company sought to settle the problem of the reset feature, traders debated whether a solution had been found. Even though RJR put a fixed interest rate on two junk bond issues that was intended to make them trade at 100 cents on the dollar plus their accrued interest, neither of the bonds traded yesterday at what investors estimate is their full value.
The exchange debentures due in 2007 closed at 91.75, up more than four points, or $40 for every $1,000 face amount. The converting debentures due in 2009 closed at 114 3/8, up more than 8 points.
 
Possible Legal Action
The closing prices were lower than the bonds' full values, analysts estimated. The difference, traders said, reflected the lack of details about the new convertible preferred stock that will be used in an exchange offer for some of the bonds. Traders said bondholders did not appear upset that the bonds did not trade at par yesterday. But they said lawsuits might be filed if the bonds do not trade at their full value in the next week.
The language of the bond agreement does not say that the two junk bond issues must actually trade at par. It says the rate set by the investment bankers must be one that they believe will make the bonds trade at their par value on a ''fully distributed basis.''
The rate on the exchange debentures due in 2007 is 17 percent, and the rate on the converting debentures due in 2009 is 17 3/8 percent. Those rates were higher than many investors had anticipated, traders said.
The interest in RJR's junk bonds helped to lift overall junk bond prices yesterday.
The complicated reset feature had allowed Kohlberg, Kravis to acquire RJR Nabisco in its battle for the company against a group led by F. Ross Johnson, who was then chief executive of the tobacco and food giant, and included Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and Salomon Brothers. The special committee of RJR board members that decided the buyout issue agreed to accept the Kohlberg, Kravis offer because it included junk bonds with the reset feature, and the bid by their opponents did not, according to a book about the battle, ''Barbarians at the Gate.''
RJR executives have put in new cash and are ridding the company of some of its most expensive debt. This includes junk bonds that were accruing interest as additional bonds instead of cash, $1 billion of increasing-rate notes, a $1.15 billion bank bridge loan and some of a $500 million bridge loan from Kohlberg, Kravis.
RJR would not disclose how the refinancing would affect the company's cash payments of interest and dividends. But Dirk Van Doren, a junk bond analyst at McCarthy Crisanti Maffei in Montpelier, Vt., estimated that the total payments -including interest and dividends on the new preferred stock - were not likely to increase. He estimated that in 1991 the company would have to pay between $500 million and $600 million in cash that under the old plan was accruing in additional bonds. Such a sum is easily covered by the company's cash flow, he said.
 
Gains Equity
In the new structure, RJR has a great deal more equity. While debt is reduced to less than $20 billion, from $23 billion, equity has been increased to $4 billion, from $1 billion. At the same time Kohlberg, Kravis's share of this equity has increased to about 68 percent, from about 58 percent, a spokesman for RJR said. The amount available to bondholders in the new issue of convertible preferred stock remains the same at about 25 percent and the proportionate share of the holders of RJR warrants declines to about 7 percent.
In addition to the change in the interest rate on the junk bonds, RJR plans to use some of the proceeds of the refinancing to buy back some of the bonds in the open market. Some of the cash will also be used in a separate exchange offer for the junk bonds. Initially, the repurchase program will affect only the exchange debentures due in 2007. Open market or private purchases of any of the converting debentures due in 2009 will begin only after an exchange offer for the converting debentures is completed.
RJR will also soon announce details of an exchange offer of $800 million in cash and $1.16 billion of new 11.5 percent convertible preferred stock for up to 85 percent of the converting debentures and some of the exchange debentures. Holders of these debentures will receive $333 in cash and $667 in stated value of the new convertible preferred stock for each $1,000 amount of principal and accrued interest.
The new preferred stock has a stated value of $25 a share and may be converted into common shares of RJR Nabisco Holdings at a conversion price of $9 a share.
 
GAF Agreement
WAYNE, N.J., July 16 (AP) - The GAF Corporation announced today that four banks had agreed to provide the specialty chemicals and building materials company with $800 million in long-term financing, primarily to pay off debt incurred when a management group bought out shareholders in March 1989. Banks involved in the agreement are the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Bank of New York, the Bank of Nova Scotia and Banque Paribas of Paris. The refinancing arrangement is expected to be completed next month, the company said. A management group led by Samuel J. Heyman, chairman and chief executive, paid $1.46 billion in the buyout.

HEADLINE: Profits Off For Some Big Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Problems with bad real estate loans and sluggish demand for new loans are depressing profits of some large banks around the country, reports yesterday of earnings for the second quarter showed.
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the First Chicago Corporation and the Bank of New York Company all reported declines in second-quarter earnings from a year earlier, while J. P. Morgan & Company and the Security Pacific Corporation had small gains. But the NCNB Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., turned in a 50 percent increase in its profits despite an increase in problem loans.
''This is as bad an environment for banks as I have seen in 20 years,'' said Thomas Hanley, a managing director at Salomon Brothers Inc., who tracks 35 large banking companies. He recently forecast declines in second-quarter profits at 21 of those banks, including 9 of the nation's 10 largest banks. 64% Decline for Chase Profits at Chase Manhattan fell 64 percent, to $52 million, or 24 cents a share, from $137 million, or $1.31 a share, in the quarter last year, when it had fewer shares outstanding. Chase said its profits were hurt by a $75 million increase in its reserve for loan losses, most of which was needed to cover possible losses on its commercial real estate lending. 
Chase said it had $1.28 billion in commercial real estate loans that were not paying interest or faced trouble at the end of the period, up from $884 million at the end of March.
The weakness at Chase, the nation's second-largest banking company after Citibank, has led to uncertainty over whether it could maintain its common stock dividend of 62 cents a share. A Chase spokesman said yesterday, however, that executives planned to recommend this week that the board maintain the dividend.
''With each quarter that Chase's earnings do not cover its dividend, the stock market gets more and more concerned and discounts Chase stock to reflect the possibility of a dividend reduction,'' said Raphael Soifer, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company.
In active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Chase stock closed down 50 cents a share, to $20.75, its lowest level of the year.
Beside its problems with real estate loans, analysts said, Chase's future earnings might be hurt by severance pay and other costs from its plans to cut 3,200 workers. Chase had said it hoped the cut in payroll and reorganization would reduce expenses by $300 million annually.
 
First Chicago
First Chicago also reported that problems with bad business loans had depressed its profits, which fell 34 percent, to $87.4 million, or $1.19 a share, from $134.4 million, or $1.92 a share.
More than three-quarters of First Chicago's profit came from its regional banking business, which includes credit cards, consumer banking in Chicago and the activities of the American National Corporation, a big lender to small- and medium-sized businesses. But while profits at the regional bank rose 39 percent, to $61 million, profits from lending to large corporations through its wholesale banking group fell 74 percent, to $20 million.
Business loans that were not paying interest or faced other trouble rose to $640 million at the end of the quarter, from $582 million at the end of March. Troubled commercial real estate loans declined by $44 milion, to $331 million, but the company's holdings of real estate acquired from bad loans rose $76 million, to $293 million.
 
Bank of New York
The Bank of New York's profit of $70 million, or 90 cents a share, was down 39 percent from $114 million, or $1.55 a share.
Most of the decline resulted from a $94 million increase in its loan-loss reserve, of which $71 million was used to pay for write-offs of domestic loans.
Problem assets, including loans that were not paying interest and real estate acquired because of bad loans, rose to $1.336 billion at the end of the quarter, up $145 million from March 31. About $115 million in loans to heavily indebted corporations were added to the problem list during the quarter, but $65 million worth of such loans improved enough to be removed from the list.
 
J. P. Morgan
At J. P. Morgan, profits of $207 million, or $1.06 a share, were up less than 1 percent from $206 million, or $1.09 a share. Morgan, which has avoided the riskier loans for commercial real estate or leveraged buyouts, added only $10 million to its reserve for loan losses, down from $35 million a year earlier.
The strongest element in Morgan's earnings was its trading activities, which produced profits of $234 million, up from $161 million. Profits were strong from interest-rate swaps and trading loans of less-developed countries.
 
Security Pacific
Security Pacific's profit rose nearly 6 percent, to $195.2 million, or $1.59 a share, from $184.5 million, or $1.58 a share, a year earlier.
Robert H. Smith, the president the of Los Angeles-based bank, noted that the strength of the California and Washington economies continued to help the company. Noninterest expenses rose by only 2 percent from a year earlier, a much smaller gain that at most other banking companies of its size.
But problems with bad loans, primarily for Arizona real estate and businesses in Britain and Australia, led Security Pacific to add $160.7 million to its reserve for loan losses, up from $111.6 million a year earlier.
 
NCNB
NCNB, which has become the nation's seventh-largest banking company since its expansion into Texas two years ago, said its earnings surged 50 percent, to $137.4 million, or $1.26 a share, from $91.5 million, or $1 a share.
NCNB added to its consumer deposit base by acquiring failed savings and loans in Texas and gaining new customers. Average deposits during the quarter of $48.1 billion were up 13 percent.
Because of slack loan demand, NCNB has been using its rising deposits to buy low-risk Government securities. When loan demand improves and risks of lending subside, analysts expect NCNB to benefit as it shifts from low-yielding Government securities to higher-yielding loans.
Problem loans, however, rose $96.1 million, to $695.2 million, while the company added $84.1 million to its reserve for loan losses. A year earlier, only $46.3 million was added to the resreve.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Programs to Keep Retirees Healthy

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
AT the Campbell Soup Company's fitness center in Camden, N.J., Bill Brown, a 79-year-old retiree, leads an exercise class called flexibility.
A growing number of employers like Campbell Soup are making special efforts to help retirees stay healthy. They say retirees feel good about the programs. So do active employees, especially those nearing retirement. ''It's great for our employees, who can see that these retirees have such a wonderful attitude about life,'' said John R. Thompson, Campbell's employee health services manager. 
And benefits managers reckon that fewer visits to doctors and hospitals will mean savings for the company health plan.
Studies indicate that wellness programs for older adults can reduce the risk of cancer and improve cardiovascular health, muscle strength and motor capacity, said Robert Levin, director of the Institute on Aging with the Washington Business Group on Health, an employers' association.
''It used to be thought that anything you did in health promotion for seniors would be too little and too late, but two new lines of thinking are changing this,'' said Dr. James F. Fries of the Stanford University School of Medicine. ''First, the likelihood of an illness is many times greater for seniors than for younger people, so you are intervening at the right time. And second, health-care expenses are so much greater for seniors that even a small percentage change will yield relatively large dividends.''
Dr. Fries recently reported on a 12-month study of 6,000 retired employees of the Bank of America. Some of the bank's retiree clubs took part in a wellness program, which included exercising, changing diets and quitting smoking. The club members' medical costs declined 16 percent while the dollar claims by retirees in clubs that did not participate rose 3 percent.
In another study, Dr. Fries and J. Paul Leigh, an economist at San Jose State University, looked at the bank's retirees whose health was thought to be at risk. They were overweight, did not exercise vigorously, consumed at least one pack of cigarettes and two alcoholic drinks each day, and usually did not buckle their auto seat belts.
''The worst-case difference in annual hospital and doctor costs between a person with good habits and one with bad habits was $4,588,'' said Clark E. Kerr, a Bank of America vice president in San Francisco. ''We concluded that health habits can make a big difference on the bottom line of actual claims dollars.''
The bank has expanded the health promotion program, now in its third year. ''The retiree clubs that participated were very happy,'' Mr. Kerr said. ''The control groups all wanted in. This is one of the few things the company can do to save money that also makes the employees happy.''
In a similar approach, Texas Instruments has started retiree clubs at 4 of its 13 fitness centers and is organizing more. Retirees get free lifetime memberships in the centers. ''We ask them to donate 10 to 15 hours of voluntary time a year, to help with mailings and organizing special events,'' said Jenny L. Brock, director of corporate health promotion at Texas Instruments, which has 50,000 active employees and 7,000 retirees. She recently started two-month ''Fit to be 50'' classes, which encourage retirees and older employees to keep active and provide advice on nutrition and dealing with stress.
The Adolph Coors Company in Golden, Colo., regularly invites retirees to take part in free exercise and other health-promotion classes.
Some companies encourage retirees to use community facilities like Y.M.C.A. swimming pools. Others keep in touch through retiree health newsletters. The Reader's Digest, for example, sends them Prime Time, a newsletter published by Kelly Communications in Charlottesville, Va.
''Retirees are a tremendous health-cost liability,'' Mr. Kerr at Bank of America said. The cost of health benefits for retirees under age 65, when Medicare kicks in, rose 14 to 16 percent on average this year at 123 corporations surveyed by the TPF&C unit of Towers Perrin, a consulting firm. The average cost for a retiree with family coverage was $4,764. But even this may be a low estimate, TFP&C said, because many employers do not break out their retiree costs.
''Our analysis for specific clients showed costs for retirees under 65 were 150 to 200 percent of the average cost for the active employees,'' said Richard Ostuw, a TPF&C vice president in Cleveland.
Mr. Kerr listed three choices for reducing such costs: ''cut benefits, shift costs to retirees or help retirees get healthier, which is the one everyone likes.'' He added, ''This is something that more and more companies will be doing.''

HEADLINE: Acquisitions By Japanese Rise Sharply

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Japanese purchases of American companies jumped sharply in the first half of this year, while American purchases in Japan remained small.
But while the Japanese buying seems to get most of the attention, Japan was not the leading buyer of United States companies. British and French companies led the list, with purchases totaling $7.9 billion and $5.7 billion, respectively. Japan was No. 3, with $3.8 billion in American acquisitions. 
In addition, there were other large acquisitions made by buyers from Italy, Taiwan and Bahrain, where Investcorp Bank E.C., which bought Saks Fifth Avenue, is based.
 
Deals Almost Double
The number of Japanese deals rose to 64, from 33 in the first half of 1989, and the $3.8 billion value of the acquisitions reported climbed from $2.1 billion, according to an analysis of mergers and acquistions by the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick in New York. Over all in 1989, Japanese purchases in America totaled $10.9 billion, based on the deals in which prices were reported.
At the same time, American companies made only $3.7 million worth of acquisitions in Japan. These were Pepsico's acquisition of Fujiya Frito Lay Ltd. for $1.7 million and the Alliant Computer System Corporation's purchase of Nihon Alliant for $2 million.
Among the big purchases made by Japanese concerns in the United States in the first half of this year were the $880 million acquisition of the Aristech Chemical Corporation by Mitsubishi and Ito/Yokado's purchase of 75 percent of the Southland Corporation for $400 million.
United States purchases worldwide in the first half of the year slowed compared with 1989. But there was a surge of large deals in the second quarter of this year that were valued over all at more than $7 billion. More than half that total came from the $3.8 billion paid by the Phillip Morris Companies to acquire Jacobs Suchard A.G., the Swiss candy maker. Another $1.5 billion is from the Bell Atlantic Corporation's purchase of the Telecom Corporation, the New Zealand telephone company.
Most of the American purchases, by the number of deals, were in Britain, with 37 out of 124 acquisitions. But the total value of those acquisitions, $1.2 billion, is far below that of the purchases the British made in the United States.
 
Drop in Credit Cited
Herbert S. Adler, the internatiional mergers and acquisitions partner for KPMG Peat Marwick, said that a declining availability of credit and the slowing economy in the United States helped curb the number of American purchases worldwide in the first half of the year. Compared with 1989, the value of deals fell to $8.1 billion, from $11.4 billion, and the number of deals fell to 124, from 213. Prices were not reported in all the deals.
With the surge of buying from Japan worldwide, which rose 84 percent to $5.3 billion in the first half of the year, and large purchases by Swedish companies, the overall value of mergers and acquisitions rose 16 percent in the first half of the year. The total value of purchases was $62.2 billion, with almost 45 percent of the deals between countries in the 12-nation European Community.

HEADLINE: G.E. Profits Set a Record For Quarter

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had achieved record operating profit margins in the second quarter and that its net earnings rose to nearly $1.09 billion, a 12 percent increase from the $972 million of a year earlier.
The company's earnings per share rose slightly more, by nearly 13 percent, to $1.22, from $1.08 in the comparable quarter last year, because the company had repurchased 22.9 million shares since starting a stock buyback program last year. The buybacks have reduced the number of shares outstanding by 1.8 percent from a year earlier.
 
Revenues at $14.4 Billion
G.E.'s revenues for the quarter rose by 6.6 percent, to $14.4 billion from $13.5 billion. 
''It was a clean quarter, in line with Wall Street's strong expectations,'' said Mark Altman, who follows General Electric for Paine Webber Inc.
John F. Welch Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive, said G.E. had experienced productivity gains in all of its main lines of business. Some groups like appliances and the industrial group, which makes locomotives, factory equipment and lighting and electrical systems, raised their operating profits even though their revenues were about the same as last year.
Overall operating margins for the company reached 12.9 percent of sales, Mr. Welch said. That topped the previous quarterly record of 12.1 percent, which was achieved in the second quarter of last year.
''The strong upward momentum in incoming order trends continued for longer-cycle businesses,'' Mr. Welch said, citing G.E.'s power-generation, medical systems, locomotive, and aircraft engine businesses. The analysts said that several businesses had been strong for years, notably aircraft engines, but that the growth in power generation was more recent and especially encouraging.
G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., has experienced especially strong demand for gas turbines.
 
Medical Orders Rise 15%
Orders for medical systems were up by 15 percent from a year earlier, led by demand for magnetic resonance imaging equipment for disease diagnosis and X-ray equipment orders in Europe. The transportation group received an order from Mexico for 100 trains, the company's largest such export order in several years. And its aircraft engine business had a record $35 billion backlog by the end of June, up by 10 percent from a year earlier, because of a large order from Japan Air Lines.
G.E. said its financial services group was among its top-performing units, with net income up by 16 percent. It reported that its GE Capital Corporation unit accounted for most of the gain, which the analysts said suggested that its reinsurance business and its Kidder, Peabody & Company brokerage subsidiary performed neither unusually well nor badly.
The company's aerospace and broadcasting groups reported unspecified declines in their operating profits. The broadcasting group, built around the NBC television network, reported that its revenues fell with its profits. G.E. attributed the troubles at NBC to ''market softness.''
NBC's problems related in part to measured declines in the audience for network television under the Nielsen rating system. The analysts said the agreement among the networks and advertisers to adopt a new system for measuring television viewership might spur improved performance in the latter part of the year.
Considering the overall trends in revenues and productivity, Mr. Welch said, G.E. anticipated that double-digit earnings gains would continue for the rest of 1990.
''The operating margin improvement continues to be very impressive,'' said Russell Leavitt, an analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc. ''They are making productivity improvements despite a sluggish economy.''
Possibly because the results were in line with Wall Street's predictions, the immediate reaction of investors was lukewarm. General Electric's shares fell in morning trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, before rebounding to finish at $74.75, down 12.5 cents.

HEADLINE: Alcoa's Net Is Down by 43%

 BODY:
The Aluminum Company of America, citing a softening in aluminum prices and lower income from the company's affiliate in Brazil, yesterday reported a 43 percent drop in second-quarter earnings.
The Pittsburgh-based company, the world's largest producer of aluminum, said that its earnings fell to $161.9 million, or $1.86 a share, compared with $285.2 million, or $3.21 a share, in the second quarter of 1989. Revenue fell to $2.73 billion in the second quarter from $2.82 billion in the 1989 period.
Alcoa said that the lower earnings were primarily a result of a 24 percent decline in the price of aluminum ingot on world markets. Also, the company said that earnings at Alcoa Aluminio, the Brazilian affiliate in which Alcoa holds a 59 percent stake, dropped to $6 million in the first half of the year, compared with $61 million in the comparable period last year. The decline was attributed to actions taken by the Brazilian Government to improve that country's economy.
Peter Anker, a metals analyst with the First Boston Corporation, said that the results were generally in line with expectations. ''They did a little better in Brazil than we had expected,'' Mr. Anker said. ''We had been expecting them to break even in the operation in Brazil, but it looks like they made $6 million.''
Other analysts said that the company's results reflected declining prices for fabricated aluminum products, adding that the prices of aluminum sheets for beverage cans had declined.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Alcoa shares rose 50 cents yesterday, closing at $69.25.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading; Gold and Silver Prices Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher against most major foreign currencies yesterday although traders continued to worry about the direction of American interest rates.
Gold and silver prices fell in the United States and abroad.
Analysts said the dollar continued to recover from a midday decline on Friday, when the Federal Reserve added funds to the banking system and financial markets interpreted the move as a relaxation of the Fed's credit policy. 
Trading was light. James T. McGroarty, senior vice president with Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. in Connecticut, said the market was uncertain about what the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, might say tomorrow about the central bank's policy when he testifies before the Senate Banking Committee.
The dollar put in a mixed performance against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8033 from late Friday's $1.8005, but in earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.8040, from $1.8055 late Friday.
 
Rise in Tokyo
The dollar was unchanged against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 148.15 yen. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 148.43 yen, from 147.42 yen at Friday's close, and it was quoted in London at 148.05 yen.
Gold prices slipped lower in New York, closing at $363.30 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, down $1.10 from late Friday. The Republic National Bank recorded a late bid of $362.50, down $1.50.
Gold traded in London late yesterday at $362.75 a troy ounce, down from $364.55 late Friday. The late price in Zurich was $362.70, down from $364.20. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $363.11 an ounce, down from Saturday's $363.59.
Silver prices also declined. In New York, a troy ounce of silver fell 6.1 cents, to $4.847 a troy ounce. Earlier, in London, silver was bid at a late price of $4.89, down from $4.93.

HEADLINE: New Rules and Incinerator Jitters Mean Hospital Waste Piles Up

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Two summers ago, the New York metropolitan area recoiled in horror as a few syringes and blood vials washed up on local beaches. The authorities pledged to hunt down and punish those responsible and New York, and many other states, made hospital disposal practices subject to sterner regulation and stricter punishment.
 
More Garbage, Fewer Sites
But now, although environmental and government officials are virtually unanimous in their conclusion that the fear inspired by the waste on the beaches was grossly out of proportion to a rather modest threat, the cure has contributed to an emerging medical-waste emergency: New York-area hospitals find themselves confronted by growing piles of garbage requiring special handling and a shrinking list of places to put it.
Environmental authorities and hospital officials generally agree that the new laws, which broaden the classification of regulated medical waste to include many items that did not previously require special handling, are useful and overdue. 
But they also acknowledge that the new rules have doubled the amount of waste that hospitals must consign to special red bags and stricter disposal requirements. At the same time, however, the hospitals' usual methods - on-site incineration or shipment out of state - are becoming more and more limited because of environmental concerns.
The hospitals must shut down or improve their incinerators by 1992 to meet stricter state pollution limits. Such improvements, even at smaller incinerators, could cost hundreds of thousands of dollars at a time when many hospitals are in financial trouble. Even if the incinerators are modified to meet the new standards, hospitals still face powerful neighborhood opposition to continued burning.
More than two-thirds of hospital medical waste is shipped out of state for burning and burial in landfills. But this practice is 10 times as expensive as disposing of regular garbage because of the costs of shipping, packaging and handling, according to the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents 120 nonprofit hospitals.
Meanwhile, the receiving states are becoming increasingly hostile to serving as a dumping ground for New York's medical waste and other garbage. Prices are rising, as are threats to close the borders.
''States will say, 'New York's garbage is no longer welcome here,' and who can blame them?'' said Peter A. Kelly, executive vice president for operations at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. Beth Israel will spend $800,000 this year on disposal, twice as much as a year ago, Mr. Kelly said, despite intensified recycling.
In New York State, regulated medical waste must be packaged in red bags before it leaves the hospital. Such waste, presumed to be infectious although it may not be, includes hypodermic needles, material that has absorbed blood and items that have been touched by patients with highly infectious diseases like AIDS.
In the year since the law on regulated medical waste changed, hospitals have been bagging much more material than they probably need to, to avoid fines and other penalties, said Elizabeth Sommers, vice president of regulatory affairs at the hospital association. Regulated waste now accounts for about a third of the 340 tons of solid waste hospitals generate daily, double the amount of a year ago.
 
Autoclaving in Brooklyn
Last week, Browning-Ferris Industries of Houston, a big waste-disposal company, proposed building a 240-ton-a-day medical-waste processing plant in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard.
Under the plan, made public last Wednesday, medical waste would be trucked from hospitals to the plant to be autoclaved - sterilized using steam and high pressure.
After sterilization, the waste would be shredded and trucked to a landfill, William Bingham, a company official in Boston, said. The landfill locations have not been determined, he said, although they could be those owned or operated by Browning-Ferris.
The board of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, a nonprofit concern that operates the yard, has approved a lease for the Browning-Ferris plant, pending regulatory approvals that could take a year or more.
Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, has scheduled a public hearing on the Browning-Ferris proposal today at 6 P.M. at Borough Hall.
Autoclaving, used in hospitals to sterilize instruments, has come into own for bulk waste only in the last two years, said Allen Hershkowitz, a Natural Resources Defense Council scientist.
But there are tradeoffs. Incineration reduces the volume of waste, but its soot can pollute the sky, and the landfilled ash may contain hazardous substances.Autoclaving is environmentally sound and processes much more waste an hour than incineration does, he said, but it does not reduce volume.
 
Betting on Shutdowns
The 261-acre Navy Yard is also under consideration as the site for a new municipal garbage incinerator. Mayor David N. Dinkins has delayed until 1993 a decision on whether to build the incinerator, which has spurred strong opposition from neighborhood and environmental groups.
Browning-Ferris is betting that most hospitals will shut down their on-site incinerators instead of upgrading them and that paying for out-of-state shipment will become untenable. Instead, the company is hoping the hospitals will turn to its plant, the first of its kind in the region.
But the company may have some competition. Local hospitals are discussing building a regional medical-waste incinerator with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.
Such a plant, intended to make disposal cheaper, could burn both normal and regulated medical waste. There are 57 hospital incinerators in New York City, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group.
Browning-Ferris, which operates incinerators elsewhere, anticipates less environmental opposition to its proposed sterilization and landfilling approach, Mr. Bingham said.
The hospitals agree. ''In the end, they won't be building something they call an incinerator,'' Ms. Sommers said. Indeed, the hospitals expect a time-consuming fight before their incinerator would be allowed to operate in the city.
As has already happened in Germany, Switzerland and Sweden, hospitals may adopt regional disposal rather than treatment at the hospital, because of economies of scale, Mr. Hershkowitz said.
For a price, hospitals can burn regular garbage at city-owned incinerators. But the Sanitation Department will not accept medical waste because of worker safety concerns.
And New York City law prohibits the disposal even of sterilized medical waste at the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island for the same reason, said Daniel Millstone, the Sanitation Department's environmental lawyer. But the city would review the law if the safety of the process could be assured and the waste chopped up and rendered unrecognizable, Mr. Millstone said.
Medical waste constitutes only a small part - about 2 percent - of the nation's solid waste. Few people cared about the disposal of such garbage until the summer of 1988.
The fear of contracting AIDS is responsible for much of the concern, but there have been few, if any documented cases of infectious diseases transmitted that way, said a report by the Medical Waste Policy Committee, a panel of industry, labor, waste disposers and environmental groups.
Still, the horror of beached medical waste spurred legislative action.
Congress passed a law requiring the Environmental Protection Agency to conduct a two-year pilot program for tracking medical waste ''from its cradle to its grave.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
2 GERMANYS VOW TO RETAIN BORDER WITH THE POLES

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 17

 BODY:
East and West Germany agreed today to resolve Polish anxieties by promising to guarantee the postwar German-Polish frontier, and in doing so, the Germans all but guaranteed international endorsement of their own reunification by the end of the year.
The German assurances to Poland that the current border will not be changed after German unification were worked out during a one-day meeting of the ''two plus four'' group, which was organized by the foreign ministers of the two Germanys and the four World War II Allies - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France - to deal with the international aspects of German unification.
The accord on the German-Polish border was widely anticipated after yesterday's landmark agreement between the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, in which Mr. Gorbachev dropped his opposition to the membership of a united Germany in NATO.
 
Polish Peace of Mind
And indeed, the Soviet-German breakthrough seemed to propel all the parties gathered in Paris today into a quickly reached compromise on how to assure the Poles that the present East German-Polish border along the Oder and Neisse rivers will not be altered. 
Before the meeting, at which the Poles accepted the pledges on the border, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany privately assured Poland's Foreign Minister, Krzysztof Skubiszewski, that a united Germany would sign a new economic treaty guaranteeing fulfillment of all business contracts between Poland and East German companies that might soon be out of business.
Mr. Skubiszewski (whose name is pronounced KSHISH-tof Skoo-beh-SHEF-skee) told reporters that ''there was indeed a problem prior to this meeting'' but ''we have received the reassurance that the border treaty would be concluded as soon as possible after unification.''
''Language has been decided that is entirely satisfactory,'' he added.
 
Next Step in September
The six foreign ministers gathered in Paris said they will now be able to meet in Moscow on Sept. 12 to draft a final settlement that would terminate all the four-power rights and responsibilities over Germany and Berlin that grew out of the Allies' occupation of Germany at the end of World War II.
That proposed settlement will be submitted for endorsement to a summit meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The meeting is scheduled for Paris on Nov. 19, provided a treaty reducing conventional arms in Europe is completed by then. Once the Allied rights and responsibilities have been dissolved, fully sovereign East and West Germanys will go ahead with plans to conduct all-German elections on Dec. 2 and proceed with unification.
Today, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, commented: ''We can trust the German people in both parts of Germany. They have proven their commitment to peace and to create a state that will not threaten others.''
''About six months ago in Ottawa we initiated this two-plus-four process,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said at a news conference at the close of today's meeting.
''Our aim was to facilitate the peaceful and democratic unification of Germany and the reconciliation of Europe. Today, we draw much nearer to that target. The outcome that has so long eluded us is now within our reach. By the anniversary of our Ottawa meeting, I expect the United States and the other four-powers will welcome the advent of a united, democratic and sovereign Germany.''
France's Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, was more categoric, saying: ''There are no more obstacles preventing a united Germany from being re-established in its sovereignty by the end of the year.''
 
Speed of the Essence
Today's Polish-German accord was worked out after the two Germanys agreed to a set of five principles confirming the border and after they promised to conclude a formal border treaty with Poland ''within the shortest possible time'' after unification.
After Mr. Skubiszewski expressed his satisfaction, a British television reporter asked Mr. Genscher whether West Germany was in effect buying off Polish and Soviet opposition to unification, given that the Kohl-Gorbachev accord also included a provision for large-scale German economic aid to the Soviet Union. The reporter also asked Mr. Genscher, a fluent English speaker, to answer the question in English.
Mr. Genscher, bristling with anger and pointedly replying in German, said that it was ''not appropriate'' to talk ''about a price paid to buy Soviet agreement.''
''One cannot buy agreement,'' he added.
Virtually all the questions were directed at Mr. Genscher and only a smattering at Mr. Shevardnadze or Mr. Baker. None at all were asked of Mr. Dumas or the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd.
 
Set of Principles
American officials said the five principles regarding the Polish border accepted by the East and West German Foreign Ministers were these:
* After a final settlement is signed, a united Germany will remove from its laws any language suggesting that the Polish-German border is provisional.
* The area of a united Germany will consist only of Berlin and what is now the territory of East and West Germany.
* The parliament of a united Germany will confirm the Oder-Neisse line in a treaty with Poland ''in the shortest possible time'' after unification.
* A united Germany will forswear any territorial claims.
* The four Allied powers agree to serve in effect as witnesses that these commitments will be fulfilled.
 
Intricate if Grim History
The question of a German-Polish border treaty has been left in abeyance since the close of World War II. At the start of the war, Nazi Germany occupied western Poland and the Soviet Union occupied the eastern part. In 1945, after the war ended, the Soviet Union, by then ally and mentor of Poland, kept parts of eastern Poland, and in compensation gave Poland part of eastern Germany.
The postwar German-Polish border was drawn along the Oder and Neisse Rivers and became known as the Oder-Neisse line. Poland's annexation of the former German lands east of the Oder-Neisse line led to the forced migration of several million ethnic Germans.
On June 21, the Parliaments of the two Germanys adopted matching resolutions guaranteeing that the Oder-Neisse line would remain the border, and called on the parliament of a united Germany to confirm this in a treaty. This was deemed insufficient by Warsaw.
 
An Evaporated Threat
On Monday, Mr. Baker hinted that the wartime Allies might not dissolve all their rights and responsibilities over Germany if the two German nations did not provide satisfactory assurances to Warsaw. That threat seems to have evaporated in view of today's understandings.
Mr. Baker was repeatedly asked why the Bush Administration was taken by surprise by the deal struck in Moscow Monday between Mr. Kohl and Mr. Gorbachev, and whether Washington was becoming concerned about unilateral German actions. To one such question, he responded with a circumlocution that left even diplomats scratching their heads.
Said Mr. Baker of the Kohl-Gorbachev accord: ''This is a delightful surprise to the extent that it is a surprise, and it is only a surprise to the extent that we anticipated.''

HEADLINE: Manila Puts Quake Toll at 309 as Search Continues

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Wednesday, July 18

 BODY:
Rescue workers continued to dig in piles of rubble for the dead and the living today, as Philippine officials said the earthquake on Monday had killed at least 309 people and injured at least 595.
As the Office of Civil Defense released its toll from the quake, officials here said the number of casualties was certain to rise, and President Corazon C. Aquino flew to Cabanatuan, about 60 miles north of Manila, to view the rescue efforts at the Christian College of the Philippines, the school knocked flat by the quake.
At least 30 people were thought to be trapped under the remains of the six-story school, officials said.
Before dawn this morning, two aftershocks, measured by the United States Geological Service at 6.3 and 5.8 on the Richter scale, hit the Philippines. The earthquake Monday was measured at 7.7. There was no immediate indication of whether the aftershocks caused additional casualties or damage. 
Some estimates of the number of people killed are running higher than that the confirmed casualty toll issued by the Civil Defense Office. The death toll was especially subject to increase in and around Baguio, a mountain resort 110 miles north of Manila, where the earthquake is thought to have done the most damage. As many as 1,000 people are thought to be trapped in more than 20 badly damaged buildings, including four hotels.
Rescue workers, including cadets from the nearby Philippine military academy and some American servicemen stationed at Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Base, struggled to find survivors in the collapsed buildings. But little heavy equipment was immediately available.
 
A Painfully Riveting Image
As the Philippines tried to cope with the death and debris of the earthquake, the strongest in 14 years, people kept returning in conversations today to one of those searing television images that comes to symbolize a disaster: a young boy, crushed under the concrete of his school, his arm stretched out as if to write, a ballpoint pen cradled in his lifeless fingers.
Frequent aftershocks continued, and the area remains without electricity, water or fresh food. Roads to Baguio have been cut by collapsing bridges and landslides.
Officials said that hospitals were full, and that relief teams were struggling without necessary equipment. The cries of people still trapped could be heard, according to reports from the scene, some of the victims pinned under concrete that baked in the hot afternoon sun.
In Baguio, the earthquake collapsed the front of the Hyatt Hotel into the lobby, killing at least 50 people, officials said, and ruptured the Nevada Hotel almost down the middle.
The United States Agency for International Development was holding a seminar at the Nevada Hotel at the time with representatives of volunteer organizations. The agency's acting executive director, William Wallamaker, said one American was still unaccounted for, but would not release his name. Several Filipinos working for the agency were also missing, he said.
 
Help From U.S. and Others
An American recreational facility in Baguio, Camp John Hay, escaped damage, officials said.
The United States made immediate relief contributions of $25,000 and nearly 2,000 pounds of medical equipment and supplies, plus tents and clothing, from stores kept at the big American bases, Clark and Subic Bay.
Teams of civil engineers, Navy Seabees construction teams, search dogs, doctors and two portable hospitals with operating rooms were also flown from the American bases to Cabanatuan and Baguio cities. Some of the wounded were being moved to hospitals at Clark and John Hay. Japan provided an eight-member medical team, Philippine officials said, and offers of help also came from Thailand, Canada, Switzerland and South Korea.
The United States Embassy spokesman, Stanley Schrager, emphasized that American aid had nothing to do with pending negotiations, scheduled for late next month, on the future of the American military installations here.
President Aquino's spokesman, Tomas Gomez, said both Japan and the United States had offered whatever help might be needed.
The epicenter of the quake was about 60 miles north of Manila. Other areas badly hit included Dagupan, 100 miles north of Manila. In the capital, life had returned to normal on Tuesday after the quake caused electricity to fail, buildings to sway and crack, and traffic lights to go out on Monday.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Hijacker Sent Back to Moscow, With a Message

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 17

 BODY:
A Soviet teen-ager who forced a passenger plane to go to Sweden last month because he was fed up with life in the Soviet Union was returned to Moscow today. Soviet officials hailed his extradition as a breakthrough in this country's struggle against a remarkable epidemic of hijackings.
The youth, Dmitri Semyonov, 17 years old, was the first hijacker ever extradited to the Soviet Union from Sweden, which like many countries has tended to assume that those fleeing this country were in some measure political refugees.
Boris Ryzhenkov, a Civil Aviation Ministry official responsible for international agreements, said Sweden's decision to send Mr. Semyonov home even though the countries have no extradition treaty would be an important message to others contemplating his example. 
''In the 1960's, when there was a wave of hijackings of American planes to Cuba, what stopped it was that Cuba and the United States signed an extradition agreement,'' Mr. Ryzhenkov said in an interview. ''Extradition of the criminals is by far the most effective measure.''
 
Wields Fake Grenade
Brandishing a fake grenade, Mr. Semyonov diverted the Aeroflot flight to Stockholm on June 9. There were 121 passengers aboard, bound from Minsk, in Soviet Byelorussia, to Murmansk, in the far north. He told interviewers in Sweden that he hijacked the plane out of frustration after his parents had kicked him out of the house.
It was the beginning of one of the worst rashes of hijacking in the history of aviation. Most of the attempts were by young men seeking to escape the draft or flee economic frustration. Ten more hijackings have been tried since then, six successfully, inspiring much black humor about Aeroflot and an official campaign to beef up airport security.
''This is all connected with the complicated economic and political situation,'' said Valery A. Kondratyev, deputy chief of security for the Aviation Ministry. ''Most of these cases were young men who could not find their place in society and decided that they would be better off settling and organizing new lives abroad.''
The hijacking wave comes when freedom of travel has expanded enormously and a new law pending in the Parliament would remove most legal barriers to emigration.
 
'People Are Impatient'
But enactment of the law has been delayed, and even when it comes into force, departure from the country will be complicated by shortages of foreign currency and long waits for airline seats.
''Young people are impatient,'' Mr. Kondratyev said. ''We cannot have passengers endangered because of the whim of someone who wants to drink beer in Finland. Everyone wants a better life, but you have to come by it legally.''
In no case was the hijacker armed, but Soviet officials said passengers faced a different danger: most Soviet crews flying domestic routes are not trained or equipped to land at foreign airports.
''We've had two cases where the planes landed only due to sheer luck,'' said Mr. Ryzhenkov, noting that Soviet crews generally do not speak English, the language of international air traffic, or have the communications devices necessary for landing at busy Western airports.
 
Beefing Up Security
When a 19-year-old Leningrad draft evader diverted a plane to Stockholm last month, the Swedes had to send two military planes to escort it to the ground.
In the wake of the recent hijackings, Soviet officials have announced moves to shore up the security system by putting conspicuous armed patrols at many airports and plainclothes marshals on selected flights. They have also ordering more intense passenger screening.
In the past, Soviet airline security has consisted mainly of issuing firearms to the commanders of all civilian aircraft and installing outdated X-ray machines monitored by attendants who often seem to be busy dozing or gossiping.
But officials say nothing is as effective in fighting hijacking as the assurance that the offender will be sent home to be tried. Hijacking in the Soviet Union brings imprisonment of up to 10 years.
Soviet officials said Sweden's decision to extradite Mr. Semyonov raised strong hopes that two other recent hijackers still in Swedish custody would be sent home to stand trial. Another two hijackers are in Finland, which has an extradition treaty with the Soviet Union, and one is in Turkey, which has no treaty.
Sweden has preferred in the past to try Soviet hijackers in Sweden and allow them to stay after they have served their sentences.
''We understand that at the time the situation was different, the reaction to our requests was cooler,'' Mr. Ryzhenkov said. ''There was a political aspect that gave rise to hesitation.''
Mr. Semyonov, the hijacker sent home today, was shown on the evening television news disembarking at a Moscow airport and penitently advising others not to follow his example.
''Several rides in a Volvo and tasty lunches are not worth the punishment I will receive under Soviet law,'' the handcuffed youth told reporters before being whisked off for questioning by the K.G.B.

HEADLINE: Young Gains Berth in a Runoff To Run for Governor of Georgia

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 17

 BODY:
Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia finished first today in the Democratic primary but was forced into a runoff next month with Andrew Young, the former Mayor of Atlanta who is seeking to become the state's first black governor.
Mr Miller led the five-man race, 41 to 29 percent with about three-fourths of the precincts counted.
In the Republican primary, Johnny Isakson, a Republican State Senator from the suburbs of Atlanta, declared victory and appeared to have won more than enough votes to avoid a runoff. Mr. Isakson, a 45-year-old real estate executive had about 70 percent of the vote. 
 
Tight Race for Second Place
Mr. Miller, 58, had been widely expected to finish first in the Democratic primary. Mr. Young, also 58, was in a tight race for second place with State Senator Roy Barnes, who said he would bring conservative Democrats back into the party's fold. Mr. Barnes had 21 percent of the vote.
Trailing well behind were State Representative Lauren (Bubba) McDonald and Lester Maddox, the former Democratic Governor who was a champion of segregation in the 1970's.
With the first primary all but over, Mr. Miller said voters in the Aug. 7 runoff would now have a choice between him and Mr. Young, both of whom have long records of service in elective office.
''I think our respective records will be an issue,'' he said. ''I know Andy Young is going to look at my record, and I will be looking at his.''
The early returns represented the voting from rural areas, and Mr. Young began building his lead over Mr. Barnes when vote tallies come in from heavily black urban areas.
 
Legal Challenge to Runoff
Today's primary had been under the cloud of a legal challenge of the state election laws. State Representative Tyrone Brooks, with the help of lawyers from the American Civil Liberties Union, sought an injunction to bar runoff elections, which are held when no candidate receives 51 percent of the vote.
Mr. Brooks had contended that the provision discriminated against black voters and black candidates. He said the system invariably favored white candidates because in a runoff, they are more likely to attract supporters of their former white opponents.
The primary campaign was largely devoid of tough issues, dominant personalities or any other sparks to heighten voter interest.
Mr. Miller, who has outspent all other candidates, called for a lottery to finance educational programs and advocated Marine-style boot camps for first-time drug offenders.
Though he built his national reputation as an advocate of civil rights and human rights, in this campaign Mr. Young has stressed his record on economic development as Mayor of Atlanta. He is also the most outspoken advocate of abortion rights in the race.
But Mr. Young's candidacy has not created the air of expectancy that many believed it would.
''This election just failed to catch fire,'' said Ed Brown, director of the Voter Education Project, a nonprofit group here that analyzes voting patterns among blacks. ''It seems that the candidates did not work hard to distinguish themselves, and so there was no real clear definition of any one candidate. Part of that was wanting to avoid negative campaigning, but it was mainly the tendency of candidates today to try to find the lowest common denominator.''

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
The President's English

 BODY:
President Bush greeted fellow summiteers at their meeting in Houston last week with a ringing but ungrammatical declaration that ''a new world of freedom lays before us.'' The major wire services and most newspapers - The A.P., U.P.I., Reuters, The Washington Post, Newsday and The New York Times, among others - reported it verbatim. But ''lays'' (incorrect) became ''lies'' (correct) in some other papers, including The Los Angeles Times, The Christian Science Monitor, The Washington Times and even Japan's Kyodo News Service.
It's a common problem for editors, whether to clean up a speaker's mistakes or leave them as spoken. When corrections are made, strict grammarians might hope that the speaker notices and maybe even appreciates the effort.
Not Mr. Bush. One day after he misused ''lays'' he flubbed again, with a vengeance. Presiding at dinner at Houston's Museum of Fine Arts, he greeted his guests anew: ''There is no work here tonight - no communiques, no amendments, no language to be corrected. We want you to have a very good time in this museum that we are very proudful of.'' Proudful. As in, before a fall.

HEADLINE: Head of Javits Center Says Major Expansion Is Needed

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
Barely four years after its completion, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center needs to expand by as much as a third - 600,000 square feet - to remain competitive and to attract the nation's largest trade shows, the acting president of the center says.
Sol C. Chaikin, acting president and chairman of the Convention Center Operating Corporation, said in an interview that there were 14 large trade shows that the center could not handle and that centers in Las Vegas, Chicago and Atlanta had expanded or were about to undergo expansions that would make them larger than the Javits Center.
With the trade-show industry having grown at a rate of 7 percent a year in the 80's, 43 cities are building centers or expanding existing ones, said Darlene Gudea, editor and publisher of Tradeshow Week, a publication for the industry. Ms. Gudea said that last year 3.6 million square feet of exhibition space arrived on the market.
That has led at least one analyst to question whether it would be wise for New York or another city to undertake an expansion, particularly amid some uncertainty about whether the industry will continue to grow at a strong pace. 
The first call for expansion in New York was made in 1984 by Thomas F. Galvin, who was president of the Javits Center, even as the huge glass-paneled building was scrambling toward completion after what turned out to be nearly two years of delay and more than $100 million in overruns. Mr. Galvin saw a need for a 750,000-square-foot addition to the center, which with its high ceilings, several levels and 1.8 million square feet has the breadth of an airplane hangar and stretches from 34th to 38th Street between 11th and 12th Avenues. That much space would be the equivalent of five city blocks. The Cuomo administration rejected the request as premature; the center was not open, and it was badgered by controversy and red ink.
''Personally I thought it would be foolhardy after our first or second year to say we need another 300,000 or 400,000 square feet,'' Mr. Chaikin said last week. ''It just wasn't propitious. Now I think we will present a pretty strong argument for expansion.''
The proposal would have to be endorsed by the board of the Operating Corporation, a majority of whose members are appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Mr. Chaikin said he would make a presentation to the board in September or October.
The financing, which could easily surpass $100 million for a relatively modest addition, would presumably have to be in some form from the state, which spearheaded the original construction, or possibly the city, which co-sponsored a study five years ago that anticipated a probable need for expansion at some point.
A spokesman for the Governor, Gary G. Fryer, said the administration viewed the center as a success, but would have no position on an expansion until it had analyzed whatever proposal was submitted.
Mr. Chaikin, as chairman of the Operating Corporation, has been an important figure at the center for seven years. For the last year he has also been acting president. But Mr. Cuomo is expected to recommend shortly that his longtime adviser, Fabian G. Palomino, be named president.
Mr. Chaikin said the city and state should also consider building a parking lot next to the center and perhaps moderate-income housing nearby.
 
Comparisons With Expectations
The architecturally striking center, completed amid great controversy in April 1986, is still among the four largest centers in the country. Long a topic of argument, the center appears by many measures to have surpassed the expectations for it in the Environmental Impact Statement published before the Legislature approved the construction in 1979.
The statement predicted that the center would operate 220 days a year and be host to 69 to 78 trade shows, conventions and public shows. Javits officials said that the center was host to 92 trade shows and conventions in the fiscal year ending in March and that counting the days to set up and take down shows, which the organizers pay for, the center was active roughly 300 days.
The officials said that 2.8 million people visited the center in the 1989 fiscal year, compared with 1.75 million anticipated in the environmental statement and that in figures that are harder to measure the visitors directly or indirectly accounted for $6 billion in spending and $500 million in taxes last year.
After years of sizable operating deficits, the center ran close to break even last year and will not receive a state subsidy this year, although the impact statement had anticipated continuing subsidies, officials said. Mr. Chaikin said he expected that the center would meet its $486.2 million budget.
The center is enmeshed in eight suits involving contractors. It is suing one company for $50 million and is being sued by seven for a total of $60 million, according to a statement for a recent bond offering. The general counsel of the center, Morris Dershowitz, said he expected the suits to be settled eventually for far smaller amounts.
 
Across 34th Street
Mr. Chaikin said an expansion should at a minimum provide 250,000 to 400,000 additional square feet of exhibition space. The ideal place for expansion would be a 150,000-square-foot block across 34th Street between 11th and 12th Avenues that the center owns and is mostly used to park trucks, Mr. Chaikin said. Because there are train tracks on the site, the plan would need special approval, and the addition might have to be built on a platform.
A tunnel or bridge could link the addition to the center.
The size and design of the addition would determine its cost. If the current design was used, a 300,000-square-foot expansion would be likely to cost well in excess of $100 million, and an extension would probably take three years to build after being approved, Mr. Chaikin added.
Chris Yoshii, a senior associate with Economics Research Associatese of San Francisco, a real-estate consulting business specializing in public and recreational projects, cautioned that although the largest trade shows were still growing, the number of trade events and the number of attendees had flattened.
As a result, he said, the economic ripple effect, which was used to help justify building the Javits Center and others, is not as potent as it once was.
''Should New York spend hundreds of millions to expand its center for a fairly marginal increase in economic impact?'' Mr. Yoshii asked. ''You have to look at it much more carefully than you did 10 years ago. You have to ask yourself at what point to cut off the spending.''
Convention officials said that there were many shows that routinely bypassed New York because of the need for large spaces and that there were several others that would likely expand soon beyond the capacity of the Javits Center.
Mr. Chaikin said complaints over costly parking that can be as far as five blocks from the center could be solved by building a publicly controlled garage on the site of an old slaughterhouse owned by the city at 39th Street and 11th Avenue. The planners of the center specifically did not recommend that because they anticipated opposition from neighbors and environmentalists. Subsidized housing, Mr. Chaikin said, could turn the often deolate area around the center into a neighborhood.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Eastern Europeans Lack Money to Study in West

 BODY:
Thousands of Eastern European students, eager to sample the educational offerings of the West, are seeking to matriculate at American universities, according to the United States Information Agency.
In Czechoslovakia alone, 2,500 students called, wrote or lined up at the American Embassy in Prague in December, January and February to get university addresses and materials on admissions procedures, said Adeline O'Connell, a U.S.I.A. education official. Before the fall of Czechoslovakia's Communist Government, only 75 students inquired in an average three-month period about American schools.
But American college officials say they have little financial aid to offer Eastern European applicants, who are largely poor and whose money is worth little outside their countries. 
''We don't anticipate large numbers of them being able to study here until some funding is made available for them,'' said Richard Tudisco, director of the international student office at Columbia University.
 
Travel Was Limited
The Communist governments of Eastern Europe limited their citizens' opportunities to travel and study abroad. In the 1989-90 school year, 2,850 Eastern Europeans attended American universities, said Peggy Blumenthal, a vice president of the Institute of International Education, a private organization that administers exchange programs for foreign students.
Almost all those students -from Yugoslavia, Poland, Hungary, Romania, Czechoslovakia and East Germany - were researchers with advanced degrees or were on short-term exchanges.
Now, a growing number of Eastern Europeans want to apply directly to American institutions, said Ms. O'Connell, whose agency disseminates materials on American schools to other nations.
John F. Reichard, executive vice president of the National Association for Foreign Student Affairs, a professional organization of international educators, said the students were eager to taste the freedoms of the West, to hone their skills in their fields, and eventually to use their knowledge to help their countries.
 
In Their Own Words
Zdenek Kratochvil, a student at Technical University of Prague, said he wanted to learn a Western approach to engineering and management at an American university. ''After 40 years of a command system, people know nothing of a market system here,'' said Mr. Kratochvil, who dreams of starting a business in Czechoslovakia with the assistance of a Western company.
Karoly Csete, a concierge at the Hilton Hotel in Budapest, is trying to enroll his two teen-age children in an American high school, hoping they will move on to college. The children, Judit, 16 years old, and Akos, 14, spent a year in school in Morris County, N.J., two years ago, when they stayed with Mr. Csete's sister.
''I would like to help them with their future,'' Mr. Csete said. ''This way, if they decide to leave this country, then they will have already made the first step.''
In response to student demand, the U.S.I.A. is supplementing its small advisory staffs and university-related reference materials in its Eastern European offices. In Hungary, the agency has established new information booths at the Szabo Erwin Public Library in Budapest and on five university campuses, Ms. O'Connell said. At the booths, advisers trained by the agency guide students through microfiche collections of college catalogues and point them toward books that evaluate American universities.
 
Ministries Get Information
The agency also plans to open an educational exchange office in Poland and has given reference books on American colleges to education ministries in Czechoslovakia.
Agency officials stress that American higher education is expensive and that the schools, trying hard to find financial aid for American students, have few resources to offer foreign applicants.
Robin Lewis, associate dean of the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia, says American universities have had little time to devise ways to help Eastern European students. ''The events in Eastern Europe happened so fast that nothing is really in place, except Band-Aid measures,'' he said.
Indeed, though Mr. Kratochvil has compiled a list of schools he plans to apply to, he knows that little financial aid is available. ''You can't pay for studies there, and you can't get a scholarship,'' he said.
 
Some Aid From Congress
Last November, Congress approved $10 million in scholarships over three years for Polish and Hungarian students who want to study in the United States, said Jonathan Stein, chief foreign policy adviser to Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat who sponsored the bill. But Mr. Stein conceded that it was ''not very much'' - enough to assist only 350 to 450 students on short-term stays. He said Congress was discussing additional legislation to assist other Eastern European students.
One promising opening is Harvard, which does not limit the amount spent on foreign students, said William Fitzsimmons, dean of admissions and financial aid. Mr. Fitzsimmons said the university was relying on alumni in Eastern Europe to tell potential students of Harvard's eagerness to admit more Eastern Europeans.
''It's one thing for our students to read about what's going on in East Germany,'' Mr. Fitzsimmons said, ''but it's another thing to go to classes with someone who has lived through it.''
Other than Harvard and a few other schools with large endowments, most universities will have difficulty finding additional financial aid for Eastern European students. It is a case, some educators say, of economics taking priority over idealism.
''It sounds like it's enterprise and commerce rather than education,'' said Mr. Reichard, of the National Association for Foreign Student Affairs, ''but in part it's reality.''
