SECTION: Section C; Page 11, Column 4; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1670 words

HEADLINE: Subsidies for Artists: Is Denying a Grant Really Censorship?

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Visitors to the benefit performance staged the other night for the Franklin Furnace, an avant-garde performance space in the TriBeCa section of Manhattan, heard angry protesters warn against what they perceived as Government censorship of the arts.
''We are in a dead-end totalitarian ecological trap,'' the poet Allen Ginsberg said in a telephone call to the benefit, which was held at the Public Theater. The painter Nancy Spero took the stage and said, ''Little by little our rights are being taken away.'' Earlier in the day, Karen Finley, one of several solo performance artists turned down for grants by the beleaguered National Endowment for the Arts this year, told a press conference, ''A year ago I was in a country of free expression; now I am not.''
That night, performing along with Eric Bogosian, Annie Sprinkle, Reno and others at the Franklin Furnace benefit, Ms. Finley chanted a poem in which she talked about how ''they'' -meaning the enemies of free expression - were ripping off her body parts, tearing out her tongue, cutting off her feet, gouging out her heart. 
Is there truth to the charges being made by Ms. Finley and many others these days that ''censorship'' and ''repression'' are taking place?
The charge comes out of the campaign against the endowment being led by conservative and religious groups and their backers in Congress, notably Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Representative Dana Rohrabacher, Republican of California, who have complained that the endowment has supported artists whose work they deemed to be harmful or obscene.
 
New Cutbacks Feared
When the endowment chairman, John E. Frohnmayer, apparently bowing to conservative pressures, vetoed grants that would otherwise have been given to several controversial performers, including Ms. Finley, many artists and others saw the move not only as censorship but also as a precursor of further efforts to stamp out other expression that the conservatives find disagreeable.
But while it is easy to understand why individuals like Ms. Finley might be angry and upset, are their claims of censorship accurate? And beyond that, are they correct in assessing a new censorious mood in the air, an atmosphere of repression?
It would seem to be one thing to deny some artists Federal funds on the ground that what they do is offensive to some taxpayers, and another to deprive them of their freedom of expression. Ms. Finley, for example, who often performs nude and symbolically defaces her body as a way of protesting the treatment of women in male-dominated society, is scheduled to present two virtually sold-out shows at Lincoln Center's Serious Fun Festival in a few days, so she has hardly been silenced.
Opponents of the arts endowment have asserted over and over that their sole concern is Government subsidies of art that they find morally offensive; there is nothing stopping people from performing whatever they want to perform, they say, as long as it does not come at taxpayers' expense.
 
'Simply Ridiculous'
''The truth is that artists in this country today enjoy a greater degree of freedom of expression than artists have enjoyed in any known civilization in the past, and to confuse the rejection of a grant application with some kind of categorical threat to freedom of expression is simply ridiculous,'' Hilton Kramer, editor of The New Criterion, a magazine of cultural criticism, said in a telephone interview.
Many clearly feel differently about the matter.
''There's no genuine repression yet, but there are little brush fires that are happening at the same time,'' Joseph Papp, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Papp mentioned as important parts of a larger pattern the prosecution in Florida of the rap group the 2 Live Crew on obscenity charges and the indictment of the director of the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati for mounting an exhibition of the works of the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, one of the artists whose work has been under attack by conservative groups.
''It's a serious thing when people are arrested and charged,'' Mr. Papp said. ''This is where the weather vane could be pointing.''
In many ways, the debate concerns some basic questions regarding Government support of the arts. What exactly is censorship in a country where freedom is more than theoretical but where the Government over the last quarter of a century has become a supporter of many kinds of artistic activity, including some experimental forms like performance art?
''Once you get Government involved in the arts, then withholding money has a kind of punitive effect,'' the novelist John Updike said in a telephone interview. ''So in this manner I can see a certain number of our artists being shaped to please our Government, to please Jesse Helms. A kind of insidious Government control could be exerted.''
 
The Focus: Motives
Here, to a great extent, the debate centers on motives. Defenders of Mr. Frohnmayer's right to deny grants, even grants recommended by the endowment's peer review panels, see not censorship, but a clash of two sincerely held points of view - the artists on one side and conservative groups on the other.
Jacob Neusner, a professor of Jewish history at Southern Florida University who is a member of the endowment's main advisory committee, the National Council on the Arts, cites the ''profoundly symbolic'' nature of Federal support. ''This is the Government saying, 'We approve or disapprove a certain kind of art,' '' he said in a telephone interview.
''I don't think anybody has told artists what they may or may not do,'' Mr. Neusner added. ''What they've been told is that an advisory council and an endowment chairman do not want to support their art.''
The issue of motives can be seen in the fears of some that the anti-endowment forces have broader goals than they have stated. These supporters of subsidies think that the success of conservatives in changing the way the endowment functions and forcing it in essence to take money away from controversial artists reflects a political power held by these groups that they will continue to use, whether taxpayers' money is involved or not.
Martha Wilson, the director of Franklin Furnace, said that the General Accounting Office, acting on a demand by Senator Helms, had asked to examine her records. The G.A.O. wants to see when and how often four specific artists have performed at Franklin Furnace, she said, citing the move as an illustration of what she sees as a growing atmosphere of repression.
 
The 'Wrong' Stuff
The four artists - Ms. Finley, Serri Gaulke, Frank Moore and Johanna Went - are all described by Ms. Wilson as artists who ''use nudity, religious imagery, bodily fluids and references to sex and violence, all the stuff that's supposed to be wrong.''
''They're trying to starve organizations and artists that have unwanted ideas,'' Ms. Wilson said.
The debate over whether censorship is taking place has intensified as the issue of whether to extend the life of the endowment or eliminate it altogether, along with all Federal aid to the arts, is scheduled to come before Congress in the days ahead. Both the House and the Senate are considering bills that would continue the agency without any of the restrictions on artistic content that have been demanded by conservatives. In recent weeks, however, individual Congressmen have expressed little confidence that the legislation will pass without bans on some of the programs supported by the agency in the past.
Another issue in the debate concerns whether public money should as a matter of right go to artists whose goal is to shock and disturb the public, to attack its conventions and assumptions, to disturb it.
''It's now regarded as an entitlement,'' Mr. Kramer of The New Criterion said of Government support of the arts. ''It's precisely the idea that if you received a grant in the past, you have an entitlement to it in the future.'' Mr. Kramer said that members of the avant-garde were behaving like officially approved academic artists of decades past in Europe in looking to the Government for support. At its origins in Europe, Mr. Kramer said, the avant-garde was a rebellion against the state-supported artistic establishment.
 
The Fringe in Europe
Indeed, it seems undeniable that the fringe movements of the past -the ''Independents'' in France and the ''secessionists'' in Central Europe, both of which were essential to the formation of the concept of artistic experimentation - flourished in part because they rejected the state-supported establishment.
Those who advocate endowment grants to avant-garde artists say that times have changed. Once the Government decides to give money for the arts, they maintain, avant-garde artists are as entitled to it as anybody else, and to deny it to them because they express themselves strongly or unconventionally is a form of censorship.
''These artists are saying, 'We're part of the culture too,' '' Ms. Wilson of Franklin Furnace said.
Moreover, these advocates say, the ability of conservative groups to pressure the endowment into denying grants it would otherwise have approved will have a chilling effect on the willingness of artists to be bold or different. Denying grants to the boldest and most outrageous of artists does not limit their freedom of expression, they argue, but, given the economic precariousness of life on the artistic fringes, it will have the practical effect of censorship.
Wendy W. Luers, a member of the National Council on the Arts, the endowment's governing board, said: ''In and of itself, not granting taxpayers' money cannot broadly be called censorship, but it is only a beginning and a clear beginning. This is because the private sector uses the imprimatur of the N.E.A. to determine how they give. If the N.E.A. decides not to give to a certain kind of art, then the private sector is going to follow suit.''

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (90%);

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (90%);

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Soldier Who Supported New Deal Social Change

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

General of the Army
George C. Marshall, Soldier and Statesman
By Ed Cray
847 pages. Illustrated. W. W. Norton. $35.
In the early 1930's, Lieut. Col. George C. Marshall helped to set up dozens of Civilian Conservation Corps camps for the unemployed, one of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's pioneering New Deal programs intended to pull the country out of the Depression. The Labor Department recruited the volunteers, the Agriculture and Interior Departments supervised the actual work and the Army trained them. They planted millions of trees for soil conservation, built fire breaks, cleaned streams and beaches, constructed small reservoirs and dams, refurbished roads, bridges and trails in national parks. 
Marshall threw himself into the work enthusiastically. He publicly praised the C.C.C., saying that it was ''the greatest social experiment outside of Russia.'' He found the experience personally rewarding because he saw malnourished, often sullen young men regain confidence and health, enter remedial educational programs and, at the same time, help to rebuild the country. But always the professional soldier, he also considered the corps ''a splendid experience for the War Department and the Army.''
His C.C.C. background and enthusiasm for a socially oriented New Deal program are among the facts about George C. Marshall's career that come to light in Ed Cray's ''General of the Army,'' a solid and readable biography that goes well beyond Marshall's familiar role as Army chief of staff during World War II and architect of the European Recovery Program, a plan that became known by his name and won him the Nobel Peace Prize in 1953.
Mr. Cray's book is also valuable as a survey of a large chunk of 20th-century history. The future five-star general served with the American Expeditionary Forces in France during World War I; he helped direct the buildup of the armed forces under Roosevelt's direction; as Ambassador to China, he negotiated a military truce for President Harry S. Truman between the Communists and the Kuomintang; then, as Secretary of State, he developed the Marshall Plan.
On the eve of World War II, 33 generals outranked Marshall, who was a brigadier general, but Roosevelt jumped over them and selected him to be the Army's chief of staff. Their respect for each other's strengths grew during the war. As chief of staff, Marshall also chose talent over seniority when it came to promotions, most famously in his choice of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to lead the American forces in the invasion of North Africa and then as the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe. It was a role Marshall coveted for himself, but running a worldwide war in the European, Pacific and China-Burma-India theaters made him too important in Washington.
On the most controversial decision of World War II, dropping the atomic bomb on Japan, Mr. Cray writes that the chief of staff was ''plainly disturbed.'' On purely military grounds, he favored use of the nuclear weapon to shorten the war, but at the same time recognized what he called ''primordial considerations.'' He told John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, ''Don't ask me to make that decision.''
Marshall said he thought the A-bomb should first be used against a straight military objective, like a naval installation, and then perhaps against a large manufacturing area from which the people would be forewarned to leave. In the end, he went along with Truman and other military and civilian decisionmakers. But the fact that he hesitated and sought alternatives reveals as much as anything in this biography about Marshall's decency and vision.
Many political incidents are recalled in the book. Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, who gave his name to one of the worst American isms of modern times, accused Secretary of State Marshall of harboring Communists and branded him a traitor. The author also writes of the dismissal of Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur for insubordination during the Korean War while Marshall briefly served as Secretary of Defense. Marshall urged caution, believing dismissal would encourage the political right in the country, but then agreed with Truman and the Joint Chiefs of Staff that MacArthur had disobeyed their orders and undermined peace efforts.
In his well-researched book, Mr. Cray notes that Senator Richard M. Nixon of California said, ''The happiest group in the country over General MacArthur's removal will be the Communists and their stooges.'' Afterward, and to this day, Marshall's stature soared while his political adversaries stumbled in public esteem.
What made George Catlett Marshall, a military man all his life, develop into a civilian statesman? Truman said he was the greatest living American. Discussing his role in World War II, Winston S. Churchill called him the greatest Roman of them all.
In ''General of the Army,'' the author sings Marshall's praises, too, but like previous biographers he finds it difficult to explain the why of the personality behind the austere facade. Still, it is hard to disagree with his interpretation of Marshall as an idealist, with a pragmatic recognition of geopolitical realities: ''Two world wars - he had fought in one and led the second -had served to tamp down the idealism, but never quite extinguish it.''

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Increases Modestly

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit rose modestly in May, to $7.73 billion, fueled by the economy's heavy reliance on oil imports and foreign automobiles, the Commerce Department reported today.
Analysts and economists said, however, that the deficit, up 5.8 percent from a revised April figure of $7.31 billion, also showed a healthy growth in exports, particularly in manufactured goods.
''Export growth is keeping us out of a recession,'' said Stephen Cooney, director of international investment at the National Association of Manufacturers, an industry group based in Washington. ''As domestic growth continues, imports will also continue to grow, though slower than exports.'' 
 
Oil Imports Show Jump
Exports rose 2.3 percent from April, to $32.79 billion, their second-best showing since March, when they totaled $33.27 billion. But the gain in May was offset by a 2.9 percent increase in imports, to $40.52 billion. That increase came primarily from a precipitous jump in oil imports.
The figures also reflected a significant decrease in May of imports from Japan and a large increase in imports from Canada.
Bush Administration officials said the latest figures were evidence that the nation's trade performance would continue to improve through the end of the year. ''While month-to-month figures can swing significantly, the deficit for the first five months of 1990 is almost $6 billion less than last year,'' Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said. ''We see strong improvements with all the non-oil-producing market economies.''
The growth in exports reflected greater shipments in a wide array of items, including automotive parts, capital goods and consumer products.
But some analysts continue to voice concern that the nation's growing reliance on foreign oil could cut into any expansion in exports. Oil imports rose 15.2 percent in May, to $4.32 billion. Since the beginning of the year, oil imports have risen 21 percent, at $23.39 billion, over the comparable period in 1989.
The May increase in the consumption of foreign oil was encouraged by a declining price per barrel of $1, to $15.57. The volume of shipments rose to 8.95 million barrels a day, up from 7.55 million barrels in April.
Shipments of imported cars were up 5.2 percent in May, to $3.88 billion, largely from Canada and other countries, while imports from Japan fell by $854 million, to $6.7 billion.
The figures reflected a decline in imports from Japan of cars, telecommunications equipment and consumer items and resulted in the lowest monthly trade deficit with Japan since January, when the United States posted a deficit of $2.85 billion.
More than 40 percent of the total trade deficit in May was with Japan, but the imbalance between the two nations shrank by more than $1 billion, to $2.96 billion, from a revised April figure of $3.95 billion. The declining imbalance with Japan was due to a modest rise in exports and a substantial drop in imports.
Over the first five months of this year, the trade deficit, on a seasonally adjusted basis, dropped to $40.7 billion from the $46.4 billion in the comparable 1989 period and $49.8 billion in 1988, according to Commerce Department calculations. At the current rate, the 1990 deficit would be almost $98 billion, down from the $109.4 billion imbalance last year.
The trade balance with the United States' largest trading partner, Canada, moved from a surplus in April of $42 million to a deficit in May of $564 million. The change was fueled by a $1.15 billion rise in imports from Canada.
The United States continued to record a surplus with the European Community in May, although the surplus shrank in May to $811 million, from $1.43 billion in April, largely because of a decline in exports.
A surplus of $69 million was also posted in May with Mexico, compared with a deficit in April of $143 million. The two nations have agreed to negotiate a free-trade pact.
With China, the deficit widened from $614 million to $777 million.

HEADLINE: Savings Crime Bill Is Proposed

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Democrats in the House of Representatives will propose a savings and loan enforcement package on Wednesday that will include a bipartisan national commission to examine the roots of one the nation's worst financial crisis as well as new legal weapons to fight crime in the savings and loan industry, Congressional aides said today.
Absent from the package, an amalgam of Democratic and Republican recommendations, are some of the far-reaching proposals tossed up in recent days as Democrats and Republicans hammered at each other in a heated debate over the blame for the crisis. The Democrats are apparently trying to incorporate Republican suggestions to achieve some cooperation to increase the chances for passage of the legislation.
 
Serious, Not Partisan
''We are trying to find out in a serious and not partisan way what really happened, and if Government is doing all it can to prevent it from happening again,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of a House Judiciary subcomittee that is preparing the savings and loan legislation. 
Some of the most hotly debated Democratic suggestions, like measures to reorganize the Justice Department to create a financial crimes division and a plan to enlist the Secret Service in the savings and loan investigations, were omitted.
Some proposals, like the commission, were originally suggested in slightly different forms by Republicans. Chalmers P. Wylie, an Ohio Republican who brought the commission idea forward, said, ''I think the political rhetoric can be laid aside, if it's not reported out just as a Democratic proposal.''
 
To Uncover Crimes
Mr. Schumer, who declined to discuss the details of the package, said the bill was intended to ''make sure that those who committed crimes can't conceal them and keep their misgotten gains.''
Several specific provisions are intended to give prosecutors and bank regulators broader enforcement powers in future cases. Among them are measures that make it a crime for the accountants of savings and loan associations to fail to report instances of wrongdoing; that increase criminal penalties against savings and loan officials who provide false information to bank examiners, and that allow bank regulators to nullify ''golden parachute'' payments to departing executives of failing savings units.
The legislation, to be attached to a crime bill under consideration in the House, differs in some important respects from the Senate's savings and loan package, which passed last week in a 99-to-1 vote.
The Senate bill, for example, does not provide for the 12-member financial crimes commission, which would be empowered to request documents from the Administration and question witnesses under oath. Under the proposal, the Administration, the House and the Senate would each appoint four members to the panel.
The Bush Administration has opposed any such commission as an unncessary duplication. ''It would potentially restrict our flexibility and micromanage the Administration's investigative and prosecutive responsibilities,'' an Administration official said today.
 
Like the Warren Commission
As envisioned by members of Congress, the commission would operate like the Warren Commission, which investigated the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. But in addition to assessing the savings and loan debacle, the financial crimes commission would monitor current efforts of bank regulators and prosecutors, as well as recommend changes in laws, regulations or procedures.
The House package would also authorize a doubling of the annual spending for additional Federal investigators and prosecutors from $75 million to $150 million, and could go higher than that, aides said. The Senate approved $162.5 million for additional personnel. The Administration has proposed spending $100 million, but Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has said the Justice Department could use additional funds without specifying an exact amount.
The Senate's savings and loan package includes several provisions stiffening prison sentences and closing loopholes against financial fraud. The Senate package would increase the maximum penalty for bank fraud to 30 years and permit life imprisonment for people who are convicted of defrauding savings institutions of large sums of money.
House Democrats are racing against the Congressional calendar to complete the legislation. The Judiciary Committee is expected to complete action on the package by the end of the week, hoping for a vote on the legislation before the adjournment late this month or early next month. Some members have said they hope to present President Bush with a bill by mid-August.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes Import Curbs On Apparel but Veto Looms

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
The Senate, by a vote of 68 to 32, approved legislation today to curb imports of textiles and apparel.
But two similar efforts to legislate quotas in the last five years failed when President Ronald Reagan vetoed them and the vetoes were sustained. The Bush Administration has signaled its own veto intentions, leading many analysts to predict the same fate for the Textile, Apparel and Footwear Trade Act of 1990.
The analysts saw today's action as a way for Senators to show support for the domestic mills and labor unions that have been lobbying hard for the bill without fear of broader consequences, since expectations of enactment are low. 
Also working against the bill's chances is a crack in the once solid coalition that had supported textile quota bills in the past.
An apparel trade association representing two-thirds of domestic production, the American Apparel Manufacturers Association, announced it was not supporting the bill. Nor is it opposing it.
''Our people simply felt that in global trade talks now under way the Administration is moving in a direction that they could accept,'' said Stewart Boswell, the association's president.
He characterized the group as being ''on the sidelines,'' and said it wanted to ''see more clearly what emerged from the Uruguay Round'' of trade liberalization talks being held among 106 nations before taking a position.
Linda J. Wachner, president and chief executive of Warnaco Inc., a big apparel maker, said that ''a lot of people have to import fabrics that are innovative and that are not available in the U.S., such as yarn-died cotton for fine-count cotton and blended shirts.''
She said the bill would ''hurt the availability of innovative consumer products that Warnaco manufactures offshore and onshore.''
But backers of the measure, which would limit the annual import growth of textiles to 1 percent and would freeze imports of nonrubber footwear at 1989 levels, described it as essential for the survival of the industry.
''If at the end of the century we have no textile industry left,'' said Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, ''don't blame it on the loss of productivity of our workers. Blame it on the lack of political productivity in this country.'' In Mr. Hollings's state, one out of seven people work in textile-related industries.
Opponents, chiefly from more export-oriented regions like the Northwest, warned that the bill would force consumers to pay billions of dollars more in clothing costs and would violate international trade obligations.
 
'It's a Turkey'
''This bill is worse than bad, it's a turkey,'' said Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, which exports electronics, machinery and other products that could be affected by foreign retaliation against American protectionism.
In a study for the Institute of International Economics, William R. Cline, an economist, placed the consumer costs of the legislation at $4.96 billion by 1992, rising to $48.48 billion annually by the year 2000.
Amendments from two Republican Senators, Phil Gramm of Texas, and Pete Wilson of California, would have jettisoned the restrictionist provisions if consumer costs rose above certain limits. They were overwhelmingly rejected during debate on the bill, which began last Thursday.
 
Outlook Clouded in House
Prospects for a similar measure in the House are clouded. The Ways and Means Committee has jurisdiction over trade matters, and neither Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman, or Sam Gibbons, the Florida Democrat who is chairman of the trade subcommittee, have expressed enthusiasm for the legislation. No hearings have yet been scheduled.
Carlos Moore, executive vice president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, which represents three-quarters of the textile industry, acknowledged that the apparel group's position was ''a disappointment.'' But he said it was ''not a major stumbling block because we have the support of other associations.''

INDUSTRY: SIC2341 WOMEN'S, MISSES', CHILDREN'S, & INFANTS' UNDERWEAR & NIGHTWEAR (66%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Does Gorbachev Know Best?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
SUPPOSE Mikhail Gorbachev threw a free-market party and nobody wanted to dance?
Soviet leaders make no secret of their worry that people reared in a socialist cocoon would be unable to adjust to the rough and tumble of open competition. Indeed, many apparently fear that the proletariat would take to the barricades before accepting the loss of guaranteed employment and cheap bread, or tolerating the rise of self-made millionaires in their midst.
But pathbreaking survey research by Robert J. Shiller, an economist at Yale and expert on the psychological underpinnings of economic behavior, suggests that the Kremlin is behind the times: Not only did Mr. Shiller discover that Muscovites were reasonably open to capitalism, but also, the survey shows, in some ways they were more open than their counterparts in New York. 
The research, done with a Soviet economist, Maksim Boiko, and a Soviet sociologist, Vladimir Korobov, and being presented today at a National Bureau of Economic Research conference in Cambridge, Mass., will not be easy to brush aside. Like a few other pioneering analysts, Mr. Shiller has used opinion polling to gauge Soviet resistance to capitalist ideas. But unlike others, he has created a controlled scientific experiment, asking the same questions of Soviet and American citizens, and comparing their responses.
The telephone survey, conducted in May, covered some 360 people in each country with similar age, sex, employment and education profiles. The poll included 36 questions crafted to minimize spurious differences linked to language or culture. A few of the questions explored attitudes toward capitalist institutions head on - i.e., ''What inheritance tax rate for really wealthy people do you think we should have?'' A few asked about current behavior: ''Did you save any money from the income you earned last year?'' But most set up hypothetical situations and asked individuals how they would react, or whether a given result was fair.
One question, for example, asked whether they would accept a 10 percent increase in working hours in return for a 10 percent pay increase. Another asked whether they would charge market-rate interest to a friend who needed a six-month loan to buy a summer house. Yet another asked whether it was fair for a furniture factory to raise the $200 price of kitchen tables by $20 if it could not meet demand at the current price.
In a few cases, responses divided along the anticipated ideological fault lines. Soviet respondents were generally more suspicious of business success: Some 54 percent agreed that ''people who try to make a lot of money will often turn out to be not very honest,'' compared with just 37 percent of the Americans. And Soviet answers showed more reluctance to mix arm's-length business with friendship. Fives times as many Americans (though still a minority) would charge interest on the summer house loan.
In most cases, though, Soviet and American attitudes were quite similar. Roughly the same proportion would be ''tempted to invest a substantial portion of their savings'' in a risky enterprise that might make them rich. Nearly identical percentages thought it fair to buy vegetables from farmers and resell them in the city at a large profit. Most Soviet respondents (64 percent) thought it unfair to raise the price of those scarce kitchen tables - but so, too, did a majority (70 percent) of Americans.
Some answers suggested that Russians are actually more willing capitalist tools than Americans. Just two-thirds as many Soviet people believed that speculation would cause more frequent shortages of bread. More Soviet respondents (49 percent versus 30 percent) would be willing to tolerate the tripling of incomes for a lucky minority to gain a 1 percent increase for everyone else. And a higher percentage in Moscow were ready to tolerate 30 percent inflation as long as their own incomes rose by more.
The survey results may not be entirely representative of attitudes in the two countries. Muscovites with sufficient clout to rate working telephones may be relatively confident they would emerge as winners in the capitalist lottery. New Yorkers, inured to rent control, may be less market-oriented than other Americans.
But such considerations hardly explain away this striking research. At the very least, the results shift the burden of proof to those who view this generation in the Soviet Union as inflexible followers of the socialist god who failed.
An obvious question, then, is why Robert Shiller seems to know better than Mikhail Gorbachev -why the Kremlin is so reluctant to ask people to take a chance on another economic revolution. The good Marxist answer is that the primary beneficiaries of the old system can hardly be expected to remain in the vanguard of change for very long.

HEADLINE: World Bank Considers Loan Charge Reduction

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
World Bank officials announced yesterday that the the bank's net income topped $1 billion in 1990, for the sixth year in a row, and that the institution would now consider reducing its borrowers' costs.
Officials said discussions were likely to begin by the end of the summer on reducing the bank's loan charges. The bank now charges countries 50 basis points over its cost of borrowing. If approved by the board of the bank, the largest provider of aid to third-world countries, it would be the first cut in the bank's 50-basis-point charge on loans. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
No formal proposal has been made. But at a news conference in New York, officials said that with a continuing net income of $1 billion, about $300 million was left over after the bank set aside money to keep its ratio of reserves for bad loans to about 11 percent. A reduction of 10 basis points would cost the bank about $90 million in net income each year, officials said.
Officials said that an opportunity to reduce costs to borrowers was at hand because the bank had reached its goal of raising reserves to 11 percent of its outstanding loans, which total about $89 billion. The level of reserves rose in the fiscal year 1990, which ended June 30, to 10.8 percent from 10.2 percent.
''We are not a profit-maximizing institution,'' said Ernest Stern, senior vice president for finance, in explaining the proposal.
''Our costs impact very directly on our own members,'' he said, and ''our objective is to keep those as low as possible, consistent with income necessary to build and maintain adequate reserves and a strong financial position.''
Mr. Stern would not predict whether the board would approve a reduction in the spread, or how soon it might do so. He said some bank members were likely to propose using the extra income for other purposes, like contributions to its global environmental fund.
But he said he expected that over the next five years, if the bank's income consistently remains above $1 bllion, there wll be some reduction in the 50-basis-point spread. Though he would not guess at the size of the reduction, he did say that a reduction of 20 basis points, which would reduce income by about $180 million, is a ''little optimistic right now.''
In the fiscal year 1990, the bank board approved a reduction in the commitment fee for loans approved but not yet disbursed. The fee was reduced to 25 basis points from 75. The commitment fee reduction has been continued into 1991.
Income for fiscal year 1990, which ended June 30, was $1.046 billion, down slightly from the $1.094 billion of 1989. Income was reduced by several charges, including $150 million for the reduction in the commitment fee.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Rises 0.4% On Auto and Utility Strength

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
A spurt in automobile production and a heat wave that increased utility output pushed industrial production up four-tenths of a percent in June, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Last month's gain, which followed a rise of six-tenths of a percent in May, surprised analysts who had expected a more modest increase.
The June increase helped push industrial production for the second quarter up by an annual rate of 3.5 percent, a significant gain over the six-tenths of a percent annual rate of increase in the first quarter. 
 
Temporary Factors
Private analysts cautioned that the upturn was likely related to temporary factors rather than any long-term comeback in the nation's manufacturing sector, which has been in a slump for months.
The Fed also reported the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities, which usually move in tandem with industrial production, rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 83.5 percent of capacity, in June. The June operating rate was the highest since December's 83.7 percent, but it was still well below the level a year ago when the industrial sector was operating at 84.6 percent of capacity.
The operating rate measures output and changes in productivity levels.
Analysts attributed much of the recent strength in auto production to the likelihood that some auto makers have been building up inventories in preparation for a possible walkout in September by the United Automobile Workers union.
''Manufacturing is not booming; it's struggling,'' said Cynthia Latta of DRI/McGraw Hill, a financial data service in Englewood, Colo. ''But since output does seem to be expanding slightly, it has to be viewed as a relatively good report.''
The Fed said that the increases in automobile production and utility output accounted for three-fourths of the total June increase.
Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods rose five-tenths of a percent in June, after increasing eigth-tenths of a percent in May.
Output of durable goods - items expected to last at least three years - also increased five-tenths of a percent after a jump of 1.3 percent a month earlier. Manufacturing of nondurable goods - items like food and clothing - was up four-tenths of a percent, after a one-tenth of a percent increase in May.
The Fed said its industrial production index in June stood at 109.8 percent of its 1987 base, up from 109.3 in May.

HEADLINE: Computer Screen Dumping Charged

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Frustrated by what they say are the unfair pricing practices of eight major Japanese electronics companies, a small group of American makers of flat screens used in advanced portable computers filed an anti-dumping petition yesterday, calling for an investigation by the United States Government.
The screens, known as flat panel displays, have increased in sales dramatically in recent years as portable computers have gained in popularity - 750,000 laptop computers were sold in the United States last year. The flat panels, made with a lithographic process similar to that used to manufacture semiconductor chips, are lightweight and consume far less power than bulkier monitors using cathode-ray tubes. 
The petition, which was filed with the Commerce Department and United States Trade Commission, charges Japanese makers with selling products at as much as 71 percent less than manufacturing cost. If a Government investigation makes a final determination that dumping has taken place and that it is injuring American industry, significant duties could be placed on the Japanese producers. Dumping is the sale of imports at less than the cost to produce them.
The use of the advanced flat panel displays is making rapid progress. Portions of computers are expected to be integrated directly into the circuitry of the flat panel displays, and advanced television sets may also use the panels.
 
Unable to Meet Competition
But the United States manufacturers producing such displays are small high-technology concerns that account for little more than $50 million in sales, and they said yesterday that they were increasingly unable to meet aggressive Japanese competition.
Last year, the executive vice president of Toshiba, Tsuyoshi Kawanishi, was quoted in the Japan Economic Journal as having said, ''We are prepared to accept red ink for the first five to six years.''
And that prospect is what is upsetting the American companies, said Curtis M. Stevens, vice president for finance at Planar Systems Inc., a maker of flat panel displays in Beaverton, Ore.
Mr. Stevens said the most blatant example of Japanese dumping practices was the flat panel display used in a new portable from Apple Computer Inc. The Apple flat panel, manufactured by the Hosiden Electronics Company, is based on a technology known as thin-film transistor active matrix, which employs a transistor to control each separate picture element in the display. In the complaint filed yesterday, Hosiden is charged with selling a product in the United States at about a third of its manufacturing cost, but the Apple product is not mentioned by name.
The anti-dumping complaint was filed by eight United States manufacturers - the Cherry Display Products Corporation, the Coloray Corporation, Electro Plasma, the Magnascreen Corporation, Ovonics Imaging Systems Inc., Photonics Technology Inc., Planar Systems and Plasmaco Inc. The companies have banded together in a trade association called the Advanced Display Manufacturers of America.
The Japanese display manufacturers are Sharp, Hitachi, Toshiba, NEC, Mitsubishi, Hosiden, Matsushita and Sanyo. I.B.M.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Campaigns For Children Criticized

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
IN a wide-ranging attack on how some of the best-known American corporations market to young children, Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, released a study yesterday detailing what it denounced as increasingly pervasive and hidden advertising to ''America's most vulnerable consumers.''
Charlotte Baecher, the director of education services for Consumers Union, said young children, especially pre-teen-agers, were especially susceptible to sophisticated marketing techniques because they were not yet able to critically assess advertising claims.
The marketing was so pervasive and frequent, she said, that it was, in effect, ''brainwashing and not advertising.''
In response, the American Association of Advertising Agencies, which represents agencies that produce and run 80 percent of the nation's television and print advertising, said the industry was sensitive to children as ''a special audience.'' The group's children's advertsing review unit, established in 1974, had persuaded companies to modify or discontinue 270 commercials that had the potential for misleading or confusing children. 
Harold A. Shoup, executive vice president of the group known as the Four A's, said, however, that ''in terms of children's vulnerabilty, children are a lot more discerning than people give them credit for.'' He said the controversy was not new. ''I remember pestering my mother for a Red Ryder BB gun,'' he said, referring to a widely advertised cowboy hero of the 1940's.
At stake in the pre-teen-age market is what Consumers Union estimates is $8 billion a year in sales, the amount spent by children and their parents on snack foods, candy, toys, games, clothes, movies, game arcades and other products and services.
In yesterday's study, Consumers Union was particularly critical of so-called educational materials provided to schools and ''advertorials,'' or advertisements made to resemble editorial matter, contained in children's or teen-agers' magazines.
It also attacked ''kids' clubs,'' or advertiser-sponsored clubs that provide discount product coupons; celebrity endorsements; paid placement of brand-name products, including cigarettes and alcoholic beverages, in movies and the proliferating licensing of toys, lunchboxes and other products.
Consumers Union, a group that attempts to assess advertiser and product claims in its magazine Consumer Reports, called for school districts to declare schools ''ad-free zones'' and to teach children about the biases in advertising. It also urged the Federal Trade Commission to investigate new curbs on ''kids' clubs'' and Congress to pass legislation banning tobacco and liquor companies from paying to display their products in movies.
Consumers Union sharply attacked instructional materials or other incentives from corporations given to often financially pressed school districts or directly to teachers interested in widening sparsely financed curriculums.
The Nutrasweet Company, for example, has since 1986 provided a ''Total Health'' nutrition publication for use in home economics classes in high schools. The corporate objective, said Rich Nelson, a spokesman, is to bring ''better food choices to consumers.''
But the materials only mention Nutrasweet as an alternative sweetener to sugar, not its competitor saccharin. The materials also do not mention the health warning to phenylketonurics, who have a rare and serious enzymatic disorder that would be aggravated by using Nutrasweet. ''By the time they reach high school, phenylketonurics know they have the disorder,'' Mr. Nelson said.
In a 16-year-old program in which thousands of schools participate, the Campbell Soup Company buys gymnasium equipment, computers, and even vans for schools in exchange for labels from Campbell soup cans.
''We do not encourage or discourage students to buy Campbell Soup,'' said Kevin G. Lowery, a spokesman, but he noted that most labels were from products that students' families have already purchased. ''But we're not ashamed of what we're doing. We want people to know who is making this possible.''
Similarly, the Coca-Cola Company and its affiliated bottlers will buy football scoreboards for schools in exchange for providing a soft drink vending machine. ''If parents and teachers didn't want our support,'' said Robert Bertini, a spokesman, ''we wouldn't be there.''
Consumers Union also denounced advertorials, and singled out an advertisement by EPI Products USA Inc., maker of Epilady, a woman's hair removal system. The ad, which was labeled as such, ran in January through April of this year in Seventeen magazine. It is in the format of an editorial advice column called ''Ask Loren,'' with a smaller headline saying ''Your Personal Answers to Questions About Make-up & Fashion.'' Only company products are mentioned in the column.
An EPI Products spokeswoman, Susanna Wilson, said ''Loren,'' the advice columnist, received 400 letters a month and that she had answered each one.
In a statement, Ed Gottlieb, EPI Products' director of advertising and marketing, said, ''It is an advertisement disguised as advice column, but we call it educational advertising.''

HEADLINE: Tartikoff Gets Promotion In a Realignment at NBC

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 17

 BODY:
NBC announced today that Brandon Tartikoff, the longtime president of its entertainment division, had been elevated to the new position of chairman of the NBC Entertainment Group.
Warren Littlefield, executive vice president of prime-time programs for NBC, will become president of entertainment. The realignment was announced at a news conference by Robert C. Wright, NBC's president. The NBC programming department is based in Los Angeles. 
Mr. Tartikoff's main new duties will involve generating more economically sound programming owned by NBC and its ventures. He already leads two divisions devoted to creating programs, NBC Productions and a program development group that is a special committee of the leaders of NBC's stations and its news and sports divisions.
''The idea of dabbling with the news department, or the sports department, or even the owned stations is no longer a dabble,'' Mr. Tartikoff said. ''It's essential that those divisions provide us with programming.''
 
Unusual New Structure
Mr. Littlefield, 38 years old, will continue to report to Mr. Tartikoff, which gives NBC a management structure in its entertainment division unlike any other in television. Neither ABC nor CBS has such a position.
Mr. Tartikoff, 41, has served as the chief programming executive for NBC for more than 10 years, longer than any other television executive.
But he said in an interview that the shift does not signal the end of the Tartikoff era, during which the network surged to leadership in television's prime-time programming. Two programs selected by Mr. Tartikoff, ''Cheers'' and ''The Cosby Show,'' were instrumental in the network's success. ''It's still a little early to be talking about ends of eras,'' he said.
But Mr. Tartikoff said he had not extended his contract with NBC, which has less than two years to run.
He cited two reasons for the moves: the need to create new opportunities for Mr. Littlefield and the program executives under him, and the necessity for NBC to respond to changes that have threatened the survival of network television.
Mr. Littlefield's contract would have expired next month. He said it was unlikely he would have remained at NBC if he had not been promoted.
 
A Feeling of Deja Vu
Mr. Tartikoff denied he was ''burned out'' in his basic programming job but said he felt a sense of deja vu when hearing about progam ideas similar to those he heard eight and ten years ago. ''I'm not saying programming Friday nights won't continue to be a challenge,'' he said. ''But I think there are also some things that are more critical and much more interesting that are going to have to do with the long-term survival of network television.''
Many of those challenges ahead involve program costs and control of profits. Mr. Wright has increasingly moved NBC into other businesses, like cable channels and satellite distribution, and has described NBC more and more often as a ''programming company'' rather than a network.
Mr. Tartikoff said a favorable ruling from the Federal Communications Commission on the dispute between the networks and Hollywood studios over syndication profits could affect future NBC businesses. ''By January, there could be a studio acquisition by NBC,'' he said. ''A small studio would be a nice complement to the network.''
Earlier this year, NBC engaged in a long, sometimes bitter renegotiation with the producers of its highest-rated program, ''The Cosby Show.'' NBC kept the show, but only at a record price of a reported $1 million an episode plus other concessions. Mr. Tartikoff said it had spurred him to shift his priorities.
''You start to see a day coming when a lot of your more successful shows will potentially become loss leaders if you don't readjust your strategy; you may be getting ratings, but you may not be making any profit,'' he said. ''You also see the studios asking for things and demanding time periods. You start to say the studios are now figuring out new strategies to guarantee they remain solvent.''
Mr. Tartikoff said he felt the time had come to ''tackle those big issues.'' Neither Mr. Wright nor Mr. Tartikoff was able to delineate how Mr. Tartikoff and Mr. Littlefield would divide the duties of managing the division. General Electric Companyd(NBC)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Gloomy Prospects Facing Retailers

BYLINE: By Isadore Barmash

 BODY:
DESPITE a slight rise in the latest store sales figures, American consumers are likely to remain reluctant shoppers for the rest of this year, according to store executives and industry analysts. And that grim outlook means no end is in sight to the difficulties facing most American retailers and their suppliers.
People do have money for shopping, economists say, citing an increased savings rate, but they note that disposable income has dropped. Consumers are putting money away in anticipation of leaner times, they say, and economic surveys confirm. 
Almost as important, many industry experts say, is an apparent growing malaise among shoppers who see few trend-setting clothing styles or must-have consumer products.
Given these factors, many economists said they were not impressed with the rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in June sales reported by the Government on Friday. That gain ended three months of declines. The overall situation leaves many analysts who follow consumer buying convinced that retail sales will not rebound strongly this year.
The dour prospects weigh especially heavily on national retailers with high debts like Federated Stores Inc. and R. H. Macy & Company. These department store companies must depend on steady or increasing sales for the cash flow to pay off the loans used to buy the stores.
And the pressure on the retailers is making life harder for apparel and textile makers, Deborah Bronston and Toni Perrelle of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. noted last week. ''The apparel and textile stocks in our closely followed universe are down 6.6 percent in the last year, compared with a 12.6 percent increase in the S.&P. 500,'' they said, pointing to a 55 percent decline at the Hartmarx Corporation, an 18 percent drop at the V. F. Corporation, a 48 percent fall at Guilford Mills Inc. and a 46 percent slide at Fieldcrest Cannon Inc.
One indication of the continuing slump was the recent report by Investcorp, the Mideast financing group that bought Saks Fifth Avenue. The group told bankers that Saks's earnings for the first half of 1990 were worse than expected and added that it foresaw flat to slightly negative sales results for Saks's Manhattan flagship store for several years.
The overall decline in sales this year seems to mirror an erosion in consumer confidence. The Conference Board, a nonprofit research organization, said that after sampling 5,000 households nationwide its Consumer Confidence Index fell to 102.5 in June, more than 4 points below the level in May and 8 points below April's level.
Robert F. Buchanan, senior retail analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, a Baltimore brokerage, said: ''What retailers are grappling with is a double whammy - a diminished rate of consumer disposable income and a continuing urge to save money. The result is a definite slowdown in personal consumption.''
National retail chains say the biggest sales declines have been in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic states, where thousands of jobs have been lost through business mergers and layoffs and because of the stock market crash in October 1987. The firmest area of the country is said to be the West Coast, particularly the Pacific Northwest. The Sun Belt states are doing relatively well in sales while business in the Midwest is mixed.
Women's, men's and children's wear are showing little buoyancy, even though sales of women's clothing increased last year after a long decline.
''In the first four months of 1990, total apparel sales were down 1 percent both in units and dollars,'' said John Tugman, vice president of MRCA Information Services, a market research company in Stamford, Conn. Men's clothing fell by 8 percent in unit sales and 10 percent in dollar sales.
Still, some analysts see opportunities for selective buying.
Jonathan H. Ziegler, an analyst with Sutro & Company in San Francisco, said, ''The strong retailers will take market share - the guys who provide values and what the consumers want.''
''Wal-Mart will always do well,'' he added. He has a strong buy recommendation on Gottschalks Inc. in Fresno, Calif., which operates 22 department stores in Central California. ''It's a special situation,'' he said. ''They are in a rapid growth economy, which is operating to its own beat right now, and housing prices there are still going up.''
Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said in a report, ''We would continue to focus investments in the premier retail companies, including Limited, Wal-Mart, Dillard, May, Toys ''R'' Us, Tiffany and Duty Free International.''
Neil Thall, retail services director of Kurt Salmon Associates, said: ''Those merchants with a different approach in goods and service are doing much better than the pack. Today's customer wants attractive merchandise, clearly good values, service that is more than just a smiling face and shopping convenience.''

HEADLINE: Panel Warns of Risks in Global Trading

BYLINE: By GREGORY A. ROBB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Warning of potentially serious risks to investors, institutions and the economy from round-the-clock trading in stocks and futures, an independent agency of Congress said today that it might fall to lawmakers to lay out regulatory policy toward the emerging global marketplace because ''it is not clear'' if the regulatory agencies share a ''common view.''
A report by the Office of Technology Assessment said Congressional action on global trading was as important as landmark legislation that created the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1934.
The S.E.C., the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury Department share jurisdiction over stock and futures trading. 
 
Risk of Liquidity Crisis
The technology for 24-hour trading is ''poised for a takeoff,'' the agency said, but risks remain because a clear international regulatory system has not been developed. The main risk would involve a liquidity crisis across borders if one major market participant failed.
The report is part of a continuing study by the Congressional agency of the impact of technology on the stock and futures markets, a draft of which was harshly criticized by the securities and futures industries. The draft questioned some fundamental practices of the two industries, including the specialist system of the New York Stock Exchange and the open outcry system of the futures exchanges. An advisory panel of industry representatives sent the report back in January for revisions.
Congressional aides said that they decided to separate the international section from the domestic section because of the reaction to the draft.
 
Hearings Set for September
The full study is scheduled to be issued at hearings in September. Representative Doug Barnard Jr., Democrat of Georgia and chairman of the House Government Operations Committee's Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs, asked for the report after the market crash of October 1987.
Representatives of the stock and futures exchanges said they had not seen the report and had no comment. But a spokesman for the commodities commission said the report's ''factual development, analysis and conclusions remain seriously flawed.''
The S.E.C. commissioners said they would reserve judgment until they had seen the full report. But Eugene Lopez, a special counsel in the commission's division of market regulation, said the report cited significant progress in the international area. ''I don't see the need for any new legislation,'' he said.
The report concluded that futures markets had made more strides than the stock markets toward a global market place and it said new electronic systems for global trading being developed by private companies were largely unregulated.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trade Report Spurs Decline In Dollar in World Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened on world cur-rency markets yesterday after the United States reported a widening of its trade deficit in May.
Gold prices also declined in the United States and abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $362 an ounce, down $1.30 from late Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $361.40 an ounce, off $1.10. 
Currency dealers said the dollar was under pressure in part because the Commerce Department reported that the May trade deficit jumped to $7.73 billion from a revised figure of $7.31 billion. The increase resulted partly from a big rise in oil and car imports.
Currency dealers keep a close watch on the trade figures, since they often affect the dollar's value. For instance, dealers worry that a rise in imports will put downward pressure on the dollar, to encourage higher export sales.
Earl I. Johnson, a trader at Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said technical factors also played a role in the dollar's decline. ''It just lost the upside momentum,'' he said.
Mr. Johnson said the traders were awaiting testimony scheduled for today by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, before Congress on monetary policies.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 148.20 Japanese yen, down from 148.43 late Monday. It traded at 148.32 yen in London, and at 147.80 yen in New York, down from 148.15 yen.
The dollar was weaker against the British pound. Each pound cost $1.8115 in London, up from $1.8040, and $1.8165 in New York, up from $1.8033.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Monday, included: 1.6440 West German marks, down from 1.6545; 1.4048 Swiss francs, down from 1.4180; 5.5155 French francs, down from 5.5500; 1,204.25 Italian lire, down from 1,211.00, and 1.15295 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15865.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with those on Monday, were: 1.6455 German marks, down from 1.6535; 1.4065 Swiss francs, down from 1.4165; 5.5210 French francs, down from 5.5460; 1.8552 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8640; 1,205.12 Italian lire, down from 1,210.75, and 1.1562 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1587.
The late bid price of gold in London was $361.25 an ounce, down from $362.75 Monday. Gold fell to $361.50 an ounce in Zurich from $362.70.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 75 cents to close at $361.15 an ounce.
Silver prices also weakened. On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.814 an ounce, down from $4.847 on Monday.

HEADLINE: EATING WELL

BYLINE: By Densie Webb; Densie Webb, a freelance writer and editor, is a registered dietitian.

 BODY:
MOST people's diets fall far short of the ideal set by organizations like the National Academy of Sciences, the National Cancer Institute and the American Heart Association: cutting back on fat, eating more fiber, reducing cholesterol, eating more fruits, vegetables and whole-grain foods.
Nutritionists say one reason Americans fail to meet dietary goals is that they cling to traditional diets in which high-fat meat is the focus.
Some advocates of vegetarianism say that the only way to follow modern guidelines for healthful eating is to switch to a vegetarian diet or at least a vegetarian-style diet, in which meat plays the role of a condiment or a side dish rather than a main course. On the other side are those who insist that healthful eating is simply choosing low-fat meats and dairy foods and eating more fruits, vegetables and whole grains. 
Dr. John McDougall, an internist in Santa Rosa, Calif., his wife and three children have had a strict vegetarian diet for 15 years, and he recommends it for his patients. ''But,'' he said, '' I never use the 'V' word. It scares people away.''
Dr. McDougall also directs a residential health program in Deer Park, Calif., offering only vegetarian cuisine. ''People are supposed to eat a diet centered around starch,'' he said, ''like pastas, potatoes, rice and breads, with the addition of fruits and vegetables. That's what best supports human nutrition.''
He said many who follow such diets experience decreases in blood pressure and cholesterol that would not occur with a diet based on meat.
Suzanne Havala, a registered dietitian who is a consulting nutritionist in Charlotte, N.C., has been a vegetarian for 13 years, but she said it was not necessary to follow a totally vegetarian diet to be healthy. ''But you have to try a lot harder to meet the dietary guidelines if you're eating a typical American diet and not a vegetarian kind of diet.'' Ms. Havala said.
She said she believed that moving toward a more vegetarian diet is a good way of putting dietary recommendations into practice. ''People haven't made the connection that if they are going to be eating a diet that is in keeping with the dietary guidelines, it isn't going to resemble the typical American diet,'' she added.
Switching to a vegetarian diet to meet dietary goals is ''absurd and unnecessary,'' said Dr. Jack M. Iacono, director of the Western Human Nutrition Research Center in San Francisco, who has been studying the effects on health of reducing fat in the typical diets of Americans, Finns and Italians for 17 years.
He said that reducing one's intake of fat to less than 30 percent from 40 percent would be easy if consumers chose leaner grades of meat and low-fat cuts of meat, and if they carefully trim visible fat from meat and use low-fat dairy products. Low-fat cuts of beef include top round, eye of round and chuck roast. The leanest grade of beef is ''select.'' If fruits, vegetables and grains are substituted for the fats that have been removed, Dr. Iacona said, the character of the diet is unchanged but the vitamin and mineral content is dramatically improved.
But choosing the right foods is not always easy without the help of a nutritionist, said Dr. Johanna Dwyer, a professor of medicine at Tufts Medical School and director of the nutrition clinic at the New England Medical Center. ''Many people have taken the tack of simply saying 'eat less animal food,' '' Dr. Dwyer said, ''because they don't know that much about food composition. They assume they've just got to give up red meat.''
A simple approach, said Dr. Paul LaChance, professor of nutrition and food science at Rutgers University, is to adjust the distribution of plant foods vis-a-vis animal foods in the diet. Currently, about 60 percent of the American diet comes from animal food (beef, fish, poultry, pork, milk, cheese, eggs) and 40 percent comes from plant food (fruits, vegetables, cereals and grains), the United States Department of Agriculture says. Dr. LaChance would reverse this so 60 percent of the American diet is from plants and only 40 from animals.
Though nutritionists disagree on whether a vegetarian-style diet is necessary to meet dietary guidelines, few of them argue against the evidence that people who follow vegetarian diets have a lower rate of chronic illness - heart disease, cancer, obesity, diabetes and gall bladder disease.
''The nutritional benefits of vegetarian diets are very well established over time with an enormous body of literature,'' said Dr. Marion Nestle, chairman of the department of home economics and nutrition at New York University.
Vegetarian diets are very healthy provided calories are adequate and the diet is varied, said Dr. Nestle, who was the managing editor of the Surgeon General's Report on Nutrition and Health for 1988. ''The vegetarian diets that get people into trouble are the ones that are too low in calories and too restricted,'' Dr. Nestle said.
Ms. Havala agrees that even vegetarian diets can be nutritionally unbalanced. Sodas and potato chips are vegetarian foods, she says, but if consumed excessively, they make a vegetarian diet high in fat and low in nutrients, just as a meat-based, junk-food diet is.
She offers several suggestions for those who want a diet that emphasizes plant food over animal food. First, she says, don't expect to make changes overnight: the evolution from one's current eating habits should be gradual. She recommends limiting meat intake to 4 ounces a day, or in practical terms, no more than one meat-based meal. Meat consumption now averages about 6 to 8 ounces a day. To accomplish this, she advises that people consider vegetables, rice and grains as the main course and meat and dairy products as the side dish or condiment.
During the transition to a more vegetarian diet, Ms. Havala suggests experimenting with vegetarian cookbooks. But, she says, be forewarned that some vegetarian recipes call for a lot of cheese, sour cream, oils or vegetable margarines, making the dishes high in fat. Cookbooks or cooking classes for such ethnic cuisines as Chinese, Thai, Japanese and Indian, she says, may also provide meatless options that are good starter dishes for those new to vegetarian-style eating.
 
Tips and Reading
THE Vegetarian Resource Group, a not-for-profit educational organization, offers information on vegetarianism and vegetarian cooking. Write to The Vegetarian Resource Group, P.O. Box 1463, Baltimore, Md., 21203, or call (301) 366-VEGE.
Two vegetarian cookbooks are THE NEW LAUREL'S KITCHEN, by Laurel Robertson, Carol Flinders and Brian Ruppenthal, (1986) $16.95 and STILL LIFE WITH MENU, by Mollie Katzen, (1988) $21.95, both from Ten Speed Press, P.O. Box 7123, Berkeley, Calif. 94707 (415) -845-8414.
Also, write or call Woodbridge Press, P.O. Box 6189, Santa Barbara, Calif. 93160 (805) 965-7039, for BEAN BANQUETS, by Patricia Gregory, (1984) $9.95.

HEADLINE: U.S. SHIFTS CAMBODIA POLICY; ENDS RECOGNITION OF REBELS; AGREES TO TALKS WITH HANOI

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 18

 BODY:
In a major policy reversal, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced today that the Bush Administration was withdrawing its diplomatic recognition of the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, which includes the Communist Khmer Rouge, and opening negotiations with Vietnam on settling the Cambodian conflict.
Mr. Baker, speaking to reporters after a two-hour meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said the move was necessary because existing American policy appeared increasingly likely to promote a return to power of the Khmer Rouge, under whose rule in the 1970's more than a million Cambodians were killed or died of starvation.
 
Pressure From Rights Groups
The Administration had been under pressure from Congress and human rights groups to change its Cambodia policy, especially in light of a recent series of major military gains by the Khmer Rouge.
The policy that was abandoned today dates to the Carter Administration, which, seeking to improve relations with China and in deference to Southeast Asian nations wishing to contain Vietnam, stifled some of its human rights concerns and condoned Beijing's support of the Khmer Rouge. The policy continued under the Reagan Administration. 
Mr. Shevardnadze, whose Government supports Vietnam, said after meeting with Mr. Baker that the American and Soviet approaches on Cambodia have ''come much closer.''
 
Seeking to Isolate Hanoi
The Administration also signaled that the talks with Vietnam could eventually lead to normal relations with Hanoi, although Mr. Baker said that such a step was not at hand. After the Vietnam War ended in 1975, the United States sought to isolate Vietnam diplomatically and economically and did not establish relations.
Since Vietnam invaded Cambodia in December 1978, ousted the Khmer Rouge and installed a pro-Vietnamese Government, Washington came to support a three-faction Cambodian coalition trying to topple the Government in Phnom Penh, led by Prime Minister Hun Sen. The United States argued that Mr. Hun Sen was an illegitimate puppet of an ''expansionist'' Soviet-backed Vietnamese Government.
The rebel coalition consists of two non-Communist groups led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian leader, and a former Cambodian Prime Minister, Son Sann, both of which have received American aid. The most powerful military force in the coalition, however, was the third partner, the Khmer Rouge. Washington, in its eagerness to oust the Vietnamese-installed regime, was seen as indirectly supporting the Khmer Rouge's aim of returning to power.
Explaining the Administration's move today, long advocated by human rights organizations, Mr. Baker said Washington had realized one of its goals on Cambodia last year with a Vietnamese troop withdrawal.
But he added: ''Another policy goal was to prevent the return of the Khmer Rouge. We've not been able to achieve that goal and, in fact, it would appear that the risks are greater as we move forward that that might occur. So we want to do everything we can to prevent a return of the Khmer Rouge to power. That has been one of our policy goals all along that we've not been able to achieve.''
 
U.S. to Continue Aid
Mr. Baker said that in keeping with this objective, the United States would now ''open a dialogue with Vietnam about Cambodia.'' He said Washington would also ''be prepared to enhance our humanitarian assistance to Cambodia'' and to withdraw support for the rebel coalition's claim to Cambodia's United Nations seat, which it has long held. Washington is expected to support leaving the seat open pending elections in Cambodia.
The Secretary indicated that Washington would continue to provide aid to the two non-Communist guerrilla factions led by Prince Sihanouk and Mr. Son Sann, to keep them politically alive until internationally supervised elections can be held in Cambodia. Whether such a policy will be sustained by Congress, however, is uncertain.
Mr. Baker said he and Mr. Shevardnadze would have discussions of such regional problems when they meet in Irkutsk, in Siberia, on Aug. 1.
 
U.S. Holds Talks With China
Mr. Baker also said that Washington has held ''consultations'' with China and Southeast Asian nations regarding the policy switch, but he declined to elaborate. Persuading China to withdraw its backing for the Khmer Rouge would be an essential ingredient in defusing the conflict.
The Administration's decision to ''change policy does not constitute a decision to normalize relations with Vietnam,'' Mr. Baker said. ''It is a decision simply to begin a dialogue with Vietnam about Cambodia.''
Mr. Baker said whether the talks would lead to a normalization of relations would depend in large part on Vietnam's responsiveness to American inquiries about prisoners of war and soldiers missing in action.
American officials said the talks with Vietnam would be held in New York, where Vietnam has a United Nations mission; a date was not disclosed. The American delegation will be led by the Assistant Secretary of State for Asian Affairs, Richard H. Solomon.
Mr. Solomon has been in Paris representing the United States at a meeting with China, France, Britain and the Soviet Union designed to push an Australian plan to put Cambodia under United Nations administration until elections can be organized.
That conference adjourned with diplomats from the five countries citing progress toward agreement among themselves, but voicing frustration with the lack of progress toward agreement among the Cambodian factions.
The American policy reversal today appeared to be a way to put pressure on the Cambodian factions to reach a settlement under the plan being developed by the five nations, the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. Their next meeting on Cambodia is scheduled for late August in New York.
 
Factors Behind U.S. Switch
The Administration's policy switch appears to have been motivated by two factors: The war on the ground, where the Khmer Rouge appear suddenly to be making major headway, and mounting Congressional opposition.
The Khmer Rouge's senior diplomatic representative in Paris, Khieu Samphan, was quoted by French newspapers as saying that the rebels have recently taken up positions near Phnom Penh.
In Congress, a series of recent votes has made it clear to the Administration that its policy of supporting a coalition that could return the Khmer Rouge to power is rapidly losing support. The end of the cold war has made the Soviet-backed Hun Sen Government less distasteful to Washington, and the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia last year has undercut the impression that Mr. Hun Sen was a puppet of Hanoi.
Mr. Baker acknowledged this change in perception of the Hun Sen Government when he said: ''It certainly was a puppet government while Vietnam troops were in the country supporting it. Those Vietnam troops have now gone and that's one of our policy goals that we've been able to achieve.''
While today's move came about in part from consultations with Congress, it is not the result of any negotiated bipartisan agreement, Mr. Baker said.
 
Fears of a New 'Killing Field'
WASHINGTON, July 18 (Reuters) -The Bush Administration's decision to open talks with Vietnam is not enough to prevent the Khmer Rouge from again turning Cambodia into a ''vast killing field,'' Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, said today.
''I welcome Secretary Baker's announcement of changes in American policy toward Cambodia, although I do not believe they go far enough in clearly and effectively preventing future Khmer Rouge domination of Cambodia,'' Senator Mitchell said.
The Maine Democrat called for a comprehensive rethinking of American policy.
Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, chairman of the House Asian and Pacific Affairs subcommittee, said the policy shift was a recognition of changed circumstances in Southeast Asia.
''I consider it a welcome adjustment in our policy in Cambodia,'' Mr. Solarz told reporters.
 
Non-Communists Oppose Policy
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 18 (AP) - Non-Communist Cambodian guerrilla leaders said today that the American decision would force them closer to China and strengthen the Khmer Rouge.
Vietnam's Ambassador to the United Nations, Trinh Xuan Lang, hailed the decision as a ''positive'' step that could eventually lead to the normalization of relations with the United States.
''In the future, to survive, to go on fighting, we will have to accept more aid from China,'' said Prince Norodom Ranariddh, son of Prince Sihanouk. Prince Ranariddh is commander of his father's army.
 
No Reaction Reported in China
BEIJING, Thursday, July 19 (Special to The New York Times) -The Chinese Government appeared to be weighing its response to the Baker announcement on Cambodia today as the Foreign Ministry announced it would hold a press conference later in the day.
China's leading newspapers carried no reaction. But in in comments quoted by the New China News Agency, Xu Dunxin, the Assistant Foreign Minister, expressed satisfaction with the progress being made in the talks in Paris among the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. His comments appeared to have been made before the Baker announcement.
