HEADLINE: Home Builders See Recession And Blame the Savings Crisis

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
For the first time since the recession of the early 1980's, the rate of new housing construction has dropped for five consecutive months, providing further proof, home builders say, that the economic and regulatory fallout from the savings and loan crisis has pulled one of the country's biggest industries into a recession.
The Commerce Department figures, released yesterday, show that single-family and apartment housing starts fell to an annual rate of 1.18 million in June, a drop of 15.7 percent from the rate of 1.4 million a year ago. The decline was steepest in the Northeast, where housing activity was 32 percent below the 1989 level.
At the same time, sales of new homes have fallen 21 percent since their peak last November, to an annual rate of 546,000 units. The drop is particularly severe in the Northeast. 
Leaders of the country's $200 billion housing industry, which accounts for about 5 percent of the gross national product, say that the slump results in part from a move by Federal bank regulators to discourage banks from real estate lending in an attempt to prevent them from falling victim to the same careless practices that bankrupted so many savings institutions. Unless conditions improve, they say -and other factors, including a smaller number of young home buyers, make any improvement unlikely for the near term - the rest of the economy will also be pulled under.
In fact, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, eased interest rates last week to offset the tightening in commercial loans.
''We're worse off today than we were in the early 80's when we had those incredibly high interest rates,'' said H. Daniel Pincus, a home builder in Brick-town, N.J. ''Then the banks were helping to keep everyone alive, not destroy us.''
The backlash from the savings crisis is only the latest in a series of adverse developments for the housing industry. Economists say the direction of the market has become so uncertain that many buyers and sellers are now staying on the sidelines, waiting to see what happens to prices and mortgage interest rates, which have remained persistently high in relation to the country's sluggish economic performance.
The fact that the market has not responded to stable interest rates and falling prices, for instance, suggests to some that prices are likely to slip further, and inventories to inch up a bit, before the next upswing in the historically cyclical housing industry.
The number of people who own homes is declining for all but those who are middle-aged and older, and demographic trends point to a smaller number of people in the age group in coming years buying homes for the first time.
In addition, the 1986 tax revision law drove tax-shelter investors, a big source of building money, out of the real estate market. And new Federal rules mandating access for handicapped people to apartment houses have scared many multifamily builders away. Apartment construction has dropped by more than half since January, when the rules took effect.
 
Low Rents Seen as a Factor
Forecasters say that part of the slump in the housing market is also a result of the low rents in the overbuilt apartment and town house market, which have encouraged renters to postpone the purchase of their first house.
''We're being hit all at once by high interest rates, low job growth, the credit crunch, the new multifamily handicapped rules, and it's putting us right at the edge of a major recession in the housing industry,'' said Martin Perlman, a Houston developer who is president of the National Association of Home Builders. ''If we topple over, and toppling over means less than one million starts a year, we might very well pull the rest of the economy down with us.''
For its huge economic size, the housing industry is remarkably fragmented, an amalgamation of entrepreneurs, part blue-collar, part banker, who do their own land deals, secure loans, finesse local building rules, bully contractors and cajole buyers in a business where a dollar too much or a day too late can mean the difference between profit and loss.
 
Factors Encouraging Sales
The industry points to economic signs that should result in better starts and sales - a fairly low inventory of unsold homes on the market, plentiful mortgage money in the 10.5 percent range, which is moderate by recent standards, and home prices that have begun to slip a bit in search of buyers.
The inventory of unsold new homes nationally, expressed in months' supply at current sales rates, stands at a 7.5 months' supply, compared with 8 months a year ago and 6.6 months two years ago. For existing homes, the figures are 8.2 months today, versus 8.5 months a year ago and 9.6 months in 1988.
Yet experts outside the industry say the market is just not ready for another building boom.
 
'To Build in This Market Is Crazy'
''The credit crunch, in some areas at least, is absolutely real, and so it should be, because anyone who wants to build in this market is crazy,'' said Carl Case, an economics professor at Wellesley College who specializes in real estate analysis. ''The way the real estate market works is that it must clear itself of any surpluses before it can begin to move again. It's hard for the builders because it's their livelihood, but, boy, I wouldn't make development loans at this point in time.''
In New York, Long Island and northern and central New Jersey, housing starts in the first quarter of this year dropped to half their rate of a year ago for single-family construction. The only exception in the three-state region was the Hartford area, which showed a 5.7 percent gain.
Glenn Crellin, another real estate association economist, said he believes that banks are waiting for the market to start to move before they go back to returning phone calls from credit-seeking developers.
 
Banks Seen as Defensive
''The banks are unwilling to contribute to what they see as an increase in the inventory,'' he said. ''They're trying to protect their own portfolios and the industry as a whole from what might happen in a further weakening of the market.''
William B. Brueggeman, consulting director of real estate research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he believes that one reason the housing market is not responding to stable inventories and soft prices is that the vacancy rate of rentals, which shot up after the boom in apartment building in the mid-1980's, is only now beginning to drop.
''In some markets it is cheaper to rent than to own, and that is only slowly correcting itself,'' he said.
 
Rise in New York Vacancy Rates
Commerce Department figures show that the vacancy rate for rental apartments nationwide declined from 7.7 percent in 1987 to 7.1 percent last year. For Long Island, however, the rate has crept upward, from 6.3 percent to 6.9 percent, as it has in New York, from 2.4 percent to 3.3 percent, which indicates that the situation is worse there.
The vacancy rates for single-family homes are even more troubling for this region. While the national rate has declined from 1.7 percent to 1.4 percent, it has increased for Nassau and Suffolk counties from four-tenths of 1 percent to nine-tenths of 1 percent, and in New York City from 2.2 percent to 3 percent, the third highest of any major city after the depressed oil cities of Dallas, where it is 3.9 percent, and Denver, 3.7 percent.
The rise in single-family vacancies is thought by analysts to be caused by the growing number of families unable to sell their homes at prices they find acceptable that are putting them on the rental market.
 
One Builder's Problems
This distressed housing market has brought down many savings institutions, worsening some developers' difficulties. For instance, when the savings and loan that had been financing Mr. Pincus failed and was taken over by Federal regulators, Mr. Pincus had about 20 of the 36 units planned for his subdivision built and sold, and another six in various stages of completion.
After a delay, the bank agreed to reopen Mr. Pincus's line of credit, but kept changing the rules, he said.
''They said on June 4 they would disburse the money,'' Mr. Pincus said. ''Then came June 4, and they came up with a newfangled problem someone had thought of, and it took until the 25th of June to straighten it out.''
To ride out the wait, Mr. Pincus persuaded contractors to wait until the closing on two more houses for their payment.
''I got lucky, because I got contractors and a couple of buyers who were willing to work with me,'' he continued. ''But you can't work an ongoing job on that basis, and if I can't get the money to stay afloat, what's going to happen?''
 
Support for Banks' Position
Mr. Pincus said he is convinced that his homes, selling for $230,000 to $250,000, are the right product for the times, and that his completion schedule, only 10 percent below the prediction he made to his bank three years ago, shows that they are.
But Professor Case of Wellesley said that every builder believes he has the market figured out, that misplaced builder self-confidence helped get the country into the savings and loan crisis in the first place, and that it is up to the banks to take the large view.
''Each individual builder believes that he can build a good product in a good location and sell it and do fine,'' Mr. Case continued. ''But if I'm a bank, I've got to be able to sort all that out, because not every builder is going to succeed in this market.''
 
Home-Start Report
WASHINGTON, July 18 (Reuters) - Construction of new homes fell 2.3 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today. The drop, which followed a revised nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in May, came despite lower interest rates that economists had predicted would at least keep starts from continuing to fall.
Tom Holloway, senior economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said that the interest rate on a conventional 30-year mortgage loan came down in June to an average of 10.16 percent, from 10.48 percent in May.
Building of single-family homes fell one-tenth of 1 percent in June, while building of apartments was down 8.7 percent from May levels, as total housing starts fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.18 million units in June, from a rate of 1.21 million units in May.
That rate was the lowest for new-home building since October 1982, when starts were 1.17 million units. The drop in June starts represented the fifth straight monthly decline, the first time that housing starts fell for five successive months since the recession year 1981, when they dropped from July through November, department officials said.
The department previously reported that May housing starts had fallen by 1.4 percent but revised that to a drop of nine-tenths of 1 percent.
By region, construction starts fell 10.9 percent last month in the Northeast. Starts were down 9.2 percent in the Midwest and 10.1 percent in the West but rose in the South by 8.8 percent.
Building permits, a sign of future plans, rose 3.9 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.11 million, after falling 3.9 percent in May and 10.1 percent in April.
But the rise in permits was entirely for apartment construction, analysts noted, while permits to build new single-family homes declined because of the large number of completed and unsold homes.

HEADLINE: Hopes Dying In the Rubble In Philippines

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CABANATUAN, the Philippines, July 18

 BODY:
A young vendor in the market here has become something of a hero in the wake of the earthquake that devastated parts of the city on Monday.
The vendor, Junjun Merosa, 19 years old, was among the first to arrive after the Christian College of the Philippines collapsed on Monday afternoon in this city north of Manila. Small and lithe, Mr. Merosa personally retrieved 12 living people and 25 bodies, he said, helping the living squeeze from the rubble by dousing them with motor oil and pulling them gently with ropes.
Accounts like Mr. Merosa's have spread through the nation in the aftermath of the earthquake. The official death toll nationwide rose to at least 311, with 682 injured, and the numbers are sure to increase. 
An American rescue worker said the body of an official of the United States Agency for International Development was found in the ruins of the Nevada Hotel in Baguio, but had not yet recovered it, The Associated Press reported. Several members of the agency had been attending a conference at the hotel.
Doctors said that any people trapped alive who could not be reached in the next day would almost surely die from shock, wounds and dehydration. Officials estimated that perhaps 1,000 people were missing, including some 150 workers who were trapped in the rubble of a Baguio chemical factory that then caught on fire.
 
'No Realistic Hope'
At the flattened Christian College of the Philippines in Cabanatuan, Col. Ramon Ong, whose soldiers were searching for survivors side by side with American Marines and Seabees engineers from Subic Bay Naval Station, said, ''Every hour that passes diminishes our hope.''
A Marine lieutenant, Michael Barrett, with a combat engineering group and one of 292 Americans helping in this city, said more bluntly, ''There's no realistic hope now of anyone still alive.''
Filipino officials here and in Baguio, the two towns hardest hit by the earthquake, said their efforts had to begin to turn to the needs of the living. Residents of Baguio are without drinking water, fresh food and electricity, and have been sleeping outside to avoid injury in a series of aftershocks.
 
Roads Still Impassable
Roads to Baguio, a mountain resort 110 miles north of Manila, were still impassable from landslides, making it difficult for equipment and supplies to get to the town. The airport, its runway buckled, is also shut to everything but helicopters.
Hundreds of people remain trapped in the rubble, but without heavy cranes, which cannot be taken in by helicopter, rescue workers can do little except listen for the cries of those still able to cry in the enormous piles of twisted concrete and steel.
At a Baguio hotel, the Hyatt Terraces, much of which collapsed, Clarita Gonzales used a megaphone to call to her daughter, 5 years old. ''Baby, Baby Michelle darling, Mama's here!'' she shouted, over and over.
A hotel spokesman said 80 people were still missing, including 30 guests, 25 employees and perhaps 25 others who had been in the casino.
President Corazon C. Aquino flew to Baguio today and asked students there, who make up at least a quarter of the population of 120,000, to try to return to their homes.
 
U.S. Team Arrives
People were leaving the city on foot while others waited at the airport to try to get rides on relief helicopters.
The American Embassy in Manila said a 14-member military search and rescue team arrived today and would go by helicopter to Baguio.
Rescue workers said one of their biggest difficulties was the lack of sensitive microphones and infrared scanners that can help identify those still alive.
Here in Cabanatuan, the last person rescued was pulled from the wrecked school about 9 P.M. on Tuesday by a Marine. The boy, Florencio Agapito, 14, was taken to a hospital, his legs and pelvis crushed.
The Americans had brought in a tactical field hospital with 54 beds and an operating room and set it up nearby, but no one else was found alive today.
Lieutenant Barrett, 25, said his Marines arrived about the time the boy was saved and worked through the night, but ''all we saw were dead ones.''
From a ladder, five bodies deep in the wreckage were visible but inaccessible. The rescue workers, most of whom wore surgical masks, studiously avoided looking at them as they searched for any sign of the living. Between 30 and 50 people are believed to be still trapped in the building; 62 have been found dead and retrieved, and 134 were injured.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Filipinos rushing to a helicopter yesterday as the Air Force began evacuating Baguio, where residents have been sleeping outside to avoid being injured by aftershocks from Monday's earthquake. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: PREMIER OF CZECHS SEEKS U.S. CAPITAL

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, July 18

 BODY:
The Premier of the Czech region of this country is to arrive in the United States on Friday in search of what he calls pluralism.
The Premier, Petr Pithart, does not mean a multiplicity of political parties, which Czechoslovakia has abundantly achieved since last autumn without foreign help. The Premier will travel coast to coast, possibly even to Alaska, to enlist American support and investment to counterbalance what he called ''terrible pressure'' from potential West German investors.
Mr. Pithart is not only the head of the larger of Czechoslovakia's two constituent republics. The 49-year-old legal scholar and historian is also one of President Vaclav Havel's most trusted political strategists and, through his leadership in the Civic Forum mass movement, a close ally in the preparation and carrying out of the revolution that ended Communist rule. 
Mr. Pithart said he understood the surprising degree of popular pessimism that has followed the peaceful triumph of democracy of last autumn and the landslide election victory that confirmed it last month.
 
'Selling Out the Country'
''The main problem is that the federal Government and economists as a group are not united on a course of action,'' he said in an interview. ''There are no precedents, only the unsuccessful or at best half successful precedents of the old regime.
''The leadership and the people see a need to go as fast as possible. But when we are in a situation to resolve a problem, to choose a way, a lot of hesitation comes to their minds. And the advice from abroad is sometimes contradictory. We have no complete scenario of the logical steps to reform.''
Mr. Pithart, whose father was an Ambassador of the Communist Government, and who was reduced in the 21 years between the revolutions of 1968 and 1989 from an academic post to many menial jobs, outlined in imperfect but carefully chosen English the quandaries that Mr. Havel and his associates must confront in the overriding task of making the stagnant, highly centralized economy advance toward Western levels of productivity.
The problem is not only economic, the Premier said.
''The prevailing mood of Czechoslovakia is an understandable fear of selling out the country,'' Mr. Pithart said. ''It is a curious reaction, arising from our poverty. It is to be understood psychologically, this pride of a people that is poor.
 
Role of Foreign Investors
''We don't want to become the property of any Western country. It's like an architectural ruin. You either sell it to somebody who can restore it or you let it go on to certain destruction. What do you prefer? There is no third way.''
Reluctantly, Mr. Pithart said, he has come to the conclusion that in a country that has no sources of capital for the privatization of the obsolete and sluggish economy, foreign investors must be granted greater concessions than many Czechoslovaks want to offer.
''At the beginning I shared their attitude,'' he said. ''But we have to be more open.'' Does that mean 51 percent foreign holdings in an enterprise? ''Up to 100 percent,'' the Premier replied.
''But the necessary precondition is pluralism of countries,'' he said. ''There is terrible pressure from West Germany. That is why we need America.''
 
'A Bolshevist State Still'
To achieve that aim, Mr. Pithart will try to enlist the support of the American Czechoslovak community, which has been far less organized in political and economic support of their mother country than Polish-Americans or Hungarian-Americans.
''The Czechs who are organized are mostly older people,'' Mr. Pithart said. Those who came to America after the Soviet-led invasion of 1968 believe that only the surface has changed, he said, ''and we are a Bolshevist state still.''
Many Czechoslovak economists and officials share concern over the fact that the bulk of the investment offers comes from West Germany. Czechoslovakia is keeping options open. But Mr. Pithart said that by the end of the summer, Volkswagen, for instance, is likely to own a controlling interest in Skoda, the country's largest carmaker.
The Premier said there was also indecision about how to introduce badly needed competition into the economy.
 
Resisting a Purge
''We are doing our best to bring to the country elements of free trade in a system in which the monopolies of the existing enterprises prevail,'' he said. ''How do you create an atmosphere of competition when most of the factories are monopolistic?''
He said one way was to create what he called an ''artificial atmosphere of competition'' by opening the market wide to imports. ''This is a very costly way,'' he said, because to make Czechoslovakia attractive, customs duties have to be pegged very low.
''A further reason for pessimism is that the old structures on the middle and lower levels are still in position,'' Mr. Pithart said. The Government faces a quandary in how to renew the Communist Party-dominated economic and administrative structures without a political purge, which the Havel leadership has forsworn. From the revolution's start, Civic Forum has insisted against much popular opposition that to dismiss masses of people only because of party membership would be unjust.
Czechoslovakia underwent wholesale purges three times in the life of its older citizens - under Germany's virtual annexation in 1939, in the Communist takeover in 1948 and after the 1968 invasion.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
U.S. Gives Soviets Menu Of American Expertise

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 18

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has given Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union a list of economic assistance projects the Bush Administration is prepared to undertake in the Soviet Union, a senior Administration official said today.
The delivery of the list today was the first time since the summit meeting at Malta in December 1989 that the Administration has formally offered a package of technical economic aid programs to Moscow. The offer was made as some American allies, particularly West Germany, are planning to offer Moscow cash grants, bank credits and low-interest loans. The list given to Mr. Shevardnadze today far exceeded that presented at Malta, the official said. 
Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze met for two hours today at the American Ambassador's residence, a day after the talks on German reunification in Paris that produced a resolution of the German-Polish border dispute.
 
Contacts With Opposition
During the talks, Mr. Baker also told Mr. Shevardnadze that Washington planned to begin contacts with the emerging non-Communist opposition in the Soviet Union, including people like Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, and Mayor Gavriil K. Popov of Moscow. The Soviet Foreign Minister registered no objections, said the Administration official, who emphasized that Washington intended to keep these contacts on a low-key, low-level basis, at least for now.
Among the projects on the list were these:
* A proposal for sending American experts who would help advise the Soviets on how to improve their clogged distribution networks, which often get so backed up that goods imported from the West sit for months in railroad cars and ships before they get to consumers.
* A proposal for providing technical advice on how to set up a private banking system. Given the American savings and loan crisis, American officials acknowledged that there was a bit of an incongruity in the notion that the Bush Administration would offer Moscow its expertise in this field.
* A proposal being drawn up by the Department of Housing and Urban Development for advising the Soviet Union on how to develop a private housing industry. When President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union flew from Washington to Camp David during the June summit, he spent much of the flight asking his hosts how much the private houses they were flying over cost to build, own and maintain.
* A proposal for developing management training courses.
* A proposal for establishing an effective tax administration. The Soviet tax system is currently a chaotic, often inconsistent, amalgam of legislation. Mr. Baker suggested American help in designing an equitable tax policy, as well as a tax-collection bureaucracy to administer it.
What all the proposals have in common, say American officials, is that they do not involve any cash infusions, but solely technical advice to help the Soviets get the most out of what they have now, and to help them move toward a more market-oriented system.
Mr. Shevardnadze, according to the Administration official, promised to give Mr. Baker a reaction to the list when the two meet again on Aug. 1 in Siberia while Mr. Baker is on an Asian tour. Because of their long discussion today of domestic developments in the Soviet Union, the two ministers agreed to postpone their planned talks about Afghanistan and other regional disputes until they meet in Irkutsk.
Senator Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, is sponsoring an economic aid bill for Eastern Europe for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, that would provide the Administration with the funds for use in delivering technical assistance to either Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union.
Most of the programs that began after the Malta talks were low-budget projects involving one-time visits by teams of American experts.
After an initial burst of visits, though, the technical aid seemed to slow down, apparently in part because of a lack of responsiveness from Moscow and in part because of diminishing energy on the American end. Mr. Baker's proposals were clearly prompted by Mr. Gorbachev's direct appeal to the West for help, and the need by Washington to demonstrate more active support at a time when its allies seem to be opening their wallets.

HEADLINE: Behind U.S. Reversal: Gains by the Khmer Rouge

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Defense and intelligence officials say they are increasingly concerned that the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas are winning their war to oust the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government. The Bush Administration's announcement today that it is withdrawing recognition of the Cambodian rebel coalition and opening talks with Vietnam underlines that concern.
State Department, Defense Department and Congressional analysts said that despite recent Khmer Rouge advances they do not believe the Cambodian Government will fall this year.
They said that two non-Communist guerrilla groups loosely allied with the Khmer Rouge had failed to make similar advances. The two groups receive more than $15 million in yearly overt and covert American assistance. 
''A primary concern of our policy is to keep the Khmer Rouge from taking power,'' said a senior State Department official. ''Khmer Rouge military advances have caused concern.''
 
A Rainy Season Offensive
''We want to do everything we can to prevent a return of the Khmer Rouge to power,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told reporters in Paris.
Human-rights monitors have documented that more than a million Cambodians were killed under Khmer Rouge rule in the 1970's during a radical restructuring of society that included the forced mass migration of urban people into the countryside.
Administration officials said that the Khmer Rouge rebels are following rural-based strategy similar to the one used in encircling Phnom Penh in 1975, when the Khmer Rouge came to power.
American officials said that in their current rainy-season offensive, the rebels are taking advantage of the Government's decreased mobility. The rebels are spreading their forces across the countryside - from northwestern Siem Reap province and Bantheay Meanchey province to southern Kampot province - while they cut off major highways and communications lines to choke the cities.
In the face of this offensive on northern, southern and central villages within 40 miles of the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, Government forces are retreating and in some cases dropping their weapons, the officials said.
A Defense Department official said the Khmer Rouge strategy was directed at ''undermining the people's confidence in the Government and the Government's confidence in itself.'' The official continued: ''The Government forces are hard pressed and extended in contending with the Khmer Rouge offensive. Morale problems and corruption are clearly evident.''
The Vietnamese-backed Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen is struggling to manage a series of problems. The Government cannot pay all of its civil servants and soldiers, a situation made all the more severe by rising inflation and a decline in Vietnamese and Soviet economic aid.
Regular Vietnamese Army forces, which once numbered up to 200,000, left the country last year. American officials report that a few thousand Vietnamese military advisers have returned to help beat back the offensive.
 
Support for Khmer Rouge
In briefings to other Government officials earlier this week, Central Intelligence Agency analysts estimated that the Khmer Rouge faction consists of 30,000 to 40,000 fighters, slightly larger than the size of the two non-Communist rebel groups combined.
They fight a Government army of from 60,000 to 100,000 men. The C.I.A. estimated that the value of Chinese assistance to the Khmer Rouge approaches $100 million a year, while the non-Communist groups receive much less from several countries, including Singapore, which sends them $10 million a year in military hardware and other supplies.
The C.I.A. estimates that the Khmer Rouge is backed in one form or another by 30 percent of the population, with larger proportions of support in areas they control, where they can exercise intimidation.
C.I.A. analysts also said the non-Communist groups and Khmer Rouge share supply lines, raising questions of how the Bush Administration can continue to supply the non-Communists without inadvertently helping the Khmer Rouge. The deeper the American-supported groups operate inside Cambodia, the more dependent they are on the Khmer Rouge.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Said to Tell China It Will Go Ahead on Loan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 18

 BODY:
A senior Japanese official has told Chinese leaders here that despite the tepid endorsement its diplomatic opening to China received from President Bush in Houston it intends to push ahead, a Japanese official who attended the meetings said.
The reported comments by the senior official, Deputy Foreign Minister Hisashi Owada, who ended an important three-day visit today, are just one step in what appears to be a focused Japanese diplomatic offensive to rebuild relations with China quickly and, implicitly, to encourage China to see Japan as its most reliable ally among the major industrialized nations.
It is also an early demonstration of Japan's stated aim of pursuing a more independent foreign policy that uses the vast financial resources it has amassed over the last decade to strengthen relationships.
''The Chinese understood that what came out of Houston was a compromise,'' said the official, who attended the meetings with Mr. Owada. ''They understood that Japan was not satisfied, because its position was not completely accepted'' on normalizing ties to China. President Bush agreed at the Houston summit not to block Japan's huge loan program to China. 
As the United States and other Western nations continue to curtail diplomatic, cultural and other contacts with China after the crushing of the pro-democracy movement in Tiananmen Square last year, Japan is sending a wave of senior figures and pushing ahead with the stalled $5.5 billion subsidized-loan program.
Shortly after the summit meeting of the seven leading industrialized nations, Japan began to plan the processing for 17 of the 42 low-cost loans for projects included in the program.
Just before the Houston gathering, in fact, a team of nearly two dozen Japanese experts had already quietly approved the feasibility of the projects, which include construction of railways, port centers, upgraded telephone lines, fertilizer plants and a city water supply system, a Japanese official said. The loans are made at below-market rates of 3 percent.
In keeping with a Japanese strategy, the projects will also make it more attractive for foreign companies to invest in China by improving the industrial infrastructure.
Under pressure from the United States and other leading industrialized nations, the World Bank and other countries have made official loans only for projects that covered basic humanitarian needs, not ones that brought broader commercial and economic benefits, as the 17 Japanese projects will.
Mr. Owada also explained in the briefing for the Chinese, the diplomat who attended the meetings said, that Japan opposed attaching conditions to its economic aid, as the United States increasingly does. China has fought the inclusion of conditions, like making aid dependent on political or economic liberalization, as an intrusion on its internal policies.
 
Hesitant Japanese Banks
Mr. Owada was the most senior Japanese official to visit Beijing since Chinese troops killed hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators last year.
Later this week, Sakutaro Tanino, head of the Foreign Ministry's Asia department, is scheduled to come and discuss the loan program directly. And a former Foreign Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, paid a visit here this week and was greeted by top Chinese officials.
Another former Foreign Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, and the president of the powerful lower house of Parliament, Yoshio Sakurauchi - both leading figures in Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party - are expected next week.
Because the Chinese economy is ailing and its outlook is muddy, many Japanese businesses, in particular, banks, have not been so quick to rush back in here. But the Japanese Government and the private sector regard China as holding immense strategic importance, and have said they do not want events like the Tiananmen Square crackdown to disturb the long-term relationship, which they see as promising as a major market and low-cost production base.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Our German Future

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Something is wrong with me. I can't rejoice at the great news.
Heaven knows, all kinds of important people are telling us to sing and dance - the President of the United States, columnists and editorial writers, professors, and also Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia, head of the House of Hohenzollern.
They are ringing bells and sending congratulations to Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Mikhail Gorbachev for getting together and working out the big deal. 
Mr. Gorbachev drops his opposition to German membership in NATO, which he could not stop anyway, and gets promises of heavy German money and trade.
Chancellor Kohl rids himself and his country of the short-term annoyance of Soviet kvetching about German membership in NATO. But more important he earns a deserved reputation as the smartest, most successful and most powerful leader in Europe, West or East, and quite probably the world.
The competition is not all that tough, but you have to hand it to Mr. Kohl for beating out the Prime Minister of Japan.
Mr. Gorbachev may have been the man of the 1980's. But the way things look Mr. Kohl will grace the cover of the history of the 1990's.
Now why am I not singing like a lark? After all, I know that German unification, which never thrilled me, is an accomplished fact, and that the best we can do now is pray for the best, with minimum snarling.
Realpolitik, Mr. Gorbachev calls it with a huge smile. A good word for it because it has plain connotations of cynicism and expediency.
For Soviet acquiescence the Germans are willing to pay billions of marks. Mr. Gorbachev needs the money and they can spare it, in wise expectation that it will be seed money for the growth of German economic and political power in the East.
But it is not the details of the German-Soviet deal that are so troublesome. It is the realization that it is the official opening of a new era of world politics - and that we do not know where it will lead us.
Headlines in The Times explain the queasiness. ''Bowing to the Inexorable: Soviets Make the Best of New German Might.''
''Germany Makes the Most of Its Newfound Power.''
And this poignant one: ''Bush Declares He Does Not Feel Left Out by Gorbachev and Kohl.'' (No, of course not. Mr. Kohl just went to see Mr. Gorbachev, worked out an economic, political and military understanding of world importance and filled Mr. Bush in. The next day Mr. Bush sent congratulations. Who said anything about left out?) It's worth facing realities, though we cannot change them. 1. The West was caught dead in the water by the collapse of Communism, never believing those Soviet rebels who kept saying it was inevitable. 2. The death of Communism sent masses of East Germans into West Germany. Instead of saying hold on, as victors in World War II we want a controlling voice in the unification process, the West and the Soviet Union watched slack-mouthed as Mr. Kohl waved at them from his speeding unification steam engine. 3. Unification creates a different German nation, not only stronger economically but moving on its own political track. It is already the first all-Europe power, strong in East and West. Mr. Kohl has worked out Moscow's expenses-paid troop withdrawal. Fine; now get ready for demands that American troops, like Soviet, withdraw from Germany. 4. The West hopes the advantages of belonging to the European economic union will chain Germany down. Maybe, but European union will also make Germany even stronger. The chain will hold fast - as long as Germany wishes. 5. None of the above need be a world disaster - just as long as the current support for democratic ways never fades among Germans, just as long as there will never ever be a German leadership that uses a crisis as the excuse for getting economically or politically nasty with the rest of Europe. 6. If you believe such guarantees exist, ring bells and cry joy. If not, wait awhile.
Wait, but don't go away. I know people who were reluctant to visit Germany or get involved with it because of memories and fears that need no explaining. I was one of them.
Not anymore. The memories will never fade; Germany is so much a part of our past.
Today we cannot do much more than visit, watch and talk with Germans. But we cannot do less, because now Germany is so much a part of our future.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: GERMANY (96%); EUROPE (93%); UNITED STATES (92%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (79%); JAPAN (79%);

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Seeking to Make The Unpopular More Palatable

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In Yonkers yesterday, Mayor Henry Spallone not only accepted a $95,000 payoff from a power broker but also held a news conference to announce it.
Mr. Spallone, on behalf of local civic groups, was among the first recipients of a $1.2 million fund established by the New York State Power Authority to compensate communities along the route of a power line linking Westchester and Nassau Counties.
For every mile the cable traverses within its boundaries, each city, town and village is eligible for $55,000; counties can collect $5,000. Grants cover public benefits ranging from a refrigerator at a soup kitchen in Tuckahoe to stage rigging at Bronxville High School. A similar program, which gives a new dimension to the phrase ''making it under the wire,'' has disbursed $12 million to upstate communities that would derive no direct benefits from the 200-mile Marcy-South power line. 
While the Power Authority chairman, Richard M. Flynn, was presenting the grant in Yonkers, New York City officials were unveiling their own version of government by mitigation. It depends largely on a more open process and on a perception: that fundamental fairness in apportioning unpopular projects will infuse their neighbors with more public spiritedness.
The Dinkins administration rejected a formula, such as one using a grant or a tax abatement, that would place a value on a project's social or environmental undesirability. Instead, Mayor David N. Dinkins's proposal to the City Planning Commission formally expands the criteria routinely considered in finding sites for public projects.
It represents, said Richard L. Schaffer, the commission chairman, ''the first attempt in the nation to combine efficiency and equity in a unified siting process.''
One goal of the guidelines, which are required by the new City Charter, is to disperse unpopular projects that have typically been dumped in poorer neighborhoods. Additional projects deemed among the most unpopular -those involving garbage and sewerage, as well as residential programs for the homeless, drug addicts and jail inmates - could be placed in overburdened neighborhoods only under certain conditions.
The guidelines are consistent with Mr. Dinkins's goals when he was Manhattan Borough President:
He won commitments for more trees and other amenities to compensate for yet another drug treatment center in Harlem, and he endorsed an initiative for the homeless that dispersed shelters to the four other boroughs.
But it's uncertain whether the guidelines, despite their good intentions, will dramatically alter concentrations of public projects and, in some cases, whether they should.
In Manhattan, market forces may confine those projects to places like Harlem and lower Manhattan where land is less expensive. Political pressure will invariably distort the process, too: why else, for example, would the Koch administration have decided to build one huge garbage incinerator in each borough? (One analysis during the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay found a preponderance of popular projects in districts that voted for him). And some neighborhoods have high concentrations of drug treatment programs because many addicts live there.
The guidelines distinguish, though, between ambulatory programs, more likely to benefit people from the neighborhood, and residential programs that, theoretically, could be located anywhere and, arguably, fulfill a regional need. They also consider the impact of Federal, state and private projects.
New York, though, is a city where some people view even a school or a park as unpopular because they might attract undesirables. What the guidelines try to address, Mr. Schaffer said, ''is how does government analyze the cumulative impact of separate intrusions on a community?''
The guidelines may cost the city more in time and money, but Mr. Schaffer reasons that adopting a rational process that is both public and equitable will create more good will than resorting to subterfuges, like closing a fire station after the company has left to answer a false alarm. (Inauspiciously, Ruth W. Messinger, who succeeded Mr. Dinkins as Borough President, complained that her staff had not been adequately consulted on the guidelines, as the charter requires).
In November, the Mayor will, for the first time, present the big picture - an annual forecast of projects that the city hopes to open or close. Yet will that overview persuade New Yorkers to accept blots on their own backyard any less begrudgingly?
Mr. Schaffer hopes so. But he acknowledged, ''How much comfort that will give people, I don't know.''

HEADLINE: Omen for Young: Low Black Turnout

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 18

 BODY:
In his bid to become Georgia's first black governor, Andrew Young may have won a place on the runoff ballot Tuesday in the state's Democratic gubernatorial primary, but many of his campaign aides and other political observers said today that he had failed to generate the enthusiasm among black voters needed to win the nomination.
Mr. Young ran second in the primary, with 28.9 percent of the vote behind Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller's 41.2 percent. The two men had been front-runners in polls well before the voting and had been expected to end up in a runoff. What was not expected, many political experts said, was the low black voter turnout, which turned a narrow lead for Mr. Miller over Mr. Young in earlier opinion polls into a yawning gap in the voting Tuesday. 
''The black voter turnout was nothing to write home about,'' said Charles Schroder, the executive director of the state Democratic Party.
 
Shoring Up Black Support
While it was difficult to come up with hard figures on black voter turnout, Neihl Horton, Mr. Young's campaign spokesman, acknowledged that the campaign had not done as well as expected. He said particular emphasis would be given to shoring up black voter support before the Aug. 7 runoff.
Some Young aides cited the tactical difficulty facing a black candidate in trying to woo white voters while retaining black support. Mr. Young, they noted, has de-emphasized race and the historic nature of his campaign, shed his long opposition to the death penalty and stressed economic development over social programs and social policy. One aide said Mr. Young had to ''lean right and moderate his positions for whites while counting on blacks to see this as a tactic and not a theological conversion.''
''Apparently many considered it a theological conversion,'' said the aide.
Claiborne Darden, a political poll taker based here, agreed, saying, ''Unless Zell Miller makes a mistake, Andy Young is through.''
 
Record Republican Turnout
The voting Tuesday also produced a record turnout in a Republican primary, giving a clear victory to to State Senator Johnny Isakson, who captured 65 percent of the vote in the gubernatorial race. The state Republican chairman, Alec Poitevint, said the party was now in a position to elect its first Republican governor in more than a century.
In the past decade, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina and Alabama have broken with century-long practices and elected Republican governors. The trend has been late coming to Georgia, Mr. Poitevint suggested, because of the Presidency of Jimmy Carter, who commanded strong loyalty in his home state.
But Mr. Schroder noted that the 111,000 Republican primary votes cast were still about one tenth of the 900,000 Democratic votes cast. He added that Mr. Isakson's stance in favor of abortion rights and his moderate political profile in a state with outspoken Republican conservatives did not make him the dream candidate of his party.
 
Moderate Appeals Fell Short
Mr. Young's apparent failure to draw a large black vote was puzzling. In Fulton County, which contains much of Atlanta, Jesse Jackson got nearly 9.000 more votes in his 1988 Presidential bid in winning the county than Mr. Young got Tuesday. Similar comparisons held for many of the predominantly black counties in rural areas of the state.
''I don't buy the idea that Andy Young didn't walk the tightrope the right way,'' said Mr. Darden, referring to Mr. Young's need to court white voters while holding on to his base of black voters. ''I thought he was even more moderate in his appeals than Doug Wilder was in Virginia, and Wilder held his black base. We know what happened, but I don't think we know why.'' Mr. Wilder, who is black, was elected governor of Virginia last year.
 
'Black Vote Was Just Neglected'
One political advisor to Mr. Young said: ''It's partly Andy's history in that he doesn't talk a lot about what he has done for poor blacks. But this time the black vote was just neglected and they assumed that they would get them. We are going to try to help build an apparatus that will make sure he gets those votes on Aug. 7.''
But Paul Begala, deputy campaign manager for Mr. Miller, said Mr. Young would have a tough time taking the lead. The Lieutenant Governor, a 16-year veteran of state politics, won in 119 of 159 counties and took all of the suburban Atlanta counties with the exception of one, Dekalb. Mr. Begala attributed this to Mr. Miller's emphasis on programs such as a lottery to finance education improvements and boot camps for first offenders, compared to Mr. Young's more general emphasis on bringing in more jobs and greater economic development.
''We had a resounding victory because Zell Miller articulated the agenda for this campaign,'' said Mr. Begala.
 
Coin Flip Picks Victor
CHICAGO, July 18 (Reuters) - A bitterly contested primary election for the Illinois Legislature that became a battleground in the fight over abortion was decided today by the toss of a coin.
Rosemary Mulligan was declared the winner by state election officials over Penny Pullen, an outspoken abortion foe. Both women were seeking the Republican nomination for a state House seat in suburban Chicago that Ms. Pullen had held for 14 years. Ms. Pullen's lawyer said he wouldf appeal to the State Supreme Court the decision declaring the race a tie.

LENGTH: 1501 words

HEADLINE: Decorators Feel the Pinch As Jobs Wane

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
''PEOPLE in this business are used to saying 'everything is fabulous,' '' a New York decorator said recently.
But the word among many professionals in the design industry is that business this year has been far from fabulous, particularly in New York and the Northeast. Although some firms and decorators report that they have never been busier (''The rich always have money,'' said one New York decorator. ''Thank God my clients are substantial.''), many are feeling the effects of the general economic slowdown, sluggish local real-estate markets and leaner times on Wall Street in the aftermath of the 1987 stock market crash.
Many decorators, those who are not celebrities but whose businesses were thriving a year ago, tell of reduced budgets, lack of phone calls from prospective clients, protracted bidding procedures, phased installations and the evaporation of ''middle-range'' jobs with budgets of $15,000 to $150,000 - the bread and butter of the business. When the phone rings these days, it's often, as one decorator put it, ''contractors looking for work, or vendors trying to sell me something.'' 
In a business that purveys image, it is not uncommon to hear decorators say that their business is fine, but they've heard others have troubles. ''Nobody wants to look like there's a problem,'' said Alan Lindenfeld, a New York designer. ''But there's definitely a problem.''
Financial data on the decorating industry is difficult to obtain, in part because there are no Government indicators for it. The interior design business is largely a closed, secretive world. Most of the major fabric houses are privately held and do not release sales figures. Many residential decorating concerns are companies composed of one to five people.
A recent survey of the country's 200 largest interior design firms by Cahners Economics, a division of Cahners Publishing, which publishes Interior Design and other magazines, asked the firms to compare this year's residential business to last year. Thirteen percent said the business, which makes up varying portions of their total billings, had increased, 30 percent said it had decreased and 57 percent said it was unchanged.
But in two weeks of interviews, many prominent decorators, manufacturers and contractors admitted to feeling a pinch, especially in the New York City area.
''Business is spotty,'' said Mark McIntire, vice president for marketing at the New York Design Center at 200 Lexington Avenue. ''Some are having record months, but generally, right now it's tough.''
The center, which has 71 showrooms, lost four over the last year, Mr. McIntire said. He described several others as shaky. He said that the customer base of the Center has changed noticeably.
''We used to have the 20- to 40-year-old all-cash customer who was making money on Wall Street,'' Mr. McIntyre said. ''They're not in the market right now. Instead, we're seeing 38- to 60-year-olds who are spending investment income. We're not getting the $400,000 paychecks. We'd sure like to have them back.'' To lure new clients, Mr. McIntire, like many others, has had to get aggressive. This October he will invite 2,000 would-be customers into this to-the-trade-only sanctum, where 100 decorators will be strategically stationed with portfolios and business cards. Such tactics have become necessary, he said, adding, ''If you get into the mentality of not spending, one of the first things you can live without is that $7,000 sofa.''
Showroom personnel at the Decoration & Design Building on Third Avenue say, there is a sense of holding back. ''I don't think people have less money, they're just less eager to spend it,'' said John Brewer, president of Fonthill Ltd.. ''I've heard everyone complaining, from designers at large firms to the housewife decorators.'' His business is ''not down,'' he added. ''I consider that up.''
Edwin W. Bitter, chairman of Scalamandre, said his company is ''not doing too badly, but we're not as active as we should be.'' New York has been hit especially hard, he said, though sales are up 7 percent in Dallas and Houston, and California is doing swimmingly.
''The Californians,'' he said, ''are holding up New York, God bless them.''
Raymond Chevallier, a vice president for F. Schumacher & Company, another well-known fabric company, began to sense a softening of the residential market in the fourth quarter last year. ''It has continued, with some ups and downs through the present,'' he said. But the slowdown ''is definitely regional. We've seen a strong pick-up in business in Texas, Oklahoma and Colorado.''
''We're looking at an attitudinal problem,' said Wallace W. Epperson, a senior vice president of Wheat First Securities in Richmond, Va. and a furniture industry analyst. ''We're seeing consumers increasingly anxious and nervous.'' Perhaps as a result, he said, personal savings have increased, suggesting that when confidence returns, consumers will have greater liquidity than after past economic slowdowns.
Rod G. Kreitzer, president of the Baker Furniture Company in Grand Rapids, Mich., in part blamed his own industry for ''lack of innovation. We've lost our sense of daring. There hasn't been much drawing customers to say, 'Wow, let's change the whole house and hock our future to get it.' ''
There will always be decorators who tell of the client who went antiques shopping with his wife and ''after $1 million, put his foot down.'' But even decorators with stellar clients have noticed a subtle change.
Anthony P. Browne, a Washington decorator whose clients include Andrew Lloyd Webber and Oprah Winfrey, observes a marked contrast to the 1980's: ''People have become more concerned about people noticing what they're spending,'' he said.
Penne Poole, another Washington designer, describes the present moment as one of ''cautious opulence.'' Once she had a steady stream of complete residential projects, she said. Now it comes in phases. ''You'll do the foyer or the dining room, but the living room isn't done. You get these pockets in a house. It's a little unsettling.'' Bunny Williams, a Manhattan decorator, said: ''You don't get five calls a week now. In the 80's, it was, 'Oh, let's call a decorator.' ''
Some clients are forgoing details, like tasseled fringes and chandeliers with a pleated shade on each light. ''They're asking the price of things now,'' said the Manhattan decorator Josef Pricci. ''They're doing the staples and filling in as they feel comfortable.'' Competition among those who perform services for the industry - contractors, craftsmen and skilled laborers - has increased, decorators say. The bidding process is taking longer. ''Where four contractors were competing for a job,'' said Diana Polack, marketing director for G. P. Winter Associates, a New York construction firm, ''there are eight now.''
Brian Kehoe, a professional wallpaper hanger in Manhattan whose business centers on new apartments, said: ''It's job to job now. There's no backlog.'' Glen Hodges, a partner in G Square Inc. in Manhattan, which specializes in kitchens, said he always had plenty of work until last year. Between last March and this spring, ''we didn't sign a single contract,'' he said. ''We lived off the ends of projects. We dried up.''
The firm was recently hired for three new jobs, and Mr. Hodges is convinced the worst is over. ''The people who have names may be O.K.,'' he explained, ''but for people like us, it's been hard.''
After a difficult winter, Carl J. Lana, a Manhattan decorator, began selling accessories and doing consulting work, and he even considered abandoning his chosen career. Recently, things have begun to look up. ''This is what I do,'' he said. ''This is what I love to do. So I'm sticking with it.''
According to Rita Sue Siegel, whose Manhattan firm recruits design professionals, there have been ''significant reductions'' in the last year in requests for both architects and interior designers.
Roslyn Dolber, director of career counseling at the Fashion Institute of Technology, said: ''It's a grim picture. We're seeing real caution in hiring, and we're certainly arming our graduates with that information.''
But many express relief that the decorative frenzy of the 1980's is unwinding and welcome the retrenchment. Overembellishment is even becoming outre.
''There was an abandonment in the 1980's that was almost surreal,'' said Timothy MacDonald, a Manhattan designer. ''It feels like we're back to reality again.''
''It almost came to overkill,'' said Murray Douglas, the senior vice president of Brunschwig & Fils, the fabric house. ''You can't go-go forever.'' She reports inklings that excess fringe is being eclipsed by architectural wallpaper borders.
In New York, at least, introspection can occasionally give rise to black humor. ''People have a sense of wanting to establish permanence and security in their home,'' Mr. Chevallier said, ''especially since they realize they can't sell their home anyway.''

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Untangling the Strands of the Wedtech Scandal

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Too Good to Be True
The Outlandish Story of Wedtech
By James Traub
Illustrated. 379 pages. Doubleday. $21.95.
One thinks of the Wedtech scandal as a farce of greed and incompetence. But what James Traub reveals in his penetrating report, ''Too Good to Be True: The Outlandish Story of Wedtech,'' is that considerable genius was involved in the story of the little Bronx military contracting company that grew to be the apple of the Reagan Administration's eye. There had to be genius involved for so many millions of dollars to be lost and stolen and for so many powerful people to be corrupted. 
The rise of Wedtech, originally called the Welbilt Electronic Die Corporation, is essentially a simple story. Wedtech began with John Mariotta, a self-taught mechanical engineer from the South Bronx who liked to call himself a New York Rican, or ''an individual that cannot speak English and cannot speak Spanish.'' It was Mr. Mariotta's genius to be able to build things, as well as to perceive in the American system a bias that set him at a disadvantage to his fellows.
Wedtech sprouted with its discovery that the United States Government would pay you to build things for it, and that if you were a minority member you were more likely to qualify for a contract. The trouble was that Wedtech was not minority-owned; Mr. Mariotta had taken on as an equal partner a death-camp survivor from Israel named Fred Neuberger. So the two men pretended that Mr. Mariotta was the controlling partner. By doing so, they revealed another facet of Wedtech's genius, its ability to misrepresent itself.
Wedtech began to blossom after a Congressman named Mario Biaggi dropped by its offices and offered his influence in Washington in exchange for a $20,000-a-year retainer for his law firm. Wedtech thereby discovered its genius for buying politicians. Now all the pieces were in place; it only remained for everything to grow - the company, the contracts, the things to be built, the politicians and the bribes.
And grow they did, until Wedtech became a multi-million-dollar military contractor whose corrupt influence reached all the way into the Reagan White House. All it took was the company's special genius. The only trouble was that it had fashioned itself into a self-destructing machine. The bigger the contracts it finagled, the greater the sums of money it lost, the more it had to bribe and cheat.
Eventually Wedtech was sunk by pontoons, a huge Navy contract to build motorized bridges to shuttle cargo between ship and shore, a contract that Wedtech never even began to fulfill. As the company went down, the law moved in, and the partners ended up in jail, along with a good many of the people they had bribed. As James Traub puts it: The ''minuteness of exposure may make Wedtech unique in the annals of white-collar crime. Moreover, in their testimony the conspirators who cooperated with the Government offered an amazingly intimate and ramified, if not always completely trustworthy, record of their own thoughts and stratagems.''
Mr. Traub has taken this record and done an unusually thorough job of untangling its details. His prose has dramatic verve. Of the moment when Wedtech met E. Robert Wallach, a lawyer from San Francisco who linked the company up with President Reagan's Counselor at the time, Edwin Meese 3d, he writes: ''What followed was a blinding moment of fusion, as fantasy, guile, political reach, and large quantities of money combined to produce an irresistible force.''
His characters pop up off the page. ''In short order Wallach succeeded in weirding out the straight-arrow Ivy Leaguers in the U.S. Government whom he was trying so hard to impress. He wore a yellow rose in his lapel, as always, and carried his leather shoulder bag, and wafted into and out of rooms like a zephyr from California, and spoke from under the vast canopy of his eyebrows in his painfully quiet and solemn tones.''
If ''Too Good to Be True'' has any flaw, it is that its superabundance of detail sometimes confuses the narrative. Or else Mr. Traub simply forgets where he is occasionally. For instance, he introduces two separate characters as Wedtech's ''nemesis,'' the ''Goddess of Retribution . . . whom men invite when they overreach themselves.'' Yet the threats of both these people - one a Navy captain who disapproved of the pontoon deal and the other a businessman who lost out in the rigged contest for the contract - end up being neutralized. And nemesis ultimately turns out to be the various district attorneys' offices that stumbled on different parts of the Wedtech beast.
But if Mr. Traub's narrative is not always in focus, the lessons of his story are. In the forefront he places the bitter economic paradoxes of the era. To President Reagan, John Mariotta was one of the ''heroes for the 80's'' who proved that free enterprise instead of welfare was the solution ''to providing jobs and training for the hard-core unemployed.'' But what also trickled down was some of the less desirable aspects of laissez-faire capitalism.
Yet behind this story there is a more complicated lesson. As Mr. Traub concludes: John Mariotta may have been paranoid in his belief that the game was fixed against him and that only by cheating could he overcome the odds. But even paranoids have enemies: the military procurement process he ran up against was a game in which special influence did count for practically everything. In short, had he not bent the rules, he never would have gotten to play.
In the end, however, his genius betrayed him, for ''the inventor had infused his creation not only with his energy and passion but with his egotism and his blindness.'' As Mr. Traub writes: ''A man-made thing can't be better than the men who make it, and Wedtech reflected all the virtues, and all the follies and the appetites, of the men who fashioned and guided it. It was a strange and wonderful creature, even noble, yet something corrupt destroyed its greatest possibilities.''

THE ECONOMY
 
Housing construction has declined for five months in a row, the first time that has happened since the recession of the early 1980's. Home builders say the fallout from the savings and loan crisis has pulled their industry into a recession. [Page A1.] 
 
Greenspan suggested that rates would not come down soon, to offset unusually restrictive bank lending practices. The Fed chairman told Congress that the risk of recession had risen slightly but that a stable policy was still appropriate. [D1.] Consumer prices rose 0.5 percent in June. The rise, which was sharper than expected, was led by food, housing and gasoline. [D5.]
 
The savings bailout agency is planning how to spend the last of the money it has budgeted. During the next three months, it will sell off fewer, but larger institutions. [D1.] Some Republicans are said to be urging that Neil Bush make a deal with regulators regarding his savings and loan problems. [A20.]
 
The patent process for genetically engineered drugs is much slower than the Patent Office says. statistics show. [D1.]
 
Imported oil provided a record 49.9 percent of U.S. needs in the first half of the year, the American Petroleum Institute said. [D1.]
 
House Republicans declared their opposition to tax increases as part of a budget package. [A20.]
 
The U.S. is softening a secrecy policy that has limited commercial use of technology from nuclear weapons programs. [D2.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Merck's profits rose 18.6 percent in the second quarter. Bristol-Myers Squibb, Warner-Lambert and American Home Products also had double-digit gains. [D1.]
 
Philip Morris's quarterly earnings surged 27.2 percent, and revenues rose 12 percent. [D4.]
 
Apple Computer had a substantial gain in profits. Ashton-Tate announced another loss. [D4.]
 
General Dynamics had a $240 million loss in the quarter, after setting aside $450 million to cover cost overruns on a new Navy plane. McDonnell Douglas and Northrop had profits. [D17.]
 
The New York Times Company said earnings fell 35.1 percent, to $26.8 million, in the second quarter. [D17.]
 
I.B.M. acquired a license for software to run a pen-like device that can be used in place of a keyboard on a computer. [D4.]
 
John S. R. Shad resigned as chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, as the firm moved to add outside directors. [D3.]
 
Nonunion employees of UAL agreed to cooperate in a buyout effort being led by unions at United Airlines. [D17.]
 
MARKETS

HEADLINE: Greenspan Not Cutting Rates Soon

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Despite increased pressure from the Bush Administration for a quick reduction in interest rates, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested today that rates would not be lowered soon, except to offset unusually restrictive commercial lending practices.
The main risk to the economy is ''a shade more'' in the direction of recession than it was last winter, Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee. Still, he said, ''stable credit market conditions at this stage would be appropriate for the best performance of the economy.''
Mr. Greenspan is required by law to report to Congress every six months on monetary policy and the economic outlook. His testimony is closely watched in the financial markets for even the slightest clue about which way interest rates might turn. 
 
Now the Markets Worry
Last week, the markets reacted favorably to testimony in which he hinted that interest rates might be pushed down to balance tighter lending practices by banks. Indeed, the Federal Reserve moved to lower a key rate slightly.
Today's testimony, however, had a dampening effect on the markets. Many traders, who had hoped to hear a clear explanation of why the central bank eased monetary policy last week, felt frustrated that the testimony did not disclose specific details on policy direction.
In addition, the Labor Department's report that the Consumer Price Index rose half a percentage point in June contributed to the markets' declines. [Page D5.] The Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.07 points to close at 2,981.68. [Page D8.] In the credit markets, Treasury prices sagged, and long-term interest rates rose sharply. By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds were offered at a price of 102 1/4, down 26/32, to yield 8.54 percent. [Page D14.] Cryptic Statements Mr. Greenspan tends to speak cryptically at these sessions, retaining his freedom to change course if economic or political forces warrant.
For example, he said today, as he has many times before, that ''a major cut in the budget'' was the most important way to strengthen the economy. And he promised that the Federal Reserve would act decisively to lower interest rates if tax increases and spending cuts seemed likely to tip the country into a recession.
But he repeatedly refused to quantify the steps the Fed might take in the aftermath of a budget deal between President Bush and Congress. ''What adjustment might be necessary and how it might be timed cannot be spelled out before the fact,'' he said. ''The actions required will depend on the constellation of other influences on the economy, the nature and magnitude of the fiscal policy package and the likely timing of its effects.''
 
Other Points From Testimony
Mr. Greenspan made these other points today:
* He asserted that restrictive bank-lending practices around the country did not amount to a ''credit crunch.'' But he said that ''the tightening is beginning to have very real, unwelcome effects,'' and he gave his first full public assessment of what he thought had caused the situation.
* He offered the Federal Reserve's economic forecast for the rest of this year and next year, predicting economic growth of 1.5 percent to 2 percent this year and 1.75 percent to 2.5 percent next year. Those estimates are slightly more pessimistic than the Bush Administration's growth forecasts of 2.2 percent this year and 2.9 percent next year.
* He provided a new range for money-supply growth next year that was slightly below the current range.
* He expressed concern that despite the relatively low unemployment rate, ''many individuals,'' particularly young people, ''now perceive job opportunities as less abundant.''
 
Leaning Toward High Rates
On balance, Mr. Greenspan's remarks seemed to tilt toward maintaining high interest rates to restrain inflation. The Federal Reserve is the only Government agency that can directly control interest rates. It does so mainly by increasing or decreasing the amount of money available for banks to lend.
The chairman insisted that despite the economy's sluggish growth this year, ''things are not doing all that badly.'' And he said, ''The likelihood of a near-term recession seems low.''
He emphasized that the Federal Reserve's decision last week to push down the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point was made solely to offset the unusual tightening of credit by commercial lenders and had nothing to do with the overall state of the economy. (The Federal funds rate is the interest rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans.) Mr. Greenspan called the sharp increase in consumer prices in June an aberration and said it would probably turn around in July. Still, the half-a-percentage-point increase shows that inflation remains a problem that the Fed needs to address.
 
Administration's Preference
That is bad news not only for the financial markets but also for the Bush Administration's top economic policy makers, who have been leaning on Mr. Greenspan for several weeks to push down interest rates.
The Administration wants lower rates for two reasons. First, easier credit would stimulate the economy in the short run, which is good for the party in power in an election year. Second, a stronger economy would generate more tax revenue, and lower rates would reduce total interest payments. Higher tax revenue, in turn, would lower the budget deficit.
At a news conference Monday, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady was asked whether the slight drop in the Federal funds rate last week was adequate. Mr. Brady replied, ''As the minister said, 'All donations gratefully received.' ''
Mr. Greenspan and most of the other policy makers at the Federal Reserve argue, however, that the only way to guarantee long-term economic growth is to keep a tight rein on inflation.
 
'A Semantic Nicety'
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged today that some commercial borrowers were having a difficult time getting loans. But he said, ''I would not call this change technically a credit crunch, as those words connote a contraction of lending on a major scale, with many borrowers effectively shut out of credit markets regardless of qualifications.''
He conceded that such a view might be ''perceived as a semantic nicety by a borrower who today is suddenly unable to get a loan on the terms formerly available,'' but he contended that credit was not abnormally tight.
Rather, lending procedures have returned to normal after ''the excesses of the 1980's,'' he said.
''When you go from excess credit creation to normal, it can feel like a tightening,'' Mr. Greenspan added.
The credit situation would require ''continued scrutiny,'' he said, but he gave no indication that it would lead to a further lowering of rates.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Sour Investment By Pension Funds

BYLINE: By Richard D. Hylton

 BODY:
A $425 MILLION deal that was widely heralded last year as the entry of American pension funds into Europe's real estate markets has been hammered recently by high interest rates in Britain, and the investors that took part in the deal have watched the value of the properties drop sharply in the last few months.
Last July the Chicago-based JMB Realty Corporation made an investment in Randsworth Trust P.L.C., a British real estate concern, in partnership with some of this country's largest pension funds. Since the start of the year, Randsworth has seen its portfolio of high-profile West London office and retail space fall some 6 percent in value.
Late last month, JMB told its institutional partners that the Randsworth partnership was paying out too much on its floating-rate debt and that its plan to sell some of the properties in the first few years of ownership was being stymied by the weak real estate market. 
JMB's problems with Randsworth are a sign that difficult times in the commercial real estate business are affecting even the most sophisticated players, and it also puts the risks of global real estate investing in sharp relief.
JMB Acquisition Partners, the limited partnership that holds about 16 percent of Randsworth, called on the partners to come up with about $34 million that they had earlier agreed to provide, but it also sought an additional $100 million from the partners to help pay down debt and avoid having to sell properties in the weakened London market.
''The sensible thing to do is to put some additional capital in and pay down debt,'' said Neil G. Bluhm, the president of JMB.
Randsworth's cash problems surprised the pension fund partners. The original $425 million buyout, valued at about $800 million when refinanced debt is included, was designed to be highly leveraged to help protect the pension funds against currency swings. But the upward push of British interest rates and the weak London property market left the partnership short of cash to make capital improvements on Randsworth's properties.
The money that Randsworth is seeking from its equity partners will eventually reduce the debt-to-equity ratio in the deal to 50-50 from the original 75-25 level.
Among the investors being asked to ante up more cash are the public employee pension funds for Massachussets, Oregon and Illinois, and the employee pension funds of A.T.&T. and Ameritech, and AMB Pension, a pension fund for public employees in the Netherlands.
JMB paid about $425 million last summer to buy the publicly traded shares of Randsworth. That was 325 pence, about $5.88 at current exchange rates, for each share, or a 2 percent premium over the book value of the shares. The equity in the original deal was about 190 million, or $340 million. Of that sum the pension fund partners contributed about $290 million, JMB contributed 16 percent, or about $50 million. The rest of the price was raised through bonds and British bank loans. Recently the properties in the Randsworth portfolio were reappraised in London and the portfolio's value was downgraded by about 6 percent. The increased borrowing costs from high British interest rates and the lower asset value of the portfolio caused Randsworth to hit its loan limits with the British banks, leaving it with insufficient money for capital improvements or further investments without calling on the pension fund partners.
In an earlier sign of the international worries about real estate, Citicorp had a difficult time trying to syndicate a $425 million loan that was part of the permanent financing for the Randsworth acquisition. The loan was to repay a bridge loan that JMB raised to help finance its bid, retire Randsworth's outstanding debt and provide working capital.
Over the last year, American institutional investors and real estate developers have been scrambling to make investments in European real estate markets because the returns in much of Europe are better than those in the United States, where overbuilding has crippled the market in many regions. The economic integration of the European Community and the political upheaval in Eastern Europe have also led many experts to predict that property values in leading commercial cities like London, Paris and Frankfurt will continue to appreciate sharply during the next decade, with demand outpacing supply.
Randsworth's portfolio of London properties includes about 650,000 square feet of prime London office space.
JMB, one of the largest privately held real estate concerns in the country, has absorbed enormous amounts of real estate and several sizable companies over the last several years. It has more than $22 billion worth of property under its management - part of it for JMB's own account and the rest for its clients.
The company has one of the strongest followings among institutional investors of any privately held concern in the country. This has allowed JMB to raise billions of dollars for acquisitions and investments from the big pension funds.

HEADLINE: Loss Reported At HomeFed

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 18

 BODY:
The HomeFed Corporation, the parent of HomeFed Bank, a San Diego-based savings institution, today reported a second-quarter loss of $108.2 million after setting up a loss provision of $234 million to cover a rise in problem real estate loans.
The loss is in contrast to a profit of $28.1 million, or $1.20 a share, reported in the comparable period a year earlier. 
''We have loaned out of state, and in general the out-of-state lending has been where we have experience problems,'' said William D. Nichol, HomeFed's chief financial officer.
Mr. Nichol said many apartment loans and some commercial loans in Florida and in the Washington, D.C., area soured this year along with a regional economic slowdown.
The shares of HomeFed fell $1.75 each today, to $19, on the New York Stock Exchange.
