HEADLINE: Price Index Surged 0.5% Last Month

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Surges in the prices of food, housing and gasoline led to a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer prices in June, the Labor Department said today. The unexpectedly sharp rise followed two months of more modest advances and moved the annual rate of inflation up to 5.9 percent so far this year.
The seasonally adjusted Consumer Price Index had increased by two-tenths of 1 percent each in April and May, and the bigger increase last month was a disappointment to economists and Government officials, who had been predicting inflation would decline.
The 5.9 percent annualized inflation rate compared with a price increase of 4.6 percent for all of last year, a 4.4 percent rise in 1988 and a 4.4 percent gain in 1987. 
 
A Blow to the Markets
Given the renewed worries about inflation, combined with the suggestion today by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that the Fed would not lower rates soon except to counter a credit contraction, the stock and bond markets retreated.
Consumer prices had increased steeply in January, following a cold spell in December that cut supplies of produce and reduced fuel oil supplies. But until today's report, those increases had been moderating.
There were wide differences of opinion about the signficance of the June change. Some economists suggested it was a monthly blip in a decelerating trend, while others expressed worry about gains in the underlying rate of inflation.
Noting the fall in housing construction for the fifth straight month, some economists also said the risks of recession now appeared greater than the risks of inflation.
 
View of Stability
David A. Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, observed that excluding more volatile food and energy sectors, consumer inflation remained stable.
In his Congressional testimony today, Mr. Greenspan took a similar approach, arguing that while the index was ''higher than one would like to see, it doesn't, in my judgment, fundamentally affect the underlying trends.''
Mr. Wyss suggested that special factors were at work in the volatile sectors. The increase in gasoline prices to consumers, contrasted with declines at the wholesale level, he noted, showed that retailers were ''jacking up'' margins. Higher homeowner costs, he added, reflected rising state and local property taxes.
Michael L. Penzer, senior economist at the Bank of America in San Francisco, and Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, contended that the underlying trend of inflation was declining.
 
An Abating Core Rate
The core rate of the index, which excludes the volatile food and energy areas, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in June, or a 5.5 percent annual rate. In the first half of 1990, the core rate rose by a 5.7 percent annual rate. In all of 1989, the increase was 4.4 percent.
But Mr. Roach said he was worried about accelerating labor costs. Unit labor costs, representing compensation increases adjusted for productivity gains, rose 5 percent in 1989 and are likely to rise ''at least as much'' this year, he said.
From 1983 to 1988, unit labor costs, which account for about two-thirds of total production costs, rose an average of 3 percent annually.
Today's index showed that grocery store food prices, which registered declines in each of the preceding two months, increased 1 percent in June, a month in which they normally fall. All of the major food groups, particularly meats, poultry, fish, eggs, fruits and vegetables, were higher in price.
 
Higher Fresh Vegetables
Fresh vegetable prices, which increased 29.2 percent in the first two months of the year and then declined 23.6 percent in the next three months, advanced 1.4 percent in June. Tomato prices rose 16.2 percent.
Gasoline prices, which normally rise with the higher demand created by the summer vacation season, climbed a hefty 2.5 percent in June, after falling 1.6 percent in May.
Energy costs over all were up six-tenths of 1 percent. The price of natural gas shot up 2.7 percent, but fuel oil prices declined by 4.2 percent and electricity was off by 1.6 percent.
Clothing prices declined for the second consecutive month, off one-tenth of 1 percent in June, reflecting larger-than-usual seasonal falls in prices for both men's and girls' apparel.
Housing costs over all rose six-tenths of 1 percent in June, following a two-tenths of 1 percent increase in May. For their shelter, homeowners paid 1.1 percent more and renters paid four-tenths of 1 percent more during June.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Drop

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report continued to decline in the week ended yesterday.
''The decline in yields reflects the Federal Reserve's action last Friday to reduce basic interest rates,'' said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's. ''Where we go from here will depend on the budget talks now under way in Washington. Because the budget talks now dominate interest rates, we can expect yields to fluctuate with the prospects for a meaningful outcome of these negotiations.'' 
As for the tax-exempt sector, Stephen C. Shachat, portfolio manager at the Evergreen Tax-Exempt Money Market Fund, said: ''We expect yields to remain stable until the new supply of debt, including some $5 billion of municipal notes, comes to market in the next few weeks. This should cause rates to move upward.''
As it was, managers of tax-exempt funds increased the average number of days that securities are held in their portfolios to 51 days, from 49 days in last week's report.
The assets were unchanged at $78.9 billion, with the average seven-day compounded yield down 7 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.23 percent, and the 30-day average yield off 3 basis points, to 5.37 percent.
For investors in the 28 percent bracket, the equivalent taxable seven-day compounded yield would be 7.26 percent, while it would be 7.81 percent for those in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million surveyed by IBC/Donogue's, the Strong Municipal Market Fund topped the list with a yield of 6.29 percent. The Strong fund is distributed by Strong/ Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee.
The assets of taxable funds increased by $3.2 billion, to a total of $382.4 billion. Those of institutional funds rose by $2.5 billion, to $82.0 billion. The gains were again attributed to a narrowing of yield spreads between certificates of deposit and money market funds.
The average days to maturity of taxable securities held in managers' portfolios increased to 44 from 43.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund was unchanged at 7.95 percent, while the 30-day average slipped 2 basis points, to 7.95 percent.
Of the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, the Alger Money Market Portfolio, distributed by Fred Alger & Company of Jersey City, showed the best return for the third consecutive week, with a yield of 8.82 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 18.07 in Heavy Program Selling

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Investors turned cautious yesterday amid heavy program selling, depressing stock prices for the first time in more than a week and leaving the Dow 3,000 level as a barrier still to be crossed.
By the end of the day the Dow Jones industrial average stood at 2,981.68, down 18.07 points.
The bellwether Dow average has, in fact, pierced the barrier several times since it first broke through last Friday but it has never been able to hold above that level until the close of a trading day, and, the record does not really count until it does.
Trading volume slumped a bit, to 168.8 million shares, from 176.8 million the day before. Stocks that fell outnumbered those that gained by 1,030 to 483. 60 Stocks at New Lows Sixty stocks set new lows, including Polaroid, the instant-photo camera company. After reporting a 23 percent drop in profits, it slid 3 1/4 to close at 36 in heavy trading; during the day it reached a new low of 35 1/4. 
''Three thousand is giving people pause,'' said Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman. ''It's just a psychological constraint. We're going into territory we've never been before, and that makes people pause and think if stocks are expensive at these levels.''
David B. Bostian, chief economist for Jesup, Josephthal & Company, said, ''You've had three attempts'' to reach 3,000 ''and they failed.''
Referring to statements before the Senate Banking Committee yesterday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, he added, ''And there was nothing in Greenspan's testimony that the market could read into the lowering of interest rates,'' a move that would send the market up again.
Mr. Bostian said that ''the euphoria'' over the easing of interest rates last Friday ''is now over'' and ''there's no immediate prospect of a further reduction.''
Moreover, he argued, investors might soon begin to focus on the budget talks in Washington, with their ''risk of tax increases'' and the posssibility that if Congress and the Administration are unable to negotiate an agreement, automatic spending cuts would be imposed by law.
 
Transportation Issues Tumble
Along with the decline in the Dow industrials, the Dow transportation stocks tumbled 16.06, to 1,171.53. UAL rose 1/2, to 162 1/2, after its nonunion workers joined in a union effort to buy the air carrier, but AMR, parent of American Airlines, fell 2 7/8, to 61 5/8, after reporting lower second-quarter profits. Delta Air Lines fell 2 3/8, to 73, after Paul P. Karos, airline analyst at the First Boston Corporation, cut his earnings estimates for Delta and AMR. Conrail fell 1 3/8, to 49 5/8, after reporting lower profits.
Among the industrials, United Technologies, which fell 1 1/2, to 60 1/2, was the only Dow blue chip to sink as much as a point. A.T.&T. rose 1/8, to 37 1/8; Coca-Cola rose 1/8, to 47 3/8; Philip Morris fell 3/8, to 50 1/8, and I.B.M. fell 7/8, to 119 7/8, all in heavy trading.
United Telecommunications, the phone company, which fell 8 3/4 Tuesday after reporting a 55 percent drop in profits, topped the New York Stock Exchange active list for the second day, falling another 2 1/4, to 27 1/4, with 10.03 million shares changing hands.
MCI, the long-distance company, which fell 1 5/8 Tuesday, fell another 1 7/8, to 36 1/2, on nearly 13 million shares, making it the most heavily traded stock in yesterday's over-the-counter trading.
Century Telephone rose 1 1/4, to 32 1/4, in a weak telephone group. Bell Atlantic fell 1, to 45 3/8; Nynex fell 1 1/8, to 78 1/8, and Rochester Telephone fell 1 3/8, to 32 5/8.
Drug stocks also weakened. Warner Lambert fell 1 7/8, to 67 1/4, and American Home Products fell 2 1/8, to 52 1/4, despite higher profits. Lilly fell 3 7/8, to 85, after a New York woman charged in a suit that its drug Prozac made her try to kill herself. But Pfizer rose 2, to 71 1/4, and Upjohn rose 2 3/8, to 43 7/8, a new high, after favorable earnings reports.
Birinyi Associates said heavy program trading - largely selling -clipped nearly 19 points off the Dow. The S.&P. 500 index fell 3.30, to 364.22; the Nasdaq composite index fell 3.66, to 460.82, and the Amex market-value index fell 2.33, to 362.06.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Higher in U.S.; Gold Prices Are Down a Bit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher in choppy trading yesterday after falling overseas, as Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, failed to erase confusion over American interest rates.
Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $361.60 an ounce, down 40 cents from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $361.10, off 60 cents. 
In discussing monetary policy before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan said rates would not be lowered soon except to offset unusually restrictive commercial lending practices.
Some currency dealers said they interpreted the remarks to mean that a drop in rates was forthcoming. But others said the remarks confused the markets.
 
'Playing With Words'
''We're not quite sure what Greenspan is up to,'' a London dealer said. ''He appears to be playing with words, which could be dangerous.''
Adding to the confusion was a report from the Labor Department showing that consumer prices had climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in June, more than double the rate of the last two months.
In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell to 147.25 Japanese yen, from 148.20 yen on Tuesday. It traded at 147.45 yen in London, and at 147.765 yen in New York, down from 147.80 yen.
The dollar was mixed against the pound compared with late Tuesday's figure. Sterling traded at $1.8205 in London, up from $1.8115, and at $1.81525 in New York, down from $1.8165.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, were: 1.6480 German marks, up from 1.6440; 1.41585 Swiss francs, up from 1.4048; 5.5285 French francs, up from 5.5155; 1,207.00 Italian lire, up from 1,204.25, and 1.15425 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15295.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $360.25 an ounce, from $361.25 on Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to $359.85 from $361.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell by $1.71, to $360.15.
Silver prices were up.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Co. Profit Dropped in the 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported yesterday that income in the second quarter fell to $26.8 million, or 35 cents a share, down 35.1 percent from net income of $41.3 million, or 53 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1989.
Second-quarter profits were down 31.6 percent from income from continuing operations of $39.2 million, or 50 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Times Company revenues rose 1.9 percent in the quarter, to $468.9 million, from $460.3 million in the comparable period last year. 
The company said the main reasons for its lower profits were lower advertising lineage at The New York Times, which reflected continuing weakness in the New York region's economy; a reduction of 7 cents a share as a result of acquiring McCall's magazine in July 1989, a deal structured to maximize cash flow, and a reduction of 8 cents a share because of higher depreciation and interest expense related to construction. The company completed the building for The New York Times's new color production and distribution plant in Edison, N.J., and it built a plant for The Gwinnett Daily News in Georgia, one of its regional newspapers.
Eric Philo, a publishing analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the earnings were a little better than expected in part because of the performance of the regional newspapers. But he said economic weakness was spreading to other parts of the country, and he does not expect the regional papers to show the growth in the second half that they showed in the quarter.
 
Two Special Items
The Times Company said that except for the acquisition of McCall's and the construction expenses, second-quarter earnings would have equaled the results from continuing operations a year earlier.
The company said operating profit in this year's second quarter for the newspaper group declined to $50.1 million from $67 million in the second quarter of 1989. The group consists of The New York Times, 35 regional newspapers and a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune.
Advertising volume at The New York Times declined 13.4 percent, to 24.7 million lines, in the second quarter. Average circulation for The Times in the first half reached new highs of 1,133,400 copies on weekdays, up 45,700 copies, and 1,713,200 on Sundays, up 65,100 copies.
Advertising volume for the 35 regional newspapers increased 2.5 percent, to 9.7 million inches, in the second quarter. Circulation also increased at the regional newspapers, to 880,200 copies on Sundays, up 16,900 copies, and to 901,700 copies on weekdays, up 19,700 copies. Circulation was 77,400 for the non-dailies, up 1,000 copies.
Profits from the company's Magazine Group were down because of the acquisition of McCall's, while results from the Broadcasting/Information Service Group held even and earnings in the Forest Products Group declined, reflecting softness in the newsprint market and unfavorable Canadian currency exchange rates.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Kohl Gets German Spotlight But Genscher Had the Vision

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, July 19

 BODY:
The man of the hour of German unity may be Chancellor Helmut Kohl, but the man who first saw it coming is certainly Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher.
In the mid-1980's when almost everybody else distrusted the gleam of ''new thinking'' in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's eye, Mr. Genscher was urging Mr. Kohl and skeptical Western leaders to take the new leader at his word and seize the opportunity to end the division of Europe and Germany.
When the breakthrough was announced at a spa in the Northern Caucasus on Monday - and the Soviet leader said that he had agreed to a united Germany in the NATO alliance - Mr. Gorbachev paid tribute to the 50 hours of meetings between Mr. Genscher and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union that paved the way.
For the man who has been West German Foreign Minister for 16 years -and a man who had been accused more than once of being willing to sell out a Chancellor, or even the whole Western alliance if it would assure success for his own small Free Democratic Party - it was a moment of quiet satisfaction. 
 
'Both Need Each Other'
''Kohl and Genscher are both too self-important and ambitious not to begrudge each other a success that each feels he earned on his own,'' said one official who knows both of them. ''But both need each other and know it too well to let it show too openly.''
Mr. Genscher never criticizes Mr. Kohl in public, but there is considerable sparring behind the scenes.
When Mr. Kohl named one of his own aides, Horst Teltschik, as his personal representative to Poland last year, Mr. Genscher was furious, his aides say, and he blocked the Chancellor from giving the aide the same assignment to Czechoslovakia.
Mr. Genscher's aides say that he nearly split the coalition Government in early 1989 by repeatedly saying that NATO should not deploy new American short-range nuclear missiles here to replace the old Lance system. Finally, Mr. Kohl went along with Mr. Genscher and President Bush acquiesced.
This spring, while Mr. Kohl was hesitating to rule out a change in the German-Polish border after unification, Mr. Genscher kept saying that anybody who did not rule out a change was damaging the cause of German unity.
Mr. Kohl finally came around on that one, too.
 
Satisfaction of Being Right
''It is not very often given to a politician to turn out to be right,'' Mr. Genscher said a few days ago. ''Even less often it happens while he's still alive, and yet more rarely while he's still in office. I have the advantage of all three together.''
It is not gratitude or personal warmth but political necessity that keeps Mr. Kohl and Mr. Genscher together, their aides say, in a coalition that Mr. Kohl may no longer think he needs if he can win an absolute majority of votes in the all-German elections that are now planned for Dec. 2.
Until he does, he will continue to need the 63-year-old Mr. Genscher, who grew up in Halle and has been dreaming of making Germany whole again ever since it was partitioned by the Allies, leaving Halle in the Soviet Zone, later East Germany.
Taken prisoner by the United States Army the day before the war ended and held briefly, Mr. Genscher, who had been drafted into the Wehrmacht, returned to his mother in Halle and moved to the West in 1952 as a politically active lawyer.
 
Christmas Visits to East
Mr. Genscher began making annual private Christmas visits back to Halle after it became possible in the early 1970's, even after he became Interior Minister in 1969 and Foreign Minister in 1974.
For years he has endured innuendo about the reasons for his ''soft'' approach to the Soviet Union, both inside and outside his country.
During the Reagan Administration, Richard R. Burt, the American Ambassador to Bonn, described the Foreign Minister as ''slippery.'' Mr. Genscher's relationship with Secretary of State George P. Shultz was terrible, diplomats who observed these things say.
With unification fast approaching, Mr. Genscher's trips home have become even more frequent. On Friday, he is going back to Halle for the second time in two weeks, to mingle with crowds that consider him a big hero, bringing local entrepreneurs and West German bankers together to discuss how to rebuild the East German economy and speaking about foreign policy to students of the Martin Luther University summer school.
 
An Active World Traveler
Here in West Germany, Mr. Genscher is far more popular than either his party or his Chancellor, according to all the major public opinion polls. The catalogue of his diplomatic trips around the world now takes up 11 single-spaced, small-print pages in one recent book about him.
Mr. Genscher, now often affectionately described by grateful citizens as ''Genschman,'' has not always been so popular. In September 1982, he withdrew his Free Democrats from a 13-year coalition with the Social Democratic Party, bringing down Helmut Schmidt as Chancellor and incurring his undying contempt.
By switching allegiance to the Christian Democrats, Mr. Genscher brought Mr. Kohl to power. His high-profile foreign policy has helped his party survive, though the pace has taken its toll on him. In frail health ever since a long bout of tuberculosis after the war, he suffered a heart attack last summer that took him out of action for weeks.
Next Monday, before an intense fall schedule, he will attend the opening of the Bayreuth Festival - Wagner's ''Der Fliegende Hollander'' - and retreat later in the week to a vacation home in Berchtesgaden, in the Bavarian Alps, until the middle of August.
 
Clues From Gorbachev in 1986
Mr. Genscher apparently formed his view that Mr. Gorbachev might deliver the key to German unity during his first encounter with the Soviet leader in the summer of 1986.
A few months later, Mr. Kohl sent German-Soviet relations into a deep freeze by comparing, in an interview with a West German magazine, Mr. Gorbachev's public relations skills with those of the Nazi propaganda chief, Joseph Goebbels.
But on Feb. 1 of the following year, in a speech in Davos, Switzerland, Mr. Genscher sounded prophetic: ''If there should be a chance today that, after 40 years of East-West confrontation, there could be a turning point in East-West relations, it would be a mistake of historical dimension for the West to let this chance slip just because it cannot escape from a way of thinking which invariably expects the worst from the Soviet Union.''
''Let us not sit back idly and wait for Mr. Gorbachev to deliver,'' Mr. Genscher said. ''Let us rather try to influence, expedite and shape developments from our end.''
''Our motto can only be, he went on, 'Let us take Mr. Gorbachev seriously. let us take him at his word,' ''
 
Three Years of Achievements
What he proposed instead sounds remarkably similar to what he and Mr. Kohl have largely achieved three years later - a comprehensive package of arms reductions, an all-European security structure building on the mechanisms set up in 1975 by the Helsinki Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, large-scale Western financial help for the Soviet Union to modernize its economy and a gradual end to the divisions of the Continent.
NATO has accepted most of this now, agreeing to study the aid question while letting Germany go ahead and provide what it can already. But only a little more than a year ago, Mr. Genscher was suspected in many NATO capitals of being an apostle of appeasement, for which ''Genscherism'' became the synonym. Now, Mr. Genscher jokes, it's a mass movement.
But in April 1989, Mr. Genscher raised eyebrows in the West German Parliament during a debate on new short-range nuclear missiles.
''We are talking about systems that can reach the territory of Poland and Czechoslovakia,'' he said and added, in reference to East Germany, missiles that could reach ''the other part of our Fatherland.''
This, he stressed, despite the fact that all West German officials had sworn an oath to provide for the well-being of the German people.
''The obligation deriving from that oath does not stop at the border cutting through Germany,'' he said then. ''The responsibility for the nation established by that oath does not exclude my native region, the town where I was born, nor the people in the G.D.R. Indeed, it includes them.''
A turning point, his aides say, was his role in negotiating free passage out of Czechoslovakia and Hungary last fall for thousands of East Germans who had taken refuge in the West German embassies. Aides who accompanied them on trains through East Germany said it was clear from the cheering by East Germans along the rail line that the Iron Curtain was cracking and was bound to break.
Mr. Genscher, in the West German Embassy in Prague, described the moment of freedom as ''the most beautiful moment of my political career.''

He and Chancellor Helmut Kohl, left, ''need each other,'' a German official said, ''and know it too well to let it show too openly.'' (Reuters) (pg. A6)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 20, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1548 words

HEADLINE: Higher Fares, Less Reward: New York Cabs Hit a Slump

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The taxi industry in New York City has undergone sweeping changes in the last 18 months that have made the business less rewarding for drivers and owners.
Some of the changes result from enforcing regulations aimed at improving service and deterring fare-gouging. Drivers complain that the enforcement campaign has made their jobs more difficult and more expensive.
At the same time, an economic slump in the city has virtually wiped out the benefits for drivers of a Jan. 7 fare increase because there are fewer customers.
 
Leasing Fees Rise
While there are no official statistics on taxi ridership, dozens of drivers interviewed last week said the increase, which averaged 12 percent, did not add to their earnings because medallion owners pocketed much of the increase by raising their leasing fees. 
For owners, the industry's distress is reflected in a highly unusual decline in the value of medallions for at least half of the city's 11,787 taxis.
One new rule from the Taxi and Limousine Commission has had a far-reaching impact - a rule that forces new owners of single-cab medallions to drive their cabs full time. The rule has made the medallions less desirable investments and has reduced their value.
Industry experts say that a single-cab medallion, which sold last year for a record $144,000, has lost 10 percent of its value and is now selling for less than $129,000 - the first time that medallion prices have ever dropped after a fare increase. Taxi commission officials said a broker reported selling a medallion last week for $119,000.
The number of medallions has been frozen since 1937. Half are reserved for fleet operators and half for owners of single cabs. Only medallion cabs may legally cruise for passengers in most of Manhattan.
As part of its enforcement campaign, the commission is issuing summonses for violations of safety rules, dress codes and other regulations that had long been virtually ignored. While the crackdown is aimed at improving service and is not expected to result in any shortages of drivers or cabs, many cabbies contend the changes are so onerous that they will ultimately force some of the best drivers out of business.
 
Aggressive Enforcement
''The Taxi Commission has taken away the incentive for people to buy a medallion as an investment, and it has effectively discouraged drivers who want to buy a medallion and drive it short term,'' said Nat Goldbetter, vice president of Medallion Transfer Inc., a New York taxi brokerage. ''The agency is also bombing guys with summonses and making life extremely difficult and driving guys to go into other occupations.''
Cabdrivers, medallion brokers and some industry officials blame the decline in medallion values and what they say are their financial woes on the aggressive enforcement of regulations initiated by Jack S. Lusk, who became Commissioner in 1988.
After taking over, Mr. Lusk began driving cabs occasionally to try to determine ways to improve service. In doing so, he noticed what he thought were areas that could be improved through stricter enforcement of commission regulations. Mr. Lusk has said that enforcement would improve the appearance and maintenance of cabs and the quality of service.
 
Overcharging Customers
Since then, the number of summonses issued to taxi drivers has increased markedly. In the fiscal year that ended in June 1989, the commission handed out 86,691 summonses, 81 percent more than the 48,000 issued in the fiscal year 1988. For the 1990 fiscal year, ended in June, the commission issued 113,350 summonses.
The most common summonses have been for overcharging customers, an offense that carries a $100 minimum fine; failure to bring a vehicle in for inspection, $100 minimum, and refusing to pick up a customer, $200 minimum.
In the weakening economy, the increase in leasing rates that followed the fare increase delivered another serious blow.
The Taxi Commission estimates that leasing rates for fleet taxis increased by about 9 percent for daytime drivers and by about 6 percent for nighttime drivers. As a result, drivers who work during the day should have kept about 60 percent of the fare increase and drivers who work at night about 75 percent, the commission said.
But taxi-leasing officials and fleet owners said that while leasing rates have risen only marginally compared to the taxi fare increase, their drivers have been hurt by the slow economy and layoffs in the financial services industry.
The recent increase in the motor vehicle tax for medallion cabs to $1,000 a year from $100 on Dec. 1, 1989 - has also cut into profits.
 
Decline in Value
''We are aware that business is off substantially across the board, especially at night so that the drivers are probably not making as much as was anticipated at the time of the fare raise,'' said Betty Lawrence, executive director of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, which represents 18 taxi fleets.
The cabbies say driving a taxicab was more attractive when people knew they could save up enough to buy a medallion, then lease it full time. Often, they said, drivers bought medallions intending to operate cabs for a few years and then lease the medallion to other drivers. The medallion became an extremely lucrative investment, and its price skyrocketed from $60,000 in 1980 to a high of $144,000 in 1989 because of the leasing power.
Under the new rule, owners of individual medallions bought after January must drive the cabs themselves at least 210 nine-hour shifts a year. Leasing is allowed at other times.
''This is not the way it was supposed to be,'' said Eddy Jacques, a 26-year-old cabby from Brooklyn who after only three years is getting out of the taxi business to become a bank teller. ''Owning a medallion just isn't worth it, man. No matter how hard you work you'll always be tied to the driver's seat.''
 
Little Sympathy
Since the new ownership rules went into effect on Jan. 1, business has been off by about 50 percent at Medallion Transfer, the brokerage, which last year sold about 120 medallions but expects to make only 60 transactions this year, Mr. Goldbetter said. ''We get a lot of inquiries but very few buyers, especially when people learn of the new rule,'' he said.
Frands Fequiere, a 35-year-old taxi driver and medallion owner from the Bronx, said he paid $60,000 for his medallion in 1980. He now says that he regrets not selling it last year when the market was at a high and there were plenty of buyers.
''Now, no one wants to buy, and I am starting to lose all the equity that I built up over the last decade,'' Mr. Fequiere said. ''Jack Lusk has dismantled the the business side of the taxi industry.''
Mr. Lusk displays scant sympathy for the complaints of those who possess medallions or hope to own them. ''As a regulator, my job is not to be worried about the price of a medallion,'' he said. ''Our major concern is that passengers get a safe, clean, comfortable ride to their destination.''
Mr. Lusk said consumers - many of whom have grown accustomed to dirty cabs and drivers who speak little English and do not know the city - are seeing an improvement in the quality of service and the condition of cabs.
 
Professor's View
He attributes the change to the commission's new inspection center in Woodside, Queens, where taxis are required to undergo a rigorous battery of tests three times a year to insure among other things that meters are properly calibrated and the vehicle is correctly aligned. He also cites tougher English and geography tests that are given to new drivers.
Prof. Elizabeth Roistacher, an economist at Queens College who studies the taxi industry, said she gives Mr. Lusk high marks for the stringent ownership requirements and increased enforcement.
''Absentee ownership, where a medallion owner doesn't drive the cab, shifts all the responsibility to the driver who has little interest in providing good service,'' Professor Roistacher said. ''But people who operate their own cabs take better care of them and their customers.''
An average cabdriver who leases a medallion can net from $500 to $700 in a five-day week working from 10 to 11 hours a day. Cabbies who own a medallion make a little more, netting about $960 a week for 11 hours' work. But they must subtract payments on the financing of their medallions, which average about $375 a week.
Victor Vega, 48, who has been driving a cab for 14 years, said that in the last month commission inspectors have twice issued him summonses for ''trivial'' violations, including his allowing a passenger to leave his cab at the airport before reaching the curb. Mr. Vega said the passenger had insisted on getting out. ''If you are ugly, you get a ticket in this business,'' Mr. Vega said.
Some drivers say that low pay, long hours and increasing crime are driving them to pursue other jobs and that the commission needs to find ways to make driving a taxi a more desirable career.
''I think in the end the consumer is not getting the better service because they are not getting the best possible drivers,'' Mr. Goldbetter said. ''If life was easier, they would attract better drivers. In London, the cabdriver is treated as a professional, but here they are treated like dirt.''

HEADLINE: China Faults U.S. Shift on Cambodia

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 19

 BODY:
China issued a stern and disappointed response today to the American announcement that Washington was withdrawing support for China's closest ally in Cambodia and beginning direct talks with Vietnam, China's bitterest rival in Asia.
Jin Guihua, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said China would stand by its current policy and continue to back its ally, the Communist Khmer Rouge. The Khmer Rouge are one of the three groups in the guerrilla coalition fighting the Cambodian Government of Hun Sen, which is backed by Vietnam.
''So long as Vietnam does not genuinely withdraw all its troops from Cambodia, China will continue to support the Cambodian people in their resistance against the foreign invaders and their just struggle for national independence,'' Mr. Jin said at a briefing today. 
On Wednesday in Paris, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced that the United States was withdrawing its support for the Cambodian guerrilla coalition including the Khmer Rouge, who caused the deaths of more than a million Cambodians during their rule in the 1970's.
 
Ties With Hanoi Possible
Mr. Baker said the change in policy was necessary to prevent the return to power of the Khmer Rouge, and the Administration also signaled that the talks with Vietnam could eventually lead to a restoration of American diplomatic relations with Hanoi.
Today Mr. Jin made it clear that China considered it a grave mistake to favor Vietnam over the guerrilla groups, since Vietnam's invasion and continued presence in Cambodia are, in the Chinese view, the principal cause of the draining conflict in the poverty-stricken country.
China was joined in its implicit criticism of the United States by other Asian officials. Foreign Minister Ali Alatas of Indonesia, the current chairman of the six-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which has been a sponsor of peace talks, said, ''We sincerely doubt whether at this stage of negotiation such a move would help toward reaching a comprehensive solution that is mutually acceptable.'' [The official Vietnam News Agency quoted Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, as approving of the American move, the Associated Press reported. Mr. Thach was quoted as saying Hanoi wanted ''an early, fair and equitable solution'' and ''is ready to negotiate with concerned countries on the Cambodia issue.''] Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of one of the two non-Communist groups in the guerrilla coalition, issued a statement from North Korea, where he lives part of the year. He condemned the American move as a ''very serious injustice'' that would only stiffen the guerrillas' resolve to carry on their military campaign.
 
China's Words Are Measured
While the Chinese response today was stern, it was also measured, and Mr. Jin reiterated positive remarks about progress being made in United Nations-sponsored talks on the Cambodian problem. Noting that ''differences of view still exist,'' Mr. Jin said progress had been made at the most recent session of the talks, held Tuesday in Paris.
This appeared to leave open the possibility that a more elaborate deal might be under negotiation between the United States, China, Vietnam, the Soviet Union and other parties.
There were no direct signs that such a deal might be in the works, but some diplomats expressed surprise that such a harsh American blow to the Chinese position had not brought stronger language or action from Beijing.
The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman did hint that China may fight the American shift in the United Nations, where the guerrilla coalition holds the seat for Cambodia.
Mr. Jin noted that the guerrilla coalition groups have had the support of more than 100 other nations in their desire to keep the seat from being given to the Hun Sen Government. He added that the seat ''should not be left vacant'' before a political solution to the conflict is reached.
Asked about Mr. Baker's announcement that the United States would start talks with Vietnam over Cambodia, Mr. Jin said, ''This is a matter between the United States and Vietnam.'' $100 Million in Chinese Support American officials estimate that China provides as much as $100 million a year in military and other support to the Khmer Rouge, which has the largest and most powerful force among the guerrillas.
Diplomats here said today that China's resistance to a direct Vietnamese role has been bolstered by the fact that recent Chinese attempts to negotiate with Hanoi had apparently failed to do anything but leave a trail of hurt feelings and hardened positions. After a meeting in Hanoi and another in Beijing this year between the enemies, Chinese officials came out of the meetings saying the Vietnamese were intransigent and rude, the diplomats said.
Mr. Jin said today that the Hun Sen Government and Vietnam had taken a ''rigid pose'' in the talks and had resisted ''reasonable formulas'' for achieving peace.
 
U.S. Official Is Hopeful
WASHINGTON, July 19 - A senior Bush Administration official today expressed hope that the Chinese criticism of United States policy would not influence what he called China's increasingly helpful position in talks seeking free elections in Cambodia.
''I would prefer to look at their actions around the negotiating tables rather than at their public comments,'' he said. ''We have taken every opportunity to tell the Chinese that they have an important role to play in bringing peace to Cambodia. It is very crucial to get the Chinese to back the process since they are only ones who can bring the pressure to bear on the Khmer Rouge.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prince Norodom Sihanouk condemned the United States decision to withdraw recognition of the Cambodian guerrilla coalition. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Manila Assesses Damage and High Cost of Quake

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, July 19

 BODY:
As the generally fruitless and frustrating search for survivors of Monday's earthquake continued today, Philippine officials began to assess the physical damage and weigh the costs of reconstruction.
By tonight, the official count was 429 dead and 1,225 injured. And Defense Secretary Fidel V. Ramos said the death toll could rise to 1,000, including scores of people believed to be entombed in landslides along Kennon Road, the highway that leads to Baguio, the resort city 120 miles north of Manila that was hardest hit by the earthquake. [A United States Marine plane helping in rescue operations crashed on Friday near Baguio, The Associated Press reported. One crew member was reportedly killed when the OV-1 observation plane from Subic Bay naval base crashed into the mountains.] Even four days after the earthquake, reports of destruction in isolated areas trickled in. In Nueva Vizcaya Province, 100 miles northeast of Manila, about 30 miles of the Dalton Pass, which cuts through the Sierra Madre range, was reported buried in mud slides. 
Finance Secretary Jesus Estanislao said today that Manila would ask the World Bank for loans, and the president of the Asian Development Bank, Kimihasa Taiumiza, said that the bank would rush the release of already approved loans for school buildings, power lines, roads and bridges.
 
Three Hotels Collapse
Private economists said the Government would have to rechannel funds intended for new projects to repair the earthquake damage.
In Baguio 28 buildings collapsed, including three large hotels, several factories and a university building. The power and water supply systems were badly damaged. Officials said it could take as long as 20 years for the city to recover from the devastation.
American, British and Japanese rescue teams used dogs and heat-sensing equipment to search for survivors in Baguio's hotels and factories. But heavy rains and continuing aftershocks hampered the search.
As the day ended, the teams recovered only corpses. The hope of finding survivors among the scores trapped in the wreckage of Baguio was fading fast. But hundreds looking for missing relatives and friends continued to keep vigil, huddling underneath plastic tents in the hard rain.
 
A.I.D. Official's Body Found
Rescuers today found the body of an official with the United States Agency for International Development in the rubble of the Nevada Hotel. An agency official said 27 of 65 participants in an A.I.D.-sponsored conference at the hotel were thought to be dead. Rescue teams left the site today, having given up hope of finding survivors.
While the painstaking rescue efforts continued, thousands of survivors continued to leave Baguio, most of them traveling on foot down a mountain road still partly buried in landslides. Military transport planes evacuated hundreds of Philippine and foreign tourists from the city. Hundreds more crowded the airport, begging to be flown out.

HEADLINE: GOV. DUKAKIS SIGNS INCREASE IN TAXES

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 19

 BODY:
Given a push by an opinion from the state's highest court, a package of tax increases totaling more than $1 billion and intended to solve Massachusetts' fiscal crisis has been signed into law by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.
Mr. Dukakis, who campaigned for the Presidency two years ago on the economic performance of the ''Massachusetts miracle,'' signed the bill in private Wednesday, with no fanfare.
''This is not something to celebrate,'' he said later. 
The measure raises state income and gasoline taxes and extends the state's 5 percent sales tax to numerous business services, virtually all of which have been exempted until now. It is expected to generate $1.2 billion in the current fiscal year, which began July 1, and $1.8 billion next year.
State officials said residents would start feeling the effects of the law within 10 days at the gasoline pump, where the tax will rise 10 cents a gallon, and would start seeing larger withholding from their paychecks within three weeks.
 
Court Opinion on Sales Tax
Proponents of the measure had argued that it was needed to help pay off a $1 billion deficit in the state's $12.8 billion budget for the fiscal year that ended June 30 and to help balance a budget for the current year that has not yet been passed by the Legislature but is expected to total $13.6 billion.
But the $500-million-a-year provision that extended the sales tax to services was vigorously opposed by business leaders and professionals, who argued that the State Constitution provided for a tax only on ''commodities'' and therefore implictly exempted services.
As a result, the Governor delayed signing the bill until he could get an advisory opinion from the Supreme Judicial Court, the state's highest judicial body. In a 4-to-3 opinion issued Tuesday, the court cleared the way for the law, holding that the word ''commodities'' was not limited ''to tangible personal property.''

HEADLINE: We'll Be Sorry if Japan's Money Stays at Home

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One can only applaud the provisions of the new United States trade agreement with the Japanese (front page, June 29), aimed at giving our goods and services a fair opportunity to compete in their market. I suggest, however, that we will one day regret their agreement, on which we insisted, substantially to increase their domestic investments - in roads, houses and the like - if they live up to that part of the bargain.
Our purpose in persuading them to invest more of their savings and use more of their output at home has, of course, been to cut down their export surplus with us, running around $50 billion a year. 
But, as the Japanese Finance Ministry has been remonstrating (Business Day, June 25), the world's capital shortage is getting worse, if anything, with increased demands for savings, and increased opportunities to invest in Eastern Europe and to buy the state-owned enterprises up for sale all over Latin America.
Increased domestic spending within Japan has produced a mild acceleration of inflation, accompanied by the inevitable rising interest rates. And that has meant rising interest rates everywhere: for example, Japanese investors have apparently sold more United States Government securities this year than they bought. Similarly, West German long-term interest rates have moved above ours despite a lower inflation rate -partly because of the cost of subsidizing the East Germans. No wonder our interest rates remain stubbornly high and the Federal Reserve Board feels unable to pursue a more relaxed monetary policy, though our economy has slowed.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady is reported to have said the new demands for capital in Europe ''should not be confused'' with the need for countries like Japan to bring down their trade surpluses, by increasing investments at home.
His position is schizophrenic. The world needs their savings, he recognizes, but we insist they invest more of them at home because we don't want their trade surpluses. That is arithmetically impossible: the way -the only way - in which any country invests or lends abroad is by exporting more goods and services than it imports.
 
ALFRED E. KAHN
 Ithaca, N.Y., July 3, 1990
The writer retired as the Julius Thorne Professor of Political Economy at Cornell University.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 755 words

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
When Reality Dawns

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

 BODY:
Representative Stephen Solarz of New York has been a principal shaper and supporter of American policy on Cambodia for years. The policy has been to isolate the Hun Sen Government in Phnom Penh as a Vietnamese puppet, aid two small non-Communist guerrilla forces, urge them into coalition with the Khmer Rouge and give the coalition Cambodia's seat at the United Nations.
Because Mr. Solarz is a thoughtful politician, and sensitive on human rights, friends wondered why he backed a policy that in effect seemed to help the murderous Khmer Rouge. His answer was that the only way to contain the Khmer Rouge was through a political settlement. 
Three weeks ago, in a telephone conversation, I asked Mr. Solarz about reports of Khmer Rouge military advances near Phnom Penh. What if the Hun Sen Government falls to the Khmer Rouge? I asked.
''That would be a great tragedy and disaster,'' he replied. ''At that point either Vietnam would have to send its forces back into Cambodia, or there would have to be some kind of international force. I personally would be prepared to support any kind of international police action, but as a practical matter it would be very difficult to put together any kind of consortium of countries.''
What a paradoxical answer, I thought. The United States has been doing all it can to weaken the Hun Sen Government - supporting two of its opponents, imposing economic sanctions, even forbidding humanitarian groups to help the destitute in Phnom Penh. Yet if that Government falls, and the Khmer Rouge inevitably takes over, it would be a ''tragedy'' calling for military intervention.
Mr. Solarz's answer showed, in short, that American policy has been disconnected from its own logical end. No doubt we were sincere in wanting a diplomatic solution; certainly Mr. Solarz was. But the actual effect of the policy on the ground was to improve chances for the return of Pol Pot and the other Khmer Rouge leaders who presided over the death of one million Cambodians.
That reality was recognized by Secretary of State Baker when he announced a change of policy on Cambodia. One sentence of his told the story: ''We want to do everything we can to prevent a return of the Khmer Rouge to power.''
The United States will now seek to oust the coalition dominated by the Khmer Rouge from the U.N. seat. It will apparently encourage humanitarian assistance to Cambodia. An American delegation headed by Assistant Secretary of State Richard H. Solomon will ''open a dialogue'' with Vietnam, as Mr. Baker put it, in talks at the United Nations.
Comment on the change of policy attributed it to growing pressures on the Bush Administration. Congress had become restive about Cambodia. Last month the Senate Intelligence Committee voted to cut off covert aid to the non-Communist resistance. The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, has been a strong voice for change. The reports of Khmer Rouge military gains were sobering.
But all that amounts to saying that the Bush Administration yielded to reality. And surely that is a credit. Far better to understand the possible consequences of a mistaken policy, and change, than to pursue it mindlessly for fear of seeming to admit a mistake.
The Bush Administration deserves credit for realism in another respect. This shift in policy directly reflects a recognition that the cold war is over.
American policy on Cambodia has been driven to a considerable extent by resentment at the outcome of the Vietnam War. We regarded Phnom Penh as not only a Vietnamese but a Soviet outpost. But this week Secretary Baker had a productive talk about Cambodia with Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze.
Exactly what the new American position will mean in practice remains to be seen, and one should maintain a certain skepticism. Still less does it give any assurance of peace to the Cambodians. That still depends on diplomacy.
The current diplomatic proposal is for the United Nations to take charge in Cambodia while an election is organized. Neither Hun Sen nor the Khmer Rouge has so far endorsed the idea. China, the crucial outside force, has said what sounds like yes. Perhaps the Bush Administration will be able to persuade Vietnam on a U.N. role. Perhaps it will put its friendship with China to good use, though Beijing reacted critically to Secretary Baker's announcement.
There are big ifs, and the hour is late. But at least the United States seems to be on the right side now, committed above all to keeping the Khmer Rouge out of power.

HEADLINE: From Rust Belt to Money Belt in Buffalo

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: BUFFALO, July 19

 BODY:
There are not many bright spots in the New York economy these days, and one of the few can be found in the unlikeliest of places: Buffalo.
Often victimized in the past by its Frost Belt geography, Buffalo has become the sudden beneficiary of its location across the Niagara River from Canada. Two streams of financial fortune, one from an overheated economy in nearby Toronto and the other from the 1988 free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada, have insulated western New York from the financial troubles afflicting much of the nation.
While New York and many other states are edging perilously close to recession, Buffalo is brimming with the self-confident boosterism of a boom town.
''For a long time, Buffalonians have had a problem with themselves,'' said Dennis T. Gorski, the Erie County Executive. ''We didn't expand our chests. We were embarrassed by the snow jokes on the Johnny Carson show. That is not the case today. People are genuinely sanguine and proud of the resurgence here.'' 
 
Gateway to American Market
The monthly unemployment rate in the Buffalo area is 4.6 percent. In March it fell below the state average for the first time in 11 years. Job growth in the Buffalo region, which is defined as Erie and Niagara Counties, has outpaced the state average in each of the last four years. At 2.8 percent, it was almost triple the state rate last year.
Economists and business figures disagree about whether the revitalization has been fueled mostly by the trade agreement or by Toronto's economic conditions, but the effect has been the same. Canadian prospectors have looked south and seen western New York as a source of cheap real estate and affordable labor and as a gateway to the huge American market opening to them.
The same phenomenon has been seen in other border towns across the country, like Port Huron, Mich., and Plattsburg, N.Y. But Buffalo has also made itself more resistant to hard times with a significant expansion of its service sector. The economy's diversification, which took place relatively quickly, saved the region from what many feared would be a death blow when the area lost nearly a third of its manufacturing jobs during the last decade.
It would be hard to overstate the sense of despair that enveloped western New York during the late 1970's and early 1980's. Headlines then seemed like dirges. When they finished mourning the blizzard of 1977, which killed stranded drivers in their cars, they began tolling the deaths of steel mills and factories. As a symbol of the Rust Belt, the city's national image and sense of worth suffered.
 
Stadium Unemployment Nights
In 1983, when the unemployment rate was 12 percent, the crumbling baseball stadium sponsored Unemployment Nights, in which discounted tickets were offered to jobless workers coming to see the minor league Bisons. A billboard erected near City Hall asked, ''Will the Last Worker Out of Western New York Please Turn Out the Light?''
''The waterfront was a wasteland,'' said Mayor James D. Griffin, who has run Buffalo for 13 years. ''Downtown looked like Seoul, Korea, back in the war. Nobody had any confidence in the city whatsoever.''
Today, the metaphors for western New York's recovery are just as abundant. Although the esthetic impact on Buffalo's uninspiring skyline has been marginal, banks are building glass and marble towers downtown. Pricey condominiums have been built along the lake front and all have been purchased.
The Bisons now play at Pilot Field, a 21,000-seat ballpark in downtown Buffalo that is three years old and has the timeless grace of Fenway Park and Wrigley Field. The Bisons set a minor league attendance record in 1988 by drawing nearly 1.2 million fans, more than saw the Chicago White Sox, the Seattle Mariners or the Atlanta Braves play that year.
 
Like the Set of 'Batman'
The city is waging a fanatical crusade to win one of two major league expansion teams in 1991, and is willing to double the size of the stadium if it does. Many see the commitment of the Bisons' owner, Robert E. Rich Jr., a frozen-food magnate, to buy a major league franchise at a potential cost of $100 million as the ultimate sign of confidence in the city's future.
From the upper deck of the stadium, one can see the hulking remains of the Bethlehem Steel mill that employed 22,000 workers at its peak before closing in 1983. The 1,400-acre site along Lake Erie looks like a set out of ''Batman,'' full of slag heaps, idle smokestacks and dark, decaying buildings.
But during the last five years, part of the site has been reclaimed. A locally based conglomerate, the Gateway Trade Center, bought 300 acres and established a commercial park, a port and a free-trade zone. Seventeen of the 24 companies operating in the free-trade zone are Canadian.
In suburban Cheektowaga and in Niagara Falls, expansive new malls have been built to capture Canadian shoppers who flock across the border to take advantage of lower prices, lower taxes and the strong Canadian dollar. There are plans to build a 1.5-million-square-foot factory outlet mall, reportedly the world's largest, within 100 yards of the falls next year. Franchised Chicken Wings? Because there are still limits on how much merchandise Canadians can take home without paying Customs duties, the visitors are often spotted stripping out of sweat suits and donning their new finery in mall parking lots to deceive Customs officials. When the free-trade agreement takes full effect in nine years, such machinations will become unnecessary.
The free-trade frenzy has even caught the attention of Dominic Bellissimo, whose mother, Teressa, invented Buffalo's famous chicken wings 26 years ago at the Anchor Bar, which he now owns. Mr. Bellissimo said he has been approached by Canadian businessmen about opening 35 chicken-wing stands in the Toronto area.
''God bless it,'' said Mr. Bellissimo, who currently serves 73,000 pounds of wings a month from the Anchor Bar. ''I wish mother was here to see it.''
The conventional wisdom among most economists and political leaders in the Buffalo area is that the free-trade agreement accelerated a comeback that had already started.
 
It Began in Canada
They say the impetus for investment in Buffalo was inflation, high taxes, and regulatory strictures in Ontario and specifically in Toronto, 100 miles away.
As the Greater Buffalo Chamber of Commerce gleefully points out, salaries, taxes, interest rates and real estate are significantly lower in western New York than in southern Ontario.
Sam Cole, director of the Center for Regional Studies at the State University of New York at Buffalo, asserts that the city is slowly becoming an economic suburb of Toronto. The two economies should become even more integrated as the free-trade agreement gradually eliminates tariffs.
Canada and the United States, which exchanged $167 billion in trade last year, are the world's largest trading partners. About 20 percent of that trade traveled over the four transnational bridges in the Buffalo Customs District, which ranks second only to Detroit in cross-border traffic.
 
Built for 'Comparatively Peanuts'
In the last three years, 90 Canadian companies have relocated or expanded in the Buffalo region, adding to the 375 already there, according to the Chamber of Commerce.
For Canadian businessmen like Edward R. Steger, president of Stetron International Inc., an electronics manufacturer, Buffalo seemed the ideal base for expansion into the American market. It was cheap, it was a two-hour drive from his headquarters in Toronto and the city and state had a record of generosity in offering tax abatements and low-interest loans.
''We built ourselves a beautiful building near downtown Buffalo for comparatively peanuts: $1 million,'' Mr. Steger said. ''In Toronto it might have cost $20 million.''
Mr. Steger, who bought one of the new lake front condominiums, said he will decide next year whether to build a 45,000-foot plant in Buffalo, which would expand his work force here from 12 to 150. An Illusory Recovery? Not everybody is bullish about the area's economic future. Some believe it is illusory because of the emphasis on service sector jobs, which on average pay 18 percent less than manufacturing jobs in New York State.
Because many younger residents left during the bad days, the population is smaller and older. Many black leaders say they believe that minorities have not shared equally in the comeback.
Others worry that the area does not have the roads and bridges to take advantage of the trade agreement. Trucks sometimes have to wait two hours to cross clogged bridges. The state is conducting a $500,000 study to analyze the cost of a new crossing.
But to most who lived through the bad years, the mere symbols of rebirth bring lasting joy. Satisfaction was on the face of 67-year-old Hank J. Kotlarz, who was laid off by his trucking company in 1984, as he watched the Bisons beat the Columbus Clippers at Pilot Field on a flawless Monday night.
''This is the best place in America to watch baseball and even with the inflation, you can afford to go to the games,'' he said. ''You won't catch me moving.''

HEADLINE: A Hudson Retreat Is Split by a Fight Over Development

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDGEWATER, N.J.

 BODY:
Joan Lawlor Reilly remembers taking the 125th Street Ferry across the Hudson River to this sliver of a waterfront town where her parents rented a shack and some sweet shade from a Dutchman named Goethius.
That was more than 50 years ago, and Ms. Lawlor Reilly, now 62, still lives here, although with additions and improvements over the years the shack is now a small house. But the land, incorporated in 1948 as a cooperative known as the Edgewater Colony, has gone through major changes.
There are still no sidewalks, no sewers and hardly any fences. All the land is owned by the 116 shareholders of the colony. But instead of the carefree rustic retreat it once was, the colony is contentious and divided. At the heart of the matter is a question any New York City co-op owner would recognize. Is the colony an investment or a home? 
The conflict started with a rumor that someone wanted to buy the colony.
''That's the whole thing that makes it so crazy,'' said Lucien A. Fontaine, the harness driver and a resident since 1984. ''There's no offer. But perhaps it's for the best, because the community is going to be stronger for it.''
Tucked into a jagged hillside in the shadow of the George Washington Bridge between River Road and the Hudson, the colony is one of the most unusual communities in the state. The entire 26 acres is owned cooperatively, and all but 30 shareholders live here.
Shareholders pay monthly maintenance fees for the land and equal portions of the property tax on the land. They own their houses and pay separately assessed property taxes on them.
The three roads in the community meander under tall densely canopied trees, sometimes turning back on themselves or leaving just barely enough room for an automobile to pass.
The homes make up an eccentric group. The tents that Ms. Lawlor Reilly remembers are gone, replaced by tar-paper shacks, expanded bungalows and California contemporaries costing more than $400,000 perched on rocky ledges with sweeping views of the river and Washington Heights.
In the late 1980's, when development swept much of the Hudson waterfront from the bridge to Jersey City, expensive houses were built in the colony, and many existing houses were modernized and expanded.
Over the last year a rumor, of which there are several versions, about an offer to buy the colony for $30 million or $58 million set residents chattering. There were also controversies brewing over how some people were spending too much or too little on their houses.
Mr. Fontaine and a group of shareholders, many relative newcomers, hired lawyers from big firms and spent more than $150,000 seeking a way to block a sale of the land to a developer.
Another group, which included many old-timers and elderly residents, insisted they had the right to sell, take the proceeds and move.
Older residents tended to favor a sale because they stood for the most part to make out very well. Because of the co-op status, the money would have been divided among the 116 shareholders. Those with big houses on the river would have received less than their houses were worth on the market, and those who owned shacks would have received substantially more.
Mr. Fontaine said he became involved because shareholders who did not live here were being allowed to vote in elections for the co-op board and would presumably be allowed to vote on a sales proposal, which he felt made it more likely that the land would change hands.
In May, Judge Arthur L. Lesemann of Superior Court ruled that nonresident stockholders could not be denied the right to vote. He did say that in the future the board could limit nonresidents' rights to own stock.
 
Split in Elections
Some tensions lingered. After decades of complacency, some residents were reluctant to say hello if they passed one another on the street. Unsigned letters of criticism were dropped in mailboxes.
A month after the ruling, an election was held to fill five of the 10 seats on the board. Both sides put up full slates and campaigned fiercely. Three candidates favoring a sale and two who opposed a sale had the highest vote totals and won. Over all the votes were split almost evenly between the two slates.
Some residents saw that balanced turnout as representative of the community's true feelings about a sale. Under the bylaws, a sale would have to be approved by two-thirds of the shareholders.
''I feel the people have spoken,'' said Jack Ennis, a resident for more than 20 years and one of the 10 who joined Mr. Fontaine. ''They want the colony to stay as a single community.''
 
Letter From Broker
''Now that the litigation is over,'' Ms. Lawlor Reilly said, ''we're hoping sincerely that everybody gets back together so we can be the community we once were.''
But there is evidence that might not be possible. Recently a shareholder who was not involved in the election, Michael J. Ignatieff, wrote an open letter to residents saying he was not for or against a sale, despite rumors that he had once tried to interest developers in the land. He is a real-estate broker.
''What I said was that if an offer should be presented, we should run it past an accountant, and if it holds water then it ought to be put to the shareholders for a vote,'' Mr. Ignatieff said. ''I told them, 'Love thy neighbor as thyself.' ''
Nothing that has occurred in the last few months would prevent a sale, but some residents said they believed that with the economy slowing, it was unlikely anyone would make a serious offer.
Mr. Ennis said he did not think that the legal battle proved that the colony's days were numbered or that the co-op form was no longer workable. ''Look, having 116 shareholders is like being in 116 marriages,'' he said. ''You've got to settle things yourself.''

HEADLINE: Law: At The Bar;
Here she comes to Wall Street: Miss America. Maybe.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
Victor Hugo once declared: ''Greater than the tread of mighty armies is an idea whose time has come.'' And it may just be that in our litigious age - when, to cite one index, there are 100,000 lawyers in California alone - the time has finally come for Miss America to be a corporate lawyer.
True, a few Miss Americas have eventually gone on to law school and become lawyers. And at least a few others have gone on to retain them. But in the contest's 70-year history no reigning Miss America has actually been a law student, someone who at least metaphorically carried a briefcase along with her crown as she floated down the runway. That brings us to Marjorie Vincent, a second-year student at Duke Law School and a summer law associate at the New York firm of Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander & Ferdon. 
Three weeks ago Miss Vincent was crowned Miss Illinois. That makes her one of at least two soon-to-be lawyers - Dana Renea Brown, Miss Tennessee, has completed her first year at the Memphis State University School of Law - and the only soon-to-be Wall Street lawyer in September's pageant. When Gary Collins soon croons, ''There she is, Miss America; there she is, your ideal,'' he might just be pointing to someone whose goal is not to be some Hollywood starlet but an authority on the Securities Exchange Act of 1933.
Can a would-be lawyer epitomize ''the queen of femininity,'' the ''fairest of the fair?'' There are no lawyers on Miss America's judiciary. But Ms. Vincent is hoping that in an affair forever seeking to shed its Barbie Doll image, her career may stand her in good stead.
The 25-year-old Ms. Vincent, who comes from Oak Park, Ill., is no stranger to pageantry. En route to Atlantic City, she has battled for Miss Chicago (three times), Miss Illinois (twice), Miss Kankakee County and Miss North Carolina (once each). In between, she became an accomplished pianist and graduated from DePaul University.
Given the poor state of the legal economy, there will be many Miss Congenialities this summer at some of Wall Street's more fragile law firms. But Mudge Rose picked a relatively small class, 29, and according to Michael De Angelis, the partner in charge of the summer program, all of them will probably get offers.
Ms. Vincent already has, though should she win the contest she will have to put off practice for a year. But according to Leonard Horn, the Atlantic City lawyer who runs the contest, even competing for Miss America is good legal training.
''A woman who would enter this type of competition obviously has enthusiasm, courage and zeal, and those are excellent qualities for any lawyer,'' he told Brett Campbell in ''Here She Comes, Miss America J.D.,'' an article prepared for Barrister magazine. And it's no mean feat, he added, to speak extemporaneously in front of 60 million people. ''I don't know if I could do that, and I've been practicing trial law since 1961.''
Anyone interviewing Miss Vincent, the daughter of Haitian immigrants, cannot be blamed for occasionally feeling like Bert Parks. He will hear how she loves the law, loves Duke, loves New York, loves Mudge Rose, and loves the work she has been doing there (even though she admits she has yet to handle her first sale-and-leaseback agreement).
But beneath all of the usual sugar coating is an articulate and talented woman. During the program she will perform a Reader's Digest version of Chopin's ''Fantasie Impromptu,'' Op. 66. ''That's the one that sounds like 'I'm Always Chasing Rainbows,' '' she explained.
Concerned that donning a swimsuit before the cameras would be frowned upon by feminist types and stuffy lawyers, Miss Vincent did not even mention her various crowns to prospective employers. But at Mudge Rose - a firm anxious, perhaps, to finally shed its image as the place where Richard M. Nixon and John N. Mitchell once worked -everyone is cheering her on.
The firm went so far as to ask its public relations company, Howard J. Rubenstein Associates Inc., to tout its ties to Miss Vincent. (With most of what law firms do either unnewsworthy or, if newsworthy, confidential, this is typical of what their publicists do.) As things turned out, Mudge Rose acted unlawfully - that is, according to the code of the pageant. It seems that contestants are barred from soliciting any national publicity prior to the gala, lest they obtain an unfair competitive advantage. ''Her law firm had no right to contact you,'' a pageant official huffily told a reporter.
Mr. Horn disputed the notion that lawyers might feel queasy about having one of their own as Miss America - that her very conspicuousness might intensify complaints that ours is a hopelessly lawyer-laden society. If anything, he argued, it could only help; most Miss Americas, he seemed to say, have a better reputation than most lawyers.

HEADLINE: Judge Upholds X Rating For Almodovar Film

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
A New York State judge upheld the X rating given to the Pedro Almodovar film ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' yesterday and said he inferred that Miramax Films, the distributor, had brought the suit for publicity purposes.
However, in his 13-page decision, Judge Charles E. Ramos of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan had harsh words for the way the Motion Picture Association of America rates movies. ''The manner in which the M.P.A.A. rates all films, not just 'Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!,' causes this Court to question the integrity of the present rating system,'' he said.
In the first challenge to the motion-picture association's rating system in 20 years, Miramax and Mr. Almodovar, who directed ''Tie Me Up!,'' filed a civil suit in May seeking to overturn the X rating. An X bars moviegoers younger than 17 from theaters where the film is playing. 
''Tie Me Up!'' is a comedy about a former mental patient who kidnaps a soft-core porn star and tries to woo her after tying her up. The film was released in the United States by Miramax on May 4.
 
'A Rational Basis'
In a highly publicized court session last month, William Kunstler, the lawyer for Miramax, asked Judge Ramos to declare the X rating ''arbitrary, unreasonable and capricious'' under Article 278 of the New York State Civil Practice Law and Rules.
These rules allow parties to petition the court for redress from the actions of an administrative body, like the motion-picture association.
In the decision, which was unexpectedly handed down at 4 P.M. yesterday, Judge Ramos said Miramax had ''clearly failed'' to prove its case under the law. ''There has been no showing that the X rating afforded 'Tie Me Up!' was without a rational basis or arbitrary and capricious,'' he wrote.
The Miramax lawsuit has drawn much attention in the media for ''Tie Me Up!'' - a fact that the judge noted. ''There are questions of the good faith of the petitioners in instituting this proceeding,'' the judge wrote. The court record ''leads to the inference that this proceeding may be just publicity'' for the film.
Jack Valenti, president of the motion-picture association, an industry trade group, commented last night: ''We are quite pleased that the case was thrown out. We are grateful that the court recognized the unambiguous supremacy of the First Amendment.''
His mention of the Constitution referred to the motion-picture association's legal defense. In court last month, Floyd Abrams, the lawyer representing the motion-picture association, asked that the Miramax suit be dismissed because it would involve the courts in the ratings process. Mr. Abrams asserted that the First Amendment bars the court ''from forcing my client to issue a rating system that my client does not want to have.''
Judge Ramos, in his opinion, acknowledged that under the First Amendment, the court could not require the motion-picture association to impose a different rating system.
However, in a statement last night, Mr. Kunstler criticized the judge, saying that ''the court's inability to rein in the forces of censorship is an alarming abdication of the judiciary's role as the protector and guarantor of free expression.''
Russell Schwartz, executive vice president of Miramax, said he was ''dismayed'' that the X rating for ''Tie Me Up!'' was upheld. For the last two months he has denied that the suit was brought for publicity purposes. Last night he added: ''Miramax is considering appealing the decision and will continue our work within the industry to encourage the M.P.A.A. to rework its rating system.''
However, Mr. Schwartz said he was ''gratified that Judge Ramos has admonished the M.P.A.A.'s present rating system as one in need of an overhaul.''
 
A Growing Debate
Yesterday's decision was the latest event in a growing debate over the motion-picture ratings system, which was created in 1968. Many film makers and distributors say the system exerts a kind of censorship through its X rating. They are calling for the creation of a new rating that would not have the stigma of the X. The judge noted this debate in his opinion, asserting that ''the rating system censors serious films by the force of economic pressure.''
The judge's opinion noted that the standard of the rating board ''is not scientific'' and criticized the membership of the board, which is composed entirely of parents.
The judge wrote: ''The industry that profits from scenes of mass murder, dismemberment and the portrayal of war as noble and glamorous apparently has no interest in the opinions of professionals, only the opinions of its consumers.''
He added: ''There are no physicians, child psychiatrists or child care professionals on the board.'' The judge asserted that no effort is made to ''professionally advise the board members on the impact of a depiction of violent rape on the one hand and an act of love on the other.''
Judge Ramos continued: ''The effort by the M.P.A.A. to encourage a more lenient policy toward violence is indefensible.''
Mr. Valenti, commenting on Judge Ramos's charges, said, ''I flatly deny that we are more lenient toward violence.''
He added: ''Just about everything the opinion had to say about the rating system is wrong, totally wrong.'' He added that he sees ''no reason to change the rating system.''
As for the judge's assertion that parents need psychological experts to advise them, Mr. Valenti commented: ''The rating system is not and does not pretend to be the National Institutes of Health. Only parents have the authority and the responsibility to set value standards for their children.''
