HEADLINE: Argentina Agrees to Sell Majority Share of Its Airline

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 19

 BODY:
Argentina, which agreed last month to sell its national telecommunications company to Spanish and American interests, has now agreed to sell a majority share of the national airline, Aerolineas Argentinas, to a consortium led by the Spanish airline Iberia.
The sale of the two state-owned companies will allow Argentina to wipe out more than $7 billion of its $62 billion foreign debt. Both deals entail the conversion of Argentine foreign debt paper.
President Carlos Saul Menem signed the decree Wednesday night awarding Aerolineas to the Iberia group, which was the only bidder two weeks ago when offers were received for the sale of 85 percent of the airline. 
The Iberia group, which also includes the parent company of the Argentine private airline Austral and several Argentine businessmen, offered $260 million in cash and $2.01 billion in debt paper, more than the minimum set by the Government.
With the deeply depressed Argentine debt paper currently trading at 14 to 15 cents on the dollar of face value in the secondary market, the real total cost to the bidders for Latin America's second-largest airline is estimated in the range of $540 million to $560 million. Aerolineas owns 24 Boeing passenger planes, ranging from 707's to 747's, and carried 3.7 million passengers last year to 28 destinations around the world.
In June, two groups led by the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Telefonica de Espana, the Spanish telephone company, were successful bidders for the purchase of majority shares of Entel, the Argentine phone company, which will be reorganized into two private companies.
Telefonica agreed to pay $114 million cash and $2.72 billion in debt paper for 60 percent of what will become Entel South, and Bell Atlantic agreed to pay $100 million cash and $2.308 billion in debt paper for 60 percent of Entel North. The remaining 40 percent of each will be sold to employees, provincial telephone cooperatives and through the stock market.
The transfer of ownership of both Entel and the airline is expected to occur in September.
The year-old Menem Government, abandoning more than 40 years of faith in state domination of the economy by Mr. Menem's Peronist Party, initiated the privatization program as part of a general economic liberalization and reform. His Government inherited fiscal deficits running 10 percent of the gross national product, plus the third-largest foreign debt in Latin America and runaway inflation now considered relatively stabilized at 10 to 12 percent a month.
Although the telephone company, which has been running deficits of $50 million a month, and the slightly profitable airline were viewed as the centerpieces for the privatization effort, Mr. Menem has promised to proceed rapidly with other privatizations as well, including the Buenos Aires electricity company, Segba.
 
Next, Armed Forces Companies
The Government is also preparing to put up for international bidding eight companies or portions of companies now owned by the armed forces. These include an iron and steel works and a shipyard in which private interests already have a majority stake, and several concerns in the petrochemical field. Private companies are expected to bid for full ownership of those put up.
Also, the oil industry is being increasingly opened to private concerns. Last week, the Government received offers from 25 consortiums of foreign and Argentine private companies totaling $260 million to exploit marginal or secondary areas now in the hands of the state oil company.
When those offers are accepted, as is expected soon, oil officials say Argentine crude production will be 37 percent in private hands. Sometime next year, the Government plans to begin offering to private interests some of the main producing areas now held by the state concern, YPF, which has long been criticized for being slow and unproductive.

HEADLINE: Earnings Decline 6% At A.T.&T.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that its earnings had fallen 6 percent in the second quarter. It attributed the drop to lower equipment sales and rentals, higher income taxes and the costs of introducing a combination calling card and credit card.
Four of the seven regional Bell operating companies reported modest earnings yesterday. The four companies, which mostly provide local telephone service, were the BellSouth Corporation, the Nynex Corporation, the Pacific Telesis Group and the Southwestern Bell Corporation. The Baby Bells' results were in line with or slightly higher than what analysts had expected. 
A.T.&T. said its second-quarter profits fell to $657 million, or 60 cents a share, from $699 million, or 65 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1989. Sales fell 2.5 percent, to $9.03 billion, from $9.26 billion a year ago. The results were similar to or slightly higher than estimates made by Wall Street analysts after A.T.&T. announced on June 27 that its second-quarter earnings would drop instead of increasing as expected.
 
Share Price Up 50/
The share price of A.T.&T., the nation's most widely held company, rose 50 cents yesterday to close at $37.625 in moderately heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock was trading at about $41 a share before June 27.
A.T.&T.'s sales and rentals of company switchboards and multiple-line telephones dropped sharply in the quarter, while long-distance telephone service revenues fell 3.9 percent, as lower average prices outweighed a 7 percent increase in volume. The company said the drop reflected, in part, moves by business customers to lower-price services.
''It's like a charge you're taking for having people on the wrong services for a hundred years,'' said Gregory R. Sawers, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York.
 
End of Long-Distance Slide Seen
Morris Tanenbaum, the chief financial officer and a vice chairman of A.T.&T., said in a telephone interview that the company was pleased with the long-distance telephone results. A.T.&T. has stopped losing market share among most types of business customers, he said, and is moving toward ending the erosion of its market share among residential customers.
Jack B. Grubman, a telephone industry analyst at Paine Webber, said, ''The underlying business trends are certainly better than I thought they would be a month ago.''
Mr. Tanenbaum reiterated that it be difficult for A.T.&T. to meet its target of 10 percent to 12 percent growth in earnings this year.
A.T.&T.'s sales of central office equipment for telephone companies grew by 1.8 percent from a year ago, as gains in international and cellular company sales offset decreased equipment sales to the regional Bell operating companies. The company told analysts that central office equipment sales in June ended up being less weak than it had anticipated in making the June 27 earnings prediction.
Mr. Tanenbaum said the modest sales growth was still below the company's targets set earlier this year. ''Our sales levels are somewhat softer than we had hoped,'' he said.
 
BellSouth
The Atlanta-based company, which provides service in nine states, said second-quarter profits rose 6.5 percent, to $445.2 million, or 92 cents a share, from $418.1 million, or 87 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 4.3 percent, to $3.62 billion from $3.47 billion. BellSouth's share price dropped 25 cents to close at $52.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
BellSouth said its earnings were held down by local telephone rate reductions in several Southeastern states, which the company had accepted in exchange for looser regulation of profits in the future.
 
Nynex
The New York-based parent of the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company reported that its second-quarter profits rose 7.7 percent, to $300.6 million, or $1.52 a share, compared with $279 million, or $1.42 a share, a year ago. Sales rose 4.2 percent, to $3.44 billion from $3.3 billion. Nynex's share price fell 37.5 cents to close at $77.75 in light trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The latest earnings included a $39 million pretax charge that was the result of an early-retirement program for managers, which ended May 31.
 
Pacific Telesis
The San Francisco-based parent of Pacific Bell and Nevada Bell, which provides service in California and Nevada, reported that second-quarter profits fell 11.7 percent, to $287 million, or 72 cents a share, from $325 million, or 79 cents a share, a year ago. Sales crept up eight-tenths of a percent, to $2.43 billion from $2.41 billion. The share price of Pacific Telesis fell 12.5 cents to close at $43 on the New York Stock Exchange.
California has imposed rate reductions on Pacific Bell in exchange for regulatory changes similar to those enacted in several states served by BellSouth. Modest growth in cellular telephone subscribers at Pactel Cellular reflected the company's decision to restrict its marketing to affluent potential customers who are likely to use the service heavily, said Kenneth N. Leon, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company.
 
Southwestern Bell
The St. Louis-based company reported an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in second-quarter earnings, to $262.5 million, or 87 cents a share, from $261.5 million, or 87 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 1.4 percent, to $2.17 billion, on sales of $2.14 billion. The company's share price was unchanged, at $53.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Southwestern Bell said it had added 71,000 new cellular telephone subscribers, more than twice as many as it had added in the quarter last year. The company has benefited from a modest recovery of the Texas economy, Mr. Leon said.

HEADLINE: American Express Net Rises 1.2%

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
The American Express Company reported yesterday that second-quarter earnings edged up 1.2 percent from the quarter a year earlier and that revenues fell slightly.
The financial services company said it earned $320 million in the quarter, compared with $316 million in the 1989 period. Earnings per share for both periods were 73 cents. Revenues were $6.1 billion, down slightly from $6.4 billion last year. 
Earnings at the Shearson Lehman Hutton brokerage subsidiary rebounded from the huge loss posted in the year's first quarter, when Shearson took a $630 million write-off for a reorganization. Second-quarter earnings at the unit were $51 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with $55 million, or 54 cents a share, in the 1989 second quarter. Revenues were $2.6 billion, compared with $3.3 billion for the 1989 period. 2 One-Time Transactions Samuel G. Liss, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, attributed Shearson's performance to improved trading results and to two one-time transactions: the sales of the Lehman asset managment operations and of Shearson's stake in a joint venture with the Nippon Life Insurance Company.
''It's too early to say much about the Shearson restructuring,'' Mr. Liss said. ''Clearly, they took significant action in the first quarter, and their expense growth seems to be contained.''
Shearson has suffered recently from the collapse of the ''junk bond'' market and problems related to its 1988 acquistion of E. F. Hutton & Company. But after trying to sell its 60 percent stake in Shearson, American Express decided to buy full ownership and renewed its commitment to reviving the company.
 
Higher Interest Expense
That decision affected the earnings of American Express as well. The company said that its earnings were hurt by higher interest expenses to cover the costs of buying $750 million of convertible preferred stock from Shearson at the end of the first quarter.
But record earnings were reported by the Travel-Related Services division, up 16 percent, to $249 million; at IDS Financial Services, up 21 percent, to $52 million, and at the Information Services Corporation, up 25 percent, to $22 million.
''Demand for American Express products and services remained generally strong in the face of softness in certain segments of the economy,'' said James D. Robinson 3d, chief executive. He termed Shearson's second-quarter performance ''encouraging'' and said that a highlight was the ''enthusiastic response'' to the company's 20 million share equity offering during the quarter.
The company will issue 25.4 million additional common shares next month, in part, because of the Shearson takeover.
Micheal L. Goldstin, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said the American Express earnings were in line with expectations. He said that Shearson had cut expenses by $250 million to $270 million. ''They are doing what they said they would,'' he added.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Evidence Backs Greenspan

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IN his testimony this week on the midyear state of the economy, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, seemed to be tiptoeing through a mine field, spread with the dangers of recession, inflation, a worsening budget deficit and a weakened financial structure in the private sector.
The biggest danger is that if a recession once got under way it would cause the failures of a host of debt-ridden corporations and financial institutions. The savings and loan disaster happened while the economy was growing steadily; a recession would harm many other sectors. With the nation's precarious debt structure, a recession now could cumulate into the worst of the postwar period. 
Mr. Greenspan responded to such anxieties by saying that the Fed was prepared to ease credit if it was necessary to prevent a recession. It would ease, he implied, if policy makers put together a budget deficit-cutting package. But he does not believe further easing is ncessary right now, insisting that he sees no signs of a recession yet.
At the same time, inflationary worries persist. Indeed, just before Mr. Greenspan testified, the Labor Department reported that consumer prices jumped five-tenths of 1 percent in June, more than twice the rate of the preceding two months. The Fed view is that too stimulative a monetary policy would worsen inflationary anxieties and send interest rates spiraling upward, jeopardizing the expansion itself.
The cardinal issue facing the Fed is how serious is the threat of recession and whether it would cause a serious crack in the nation's financial structure.
James J. O'Leary, economic consultant of the United States Trust Company of New York, argues that the threat of recession is real and the danger to the financial structure grave. He contends that the Fed has overstayed its policy of heading off rising inflation by trying to encourage sustained low economic growth without precitating a recession. ''This strategy, laudable as it has been, now seems in danger of tipping the economy into a recession, given the pervasive and very serious problems in our financial system,'' Mr. O'Leary said.
The economy, he warned, is ''very highly leveraged,'' with total outstanding debt having soared to $12.1 trillion from $4.2 trillion a decade ago. The substitution of debt for equity has led to a sharp increase in fixed interest payments as a share of corporate earnings: In the 1950's and 1960's it took 17 cents of every $1 of pre-interest earnings to service debt. In the 1970's the figure rose to 35 cents, and has now reached 61 cents.
With this year's decline in cash flow and profits, many companies are finding it hard to meet their fixed charges. Lenders, including both banks and life insurance companies, are experiencing high delinquencies and foreclosures on commercial mortgage and home mortgage loans. Delinquencies have also been rising on consumer loans.
There are signs, Mr. O'Leary says, that ''the constant din of troublesome developments in the financial system'' is starting to have a negative effect on consumer confidence. The American Express Bank Review supports that position, declaring that three factors are adding to the risks of recession: growing corporate debt, the savings and loan crisis and the need to cut the budget deficit.
Nevertheless, Mr. Greenspan is holding to a no-recession, moderate-growth forecast for the rest of 1990 and through 1991. He forecast economic growth of 1.5 percent to 2 percent for 1990 and 1.75 percent to 2.5 percent next year.
Is he whistling in the dark? The weight of the evidence is on his side. The structure of interest rates indicates that there is no credit squeeze, and none is likely. A forecasting model developed by Prof. Campbell R. Harvey of Duke University, based on the spread between short- and long-term interest rates, generates forecasts very close to those reported by Mr. Greenspan.
Last June the Harvey model predicted real economic growth of 1.7 percent through the next four quarters; that prediction looks right on target for the rest of this year.
And the model, based on the difference between the five-year bond yield and the three-month Treasury bill, now predicts real growth of 2.4 percent during the next four quarters; the economy is likely to be sluggish until mid-1991 and then turn gradually upward. Applied retroactively to the business cycle over the last 25 years, the Harvey model has called every recession correctly, and it foresees no downturn in the coming year.
Policy blunders could blow this outlook. The best way to assure stable growth in the year ahead would be a Fed policy of easing short-term rates down gradually as the Administration and Congress move to narrow the budget deficit. And that is the best prescription for avoiding a devastating shock to the nation's financial structure.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Integrated's Battle Over Partnerships

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IN the world of investing, there are few better positions than that of general partner in a widely distributed partnership. The fees roll in, generally regardless of how well the partnership is doing, and it is difficult to lose the job.
Those advantages, however, are not absolute, and a decision that a Federal bankruptcy judge in New York is facing may reinforce the rights of limited partners to throw out the management and redirect the lucrative fee income. Or it could serve to entrench the management. 
Judge Howard C. Buschman 3d heard arguments yesterday in the bankruptcy case of Integrated Resources Inc., the collapsed financial-services company. Much of Integrated's remaining assets consist of its general-partner interests in more than 600 partnerships that it sold to investors.
At stake is Integrated's plan to sell its stake in four of those partnerships, for at least $38.6 million and perhaps an additional $6.5 million, to another company, Krupp Inc. But Krupp will buy only if it can be assured that the fees will keep flowing, and there is a threat to that from an attempt by CRI Inc. to make a tender offer for the limited partnership units. So Integrated is seeking an injunction to bar CRI, a money-management company, from making the offer.
A ruling against Integrated would threaten to reduce severely the value of Integrated's remaining assets and to damage Integrated's bondholders even more. But a ruling for Integrated would, in effect, deny holders of partnership units their rights to sell their units to whomever they wish. Judge Buschman did not indicate when he would rule on that issue, although he did delay until Aug. 1 any proceedings in two related suits, filed in Delaware and California state courts, in which CRI is seeking to reverse some partnership rules it claims were hurriedly and illegally adopted this year to entrench management.
In a partnership, the general partner is usually the company that organized the partnership and picked up a variety of fees for doing so. The general partner owns a small part of the partnership, usually 1 percent or less, and there is no question that it has a right to sell that stake.
Its more important right as general partner is to choose the managers who run the partnership and collect fees that can be sizable. Generally, it chooses itself or affiliated companies.
But in most partnerships, the limited partners have a right, any time they choose, to change general partners. And the new general partner can hire different managers.
One glaring example of the value of being the general partner can be seen in a pending attempt by the Hallwood Group Inc. to take control of 11 real estate partnerships that were organized and managed by Equitec Inc., which is now in serious financial straits, although it has not filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws.
Hallwood, in a proposal that partners of the 11 funds will vote on next month, wants to combine the partnerships into a new, publicly traded partnership. In the process, it will pay Equitec more than $5 million for its stake, in effect valuing it substantially higher than the stakes of the other partners. In addition, the partnerships will pay Equitec an additional $9 million for little more than going away. Finally, Equitec will be allowed to share in the management fees for at least two more years.
Anthony J. Gumbiner, the chairman of Hallwood, said yesterday that he was not happy about the payments to Equitec, which he said had chosen properties poorly and had made some questionable decisions in running them. But he added that ''for the common good of the investors, it is far better to overpay Equitec to go away'' than to have it stay on. And he added that the management fees would be cut back, in effect paying back the partnerships for the $9 million within two years.
The other alternative, he said, would have been an expensive proxy fight, which would not have interested Hallwood. To make sure that Hallwood cannot be easily thrown out later, one provision of its offer provides that a two-thirds vote of the partners would be needed to dismiss it.
In the Integrated case, the partnerships at issue bought insured mortgages and have not performed as badly as the real estate partnerships in the Equitec case. CRI negotiated with Integrated to buy its stake, but was willing to do so only if it could get assurances that it would not be ousted, something that would need the approval of the limited partners. Instead, Integrated chose to proceed with a different sale and to seek the court order.
The judge's ruling, when it comes, may set a precedent for whether partnership investors who have suffered in bad deals will lose their rights when the sponsor gets into financial problem. In effect, the judge will be choosing between the bondholders who lent money to Integrated and the partnership investors who put up the money for the assets in the partnership.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading; Small Traders Take Profits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday in lackluster trading, with little news to affect the market.
Gold prices softened. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $361.40 an ounce, off 20 cents from late Wednesday. 
Traders described the market as listless, with primary dealers sidelined because of a lack of news.
''There's no real reason to buy or sell dollars,'' said Gabriele Schmitt, a vice president in the foreign exchange department of the Bank of New York.
The only activity came from small traders taking profits, she said. ''It was one of those choppy days that didn't have much reason behind it,'' Ms. Schmitt said. The traders said the market was seeking clearer signs on the direction of interest rates and inflation. Congressional testimony on Wednesday by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, failed to ease confusion about where American interest rates were headed, they said.
Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee that the Fed would lower rates to prevent a recession, but only after lawmakers agreed on a deficit-reduction plan.
The market was further confused about inflation by a report from the Labor Department on Wednesday that consumer prices rose five-tenths of a percent in June, more than double the rate of the last two months.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 147.60 Japanese yen, from 147.25 yen late Wednesday. Later, in London, it rose to 148.00 yen. In New York, a dollar bought 148.09 yen, up from 147.77 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8155, from $1.8205 late Wednesday. In New York, a pound cost $1.8165, more expensive than $1.81525 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Wednesday, included: 1.6408 German marks, down from 1.6480; 1.4060 Swiss francs, down from 1.41585; 5.5045 French francs, down from 5.5285; 1,201.75 Italian lire, down from 1,207.00, and 1.1524 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15425.
The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $360.40, down 70 cents an ounce. The precious metal rose in London to a late bid of $362.75 an ounce, from a $360.25 bid late Wednesday.
Silver prices fell domestically after rising overseas. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $4.851 an ounce, down from $4.884 late Wednesday.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1544 words

HEADLINE: Heroin Is Making Comeback In Lethal Tandem With Crack

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Stepping behind a rusty railroad car on the Brooklyn waterfront the other day, Brenda Gonzales stoked her crack pipe and inhaled deeply. Moments later she scooped grains of heroin into her nostrils.
''The crack gets me hyper,'' Ms. Gonzales said. ''I start sweating and I want more crack. So I take the heroin and get calm. It relaxes me.''
At 23 years old, Ms. Gonzales is part of a new and perhaps unwary generation of heroin users, discovering a drug that in the 1960's and 70's was synonymous with addiction and death. Now, amid the cocaine epidemic, heroin is making a comeback, creating dual addictions and increasing the potential for spreading the deadly AIDS virus through the use of hypodermic needles. 
 
New York a Heroin Hub
Although there has been no recent census to measure the increase in heroin use, interviews with researchers, clinicians and law enforcement officials suggest that the upsurge is most pronounced in New York, which has long been the national center for heroin distribution and where 200,000 of the country's estimated 500,000 heroin addicts live.
But the drug is also finding new followers in Washington, Baltimore, Detroit, Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Diego and Seattle, as well as in Newark and Jersey City, the experts say.
''Two generations of young people were scared off heroin,'' said Philippe Bourgois, an anthropologist from San Francisco State University who has been doing field work in East Harlem for five years. ''Now cocaine and crack have turned out to be so extraordinarily destructive that people, ironically, end up back with heroin.''
Production of opium, the raw material for heroin, is booming in Asia and Latin America and seizures of the drug in the United States have been rising.
The growth in heroin use comes as evidence is accumulating that the consumption of crack and powdered cocaine has peaked and may be declining. And it seems to fit with a theory of many experts that drug use runs in cycles, with stimulants like cocaine alternating with depressants like heroin.
''I think heroin is going to be the drug of the 90's,'' said Felix Jimenez, the chief of the heroin division of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in Washington.
David F. Musto, a professor at the Yale School of Medicine who is perhaps the country's leading historian on drug abuse, says he doubts heroin will come close to matching cocaine as the favorite drug of millions of Americans, largely because the growing anti-drug atmosphere in the country will serve as a brake on any new epidemic.
 
Soothing, Pure and Deceptive
Nevertheless, the revival of heroin compounds the country's struggle with drugs and raises new dangers for those who fall under its spell.
''The potential is pretty great for heroin becoming a major problem,'' said Dr. Richard E. Lopez, the acting director of the substance abuse program at District of Columbia General Hospital.
Heroin's allure, in this era of nerve-jangling crack, is its soothing quality, leading many to rely on it as a kind of self-medication. It is being sold at such high levels of purity that users no longer need confront the hypodermic needle, but can snort or smoke the drug. This, however, has given rise to the myth that if heroin is not injected, it is not addictive.
Most often, drug users take heroin to soften and prolong the effects of crack. But after a crack binge of three or four days, known as ''a mission,'' some take heroin as a sleeping pill. Still others take a $10 bag of heroin, the standard measure sold on the streets of New York, to stabilize a crack high in order to keep an appointment, for instance, or hide their addiction at work.
By following a hit of crack with a snort of heroin, ''You feel normal,'' said Mildred Mercado, a 25-year-old Brooklyn woman. ''You aren't really normal,'' she said, ''but it brings your heartbeat back to normal.''
 
Double Addictions Increasing
Enjoying a false sense of well-being, crack addicts using heroin often fail to recognize the extent of their deterioration. Increasingly, people are becoming addicted to both drugs, making recovery longer and more difficult.
Moreover, heroin addicts inevitably build up a tolerance for the drug and many eventually turn to the more efficient but extremely risky practice of injecting, which has become the leading way of transmitting the deadly AIDS virus in the metropolitan area.
Often the shift to shooting, as the addicts say, is explained as common-sense economics. ''Why should I buy three bags to snort when I can go shoot one bag and feel the same?'' said Michael Bethea, a former addict who works for the Association for Drug Abuse Prevention and Treatment, a private group that counsels drug addicts in East Harlem and Brooklyn.
Ms. Mercado changed from snorting to shooting heroin about a month ago. ''It hits you quicker,'' she said, shortly after taking an injection the other day. ''Boom. I love it.'' Moving Directly to Heroin Officals at several drug-treatment programs in the city as well as sociologists working in the drug culture say they are routinely seeing cocaine and crack users shifting to heroin. Some young people, they say, are bypassing crack and moving directly into experimentation with heroin.
The New York State Division of Substance Abuse reports that 31 percent of the heroin users in drug-treatment programs last year said they snorted the drug compared with 15 percent three years earlier, adding that many of the users last year appeared to be newcomers to heroin.
Deaths from heroin overdoses, usually taken as an indicator of the drug's popularity, declined 22 percent in New York last year. But state drug officials say that figure is deceptive. An overdose death is less likely ''if you're snorting, as opposed to shooting heroin in the veins, because of the speed and the amount that gets in,'' said Dr. Stanley Yancovitz, the chief of medical dependency at the Beth Israel Medical Center, which operates the largest drug-treatment program in New York.
 
From Luxury to Obsession
In the early stages, drug users may treat heroin as a luxury, using it sparingly while spending most of their money on vials of crack for $2.50, $3 or $5, each vial containing three or four pinhead-sized pebbles of dehydrated cocaine. Eventually, however, the desire for heroin begins to feel like a necessity, said Ms. Gonzales and others.
She tried heroin as a teen-ager. Then in her 20's she shifted to crack and her heroin consumption more than quadrupled. She was dismissed from her job at a bakery and has been working as a prostitute. Now, she said, she doesn't start smoking crack unless she has a bag of heroin with her. ''If I don't have that bag of heroin,'' she said, ''I just keep smoking and searching for more money to get more crack.''
Jean Williams, a 34-year-old Brooklyn woman, used to snort heroin to mask her crack addiction when she worked as a clerk in a Manhattan law firm. ''You don't want to go to work feeling all jittery,'' she said, ''and I couldn't appear to be high. So I'd take a bag of dope.''
 
Crack Epidemic Fading
Many young people, according to researchers in New York and other cities, are beginning to shy away from crack after seeing how quickly people become addicted and burned out by the drug, how craving for it comes to dominate their lives. In contrast, they see heroin, which produces a rather peaceful high, as a benign drug. The newcomers seem to know nothing of the great heroin plague that laid waste to New York and many other cities in the late 60's and 70's. The number of addicts soared tenfold then, from about 50,000, and scores died from overdoses.
Terry Williams, a sociologist who has been studying the drug culture in New York for nearly 20 years, said that while crack use remains high, the epidemic appears to be burning itself out.
''You've reached a period where people have gone through the freneticness of crack; they've had friends and family members who've been involved in a negative way,'' he said.
Mr. Williams, the author of a book on young drug dealers called ''The Cocaine Kids,'' said he began to notice ''a really serious increase'' in heroin use last fall and discovered that many cocaine and crack dealers had added heroin to their line of products.
 
Typical Bag's Purity Rising
Heroin, like the cocaine products, is most widely available in the poorer sections of New York and other cities. Federal officials say that Chinese racketeers dominate the heroin trade in New York and mainly import a type known as China White, which is made from opium grown in the Golden Triangle, at the juncture of the borders of Thailand, Laos and Myanmar, formerly Burma. Dominicans, Jamaicans and American blacks serve as middlemen in New York's heroin business, the authorities say, with neighborhood youths handling street sales. While wholesale prices have declined, the price on the street has remained $10 a bag. But a typical bag now contains 20 percent pure heroin, up from less than 10 percent in the past. Often, the mix consists of 40 percent or more heroin.
''Heroin is starting to play a very strong role here,'' said Mr. Williams. ''I haven't seen so much of it since the early 70's.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 21, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1839 words

HEADLINE: VACANCY ON THE COURT;
BRENNAN, KEY LIBERAL, QUITS SUPREME COURT; BATTLE FOR SEAT LIKELY

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Justice William J. Brennan Jr., the Supreme Court's senior member, resigned from the Court tonight, effective immediately.
The sudden resignation of the 84-year-old Justice, the Court's leading liberal, raised the prospect of a major political battle over the future direction of the Court between the White House and the Democratic-controlled Senate, which would confirm or reject President Bush's nominee. .
President Bush said tonight that he planned to turn immediately to the task of choosing Justice Brennan's successor. He said he would convene a meeting at the White House Saturday morning to discuss possible nominees.
 
Bush Says He's 'Not Afraid'
He said he wanted the best-qualified person and was ''not afraid of starting a nomination fight.''
In the term that ended last month, Justice Brennan's vote made the difference in a series of 5-to-4 liberal victories on subjects including affirmative action and political patronage. 
Without his vote, the Court's razor-thin margin in favor of continued recognition of a constitutional right to abortion could well disappear.
The resignation came as a shock to the Court, the Congress and the White House, which apparently got the news in a letter Justice Brennan addressed to President Bush.
 
'Strenuous Demands' Cited
''The strenuous demands of Court work and its related duties required or expected of a Justice appear at this time to be incompatible with my advancing age and medical condition,'' Justice Brennan said in the letter. ''I therefore retire effective immediately as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States,''
He did not elaborate on his health problems. But a family friend said tonight that Justice Brennan had suffered what turned out to be a mild stroke just before taking a two-week Scandinavian cruise with his wife, Mary. The couple completed the cruise and returned home on Tuesday. Justice Brennan's doctor diagnosed the stroke later in the week and advised the Justice that he needed to rest.
Justice Brennan had suffered a mild stroke in 1979 and had been hospitalized briefly for several relatively minor illnesses in the last few years.
The family friend said Justice Brennan was at home, was comfortable and was suffering no obvious impairment.
The Court released a statement from Justice Brennan tonight, saying ''This was a very difficult decision after almost 34 years of service on the Court.'' [Text, page 7A.] The choice of a successor presents President Bush with an important political challenge on the eve of the Congressional elections. The nomination could well become a battleground over abortion rights and similar issues, as the contentious battle over President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork demonstrated three years ago. Judge Bork was defeated for the vacancy that was eventually filled by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.
In several dozen appointments he has made to the Federal bench so far, Mr. Bush has generally followed President Reagan's approach in seeking judges who interpret laws narrowly, favor the prosecution in criminal matters and defer to Congress and state legislatures. He has been generally praised by conservatives for his judicial nominations.
Aboard Air Force One, which was taking the President to Washington from Cheyenne, Wyo., the President told reporters tonight: ''I've always said I want somebody who will be on there not to legislate from the bench but to faithfully interpret the Constitution. So that gives me wide latitude.''
Mr. Bush said he hoped he would select a nominee ''very very soon.'' He said he would meet Saturday with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh; John H. Sununu, his chief of staff, and C. Boyden Gray, his legal counsel.
''I want to move swiftly,'' the President said, ''but I want to move so that my nominee will be widely approved and quickly confirmed for this important post.''
 
A File of Potential Candidates
A senior Bush Administration official said tonight that Administration officials had discussed filling a Supreme Court vacancy in the abstract, without knowledge of when a vacancy might occur. He said that a file of potential candidates existed but that there was no ''short list'' of possible choices or even a firm idea of the process that the President would employ to select his first Supreme Court nominee.
Among those who have been mentioned as possible nominees are Kenneth W. Starr, the Solicitor General; Ralph K. Winter of New Haven, a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, and Abraham D. Sofaer, a former Federal judge now in private law practice, who until recently served as the State Department's top lawyer.
Several other sitting Federal appellate judges have been mentioned, including Patrick E. Higginbotham of Dallas, who sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit; Roger Miner of Albany, who is on the Second Circuit; William W. Wilkins Jr. of Greenville, S.C., of the Fourth Circuit, and J. Clifford Wallace of San Diego and Cynthia H. Hall of Pasadena, Calif., both of the Ninth Circuit.
Some Congressional Democrats speculated that the President might choose a Senator in an effort to assure a speedy confirmation. Several prominent Republican incumbents are lawyers with an interest in the judiciary, including Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, a former state attorney general.
The Court, now in recess, returns for its 1990-91 term on Oct. 1, just over two months from now. With Congress due to leave early next month for a month-long recess, there is a prospect that only eight Justices will be sitting when the Court goes back into session. However, the Court does not begin handing down decisions until close to Thanksgiving. Arguments in cases on which there is a 4-to-4 deadlock can be reheard later in the term after the vacancy is filled. Several cases were argued again after Justice Kennedy's confirmation, in February 1988, filled a vacancy left by the retirement of Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. the previous June.
 
Senator Gives Democrats' Reply
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, served notice tonight that a political fight was possible. Senator Kennedy, a leader in the battle that denied confirmation to Judge Bork, said: ''Justice Brennan's America is the kinder, gentler nation of which President Bush has eloquently spoken. I urge the President to nominate a successor worthy of that vision.''
Senator Kennedy hailed Justice Brennan, saying he had ''earned an extraordinary place in American history and American constitutional law'' and ranks ''with Marshall, Holmes and Brandeis as the greatest Justices the country has ever had.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said Justice Brennan was a ''great figure in American law, and his wisdom on the court will be missed.''
 
'Voice of Caution'
Justice Thurgood Marshall, Justice Brennan's closest ally on the Court and at age 82 two years his junior, said tonight that Justice Brennan had been a ''voice of caution and compassion in urging that this Court not retreat from its constitutional mission to protect individuals' rights of freedom of expression, guarantee that minorities be free from discrimination and to assure the rights of those accused of crimes.''
In an interview tonight on the ABC News program ''Night Line,'' former Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. said he ''was very surprised'' by Justice Brennan's resignation.
''He has had health problems, but I did not realize that they had reached the point at which he would resign,'' Mr. Powell said.
The former Justice also said, ''A change of one Justice often affects various areas of constitutional law.'' Asked to name some areas that he thought would be affected by Justice Brennan's resignation, he mentioned affirmative action, abortion, criminal law and the interpretation of Federal habeas corpus law, which has often been used by inmates facing execution to challenge their sentences before the Supreme Court.
 
'One Person, One Vote'
After a judicial career with few parallels for length and dimension, Justice Brennan's influence extends to virtually every corner of modern constitutional law and to much of daily life.
As a relatively young Justice in 1962, he wrote the opinion in Baker v. Carr that led to the ''one person, one vote'' reapportionment cases. In his last week of active duty on the Court, last month, he wrote the opinion affirming the constitutional power of Congress to enact affirmative action programs.
In the decades in between, he played an instrumental role in a series of cases that opened the doors of Federal courts to people with complaints against government officials and that established the Federal courts as the guarantors of the quality of justice dispensed by state judicial systems.
His vote in school-prayer and other religion cases maintained strict separation of church and state. He wrote the 1964 landmark libel decision, New York Times v. Sullivan, finding that the First Amendment shields the press from liability for statements about public officials that cannot be shown to be deliberately false or published with reckless disregard for the truth.
Over the past decade, support eroded on the increasingly conservative Court for some of Justice Brennan's most cherished legal doctrines, particularly those involving the role of the Federal courts. And he was not able to win a majority for his view, shared with Justice Marshall, that the death penalty is unconstitutional under all circumstances.
 
A Harvard Law Scholarship
William Brennan was born in 1906 in Newark. He attended the Newark public schools and graduated with a bachelor's degree, cum laude, in economics from the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania in 1928. Shortly before his graduation, he married Marjorie Leonard of Belfast, N.Y.
Mr. Brennan then won a scholarship to Harvard Law School, where one of his professors was Felix Frankfurter, later a colleague on the Court. He graduated in 1931 among the top 10 students in the class.
Mr. Brennan became a trial lawyer specializing in labor cases. After World War II service in the Army, he worked in private practice for four more years.
In 1949 Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, a Republican, offered him a seat on the New Jersey Superior Court, he gratefully accepted.
Two years later, he was elevated to the Appellate Division of that court, and in 1952 Governor Driscoll named him as an Associate Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court.
Judge Brennan's elevation to the Supreme Court in 1956 came as a nearly complete surprise to the bench, to the bar and to Mr. Brennan. President Eisenhower named him to succeed Associate Justice Sherman Minton, who was about to retire because of poor health.
Eisenhower wrote later in his memoirs that he had been heavily influenced by praise of the appointee by Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Justice William J. Brennan Jr., who announced his resignation. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times, 1986); Photo of current supreme court members with dates of appointments. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)(pg7A)

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Now a New Europe

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Now comes the long, intricate process of reorganizing Europe. The last couple of weeks - the NATO summit meeting, the Kohl-Gorbachev accord, the Paris talks on Germany - have removed all important barriers that kept Germany and the Continent divided since World War II.
It will take a few more years for the Soviet troops to go home, for getting rid of extravagant arsenals, for the two parts of Germany to meld effectively, for the Eastern Europeans to climb up into the modern economic and political world, for the Soviets to work out what kind of country, or countries, they intend to be.
But the new era starts now. The decisions being taken will hold for a long time, perhaps as long as the cold war lasted. This sense of novelty, of the fateful moment with all kinds of uncertain implications, accounts more for the unease, I think, than the behavior of Germany from Bismarck to 1945. 
Certainly the unease is there. And it is natural that fears focus on Germans, not only because of the past but also because of their capacity to exploit technology for economic power and because of their mass. They will outweigh each of their partners. It will be up to their partners, including the U.S., to show the energy and dedication to keep up with them in the East.
The Germans feel the discomfort too, in the midst of their euphoria at regaining full sovereignty and a single state. Their leaders are convinced that Mikhail Gorbachev wants American troops to remain ''to control the Germans,'' and so do they, officials say in private.
Still, it is oddly self-lacerating to complain at the skill and the snappy, crisis-free tempo with which the postwar European order is being demolished. Apparently President Bush and Chancellor Kohl have done such a good job of chocolate-coating the collapse of empire for the Russians that some critics think they've given away the goodies.
There have been some compromises that could cause trouble one day if the policy fails. One strange anomaly is that NATO's protective guarantees will extend to the Oder-Neisse border with Poland as soon as East Germany is absorbed, even though there will still be Soviet forces in the area for three or four years. The diplomats couldn't find a way around it, so they agreed to cross their fingers and live with it for the time being.
Another possible problem down the road is the ban on nuclear weapons and stationing - presumably also training and exercising - non-German NATO troops on former East German territory even after the Soviets leave. It's essentially a matter of principle, since nobody intended to send American soldiers or nuclear weapons there anyway. But it will leave an artificial, internationally endorsed military line down the middle of Germany when all the other remnants of partition are swept away.
These are the sorts of things that could bring friction if the overall policy fails, and the climate goes bad again. But if it fails, they would be minor sources of irritation compared with the big dangers. The chance of success for the new Europe requires sensible planning on how it can work. Anticipating only the worst possible cases would block that hope.
The limelight of attention switches compulsively from one personality to another. It's the Russian, the German, the American who is running away with the show, deviously leaving the others behind. That is largely optical illusion. In fact, there has been an unusually effective triple play among the three, each one passing the ball at a critical moment and advancing to the solution now achieved.
If the French and the British had little impact, it's mainly because they chose to dither, imagining they could delay events rather than joining the action. The Poles, who had a perfectly clear sense of what they needed all along - watertight renunciation of any German territorial claims - supported a united Germany in NATO from the start. They wound up proclaiming the result ''completely satisfactory,'' in the words of their Foreign Minister, Krzysztof Skubiszewski. They will also get a general treaty of friendship and trade with Germany that they hope will be modeled on the French-German treaty, with similar profound effect.
Once again Mikhail Gorbachev has shown his capacity to do a flip-flop, moving with events when he is convinced he cannot forestall them. The interaction among him, Mr. Kohl and Mr. Bush has been a good sign, each showing an ability to take the others' needs into account. It enabled NATO's two-fisted Secretary General, Manfred Worner, to go to Moscow and declare, soothingly, ''We intend to steer change in Europe so that there are no losers, only winners.''
This is only the start. But the direction is right.

HEADLINE: Helms Aide Stirs Furor With Racial Accusation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
The head of the N.A.A.C.P. and a black civil rights pioneer employed by Senator Jesse Helms have clashed over assertions by the Helms aide that some American black leaders are controlled by 15 powerful white men and are engaged in criminal and immoral activities.
The Helms staff member is James H. Meredith, whose enrollment at the University of Mississippi in 1962 touched off riots that left two dead and hundreds injured. On Monday, in a news release on Mr. Helms's Senate stationery, he said many leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and some black Democratic leaders were puppets of a small group of ''liberal elite'' whites.
He said he knew the names of the whites but he refused to divulge them or the names of any of the blacks he said were being controlled. He also charged that many of the 3,000 delegates at an N.A.A.C.P. convention in Los Angeles last weekend were involved in drug use, crime and immoral activities. He offered no evidence for any of his assertions. 
 
Compelled to Respond
Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., declined to respond at first, saying he would not ''dignify the stupidity of his allegations.'' But on Wednesday, he said the wide publicity given the Meredith assertions and the fact that they appeared on Mr. Helms's stationery compelled him to respond.
Describing the assertions as ''sheer nonsense'' and ''ludicrous,'' Mr. Hooks suggested that they were part of a ''sinister, devious and unholy plot'' to aid Mr. Helms's political career, and he called on the North Carolina Republican, a staunch opponent of civil rights legislation, to disavow and censure Mr. Meredith.
''I pose the question whether this entire episode is influenced by the fact that Senator Helms's opponent in the general election is Harvey Gantt, the Democratic candidate, who happens to be black,'' Mr. Hooks said at a news conference in New York. Mr. Gantt is a former Mayor of Charlotte.
Mr. Helms, in a statement Wednesday, said he had not authorized Mr. Meredith's news release and faulted him for using his Senate stationery and his free mailing privileges. But he added: ''It is his right to express his opinion, and I would think the press would respect that - even if he does not espouse the liberal ideas the press supports.''
Questions yesterday about the affair were referred by members of the Senator's staff in Washington to a spokesman, Eric Lundgren, who did not return two phone calls to a reporter seeking comment. The office said Mr. Meredith was unavailable.
 
A Harsh Critic
Mr. Meredith, after desegregating the University of Mississippi, was wounded in a civil rights march in Mississippi in 1966. But in later years, he became a harsh critic of the civil rights establishment and he has denounced integration and argued that a white liberal elite wants to keep blacks down under the pretext of helping them.
The 58-year-old Mr. Meredith has held many jobs, including financial planner and tree farmer, in various parts of the country and has made a number of trips to Africa to promote black economic development. Last September, he joined Mr. Helms's Washington staff as a domestic policy adviser.
Many blacks expressed surprise at his appointment, noting that Mr. Helms, since his election to the Senate in 1972, had been a scathing critic of domestic programs favored by many blacks, a defender of South Africa's white minority government and an opponent of efforts to make the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a national holiday.
But Mr. Meredith, at the time of his appointment, said he did not believe Senator Helms was hostile to blacks. ''I have never seen anyone sustain that charge or give one iota of evidence,'' he said.
Mr. Meredith, in his assertions on the Helms stationery this week, accused American black leaders, especially in the N.A.A.C.P. and the Democratic Party, of selling out to a cadre of white conspirators.
''The truth of the matter is that the liberal elite - with knowledge and full thought on the part of the black elite -have deliberately set up a phenomenon as part of their political power control, of taking a handful of selected blacks, giving them high rewards and using them to control the black population,'' Mr. Meredith said. Mr. Hooks, in his news conference, said ''the charges were so outlandish that no sane person could give them any degree of credibility.''

GRAPHIC: Photos: James H. Meredith, left, a civil rights pioneer employed by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, has clashed with Benjamin L. Hooks of the N.A.A.C.P., after asserting that several prominent blacks were puppets of a group of ''liberal elite'' whites. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. Says China Backs Halt In Weapons to Khmer Rouge

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
A senior State Department official told Congress today that China had agreed to stop arms shipments to the Khmer Rouge guerrillas and to support a disarming of all military forces in Cambodia as part of an arrangement leading to elections there.
Richard H. Solomon, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, told a committee of Congress that China's pledge, made at a meeting sponsored by the United Nations in Paris last Tuesday, was an advance in international negotiations to settle the Cambodian civil war.
The commitment he attributed to the Chinese came a day before Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced in Paris that the United States was withdrawing its support from the Chinese-backed Cambodian coalition that includes the Khmer Rouge. That decision was in turn attacked in Beijing on Thursday. 
 
Tough Questioning
Mr. Solomon conceded, ''I wouldn't say time is on the side of a political solution.''
Mr. Solomon faced heavy criticism and tough questioning before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee two days after the Administration announced a revision of its Cambodia policy by dropping diplomatic recognition for the Cambodia guerrilla coalition and opening talks with Vietnam.
Several senators asserted that despite the change, the continuation of United States aid to two non-Communist groups fighting to overthrow the Government still threatened to help the Khmer Rouge retake power.
The 11-year war pits the Vietnamese-backed Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen against a loose guerrilla alliance including the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist rebel groups. The United States gives more than $15 million in covert and overt aid each year to the non-Communist guerrillas.
The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia between 1975 and 1978, when more than a million people were systematically killed or starved. A Vietnamese invasion force overran the Khmer Rouge in 1979.
 
'Very Positive Development'
Mr. Solomon said the Administration's policy change accompanied previously unreported progress in the latest round of talks on Cambodia between the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council.
''One of the very positive developments'' that came out of the Paris session, Mr. Solomon said, was the agreement to ''a framework that would involve cantonment of the various forces after a cease-fire and a phased process by which the armed units would stack arms, and arms would come under United Nations control and supervision.''
He added: ''You've got to have the Chinese on board committed to cutting off arms and encouraging their friends to join in the political process. And they have told us they will do so. They have been constructive.''
The United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China have held five meetings on Cambodia since January. The talks, which will continue in New York on Aug. 27 and 28, have agreed that the United Nations should provide peacekeeping forces and foster an administration structure including all the known warring factions.
 
'The Time Is Past Due'
Mr. Solomon's description of the diplomatic advance went beyond the short communique released by the five countries on Tuesday that said ''the time is past due for the Cambodian parties to turn from the battlefield to the negotiating table.''
But neither the communique nor Mr. Solomon have indicated that the warring Government and guerrilla factions have come any closer to a settlement of their differences. The Khmer Rouge has insisted that guerrilla representatives outnumber Government representatives in the pre-election Supreme National Council, a proposal Mr. Hun Sen has dismissed as out of hand.
Critics, including several senators and witnesses who spoke today at the hearing, assert that China and the Khmer Rouge are interested in the negotiations merely to stall for time. The Communist guerrillas' real strategy, they say, is to amass their guerrilla forces and political cadres for a final offensive in the next year or two.
In testimony, former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie said, ''If Cambodia should again fall to the Khmer Rouge, the United States Government will have the blood of the Cambodian people on its hands.'' He recommended cutting off aid to the Cambodian guerrillas, opening talks with the Hun Sen Government, terminating the economic embargo on Cambodia, and pressing the Chinese to cut aid to the Khmer Rouge.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Shopping for CD Rates by Telephone

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Dialing for dollars has moved from the fantasy of television game shows to the reality of the trillion-dollar market for certificates of deposit.
A new telephone service started earlier this month by CD Rateline, a company in Armonk, N.Y., allows consumers to compare certificates of deposit and money-market accounts, either to obtain the highest interest rate or to make sure that their bank is offering a rate close to the competition.
When customers call 900-BANK-CDS, a recording tells them to select the information they want by pressing buttons on the telephone. One option provides a list of the five institutions offering the highest yields for CD's of the maturity selected by the caller. Another option provides CD yields of a particular institution. 
 
Sorting Things Out
 ''People are getting more comfortable doing their banking over the phone,'' said Les Dinkin, head of a management consulting company in Westport, Conn., that specializes in financial services. ''A rate-shopping service like this can help consumers sort out what is going on.''
Organizers of the new business started with information for more than 100 institutions in New York City, and plan to include northern New Jersey banks by next week and other major markets around the nation within a few months.
Because interest rates offered on certificates of deposit vary widely from bank to bank, shopping for a higher interest rate is easily worth the price of a phone call to the new service. Calls to CD Rateline are $1.95 for the first minute and 95 cents for each additional minute.
Before investors jump at the chance to earn a higher interest rate, they should consider the time and effort required to visit the new bank and complete forms. And investing by mail can mean lost checks.
But there are times when the attraction of a higher rate might be compelling, despite the inconvenience of changing accounts. This week, for example, the highest rate available in New York for a six-month certificate was 8.21 percent, yielding 8.50 percent after compounding, at the Eastchester Savings Bank. The lowest was a 6.85 percent rate, yielding 6.97 percent, at the Israel Discount Bank. The average for more than 100 banks was a yield of 8.20 percent.
The difference in interest earned on $10,000 over six months with the highest-rate CD compared with the lowest-rate one is $68. The difference between the highest and lowest rates varies depending on the maturity of the deposit, but often exceeds three percentage points, according to CD Rateline data.
''The inherent conflict between banks, who want to pay the lowest possible rate, and consumers, who want the highest rate, is the basic idea behind our business,'' said Keith Trauner, president of CD Rateline. ''We see this as a way we can make some money by providing money-making information for the average consumer.''
Since the early 1980's, when Federal ceilings on interest rates paid by banks and savings institutions began to be lifted, consumers have been confronted with a bewildering array of CD's, each with a different rate. Finding the best rate is often a hit-or-miss affair.
''Most people do not have time to do any serious survey of what is available,'' Mr. Trauner said. The lack of information, plus the time and effort needed by consumers to open a new account, gives bankers more leeway to keep rates as low as possible.
CD Rateline contacts each bank on Tuesday to collect the latest rate information. By Wednesday the information is on the telephone recording.
Interest rates quoted in the phone service are for $10,000 certificates. The service does not cover the higher interest rates available for larger deposits, and it lists only CD's with maturities of 3, 6, 12, 24, 36 and 60 months.
While CD Rateline says it is the first to offer bank-deposit information over a 900 phone number, there are several other companies that provide similar information in newsletters. Bank Advertising News of North Palm Beach, Fla., publishes ''100 Highest Yields,'' which tracks rates for small-sized certificates of deposit, as well as the ''Jumbo Flash Report,'' which tracks rates for $100,000 deposits. Many newspapers also publish lists of the highest rates for large- and small-sized CD's from banks and savings institutions nationwide.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Keith Trauner, president of CD Rateline, says it can save time. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;
With Buying Luggage

BYLINE: By DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Luggage is coming out of the closet as people prepare to pack for August vacations. And while most will carry bags they have toted on previous trips, others will head for department stores, luggage shops, chain stores and discount stores.
But unlike the impulse to shop for a new summer outfit, the motivation to buy new luggage is largely need rather than whim, according to a recent study by the Gallup Organization. Most people, the researchers reported, buy new pieces only if theirs are stolen, lost or falling apart. 
Last year Americans spent $2.6 billion on luggage, the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America, an industry group, estimated. The purchases were based more on practical needs like durability and ease of handling rather than style. With that in mind, manufacturers have developed new lines of luggage designed to ease the burden of packing and toting vacation or business essentials.
''The public is saying, 'I don't want a bag that weighs 30 pounds before I even put anything in it,' '' said Michele M. Marini, editor in chief of Showcase Magazine, a trade publication. ''And as a result manufacturers have been introducing some new lines to meet those criteria.''
Samsonite recently introduced the Ultralite bag, which it says is 30 percent lighter than other structured soft-side bags. The 26-inch suitcase, the most popular size, weighs about five pounds and is on wheels. It costs $115.
Another Samsonite bag has a built-in luggage cart and comes in a carry-on size for overhead storing on a plane. The Piggyback Carry-On is a hard-side molded bag that can be pulled down an airplane's aisle. It is also made with a retractable strap so that up to two other bags can be pulled along with it. It measures 14 1/4 by 21 3/4 by 8 inches. It will be on the market next month at $179.99. While the airlines differ in their allowances for size, weight and number of pieces that can be carried aboard, the Air Transport Association offers these guidelines:
* Underseat bags, 9 by 14 by 22 inches with total dimensions of 45 inches.
* Garment bags, 4 inches by 23 inches by 45 inches with a total of 72 inches.
* Overhead bags, 10 inches by 14 inches by 36 inches with a total of 60 inches.
A need for portability and easy storage led to the Hartmann Luggage Company's new Trifold Hangbag. Extended, the garment bag measures 48 inches and can carry two suits. Folded, it reduces to 12 to 14 inches and will fit under a seat. It ranges in price from $305 to $680, depending on the material.
The new Hartmann Extended Hanger is 10 inches longer than the standard 44-inch bag, for the dresses of taller women, or an evening dress. The extra 10-inch flap folds up and the bag folds in half to measure 44 inches. It's $380 to $960.
Then there are the large-capacity bags and bags within bags, for items acquired on vacation. The bags are so big they are on wheels. One is made by Baltimore Luggage of especially sturdy nylon. It measures 32 by 15 by 15 inches and costs $125.
Samsonite's new Oyster Sport Edition is a hard-side case with a removable sport tote inside that can be carried separately. It comes in 24-inch, 26-inch and 29-inch sizes and sells for $90, $120 and $140.
After function, size, style and price, the buyer is left with a final consideration: color. Navy, tan, maroon, gray, rose and red are common choices. But Bob D'Addario, the buyer for the 30 Innovation Luggage stores in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, says the undisputed favorite is black.
''Black, black, black and lots more black,'' he said. ''You can open a luggage store with nothing but black luggage in it and be successful.''
 
BAGGAGE CHECK
The Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America offer these tips:
COVERING: The material should be tightly woven and smooth to avoid snags. Look for bags treated to be stain- and water repellant.
CONSTRUCTION: Cases with reinforced narrow sides and corners wear best. Hard-sided cases should close tightly, with no gaps. Lids should stay open for easy packing and unpacking. Look for even stitches, with double-stitching at stress points.
HARDWARE: Solid brass and die-cast metal hardware are stronger than plastic or stamped metal. Look for secure shoulder-strap attachments and detachable straps that resist when you pull on them.
WHEELS: Wheels should be solidly affixed and the wheel system should handle turns easily.
GARMENT BAGS: Does the top of the bag have a bar support? A center bar in the middle of the case will anchor the handle and keep the case from sagging. A double track that allows hangers to be staggered maximizes space. A pocket or snap should secure the hanging hook when it is not in use.
HANDLES and STRAPS: Double screws or rivets are more secure than prongs. Look for adjustable shoulder straps and pull-straps that are long enough so you can pull the bag comfortably while standing upright.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Are Mixed; Trading Is Light and Choppy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday, ending slightly lower in domestic trading against every major currency but the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar.
Gold prices were mixed in New York after falling overseas.
Karen Gibbs, senior financial futures analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said currency trading was light and choppy largely because of uncertainty about the direction of the American economy. 
The dollar turned in its strongest performance against the yen.
Dealers said traders sold the yen for dollars and West German marks after Japanese money supply figures dashed hopes among some traders that Japanese authorities would move soon to lower interest rates.
Masayuki Takaura, senior foreign exchange manager at Sanwa Bank Ltd. in London, said the yen was due for a modest correction after recent gains. But he said the dollar's move through 148.50 yen in early European dealings helped produce a flurry of stop-loss dollar buying.
Ms. Gibbs said she felt that ''the path of least resistance is still down for the dollar.''
She said that the Federal Reserve's relaxation of credit conditions a week ago made American interest rates ''unattractive globally.'' She also said there was downward pressure on the dollar because Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had expressed willingness to lower rates further if a budget compromise was reached and the economy remained weak.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks, she said, showed ''they are not going to tighten, and that would be the only thing making the dollar more attractive.''
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 148.35 yen, from 147.60 Thursday. The dollar was quoted later in London at 148.90 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 148.65 yen, from 148.09 yen late Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8140, from $1.8155 late Thursday. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8185 from $1.8165.
Late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.6385 West German marks, down from 1.6408; 1.4043 Swiss francs, down from 1.4060; 5.4965 French francs, down from 5.5045; 1,200.00 Italian lire, down from 1,201.75, and 1.15495 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15235.
The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $360.75 a troy ounce, up 35 cents from Thursday's after-hours bid.

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Issues Post Small Rise

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities posted small increases yesterday in a muted reaction to further indications that the Federal Reserve was lowering key interest rates.
Dealers said the market would have been more positive to the Fed's latest move except for the fact that a record $135 billion of Treasury borrowings have been listed for auction during the next four weeks.
As has been the case recently, much of the money raised by the Treasury borrowings will be used to cover the mounting losses of the savings and loan industry. $2.5 Billion Injection ''The market has yet to fully absorb the significance of the flood of Treasury paper, including the quarterly refunding, that has been placed on the auction calendar,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''The market's reaction thus far has been to keep prices of the longer maturities from rising.'' 
The Fed's latest move on interest rates was to inject $2.5 billion of temporary reserves into the banking system by effecting repurchase agreements on behalf of foreign central banks and other customers.
As usual, the immediate impact of this move was to reduce the key Federal funds rate to 7 15/16 percent from 8 percent, where it had been trading all week. The rate is what banks charge each other for temporary loans.
A much bolder move by the Fed a week earlier sent the Federal funds rate to 8 percent after hovering around the 8.25 percent level since last December. Normally, Treasury bill rates respond immediately to changes in the funds rate, but they hardly moved yesterday.
In late trading, the discount rate on 90-day bills was off a basis point, or hundredths of a percentage point, at 7.54 percent; six-month bills rose a basis point, to 7.46 percent, and the one-year bills were unchanged at 7.34 percent.
The Treasury announced that it would auction $10.25 billion of new one-year bills at its monthly auction of this maturity next Thursday.
At the far end of the Treasury market, the benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue that will mature in 2020, were offered late in the session at 102 11/32, up 6/32, to yield 8.53 percent, compared with 8.54 percent the day before and 8.45 percent a week before.
 
Notes of 1992 Rise
In between, the secondary market in Treasury debt found the 8 3/8 percent notes of 1992 up by 1/32, at 100 17/32, for a yield of 8.06 percent.
Next Wednesday, the Treasury plans to auction a record $11.5 billion of new two-year notes, which traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.05 percent, against 8.11 percent the day before.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8 7/8's of 2000, rose 4/32, to 102 21/32, for a yield of 8.47 percent, up from 8.43 perent a week earlier. The yield on the comparable Japanese maturity climbed to 7.38 percent from 7.21 percent the week before, while that on the West German 10-year bonds dropped to 8.39 percent from 8.54 percent during the week.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Profit Off 67.4%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., July 20

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said today that its earnings fell 67.4 percent in the second quarter, confirming its earlier prediction that profits would plunge.
The construction equipment maker said it earned $46 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $141 million, or $1.39 a share, in the comparable period of 1989. 
Revenue for the quarter totaled $2.95 billion, down 3 percent from the period of last year, when Caterpillar reported $3.04 billion in revenue.
The company attributed the decline to an 8 percent drop in sales volume, offset in part by higher prices and a $19 million improvement in revenue from its financial subsidiaries.
In a statement, the company attributed its sagging profits to a lower demand for machines among many industrial nations. On June 25, Caterpillar announced that drastic new economic policies in Brazil were having a disastrous impact on the company's profits.
Sales inside the United States were $1.3 billion for the quarter, a drop of $59 million from last year.
Caterpillar also said that it was the target of a class-action lawsuit filed this week in Peoria, Ill., regarding its financial condition. The company had no further comment on the suit.
