HEADLINE: Meetings Are Shifted By Chase

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Hurt by weak earnings, Citicorp and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's first- and second-largest banking companies, are cutting costs and focusing on the most prestigious part of their businesses: handling large corporate clients.
The more austere approach at Chase was signaled on Thursday, when senior officers were told that the international advisory committee - a group of 19 of the world's most prominent business executives headed by David Rockefeller, chairman of the bank in the 1970's - would hold two meetings later this year at Chase's headquarters in New York rather than in London and Brussels as planned.
And Chase directors, in an apparent effort to set an example for the rest of the bank, agreed to shift a meeting later this year from Williamsburg, Va., also to the more economical setting of Chase's headquarters building near Wall Street.
 
'A Massive Effort'
Chase officials declined to comment publicly on the changes. ''It is true, however,'' said Fraser P. Seitel, a spokesman for Chase, ''that we are engaged in a massive effort at Chase to do two things - boost revenues and reduce operating expenses by $300 million a year.'' 
Bank insiders said the changes were disclosed Thursday morning when Thomas G. Labrecque, Chase's newly named chairman, briefed senior officers about the previous day's board meeting.
At Citicorp, cost-cutting is concentrating on the global finance group, which lends to large corporations in North America, Europe and Japan. The bank said yesterday that it was reorganizing the group's management structure in ways that ''ultimately will result in fewer people and lower costs.'' Job Losses Acknowledged While both Chase and Citicorp are still working on details of how to reorganize their corporate lending businesses, they acknowledge that many jobs will be lost. At Chase, executives estimate that more than 3,000 employees might be cut, out of its work force of 42,000. Citicorp, with 90,000 employees, has not indicated how many jobs might be lost as it reorganizes the 15,000-employee global finance group, but analysts expect that a cut of several thousand is likely.
A large number of the layoffs are expected in New York City, where both banks are based. But both are continuing to expand their consumer banking business, which employs the greatest number of workers.
''We are witnessing truly major efforts to control costs, the like of which American banks have never seen before,'' said Thomas Hanley, a managing director at Salomon Brothers.
While the cost-cutting ''is long overdue,'' Mr. Hanley added, a determined management could cut costs more than might now be expected. At Chase, for example, ''I expect they will ultimately achieve cost savings substantially greater than the $300 million target they have set,'' he said.
Frank DeSantis, an analyst of large New York City banks at Paine Webber Inc., said the actions at Chase were a reminder that ''it is amazing what people can do in a crisis.'' Spending on meals and lodging for directors and the advisory committee is not the major problem at Chase, but ''the changes are symbolic and show a willingness of management to cut expenses starting at the top and going down,'' he added.
The shifts of meetings were suggested by Mr. Labrecque, whose announcement was loudly applauded at the normally uneventful monthly meeting of the senior officers, bankers at the meeting said. The 51-year-old Mr. Labrecque, an executive with 26 years of experience at Chase, was named in June to succeed Willard C. Butcher as chairman at the end of October. Mr. Butcher, who is retiring, was selected by Mr. Rockefeller to run the bank during the 1980's.
 
Profits Rather Than Prestige
Because Chase has been well known in banking circles for lavish spending on entertainment of clients and senior employees, analysts saw the willingness to cut spending on meetings of the advisory committee and the directors as a sign that under Mr. Labrecque the bank will become more concerned with profits than prestige.
The international advisory committee was created by Mr. Rockefeller as a way for Chase to benefit from the economic and political insights of key business leaders. Henry A. Kissinger is a member of the committee, along with Giovanni Agnelli, the chairman of Fiat S.p.A., and Lord Carrington, chairman of the Christies International auction house and a former British Foreign Secretary.
Under Mr. Rockefeller, and to a lesser extent Mr. Butcher, the chairman of Chase has tended to be more involved with activities like the international advisory committee, leaving to subordinates the nitty-gritty work of controlling costs and avoiding bad loans.
Mr. Labrecque has already indicated he will be more active than his predecessors in the daily management of the bank.
 
Employee-Protection Plan
Other action taken by Chase's board on Wednesday included approval of a plan to protect all employee severance pay agreements and retirement funds if control of the company changed. The so-called ''tin parachutes'' would not necessarily prevent an unwanted acquisition or merger, but they have been adopted by other banking companies because they make employees more confident about their future.
The need for cost-cutting is especially evident at banks like Chase and Citicorp, which have been hurt by a decline in wholesale lending and other financing for large corporations. While the banks still maintain expensive networks of foreign offices, corporate treasurers have learned how to borrow more cheaply in the securities markets or from foreign banks. During 1989, the decline in the wholesale banking business with large corporations accelerated, as the number and size of corporate takeovers and leveraged buyouts dropped.
Citicorp executives say they do not have a target for how many jobs will be cut in the next few years. But analysts said they expected Citicorp would cut costs in its global finance group by at least 10 percent, with the loss of several thousand jobs. Profits in the global finance group, headed since January by Michael A. Callen, fell 69 percent in the second quarter, to $42 million, as operating expenses rose along with the costs of bad loans.
 
Change in Measurements
To improve the performance of the global finance group, Mr. Callen said that the practice of measuring bankers' performances by earnings of each profit center would be de-emphasized and replaced by measures of market share, rankings compared with other banks and the total amount of revenues from a corporate client.
Mr. Callen said he was beginning to review staffing in each of 50 different activities of the global finance group with a goal of cutting back the layers of management.
Citicorp and Chase are not the only money-center banks acting to reduce costs. Earlier this week, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the eighth-largest banking company, said it was planning to cut 1,400 jobs and reduce costs by $125 million annually. Most of the cuts are also expected in the corporate finance area.

HEADLINE: Tax Protest Shows Splits In New Jersey

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLMDEL, N.J., July 19

 BODY:
A gathering of mayors from across New Jersey tonight was advertised by its host, Mayor Peggy Lasky of Holmdel, as a search for ''constructive reform'' of the $2.8 billion in higher income taxes and sales taxes that Gov. Jim Florio pushed through the Legislature.
But over three and a half hours, the meeting of 110 mayors and municipal officials evolved into partisan fighting between Republicans and Democrats, and an illustration of the wide gulf separating New Jersey's poor cities and prosperous suburbs.
The Governor, in arguing that New Jersey cannot afford to remain separated into rich and poor, fashioned his tax and school-financing package so that the state's wealthiest residents and communities would bear much of the tax burden for increasing school aid and providing property-tax relief in cities and poor rural areas.
 
Urban Democrats
John F. Zisa, a Republican who is Mayor of Hackensack, which is to lose millions of dollars in school aid under Mr. Florio's plan, called the session ''New Jersey's first 'Tea Party.' '' And for Republicans the meeting was a pep rally, with Republican mayors serving up anti-tax rhetoric to a crowd of about 350 people in the audience at Holmdel High School already brimming with hostility to Mr. Florio. 
Two pro-Florio, big-city Democrats, Sharpe James of Newark and William Pascrell of Paterson, appealed for unity and drew hoots in response.
''Instead of pointing fingers at one another, we should work together to get an equitable solution,'' Mr. Pascrell said. ''We need to lower our voices if we're going to have one New Jersey. Each of our pains should be all of our pains.''
That drew a deep round of boos from the audience. Mr. James called the Governor courageous for cutting the state budget by $2 billion and said ''we should march together.'' More boos erupted. ''Come up with alternatives and I'll listen,'' he said. More boos arose. When Ms. Lasky summoned the mayors in a July 4 letter, she wrote that she was ''fighting mad'' about the Florio tax package and told her colleagues that they should ''do something that will be heard all the way to Trenton.'' An agenda accompanying the letter suggested withholding tax payments to the state and organizing a major march on Trenton.
No such plans emerged tonight. A 16-member committee was created, but with a murky agenda and its schedule for future meetings vague.
At the meeting's end, Mr. Lasky said that she would summon the committee in mid-August, after her vacation, and that they would consider a list of issues to present to the Governor, including repealing the tax package and dropping the state's mandate that school districts, rather than the state, pay their teachers' pensions costs.
Despite Mr. Zisa's talk about a tea party, nobody suggested withholding tax payments.
At one point, Democratic mayors sought to undercut the entire proceeding. They pressed for a vote that would have allowed the state's League of Municipalities and its Conference of Mayors to act as the official mechanism for any mayors' complaints about the higher taxes.
 
'Like a Republican Conspiracy'
Ms. Lasky refused to allow the vote, and many Democrats left.
After they did, Florio aides who said they had come as observers spent several minutes ushering Democrats to reporters.
''It's like a Republican conspiracy,'' grumbled Michael Voll, Mayor of Middle Township.
''I'm not sure what this ad hoc group wants to accomplish,'' complained Donald Rainear, Mayor of Bridgeton. ''It appears to be a lot of Florio-bashing.''
Holmdel and other towns in Monmouth County and neighboring Ocean County are a center of anti-Florio, anti-tax sentiment now. A grass-roots tax-revolt movement, Hands Across New Jersey, is centered in the two counties. Its founder, John Budzash, a 39-year-old mailman, said 350,000 people have signed petitions calling for repeal of the Florio tax package, legislation allowing voters to recall a governor and members of the Legislature, and binding referendums on the November ballot.
 
A Committee Is Proposed
Those petitions have recently started appearing in the affluent suburbs of Bergen, Essex, and Morris Counties. Those areas face the stiffest increases in income taxes and deepest cuts in state school aid under the Florio package. Resentment runs deep in those counties, but there has been no coordinated protest there.
On a night thick with political verbiage, one novel reformist idea was offered. Timothy McDonough, a political independent and Mayor of Hope Township, a community of about 1,700 in rural Warren County on the Delaware River, proposed creation of a committee of business executives, citizens and state officials to monitor the state's revenues each month.
''The minute they drop below projections, we cut state spending on the spot,'' Mr. McDonough said. ''It's a simple law of economics. You've got to have money to spend it. What's the alternative? Raising taxes, which is why we are here tonight.''
Democratic mayors said a multimillion-dollar deficit left behind by Gov. Thomas H. Kean, a Republican, forced Mr. Florio's sweeping tax increases, the largest in state history. Republicans and their sympathizers in the audience wanted none of that.
 
'Something Called Recall'
The Mayor of Parsippany-Troy Hills, Frank Priore, a Republican, accused the Governor of over-taxing residents. He said $700 million could have closed the budget gap and another $500 million could have satisfied the recent State Supreme Court mandate for additional financing for the state's poorest 28 urban school systems.
''Why take $2.8 billion from the taxpayers?'' Mr. Priore shouted to the audience, drawing a roar of approval. ''In my town they have something called recall. It makes you receptive and responsible to the people.''
Another Republican Mayor, Bob McKenna, of Wall Township, devoted his time to a second theme of the anti-tax movement - legislation to establish initiative and referendum processes to give voters the authority to write law without going through the Legislature.
''People have to feel they have some degree of control,'' Mr. McKenna said. ''The greatest shame of this entire situation is the cynicism the average person in the state has developed. People have lost faith.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Peggy Lasky of Holmdel, who called a meeting of New Jersey's mayors to fight Gov. Jim Florio's new tax package. (F. N. Kinney for The New York Times) (pg. 24)

HEADLINE: Sandinistas' U.S. Friends: Case of Dashed Ideals

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
Americans who spent much of the last 10 years working in the United States and Nicaragua on behalf of the Sandinista Government now find themselves back in their cramped and dreary offices in New York, stunned by defeat, deserted by their constituency and searching for a new outlet for their dreams.
After the Sandinista Party lost the national election in February, donations to the American groups plummeted, projects in Nicaragua were suspended, volunteers returned to the United States, and trips to Nicaragua were cut back or canceled.
The morale of those men and women has suffered what many say is an irreversible blow. They went to Nicaragua to help the Sandinistas build what they called a new society. Although the Americans could continue their humanitarian programs there, the Sandinistas' loss of power has removed much of the utopian appeal of the work. ''The only thing I can compare it to is the day Kennedy was shot,'' Lynda Sharp said of the election. She belongs to the Nicaragua Solidarity Network of Greater New York. 
The election brought Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and her United States-backed coalition, the National Opposition Union, to power. The vote shattered the faith that many volunteers had in the Sandinistas, who survived nearly 10 years of war with the American-backed contra rebels. Scores of volunteers are searching for new political movements to support.
''Folks are finding themselves moving to other countries where there is a lot of conflict, like the Middle East and South Africa,'' said Lucy F. Harris, coordinator of the Witness for Peace delegations in Nicaragua. ''Since the elections our numbers have fallen off by about 50 percent.''
At the cluttered office of the solidarity network on the top floor of a three-story brick building at Bleecker and Lafayette Streets in Greenwich Village, the walls document the cause. There are posters in English and Spanish denouncing United States intervention in Nicaragua, pictures of Augusto Cesar Sandino, the Nicaraguan revolutionary hero, and multicolored banners tightly furled around wood poles that denounce American policy and call on people to defend the Sandinista revolution.
The 30 volunteers involved with the solidarity network, which has a yearly budget of $20,000, said they remained committed to the Sandinistas. But even they recognize that times are difficult. The Sandinistas, who were armed by Cuba and the Soviet bloc but were also supported by many democratic governments in Latin America and Europe, describe themselves as democratic socialists trying to provide a better life for workers and peasants. They sought to abolish privilege and economic inequities, including the unequal distribution of land and basic resources.
The American workers, many of them alienated by the culture and political life in the United States, saw in the Sandinista Government the embodiment of a simpler and more egalitarian society that they thought the United States should emulate.
''They gave a new definition to democracy,'' William Wilhelm, 29, a leader in the solidarity network, said. ''They built a democracy that was striving to be economic and political, that pervaded all levels in society.''
Solidarity groups had an important role in the often angry debate about United States policy toward Nicaragua. They publicized what they saw as atrocities by the contra army, which was backed by the United States, and developed a wide grass-roots network, especially in churches and universities.
The groups organized two- or three-week tours in which an estimated 250,000 Americans paid their way to Nicaragua. The Americans were often taken to pro-Sandinista organizaions in air-conditioned buses and returned to meet local groups to extol the virtues of Sandinismo and expose what they saw as the terrorism of the contras.
 
Historical Precedents
Hundreds visited for longer periods to work for pittances for the Sandinistas or Sandinista-backed organizations. The visitors worked on activities like water purification and erecting community buildings.
''The extraordinary thing about the Nicaraguan political tours and the attraction exerted by the Nicaraguan political system is that there were many historical precedents of the same phenomena,'' said Dr. Paul Hollander, a professor of sociology at the University of Massaschusetts at Amherst. Dr. Hollander wrote ''Political Pilgrims,'' an examination of socialist systems and their attractions to Western intellectuals.
''High hopes were dashed when earlier generations learned about the realities of the Soviet, Chinese, Cuban, Vietnamese and other political systems,'' Dr. Hollander said. ''A lot of well-educated people learned nothing from this, because they had an urgent need to find a countermodel to the inequality and meaninglessness that they felt prevailed in their own society.''
The loss of the election on Feb. 25 tarnished the messianic quality of the effort in Nicaragua.
''If they remained involved in projects in Nicaragua, their humanitarian activities would have had a more mundane or prosaic aspect to them,'' Dr. Hollander said. ''It would have been no diffferent from building clinics or rural schools in, say, Mexico, where the poor would equally have benefited from such activities, but without the mystique of building a fundamentally different society. Nor would they have been in a position to make a statement against U.S. foreign policy through such activities.''
Witness for Peace, which has taken more than 3,400 people to Nicaragua since 1984, canceled 6 of its 28 delegations this year and combined 2 others.
Two weeks ago the New York Nicaragua Construction Brigade, which had sent 10 groups, closed because money and interest were lacking. Other groups like the Nica School in Nicaragua, which gave classes in Spanish and lectured on the achievements of the revolution, have also closed.
''The members were involved in other things, and there was no new life in the organization,'' said Regina M. Shields, 24, who had worked for the construction brigade. ''The concept of a construction brigade lost its flair.''
 
Decline in Number of Travelers
Contributions have also fallen off sharply. ''The financial effect has been grave,'' said Vivian Stromberg, executive director of Madre, a group that says it has sent more than $1 million in medical supplies to Nicaragua since 1984 and has cut its full-time staff, to 5 from 10.
Marazul Tours, which specializes in trips to Cuba and Nicaragua for political groups, advertised a travel package to Nicaragua for the 11th anniversary of the revolution, which was celebrated on Thursday. The agency, which has arranged trips to Nicaragua for 25,000 people in the last 10 years, helped 250 people attend the anniversary last year. This year no one signed up for the group tour, although the agency arranged for 12 individuals to go to the fete.
Many workers who had lived in Nicaragua have returned to the United States. ''Our ability to continue doing what we were doing there has been reduced following the election,'' said Dee C. Knight, 43, who worked for more than two years with the newspaper of the Sandinista Party and returned recently to New York.
Projects in Nicaragua have wound down in the wake of the elections. A group in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, a ''sister city'' group, has suspended the aid it was sending to build a well in the town of El Jicaral.
''After the elections, suddenly there was a division in our group,'' said Guadalupe Landaverde, 45, a high school teacher and a leader of the Chelsea group. ''We are trying to make a decision. Should we continue to work on the well or work with organizations here that deal with drug abuse, the dropout rate in the schools, housing and health care?''
Ms. Landaverde said she knew of other groups that had more difficulties. ''You should see the groups that are in solidarity with the people of Eastern Europe,'' she said. ''I hear they are in real trouble.''

HEADLINE: Japanese in the New York Region Begin to Feel the Sting of Prejudice

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Japanese who have settled in the New York suburbs, whether for a temporary business assignment or for good, are starting to feel a backlash from their growing presence and the rising economic tensions between Japan and the United States.
In Rye, N.Y., a handful of American parents, unhappy that Japanese enrollment in public schools has swelled so that in one elementary school a fourth of the pupils are Japanese, have quietly pulled their children out of the prestigious system, school officials say.
''You will find people who are totally offended by their being here, which, to me, is a very basic form of bigotry,'' said Lynn Ferrari, a spokeswoman for the district.
 
Japanese-Americans Affected
In Knollwood, N.J., Tak Furumoto, a 45-year-old real-estate broker born in the United States, was dining in a restaurant not long after Mitsubishi bought a majority stake in Rockefeller Center when, he said, ''A couple came up to us and said, 'Why are you guys buying up America?' I told them, 'Hey, we're Japanese-Americans, and I fought in Vietnam.' ''
''But that didn't help,'' he continued. ''Japanese-Americans are affected as well. People don't make the distinction.'' 
Several factors have contributed to what some Japanese and experts in relations between the two countries see as a backlash of feelings.
A rapid movement of Japanese during the 1980's - into many of the New York metropolitan region's most affluent suburbs - has transformed neighborhoods and school districts.
Once here, Japanese students tend to spend more time studying and earn better grades than American students, educators say. #60,000 in Region Language and cultural barriers, as well as the fact that most Japanese families are on temporary assignment, have led to social isolation. And as the Japanese presence has increased, there has been a growing resentment among many Americans who believe the Japanese have usurped the United States' position in the world economy.
Safety and good school districts have attracted many of the Japanese to suburbs like Fort Lee, N.J., and Scarsdale, Hartsdale and Rye, all in Westchester County, N.Y.
There are an estimated 60,000 Japanese men, women and children living in the New York region, according to the Japanese Consulate. For the most part, they are here for a few years with Japanese corporations, but there are also long-term residents who never obtained United States citizenship and spouses of American citizens.
''It's a new phenomenon that people have yet to absorb,'' said Daniel Bob, the assistant director of studies and policy programs at the Japan Society, a private organization committed to bettering understanding between the United States and Japan.
 
Tensions Are Often Muted
''It's similar to the American invasion of Europe in the 1960's,'' he said. ''Initially, there was a great uproar over American investments and fear of an American takeover. It's a natural reaction to something that happens so quickly.''
Many Japanese say they have yet to encounter strained feelings. Moreover, signs of tension are usually muted in the educated, sophisticated communities with the greatest concentration of Japanese.
''You see Japan blamed and put down on television, in newspapers and in political speeches,'' said Masato Matsuo, 53, a Scarsdale resident and president of Nippon Zeon, a chemical company in White Plains. ''But I don't directly see this in my personal relationships. The intellectuals know exactly what's going on and don't blame me for it.''
In gestures grand and small, the Japanese have also tried to smooth relations. Many drive American cars - a symbolic act bespeaking a respect for American products at a time when Japanese consumer products dominate.
 
Tour for Educators
In Harrison, N.Y., another Westchester town, the founders of a new Japanese high school gave the town $500,000 in thanks for its cooperation. In Rye, 48 Japanese families donated 10 fully grown Japanese cherry trees to a school at graduation this year.
And for the second year in a row, the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry of New York flew a dozen educators from the New York region to Japan for a two-week tour.
''It was fantastic,'' said Dr. Barry Farnham, the Superintendent of the Rye school district, after returning this month. ''I really got to know Japan as a country and the Japanese as a people.''
Yet it is not unusual to overhear people castigating the Japanese in whispered conversations for ''taking over'' their neighborhoods or schools or country clubs. Racist outbursts have grown common, too. Motorists yell ''Japs'' at Japanese golfers as they drive by.
''I've been playing golf for years, and I've never heard this as much as in the last year,'' said Mr. Furumoto, who was born in an internment camp in California during World War II.
 
Cultural Barriers
Recently Hisako Cunningham, a New Yorker for 23 years, approached a woman who had illegally parked in a handicapped-parking space in Elmsford, N.Y. Mrs. Cunningham, who works with handicapped people, said she asked the woman if she had a permit, and was told to ''go back where you came from.''
''That wouldn't have happened 10 years ago,'' said Mrs. Cunningham, who is married to an American citizen.
Mrs. Cunningham is also president of a self-help group in Westchester County that serves some 90 Asian mothers, most of them Japanese.
She says she understands why many Japanese appear to shy from social connections - they don't seek ''social expansion'' even in Japan, she said, and are hindered by the language barrier. But the isolation worries her.
 
Confrontations at School
''Their attitude is 'As long as we don't become a social burden, as long as we are law-abiding residents, then we're O.K.,' '' she said. ''They're not aware of the impact their clinging tendency has on American society.''
This spring her group, Services to Parents of Exceptional Asian Children, surveyed 147 Japanese households to see how parents felt about their children's education and assimilation. An intitial look at the responses, she said, found that parents were concerned about bullying and the mysterious disappearance of their children's belongings, especially high-tech gadgets, in school.
Indeed, school seems to be the place where conflicts, real or perceived, are played out most. Some American parents object that a teacher's attention is diverted at the elementary level by children speaking Japanese. In high school, some argue, the academic success of Japanese students who then return to Japan for college is unfairly skewing the class rank of American students.
''By the time kids around here reach high school, they expect Japanese students to win most of the high-achievement awards,'' said a mother in Rye. ''That can be defeating.'' 'Extremely Distracting'
The mother, who has lived in Rye for 16 years and has three children, took her son out of the public elementary school a few years ago in part because of what she called the ''imbalance'' of Japanese students. She agreed to discuss her reasons on condition that she not be named.
''There were 20 students in his class and six were Japanese,'' she said. ''It was extremely distracting for my son to hear students speaking Japanese while the teacher spoke English.''
Education and government leaders brush aside those concerns. ''You don't have to give the Japanese students much attention because they pick up the language rapidly,'' said Dr. Charles J. Murphy, the Superintendent of the Eastchester school district, where 15 percent of the enrollment is Japanese, up from 8 percent 10 years ago.
Dr. Farnham of Rye said, ''My feeling is that we are a public school system, and we need to respond to our constituents. If we have large numbers of Hispanic students or Japanese students, we must adapt accordingly.''
 
'A Wonderful Challenge'
The competition from Japanese students at the high school level is healthy, in the view of Charles Balancia, the Town Supervisor of Harrison, where the private Keio High School of New York is to open soon.
''If it takes the Japanese children to show us how to excel, so be it,'' he said. ''We have to become more competitive in the world marketplace. This is a wonderful challenge.''
The relations between students themselves are becoming standoffish. When Maki Morimoto arrived in Rye five years ago, he was one of five Japanese students in the eighth grade, but the population has since grown.
''As the number of Japanese students increases, there's more isolation, both because the Japanese are grouping together and Americans aren't making an effort to know them,'' said Mr. Morimoto, the only one of 10 Japanese graduates from Rye this year staying in the United States for college. He will enter Brown University this fall.
''I think, too,'' he said, ''that the American students are probably jealous of the Japanese math and science whizzes.''
Mr. Morimoto was unusual in high school, able to bridge the gap between the communities. A member of the tennis, cross-country and ski teams, he attended American parties, which few of the Japanese students did. His assimilation was eased by his relatively long stay in the United States and by his father's familiarity with American culture after graduate studies at the University of Wisconson.
''I'm so happy being here,'' Mr. Morimoto said. ''Although there's tension between Americans and Japanese -it's definitely there - I can deal with it.''

HEADLINE: Army Town in Texas Pays the Price of Peace

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT HOOD, Tex., July 20

 BODY:
There were no victory parades here when the cold war ended. Instead, warriors began slipping away, tanks were lined up neatly on parking lots for storage, and the civilians who live around this huge Army base started feeling as though they were the losers.
This summer, responding to what it calls ''recent changes in the international climate,'' the Army has begun to dismantle the Second Armored Division, which has 12,000 soldiers based here. The division, known as ''Hell on Wheels,'' was created by Gen. George S. Patton Jr. and fought Nazi panzer divisions in France, Belgium and Germany as part of his Third Army in World War II. Since 1951 it has been poised to fight World War III by rushing troops to protect West Germany from Communist invaders.
''We're all for peace,'' said Mayor Major Blair of Killeen, a central Texas city situated just beyond the gates of the fort. ''But there is something totally wrong about how this is happening. We've always backed the military 100 percent all the way, but now that everything is supposed to be just fine over there, we're going to be living in welfare conditions over here.'' 
 
A Devastating Local Effect
Even though the base is not closing and thousands of troops will remain, the dismantling of the division is expected to have as severe an effect on the local economy as any of the military cutbacks announced so far. The fort is virtually the only source of economic activity for the surrounding area.
Property values in Killeen and neighboring towns have dropped 20 percent since January, when the move was announced, and economists have said unemployment could approach 25 percent after the Second Armored is completely gone by September 1991.
Already some guidons, the banners that the division carried to victory in places like St. Lo and the Battle of the Bulge, are being furled. By the end of the summer about 3,500 soldiers from the Second Armored will be reassigned to other units, and their tanks and other vehicles will be stored in motor pools stretching two and a half miles into the rolling hills.
 
Some Misgivings at Home
In Washington, politicians and analysts are debating whether the United States has been left behind in a world changing so quickly that West Germany decides to offer economic aid to the Soviet Union.
But in Killeen, people like Mayor Blair find it bitterly ironic that their city has fallen victim to the cold war it helped to win. And they express misgivings that go beyond their own hardships.
''This is an awfully fine unit to be throwing away,'' the Mayor said. ''I wish we'd wait until the Russians got rid of theirs before we did it.''
Attracted by the mix of woodlands and rolling savanna, the Army started buying land around Killeen in 1942. There were fewer than 2,000 people in the area then, and there was a lot of empty space.
 
Heavy Military Presence
The base now covers 217,237 acres, and 68,000 people are living in Killeen. The Army fills the vast emptiness. Roughly 100 miles from both Austin and Dallas, Killeen is close enough to be outclassed economically by the two cities but too far away to benefit from their growth. Nearly two-thirds of the families in Killeen, including a growing number of retired military personnel, draw their income directly from the Army.
The military presence gives Killeen a gaudy look not found in the average central Texas town. Cars with out-of-state license plates driven by young men with close-cropped hair fill streets, like Rancier Avenue, that are lined with fast food restaurants, motorcycle and used car dealers, cheap motels and pawn shops.
''My grandparents farmed land that had been in the family for generations until the Army came along and bought them out,'' said Bruce Whitis. ''Without land they had to come to town and learn how to make a living off the military people who moved onto the land.''
Mr. Whitis, aware of the money management problems seemingly endemic to young soldiers, manages five pawn shops strategically situated near the fort's gates.
 
'Prepare for the Worst'
''We've become totally dependent on the military,'' he said. ''Now we aren't going to have either the land or the people, so all I can do is prepare for the worst.''
The Pentagon is also preparing for the worst. Adapting to a reduced Soviet threat abroad and increasing budget deficits at home, the Bush Administration decided to dismantle the Second Armored as part of a series of spending cuts that could eventually reduce forces at 20 bases and close 35 other installations. Those proposals are now in various stages of study and action.
In any case, Fort Hood is not about to disappear.
The Pentagon has said the Second Armored is the only division that can be dismantled without closing an entire base. Fort Hood is the only Army base in the United States that is the home of two divisions - the First Cavalry Division is the other. That division and other assorted units will remain, leaving about 26,000 troops at Fort Hood.
But there is a widespread feeling in Killeen that the military has somehow betrayed an essential bargain.
 
'Brick and Mortar Activity'
In the last decade the Army spent $350 million on three headquarters buildings, motor pools, barracks and other complexes.
''I and lots of other officers encouraged the local people to keep pace with all the brick and mortar activity we had on the base,'' said Gen. Bob Shoemaker, who held several command posts at Fort Hood in 1970's and returned here after retiring. ''We told them Fort Hood was here to stay, and that with an all-volunteer Army it was especially important that they develop the amenities - the schools, roads and hotels and retail shopping.''
In the last 15 years the population of the Killeen area doubled. In the last few years local government agencies have issued bonds worth nearly $40 million to expand water treatment systems and public schools used extensively by the fort.
On June 8, Bell County, which encompasses the Killeen area, along with an ad hoc citizens' group called Keep Hood Alive and Kicking Inc., or Khaki, filed suit in Federal District Court in Waco seeking a preliminary injunction to halt the dismantling of the Second Armored.
 
Army Motion Rejected
Federal District Judge Walter Smith rejected an Army motion to dismiss the suit. He does not expect to issue a ruling before next month.
The suit contends that the Army should have completed a statement on the effect the action would have on the environment and says that if it had done so it would have uncovered some substantial ill effects.
In two days of testimony earlier this month the plaintiffs presented studies they commissioned. They contended among other things that the drop in use of the water and sewer systems would render them dangerously inefficient. They even argued that Army activity enhanced the growth of shrubs that are home to the black capped vireo, an endangered species, and that the birds could lose habitat if the Army abandoned its training grounds.
A main contention is that the ''human environment'' faces harm. There was testimony that 10,000 houses and apartments would be left empty, creating the potential for decay, vandalism and crime. An economic study was produced that forecast ''severely devastating economic damage'' based on the loss of more than 19,600 jobs.
''We are going to be hit by a double whammy,'' Mayor Blair said. ''Just as our tax base is shriveling, we're going to have to provide additional services to all these people in economic distress.''
The Army readily acknowledges that the dismantling of the Second Armored Division will have a severe economic effect on the area. But it contends that the effects on the physical environment can be mitigated and that legal precedents do not allow socio-economic problems to be considered environmental damage.
''What gets me is that everything is changing so fast,'' said Gaylon Christie, chairman of Khaki. ''We are all pro-military here, and I think we'd all go along with whatever the Army decided, even if it cost us, if we just had the feeling that there was a plan, that someone, somewhere knew where we are heading in this crazy world.''

HEADLINE: Western Europe, Its Births Falling, Wonders Who'll Do All the Work

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 21

 BODY:
French families receive generous welfare and tax incentives to have more children, but to no avail. Mothers in France are no longer averaging the 2.1 children needed to insure a natural replacement of the country's population.
In Italy, families are now smaller on average than they are in any other Western European country. So the Government in Rome is trying to woo back descendants of Italians who emigrated to Latin America.
Throughout Western Europe, the trend is clear. As birth rates tumble and life expectancy grows, populations are aging rapidly. 
 
Opposition to Immigration
The number of entrants to the job market will drop in the 1990's, demographers say, and total populations will begin to fall early in the 21st century.
A product of prosperity, this population revolution is posing a complex new challenge. Throughout Western Europe there is strong opposition to new immigration, yet demographers say that foreign workers will be needed to keep up living standards.
For the moment, with millions of Europeans out of work, a labor shortage is not apparent. In several places, immigration is even blamed for unemployment. But immigrants are needed to do the menial or low-paid jobs that out-of-work locals refuse to do.
''A number of countries may be about to enter a long cycle of dependence on migration even though a large proportion of public opinion and of the political class is violently hostile to the idea,'' said Jean-Claude Chesnais, an expert with the National Institute of Demographic Studies in France.
In the 1960's, immigration began changing Europe's social profile. Today, of the 327 million people in the 12-nation European Community, about 12 million are immigrants or descendants of immigrants, with close to 4.5 million in France, 2.5 million in Britain and 1.8 million in West Germany.
Belgium and the Netherlands have large numbers of immigrants from their former colonies in Africa, Asia and the Caribbean region. Over the last five years, Arabs have begun flocking to Italy and Spain.
Even East Germany contracted laborers from Vietnam and Cuba to work in factories.
 
Few Nations Deal With Issue
Beyond building child-care centers and extending maternity leave to encourage mothers to keep working, experts say few governments have dealt with the link between demographic trends and immigration, preferring instead to respond to public pressure to keep out foreigners.
''People have tended to look at immigration as the problem,'' a British sociologist said. ''But it really is the consequence. Look at the United States and Mexico. As long as there are poverty and people in the third world and jobs and capital in the first world, economic forces will work naturally.''
While these forces are also at work in the United States and Japan, the demographic change is strongest in Western Europe. Of the European Community members, only Ireland has a fertility rate that is keeping up with the natural replacement level of 2.1 children.
In Italy and Spain, traditionally countries of large families, it is down to 1.3. And in the European Community as a whole, where there were 41,000 fewer births in 1989 than in 1988, the average is only 1.58.
Demographers calculate the replacement level at 2.1 rather than 2 to take account of people who die before they reach reproductive age.
 
Ranks of Elderly Growing
As life expectancy has surged, the ''graying of the population'' has accelerated. ''There are already 100 million people in the European Community nations over 50 years of age and their number is growing steadily,'' the European Commission said in a recent report. ''By the early years of the next century, Europe will have more older than younger people. The traditional 'age pyramid' will stand on its head.''
One effect will be on social welfare budgets, with governments required to switch the focus of spending from children and education toward senior citizens, pensions and health care.
For example, a recent study in Madrid showed that the city had more people over 65 than under 15.
Still more significant will be the impact on a labor force that is being squeezed by youths who are stretching out their years of education and older workers seeking early retirement.
By the year 2020, according to the European Commission, nonworking dependents will account for two-thirds to three-quarters of the people in the 12 European Community nations.
 
Need for Immigrants Will Grow
For demographers, the statistical message is clear. ''The need for immigrants will grow,'' Mr. Chesnais said. ''You'll have fewer people entering the labor market and more leaving. You'll have an aging labor force that is tired and less efficient but also wants higher salaries. What does a businessman do? He turns to immigrants who earn less and work harder.''
Mass immigration to Western Europe began in the 1960's, with concentrations of Algerians in France, Indians and Pakistanis in Britain and Turks and Yugoslavs in West Germany. By the mid-1970's, political pressure brought restrictions. But the flow continued as relatives joined immigrants and as illegal immigration rose.
Today, with tens of thousands of third-world citizens entering the region each year, either as illegals or as refugees, hostility towards immigrants is growing in several countries, notably France and West Germany.
As it prepares to eliminate its internal borders in 1993, the European Community is also planning a unified policy to keep out new immigrants.
 
Move on to Better Jobs
Foreign workers now pick crops on farms, wash up in restaurants, work on assembly lines, keep city streets clean and run small shops in many countries. Experts say that new immigrants will be needed because once immigrants have settled down they tend to look for better jobs.
From an economic point of view, the need for a constantly replenished work force - a labor reserve, as economists put it - is still greater. And as European populations move deeper into the cycle of aging, stagnating and falling, experts say that the European Community's labor deficit will grow.
During the 1990's, demographers said, some of the gap will be bridged by more women entering the job market and by falling levels of unemployment. But noting that a need for immigration will continue to coexist with unemployment, they said the community would have to look elsewhere for cheap labor.
 
East Germans Take Over Jobs
In the short term, Germany will be an exception. A million East Germans arrived in West Germany in the last year and many more East German are expected to lose their jobs after economic unification.
Some third-world migrants in West Germany, notably Turks, are already being put out of work. Yet a united Germany will still have one of Europe's lowest fertility rates - an average of 1.5 children.
Some countries of Eastern Europe, on the other hand, may become suppliers of labor to the European Community if their economic reforms bring high unemployment. In the past, immigrants from countries like Poland, Romania and Yugoslavia have been more easily assimilated than those from most third-world countries.
North Africa is the region where European political concerns appear likely to clash with economic needs. The birth rate in North Africa is more than three times higher than in the European Community. This population growth and an acute economic crisis are already combining to create enormous pressure on young North Africans to emigrate.
 
More Muslims Are Expected
Calculating the ''pull'' of European labor needs and the ''push'' of third-world poverty, one demographer has estimated that new immigrants and their children could number between 25 million and 65 million by the year 2025, with the great majority of them Muslims from Mediterranean nations.
When many Europeans express fear of immigration, they are usually refering to North Africans. Muslims are perceived as having more difficulty than other foreigners in integrating into Christian societies. For example, France's largest immigrant population is Portuguese, yet Arabs are the main focus of French hostility toward foreign immigrants.
''I don't think Europe is going to be hit by a tidal wave of immigration,'' said a demographer who works for the European Community.
''I think it will be regulated by demand, although demand will grow at the end of the century. But Europe's big challenge is not how to keep out immigrants but how to integrate them.''

HEADLINE: Stories of 2 Ex-Wives Enliven Michigan Race

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 18

 BODY:
Here's the top of the political news from Michigan: Gov. James J. Blanchard, a two-term Democrat, has begun his campaign for re-election, facing a well-financed challenge from State Senator John Engler, a Republican.
But politics aside, the Michigan governor's race is noteworthy for another reason: The former wives of both candidates have written books that document, in part, the breakups of their marriages.
On July 29, excerpts from Paula Blanchard's book, '''Til Politics Do Us Part,'' are scheduled to begin running in The Detroit News after the newspaper paid $20,000 for the publication rights. Ms. Blanchard, who was divorced in 1987, says the book is a description of the highs and lows of her 21-year marriage.
She said she did not believe that anything in the book would be politically damaging to her former husband, adding that she remained proud of him and did not want to hurt him. Even so, she said, the Governor asked her to postpone publication until after the November election but she refused. 
 
Life of a Political Spouse
''It's basically a story about the high price of being a political spouse,'' said Ms. Blanchard, an associate vice president of a Detroit public relations firm.
Mr. Engler's former wife, Colleen, says her manuscript, ''A Matter of Trust,'' will not be submitted to publishers until after the election.
Ms. Engler, an unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor in 1986 who then ran for lieutenant governor the same year, filed for divorce the day after she lost the election.
''My book is a lot different than Paula's,'' said Ms. Engler, who now works for the Commerce Department in Washington. ''Although I discuss somewhat what happened to my marriage to John, it is really incidental to the story of the campaign in 1986 and my life as a woman running for public office.''
Campaign aides for the Governor -and even Republican Party officials -play down the potential political consequences of Ms. Blanchard's book, but they concede that coming in the middle of a political campaign, it has kept the gossip mills churning in an otherwise sleepy summer. 'A Non-Event'? According to the Detroit Free Press, which recently printed a long interview with Ms. Blanchard, the book will address her reaction to rumors that her husband was having an affair with a staff member, Janet Fox, to whom the Governor is now married. In the same interview, Ms. Blanchard said any suspicions that she or others had about her husband's fidelity were not a direct cause of their divorce, and she said she ''chose to believe'' that he had been faithful.
For his part, Governor Blanchard has turned away inquiries about his former wife's book, which is being published by the A & M Publishing Company of suburban Detroit.
Mr. Blanchard's campaign manager, Gary Bachula, said he expected the book ''to be a non-event,'' in terms of its political effect. ''But it will be a major event in Paula's life,'' he said, ''and we wish her well.''
Rusty Hills, a spokesman for the Michigan Republican State Committee, said: ''From what I know, I don't think there is anything in the book that will damage the Governor politically. But coming during the middle of the campaign, I suspect it will sell her some books. I know a lot of Republicans who will probably buy one.''
David W. Rohde, a political science professor at Michigan State University, said he regarded talk of the book as little more than a summer diversion. ''We're a long way from the time when people react negatively to a candidate because of a divorce,'' he said. ''Even to learn later, after the marriage broke up, that one or other of the parties was involved with someone else, I think it's a ho-hum kind of thing.''
 
Contest for Senate Seat
Governor Blanchard, who enters this season's campaign as the front-runner, has no opposition in the statewide primary on Aug. 7. Mr. Engler, who has been the Senate majority leader since 1984, is being challenged on the Republican ballot by John Lauve, a perennial candidate who is expected to win few votes.
In another Michigan race, voters will have to decide between two Republicans competing to challenge Senator Carl Levin, a Democrat who is seeking a third term.
The two are Representative Bill Schuette, who has represented the 10th Congressional District in central Michigan since 1984, and W. Clark Durant 3d, a lawyer who was chairman of the Legal Services Corporation in the Reagan Administration. Mr. Schuette has been endorsed by the state party leadership and is leading in polls.
In the governor's race, Democrats are counting on the staying power that incumbents have traditionally enjoyed in Michigan. Two of Mr. Blanchard's predecessors, William G. Milliken, a Republican, and G. Mennen Williams, the Democrat everyone called Soapy, held the office for 14 years and 12 years, respectively, before deciding not to run again.
 
A Boost From Chrysler Role
Governor Blanchard is a former Congressman from suburban Detroit who acquired a broadened political profile in Michigan as the House floor manager for the legislation under which the financially troubled Chrysler Corporation received Federal loan guarantees of $1.5 billion.
Over his first two terms as Governor, he has received high marks for his efforts to make the state's manufacturing economy more competitive. In his last election, in 1986, he rolled up 68 percent of the vote against his Republican challenger, William Lucas, the former sheriff of Wayne County.
But Mr. Engler, a state lawmaker for 20 years, may be the most formidable opponent yet for Mr. Blanchard. Although Mr. Engler's campaign has sputtered in the early going, he has the solid backing of the state Republican leadership, and his aides say he has raised $3 million, which includes the maximum amount of state matching funds allowed by law.

HEADLINE: Soldier and General Alike To Feel Bite of Budget Ax

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Driven by sharp budget cuts and a decrease in global tensions, the Pentagon is drastically shrinking its all-volunteer force, and the effort is causing anxiety at all levels of the military.
No one is spared, from admirals and generals to the soldiers and sailors of the future. The military is cutting recruiting quotas, tightening re-enlistment requirements, slashing commissions for new officers and forcing retirement on thousands of senior officers.
Leaders in Congress and the Defense Department say the 2.1 million troops on active duty could be cut by 100,000 a year through 1995, and perhaps through the end of the decade. In the 1991 fiscal year alone, lawmakers have proposed cutting troops by 100,000 or as many as 140,000, nearly four times what Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has proposed. 
''The kind of changes that would be required if I have to do that would include laying a lot of people off,'' Mr. Cheney told a Senate panel last month. ''I am going to have to throw people out on the street. I am going to have to freeze promotions. I am going to end up doing great violence to our most important military asset, our men and women in service.''
 
'Working Backwards'
With a vastly diminished Soviet threat, even the military's most vocal backers concede that troop strength has to drop, particularly in Europe, where the United States has more than 300,000 soldiers.
But Congress and the Pentagon are squaring off over the extent of the cuts, particularly for the next fiscal year, which begins in October. The ballooning Federal deficit has emerged as a powerful force in driving down military spending, currently more than $300 billion a year, half of that for personnel.
Troop levels are likely to be set, at least in the short run, before Defense Department officials decide what size the future military structure should be - the Army divisions, Navy ships, Air Force planes and their home ports or bases that the personnel will support.
''The process seems to be working backwards,'' said Vice Adm. Mike Boorda, the chief of naval personnel.
 
The Cost of Savings
Pentagon planners fear that a Congressional craving for immediate budget reductions may force deep cuts that yield annual savings of $1 billion but hurt future recruiting, badly skew the balance of officers against enlisted personnel and ultimately jeopardize battlefield readiness.
Military experts in Congress, like Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, dispute the military's warnings and insist that their plans offer prudent reductions without painful layoffs. The committee has proposed cutting 100,000 troops next year.
The Senate panel's proposal would require the services, before laying anyone off, to consider cuts in recruitment, reductions in re-enlistments and increases in early releases from service commitments, in that order.
The Defense Department has scaled back sharply in the past; Army troop strength fell by 200,000 to 300,000 soldiers a year shortly after the Vietnam War. But wartime forces were made up largely of draftees eager to leave the service. Since the all-voluntary force was established in 1973, most people have joined with the intent of making the military a career.
 
Effect on the Army
Labor analysts say there is ample room in the national economy to absorb displaced servicemen and servicewomen, many of whom have skills that civilian employers seek. But fewer opportunities to join the services spell trouble for many minority members, economists said. Blacks, in particular, have customarily used the military, and especially the Army, as a ladder of upward mobility.
''The cuts will be a serious problem for black males coming out of high school,'' said Barry M. Blechman, president of Defense Forecasts Inc., a consulting organization in Washington.
The Army, the largest of the services, is bracing for the deepest cuts, largely because one of its major abilities, fighting a conventional war in Europe, has been made all but unnecessary by the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union's promise to withdraw its troops there.
Under a House Armed Services subcommittee plan, the Army would shrink by nearly 82,000 troops next year, twice as many as Mr. Nunn's committee proposed. Under the Bush Administration's plan, the Army would drop by 16,669 troops, virtually all through attrition.
''If the cut is beyond 35,000 next year, I will have to decimate the enlisted forces,'' said Brig. Gen. Theodore G. Stroup Jr., the Army's director of military personnel.
 
Cuts in Officers
General Stroup said a reduction of 80,000 would result in enormous layoffs among enlisted personnel, junior officers and retirement-age officers. Federal law protects most mid-career officers from dismissal, a regulation that Mr. Cheney is seeking to relax through new legislation.
This year the Army, using special review panels, forced out 646 lieutenants and 300 colonels eligible for retirement. The Navy and Air Force face less severe cuts that service officials say they can handle through forced retirements and less recruiting. The Pentagon plans to eliminate 78 general and admiral positions within four years, 7 percent of the 1,073 top-ranking officer jobs. The services this year reduced recruiting quotas by 60,000, or 23 percent, and are projecting at least the same proportional reductions for next year. Re-enlistment bonuses have been pared or eliminated.
 
Layoffs or a Top-Heavy Force
As the services study further cuts, personnel bosses face an agonizing choice: sharply reduce recruiting and new officer commissions, creating a top-heavy force, or make across-the-board cuts, including layoffs of mid-career officers and enlisted personnel.
To cushion the blow for casualties of peace, Mr. Cheney and several lawmakers have proposed separation pay for enlisted personnel, improved medical benefits, extended military housing and commissary privileges, and job counseling, among other things.
Despite assurances from nervous Pentagon officials that the Government will not shortchange officers and enlisted personnel who remain in the trimmed-down military, there are troubling signs that some young people aren't listening.
Air Force first-term re-enlistments have dropped to 46 percent from 59 percent a year ago, in part because of an offer this year to allow officers and enlisted personnel to leave before their commitments were up. The Air Force expected 6,000 to apply. Instead 17,000 people volunteered, and embarrassed officials had to turn away 3,000 of them.
 
Disillusionment
Nearly 20 percent of the 1986 graduating class at the United States Military Academy, the elite of the Army's newly commissioned officers, opted to resign this year.
''You're seeing the beginning of a wave of disillusioned, uncertain young people who are not going to find the Army attractive,'' said Brig. Gen. Robert B. Rosenkranz, who is responsible for matching the Army's force needs with the proper personnel levels.
Meanwhile, with no agreement imminent from the White House and Congressional budget negotiators, and final Congressional approval of Pentagon spending in the fiscal year 1991 months away, military planners must begin cutting.
''Give the services a goal, and they can plan how to achieve it,'' concluded a recent Congressional Budget Office report on personnel cuts. ''Leave them with uncertainty, and they must continually either make second-best choices or risk taking irreversible actions that could have severe repercussions in later years.''

HEADLINE: MAGNET TRAINS' USE LIMITED, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
High-speed passenger trains that ride on magnetic cushions are economically feasible in the next 10 or 20 years, but only on a relatively small scale, according to a new report by the Federal Railroad Administration.
The magnetic levitation trains, which would travel about 300 miles an hour while suspended above a guideway by powerful magnetic fields, are under development in several nations and have been proposed as an alternative to air travel between some cities in the United States.
But the railroad agency said in the study that costs might be too high to permit nationwide networks of the train lines. 
The agency's economic analysis found that the train lines could generate enough revenue from fares to cover construction and operating costs on only a relatively few routes, totaling 500 to 2,600 miles. Although the agency conceded that its estimates ''need refinement,'' it said the best estimate of the approximate total of magnetic levitation lines that could be built and operated without public subsidies was about 850 miles.
 
Several Routes Proposed
Several of the train routes have been proposed by state and local governments, including one from Los Angeles to Las Vegas and another to connect Miami, Orlando and Tampa, Fla. The study, which was released on Monday, did not judge the merits of individual proposals, but they were used as the basis for the agency's analysis.
The ''maglev'' technology is expensive and risky, leading many proponents to call for an increased Federal role in development. The study said, ''No firm conclusions can be drawn regarding the appropriate U.S. role in future maglev development until further detailed analysis can be conducted.''
The cost of building magnetic levitation routes that totaled 500 to 2,600 miles would be $15.2 billion to $54.7 billion, plus several billion dollars more for the vehicles, the study said.
Although the railroad agency's head, Gilbert Carmichael, has spoken enthusiastically about the prospects for magnetic levitation trains in the United States, he has said private companies should bear the main burden of developing them, with the Government providing some money for research.
His agency's report to Congress casts some doubt on whether these lines would prove profitable enough to attract private investment on a large scale.
 
Role for Trains in Future
The study assumed that tax-free bonds issued by state or local governments could be used to finance construction by private companies that would own and operate the trains; that the cost of rights of way would be minimal; that the demand for transportation would continue to grow, and that the systems could attract more than one-fourth of all travelers.
''These findings suggest that there is a role for maglev in the future U.S. transportation system,'' the study said. ''However, the market for maglev facilities and equipment may not be large enough and certain enough to induce U.S. industry to make a significant commitment of its own resources to a maglev technology development program at this time.''
Robert J. Casey, executive director of the High Speed Rail Association, an industry group, said he viewed the agency's report as ''a fairly conservative estimate'' of the trains' prospects.
''A lot of people are being cautious at this moment in history,'' he said. ''My personal belief is that there will be many thousands of miles of maglev and other high-speed trains in the next 20 years in North America.''

HEADLINE: A.B. Duke to Leave Post as Chancellor Of L.I.U. Campus

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Angier Biddle Duke announced his retirement yesterday as chancellor of Long Island University's Southampton campus, ending a long career in international diplomacy and academia.
Appointed chancellor in 1986, Mr. Duke helped transform the struggling college in a summer resort into a cultural and intellectual center by organizing annual forums that drew notable speakers. But he is best known for his years as Ambassador to El Salvador in the 1950's, followed by ambassadorships to Spain, Denmark and Morocco.
He was also Chief of Protocol under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson.
Mr. Duke will retire Dec. 31, a month after his 75th birthday. ''I'd much rather leave when the flags are flying than to be pushed,'' he said yesterday.
He will remain a university trustee.
 
Tapped Social Connections
The great-grandson of Washington Duke, the founder of the American Tobacco Company, Mr. Duke, who dropped out of Yale University, unabashedly tapped his social and political connections.
After being named a trustee of the university in 1981, Mr. Duke formed the World Affairs Council, using the Southampton campus as its home base for panels and forums on global issues. Later, as chancellor, he created annual forums on the economy.
Yesterday, Mr. Duke presided over the ''Global Forum on Economic Development and the Environment,'' whose panelists included Dr. Noel Brown, director of the United Nations Environment Program, and United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
During Mr. Duke's tenure, the campus's enrollment, which had been declining, began to edge upward. From 1981 to 1984, enrollment fell to 1,050 from 1,400. It is now 1,200.
The university has not chosen Mr. Duke's successor.

HEADLINE: Campus Life:;
Summer's Hot Topics: East Bloc and the Earth

 BODY:
Eastern Europe, particularly the Soviet Union, is this year's summer vacation destination of choice for American students, who are flocking to glimpse the rise of democracy or exchange cultural values in what were recently less-friendly lands. For those sticking closer to home, environmental issues are an increasing concern, while political internships in Washington and elsewhere and archeological digs have maintained their traditional prestige.
An informal survey of leading colleges and universities indicates that the pursuit of solid credentials to add to resumes is keener than ever, but that the political and social developments of the last year have added spice to the chase.
In an venture that reflects a number of these currents, an 18-member theater company from the University of Illinois at Chicago will travel to Moscow and Kiev to perform ''The Birds - a Recycled Play,'' an updated version of Aristophanes's play emphasizing the theme of humanity's destruction of the earth's natural resources. The troupe will then take ''The Birds'' on the road to the Save Lake Michigan, Save Lake Baikal Environmental/Ecological and Theater Festival in Ulan-Ude, Siberia. 
Austin Goolsbee, a junior economics major from Yale, went to Poland ''to be part of history in the making.'' He is part of a macroeconomic task force headed by Jeffrey Sachs, the Harvard professor who has been advising the Solidarity Government as it reshapes the Polish economy.
''It's a great opportunity to be here as the country moves toward a free-market economy,'' said Mr. Goolsbee in a telephone interview from Poland.
 
'A Universal Language'
Kenzie Cameron, a junior at Northwestern University, is one of about 60 students from colleges nationwide who are participating in an exchange organized by the American Council of Teachers of Russian, a Washington-based nonprofit organization. Ms. Cameron, who is majoring in Russian and communications studies, is studying Russian at the Institute of Steel Alloys in Moscow and going on field trips, including one to Lithuania earlier this month.
Fifty students from various American colleges are pursuing cultural enrichment against the backdrop of history in the making as members of the American Soviet Youth Orchestra. With 50 counterparts from the Soviet Union, they will appear for two weeks at the Moscow Conservatory and then play in four other European countries, including East Germany. The Youth Orchestra, which is jointly sponsored by the Moscow Conservatory and Oberlin College, will perform in the United States next month.
''I cannot express how excited I am to work with a group of individuals who share a common interest that speaks a universal language,'' said Nathan Pawelek, an English and horn performance major at Oberlin.
Fifteen American students, mostly from Rutgers University and sponsored by Worldworks Foundation in Bridgewater, N.J., have also headed east this summer, to study the problems of hunger. The students will meet with a delegation from Moscow State University and visit Soviet farms, agricultural stations and research centers.
 
'What We Both Can Do About It'
''We need to understand why there is hunger in our country, why there is hunger in their country and what we both can do about it,'' said Krishna Patel, the 1990 class president of Douglass College at Rutgers.
Another Northwestern student, Gregory Schoof, spent his Fourth of July watching political fireworks as he observed Canada's constitutional crisis. As one of 13 Northwestern students studying Canadian politics and French, he was in Ottawa during the tense negotiations that preceded the collapse of the Meech Lake Accord, the compromise meant to accommodate within the constitution Quebec's aspirations for autonomy.
''We taped off the television history as it was happening,'' he said from Laval University in Quebec City.
Nhat-Dien Nguyen, a senior engineering major at California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, and Hien Lam, a senior biology major from the University of California at Santa Barbara, are working as volunteers in detention camps for Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong. Both Mr. Nguyen and Ms. Lam fled Vietnam as youths and spent time in detention camps themselves.
''It's not going to be easy,'' Ms. Lam said before leaving. ''But I know in my heart that we can help free the boat people.''
Benjamin Tang, a recent graduate of the University of Texas who is fluent in Chinese and who has lived in Taiwan, traveled to Beijing to observe the aftermath of last summer's student massacre.
''It was remarkably serene,'' he said. ''It seemed like people remembered how bad things were last year, and knew there would be terrible repercussions if it happeneed again.''
 
France and Ibadan
Susan Gray, a senior Russian and history major, journeyed to northern France to study the roles of 13th-century medieval noblewomen. She is hoping to refute what she calls a common misconception that the political and economic power of women declined after the 12th century.
College students traveling overseas are encountering at least one type of cultural shock. Cigarettes, which are becoming increasingly declasse on American college campuses, are coveted in the Soviet Union, for example, and savvy Americans are using them to their advantage. David Schwimmer, a senior English major at Yale, recently accompanied an American business executive to the Soviet Union as a consultant and translator. He knew exactly what to pack. ''Marlboros go a lot farther than rubles,'' said Mr. Schwimmer, who always brings several cartons.
 
Competition in Washington
A considerable number of aspiring politicians remained in the United States this summer, heading for the nation's capital. But they had to overcome tough competition for coveted internships. Only five of the 170 student applicants to the Brookings Institution were selected, a spokeswoman for its Washington office said. Jennifer Nelson, a Carleton College senior, said she submitted her resume more than a year and a half before landing her present job in the office of Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado.
Shepley Orr, a junior psychology major at Vassar College, went to New York to work for the city's Human Rights Commission. He is involved with local communities and public schools as they promote the hiring of more minority teachers.
Working in the Department of Human Services for Davenport, Iowa, gives Katherine Holland, a University of Iowa senior, an opportunity to complete the necessary requirements for her social work degree. Ms. Holland is taking part in a substance-abuse program and helping redesign child-welfare programs.
Sarah Davis, a sophomore at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, is viewing the gritty side of law enforcement this summer. Her job for the County Council in San Mateo Couny, Calif., has taken her to the homes of a prostitute, a petty and a heroin addict and on a helicopter chase of a drug dealer. Her most vivid memory is of an autopsy. ''I was like a mechanic looking into the hood of a car,'' she said.
 
History Begins at Home
Eleven students at the University of Kansas and Kansas State University have discovered that they do not have to move far from their campus to study history. For six hours of college credit, these summer students at the Kansas Archeological Field School are sifting through dirt in Clearview, Kan., to find remnants of lodges built by the Pomonas Indians between 900 and 1400 A.D.
Despite a rotating kitchen duty, a 10 P.M. curfew and the Kansas heat, several of them report that the experience has encouraged them to consider careers in archeology.
Two University of Iowa seniors, Carmen Jans and William Raatz, are also working in the fields. The two geology majors are with the Utah Field Company in Park City, Utah, where they are mapping mountains to uncover their geological structures.
Joyce Whitney, an Ohio State senior, and Ellis Godard, a University of Virginia sophomore, are also engaged in environmental work - rural and urban, respectively. Ms. Whitney, an environmental-education major, is working in the Tongass National Forest in Alaska. She flew across the national forest in a helicopter in June, spotting and recording the location of 30 bald eagle nests. The flight was made before egg-hatching time - if the search had been postponed, Ms. Whitney said, ''the young eagles would probably have been frightened and fallen to their deaths.''
 
Recycling and More
Mr. Godard is arranging the locations of recycling bins in the Charlottesville, Va., area, but there is more than recycling on his mind. He has joined the fight to legalize marijuana by writing a book on the subject, which he is seeking to have published, and negotiating with the Charlottesville police department for a 'smoke in' scheduled for October on the university campus.
David Egelman, a sophomore majoring in space physics at Rice University, is not averse to summer high jinks. Mr. Egelman recently gave to his agent an episode to submit to the Fox Network for its show, ''Married With Children.'' The resident of Albuquerque, N.M., has also completed a script for an episode of NBC's ''Cheers.'' Between scripts he is revising a book of humor on the college-admissions process.
Art of a different kind is being pursued by Miranda Junowicz, a Russian major at the University of California at Berkeley, who boasts that this summer she has seen eight Grateful Dead concerts across the nation. The 19-year-old is planning to attend another in Chicago later this month.
 
Dirty Dishes
Not all summer activity was designed to change or discover the world. For many students, the main goal has been income to enable them to return to school in the fall. But every job can have its surprises.
Michael Warren, a junior at Carnegie Mellon University, may have got more than he bargained for when he accepted the job as summer manager for his fraternity, Sigma Alpha Epsilon. An architecture major from Pittsburgh, Mr. Warren spends his days cleaning up after the nearly 30 occupants of the three-story fraternity house. He has faced stacks of dirty dishes, a broken garbage disposal and frequent visits from the city's health inspector.
Some, like Martin Grunder, a senior at the University of Dayton, are humble about their summer plans.
''I don't really think what I do is a big deal,'' said Mr. Grunder, a management major whose sales from his business enterprises are currently above $700,000. The Bellbrook, Ohio, resident owns a truck wash, a landscaping business and is a partner in a company that provides maintenance to commercial properties.
Mr. Grunder covers all college expenses and says he still has ''plenty of money to have fun with.''
