HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/July 15-20

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

Home Builders' Lament: Fewer New Houses, Fewer New Buyers
 
Everyone's favorite leveraged investment is going sour. Housing starts have fallen five months in a row, the Commerce Department reported last week - down 15.7 percent in a year to an annual rate of 1.18 million in June. Home builders blame their old friends, the savings institutions, who are now unwilling or unable to back them. But they might as well blame population tides, too, because young buyers are scarce. Revisionist statisticians are rewriting the economic history of the 1980's, after suddenly discovering that real, inflation-adjusted housing prices stagnated everywhere but the Northeast and West Coast, where they rose but are now falling. Economists are consoling builders and sellers with the news that they are part of a much broader trend. ''The 1980's was the era of debt and credit-creation,'' said David G. Shulman, director of real estate research at Salomon Brothers. ''In the 1990's, we're unwinding, and housing is the most credit-intensive sector of the economy.'' 
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Deciphering Greenspan
 
The credit markets can expect no great help any time soon from Alan Greenspan. The Federal Reserve Board chairman said on Wednesday that economic conditions called for no further lowering of interest rates. The Fed's easing the week before will not be repeated unless needed again to counter the reluctance of banks to make business loans, he said. The bond market, which had jumped the week before, slid after his Wednesday statement. Some listeners thought he was more worried about economic weakness than he let on. His remarks, to the Senate Banking Committee, scarcely touched on inflation, usually a favorite topic. ''Hardly a mention,'' said Kevin Logan, chief economist at Swiss Bank in New York. ''The tone that came out is that the Fed is a little bit closer to easing monetary policy than tightening.''
 
Consumer Prices Rise
 
The same day that Mr. Greenspan testified, consumer prices for June were reported to have risen five-tenths of 1 percent. No cause for panic, but worse than economists had expected. Mr. Greenspan himself called the figure an aberration. Joseph Carson, senior economist at Chemical Bank, pointed out that inflation reached a 5.9 percent annual rate for the first half of the year - higher than before, he said, but not likely to persist.
 
Thanks, but No Thanks
 
Pity the Pennsylvania executives who welcomed the toughest anti-takeover law in the nation three months ago. Now, big investors, pension funds especially, are threatening to dump their shares unless the companies reject the protection. Westinghouse Electric, H.J. Heinz and the Sun Company have decided that they don't really need all of the law's protections - though Armstrong World, PPG Industries and Alcoa say they will accept the shield. Companies have until Thursday to decide.
 
The Long-Distance Deficit
 
A 10-minute call from the United States to Spain costs $6.20 to $11.75, but in the other direction, $24.67 to $36.29. The Federal Communications Commission wants to force down foreign rates by as much as 50 percent in three years. Foreign telephone monopolies, which use international rates to subsidize domestic service, are certain to object. But the F.C.C. is likely to persist, because the rate structure adds $2.4 billion to the annual United States trade deficit. Foreign Oil Gushes in Exports rose, but imports rose more quickly in May. The trade deficit widened by 5.8 percent from April to $7.73 billion. More auto parts and consumer goods went out, as surging exports helped keep the nation out of a recession. But more cars and oil came in. Because of shrinking domestic production, oil imports rose to a record 49.9 percent of supplies in the first half of the year.
 
In Brief
 
Six Federal judges from around the nation are to gather in an unusual meeting to resolve tens of thousands of asbestos cases jamming their dockets.
 
*
 
Chrysler suggested to the United Automobile Workers on Friday that its financial difficulties argue for a contract more favorable than those to be negotiated with Ford or General Motors. Owen F. Bieber, the U.A.W. president, rejected the idea.
 
COMPANIES
 
The Steinbrenner Philosophy
 
Attila the Hun's business insights have appeared in hard-cover. Donald J. Trump's next book will reveal how he has survived, sort of, at the top. So why not repackage the transcripts of a hearing before the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, as ''The Business Secrets of George Steinbrenner''? Among his lessons: First, don't be afraid to fend off hostile overtures with greenmail. ''He scared me,' the Yankees' owner said, to explain why he paid Howard Spira, a gambler, $40,000. ''I felt that if this guy had this money, he would go away.'' Then, when your deals end up in court, blame your lawyers. Regarding his illegal campaign contributions to Richard M. Nixon, Mr. Steinbrenner said, ''My two lawyers, one of whom was later disbarred, told me that it was O.K.'' And what's an executive to say if all his machinations fail? Simple, Mr. Steinbrenner wrote after the hearing: ''I do not believe that it is fair to judge me in hindsight.''
 
No Time to Celebrate at I.B.M.
 
At the International Business Machines Corporation, good news passes in the time it takes a mainframe to do single-digit addition. Second-quarter earnings, announced last week, rose 5.2 percent from a year ago, to $1.41 billion, and I.B.M. stock jumped to a 17-month high. But I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, hastened to diminish investors' expectations, saying, ''Much remains to be done this year.'' And next year, some analysts added. I.B.M.'s hardware sales might suffer well into 1991 as buyers await the introduction of the Summit mainframes. Mainframe shipments were down from the first quarter, reversing the seasonal pattern, said Daniel C. Benton, an analyst at Goldman Sachs. He predicts that I.B.M.'s mainframe revenues will come under pressure from other technologies, like personal computer networks ''at a fraction of the cost.''
 
Citicorp's Weak Spots
 
Having the world's strongest consumer banking business can't always compensate for Citicorp's mistakes. Second-quarter earnings at the nation's largest banking company fell 37 percent from a year ago to $248 million. Loan demand among large corporations weakened, and troubled real estate loans rose. But consumer banking profits increased 28 percent from a year ago to $266 million. Arthur P. Soter, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said Citicorp is spreading teller machines, credit cards and branch networks abroad. ''They have the biggest consumer finance franchise in the world,'' he said.
 
*
 
Among other banks, the regionals continued to outperform the money centers. Second-quarter earnings fell 12 percent at Chemical and BankAmerica, 64 percent at Chase Manhattan and 69 percent at Manufacturers Hanover. Chase and Citicorp both announced plans to cut costs. But profits at Security Pacific of Los Angeles rose 6 percent; at NCNB of North Carolina, 50 percent, and at Wells Fargo, in San Francisco, 58 percent.
 
In Brief
 
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation plans to prune as many as 17,000 jobs because of cuts in defense spending and continuing losses on commercial jets.
 
*
 
Second-quarter earnings: American Express, up 1.2 percent from a year ago, to $320 million; A.T.&.T., down 6 percent to $657 million; Merck, up 18.6 percent to $470.2 million.
 
*
 
John O'Brien abruptly resigned as chairman of Grumman Aerospace on Thursday. Federal officials said he is the subject of an investigation into wrongdoing in the defense industry.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Where the Money Is
 
As East and West Germany prepare to be joined, the Soviet Union will share in the dowry. Last week, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union announced that he had agreed with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to let a united Germany join NATO. As part of the deal, West Germany will pay billions of marks for the maintenance and relocation of Soviet forces in Germany. It is also providing substantial credits and a commitment to honor East German contracts with the Soviet Union. With the United States promising only technical assistance and Japan still fuming in a territorial dispute, the temptation for the Soviets to embrace Germany is greater. As Michael Mandelbaum, director of the Project on East-West Relations at the Council on Foreign Relations, put it, ''They went where the money is.''
 
In Brief
 
Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. will now answer to its creditors, not to Alan Bond. The Australian brewer, media executive and real estate investor agreed to resign as chairman to gain the cooperation of bondholders in arranging refinancing. The G. Heileman Brewing Company in Wisconsin is owned by Bond Holdings.
 
*
 
The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for bombing the London Stock Exchange on Friday. Thanks to an evacuation, nobody was injured. Trading, which is mostly electronic, was not disrupted.

LENGTH: 126 words

HEADLINE: Currency;
For Now, the Dollar Holds Its Own

 BODY:
Well, not much happened. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's semi-annual testimony to Congress on monetary policy was a little anticlimactic after he said the previous week that the Fed would lower interest rates to offset a credit squeeze. If anything, he signaled in his testimony that interest rates would not be moving lower again soon. So the dollar held its ground fairly well, even managing to rise against the yen by the end of the week. The higher-than-expected increase in the Consumer Price Index in June also provided support. But the downward pressure is still on the dollar as the economy struggles and the view persists that interest rates are likely to fall, especially if there is an agreement to reduce the Federal deficit.

HEADLINE: Tax Reform Is a Gremlin in the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William B. Michaels, in ''A Different Savings and Loan Villain'' (July 8), was quite accurate with respect to the Tax Reform Act. However, there are several other ramifications of the 1986 law. It seems lawmakers in Washington are so caught up in politicking that they've failed to see certain obvious effects of tax reform.
The first of the disasters was the 1987 stock market crash. I believe the volatility at that time was caused by too much money looking for a place to be put to work. This money came from the nearly $10 billion of private placement, tax-oriented investments that had to be redirected because of tax reform. Much of it went into mutual funds, and even more into the stock market. Money going into private placements is traditionally long-term capital, which is illiquid and under the old tax law was used to promote investments. Given the liquidity in the stock market, investors are now able to trade that equity making the market a lot more volatile. The savings and loan crisis was the second disaster. The third has been happening quietly. Commercial banks are now seeing severe losses not only on real estate, but in all areas of industry where tax benefits heretofore played a role.
It's time that Congress took a good look at itself in the mirror after all the flag waving about what a great new tax law this was to be. It was no simpler; it will certainly be more expensive as a result of the savings and loan criss, and if the commercial banks go next, the price tag will be incalculable.
 
LEONARD J. MESSINA
 July 10, New York

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Japan Isn't Playing by Different Rules

BYLINE: By MICHAEL E. PORTER; Michael E. Porter, a professor of business administration at the Harvard Business School, is author of ''The Competitive Advantage of Nations.''

 BODY:
Slowly and almost imperceptibly, over more than a decade, America has been retreating from one of the most fundamental principles that has distinguished our nation from others: our faith in competition. We have been finding excuses to avoid competition and adopting policies to that effect, often, ironically, in the name of competitiveness. The words of the day are collaboration, relaxing antitrust regulations, managing trade, getting tough on dumping and protecting ''intellectual property.''
It is claimed that the globalization of markets has created a new era in which the old rules of competition must be discarded, and in which domestic rivalry is unimportant. Japan, widely thought to be playing by different rules, is seen as invalidating the principles of free trade. ''Japan Inc.'s'' conquest of world markets is said to show that a new balance between competition and cooperation, and a new role for government, is now needed. Or does it?
This line of thinking is seductive to both companies and policy makers, but it is fundamentally flawed. It rests on an incorrect view of what creates competitive advantage in today's international markets, and on a wholly mistaken view of Japan's success. Retreating from competition will not make American companies competitive, or make America competitive. 
 
The Need for a New Paradigm
Our retreat from competition is based on an erroneous, outdated and static view of international competition in which it is believed that low capital and labor costs, a cheap currency, and economies of scale are the keys to competitive success. Thus mergers, alliances, and collaboration to gain scale and avoid wasteful duplication are thought desirable, and government intervention to foster such behavior and to reduce corporate risk is justified. We think we are doing what our successful competitors have done.
However, my recent study of 10 leading trading nations found that competitive advantage in the knowledge- and skill-intensive industries that form the backbone of advanced economies - those of Japan, Germany and the United States - is the result not of static efficiencies but of rapid improvement, innovation and upgrading. Nations and industries prosper because they can achieve high and rising levels of productivity. This occurs when companies continuously upgrade by improving quality, adding new features, penetrating new and more sophisticated market segments and applying new technology and skills to produce their products more efficiently.
Innovation and upgrading result not from a comfortable home environment in which risks have been minimized, but from pressure and challenge - from demanding home customers, from capable home-based suppliers and most of all from local rivalry. In my research I found that the most internationally competitive industries in every nation were those where there were a number of able local rivals that pressured one another to advance. Examples are American software and consumer packaged goods, German cars and chemicals, Italian fabrics and packaging machinery, and Swedish heavy trucks.
Domestic rivals engage in active feuds. They compete not only for market share but for people, for technical excellence, and perhaps most important for ''bragging rights.'' Progress comes not from unitary or collective approaches but from diverse efforts at innovation by such a group of jealous rivals. Local rivals push each other to compete globally - a better way to gain scale than dominating the home market.
The presence of fierce local rivalry also benefits the entire national industry by stimulating the formation of specialized educational and research institutions to serve the industry. For example, every university in the south of Germany has a department of automotive engineering. This attracts and supports entry into supplier and related industries, and is a magnet for talented individuals and for investments in specialized infrastructure. The national environment becomes a self-reinforcing system that promotes rapid progress.
Globalization does not supersede the role of nations and of domestic competition but arguably makes them even more important. National differences in values, institutions and culture are integral to innovation.
Indeed, competitive advantage is often highly localized in regions or cities, in which entire clusters of rivals, their suppliers, related industries and sophisticated customers in close proximity create a rapid rate of progress. Japan, contrary to popular perception, demonstrates more clearly than any nation the incredible power of competition to foster dynamism.
Many Americans think Japanese companies have succeeded because of cooperation, cartels, and government intervention. Japan does have many cartels - such as in agriculture, chemicals, construction, paper and metals - but these are in sectors where Japan is not competitive.
In the world-class Japanese industries there are numerous Japanese rivals that have diverse strategies. These companies slug it out daily in the home market. Market shares fluctuate rapidly, as new products and production improvements are introduced at a stunning rate.
Japan's 9 automobile companies, 34 semiconductor producers and some 300 robotics competitors show how local rivals, each holding only a modest share of the home market, can prosper through rapid upgrading and global sales. The lesson to be learned from Japan is that competition works, not that we should limit it.
 
Benefits of Duplication
Japanese cooperative research projects, far from eliminating ''wasteful'' duplication, stimulate more of it. Projects sponsored by the Ministry of International Trade and Investment, take place through independent entities to which government and companies contribute personnel and modest amounts of money. However, companies invest much more internally on proprietary research on the same technologies, stimulated by the fact that all their competitors are working on them, too.
Significant joint production ventures involving Japanese rivals, moreover, were not found in any of the internationally competitive industries I studied. In semiconductor memories, where an American joint-production effort called U.S. Memories is widely viewed as necessary, there is not only no Japanese joint production but no fewer than 13 Japanese competitors producing megabyte chips, some with more than one plant. And all the frenetic innovative activity in Japan takes place within a framework of patent and copyright protection that is looser than America's.
The role of government intervention in Japan is also misunderstood. The direct and heavy MITI intervention in specific industries that Americans associate with Japanese success did not take place in many of the competitive Japanese industries like copiers, VCR's, facsimile machines and robots. Much of the direct intervention that did take place occurred in the 1960's, when Japan was a much less advanced nation. But even then, MITI failed repeatedly when it attempted to consolidate industries in areas like steel and automobile production and machine tools.
The notion that Japan is somehow playing by different rules from ours is misguided and nothing more than a smoke screen to justify suspending competition. Import protection, reluctance to buy foreign goods and ''copying'' foreign technology were characteristic of America and also Germany when they were developing. Japan is behaving just as we did.
 
Renewing Competition
What is needed today in American industry is not less competition but more. Instead of relaxing antitrust enforcement, we should be tightening it. Mergers and alliances between leading competitors should be prohibited - they are good neither for companies nor for America. Cooperative research and development involving leaders should be sanctioned only when it is through independent entities involving the majority of industry participants and represents a modest proportion of companies' overall research efforts. The Export Trading Company Act should be sharply curtailed to allow only joint sales promotion abroad and information-gathering activity. The proposal to relax antitrust scrutiny of joint production ventures should be quietly and quickly dropped.
Trade policy should focus on opening up competition rather than using comforting though false arguments to restrict it. The vigorous and increasingly effective efforts of Carla Hills, the United States Trade Representative, to reduce trade barriers in Japan and elsewhere should be the principal focus. Limiting domestic competition in response to trade barriers will only make our problems worse. The ''Voluntary Restraint Agreement'' should be banished from our trade repertoire. Dumping should be claimed only when foreign rivals persist in selling below their cost, not just when American companies are feeling the heat of price competition. Americans should not be influenced or persuaded by Europe's failure to stem the flood of mergers and alliances that threaten to eliminate competition in many European industries. The results of curtailing competition will prove disappointing in Europe as well.
At the root of many of the policy initiatives limiting competition is a loss of self-confidence in American industry, which is reflected in Washington. Instead of looking forward to the next generation of products and processes, too many companies are scrambling to block challenges to their current market positions through mergers, alliances and trips to Washington to secure government help.
A momentum of retreat has been created that is hard to arrest. Once government begins to ''help'' by allowing companies to reduce their risk or avoid the painful steps it takes to become truly competitive, almost irresistible demands are created for more help. This retreat must stop before it becomes a rout. This is the lesson of company history and of national economic history. When a nation becomes preoccupied with complaining about other nations' ''unfair'' practices, its days of economic dynamism are numbered.
What is needed instead is re-commitment to one of America's most unique national values, competition. Ironically, it was America that exported competition to Japan and Germany after World War II. The postwar breakup of their cartels and dominant companies played an immeasurable role in their startling economic success. As uncomfortable as competition always is, it remains the only way that American industry will ever truly prosper.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
France's Buying Binge Takes Its Toll

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
STATE-CONTROLLED French companies are breaking the mold. Rather than tending to their home market, they are aggressively buying abroad, both in Europe and the United States. Some, like Renault, are positioning themselves for the economic union of Europe in 1992; others, like Rhone-Poulenc, are pursuing the grander goal of a top ranking in their industry, worldwide.
But the buying spree is taking its toll. Shares of some of the companies, which are partially publically owned, are lagging far behind what is in any case a mediocre performance by the Paris Bourse. 
Some analysts suggest it is risky for investors to buy the stocks because the state-controlled firms show little concern for their public shareholders. ''A lot of these companies are not being run for the shareholders,'' said one analayst in a French firm, speaking only with assurances of anonymity. ''They are being run to secure a strategic position for France. So it is quite dangerous for shareholders to be in companies like this.''
In addition, the British, who have the most open market in Europe, are getting annoyed as more and more of their companies are picked off by France's state-controlled ones.
And the European Commission, whose competition commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, is working on proposals to curb unfair competition by state-controlled companies after 1992, might also take notice - especially of companies dramatically underperforming the market.
More than 80 deals have been completed during the French buying spree in the last year and a half, according to data gathered by Translink's European Deal Review and by the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick. The total value of the deals, where prices were reported, is around $6 billion.
More important, the French, according to Mark Dixon of Translink, have outgunned state-controlled companies in other countries. Last year, purchases by state-controlled companies equaled 28 percent of total French acquisitions - no other country's state companies reached 5 percent.
Among the deals: Rhone-Poulenc, a chemical and pharmaceutical company, bought the Rorer Group, the American drug company, and RTZ Chemicals, the British speciality chemicals firm. Thomson CSF, the defense contractor, bought Ferranti Thomson Sonar Systems in Britain. Renault joined in a cross-ownership deal with Sweden's Volvo. And Pechiney International, which bought American National Can in 1988, purchased Celegraf in Spain, a food packaging company.
In the last 12 months, Rhone-Poulenc has underperformed the French market, as measured by the CAC general index, by 25 percent; Thomson CSF, by 57 percent; and Pechiney International, by 36 percent. (Renault does not have a significant amount of stock trading.) Rhone-Poulenc's performance is most directly attributable to it aggressive acquistions, although it was also hurt by the economic freeze in Brazil and the weak dollar, which reduces foreign earnings. ''It's been overly aggressive acquisitions, purely,'' said Michael Diehl, an analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities in London. ''It's been a little bit of disregard for the shareholders and the market doesn't appreciate it.''
But while the short-term prospects of Rhone-Poulenc and the others might not be that good, some analysts feel that the buying spree has better positioned them for the long run.
Pascal Viornery, managing director of Bertrand Michel Securities Inc. in New York, argues that Pechiney, for example, has successfully made itself over from an aluminum company to a packaging firm and the market has yet to catch on.
On the issue of unfair competition, some analysts agree that aggressive acquisitions have been made easier by having less concern for the stock price and shareholders. But they also argue that these companies are still hampered in raising money by the limit on public stock ownership, which is 25 percent of capital.
But since the European Commission, at the least, is likely to look at the issue, the French state-controlled companies will have the reason to acquire as fast as possible before some new, and possibly restrictive, guidelines are in place.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Balancing Retirement and Growth

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
LAST month, when he was named emeritus university librarian, Phillip Rosenstein was honored at a champagne bash for 250 people at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. But he still doesn't know what he will do later this month, when he actually leaves the Newark-based library, taking a big chunk of his pension money with him. ''I want the money to be safe, and grow, and be available if I need it,'' he said.
Like Mr. Rosenstein, many retirees have three goals - income, growth and low volatility - that contradict one another. And that's complicated by the fact that most new retirees can expect to live 20 years or more. During that time, they need income to cover expenses and protection from inflation. That protection could come from stock holdings, but stocks are riskier than bonds - and risk is anathema to many retirees. 
''It's an intricate web, so you don't maximize each objective but accept some balance among the three,'' said Gerald W. Perritt, editor of the Mutual Fund Letter, in Chicago.
But many retirees - and people planning retirement - make a common mistake. ''The tendency is to be too conservative,'' said Sheldon Jacobs, editor of the No-Load Fund Investor, in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Too often, retirees opt for guaranteed income and forget that, over time, total return is more important. And retirees have special needs that must be considered. Most withdraw money from their portfolios regularly so they need low volatility. After all, they don't want to liquidate when prices are low.
And then there are taxes. To decide whether tax-free or taxable investments make more sense, you must figure ''taxable equivalent yield.'' To do that, divide the tax-free yield by the inverse of your tax rate. For example, if a municipal bond fund yields 6 percent and you are in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent yield is 8.3 percent (6 divided by .72). This means you must earn at least 8.3 percent in a taxable investment to get the same after-tax return.
Retirees who live in high-tax states like New York should think about state taxes, too. They may want to look at single-state municipal bond funds that invest in bonds from the state in which they live. That way, income earned is free of Federal and state tax.
One caveat: Loading up too heavily on tax-free investments can backfire if you collect Social Security. Social Security payments generally become taxable when the sum of your adjusted gross income, one-half of Social Security benefits plus tax-exempt income exceed $32,000 for couples ($25,000 for single taxpayers). But you can never be taxed on more than half of the benefits.
With all this in mind, what kind of retirement portfolios do experts recommend?
Mr. Perritt advises putting 50 percent of the portfolio into bond funds. His favorite: the Benham Treasury Note Fund, which invests in intermediate-term Treasury securities. For protection from inflation, he puts 5 percent in gold, and likes the Lexington Gold Fund.
He also puts 25 percent of the portfolio into stocks and recommends equity-income funds, which invest in high-quality, dividend-paying stocks. He especially likes the T. Rowe Price Equity-Income Fund. The remaining 20 percent of the portfolio is set aside in money-market funds.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's MoneyLetter, in Holliston, Mass., also likes intermediate-term bond funds for one-half of retirees' portfolios. He recommends Dreyfus A Bonds Plus, a high-quality corporate bond fund; T. Rowe Price's New Income Fund, which combines corporate bonds and Treasury securities, and the Rushmore U.S. Government Intermediate Fund, which invests in securities of the Federal Government and some agencies. He also advises keeping 25 percent in stock funds. He likes Fidelity Magellan, Vanguard Windsor II and the Janus Fund, part of the Denver-based Janus Group. The other 25 percent he would set aside in money-market funds.
In his model portfolio, Mr. Jacobs of the No-Load Fund Investor keeps 10 percent in money market funds. For the bond portion (35 percent), he likes Fidelity's Spartan Government Fund and its Intermediate Bond Fund. He divides the portfolio's growth portion between two categories of stock funds. For an aggressive stock play (10 percent), he likes the Janus Venture Fund, which invests mainly in small-company stocks. For the international part (15 percent), he likes the Financial Strategic European Fund, sponsored by Financial Programs of Denver.
The rest of the portfolio is devoted to long-term equities. He likes the Financial Industrial Income Fund, Vanguard's Wellesley Income Fund and the Fidelity Convertible Securities Fund.
Which model portfolio is best for you? That depends on which fit you find most comfortable. Some retirees avoid gold or aggressive stocks; others say the risk is small and worth the potential for gain. In all of these cases, the model portfolio constitutes the total investment, and assumes the funds set aside in money markets can cover emergencies.
 
BACK TO CLOSED-END FUNDS?
AS a group, closed-end stock funds did not fare well in the first half of 1990, rising only 2.4 percent against a 4.63 percent rise in the Dow Jones industrial average. Prices for closed-end funds, which trade on listed exchanges like common stock, are set by supply and demand and fund shares trade at a premium or discount to the value of the stocks in their portfolios.
Share prices lagged the broad stock market because funds began the year with average discounts of about 8 percent and that widened to 10 percent during the first half.
With such big discounts, investors will probably jump back in and, as a result, ''I think more money will be made during the second half of the year than the first,'' said Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser who specializes in closed-end funds.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1209 words

HEADLINE: SHIFTING GROUND;
Taxes, S. & L.'s, Anxiety: Recipe For a Political Shakeout?

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER months of quiescence in American politics, the two parties are finally stirring, lurching into the 1990's and the uncharted political terrain beyond Reaganism.
For the first time since the 1988 campaign, Republicans are showing a trace of fear, buffeted by the savings and loan scandal and riven by bitter feuding over President Bush's decision to renege on his ''no new taxes'' pledge. There are cracks in the coalition that ruled the 80's, cracks that could be exacerbated by President Bush's choice of a Supreme Court nominee to replace Justice William J. Brennan Jr. Selection of an appointee to the Court is a contentious process in the calmest of times, and Justice Brennan's replacement will be chosen in a political atmosphere already polarized by the issue of abortion, with both sides seeing the next appointment to the court as critical. 
Many Republicans are trying desperately to hold on to the Reagan magic, uncertain of what will replace it. House Republicans voted last week to defy their President and reassert their opposition to new taxes. Peggy Noonan, La Pasionara of the Reagan Revolution, the White House speechwriter who wrote the last great repudiated soundbite of the 1980's, ''read my lips,'' insisted at a recent meeting of the Republican National Committee that the old magic still had power.
She sketched a vision of President Bush storming away from recalcitrant Democrats at the budget summit meeting and taking his case to the people, a vision grand, defiant, Reaganesque. But her words had the eerie echo of an aging Democrat keening for the glory days of the New Deal. Mr. Bush plods on in the budget talks; the economy, the White House says, demands it.
The times are churning, quickening. Surveys show that the voters are increasingly anxious about the economy, increasingly pessimistic about the country's future, increasingly angry and cynical toward government. ''People are not sitting pretty any more,'' said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic polltaker. ''The nervousness that everyone said had been just beneath the surface for years is coming straight to the surface, and it changes the way they think about politics.''
 
The chant of ''We're
Number One!,'' the proud signature of American foreign policy in the 1980's, is ill-suited for a multipolar age, when Helmut Kohl and Mikhail S. Gorbachev - but not President Bush - sit down at a Soviet spa and remake the map of Europe. At home, the prosperity of the Reagan years is now a subject of fierce debate and searching re-examination.
Kevin Phillips, a conservative analyst, has provoked much furor in political circles with his new book, ''The Politics of Rich and Poor,'' in which he asserts that the 1980's produced an extraordinary concentration of wealth at the top of American society. In the book, which was excerpted recently in The New York Times Magazine, Mr. Phillips foresees a reformist backlash, such as the ones that followed the 1920's and the Gilded Age in the late 19th century.
Two issues have intersected to feed the debate: the drive for new taxes and the mounting bill for the savings and loan bailout, which helped propel the President into budget talks with Congressional Democrats. Day after day, the images of high-flying savings and loan operators, with their condominiums, their yachts and their insider deals, are juxtaposed with grim talk of new taxes and deep spending cuts.
''Taxes and the S. & L.'s are providing handles for this whole question of who profited from the 80's and who got gypped,'' Mr. Phillips said in an interview.
Resentments are simmering. In South Dakota, Democratic Senator Tom Daschle said that people refer to the new farm legislation under debate in Congress as ''the S. & L. farm bill.'' They feel their benefits are being cut because of the cost of the thrift industry bailout, he said.
Representative Lynn Martin, an Illinois Republican, complains of ''an incredible transfer of wealth to Texas.'' Voters who are ''trying to make a mortgage payment'' don't care to hear about savings and loan operators ''with eight houses,'' she said.
Democrats, lately in search of a voice and a message, are trying to capitalize on the growing storm. Party leaders including Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic chairman, accuse the Republicans of wanting to make the middle class pay for the excesses of the wealthy.
''George Bush has finally asked for higher taxes at the same time he's still trying to get a capital gains tax cut for the privileged few,'' said Mr. Brown. ''We know who he wants to pick up the tab for the S. & L. predators' ball.''
The Democrats' efforts to put a Republi-can face on the thrift crisis have been helped by the difficulties of the President's son, Neil Bush, who has been accused of conflicts of interest as a director of a Denver thrift that failed. But the Democrats' hands are by no means clean; four of the ''Keating five,'' the Senators under fire for their relationships with the head of a failed savings and loan institution, are Democrats.
Democrats dream of a populist uprising, but they still have no one to lead it. Their own strategists acknowledge that only a charismatic Presidential nominee can redefine the party.
There has been a flurry of Presidential speculation in recent weeks, particularly around Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, but it is still only speculation. After 10 years out of power, the Presidential wing of the party seems atrophied.
Still, for the first time in a long time, the Republican Party is having its own problems. Many Republican strategists say that the party must change for an era when Communism is collapsing, when voters are increasingly concerned about domestic issues like the environment and education, when abortion is exposing the fault line between the baby boom voters and the new right.
Roger Stone, a Republican strategist, said, ''Issues that were extremely successful for us in the 80's aren't on the radar screen anymore.'' But Robert Teeter, the Republican polltaker, insists that the frictions and tensions are simply the growing pains of a governing coalition. ''The Democrats lived with it for 50 years, and they still won elections,'' he said.
But the Roosevelt legacy was about activist government and was easily institutionalized; many conservatives worry how to preserve the Reagan legacy when its philosophy, at its roots, was an opposition movement.
Many Republicans are wary of a President who appears to be torn between Connecticut and Texas, between the old establishment Republicanism and Reagan-era conservatism. Loosed from the moorings of Ronald Reagan, they look for direction from Mr. Bush and find it varies with the issue and the day - accommodating on taxes, staunch on abortion.
''We all expect him to leave his imprint,'' said Representative Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican. But he added that the ''loyal troops'' have a right to express what they would like that imprint to be.
White House aides, ever fortified by the President's high approval ratings, say Mr. Bush is providing the leadership the country wants, temperate and committed to making government work. But all around there is a quickening, a shifting. This is a pregnant moment in American politics.

LENGTH: 1020 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
A Windfall Nears In Inheritances From The Richest Generation

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
WITH the wealthiest generation of elderly people in the country's history reaching the end of their lives, economists are trying to predict what will happen to their money.
The assumption is that a wave of inheritances will provide their children, the baby boom generation, with a windfall. But the Federal Government is also expected to keep its eyes on the money, and some economists predict a push for higher inheritance taxes to help solve the budget crisis.
''There has been a great run-up of wealth among the elderly,'' said Robert B. Avery, an assistant professor of economics at Cornell University. Much of this accumulation was built between the late 1940's and the late 1960's, when real wages and savings rates were higher and housing costs were lower. For the middle class, the most significant factor may be the escalation of real estate prices over the last 20 years. 
''It's a substantial amount of wealth,'' said Frederick A. Elkind, vice president and director of the TrendSights division of the Ogilvy & Mather advertising agency, which forecasts buying and spending habits. ''And there is a potential for a substantial amount of money and assets to be released or transferred to the baby boomers.''
Not everyone believes there will be an inheritance boom. Cheryl Russell, the editor in chief of American Demographics magazine and the author of ''100 Predictions for the Baby Boom Generation,'' acknowledged the unprecedented wealth of today's older people, but she argued that the size of the baby boom generation has grown faster than the size of the parents' estates. ''Most people will inherit only a middling amount of money,'' she said.
Ms. Russell also maintained that a variety of variables, particularly health care costs, may reduce the size of many estates. ''It's counting chickens before they hatch,'' she said.
But many economists say that even when rising medical costs and other factors are taken into account, inherited wealth is expected to become a significant economic force.
According to Cornell's Department of Economics and Housing, the total worth of estates at death is expected to rise from $924.1 billion between 1987 and 1991 to $2.1 trillion between 2007 and 2011. The estimates are in 1990 dollars.
''Inheritances as a proportion of total wealth have been increasing over the last 20 to 25 years and will certainly continue increasing in the future,'' said Edward N. Wolff, a professor of economics at New York University.
 
'The Rich Beget Rich'
In all, the 64 million baby boomers stand to inherit an estimated $6.8 trillion between 1987 and 2011. Of course not everyone will benefit equally. According to the Cornell study, the richest 1 percent of the population will divide one-third of the worth of the estates, each receiving an average inheritance of $3.6 million; the next richest 9 percent will divide another third for an average inheritance of about $396,000; the remaining 90 percent will share the rest. That means an average inheritance of only about $40,000 for this group. ''The rich beget rich,'' Mr. Avery said. Mr. Elkind predicted that much of the wealth may be passed on as property that, depending on market conditions, may be sold or used as second homes. He said that the prospect of inheritances will help many baby boomers maintain highly leveraged, spendthrift lives. But he also predicted that many inheritances will be used to make gifts to charity or to help meet tuition costs for members of the so-called boomlet generation. ''It wouldn't surprise me if we started seeing more people put their kids in private schools, especially with the baby boomers having fewer kids,'' he said.
Predictions of an inheritance boom may also lead to efforts to raise inheritance taxes, close loopholes or lower the tax exemption levels. The Federal estate tax now ranges from 37 to 55 percent of the value of an estate exceeding $600,000, or, in some cases, $1.2 million if the money is left by a couple.
''The dead don't vote,'' said Thomas J. Drew, an estate lawyer in New York City and Westport, Conn. ''And with legislators groping to reduce the deficit, it's a more politically palatable target than income taxes.''
The argument for increased inheritance taxes has won favor among some people who oppose most taxes. The philosopher Robert Nozick, known for his libertarian views, recommends that the Government lay claim to estates after they pass beyond one generation.
''It sticks out as a special kind of unearned benefit that produces unequal opportunities,'' Mr. Nozick said.
 
'Wooing Retirees'
Some conservatives, however, have argued that inheritance taxes are unfair because they represent double taxation or are ''anti-family.'' And, so far, many state governments seem more interested in reducing their inheritance taxes. In the last two years, for example, Idaho repealed its tax, and Wisconsin is phasing out its tax.
''It brings in a relatively low amount, and it makes states non-competitive for attracting retirees,'' said Corina Eckl, a senior policy analyst for the National Conference of State Legislatures in Denver.
Furthermore, many people avoid inheritance taxes by giving away some of their money before they die. Others, worried about paying for long-term health care, give away estates so they can qualify for Medicaid.
Looking further into the future, some economists predict that the wealth of today's elderly may have particularly striking effects not on their children but on their grandchildren.
This may be especially true considering that baby boomers are having smaller families than their parents had and are often supporting themselves with two incomes.
''The potential for boomer wealth, in theory, should be even greater than for their parents, because they have been accumulating their own wealth with their parents' wealth,'' Mr. Elkind said. ''It could reach a critical mass and be a tremendous windfall for their children.''
Then again, he added, baby boomers will likely live longer than their parents did. ''Their kids may have to wait a long time to benefit fully,'' he said.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
New Ideas Are Changing Nuclear Debate

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A NEW generation of nuclear power plants - smaller, simpler and probably safer - is taking shape on the drawing boards. But rethinking the nuclear reactor is raising difficult issues for manufacturers and critics alike.
The conundrums involve safety. While the manufacturers can speak of marked improvements, they are reluctant to draw comparisons that would cast doubt on the safety of the 110 existing reactors, which have decades of service remaining. 
The critics say the new designs sometimes trade old problems for new ones. Their latest study, which examines three distinct reactor systems, suggests that these designs are not without risks.
For years, the industry has asserted that its reactors are safe and pose only a minuscule chance of accident. Debates over what could be done to lower the risk further, industry officials say, are really debates over how safe is safe enough.
The issue has lost some of its edge lately, since all the plants ordered after 1974 in this country have been canceled and only a few are still under construction. But major reactor manufacturers sense the prospect of new orders, which would rekindle the debate.
The demand for power today is growing, and the fear of global warming gives nuclear generators an edge over those fired by coal, which releases carbon dioxide, a gas which scientists say tends hold heat in the atmosphere, contributing to global warming. Environmentalists have yet to embrace this logic, but it has encouraged the manufacturers, with large Federal subsidies, to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in drawing up new designs.
The new plants, like those already in service, would all split atoms to make heat, which is then used to make electricity, but they differ greatly in their approach. Yet all seek to use basic physical principles to increase safety. Incorporation of such principles, specifically the propensity of water to flow downhill and natural convection to limit overheating of small objects, can make a reactor ''inherently safe,'' according to the new design proponents.
One of the more promising designs is a gas-cooled graphite reactor proffered by General Atomics, a company based in San Diego, Calif., and one the Department of Energy would like to test. Heat-resistant graphite would encapsulate uranium fuel, and helium would conduct the heat needed to make electricity. Current reactors use fuel wrapped in metal, which melts at high temperature, and water, which transfers heat but can boil away in an accident. Helium's safety advantage over water lies in its already being a gas; in an accident water will turn to gas, thus losing much of its ability to carry away heat.
 
Risk Is Always Present
''The temperature characteristics of the fuel, and the inherent character of the helium, factors that are there because they are parts of physics, give you the inherent safety you're looking for,'' said Linden S. Blue, the vice chairman of General Atomics. The uranium cannot get hot enough to break out of its graphite shell, he said.
The General Electric Company is so persuaded of the significance of the new designs, not to mention the public-relations value of the phrase, that it has incorporated the term ''inherently safe'' into the name of one of its designs, the Power Reactor Inherently Safe Module, known as Prism.
But a study of three major reactor designs released last week by the Union of Concerned Scientists in Cambridge, Mass., which is regarded as the most technically competent of the private nuclear safety groups, said that such claims confuse the issue. According to Gregory C. Minor, a former manager in the advanced control and instrumentation department at General Electric and a consulting engineer who oversaw the study, ''You are dealing with a radioactive reaction, with enormous energy, and enormous potential disruptive action if you don't treat it properly.'' A reactor, he said, can no more be inherently safe than a car can be; improvements can be made, but risk is always present.
A few industry engineers privately concede the point. At the American Nuclear Energy Council, a lobbying group in Washington, James McDonald, a spokesman, said of the idea of inherent safety, ''I don't think that message has credibility.''
Another aspect of the newly proposed designs is their apparent lowering of defenses. Mr. Minor's firm, MHB Technical Associates, of San Jose, Calif., faulted some for lacking two secondary defenses: a containment building, the huge, costly concrete and steel structure devised to retain radiation accidentally released, and off-site emergency plans, which were required by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission after the accident at Three Mile Island, near Harrisburg, Pa., in 1979.
''There's nothing to contain,'' Mr. Blue argued, referring to the desirability of containment structures. ''It's about as useless as wearing a fur coat in the middle of summer.'' At Westinghouse, Richard J. Slember, the vice president and general manager of the Energy Systems Business Unit, said, ''It's a question of the need for an evacuation zone. That doesn't mean you wouldn't put that in. But the plant is so safe it may not require one.'' Before any new reactor could be built, the design would have to be approved by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
The Union of Concerned Scientists study, which analyzed the designs of General Electric, Westinghouse and General Atomics, welcomed some of the innovations. It applauded taking advantage of natural features in accomplishing vital tasks, including removing heat that continues to be produced after the nuclear reaction has ceased, also known as radioactive decay, which can cause a meltdown.
The study found some countervailing disadvantages. In two designs, ''the passive-decay, heat-removal systems which appear to be so beneficial in terms of accident prevention appear also to present a significant potential sabotage vulnerability,'' the study said, because the heat outlets are above ground. In existing reactors, heat is generally dissipated through cooling towers or into rivers and oceans.
Another design change is to build far smaller reactors, so that the amount of heat that must be removed in an accident is small enough to be removed by natural convection or other simple systems. One design calls for nine clustered reactors, run from a single control room with four operators. Yet mistakes have already occurred with operators at two-reactor control rooms, the study said.
Even as the study was being released, the American Nuclear Energy Council responded that the criticism was premature ''because of the rapidly evolving aspects of these designs.'' The Union of Concerned Scientists, it said, was showing ''its bias against nuclear energy and its long-held goal of phasing out nuclear energy plants.''
Mr. Minor, who oversaw the study for the Union of Concerned Scientists, said that even with looming questions about safety, new reactors might be ordered later in this decade. But unless the issues are resolved, he said, the second generation will be few in number and short lived.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
H.U.D. Scandal's Lesson: It's a Long Road From Revelation to Resolution

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
IN the fall of 1989, when the scandals at the Department of Housing and Urban Development were one of the biggest stories in America, David Burns, a senior staff member in the department's New York office, asked his superiors in Washington for permission to talk with the press about past wrongdoing at the agency. He got the go-ahead and the story he told of political pressure put on department bureaucrats in New York during the Reagan years made national headlines.
Mr. Burns's views have to a great extent been vindicated by a recent Federal court ruling and a new shift in housing policy by New York City. The officials brought in to run the agency's New York office by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp in the last year seem to be far less political, Mr. Burns says, and more inclined to make decisions on merit. 
But all that said, Mr. Burns has paid a price for whistleblowing, even in an Administration that seems committed to reform. The week after he went public in October 1989 he was excluded from senior staff meetings he had been routinely attending for a decade and, he says, ''I've never gone to another one since.'' Many of his responsibilites have been taken away, he says. ''I have been isolated at H.U.D.'' Mr. Burns's superiors acknowledge that he is no longer invited to some meetings but they say this has nothing to do with his disclosures.
Today Mr. Burns, a Columbia Law School graduate with 28 years in government, who regularly received good job reviews and bonuses, says, ''For speaking out, I am looked at as an unstable odd-ball by the H.U.D. leadership in New York.''
In many respects Mr. Burns's experience is a study in the difficulty of changing any large bureaucracy and the price that can be paid for trying. The H.U.D. scandals have largely disappeared from daily news, edged aside by the savings and loan story, among other things. But Federal investigators continue to probe and try to build cases. Events set in motion in 1989 could take years to play out. While they do, the targets as well as the whistleblowers live in limbo.
As a regional economist, Mr. Burns had the power to reject a proposed housing project if he felt there was already an ''undue concentration'' of subsidized housing nearby. In 1987 he rejected a site on the Lower East Side of Manhattan where an 80-unit senior citizen project known as Casa Victoria was planned. He calculated that nearly two-thirds of the housing in this high-crime area was subsidized. Mr. Burns says he was then pressured by the department's regional administrator, Joseph Monticciolo, until he changed his decision.
Mr. Burns says he was never sure why he had been pressured, but a sequence of events appeared to point to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican. Mr. Monticciolo and the Senator were close allies. Senator D'Amato wrote a letter to Mr. Monticciolo in support of the project. Shortly after the project was approved in 1987 a construction company that was a major contributor to the Senator, and employs the Senator's brother as an attorney, was picked on a no-bid basis. Senator D'Amato and Mr. Monticciolo have repeatedly said they supported the project on its merits alone. The F.B.I. is investigating.
After Mr. Burns went public, a group of neighborhood people who favored using the site for a park sued in Federal court to block construction. In February, in response to the suit, the housing agency reviewed its 1987 decision and over Mr. Burns's protests, approved the site again. Mr. Burns was then put in the spot of testifying against his employer in court.
 
Earlier this month Federal
District Judge William C. Conner issued an injunction blocking the project, relying heavily on Mr. Burns's testimony.
Judge Conner found that to justify the project the housing department had used inaccurate data and then interpreted its own regulations so loosely that those rules were made meaningless. The key issue, Judge Conner wrote, was whether there was already an ''undue concentration'' of subsidized housing and whether the area suffered from related pressures like crime. The problem, he said, is that in the 16 years the regulation has existed, the housing agency has never defined the term ''undue concentration.'' Housing department officials maintained that housing in the Lower East Side neighborhood was 50 percent subsidized. Judge Conner found several omissions in the estimate and wrote that the area was closer to Mr. Burns's estimate of two-thirds.
The housing agency acknowledged that it was a high-crime area, but contended that it was improving. Judge Conner noted that felonies were on the increase in the nearby housing projects and that residents had testified about heavy drug trading. By putting a project for the elderly there, Judge Conner said, the housing agency would be ''providng additional highly vulnerable crime victims.''
A housing department official, David Shenk, maintained that because the regulation is so vague it would not preclude building in an area that already had even 90 percent low-income housing. But Judge Conner wrote, ''This court cannot sanction such a broad exercise of discretion as to eviscerate the very meaning of the term 'undue concentration.' The effect of deferring to H.U.D. in this case would be to give H.U.D. an effectively unlimited license to build assisted housing regardless of the concentration of such housing in the area.''
 
'No Rational Connection'
Judge Conner said he found ''no rational connecton between the facts found and the choice made'' by the agency. Housing department officials say they have not decided whether to appeal the ruling.
Joseph Lynch, who was the acting regional administrator in the fall of 1989, says he was not punishing Mr. Burns for going to the press. He said he was reorganizing the office in the midst of the scandals and excluded several people, not just Mr. Burns, from senior staff meetings at the time. ''We had so many investigations going on I didn't know who was involved and how deep and who I could trust,'' Mr. Lynch said. He said the fact that he took action right after Mr. Burns went public was ''coincidence.''
For Mr. Burns, who still remains a regional economist, Judge Conner's decision brought mixed feelings. ''I'm very happy that my credibility is vindicated,'' he said. ''However, the feeling still persists in the New York office that I was wrong. I am unable to conclude that my speaking out has contributed to improving the department. It has created discomfort, resentment, and a very defensive reaction.'' He said he felt further vindication last week, when, in an unrelated matter, New York City took its own steps to stop overloading poor neighborhoods with social service projects. ''One of the satisfactions I've gotten from speaking out,'' Mr. Burns said, ''is I have the admiration of the staff, other than the very top. People say, 'keep it up, we appreciate what you did.' You see it in their eyes when you pass in the corridors.''

HEADLINE: If We Don't Give Gorbachev Help, Europe Will

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Should the West Bail Out Gorbachev?'' (Op-Ed, July 5), Graham Allison and Judy Shelton present diverging views in the dialogue on helping perestroika. Mr. Allison proposes targeted technical assistance. Ms. Shelton asserts financial assistance will promote diversion of Soviet resources to defense.
While her misgivings are justified in view of the high level of Soviet defense spending, her analysis smacks of the days of the cold war. Under perestroika, the Soviet leadership's priorities have shifted decisively in favor of assigning a larger slice of the national pie to consumption, followed by investment and, finally, defense. According to Central Intelligence Agency estimates, Soviet consumption in 1989 grew by almost 4 percent in real terms, while investment allocation grew by a minuscule .6 percent, and defense outlays declined by 4 percent to 5 percent. Soviet living standards are so low and public pressure to raise supplies of consumer goods is so overwhelming that the Soviet Government has to adopt sustained cuts in defense. 
Even if defense outlays were reduced drastically in a single stroke, supplies of consumer items and machines to produce them in abundant variety and quality are unlikely to materialize quickly in an efficient market environment. As Ms. Shelton points out, the Ryzhkov plan of May, announcing specific price rises, is hardly the way to introduce markets. But the radical reformers are no better. Boris Yeltsin, in a display of dangerous populist rhetoric, promised ''painless'' price reform on election as president of the Russian Republic. The Moscow City Council, inspired by Mayor Gavril Popov, decided to hand over all apartments to current residents. Given the chance, would the reformers carry populist zeal to the limit and hand factories to the workers and farms to the peasants as cost-free doles?
With the inability of Soviet planners and reformers to implement viable market reforms, what should our response be? At the Houston summit, the Group of Seven decided to set up a joint task force to study aid to the Soviet Union. In the Soviet predicament, that resembles the offer of swimming lessons to a drowning man.
In the meantime, the European countries were left free to extend credits to the Soviet Union, whereas the United States offered technical help without cash. President Bush argued that the Soviet Union must first undertake decisive market reforms. This two-track approach, with the European leadership offering a carrot and the United States President wielding a stick, will push perestroika further on the market route. From our perspective, however, it has two shortcomings:
(1) It would give European business a competitive edge over ours. Most Soviet infrastructure retooling will require not only technical help, but also cash and hardware. A French group of manufacturers and consultants ready to renovate the Soviet rail network would be paid for equipment and services to the Soviet agency out of credits guaranteed by the French Government. The European practice in such ventures is largely for government, industry and banks to work in tandem.
By contrast, legislative limitations on official Export-Import Bank supplier credits for financing United States exports to the Soviet Union, and the prohibition of guarantees by the Overseas Private Insurance Corporation on private United States lending, deprive American business of similar financing. President Bush's denial of concessionary credits to aid perestroika endorses continued restrictions. Congress should consider amending the legislation and ratifying the Bush-Gorbachev Trade Treaty signed at the Washington summit. (This step toward full-fledged commercial and trading relations with Moscow would be timely also because Mikhail S. Gorbachev has lifted sanctions against Lithuania.)
(2) There is an equally compelling, though less tactical, consideration. President Gorbachev's steps of reforming the Soviet economy have undoubtedly been measured. On this side of the street also, it has taken us five years to move from initial doubts about his survival as Soviet leader and the subsequent jitters about the irreversibility of his reforms to finally discussing concrete ways of assisting perestroika. With each hurdle crossed by him, our policy makers have raised the stakes. Such a calculated approach may have spurred him to make the correct moves, but it is likely to reduce our role to that of mere bystanders at a unique moment of history.
 
PADMA DESAI
 New York, July 11, 1990
 
The writer is professor of economics at Columbia University's Harriman Institute for Advanced Study of the Soviet Union.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 322 words

HEADLINE: If We Don't Give Gorbachev Help, Europe Will;
Everyone Gains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Bush's shift on taxes may be belated, but it is also timely. Now nothing less is needed than reversing the flow of savings into the United States and creating an outflow of capital, especially to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. We created such a flow with the Marshall Plan, with great effect. The infusion of desperately needed capital into Western Europe at the price of abolishing inward-looking cartels and abandoning narrow policies in favor of integrated economies and broad market efficiencies transformed Western Europe. The result was unprecedented prosperity on both sides of the Atlantic. 
We can cast that net wider. Orderly transformation of Eastern Europe requires outside resources to cushion the pain, which otherwise will be too excruciating. Again, the aid can be conditional on market-oriented reform. The cost will be substantial, but the benefits will be even greater. This time Western Europe can help, but we must play our part. This implies a massive increase in taxes to raise our share of the capital and have the chips to play in the game.
We found the resources with the Marshall Plan and similar economic and military aid around the world when we were much poorer. They are mobilized through taxes. Our fiscal burden is much lower than every other Western developed country. We need to catch up. It will be a tremendous shock to our economic system, just as financing World War II was a tremendous shock, but worth it. Careful management is required - the sort Americans are capable of when they see the need and the opportunity. If we respond properly and in time, all of us around the world will reap the dividend. If we don't, we will all be poorer.
 
LAWRENCE J. KENNON
 Berkeley, Calif., July 6, 1990
 
The writer, a retired senior Foreign Service officer, directed the Office of Monetary Affairs and of Economic Research in the State Department.

HEADLINE: Let the Elderly Choose to Work or Not

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Older Americans are an increasingly large group. They are healthier than ever before. A 65-year-old can look forward to 10 or even 15 more working years, if he or she wants to work and is allowed to do so. 
As a matter of national policy, what do we want them to do - work or loaf? It has never been up to them.
For years, employers followed an inappropriate policy of mandatory retirement at 65. Congress countered by making age discrimination unlawful. In 1983, Congress nullified its antidiscrimination stance by imposing a tax on the benefits of Social Security recipients older than 65, putting them into a marginal tax bracket that in some cases approached 100 percent. Those between 65 and 70 became the highest taxed group in the country. This tax is to be reduced modestly this year, but remains a powerful incentive not to work. This year, two competing bills are being considered. One would further raise the effective tax level on the elderly, while the second, from Representative J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, would remove the tax on Social Security benefits altogether. According to The Wall Street Journal, the House Ways and Means Committee (under Dan Rostenkowski) refuses even to let the Hastert bill come to the House floor for discussion, despite support of a majority of the House.
Many of the elderly prefer to work and contribute their skills and wisdom to our economy. All should, at the least, have the choice of working or not working.
Representative Hastert's bill to repeal the earnings limit makes sense. It would likely pass the House if only the Ways and Means chairman would release it.
 
TOM WHISLER
President, American Seniors Inc.
 Indianapolis, July 2, 1990
