HEADLINE: Behind the Facades, Surprises in Budapest

BYLINE: By Alexandra Shelley; Alexandra Shelley is a journalist who writes frequently about Hungary. She has lived in Budapest while researching a novel based on her grandmother's life.

 BODY:
Behind the iron gates of Budapest, in courtyards buried within unassuming apartment buildings, offices and universities, a traveler can find forgotten treasures of art and architecture, and footprints of the wars and revolutions that have marched across Hungary for the last millennium.
Unlike the ornate facades of the Hungarian capital's late-19th-century buildings, recently renovated and decked out in gaudy yellows and oranges, powder blues and pinks, the interior yards often remain untouched, their bullet-pocked walls a pentimento of epochs.
Here one can find sculptures ranging from neo-classical Greek gods to a socialist-realist bear on a scooter; an old dungeon; silversmiths' workshops and stables; lush gardens, and the basic component of Hungarian urban landscape architecture: car tires planted with flowers.
The sense of discovery in coming across these is keener for their being completely neglected in the midst of everyday life. And searching for them is a good excuse to stray slightly from the beaten tourist path. 
Courtyards tell the story of the evolution of urban Hungary. From the 19th century through World War II, maids and housewives congregated here to use the rug beaters (wooden contraptions that can still be seen) and pass the scuttlebutt.
An interior yard allowed the coexistence within one building of both lower and upper classes - ''Park Avenue and the South Bronx in the same building,'' as one Hungarian professor of urban anthropology, Istvan Teplan, put it. Facing the street were exclusive apartments. But fronting on the interior were small flats whose residents shared one bathroom in the corridor and drew their water from the courtyard well.
In the country's stormy history courtyards have also served as centers of rebellion. After the invention of the vacuum cleaner and the Communist system, grievances (if not rugs) continued to be aired. In fact, Professor Teplan speculates that this architectural device was abandoned during the Communist era precisely to discourage the subversive commerce of ideas.
''The courtyard was an arena of social conflicts,'' he told me. ''The old houses look inside. The new blocks, the housing developments on the outskirts of Budapest, don't look inside - to avoid space where people can gather.''
Yet in the old workers' districts of Budapest the interior yards remain an agora. Here children improvise games with scraps of wood and Ping-Pong balls, and old people lean their elbows on the windows sills and call across to each other. IN one such neighborhood, the industrial district of Jozsefvaros, I pushed open the doorway of what seemed yet another soot-covered building - at 22 Dioszegi Samuel street - to find an oasis of pink flowering hydrangea, roses, tomato plants, acacia trees. A woman asked me what I was looking for. I told her I had heard that the garden here was beautiful. ''Well, yes,'' she said, ''nothing else is'' - and that was the crux of it: the carefully tended garden was a defense against the squalor outside. (Although some of these courtyards are attached to public buildings, others are private and permission to visit them should technically be asked.) It is not surprising in a country that since the Mongol attack in 1241 has almost continuously been assaulted by invading hordes, that such fragile beauty is secreted away in the protected interior of the buildings.
One does not have to venture as far as Jozsefvaros to find it. In neighborhoods within walking distance of the downtown hotels, from the old Jewish ghetto to the elegant Castle district, the courtyards provide a glimpse of daily life both past and present.
I began my round of courtyards on the Pest side of the Danube just in back of the Intercontinental Hotel, armed with three tools: a good map of the city (available in most bookstores); a copy of ''Budapest: A Critical Guide'' (Park/Officina Nova, 1989), a humorous and intimate book by Andras Torok, and enough curiosity to follow the ghostly path of horse-drawn carriages through the carved wooden doors or ornate iron gates.
Reigning over the faded pink alcove and a bank of mail boxes off the courtyard at 3 Apaczai Csere Janos Street is the queen of the ancient underworld, Persephone. An Italian sculptor, Benno Elkan Roma, has depicted her in a dreamy moment - her eyes closed, her head canted, her pink marble lips a lovely contrast to the sleek white of her face and torso. She half-heartedly covers her nakedness with a bouquet of pink, purple and russet roses of quartz and marble. In the courtyard proper, the wooden stable doors and the water trough form a down-to-earth contrast to the neoclassical pretensions of this early-19th-century building.
Walking the few blocks to Kigyo street and 5 Felszabadulas Square, I stopped at the Parizai arcade. The building, built in 1911 by a bank, gives the impression of a Venetian palace. It is characteristic of the turn-of-the-century eclecticism that resulted from the search for a uniquely Hungarian style of architecture, its eastern motifs derived from a theory that the Hungarian people were of oriental origin.
The architect, Henrik Schmahl, took pains to distinguish the internal arcade from the mundane shoemaker's bazaar it supplanted. It is difficult to find a right angle in this passageway, with its fanciful carved wooden window frames, balustrades and even telephone booths.
The shops in the arcade are marked with mid-1980's neon signs: pocketbook for a luggage store; book for a bookstore, and harem girl, of course, for the carpet store.
I then made my way down Belgrad street, along the Danube, to Dimitrov Square and what was, last year when I studied there, the Karl Marx Economics University - in the new post-communist world the Budapest University of Economic Sciences. The university occupies a 120-year-old former customs house, designed in a neo-Renaissance style by Miklos Ybl, the Budapest Opera architect.
Although this year the school was shorn of his name and the Marxist curriculum, Karl Marx remains in the glass-covered courtyard. His somewhat tortured contemplative look seems to have deepened as the rapid democratization of Hungary took place before his unblinking bronze eyes.
In this hall in the past two years he has seen a succession of speakers indicating the waning of his power, from President Bush to the Dalai Lama to Prince Charles, to, in the spring of 1989, the leaders of the relatively obscure opposition group, the Hungarian Democratic Forum (hashing out a platform and thanking supporters). Not two years later the Democratic Forum is the leading power in the freely elected Hungarian Government.
Walking to Calvin Square and then along Muzeum Avenue, I came to the narrow streets of what was once a working class Jewish neighborhood, behind the Dohany Street Synagogue.
At 18 Dob Street is the Gozsdu building. Seven linked courtyards form the spine of this former dormitory complex built in the late 1800's by a childless Romanian judge, Elek Gozsdu, to house visiting Romanian students.
Some of the small jewelers workshops that lined the courtyards before World War II have been supplanted by what at first appear to be similar businesses - carpenter, hairdresser, dressmaker - but on inspection turn out to be affiliated with the Nepszinhaz, the People's Theater, making costumes, sets and props.
Major acts of Hungarian history have played in the Gozsdu courtyard. One of its groaning wrought-iron gates was the border of the Jewish ghetto during World War II.
During the 1958 revolution it was a headquarters for Hungarian insurgents. Russian tanks leveled the building next door and the struggle is spelled out in the bullet holes in the walls.
In a courtyard at 29-31 Kazinczy Street, behind a cavernous Orthodox synagogue with a crenelated roof, is the Hanna kosher restaurant. The smells of kosher cooking, the clank of pots on stove burners and the shouts of children in recess from Talmud-Torah class recall a time before the Holocaust when more than a thousand worshipers came to the synagogue each week.
One of the older men dining at the Hanna restaurant told me his was the first wedding held under the courtyard's wrought-iron canopy, or huppah, after the war. In Hebrew letters on the huppah's frieze is one of the blessings of the ceremony: ''The voice of joy, the voice of rejoicing, the voice of the bridegroom, the voice of the bride.''
Tucked under the courtyard's entranceway is the Sasz Chevra temple. At dusk each day, the murmuring of prayers come from its open door, through which can be seen the clocks that mark the different times of sunset - the beginning of the Jewish Sabbath - in major Hungarian towns.
From here I took a taxi toward Margit Bridge and the Buda side of the Danube, asking the driver to wait for a minute while I stopped in at 13-19 Palffy Gyorgy Street, a huge block of apartments built in the 1950's for military personnel. From the courtyard one feels the full monolithic weight of what Budapesters call the Stalinist Baroque style. On one courtyard wall are two bas-reliefs in bombastic, socialist-realist style: a soldier leaves for war, bidding goodbye to his wife and his flag-waving baby, and a worker in overalls reads to a child dressed in the uniform of the Communist youth group. But what about the bear on the scooter? In the center of the courtyard, this sculpture, although in the same realistic style, is an inexplicably whimsical deviation.
Crossing the Margit bridge I got out of the taxi at the Lukacs Spa, 25-29 Frankel Leo Street. Its swimming pools and medicinal hot baths scented with camomile are a traditional meeting place of journalists and politicans - in these waters much of the country's policy has been brewed over the past century.
On one of the courtyard walls, just below the statue of St. Luke, are plaques donated by thankful spa-goers from faraway lands. They describe in lurid detail the illnesses supposedly cured by the Lukacs. ''An enormous cramp was in my back for months. And this bath relieved it,'' wrote one Hungarian visitor in 1898. ''God's blessing on this miraculous place!''
These waters are said to have been sought out as early as the first century by the Roman legions. The present neoclassical complex was built during the Austro-Hungarian monarchy in the mid-19th century. It is ironic that after the Hungarians paid dearly to free themselves from the domination of Vienna, the state spa authority recently sold half of the Lukacs to an Austrian concern. Habitues speak nervously of price increases.
But, for the moment, a weary tourist may still buy a ticket to the two swimming pools for around $1.25. The sulfurous spring water is also sold in the glass-walled drink hall near the courtyard entrance. A giant mug said to cure arthritis can be had for 1 forint (about 2 cents) - although its faint rotten-egg smell may intimidate some visitors. I had no choice but to finish mine as the woman who draws the water explained proudly that families from the countryside take home liters of the stuff.
From here I took the tram at the foot of Margit bridge some five minutes to the last stop, Moscow Square, and caught the Castle Hill jitney to Szentharomsag Square.
Anyone who has gotten this far deserves to duck into the cozy Biedermeier interior of the 180-year-old Ruszwurm pastry shop, 7 Szentharomsag Street. From here it is a short walk on Uri Street to No. 19 (although almost all of the Castle district's restored Gothic and Baroque houses are worth exploring). Inside this house, built on the medieval ruins of an Italian warlord's mansion, is a courtyard whose white-washed walls, balconies and low archways evoke a Mediterranean serenity.
In the courtyard's rock garden, underneath a sundial painted on the wall, is the tombstone of Izabella Lenkey, daughter of the then-owner. The girl died at age 22 in 1850. Her fiance, forced to flee to America after participating in the failed Hungarian revolt against Austrian rule, wrote the poem on her gravestone. ''Two things were aflame in your youthful heart. Your fatherland and its son, your betrothed'' it begins, ascribing her death to the defeat of both of these.
When I inquired about the poem, a gracious elderly lady cooking lunch at an open window welcomed me into her apartment. Mrs. Bela Borsos sat down with me at the dining room table and, in a profound silence broken only the ticking of a deep-lunged clock, she wrote the verses.
How did she know this by heart? Time has blurred beyond recognition the words carved on the tombstone. Her great-grandmother was Izabella Lenkey's sister, said Mrs. Borsos.
As I stood once again in the sun-filled courtyard after an afternoon touring these sanctuaries of the past, it struck me more strongly than ever that history does not end with the final chapter in the textbook.

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory

 BODY:

Air Fares Cut In California Price War
A price war has broken out in the air corridor between Southern California and the San Francisco Bay Area, and passengers willing to plan three weeks ahead can fly for as little as $58 round trip. The most expensive full fare is $186 each way.
United, USAir, Delta, American and Alaska Airlines, all of which operate frequent flights between Northern and Southern California, have been offering the $58 fare since the beginning of July. To get it, customers must buy tickets 21 days in advance, travel any day but Friday and Sunday and stay over one Friday night. The number of $58 seats on any flight is limited, and the cost of the tickets generally cannot be refunded. 
Southwest Airlines sparked the $58 fare battle when it introduced flights between Oakland and Burbank or Ontario in Southern California.
USAir followed suit with hourly flights between San Francisco and Burbank, then added hourly service between San Francisco and Los Angeles International Airport. United, which has the most flights between Los Angeles and San Francisco, proceeded to match USAir's $58 price.
The three-week advance-purchase weekend fare, for travel on Friday or Sunday, is now only $68 round trip. Most airlines also offer a $98 round trip with one-day advance purchase, and a $142 round trip with no advance purchase required.
Airline officials will not say how long the reduced fares will be in effect.
 
Delay Seen on Boat Casinos CHICAGO
Wagerers looking forward to the start of riverboat gambling Jan. 1 in Illinois and April 1 in Iowa could be disappointed. Although plans are proceeding to introduce the floating casinos on the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers as well as on some of Illinois's inland waterways, it seems unlikely that betting will start on schedule.
The problem is that only recently did the Iowa Racing and Gaming Commission grant its first five licenses to prospective operators of riverboats. In a number of cases, the boats must be built from scratch, and gambling equipment, such as roulette wheels, slot machines and craps tables, brought in from outside vendors.
Things are proceeding even more slowly in Illinois. On July 1 the Illinois Gaming Board accepted its first 10 applications from prospective riverboat operators. The agency must now conduct background checks on the applicants and set the rules for gambling. For example, it has already ruled that no gambling will take place while the boats are docked.
Because the two states passed their gambling laws to promote tourism, it seems likely that the Iowa commission and the Illinois board will require the applicants to base their boats in economically depressed cities such as Rock Island and Moline on the Mississippi River and Sioux City on the Missouri River. The boats will venture on short excursions - say, four hours or less - during which those on board will be free to try their luck at everything from one-armed bandits to baccarat. Illinois and Iowa both have provisions in their laws requiring the boat operators to include entertainment for minors.
The arrival of the boats, which will likely be designed to be reminiscent of 19th-century paddleboats or casino cruise ships, should also spur development. A number of the prospective boat operators in Illinois, for instance, have said they would build hotels and restaurants in the state if their licenses were granted. And in Iowa, one of the licensees, John Connelly, an entrepreneur who operates riverboats in Pittsburgh and St. Louis, has committed to spending $90 million to renovate an existing hotel in Davenport and to build a new hotel and promenade nearby. ERIC N. BERG
 
German Booklet For Visiting Jews
For the first time, the German National Tourist Office has produced a brochure aimed specifically at Jewish travelers. The 40-page ''Germany for the Jewish Traveler'' includes a history of Jewish communities in several West German cities, advice on contacting the local rabbi and information on obtaining kosher food. Synagogues and Jewish cemeteries are also listed. The brochure begins with a four-page summary of the history of the Jews in Germany, with emphasis on the Holocaust.
In addition to Berlin, Frankfurt, Munich and major cities, some lesser-known communities with sites of interest to Jewish visitors are described, including Augsburg, Furth and Bamberg. There are also sections on the Bergen-Belsen and Dachau death camps.
Copies of ''Germany for the Jewish Traveler'' are available free from the German National Tourist Office, 747 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.
 
Grounded Ship Set to Return 1
The cruise ship Bermuda Star, grounded since striking a reef near the Cape Cod Canal June 10, is scheduled to take to the seas again July 28. The Bermuda Star Line ship has been in Brooklyn undergoing repairs to its hull, which received a gash 115 feet long by 2 feet wide.
Effjohn International Cruise Holdings, which owns the Bermuda Star, has canceled six scheduled cruises, in addition to the one in which the accident occurred off Woods Hole, Mass. The Bermuda Star sails on 7- or 10-day cruises from New York to Canada and Bermuda in summer and fall and from San Diego to Mexico in winter and spring.
The 680 passengers who were on a cruise to Montreal when the ship ran aground and those scheduled on canceled cruises have been given the choice of a refund - plus a $250 credit toward a future cruise - or a 7- or 10-day cruise on any of the Effjohn ships, which include the Queen of Bermuda and the Caribe. Also, each passenger will receive a $100 bar-bill credit.
 
French Trains Curb Smoking
Smoking will be banned on French commuter trains from Jan 1, 1991. Smoking will also be banned in the corridors of nonsmoking cars on long-distance lines and on platforms reserved for nonsmokers. The railroads announced that by January 1993 at least 70 percent of the cars on long-distance routes will be nonsmoking.
 
Hotel Programs for Children
Hotels, resorts and travel agencies are taking steps to appeal to parents through their children.
THE HYATT HOTEL chain, for instance, has introduced Camp Hyatt at many of its hotels and resorts. The camp, for youngsters under age 15, usually runs from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., and includes such activities as kite flying, sand-castle building, and arts and crafts. Children stay free in their parents' rooms at the Hyatt hotels; a separate adjoining room is 50 percent off.
THE CASA DE CAMPO RESORT in La Romana, Dominican Republic, offers children a summer camp that includes lessons in a variety of sports - wind surfing, horseback riding, golf and tennis, among them. The cost is $20 a day, and includes lunch. Camp continues through Sept. 30.
THE HILTON HAWAIIAN VILLAGE in Waikiki features a new children's program with a cruise on Hilton's own Rainbow I catamaran, a tropical bird show, a treasure hunt and a trip to the Dole Pineapple Cannery. All the activities are free for those aged 3 to 12; if there is space, parents are allowed on the excursions.
THE HOMESTEAD, the Allegheny Mountains resort in Hot Springs, Va., offers tennis, fishing and other sports instruction for children aged 7 to 12 in a program called Tower Troop. The program costs $15 a child a day.
THE ROSENBLUTH TRAVEL AGENCY in King of Prussia, Pa., near Philadelphia, has opened the Family Vacation Station. It has opened a ''Kid's Test Flight Room,'' which prepares a child for the experience of air travel. The room has regulation-size airline seats, and there is a musical video that follows a family through an airport and onto a flight.

HEADLINE: Culture Shock as East Greets West

BYLINE: By Stephen Engelberg; Stephen Engelberg is head of the Warsaw bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
West is meeting East this summer in Europe's newly democratic countries, and the clash of cultures has bewildered, frustrated and exhilarated both the visitors and the hosts.
The summer of 1990 has seen record or near-record numbers of Western tourists in Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, with the most significant surge of visitors going to Prague and Budapest, according to tourism officials. Romania, with its continuing unrest, and Bulgaria remain less popular destinations.
The tourists came for a glimpse of the places where Central Europeans made history last fall, but when they returned to their hotel rooms, dined in restaurants and tried to make phone calls, they got a first-hand understanding of the legacy of Communism.
While some found the standards of service disappointingly low and road and rail travel within Eastern Europe often erratic, others said the thrill of seeing the places that have dominated the news in the past year made it all worthwhile. 
''This is not a place where things are easy,'' said David Resnicow of Manhattan, as he reflected on a $350-a-night hotel in Prague that disdained answering telephone calls to its main switchboard.
''You wouldn't call coming here a sensual experience,'' he said during a visit with his wife to Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary. ''It's more a socioeconomic and political experience. You can feel an exuberance in the streets, a festiveness, a sense of rediscovery. It's almost like the 1960's in the way set patterns are changing.''
But many of the state-run enterprises in Eastern Europe still retain an ethos - briefly summarized as ''the customer is always wrong'' - that Americans found unnerving. Bill Stamp, a pastor from Birmingham, Ala., who has been driving to some of Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Romania's more obscure cities in the course of delivering Bibles, said he was troubled by the ''Communist mentality'' he encountered. ''The people aren't too willing to help you,'' he said. ''When it's time to close shop, they close shop. And you'd better not be in a hurry when you eat in a restaurant.''
The food of Eastern Europe, most of which stems from a meeting of the Communist shortage economy and traditional heavy Slavic recipes, is getting mixed reviews from Americans. Frances Carlson, of Lexington, Mass., was visiting Poland, the country of her parents' birth, for the first time. '' The food is just too greasy,'' she said. ''The Poles don't seem to have found healthy food yet.'' But Buford Alexander, an American living in Amsterdam, said he was impressed. ''I was prepared for a lot worse from what I read in the papers,'' he said. ''I find the food to be very good.''
Mr. Alexander was one of many tourists who expressed particular affection for Prague. ''It's incredibly well-preserved,'' he said.
Some Western visitors came prepared for the somewhat rustic conditions - and were pleasantly surprised by what they found.
Jim Goldgeier, a Sovietologist at Stanford University, and his fiancee, Kathy Bodovitz, a newspaper reporter from San Francisco, said they decided to venture East early this year braced to do without the pampering many Westerners expect on vacations.
''I expected Poland to be the Soviet Union, but I'm shocked,'' said Mr. Goldgeir. ''There are bananas, kiwis and raspberries everywhere. You would never see this in Moscow or Leningrad.''
Americans are still finding bargains in Eastern Europe - an ice cream cone for the equivalent of 4 cents in Czechoslovakia, for instance - but the economic reform programs in Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary have driven prices much closer to Western levels.
Eva Kucsas, owner of a souvenir shop in Budapest, said the free-spending tourists who used to come to the city on luxury tours had been replaced by a more tight-fisted crowd. ''My experience is that more of the poor tourists have been coming in the past 10 years. They even fret over 100 forints'' - about $1.50.
Beth Kirchhoff, a classical pianist from Seattle, said she was forced to go 20 minutes outside of Prague before she could find a room within her budget, a student dormitory that would rent a room for $25 a night.
Sue Volz from Florida, a dancer in the European road company of ''A Chorus Line,'' said she was dismayed to discover that only two possiblities for rooms were available when she arrived in Berlin: a cheap pension and a hotel at $470 a night. Ms. Volz said she chose the pension before moving on to better accommodations the next day.
For the East Europeans, the demands and habits of traveling Westerners have proved a bit of a shock in countries where until recently the tourist trade came mainly from neighboring Eastern-bloc countries.
Witold Lawnicki, manager of a state-run store in downtown Warsaw that sells Polish handcrafts, complained about the visitors' aversion to carrying cash, Polish or American. ''We like foreigners to buy our things,'' Mr. Lawnicki said, ''but they are always using these cards of plastic.''
Laszlo Lantos, a Budapest boutique owner, echoed Mr. Lawnicki's concerns. ''The Americans always want to make a bargain by wanting to buy three T-shirts, thinking it will cost less. They simply do not understand we have fixed prices.''
In West Berlin, the tendency of American tourists to look and run has irritated some hoteliers. ''Most Americans come in on the night train, take a walk through the wall and leave early the next morning,'' said an owner of a pension who declined to be named. He said he no longer provided rooms for one-night visitors, adding, ''Many of my colleagues are doing the same.''
Government officials throughout Eastern Europe predict that the number of Americans will rise higher in the late summer and fall as a result of recent changes in a visa process that tried the patience of even experienced travelers. East Germany and Czechoslovakia dropped visa requirements for American tourists earlier this year. Czechoslovakia has dropped all visa requirements for visitors staying a month or less. Hungary still requires Americans to obtain a visa; the charge in the United States is $15.
Figures for the numbers of tourists visiting the region so far this summer are not yet available, but even statistics from the winter months show large increases in the number of visitors to several of the countries.
More than 10 million tourists - about a third of them from Western countries - visited Hungary in the first five months of this year, an 83 percent increase over the same period last year, the Government tourist agency said.
In Poland, Robert Kepinski, General Director of the Department of Tourism, predicted that Western tourism to his country would rise 20 percent this year above the 1989 total of 1.8 million, with the number of Americans perhaps increasing even more sharply.
A spokesman for the West Berlin Tourist Board said 8,000 Americans visited the city in March, nearly twice as many as in March 1989.
In Czechoslovakia, Government officials said 1.2 million Western tourists, mostly Austrians, visited their country from January to March, a 159 percent increase over the same months in 1989. American visitors to the country in the first quarter of the year rose from 6,283 to 15,941, continuing a trend established last fall.
''There has been no tourist season this year,'' said Zdenek Pokorny, receptionist at the Ambassador Hotel in Wenceslas Square, Prague. ''Prague has been full since the revolution days in November.''
In June, crowds in Wenceslas Square were so large that visitors hoping to browse in Bohemian crystal shops or sip espresso in outdoor cafes found themselves part of a social phenemenon all too familiar to Czechs and Slovaks: a line. But like natives, visitors often found that queuing was for naught. A few overwhelmed cafes ran out of coffee, and the shelves of crystal shops in even the country's most remote cities had nothing but salt and pepper shakers.
Bohuslav Pinkas of the state-run travel agency in Czechoslovakia said: ''South Bohemia is overcrowded. It is impossible to find a place to drink a beer within 100 kilometers of the frontier.''
''You need connections to buy crystal now,'' said Suzanne Stefan, who lives in the small town of Kralovsky Chlmec, near the Czechoslovak-Soviet Union border. ''I can barely get it any more, and I know where to find it.''
It is not yet clear whether this summer will see a net gain in tourism for the countries of Central Europe, because the easing of travel restrictions means that Eastern Europeans are going to Western Europe and elsewhere in record numbers.
According to Krzysztof Gerula, vice president of the state-run Orbis tourist company in Poland, bookings from tourists in the formerly Communist countries have collapsed.
In addition, Poland eliminated its longtime policy of heavily discounting the price of hotel rooms for Polish citizens, a step that may also cause revenues to drop this year. In 1989, the last year for which statistics are available, more than 6 million of the 8.2 million people who came to Poland on visitors' visas were from Eastern-bloc countries.
One business in East Europe's cities that seems to be making a seamless transition to capitalism is the taxi industry, but the attempts to overcharge tourists are still more good-natured than surly. In Budapest, managers at the Hilton Hotel have begun monitoring the fares of drivers carrying hotel guests. In Prague, some taxi drivers become irate if the passenger insists that the meter be turned on, while in Bratislava drivers routinely refuse short-hop fares.
In Czechoslovakia, at least, Americans can feel confident that such treatment is not based on nationality: Everyone who looks like he isn't a native is usually addressed first in German.
One remnant of the Communist system persists in all of the region's countries but Poland: black market currency dealings. The Polish zloty is easily exchanged for dollars at a rate that has held steady throughout this year. In other countries, the main squares and hotels in the major cities are filled with young men who whisper ''Money? Money?'' and offer about a 20 percent premium above the Government-set rate.
Although authorities seem to turn a blind eye, the deals are illegal and sometimes tricky. One visitor to Prague from Houston, for example, complained that she had exchanged dollars for Czechoslovak currency that is no longer in use.
Tourists are finding less of Western Europe's ease when they travel in the region, whether by car or train. Cars are available for rent in all major cities, but road quality varies greatly between countries and urban and rural areas. Car rental rates in Hungary are from $24 to $84 a day plus 24 cents a kilometer, with a weekend rate of $150 plus milage. In addition there is a 25 percent tax on the total. Rates in Poland are from $22 to $60 a day plus mileage of from 10 cents a kilometer to about 64 cents a kilometer.
In Poland, newly paved roads link many of the country's big cities, but a lack of street lights makes night travel difficult, and the number of drunken drivers in rural areas is a major concern.
Czechoslovakia has long stretches of remarkably straight two-lane highways, making car travel in the country a reasonable possibility for tourists who want to travel between the major cities.
Trains in Central Europe are inexpensive - a first-class ticket for the four-hour trip in Poland between Gdansk and Warsaw costs about $5 -but often without the promptness, dining cars and smoking sections found in Western Europe.
In addition, some stretches of track are rundown, forcing the trains to move at a comparatively slow speed for hours at a time. The 40-mile trip from Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, to Vienna, for example, takes two hours by train and an hour by car.
Furthermore, train stations such as Warsaw Central tend to attract slick groups of pickpockets, who often choose travelers speaking foreign languages as their targets.
The American Embassy in Warsaw routinely warns Americans about the problem, but an official there said the business in replacement passports had been brisk.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Berlin

BYLINE: By Thomas Seibert; Thomas Seibert contributes to The Times from Bonn.

 BODY:
Less than six months ago, preparing for a night out at one of East Berlin's theaters was a nerve-racking experience for the Western visitor: tickets had to be reserved well in advance through an East German Government agency and crossing from West Berlin involved standing in long lines at one of the two border crossings open to foreigners, Friedrichstrasse and Checkpoint Charlie. A mandatory exchange at the border of West German for East German marks was an additional inconvenience.
Today all border checkpoints have been eliminated, the West German mark has also become the currency of East Germany and theater tickets can be obtained at box offices in both parts of the city.
As the two Berlins come together, the lifting of travel restrictions has not only made it easier for the visitor to cross over to the East, but has also generated the kind of bicultural life that the city has not seen since the Berlin wall went up in 1961.
After World War II each part of the city emerged as a cultural center in its own right. West Berlin, by far the Federal Republic's biggest city with 1.96 million inhabitants, became a center for West German art, while East Berlin, the privileged capital of East Germany, had most of the famous museums of the prewar city center. With the wall gone, East and West Berlin can merge their attractions. 
A fully reunited Berlin will have around 30 major art museums, from the Pergamon in the East, with the 2,000-year-old Pergamon Altar, built for Zeus between 180 and 160 B.C. in Pergamon, Asia Minor, to the National Gallery with works by Max Ernst and Francis Bacon in the West.
Scattered across its 341 square miles, Berlin boasts a cultural landscape that ranges from the Berlin Philharmonic in the West and the Berliner Ensemble in the East, a theater group founded by Bertolt Brecht, to political cabarets like East Berlin's Distel (thistle) on the Friedrichstrasse (telephone 200-4704) and West Berlin's Stachelschweine (porcupines) in the Europa Center on Tauentzinstrasse
 
Logistics
Getting around the two parts of Berlin is no longer a problem that requires careful planning. On July 1, when East and West Germany merged their currencies, economies and social systems, East Germany dropped visa requirements for most Western countries, including the United States. There are around 120 road links, cross-border subway and bus lines and former official border crossings between West Berlin on one side and East Berlin and East Germany on the other side. In addition, hundreds of unofficial breaches have been opened in recent weeks.
 
Museums
The Eastern part of town, the center of prewar Berlin, has the famous Museumsinsel (museum island) on the River Spree, a cluster of museums including the Pergamon (open daily from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.), the Bode Museum (open Wednesday to Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.), the National Gallery (Wednesday to Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.) and the Old Museum (Wednesday to Sunday 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.) Admission is 65 cents at each museum, calculated at 1.68 marks to the dollar.
Among the more important in West Berlin are the National Gallery (50 Potsdamerstrasse, open daily except Monday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; admission free), the Gemaldegalerie (painting gallery) in the Museum Dahlem (23-27 Arnimallee, open daily except Monday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; admission free) and the Egyptian Museum in the Charlottenburg Palace (Luisenplatz, open daily except Friday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; admission free).
Berlin's museums reflect the changes that have swept through the two Germanys and the city. The East Berlin National Gallery, which in the past specialized in displaying the art of 40 years of Communist East Germany, now houses an exhibition by the Austrian Alfred Hrdlicka.
Scheduled to run until Aug. 8, it is titled ''Der Anschluss'' (the annexation), a bitterly negative comment on the moves toward German unity.
 
Performing Arts
Cabarets and theaters in East Berlin, free of the totalitarian regime that regulated their repertory, have plunged into staging politically controversial programs.
The Maxim Gorki Theater in Kastanienwaldchen will interrupt its summer break on Aug. 17, 18 and 19 for three performances of ''Mein Kampf'' by George Tabori, a satirical play about the forming of the mind of the young Hitler (ticket information 208-2748). Tickets are from $2 to $20.
Cabarets like the Distel and the Berliner Kabarett Sundikat (18 Jan Petersen Strasse; 542-9100) deal with the mood and the attitudes of Germans as they prepare for unification. Ticket prices for East Berlin cabarets are around $15.
Tickets for East Berlin concerts, operas and cabarets can be obtained at such West Berlin ticket services as Box Office at Nollendorff Platz (215-1954) and Kurt Schumacher Platz (496-2223), and Theaterkasse Zehlendorf at 22 Teltower Damm (801-3056). In the East they can be obtained at the box office in the Palast Hotel at Spandauer Strasse (212-5258).
Several festivals, such as the Berliner Festwochen, a mainly musical gathering, will highlight the growing links between the two parts of the city. The Festwochen, strictly a West Berlin event in recent years, will be staged on both sides of the wall for the first time. The festival's first concert will feature the Gustav Mahler Orchestra conducted by Claudio Abbado in the West Berlin Philharmonic Hall on Aug. 7. The concert will be repeated the next day in the ruins of the Chorin monastery outside East Berlin.
On Sept. 1 Leonard Bernstein and the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra will appear on the Waldbuhne, a West Berlin open-air stage. Tickets are available at 882-7011.
 
Art Exhibits
Starting Aug. 28 the Martin Gropius Bau gallery near the wall on the western side will house an exhibition by the German Historic Museum, titled ''Bismarck and Prussia, Germany and Europe.'' (Open 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday; admission $5. Information 329-010.) In East Berlin, the Otto Nagel Haus on Museum Island features Russian and Soviet art from 1910 to 1930 in an exhibition that will run to July 31 (279-1402). It is open Sunday to Thursday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.
Paintings by the East German artist Bernhard Heisig can be seen at the New Gallery of the Old Museum on Museum Island until Aug. 26 (open Wednesday to Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; admission 65 cents. Information 212-7231). ''Out of Rank'' is the title of an exhibition of works of a new generation of East German artists in the Studio Galerie at 3 Strausberger Platz in East Berlin (open Monday to Friday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; 436-3370 for information).
 
Where to Stay
Unfortunately, the united Berlin's new and old attractions can be soured for the tourist by a chronic shortage of hotel rooms. Early booking is essential, at least a month before arriving. The West Berlin Tourist Board can provide visitors with day-to-day vacancies. The board, in the Europa Center on Budapester Strasse near the Kurfurstendamm, is open daily from 7:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.; 262-6031.
A new way to look for a hotel in Berlin is provided by Zimmer Frei? (vacancies?), a telephone information service that puts together a list of rooms in different price categories every day (19-414; recorded announcements in German only).
In West Berlin the Hotel Kempinski at 27 Kurfurstendamm (884-340), the city's busiest shopping street, offers luxury accommodation. The lobby has the atmosphere of a 19th-century grand hotel. Double rooms cost around $225 a night; $15 for a buffet breakfast.
The Grand Hotel Esplanade on the Landwehrkanal at 15 Lutzowufer (261-011) is a high-standard hotel with light airy rooms. The modern architecture of the Esplanade, the huge lobby and the hotel's own exhibition of modern art create an atmosphere of cool elegance, quite different from the cosiness of the Kempinski. Double rooms from $196; $12 for breakfast.
A less expensive but comfortable place is the Hotel Kronprinz at 1 Kronprinzendamm (896-030). Built in 1890, it captures some of the traditional, prewar Berlin atmosphere with its high, airy rooms and big windows. Double rooms are $113 with breakfast. In the same category is Hotel Agon at 4 Xantener Strasse (882-851). Doubles are $102 with breakfast. Situated in a modern building in a quiet residential area off Kurfurstendamm, the Agon, with its light, modern rooms, is ideally situated to serve as a base for walks through the city or trips to Berlin's hinterland.
Hotel Econtel International, around the corner from the Charlottenburg Palace at 24 Soemmeringstrasse (346-81147), is medium-priced and convenient to downtown. A double is $86 with breakfast. The Econtel's lobby and rooms stress simple structures and basic functionality.
Budget choice: Large old-Berlin style rooms and a quiet atmosphere can be enjoyed in the Hotel-Pension Pariser Eck (19 Pariser Strasse; 881-2145). Doubles are $57 with breakfast.
In East Berlin a dozen high-price hotels are officially still the only accommodations available. The Victorian-style Grand Hotel at 158 Friedrichstrasse (20-920), built by the former Communist Government to bring in hard currency, offers a grandiose lobby that is a favorite place for afternoon tea. The rooms, which offer every luxury, are $210 with breakfast.
The Palast Hotel (Karl Liebknecht Strasse; 212-5750), next to the Berlin cathederal and the East German Parliament building, the Palace of the Republic, is another luxury place. The hotel's restaurant, the Markisches, (2410), offers a splendid view of the river and the cathedral and has a menu of typical Berlin dishes. Good selection of wines. Dinner around $21 a person. Slightly less expensive than the Grand (a double with breakfast is $160), the Palast is right in the center of East Berlin.
Reservations in East Berlin can be made with the hotels directly or through Zentrale Zimmervermittlung, 5 Alexanderplatz, Postfach 77, 1026 Berlin, East Germany; 215-4402.
 
Where to Eat
The Ermeler Haus at 12 Markisches Ufer (275-5103) has international cuisine for about $20 a person.
For good German food in East Berlin, the Offenbach-Stuben at 8 Stubenkammer Strasse (448-4106) is a good choice. Meals are around $20.
In West Berlin, Fofi's Estiatorio in Fasanenstrasse (881-8785), a meeting place of a colorful in-crowd of artists and actors, offers Greek dishes. A three-course meal with wine is $30 to $40.
Alt Luxemburg, which has become increasingly popular recently, offers haute cuisine in a nostalgic atmosphere on Pestalozzistrasse (323-8730). Dinner with wine is around $71 a person. Reservations necessary.
Florian's, at 52 Grolmannstrasse (313-9184), with dinner at $30, is a good place to have a long chat in a cozy atmosphere. Florian'sspecializes in German food from Franconia.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1634 words

HEADLINE: The Chernobyl Syndrome

BYLINE: By GLENN GARELIK; Glenn Garelik, a correspondent for Time magazine, writes frequently about environmental issues and is a translator of ''Chernobyl,'' a Soviet eyewitness account.

 BODY:

THE LEGACY OF CHERNOBYL
By Zhores A. Medvedev.
Illustrated. 352 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.
 
DEADLY DECEIT
Low-Level Radiation, High-Level Cover-Up.
By Jay M. Gould and Benjamin A. Goldman with Kate Millpointer.
Illustrated. 222 pp. New York:
Four Walls Eight Windows. $19.95.
''Socialism is Soviet power plus electrification of the whole country,'' Lenin said in 1921 when he introduced his program to bring his nation into the industrial 20th century. Even today the centrality of that tenet to Soviet economic philosophy can hardly be exaggerated. The Soviet Government has taken the production, and consumption, of electric power not just as an index of the nation's economic progress but as a metaphor for the health of its entire system. 
As Lenin initiated the country's electrification by developing its coal and oil resources, and Stalin and Khrushchev promoted heroic hydropower projects, so Mikhail S. Gorbachev made it his mission to accelerate the conversion of the Soviet Union to nuclear power. By 1986 the Soviet Union had the world's third largest nuclear program, after the United States and France. And Mr. Gorbachev's first five-year plan, adopted in February of that year, called for doubling the nation's nuclear capacity, from 11 percent of its electricity to 22 percent. But just two months later, on April 26, 1986, the accident at the nuclear reactor in Chernobyl, the largest plant in the Soviet Union, undermined Mr. Gorbachev's plan - and along with it many of the assumptions on which the nation was built.
In ''The Legacy of Chernobyl,'' Zhores A. Medvedev, a biochemist who was exiled from the Soviet Union in 1973 and is now a research scientist for the National Institute for Medical Research in London, combines an exhaustive accounting of technical data with an insider's knowledge of the Soviet bureaucracy to synthesize a damning history of the Chernobyl affair, from its origins in the plant's primitive design and careless management to the economic and political crisis the accident precipitated. Using the same painstaking analysis that distinguished ''Nuclear Disaster in the Urals,'' Mr. Medvedev's now largely vindicated investigation of a devastating nuclear accident in the 1950's, he makes the Chernobyl disaster seem almost inevitable.
The accident itself, Mr. Medvedev asserts, occurred not during the testing of a safety system, as official accounts have suggested, but during a belated attempt to install such a system, more than two years after the plant went on line. Disaster, he believes, was the inevitable result of the sequence of simple operator errors that, as fate had it, occurred in the wee hours of April 26.
Mr. Medvedev also makes it clear that the haphazard, and often bungled, attempts to handle the Chernobyl disaster resulted not just from technical inadequacy but from a bureaucratic cover-up - of the accident itself and of its potential medical effects - that reached as high as the central ministerial level. Hundreds of thousands of Soviet people were exposed to dangerous levels of radioactivity because they were not evacuated, and even today many remain exposed as they eat food from and live in irradiated areas, mainly Byelorussia and the Ukraine. Many of these accusations, which were first made in the Soviet press last fall, point in the direction of Yuri A. Izrael, chairman of the State Committee on Hydrometeorology, which kept radiological data hidden from the public, and Yevgeny I. Chazov, the Minister of Health, who played down the biological impact of radiation.
The long-term effects of Chernobyl have yet to play themselves out. Ultimately, Mr. Medvedev suggests, cleanup costs could exceed the Soviet Union's entire investment to date in its nuclear capacity. And, he believes, Chernobyl was the catalyst for some of the momentous political and economic changes now taking place. By exposing institutional weaknesses within the Soviet bureaucracy, he writes, the affair forced the examination of the system's ills that became perestroika; and by trespassing international boundaries, the tragedy forced the public admissions from high-ranking Government officials that became the first glimmerings of glasnost. Moreover, the accident triggered an interest in conserving energy. An antinuclear - and, in turn, broadly environmental - movement has gathered across the Soviet Union, and that movement is now the foundation for the ''people's fronts,'' the vanguard of democratic and secessionist sentiments.
If Mr. Medvedev faults the Soviet bureaucracy mainly for its reflexive silence on Chernobyl, Jay M. Gould and Benjamin A. Goldman, the authors of ''Deadly Deceit,'' take pains to demonstrate a history of active deception in American bureaucracies. They contend that the United States Energy and Defense Departments, and even certain state health offices, have falsified data in order to hide the health effects on Americans of both the distant Chernobyl accident and the radiation that has been released by bomb tests, weapons facilities and power plants here.
Mr. Gould, the author of ''The Technical Elite,'' and Mr. Goldman, the author of ''Hazardous Waste Management,'' take as the starting point of their investigation the month following the Chernobyl accident. In that period, they contend, there were sharp increases in the United States figures both for mortality and for the levels of radioactive iodine in milk. What is the connection? They hypothesize that low-level radiation not only triggers long-term chromosomal damage (and thus, frequently, cancer), but can also, when ingested, break up oxygen in the body into highly reactive atoms that can wreak all sorts of additional havoc - from damaging cells in the immune system to encouraging the deposit of cholesterol in arteries. These phenomena, they believe, could cause an immediate rise in mortality, especially among infants and the elderly. Thus, they say, the accidents at Three Mile Island in 1979 and at the Energy Department's Savannah River facility in South Carolina in 1970 could explain as many as 100,000 statistically ''excess'' deaths.
There have been decades of Federal, if not state, cover-up of nuclear mismanagement. That much has become all too clear in the course of recent Congressional testimony. But the authors, in the manner of their mentor Ernest J. Sternglass, professor emeritus of radiology at the University of Pittsburgh, seem to get so caught up in raising what may be valid issues that they fail to worry about whether they have manipulated data to make their points. For instance, it is interesting if it is true, as the authors claim, that infant mortality between 1968 and 1983 rose faster in South Carolina than the national average; but it is not clear why they have selected precisely those years, nor whether the causes of death in South Carolina are indeed those (opportunistic pneumonias, for example) that might support their theory. They simply relax their hypothesis.
The authors also allow themselves audacious lapses of logic. For example, they say that the Soviet Union stopped publishing infant mortality data in the early 1970's, just about the time some of its nuclear plants came on line. That's provocative. But to suggest causality, as they do, is to go much too far. Indeed, no modern scourge escapes their speculation. AIDS, they believe, may be the result of above-ground nuclear testing; tick-borne Lyme disease, they suggest, may be the result of a 1975 accident at Connecticut's Millstone reactor.
Late in the book, the authors warn that ''the search for statistical correlation is not meant to replace causality studies, but rather to provide clues where to look.'' To do even that, though, the search for correlation must be beyond reproach.
 
PARANOID DELUSIONS OF REFORMING SOCIETY
 When the British Broadcasting Corporation called Zhores Medvedev to inform him of the nuclear accident at Chernobyl, his reaction, he said, was ''complete disbelief.''
''I was puzzled,'' the exiled Soviet scientist said in a telephone interview from his home in London. ''I didn't believe reactors could explode.''
As the author who revealed a previous nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union that had been covered up for more than 20 years, Mr. Medvedev was naturally drawn to the Chernobyl story.
''As soon as the accident at Chernobyl happened I became suspicious,'' he said. He found reams of reports that either played down, exaggerated or falsified facts. ''In the end, I was surprised at how poorly designed the reactor actually was.''
In the Soviet Union, Mr. Medvedev was a victim of official attempts to stifle opposition. Diagnosed in 1970 as having ''paranoid delusions of reforming society,'' he was committed to a mental institution before being exiled in 1973.
The 64-year-old biologist is now a senior research scientist for the National Institute for Medical Research in London. While he describes himself as a researcher and not a reformer, he is nonetheless quite bold when rooting out truth.
''I wanted to write this book not only to show the real scale of this particular catastrophe, but also to demolish a few more secrets and deliberate misconceptions,'' he said.
In recent years, the Soviet Union has warmed toward Mr. Medvedev and his twin brother, Roy, a prominent dissident historian who is now a member of the Soviet Parliament. Mr. Medvedev has returned twice to the Soviet Union to attend scientific seminars. Recently, the Soviet Academy of Scientists invited him to a conference on biological fallout from Chernobyl that will be held near the site of the reactor in September.
''I accepted immediately,'' he said. ''I'll be taking as many copies of my book as I can.''
TERESA L. PETRAMALA

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 22, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 959 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:

WASTED, by Linda Wolfe. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) The author of ''The Professor and the Prostitute'' tells the story of the jaded Upper East Side subculture of sex and drugs that gave rise to Jennifer Levin and Robert E. Chambers Jr., the friend who killed her late one night in Central Park. ''In the end, what makes this an excellent, valuable book is that it raises larger questions no less deserving of our attention and consideration,'' Michael M. Thomas said here last year. ''Drugs are an antidote to neglect, and neglect, this story tells us, is not something that begins north of 96th Street.''
 
THE MAMBO KINGS PLAY SONGS OF LOVE, by Oscar Hijuelos. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $9.95.) For the Castillo brothers, who emigrated from Havana in the late 1940's to become New York City mambo stars, the high point of their lives comes when they are discovered in a nightclub by Desi Arnaz, who invites them to make a brief appearance on the ''I Love Lucy'' show. When this novel was published last year, our reviewer, Margo Jefferson, said, ''Mr. Hijuelos is writing music of the heart, not the heart of flesh and blood that stops beating, 'but this other heart filled with light and music . . . a world of pure affection, before torment, before loss, before awareness.' '' 
 
MEMORIES AND HALLUCINATIONS: A Memoir, by D. M. Thomas. (Penguin, $8.95.) This autobiographical book by the British novelist ''lacks energy,'' our reviewer, Helen Dudar, said in 1988. But D. M. Thomas ''is terrific at remembering creative connections. In about two and a half pages, he tells us how 'The White Hotel' was born, and the account is fascinating.''
 
THE MARK TWAIN MURDERS, by Edith Skom. (Dell, $3.50.) A professor of English believes there is a connection between a plagiarism scandal and the murder of a student in the Midwestern University library. ''Literary allusions are dropped into the puzzle plot with easy familiarity by the well-read author, who sharpens her quill for some amusingly barbed character studies of the idiosyncratic faculty in the English department,'' Marilyn Stasio said here last year.
 
BALANCING ACTS: Technology, Finance and the American Future, by James K. Galbraith. (Basic Books, $9.95.) Inflation is not such a bad thing, the author argues, if the alternative is the high interest rates that keep the United States from doing what it does best: manufacturing high-tech goods. ''In a period of so much economic malaise, contrarian ideas can be very helpful in sorting out solutions - particularly when the ideas are as insightful as Mr. Galbraith's,'' Louis Uchitelle said here last year. Basic Books has also republished MEMOIRS OF AN UNREGULATED ECONOMIST ($9.95), in which George J. Stigler, a Nobel Prize winner, tells why the dismal science is not really so heartless after all. ''To win us over, he presents a loving and fierce defense of economics,'' Robert Krulwich said here in 1988.
 
LEAVES OF FORTUNE, by Linda Barlow. (Dell, $4.95.) When this three-century saga of a Boston tea dynasty was published in 1988, our reviewer, Carrie Carmichael, said it should be subtitled ''Something for Everyone.'' The novel has ''channeling and crystals for the New Age crowd. And for mainstream readers, there is money, lots of it, as well as power plays, revenge, death and even eating disorders.''
 
CALDECOTT & CO.: Notes on Books & Pictures, by Maurice Sendak. (Noonday/Michael di Capua/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.95.) The author and illustrator gives his thoughts on Mother Goose, Beatrix Potter, Walt Disney and other inspirations. Last year our reviewer, Michael Cart, said, ''To many readers, the chief value of this important collection will be the opportunity to infer from Mr. Sendak's criticism the creative origins and workings of his own timeless art and to understand, moreover, the consistent importance to the picture book form of rhythm, music . . . and 'the satisfying balance of language and illustration.' ''
 
SECOND FIDDLE, by Mary Wesley. (Penguin, $7.95.) Laura Thornby, a middle-aged woman whose specialty is restoring broken statues, takes an aspiring young writer under her wing, resolving to remold him in her own image. The question, though, is who is remolding whom. ''There are special treats here for writers and those who love and inspire and put up with them,'' Eric Kraft said here last year, ''for this is a novel with much to say about the giddy elation and awful terror that attend creation.''
 
ARNOLD J. TOYNBEE: A Life, by William H. McNeill. (Oxford University, $10.95.) Renowned for his theories of the cyclical nature of history, Arnold J. Toynbee became so well known that his picture appeared on the cover of Time. Last year our reviewer, Mary Lefkowitz, called this book a ''carefully documented and eminently readable account'' of the historian's life.
 
INDECENT DREAMS, by Arnost Lustig. (Northwestern University, $9.95.) Set in Prague during the Nazi occupation, a trio of novellas tells the story of three women forced into reluctant acts of heroism. ''Mr. Lustig's prose is smart, spare, tough-minded and then, abruptly, piercingly lyrical in its evocation of the natural world,'' Johanna Kaplan said here in 1988.
 
THE TALE OF GENJI, by Murasaki Shikibu. Translated and abridged by Edward G. Seidensticker. (Vintage, $9.95.) Three centuries before Chaucer, this story of life in imperial Kyoto became what is now believed to be the oldest existing novel. Its author has been called the Marcel Proust or Jane Austen of Japan. It is ''a long, leisurely but deep examination of love, jealousy, joy, sorrow and intrigue that to this day influences Japanese ideas of manhood and femininity,'' Fumiko Mori Halloran said here in 1986.

LENGTH: 2264 words

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
Time for Colleges to Take Back the Field

BYLINE: By JOHN UNDERWOOD; John Underwood is finishing his eighth book, a personal odyssey through the religious chaos in America, entitled ''Loathe Thy Neighbor.''

 BODY:
THE word is out: big-time college sport, which had been moving rather impressively toward a new rectitude under the whip of a born-again leadership (mostly college presidents fed up with being truant officers), is about to go off the wagon again. Thanks once more to the willingness of television to sponsor debauchery, and the eagerness of college athletic departments to sucker in, half - or so it seems - of the major college programs in the country are said to be preparing to throw caution - and tradition, and common sense - to the winds in a wholesale realignment of who-plays-whom.
According to wild rumor and runaway speculation, a reshuffling of mind-bending proportions is imminent. If transacted to the extreme, it would affect such a face lift on leagues and conferences that the geography of major college sport would take on the aspects of a cartoon rendering . . . of a map the cartoonist only saw once . . . in an opium dream. 
Three (or more) schools from the Southwest Conference would relocate into the Southeastern Conference, including those good ol' Deep South sidekicks, Arkansas and Texas A&M. The Pacific-10 would become the Pacific-16 and include Arizona and Utah-by-the-sea. The Big Ten would become the Big Eleven - at least. Miami and Florida State, the glamour boys of the independents, would wind up in any of two or three old leagues, or one new one, including a football-only ''Metro'' conference that would have Miami - Miami of Florida - in its ''northern'' division. Notre Dame, the Independent, would be left to serve as the only celibate, because, as always, Notre Dame goes its own secure, self-indulgent way.
This fast reshuffle is being roundly advertised as a Good Thing, and an Inevitable Thing, and, most important, a Profitable Thing. It is, of course, a Bad Thing that, once and for all, would stamp big college football and big college basketball as the professional leagues their critics say they really are. And this is a Very Bad Thing indeed, especially now when college leadership is at last exercising its prerogatives and making genuine headway toward straightening out the mess that years of intemperance and malfeasance have created.
As for it being an Inevitable Thing, I'm not so sure. I like to think there are surer hands on the tiller than we are being led to believe.
There is no doubt, however, from which alien planet the stimulus for this madness comes. Television, the great financier of sport, has been getting college athletic departments lucred up for years in order to get them to do what it wants. To get them to play whenever and wherever, and by almost any format, up to and including the distortion of the games themselves (for the glory and accommodation of ''commercial messages,'' the only thing in televised sport that is inevitable).
Television money, as any accounting major knows, is the wonder drug of spectator sports. It is the great elixir that closes the wounds and hides the scars and makes everybody fiscally whole. You can't really blame professional leagues or professional events for throwing in, for becoming ''products of television.'' They are as tied to it as a man's leg is to his hip. But college sport should not be, and deserves better - I think because it happens to be better. Traditionally, at least, the colleges are where sport made its best impression on the American ethos.
Some years ago, however, the administrators of college sport made a fateful decision. They allowed television - or, rather, television's money - to become their best friend. Sometimes your best friend can be your worst enemy. The administrators of college sport gradually came to believe that it was all right to be manipulated by television, as long as the pot was right.
And, lo, the tradeoff turned out to be habit-forming, so much a part of budgetary considerations that what was once thought of as kind of a happy fiscal fluke is now a way of life. The appetite for television money grew ever larger and became insatiable, even to the point of blinding college sport's best examples, Notre Dame now included, into acting as if they were islands unto themselves. As if nobody else mattered. What has made it worse, and so counterproductive, is that the unholy alliance disturbed even further the already shaky academic-athletic balance (the necessary illusion that the athlete is a ''student first''), not only in fact but in the critical eyes of the public - and, most important, in the minds of coaches and players. Don't think for a minute that when coaches are saddled with the added pressure to succeed, to win enough in order to be attractive enough to be on television, so that there'll be more television money, so that the athletic department can live forever in the happy black, that they don't realize how cynical the process has become.
Don't think for a minute that the players don't see it, and don't know that greed is at the beating heart of it.
The pressure to win at any cost costs a lot. From such pressure comes the breakdowns in integrity, the rule-bending, the outright cheating that despoils all of sport. I know one basketball coach on the West Coast who was told flat out by his superior a couple of years ago: ''You need to get us on television to pay our bills, Coach X. Either win the conference championship this year or you're fired.'' He didn't, and he was. You can hardly preach ''the values'' of college athletics to such people, nor the importance of keeping them in line with - and subordinate to - the academic mission. You can't preach to anybody about values when your own eyes are so easily lit by the color of money.
Make no mistake about it. The explosion in the map factory now being talked about for college sport, the massive realignment that would make a shambles of the tradition and order of games, is founded on the hope of cashing in on still one more financial bonanza spawned by television's high finance.
But let the buyer beware. Granting the benefits and the pleasure television brings to sport (and they are many), one should not misidentify the beast. Television is not in the business of standing up for tradition, or fretting over integrity, or helping colleges practice what they preach. It is simply In Business. It does what it has to do, sells what it can sell. When we no longer buy Armstrong Circle Theater, television gives us Who's The Boss.
When the colleges started taking the money, like everyone else they allowed television to transform their games to fit the medium. The best example of the noxious fallout is what television does to the ebb and flow of actual play. Impetus, as any weekend tennis player knows, is a big factor in athletic competition. But television ruins impetus. You see it all the time: big game, fraught with implications . . . a sudden twist of fortune, the ball changing hands . . . players rushing onto the field . . . fans going crazy. And then everybody stands around for two minutes while the folks at home are sold a piece of the rock or a better way to control their bladders.
And while the fans at home are getting those messages, the fans at the stadium, and the players and the coaches, too, are getting this one: we'll do anything, allow anything, forfeit anything for money. Draw up the contract and show us where to sign. The biggest college football game of the year last season was Miami vs. Notre Dame. The two teams ran 126 plays. CBS ran 73 commercials.
But that's just the more obvious manifestation of the problem. The real crux of the television misadventure is the colleges' own mistake in allowing the money madness to spread, and, ipso facto, to confuse what is good for college sport with what is perceived to be good for the individual schools who play it: i.e., the more I squeeze out of the system the better off I'll be. It has caused an ever-widening gulf between the Haves and the Have-Nots, and all but deadened the moral obligation to one another - and to the spirit of competition - that must prevail to justify having intercollegiate sport in the first place.
Well, it just so happens that the time is ripe for the colleges to change all that. At the vortex of chaos, a light has been growing. Primarily it shines from an unprecedented effort on the part of presidents and chancellors, the leadership of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, big-name executives among concerned alumni groups, et al, to make amends for years of neglect. Creating commissions, even, to lead the attack.
Evidence abounds that the N.C.A.A. has at last begun to solve its academic problems. Being a longtime critic of that effort, I feel reasonably assured in saying that the day has finally come when it is next to impossible for an athlete to qualify for a Big Ten scholarship by passing a high school history exam that requires him to name the 12 months of the year, as one did a few years ago. (He passed by naming 10.) The N.C.A.A.'s Proposition 48, and subsequent sword-rattling talk about even stiffer entrance requirements, sent the appropriate message to those high schools and grade schools that graduate without educating: we won't take your morons any more. And the same administrators who pushed for that reform have been joined by a whole new army of reformers, including many athletic directors and coaches, to push for other needed changes: an end to freshman eligibility, an end to athletic dormitories, greater limitations on practice time and recruiting privileges and reduction of scholarship limits.
But also the time is ripe because the very conditions that have stimulated the new thirst for television money (and the talk of super conferences that will vacuum it up) also, ironically, make it possible for the colleges to wean themselves off the TV bottle. Make it possible to break the dependency without necessarily losing the nourishment, and benefit all of college sport in the process.
With the burgeoning of cable networks, ever heavier into sports coverage, television lusts for college sport. And the one salient fact that has long been overlooked is now ''truer'' than ever: television needs college sport more than sport needs television.
Contrary to what the credits say, television does not produce anything in this realm. It merely buys in.
And when the colleges start demanding, as they should have a long time ago, that television ''take us as we are, on our terms, or leave us alone,'' a strange and wonderful thing will happen.
Television will continue to televise the competitions.
It will continue to pay stupefying sums for the privilege. It will have to. What else can it do, form its own leagues? And if, say, in this accommodation, the colleges find that less money comes from that commercial sponsorship (it won't, but say that it does), so what? Let the colleges take a little less. Learn to live a little cheaper. Take the pressure off coaches and athletes to ''win one for the money.'' Go back, says Dick Schultz, executive director of the N.C.A.A., to ''playing for trophies.'' They'll feel a lot better about themselves. And no matter how it totals out, there'll still be plenty to go around.
Which is exactly what should happen to the money: it should go around. Literally. For big-time college sport to advance safely into the 21st century, all that money, every dime of it, should be shared equally among the brotherhood - divided up among those schools that have committed to the expense of playing college sport at the top level. Maybe giving the Have-Nots reason - for a while longer at least - to think it's worth it to continue on as punching bags for the Haves.
From a capitalistic point of view of course, share the wealth would penalize winners from reaping the rewards of their victories, especially now when budgets are so large and they need the money to make ends meet. Well, no, they don't. They have created monstrous athletic budgets to try to keep up with the Smiths and the Joneses - to match thicknesses of carpet, quadraphonics in the training room, the tonnage of gleaming metal in weight rooms - and the budgets simply don't have to be so monstrous.
Ideally, intercollegiate sport would be played whether it made money or not. By the good it brings the schools that foster it and the athletes that participate, its worth should be measured by ''cost-value'' considerations rather than ''profit-loss.'' There was a time when this was so. A return to safer, smarter economics could, in due course, make it so again, and at the same time, level the playing field a little more for competing teams.
Meanwhile, there are ways to save money and some have been suggested here. One has not, and it doesn't get talked about because it would require college football - the big moneymaker, and the big money spender -to go back to its roots: to what Bear Bryant used to call ''total'' football, where players have to play both offense and defense, just like in every other sport, and all those 285-pounders bulked up with extra weight would wear themselves out running up and down the field. Then, Bryant said, you could win the old-fashioned way: with spirit and zeal and real players.
And look, he said, how it would cut costs: instead of 95 players, you could make do with 50. Instead of 16 coaches, with half a dozen. Would the game suffer aesthetically? Well, maybe, he said, but the average fan would never know the difference, and the true athletes would love it. And isn't that the reason you hold athletic contests in the first place?
But, of course, that's another subject.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

The Red House
 
Question: I have always been curious about the building known as Red House on the south side of West 85th Street just off off Riverside Drive. What can you tell me about it? . . . S. L., Manhattan
 
Answer: The six-story, 50-unit apartment building at 350 West 85th Street was completed in 1904. Built as a multifamily dwelling, it was designed by the firm of Harde & Short, also responsible for the Alwyn Court on West 58th Street and Seventh Avenue and the Studio building at 44 West 77th Street. 
French Ressaissance in style, the building was designated a landmark by the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1982. Among its most interesting features is the salamander and crown motif set in its brickwork. It still functions as a rental apartment house.
 
The Owner of Record.7
 
Question: Where do I go to find the name of the owner or owners of a building on Central Park West in Manhattan? There has to be some place where owners of buildings are registered.. . . M. S.,Falls Church, Va.
 
Answer: The place you want is the Manhattan office of the City Register at 31 Chambers Street. Ownership of a property, the dates when it changed hands and the tax billing address are recorded on a document known as the deed. Microfilmed copies of deeds to all properties in New York City are kept on file in the City Register offices in each borough except Staten Island, where they are kept in the Richmond County Clerk's office.
To find a deed you need the block and lot number of the property, which you can look up in the land and map books in each borough office. Properties for which deeds have been recorded since 1982 are listed in computerized indexes; those recorded before are in manual files. A copy costs 25 cents a page.
While the information on deeds is a matter of public record, it is not available over the telephone or by mail. You must do the research in person or have someone do it for you. The City Register offices are open weekdays from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M.
 
Calculating the M.C.I.
 
Question: How do Major Capital Improvement increases affect the calculation of regular rent increases? . . . A. C., Manhattan
 
Answer: The M.C.I. increase is not a surcharge but rather a permanent addition to the base rent for both rent-stabilized and -controlled tenants.
According to Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, most leases for rent-stabilized tenants include clauses that permit M.C.I. increases to take effect as soon as they are ordered by the agency. In leases where this clause does not exist, the landlord must wait until the lease is renewed or a new lease is written to make this adjustment. Moreover, landlords of rent-stabilized tenants are allowed to collect M.C.I. increases retroactive to the date their applications for the increases were filed.
For rent-controlled tenants, M.C.I. increases become effective on the first rent payment date after the order is issued. Landlords of this category of tenant are not entitled to retroactive M.C.I. increase payments.
Another provision of the regulations regarding M.C.I. increases says that for rent-stabilized tenants, landlords may not impose an increase of more than 6 percent of the monthly rent in one year. Any allowable increase above the limit would have to be added the following year. Landlords of rent-controlled tenants are limited to annual increases of 15 percent of the monthly rent.
