SECTION: Section 10; Page 15, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1389 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Ladies' Mile;
Some Landmarks Languish as a Precinct Prospers By David W. Dunlap

 BODY:
Until recently, it did not seem too farfetched to imagine the Avenue of the Americas reclaiming some of its Gilded Age vibrancy south of 23d Street, where heroically scaled but long neglected department stores line the street.
Several former emporiums on the avenue, which is part of the Ladies' Mile Historic District, were renovated: the B. Altman Store at No. 625, the Hugh O'Neill Store at No. 655 and the Adams Dry Goods Store at No. 675. An ambitious restoration - accompanied by a 29-story tower - was proposed for the gigantic Siegel Cooper Store at No. 620. And it appeared that an enormous vacant lot at 23d Street would be redeveloped.
Today, however, almost all of the cavernous ground floors where New Yorkers shopped for dry goods at the turn of the century are empty and dark. All that is being offered to buyers - judging from the ''For Rent'' signs in the vast, plate-glass windows - are the spaces themselves. 
No ground-floor tenants have been signed yet for the Altman, Adams, or O'Neill buildings. The Siegel Cooper project is on the shelf indefinitely while the developer waits for market conditions to improve. And although the owner of the 23d Street site is still talking redevelopment, he has taken steps to turn the parcel into a parking lot, in an effort to recoup some of his carrying costs.
Not that all is empty, by any means. Office tenants fill the upper stories of several of the old stores. In fact, the Ladies' Mile area has one of the lowest commercial vacancy rates in Manhattan, according to the Edward S. Gordon Company.
The June vacancy rate was 9.4 percent in this district, which runs along the Avenue of the Americas, Fifth Avenue and Broadway, from 14th to 28th Streets. That is in contrast to 13.7 percent in the Park Avenue South-Madison Square area, 13.8 percent in Chelsea, 15.1 percent in mid-Manhattan, 15.6 percent in TriBeCa, 19.4 percent in SoHo-NoHo and 19.6 percent downtown.
And the director of preservation at the Landmarks Preservation Commission, Alex Herrera, estimates that about 20 applications come in each month - most of which are to renovate or alter storefronts - from owners and tenants in the Ladies' Mile district, which was designated in May 1989. It runs roughly from 15th to 24th Street, Broadway to the Avenue of the Americas.
''The economic times have been bad,'' said Tracie Rozhon, a spokeswoman for the landmarks commission, ''but that area appears to be - although I hate the word - hot.''
If Ladies' Mile has a cynosure, it would be the Flatiron Building, on the triangular block bounded by Broadway, Fifth Avenue and 22d Street. For decades, there was so little call in the area for ground-floor retail space that this building's ''prow'' was given over to an anonymous-looking importing firm.
That space is now being renovated and is to reopen in October as the retail outlet of a men's clothier, C. P. Company, which is based in Bologna. The store will include the angular one-story structure at the very tip of the building, dubbed the ''cow-catcher.'' The architects are Bentley LaRosa Salasky, Design of Manhattan and Cordero Progetti of Italy.
''We're looking to try to restore the building to as close to its early state as possible,'' said Jules Olsheim, who is one of the owners of the fully leased Flatiron Building, as well as the managing agent on behalf of Helmsley-Spear. ''There are some interesting things soon to be happening such as the restoration and cleaning of the exterior, in conjunction with the landmarks commission.''
''Fifth Avenue has turned into the boutique part of the area, almost all the way up to 23d Street, with Matsuda, Armani, Kenneth Cole,'' said C. Bradley Mendelson of Edward S. Gordon. ''On Seventh Avenue, you've got Barney's and the Gap. On Sixth Avenue, nothing seems to have happened.
''Sixth is stuck right in the middle,'' he said. ''You need a destination tenant. It's not what we'd deem a high-traffic area. Traffic needs to be cultivated. If you had a big user who had a big draw, you'd really make that a good, strong shopping area.'' Mr. Mendelson represents No. 625, between 18th and 19th Streets, and No. 675, between 21st and 22d Streets. Both are owned by Israel Taub and neither has a ground-floor tenant.
''To be quite honest, people are asking too much - $50 to $60 a square foot,'' said Jay Caseley of Newmark & Company Real Estate, the primary leasing agent for the old O'Neill store. ''The market is maybe in the high $30's, averaging into the $40's over a 15-year term.'' Mr. Caseley said that a lease has been ''finalized'' - but not signed - for a restaurant on part of the ground floor at 655 Avenue of the Americas, in the ''high $30's''
The O'Neill store, betweeen 20th and 21st Streets, is now known as the Elsevier Science Publishing Building, after its major tenant. Elsevier, which publishes scientific, technical and medical books and journals, moved its 200 employees downtown from the Grand Central Terminal area in December 1988.
''The feedback we've gotten from our employees has been positive about the neighborhood,'' said an Elsevier executive, who requested anonymity. ''It is less congested than midtown. There are interesting little shops to look at, good restaurants that are more reasonably priced than midtown and good space to work in. I think everybody would like to see tenants in the ground-level spaces but I don't think it really upsets anybody that it isn't here yet.''
As for office tenants, a lease is now being negotiated for the second floor at 675 Avenue of the Americas, Mr. Mendelson said, and the rest of the building is occupied by Mattel Toys and the Young & Rubicam advertising agency. At Mr. Taub's other building, where B. Altman did business in the 1870's and 80's, the J. Crew Group, a direct-mail and retail clothing concern, has offices.
North of B. Altman is the former Simpson, Crawford Store, No. 641. Perhaps its best known tenant is the architectural firm of Hellmuth Obata & Kassabaum, which moved to Ladies' Mile from Rockefeller Center in the mid-80's in search of lower rents and high, open loft floors.
On the east side of the avenue, more ambitious projects were envisioned, but only one - the New York Foundling Hospital, at 17th Street - has been realized.
In the late 80's, Tishman Speyer Properties proposed a 38-story midblock tower at the eastern end of the enormous old Siegel Cooper Store, between 18th and 19th Streets, and to restore the building at the same time. The architects were James Stewart Polshek & Partners of Manhattan.
As the project made its way through the review process at the landmarks commission last year, the tower was reduced to 29 stories, but this did little to appease the critics. ''It was way out of scale,'' said Margaret Moore, a leader in the drive to create the Ladies' Mile Historic District. ''And putting a skyscraper on top of a landmark is one of those things that the commission has never approved and - I hope - never will.''
The tower plan was withdrawn before the commission could vote on it. A scheme that would have added two stories to the Siegel Cooper building was approved ''in principle'' by the landmarks commission, Ms. Rozhon said, but nothing has come of that.
''We have great confidence in the building and in the long-term potential of the area,'' said Geoffrey Wharton, a managing director of Tishman Speyer, ''and when market conditions permit, we will initiate a development program.''
Confidence is also expressed by Fraydun Manocherian, who is the founder of the New York Health and Racquet Club and owner of a 40,000-square-foot lot on the east side of the avenue, between 22d and 23d Streets. But he has paved the parcel so that it can be used as a parking lot until the market improves.
''We've had interest from very major department stores, as well as other commercial users,'' Mr. Manocherian said, including a ''major'' hotel operation. He would not identify any of the interested parties. ''But at this particular time, because of the conditions that exist, without a major tenant, we would not go ahead.''
''I am pretty certain that in the decade we've just entered, Sixth Avenue will be all developed'' between Ladies' Mile and mid-Manhattan, Mr. Manocherian said. ''But when will it start? I really can't tell you.''

HEADLINE: Home Market Opening Doors For First-Time Purchasers

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
After years of sitting on the sidelines because of soaring housing costs and high interest rates, first-time home buyers in the New York region are finally getting a break. The relief, say bankers, brokers and the buyers themselves, is in lower prices, cost-cutting incentives offered by both builders and individual sellers and more flexible loan policies of mortgage lenders and insurers.
The National Association of Realtors reports that the median price of existing single-family homes in the metropolitan region has been declining steadily since it peaked at $183,800 in 1988. By the end of the first quarter of this year, the median price had fallen to $174,700. To afford a home at that price, the association has calculated, a family would need an annual income of $58,722. That is still far above the $30,867 median income of households in the region, but the lower prices have brought more families into the market.
Many builders are offering rent-to-buy programs that enable a family with insufficient savings for a conventional down payment to move into new housing and apply part of the rent to a purchase later. Other sellers are cutting their prices for first-time buyers because they are unencumbered by a house they have to sell and can close quickly on a purchase. 
And while mortgage interest rates, now hovering just above 10 percent, are not the relative bargains they were in late 1987 and early 1988, when average rates dipped to about 9.3 percent, neither are buyers stymied by the much higher rates that plagued the housing market in the early 80's.
''Things are easing up for first-time buyers,'' said Nicholas Rizzetta, senior vice president of the East River Savings Bank, which is based in New Rochelle, N.Y. ''We are seeing it in the number of mortgages we are making for this category of borrowers.''
Among those benefiting from the looser climate are Robert and Robyn Hakim, of Hartsdale, N.Y., who want to buy their first home, a two-bedroom apartment they now rent in a building about to be converted into a cooperative. Like many young people, they found that even with two incomes - Mr. Hakim is an accountant and his wife is an office manager - rent was so high that putting money aside for a down payment was all but impossible.
But the Hakims have been given preliminary approval for a mortgage from the East River Savings Bank that will allow them to buy the co-op apartment with no money down.
Even though most mortgages require a down payment of at least 5 percent of the purchase price, the bank can justify the 100 percent loan to the Hakims. First, as ''insiders'' they will pay $81,000 for an apartment expected to be appraised at about $125,000. Their credit rating is good and their monthly mortgage and maintenance payments will be only $105 more than the $975 a month they now are spending on rent.
''Even before you take into consideration the tax deduction of owning, which will be about $10,000 in our case,'' said Mr. Hakim, ''we are in a good position.''
While no lender claims to be making a record number of loans to first-time buyers, some banks and mortgage companies report that since the first of the year those borrowers have made up a higher percentage of all mortgages written.
At East River Savings, 35 percent of the bank's new mortgage business during the second quarter of this year was with first-time buyers. In the last quarter of 1989, the bank was writing only 15 percent of its new mortgages for first-time buyers.
The Dime Savings Bank of New York has seen a similar increase in business with first-time buyers. A survey the bank made last spring that included its own mortgages as well as a random sampling of mortgages by other lenders showed an increase of 20 percent since January.
A large part of the increase can be attributed to a significant decline in the number of other borrowers, including homeowners who want to trade up but cannot sell at a price they find acceptable. Still, many in the industry say there are more opportunities now for those looking to purchase their first homes than there have been in many years.
The East River Savings Bank, for example, will extend 100 percent financing to qualifying inside buyers in co-ops whose conversion plans pass the bank's requirements, and where residents are getting substantial price breaks. The bank has also recently changed its policy to allow up to 3 percent of a borrower's down payment to come from gifts.
East River is also one of several lenders that offer what amounts to a 93 percent mortgage by allowing borrowers to wrap up to 2 points, as well as the first year's mortgage insurance payment, into the loan amount.
Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation, the country's largest private mortgage insurer, has raised its gift-money ceiling to 10 percent of the down payment for qualifying first-time buyers. The gift must come from immediate family members.
James Englehardt, regional director for the Northeast, said this change means that some borrowers would be able to take a 100 percent mortgage. Mortgage Guaranty's gift ceiling previously was 2 percent of the purchase price. Lenders and mortgage insurance companies often limit the amount in a down payment that can come from gifts because they have found that when even a small portion of the equity comes from the borrower's own pocket, default on the loan is less likely.
The underwriting policies of mortgage insurers like Mortgage Guaranty are critical to the cash-poor borrowers, who tend to be those buying homes for the first time. That is because virtually all loans for which the borrower's equity is less than 20 percent of the purchase price must carry public or private mortgage insurance against default. The annual premiums can be as high as 1 percent of the purchase price in the first years.
Dime Savings is developing a mortgage to ease the burden on parents who want to help their children clear the down-payment hurdle. The program, which is still in the planning stage, would allow interest-bearing instruments owned by the parents, like certificates of deposit and savings accounts, to serve as the equity on their children's loans.
Richard D. Parsons, the bank's president, said he hoped that the new program could be crafted in such a way that the parents could make a contribution without ''just turning cash over to the kids.''
Mr. Englehardt of Mortgage Guaranty said his company was also searching for ways to give a boost to the first-time buyer.
''The goal is to get more middle-income people into housing,'' he said, referring to the company's liberalized underwriting policies. ''Of course, we must make sure that the buyer has the resources to keep up once they get their loan. But we are working with lenders, public mortgage agencies and nonprofit housing groups to to make it a little easier for young families to buy homes.''
This flexibility, lenders and mortgage insurers readily acknowledge, is not motivated entirely by altruism. As the number of resales and new construction projects eases off, many lenders see the first-time buyers as a part of the market that can expand the demand for funds for several years to come.
''There is no question that the top end has fallen off,'' said Mr. Parsons, Dime's president, referring to residential loans in the $200,000-to-$400,000 range.
''We are also feeling the impact of the decline in new construction. As far as the future is concerned, I don't see any sign that things will turn around soon. So we have been doing a lot of planning to better serve the first-time buyer.''
This fall, as part of a program intended to draw first-time buyers, Dime will offer a series of free seminars on how to find and pay for a first home.
This increased respect for the money of the first-time buyer is not coming just from the mortgage industry.
''They are seen as valuable customers not only by the banks but by home sellers,'' said Edward Tonero, a broker with the Short Hills, N.J., office of Coldwell Banker, a residential brokerage. ''They aren't burdened with homes they have to sell so they are often in a good bargaining position because if they qualify for a mortgage, they can move fast.''
Robert and Suzanne Young, who recently moved into their new home - a three-bedroom Cape Cod in Madison, N.J. - got a good deal on their house because the relocation company handling the property for the previous owners was eager to make a fast sale.
''The owners paid about $230,000 in 1987,'' said Mr. Young, who works at National Westminister Bank in Manhattan. ''That was the first asking price and it was way out of our range.
''But by the time we saw it the people who lived there had already gone back to England and everybody was in the mood to negotiate. The price came down to $208,000. We could live with that.''
Even though the Hakims of Hartsdale are buying an apartment they already occupy, they are benefiting from Westchester County's softer real estate market. Mr. Hakim believes that the drop in prices there helped his building's tenant negotiators cut the price of shares for inside buyers from $850 to $613. The sponsor of the conversion plan has also agreed to give inside buyers cash payments to cover the cost of renovations.
Some first-time buyers are getting a leg up from Federal and state mortgage programs that were created to serve low- and moderate-income borrowers by providing low interest loans.
In March the State Mortgage Agency of New York, also known as Sonny Mae, made upward adjustments on the income limits and the purchase prices for borrowers in some districts, including the one that covers Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
In those counties, the income limits on Sonny Mae mortgages were increased to $46,000 for households of one or two people and to $64,000 for households of three or more.
Moreover, the ceiling on the purchase price of a single-family home on Long Island was raised to $152,000, from $128,000, for existing residences and to $182,300, from $152,300, for newly constructed homes.
The state mortgage agency is required by law to raise or lower its income and purchase price limits so that it keeps pace with regional fluctuations in the cost of living.
John N. Spano, the agency's vice president and director of single-family housing, said its monthly loan volume had nearly tripled since January. Mr. Spano said the agency was reserving about $1 million worth of home loans in January, while the amount put in reserve in June was $3.437 million.
''Another factor that has influenced the demand for our mortgages,'' said Mr. Spano, ''is the increase in interest rates. Whenever there is a pronounced spread between open market rates and ours, our volume increases.''
The current interest rate for a Sonny Mae mortgage for a 30-year fixed-rate instrument is 8.3 percent. That is about 2 percentage points below the rates for 30-year loans from private lenders, which currently range from 10.1 to 10.71.
Last March, the Federal National Mortgage Association - known as Fannie Mae -introduced a new type of loan which lenders say has been especially popular with first-time buyers. Dubbed the two-step, it is a 30-year loan for which the interest rate charged in the first seven years is lower than it is for the remaining 23 years.
''The two-step mortgage has helped put some of our customers in their homes,'' said Arthur Ciatta, an assistant vice president of East River Savings. ''Even though the break is less than one half of a percentage point, it can make a difference to the buyer on a budget. It lowers the payments in the first years, which are often the toughest for people starting out.''
Earlier this year, the Federal Housing Administration increased allowable purchase prices for homes it finances by nearly 25 percent, from $101,250 to $124,875. That upward adjustment, lenders said, had a considerable impact on buyers in the New York metropolitan area who for the most part had to skip the F.H.A. when shopping for a loan.
But the news was not all good for buyers contemplating an F.H.A. loan. The Government's mortgage insurance program has lost about $350 million in the last several years and is slipping further into debt. Some officials have predicted that without changes in its policies, the F.H.A. could be insolvent within 10 years.
The Senate recently passed legislation intended to shore up the troubled insurance program. It would raise the mortgage insurance premiums for Federal Housing Administration borrowers. The Senate proposal would require all borrowers to pay an upfront premium of 3.8 percent as well as a 0.5 percent risk-based premium for those making down payments of less than 10 percent. The House of Representatives is also considering legislation.
But Norman Lynn, president of the National Association of Realtors, a major trade group based in Washington that represents the residential brokerage community, said the proposed increase in the mortgage insurance premium would have a chilling effect on low- and middle-income buyers.
''Our major objection is that this proposal attacks the market exactly at the wrong place,'' said Mr. Lynn, who predicted that such a change would eventually have an impact on the resale market as well.
His organization supports proposed legislative changes through which the Housing and Urban Development Department would collect a lower one-time upfront fee of 1.35 percent of the loan from the borrower at closing, as well as an annual renewal fee of 0.5 percent, paid on the principal.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: 42d Street Redevelopment;
Picking Up the Pace of Preparing the Site

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
In the life of a longterm development project there are frustrating periods followed by bursts of progress. A condemnation order from a judge in April set off such a burst in the saga of New York City's effort to redevelop 42d Street from Times Square to Eighth Avenue.
The order gave the public title to eight acres of property with 34 parcels occupied by 250 businesses and a few individuals. Since then, closings or relocations have begun in earnest, although an appeal has been filed by the Durst Organization. The relocations are centered in the Times Square area, where new office construction is scheduled to start early next year.
The sight of it all gives the project a new credibility after seven years of controversy, planning and litigation, but also raises the question of its timing. Will the project's four million square feet of new space in four buildings overwhelm the midtown office market? In 14 newly built West Midtown buildings an estimated 5.5 million square feet of space is still unspoken for, and contraction in major industries that use Manhattan office space has gradually pushed up the vacancy rate. 
The project's supporters respond that the benefits of the project go beyond cyclical conditions in employment. They say the project will reclaim blighted 42d Street west of Times Square as the heart of Manhattan's theater and entertainment district and should thereby affect economic activity positively for decades to come.
Nine theaters are to be rejuvenated, and new entertainment uses may emerge on two vacant sites. An independent 42d Street Entertainment Corporation will be named to oversee the renovation of six of the old theaters and the development of the vacant sites.
The Nederlander Organization already has been awarded two other theaters, the Harris and the New Amsterdam.
Still further ahead lies the development of a trade mart and a hotel on the Eighth Avenue side of the site. In the more immediate future is a planned improvement of the Times Square subway station, for which the developers are paying 75 percent of the $100 million cost. The entire redevelopment site is 13 acres.
But in the real estate world it is the impact of the project on the office market that is the arresting question. The developer, a partnership of Park Tower Realty, of which George Klein is the principal, and the Prudential Insurance Company, has the advantage of a tax abatement that permits lower initial rents than builders on private sites could afford.
''It's insane to build subsidized office space when there is a huge oversupply,'' said Douglas Durst, a partner in the Durst Organization, a midtown developer that has long fought the Times Square project. ''It will be the ruination of midtown just as the Port Authority was the ruination of the downtown market.'' The allusion is to the 10 million square feet of space created by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in the World Trade Center in the late 60's. A few major developers opposed the Trade Center at the time as oversized.
But that is probably a minority view, even among developers. The rejuvenation of 42d Street probably will boost the capacity of west midtown generally to draw office tenants, a major planning goal. ''It's not an overwhelming amount of space,'' said Franklin Speyer, a commercial broker with Cushman & Wakefield, Inc. ''And the timing bodes well.'' In the mid-90's, when the new Times Square space is ready for occupancy, few other new buildings will be coming on the market.
The larger question is what will be happening to white-collar employment growth in the 90's. Office leasing has been set back sharply by contraction in financial services and related industries.
Two years ago the real estate research department of Salomon Brothers, the investment firm, published a study forecasting a sluggish demand for office space through 1991. David Shulman, who did the study, said he ''doesn't see a lot of demand'' in the next two or three years. He considers Atlanta a significant competitor with New York for one sector where growth may occur, European-related trade and legal-services firms.
At Landauer Associates, the real estate consulting firm, there is greater cheer in the mid-90's forecast. Mr. Landauer notes that financial-services, insurance-related and real estate-related sectors tend to lose jobs in large numbers and gain them back in large numbers as well.
The current downtrend is a ''correction but not a structural change'' for the economy, Landauer says.
In any event, there are other midtown sites where developers are in a position to produce 13.3 million square feet of new office space, but will probably continue to hold off until demand rebounds.
The midtown market leased out about 18.3 million square feet of top-rated, or Class A, office space in 1989 and is expected to lease out at least that much this year, according to Cushman & Wakefield. By the time the Times Square space is available, nearly all of what is currently available in new buildings should be taken.
The first of the new Times Square buildings should be ready for occupancy in late 1993 or early 1994 and the others will follow rapidly. When two of the four office sites are cleared, the developer is obligated to begin construction within six months. One of the two sites is to be the one called the ''Crossroads'' site between Broadway and Seventh Avenue and 41st and 42d Streets. It is essential for the subway-station improvement, a four-year reconstruction that is due to begin next spring.
In the rebuilt station there will be a new 10,000-square-foot mezzanine level and a large rotunda with an elaborately designed ceiling fixture in a greatly expanded ''free'' zone before the customer pays a fare. It will connect all the office buildings. Instead of the current four tracks for the Grand Central shuttle (only three are used) there will be two, with a large platform between them. The shuttle platform will be extended so that a five-car train can operate. Currently the shuttle is a three-car train. The subway planning has been done as a joint venture of William Nicholas Bodouva & Associates and Vollmer Associates.
Most public attention has focused so far on the proposed design for the new office buildings, by Philip Johnson and John Burgee. Spokesmen for the development partners say that all designs so far have been preliminary. The task is to find a design that is neither stodgy nor glitzy, one that relates to Times Square and its entertainment function and yet appeals to the buildings' corporate users.
But at the Urban Development Corporation, the main immediate concern is relocation.
A large Nathan's restaurant on Broadway at 43d Street has closed. So has the Cineplex Odeon's Warner movie theater on Broadway and 42d Street. First Federal Savings and Loan has given up a retail space in 1457 Broadway, near 41st Street. Kentucky Fried Chicken has shut up shop on 42d Street near Seventh Avenue.
Upstairs the tenants are vacating, too. Thirty occupants have either moved or committed themselves to a move date, said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, the Urban Development Corporation subsidiary that is in charge of site preparation. The agency is also working with 30 more tenants who want to move.
''We have no legal obligation to do more than pay for the fixtures,'' said Rebecca Robertson, the subsidiary's president, ''but we're providing reasonable moving expenses and some relocation assistance.'' The 250 occupants received letters in June saying they would have to be out by Oct. 31.

LENGTH: 1075 words

HEADLINE: Returning Workers Trained for Real Jobs

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
A SIMPLE premise lies behind the Re-entry Program of the Middlesex County Chamber of Commerce: people who have been out of the work force a long time need training that prepares them for available jobs. Since its inception in 1986, the program has trained 400 people, placed more than 90 percent of them in jobs and earned the trust of employers in Middletown and neighboring communities in Middlesex County. ''It has worked,'' said the program's director, Edmund J. Gubbins. The program is geared to, but not restricted to, older workers. This fall, it will be extended to 25 people - most of them on welfare - who live in subsidized housing in Middletown.
Dr. Gubbins, superintendent of schools in East Haddam during the 1970's and later an East Haddam selectman, also developed education programs for Connecticut prisons. He said he got the idea for the re-entry program after an East Haddam widow described to him her need to go back to work. Her skills were out of date, she said, she could not afford training on her own, and she did not qualify for government-paid instruction. 
 
Confidence and Skills
Dr. Gubbins said he figured that others faced similar problems, and he realized that little was available to aid them. He noticed especially that women who had long tended homes and families were often short of confidence as well as skills when they needed to find a job following a divorce or the death of a spouse, he said.
Dr. Gubbins approached the State Labor Department, citing the lack of state programs to help mature people re-enter the work force. He came away with a challenge: if he could develop a program, the state would provide the money for a pilot project.
In cooperation with the Middlesex Chamber of Commerce, Dr. Gubbins set out to arrange ''a marriage of the needs of business with the needs of people coming in,'' he said. He added that he was determined to provide ''training for jobs, not training for the sake of training.''
A study by the Department of Labor showed that Middlesex County's growing businesses needed people with clerical skills. Through Middlesex Community College, Dr. Gubbins set up a program offering courses like word processing, data processing, programming, general office procedures and one to alleviate math anxiety.
The pilot proved successful, and the program - promoted through brochures, the local media and word of mouth - has continued.Participants, who pay nothing for their training, are selected after testing and counseling by Dr. Gubbins and his staff. They take courses at the college or at the chamber office in Middletown, choosing only the courses they need and going at their own pace.
 
Some Young Participants
Most participants are 55 or older, but some younger people - including low-income single parents - have also taken part. The chamber provides space and pays staff salaries, the State Labor Department pays for the training, and Aetna Life and Casualty and Southern New England Telephone have provided grants for equipment and staff support. Dr. Gubbins said that the cost, about $1,200 for each participant, is considerably lower than the cost of programs at private business schools.
The participants receive informal counseling as they progress through the course work. One of the coordinators of the program, Elsie Snell, of Moodus, is also a graduate.
''I'm a model,'' said Mrs. Snell, who is in her 50's. She said that she knows how students feel when they face instructions like, ''Boot up the machine.'' She said: ''I tell them, 'It will come. Take it step by step.' '' Jobs await those who complete their training, because from the beginning many of the Middlesex chamber's approximately 1,400 members have committed themselves to hiring people from the program.
''In the beginning, the employers took a risk,'' said Larry McHugh, president of the chamber. ''But now, they're waiting in line for people.''
 
Loyal and Dependable
The employers agree with Dr. Gubbins that the program has worked. ''It's tremendous,'' said Joan Lee, senior vice president for human resources at the Farmers and Mechanics Bank in Middletown, where several graduates of the program now work. Mrs. Lee called them loyal and dependable.
''They have a good work ethic, and they've adapted very easily,'' she said. ''The re-entry program prepared them.''
Adele Riley, a recruiter for the Employee Benefits Division of Aetna in Middletown, said: ''The program gives people basic skills, and we can expand on that. It saves a corporation like us from training from ground zero. And the chamber is receptive to our needs.''
Graduates also vouch for the program. William Halligan, of Cromwell, 64 years old, said he had been job hunting for months when he learned of the re-entry training.
''I operated a business that fell on hard times,'' said Mr. Halligan, who is a violinist but said he needs more income than he earns from teaching and performing. He studied computers in the re-entry program. ''It's an excellent program,'' he said, noting that it led him to his job in the loan department of Farmers and Mechanics Bank.
Eleanor Waylock was a nurse for decades; now she is widowed and in her 70's. She came to the re-entry program because she sought part-time work that would be less strenuous than nursing and would augment her pension. In addition to the training, she said, she was helped by the support and friendship of teachers and fellow students.
''You need somebody to build up your morale, to say 'You can do it,' '' Mrs. Waylock said. Today she works part time at the office of Rayco Metals in Middletown.
 
'Takes a Lot of Work'
When other chambers express interest in the program, Dr. Gubbins and Mr. McHugh point out that its success is dependent on having employers committed to offering jobs.
''It takes a lot of work,'' Dr. Gubbins said. ''The sweater won't stay together unless you knit it.''
This fall, the re-entry program will offer a similarly designed program of courses - followed by jobs - geared to the needs of 25 people being recruited through tenant organizations in subsidized housing in Middletown. Dr. Gubbins and Mr. McHugh are working with employers and with government agencies to coordinate the project, which they called a way to get people off welfare rolls and into productive, satisfying work.
''It's going to take time,'' said Mr. McHugh. ''But we're going to go in there and attempt it.''

HEADLINE: Tax Increase: Challenges Amid the Furor

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE mounting grass-roots opposition to Gov. Jim Florio's tax package and school aid plan is posing difficult challenges for all sides involved in the intensifying debate.
For Mr. Florio, the growing protest threatens to raise the stakes of his bold gamble to be one of the nation's first governors to repudiate the Reagan economic policies and increase taxes - a risk made painfully clear by a recent poll showing a 19 percent decline in voter approval.
For the state's Democratic legislators, the opposition to the tax plan forces them deep into the cities and towns of their districts to sell the program to angry voters or risk losing the slender majority they now hold in the Legislature.
 
Debate Draws National Scrutiny
And for the organizers of the protest, the hundreds of thousands of signatures and the substantial support they have gathered may have given them a persuasive popular mandate that has no legal force.
Republicans, on the other hand, may be the only beneficiaries of the current uproar, needing only to ride the crest of taxpayer resentment and hope that its momentum can carry them through the 1991 legislative elections. That advantage could evaporate if the Governor's program proves successful. 
The debate is taking place under the scrutiny of Democratic and Republican leaders across the country, as state and Federal officials grapple with the increasing deficits that pose major economic challenges.
Mr. Florio's tax package includes an increase in the income tax rate for the state's wealthiest taxpayers, to 7 percent from 3.5 percent; an increase in the state sales tax to 7 percent from 6 percent and inclusion of previously excluded items like toilet paper in the taxable category, and a school aid program that will gradually shift state funds from the more affluent school districts to the poorest ones.
In addition, administration officials have said that property tax rebates that will be paid to 1.3 million homeowners and 812,000 tenants will make up for income tax increases in all but about 20 percent of the cases.
''We want some say in our government, and we want it now,'' said John L. Budzash, the 36-year-old mail carrier who founded Hands Across New Jersey, the organization behind the tax protest. ''It seems that we've been lost in the shuffle of the politicians in this state.''
The group, organized by Mr. Budzash and six acquaintances only one month ago, has already collected more than 350,000 signatures protesting the tax increase and asking for the right to recall Mr. Florio from office. Mr. Budzash hopes to have one million signatures by the end of the summer.
In addition, the group's efforts are being indirectly enhanced by grumbling from other statewide organizations unhappy with the Governor's tax package.
The New Jersey state legislative committee of the American Association of Retired Persons, for example, which represents a majority of the state's 1.1 million elderly people, has said that thousands of retired low- and moderate-income homeowners living on fixed incomes might have to sell their homes because of increased property taxes resulting from the Governor's school aid formula.
 
Opposition on Teachers' Pension Shift
The New Jersey Education Association, the state's 134,000-member school employee union, vehemently opposed Mr. Florio's shifting of teachers' pension benefits from the state to local school districts, saying that local property taxes will ultimately have to be raised to cover the increasing cost of those benefits.
And the United Taxpayers of New Jersey, a coalition of more than 200 taxpayer groups across the state, now plans to step up its 15-year-old campaign to amend the State Constitution to allow referendum and recall, which is the right to remove an elected official from office by a public vote. That demand is also contained in the Hands Across New Jersey petition.
But most importantly, political scientists say, is the endorsement of the Coalition of New Jersey Sportsmen, its 624,000 members still smarting from Mr. Florio's recent ban on assault rifles. The coalition has pledged its support and lobbying experience to Hands Across New Jersey.
''It's a distinct possibility,'' said George Sternlieb, a professor emeritus at Rutgers University and founder of its Center for Urban Policy Research, that the antitax forces now at work could maintain their momentum long enough to ''dynamite every Democrat in the legislative elections next year.''
In November 1991, every state legislator must stand for re-election. The Republicans, who are now in the minority, need only take three seats in the Senate and four in the Assembly to gain parity with the Democrats.
 
A Sense of Betrayal
Ordinarily, Mr. Sternlieb said, a tax increase so early in a legislative term might be forgotten by election time. But the depth of the current antitax sentiment, he said, combined with residents' sense of betrayal, could serve to maintain voter animosity through the 1991 elections.
And voters' memories are certain to be enhanced, he said, by the involvement of the Coalition of New Jersey Sportsmen.
''Those guys know how to do business,'' Mr. Sternlieb said. ''They know how to reach people; they know how to do direct mail.''
That, combined with the thousands of names and addresses that Hands Across New Jersey is daily pumping into its computers, he said, assures the alliance a prominent voice in the 1991 elections.
Mr. Florio, Mr. Sternlieb said, has a problem, but that is less a problem of substance than one of perception. The Governor's program, he said, is basically sound, but the payoff lies 5 to 10 years in the future.
 
'Promising Future Wonders'
''The Governor's problem is that he's promising future wonders at the cost of present pain,'' Mr. Sternlieb said. ''The electorate isn't used to that.''
State Senator Gabriel M. Ambrosio, Democrat of Lyndhurst, said the most difficult aspect of explaining the tax package to residents was not the complexity of the plan itself, but cutting through the amount of attention from news organizations that the protest group has aroused.
''The press is only telling half the story,'' he said. ''It's only telling the bad news half. But the good news half is that over 80 percent of the people in this state are not going to pay more taxes.'' Any income tax increase paid, he said, will ultimately be returned as property tax relief.
But if that is the message Mr. Florio has to get across to voters, it seems that he is going to have to work a little harder.
 
Poll Finds Dissatisfaction
A recent poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, commissioned by The Star-Ledger of Newark, found that 80 percent of the New Jersey residents surveyed were dissatisfied with Mr. Florio's tax program. And only 23 percent believed that he was doing a ''good'' or ''excellent'' job as Governor - 19 percent fewer than in a similar poll taken in March. The poll had a sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
But Mr. Florio has said he plans to wage a campaign of his own to bring his case to public. ''They say there's a tax revolt in New Jersey,'' he said recently. ''Well, there is - and I'm leading it.''
If Mr. Florio's tax plan works, Mr. Sternlieb said, ''he's going to look like a million bucks going into the 1991 elections.''
Mr. Sternlieb added that since Mr. Florio ''has basically exaggerated the size of the deficit,'' he would probably be able to cut taxes in 1992.
 
Immediate Repeal Sought
But organizers of Hands Across New Jersey would rather not wait until 1992 to find out. Their petition includes demands for the immediate repeal of the tax increase, an independent audit of the state's current financial condition, a rollback of ''unreasonable'' salary increases and the right to recall Mr. Florio.
But despite the vast number of supporters the group has attracted, and notwithstanding the other statewide organizations that are protesting the tax package, residents will most likely have to wait to vent their frustration in the voting booth. Even if Hands Across New Jersey meets its goal of one million signatures, political experts say, the petition has no binding effect.
''It doesn't mean a thing,'' Mr. Sternlieb said. ''It has no legal standing.''
The reason, he said, is that the State Constitution does not provide for initiative and referendum, the process whereby voters can place specific questions or issues on the ballot by petition.
Approximately half the states have such a provision in their state statutes or constitutions. The most commonly cited example of initiative and referendum is California's Proposition 13, in which a successful 1978 voter initiative limited increases in property taxes.
 
Bill Died in State Senate
Last year, the New Jersey Assembly passed an initiative and referendum bill that would have required an amendment to the Constitution, but that bill later died in the State Senate.
And though some Republican lawmakers have resurrected the possibility of initiative and referendum in light of the Hands Across New Jersey drive, most political experts believe that such a measure could be passed only by the majority party. And the majority party, they say, typically has the most to lose by allowing initiative and referendum.
''You can ask a politician to do anything but commit political suicide,'' Mr. Sternlieb said.
Gerald M. Pomper, professor of political science at the Eagleton Institute, said initiative and referendum might not be as beneficial as imagined.
''We have a representative form of government with a process that allows for negotiation,'' he said. ''Initiative and referendum may be good in some cases, but the trouble is that they're just yes or no propositions.'' As a result, he said, questions placed on the ballot by public acclamation might result in simplistic solutions to difficult problems.
But residents, he said, can and do influence their elected officials even without resorting to the ballot box. In 1935, for example, a sales tax that had been adopted by the Legislature was repealed four months later as the result of protests by taxpayers.
 
Freeholders Acting
Indeed, officials in several New Jersey counties with Republican majorities on their Freeholder boards are giving their electorate the opportunity to send a message to legislators a year before the 1991 elections.
In Bergen, Passaic, Morris and Sussex Counties, and perhaps others, voters will be allowed in this November's election to vote on a nonbinding referendum ''decrying the disastrous effects of Governor Florio's tax package,'' in the words of the referendum measure.
Although the vote, like the petition, has no legal consequence, it is intended to ''send a message loud and clear'' to the Governor, said Charles J. O'Dowd, chairman of the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders.
''Some people feel that it's an act of futility,'' he said. ''But if there is one thing that even a governor understands, it's votes. And that's the exact purpose of it - to send a message in votes.''
Susan Vetere, a Clark Township resident who recently signed the Hands Across New Jersey petition, is also hopeful of getting her message across to Trenton.
''It's sort of like bailing out the seashore,'' she said. ''But I just feel in my heart of hearts that they have to hear us; somebody down there has to hear us and they have to do something.''

LENGTH: 1104 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
''Herein lies the tragedy of all the age: not that men are poor - all men know something of poverty; not that men are wicked - who is good? Not that men are ignorant - what is truth? Nay, but that men know so little of men.'' - W. E. B. DuBois.
IT is just after 7 on a muggy summer's night. Instead of playing ball, watching television or hanging around careless about time, nine young men and women from hard cities around New Jersey are inside a suburban dorm room discussing how men can know more than just a little of men. 
They are told by their teacher that in order to have a relationship of value, you must first know yourself.
''You cannot hide from yourself,'' she tells them. ''You have to be open.''
The nine students in the room are members of minorities who have been selected for an unusual project called the W. E. B. DuBois Scholars Program at William Paterson College. In the three years since it began, the program has garnered high praise for its unusual approach and farsighted commitment.
''Given the national need for a mosaic of thinkers, scientists and artists, they are attempting to not waste any human resources,'' said Dr. William M. Phillips Jr., a professor emeritus of sociology at Rutgers University, who has watched the DuBois program since its inception.
This year, 47 African-American and Hispanic-American high school students with good grad a and bright futures from public and private schools around the state are spending five weeks at the college furthering their academic skills and learning how to be leaders.
The purpose of the program is simple, though in some ways it flies in the face of common wisdom. For what the DuBois program aims to do is solve some of society's intractable problems of poverty, urban decay and disintegrating families, not by attacking the problem but by strengthening the solution.
What this means, for instance, is that instead of working to get another drug-treatment program established in Jersey City, the program takes a high-achieving student like 16-year-old Derrick James and helps him find the encouragement, self-awareness and confidence to become a leader of his community, raising up an example others can follow.
''At this age I can be very influential in solving the problems in Jersey City,'' said Mr. James, his level, serious tone belying his age. ''Being knowledgeable helps you to talk to other people.'' Mr. James is completing his second summer as a DuBois scholar. In order to have been invited back, he had to improve his grades (now mostly A's and a few B's) and get involved in a community project at home.
To meet that requirement, Mr. James revived a peer leadership group at his school, Synder High, one of the toughest of Jersey City's tough schools. In the group, he helped relay to others what he had learned about himself and about being black. The effort culminated in a Pride Day at the school, with an address by the Mayor of Jersey City and a parade.
Such activities carry special weight on the hopeless streets of Jersey City's Greenville section, where Mr. James lives with his mother, a single parent. There, he said, pride is hard to find.
Mr. James's experience underscores the most important parts of the DuBois program: self-esteem, leadership and a sense of duty.
''Even if I did someday move out of Jersey City, I wouldn't completely forget about it,'' said Mr. James, who plans to own his own business, preferably in the field of communications. ''One of my goals in life is to make something of myself and then give back something to my community.''
The lesson here is one that has been applied, successfully, to urban problems of a different sort. When developers move into a shattered city, they generally start not by rebuilding an old tenement in the worst, most devastated slum, only to watch it become engulfed once more by the tide of decay. Rather, they seek out the strongest part of the weakened community, the area that with help can be made whole enough to stabilize and, in time, spread its healing into the rest of the community.
This, explained Dr. Sherle L. Boone, director and founder of the DuBois Scholars program, is essentially the philosophy of W. E. B. DuBois, the noted black historian, scholar and author. Dr. Boone, a professor of psychology at William Paterson, said he started the program because he felt that society had forgotten how to heal itself.
''We have tended to look at addressing problems by going to those who are victims,'' he said. ''Doing that, we've largely ignored those who ought to be the solvers of the problems.''
During the five weeks of the institute, the DuBois students live on the Paterson campus in Wayne and go through a rigorous schedule of advanced courses in psychology, calculus, economics and African history. They read DuBois. They write a thesis. After dinner each night they attend self-esteem workshops intended to help them discover who they are at the time in their lives when the answer might seem most confused.
Since the program is only three years old, and the first participants are just entering colleges like Cornell, Georgetown and Purdue, it is too early to measure how effectively the DuBois scholars have been instilled with the spirit of leadership.
But the blooming of the students' self-esteem is evident. ''In a way I just feel really good about myself,'' said Maribel Bueno, a 16-year-old junior from Paterson. ''I do.''
In their own classrooms, students like Miss Bueno are often the only serious students, and sometimes they feel like aberrations. But in the summer they get to meet dozens of hard-working minority youths. Seeing that, they realize they are not alone.
Miss Bueno and Mr. James are good students, at the top of their classes. Even without the DuBois program they would be doing well. They have the support of encouraging parents, and they have tasted the first bubbles of success.
Mr. Boone said he knew when he started the program that some people would criticize it, calling it elitist because it skips over the disadvantaged in favor of those who already have considerable talent. He sees it differently. ''Our concern here is a very selfish one for African-Americans and Hispanic-Americans,'' he said. ''We want the very best minds. That's the bottom line. It has nothing to do with wealth or privilege.''
One of the DuBois faculty, Douglas Evans, a professor of communications, put it in a different perspective. ''There are Grotons, Deerfield Academies, Exeters,'' he said. ''We, as the black community, have limited access to them. But we do have W. E. B. DuBois.''

HEADLINE: Getting Close to Nature in Montana More Women Gaining Entry To Boardroom

BYLINE:  By ANDREW H. MALCOLM; ANDREW H. MALCOLM is national affairs correspondent of The New York Times. By JOAN M. LANG

 BODY:
ACCORDING to a treasured adage in the American West, Montana is what America was. And nowhere does that natural beauty and spirit better exist than in Glacier National Park, a one-million-acre pocket of purity tucked into the northwest corner hard by Canada. Glacier's awe-inspiring alpine vistas are easy to get to but hard to forget. The severity of its mountain geography and its location, slightly off the usual over-traveled Western park trek, have in a wonderfully quiet way helped preserve Glacier from the hordes of Winnebagos, trailers and over-burdened station wagons that clog the roadways at places like Yellowstone and the Grand Tetons. Because of weather conditions, the upper reaches of the park usually do not open until June and the lower portions in April, but now is the time to plan a visit, since accommodations are limited and reservations often necessary. 
Although Glacier is the 10th most visited of the 50 national parks, few of its 1.8 million visitors would ever know it. Most confine themselves to the park's lone paved highway, the marvelously named Going to the Sun Road, which clings precariously to the high-altitude rockfaces. While Glacier and its surrounding area have a vast array of attractions, both natural and manmade, to satisfy the most varied tastes of any family (even one containing teen-agers), this is not a park for city dwellers who need their nature safely canned and neatly labeled along obvious paths packed sidewalk-hard by the soles of thousands of designer hiking shoes.
Because Glacier is adjacent to Canada's Waterton Lakes National Park, another 203 square miles of pristine landscape, it also has the distinction of being the world's first international peace park. Everything from hiking trails to nature studies are coordinated between the two countries.
The mountains on both sides of the Montana-Alberta border were formed by seabeds being thrust up about 100 million years ago. The park came somewhat later, being formed by Congress just 80 years ago. But nature is obviously still in charge. Glacier is one of the few places where wolves and grizzly bears roam freely. Remote forest fires can burn for weeks, untouched by man, as the woods methodically cleanse themselves of decades of accumulated brush and simultaneously stimulate new life. More than four dozen groaning glaciers live at the higher altitudes, packing this year's snows on top of those from 10,000 years ago and moving their icy masses another inch or two down a mountainside.
Even where man intrudes with a road, nature controls the traffic. The 50-mile-long Going to the Sun Road, which took 12 years of hand picking and blasting to build in the 1920's and 30's, must close each mid-October. In April crews begin the two-month process of removing the 60-foot-deep snowdrifts so that family cars can struggle through by late June, their carburetors coughing and their Instamatics clicking.
If a day is all the traveler can spare, the highway alone is worth a detour for its mountain vistas, its wildlife and its wildflowers, which make up for the short summer by their explosion of vivid colors. The road's grade and the park's vehicular length restrictions (30 feet maximum) largely confine the traffic to vehicles that can handle the arduous climb. For those who don't drive, there are bus excursions in both directions over the highway.
Horseback riding is available, though guides are required. There is fishing everywhere, and private boats are permitted on most park waters. Additionally, there are regular boat excursions on the lakes; especially popular is the $5 hourlong evening cruise from the Lake McDonald Lodge to watch the spectacular mountain sunsets of pink and yellow and deep blue, which this far north and west come well after 10 o'clock on midsummer nights.
But Glacier is a park that invites exploration on foot. There are more than 750 miles of subtly marked trails for short strolls or more demanding two-week sojourns into solitude. In keeping with the spirit of freedom in Montana, which did not have a state speed limit until the mid-1970's, back-country rules are blessedly few and common sensical. No pets. No guns. No vehicles. Register your itinerary with the ranger (for your own safety, not his curiosity). If camping, get the required overnight permit. And watch out for bears. ''Remember,'' one park brochure advises humans, ''you are the visitor.''
WILDLIFE encounters are, in fact, one of Glacier's major attractions - and dangers. Deer, moose, elk, mountain goats, eagles and, rarely, gray wolves can be seen, or heard. So, too, can bears, which can be exciting and sometimes fatal. A photographer was killed in Glacier three years ago when a mother bear decided he was too close to her cubs.
Like muggings in urban parks, such events feed fear and inspire caution (make lots of noise when hiking, never store food in a tent, avoid dead animals and don't wear fragrant cosmetics in the woods). If you do encounter a bear, advises one helpful pamphlet, keep calm, look for a tree, watch for aggressive behavior (woofing or chomping of jaws, for instance, is reason for concern) and back away slowly. ''When you are out of sight,'' suggests the booklet, ''retreat more rapidly. At this point, seriously consider abandoning your trip.''
More common than encounters with bears are meetings with marmots, memorable little furry folk who resemble chubby gophers. Few of these brassy creatures know enough to fear humans. So they emerge at any time close by to sit up and utter their distinctive loud whistle, as if hailing a taxi when, in fact, they are requesting a piece of your lunch. Humans are forbidden to feed park wildlife although few marmots are prosecuted for theft of unattended sandwiches.
Adults may be more impressed by rounding a trail corner to come upon a view of a breathtaking drop of several thousand feet and rugged, two-mile-high mountains stretching to the horizon. But simple wildlife encounters seem to be the stuff of significant memories for many youngsters. The pilfering marmot. The curious fawn. The migrating Monarch butterfly that tags along with some hikers for an hour or more. Or the hummingbird that falls in love with a little girl's red shirt, so much so that he hovers by her shoulder while the two worlds peer at each other for a full minute.
Glacier is also home to Granite Park and Sperry Chalets, two hostelries built far from any road. Supplies ride in for six or seven miles on mules or horses; humans hike. Rooms, which are available from July 1 to Labor Day for about $50 a night, are simple, comfortable and private with candles provided for light. All meals are also provided, including sack lunches for individual hikes when hikers are sometimes shadowed by curious, bearded white mountain goats. Reservations within the park are a must months in advance.
For those requiring less austere accommodations, park concessionaires offer more than 700 rooms at several lodges from about June 1 through the first week of September. Prices range from about $20 for two in a one-bedroom cabin without bath at the Swiftcurrent Motor Inn to $116 for a two-room suite at the Many Glacier Motel. Rates for the 81 rooms at the grand old gabled Prince of Wales Hotel in Waterton Park, Alberta, range from $70 for one to $128 for a suite for two. High tea is served every afternoon, British style, overlooking the mountains surrounding Waterton Lake.
Additionally, there are numerous motels of varying size and quality in communities just outside the park like West Glacier, Columbia Falls, Whitefish and Kalispell. With the area's growing popularity, reservations are fast becoming advisable outside the park as well in the summer.
Local highways, namely U.S. 2, provide the usual array of commercial attractions from chain food stops to go-kart tracks, waterslides and whitewater float trips. Secluded dude ranches are also available nearby. But Whitefish is fast developing a reputation for its clothing and gift shops. They are busiest during the Thanksgiving-to-April ski season at the adjacent mammoth Big Mountain Resort, with 45 runs the largest of Montana's rapidly growing ski spots. The chairlift is also open in the summer for rides to the Summit Restaurant, which offers spectacular views. Summer lift tickets are $7, $5 for children.
Although Glacier Park's main through highway is closed by mid-October, the road remains open at lower levels for needle noters, the Rocky Mountain equivalent of New England's leaf peepers - people who wander the roads every autumn admiring the foliage.
Typically, evergreens are just that, because they shed only a fraction of their needles every year. But the mountain larch is a different sort. It sheds all its needles every fall, which helps make a lot of soil for future generations of trees. But before falling, each of the billions of needles turn a variety of brightly colored yellow and red and gold, dotting the vast mountainsides with a last splash of brilliant color before the long white winter.
By late fall the kokanee salmon are spawning in Glacier's rivers and streams. As if by appointment, eagles appear, according to the park's natural rhythm of life and death, closely followed by a few wily tourists with telephoto lenses on their cameras. The tourists sit in their warm cars with the windows open. The majestic birds sit high up in the bare trees, their bright white heads turning sharply, watching for that telltale flash of white that signals that another salmon has spawned and expired and floated to the surface, belly up, to become part of the food cycle.
In April, about the time the crews start trying to clear the park's mountainous highway, the baby salmon emerge from the gravel. Not long afterward they are swiftly swimming downstream beneath the highway bridges, which by then are carrying migrating hordes of tourists back into Glacier National Park.
 
ROAD CONDITIONS, LODGINGS AND SUMMER COURSES ON WOLVES AND BEARS
 
When to Go
The Going to the Sun Road is usually not passable at higher elevations until mid or late June, but lower regions of Glacier National Park are open year round, especially at West Glacier, where 12 miles of the road (to the head of Lake McDonald) are kept plowed to provide access for cross-country skiers. Other roads are allowed to ''snow themselves in,'' said a park ranger, and become usuable as the snow melts. Call park headquarters (406-888-5441) for details on road conditions and other information.
 
Getting There
The park can be reached by flying into Glacier International Airport in Kalispell, Mont., which is served by affiliates of Northwest, Delta, United and Alaska airlines. Amtrak's Empire Builder, which runs between Chicago and Seattle and Portland, Ore., serves the park on a daily schedule.
 
Where to Stay
Accommodations in Glacier Park's Many Glacier Hotel, the Lake McDonald Lodge and the three inns - the Village Inn, the Rising Sun Motor Inn and the Swiftcurrent Motor Inn - are booked well in advance. From October to mid-May, get in touch with Glacier Pak Inc., Greyhound Tower, Station 1210, Phoenix, Ariz. 85077; 602-248-6000; from mid-May to late September, the address is East Glacier Park, Mont. 59434, and the phone number is 406-226-5551. Reservations require one night's deposit in advance.
Reservations for the Sperry and Granite Park Chalets can be made year round through Belton Chalets, Box 188, West Glacier, Mont. 59936. The phone, 406-888-5511, is operational from April to October. Rates for 1989 were $50 a person a night including three meals, $44 for children under 12.
During the summer the phone number for the Prince of Wales Hotel in Waterton Lakes National Park, Alberta, is 403-859-2231. After mid-September reservations are handled through the same numbers as the American park's hotels.

Summer Classes
The Glacier Institute, a division of the Flathead Valley Community College, offers classes of a single day up to a week on various aspects of the park's natural life ranging from the return of wolves, forest fire recovery and alpine wildflowers to glacier life, bear studies, mountain geology and bird watching. Classes begin in June and run into late August. The minimum age is 10. Fees start at $20 for one, $30 for a couple and $8 for each additional family member. For details, write to Glacier Institute at Box 1457A, Kalispell, Mont. 59903. The winter and spring phone is 406-752-5222, Extension 254. From June 15 to Aug. 15: 406-888-5215. - A. H. M.
A SEAT on a board of directors has always been one of the ultimate signs of achievement. Increasingly, the doors to the boardrooms of major corporations and foundations have been swinging open to admit women.
Moreover, the role of women on boards has been changing. In the 1970's, the small number of women who were invited to sit on a board were often asked to do so for the sake of appearance. Well-known and highly visible, these women were active in nonprofit organizations or in government, or they were major shareholders. But over the last decade, as women have entered the corporate world in larger numbers, they have had the opportunity to wield influence on the boards of major corporations.
''It's really the logical progression as a woman moves into top management,'' said Beth Bronner, a senior vice president and general manager of the shop division of the Haagen-Dazs Company in Teaneck and the highest-ranking woman at the ice cream manufacturer and retailer. In addition, for the last two years she has served on the board of MasterMedia Limited, a New York-based publishing company. ''As we progress as individuals,'' she said, ''we need to find new ways of affecting policy, and being on the board is an excellent way to do that.''
Today, women are being selected to fill board seats in much the same way as men: on the basis of expertise. As more organizations begin to expand the strategic role of their boards, more women are being sought for their specific skills and contributions. Yet because women as a whole have not achieved equal representation among the ranks of executives, female board members tend to be younger and at earlier stages in their careers than their male counterparts.
And while an increasing number of companies and foundations are actively seeking women to fill board positions, many people involved in women's issues believe that it will be years before women are fully represented on boards.
''Women have made tremendous professional strides, but it's going to take another 10 to 20 years before they truly attain equality in the workplace,'' said Patricia Harrison, president of the National Women's Economic Alliance, a nonprofit organization formed in 1983 to help women develop more career and economic opportunities.
Women will constitute about two-thirds of new entrants to the work force from 1985 to the year 2000, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. Currently they account for about half of the work force, or about 57 million, and as the workplace becomes more integrated, it is expected that the proportion of women in management will begin to increase at a faster rate.
In 1989, 59 percent of Fortune 1,000 companies had women on their boards, compared with 36 percent in 1979 and just 11 percent in 1973, according to the 1990 Board of Directors study, which is conducted annually by Korn/Ferry International, a New York City-based executive recruitment concern.
According to Directorship, a consulting organization based in Westport, Conn., there are 30 Fortune 1,000 companies with headquarters in New Jersey, and 28 women holding seats on their boards. Several companies, including Merck & Company, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and C.P.C. International, have more than one female director.
Nationwide, Directorship says, women hold 693 board positions, or nearly 7 percent of the 10,199 seats on the 818 public companies on the Fortune 1,000 list.
''There is no doubt that gaining a position on the board is a more efficient route to establishing a power base,'' said Arlene Johnson, the director of work force programs for the Conference Board, a New York City-based global resource organization for corporations. ''It's easier for a company to bring a woman onto its board than it is to integrate its senior management staff. Advancing through the ranks takes a long time, and the cooperation and commitment of all the people involved are essential.''
 
Actively Seeking Women
Today, many companies are actively seeking female board members. Dr. Carolyne K. Davis serves on the boards of four companies, including the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Merck, and says she believes that in every instance their chief executives were making deliberate attempts to bring a woman onto the board.
''They had made up their minds to have a woman director and were vigorously seeking women candidates,'' Dr. Davis said. ''That gave me an added advantage.''
Which is not to say that sex was the only criterion. As head of the Health Care Financing Administration until 1985, Dr. Davis ran the nation's Medicare and Medicaid programs, and today she is national and international health care adviser to Ernst & Young, a Washington-based accounting company with more than 700 clients in the health care field.
Expertise in a field has become a primary means for an invitation onto a board. Zoe Coulson, the first female corporate vice president in the area of consumer marketing at the Campbell Soup Company, was asked to join the board of Rubbermaid Inc. eight years ago on the strength of that experience.
''At the time, Rubbermaid was beginning to see the potential in the marketplace for all kinds of new consumer products, and I was invited to join because of my background in that area,'' she said. ''I've been in marketing since before they even called it marketing.''
Ms. Coulson's position as vice president for consumer issues at Campbell was eliminated this spring during reorganizing.
 
Variations in Experience
Some people involved in women's issues, however, say companies are willing to relax their standards somewhat in order to have a woman as director.
''Companies are looking for directors who have specific functional experience, people who have demonstrated their effectiveness in running a company or large division, but they are also looking for women,'' said Gardner Heidrick, chairman of Heidrick Partners, a Chicago-based national executive search company. ''And not that many women have achieved the status of C.E.O. Most women are still in staff positions, and many companies are willing to accept a lower level of functional responsibility in order to bring a woman onto the board.''
For this reason, Mr. Heidrick said, the typical female board member tends to be both younger and lower on the corporate ladder than her male counterpart.
''It's true: there aren't that many high-level women out there,'' said Marianne Alfano, president of Executive Women of New Jersey, a professional organization that sponsors a biennial Salute to the Policy Makers program to honor women who sit on the boards of corporations and foundations with offices in New Jersey. Proceeds from the awards dinner benefit a scholarship fund that supports women who are pursuing graduate degrees while working full time, or who are returning to school after spending time in the workplace.
 
Serving With Nonprofit Groups
It is considered easier for women - or men, for that matter - to get on the board of a nonprofit organization, and many women are advised to begin their entry into the boardroom by first serving on a nonprofit board.
''The nonprofits are excellent training grounds, and they afford tremendous visibility,'' said Dr. Marilyn Machlowitz, executive director of the Corporate Board Resource of Catalyst, a New York City-based research and advisory organization geared to women in the business world. The mission of the 13-year-old organization is to work with chief executive officers to help place qualified women on boards.
Barbara Roberts, the chairwoman of the directors' resource committee of the Financial Women's Association of New York, an organization dedicated to the professional development of women, said there was a natural progression at work regarding board membership.
''Younger women, women in their 20's and early 30's, can learn how boards function and establish valuable contacts on nonprofit boards,'' she said. ''Later, they can move on to local government boards and then into the boardrooms of public companies.''
Like other groups, the directors' resource committee maintains data banks of qualified female board candidates and makes the information available to chief executive officers.
 
Corporate Transition Eyed
Dr. Brenda Davis is trying to make just such a transition into the corporate boardroom. She currently serves on the board of the Community Foundation of New Jersey, a statewide philanthropic fund, as well as on the board of the State Urban Development Corporation. Now a visiting fellow at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and Internal Affairs at Princeton University, Dr. Davis was for four years Gov. Thomas H. Kean's chief of policy and planning, and her knowledge of state issues covers the areas of health, human services and the environment.
Yet despite these qualifications, she said she felt that her lack of experience in the private sector had so far blocked her in her attempts to gain a seat on a corporate board.
''Perhaps I'm restricted because many companies in the state already have their requisite women on the board, and they want additional women members to be from the ranks of business, not academia or government,'' she said. ''Or perhaps I'm still too young,'' said Dr. Davis, who is 41.
Yvonne Shepard, division manager for new business development in consumer communications services at A.T. & T., was recently named to the board of the $30 million A.T. & T. Foundation, the philanthropic arm of the communications company. She said she was appointed to the board because she is both Puerto Rican and a woman - which makes her a ''two-fer,'' in executive search parlance.
''The company had made a conscious effort to add representation of both Hispanics and women, and I am the only Hispanic woman on the foundation's board,'' Ms. Shepard said. ''I have taken it upon myself to help effect change for minorities and women through the activities of the foundation, and I suspect that that is one of the reasons the foundation asked me to sit on its board. And it is a wonderful place to influence policy - even though it's not the board of A.T. & T. itself.''
 
Special Role as Mentors
Many women who are board directors do indeed see a special role for themselves as mentors and advocates for younger women within the organization and the community at large. Irene Kramer, a practitioner of naturopathic medicine, has served on the board of the First National Bank of Toms River since 1976 - one of the first women in New Jersey to sit on the board of a for-profit organization. During that time, she has worked with a number of women within the bank to help them advance.
''I see that as a very important role for women like me,'' she said. ''Several of my male colleagues have commented to me that they expected it to be strange to sit across the board table from a woman, and then found that not to be the case at all. And I'm delighted by that.''
In addition to providing their management and functional expertise, many women say they feel that they add something ''different'' to the mix simply because they are women.
''C.E.O.'s and board chairmen are realizing that women offer a tremendous pool of untapped talent, one that can make different but highly valuable contributions to an organization,'' Ms. Harrison said. ''Women can bring as much to the board as men can from the point of view of the experience, along with their own unique perspective.
''The real issue over the next decade is going to be how rapidly and how successfully women can move into the ranks of top management. Until that happens, organizations will continue to have to make a conscious attempt to place women on their boards, rather than simply finding the best candidate for the position, male or female.''

CORRECTION-DATE: August 12, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 22 about an increase in the number of women on corporate boards misstated the age of Catalyst, a research and advisory organization for women in the business world. Catalyst is 28 years old; its Corporate Board Resource service, which helps place women on boards, is 13 years old.
