HEADLINE: Some Points On Affordable Housing

 BODY:
The article ''Effort on Affordable Housing Is Falling Short of Goal'' (May 27) provided an excellent update on the status of affordable housing in New Jersey. With due respect to the tireless efforts of many builders, nonprofit organizations, the Council on Affordable Housing and the State Division of Housing Development, I would like to point out the following.
* If the central concern is to increase the supply of affordable housing, attention needs to be focused away from new construction and toward rehabilitation of existing structures. In New Jersey, where many of the older towns and cities have abandoned buildings and neighborhoods, much can be done to turn them into lively places for people. Economic incentives for rehabilitation, technical assistance, streamlining of zoning and building regulations and other actions may accelerate the supply of affordable housing much more rapidly than new construction. 
* For the first-time home buyers, two big obstacles are the ability to qualify for a mortgage and the down payment. Employer assistance as well as innovative financing techniques can certainly help in removing these obstacles.
* While many builders are looking for innovative and efficient methods of building construction, very little has changed in the way the buildings are built today. With the exception of modular building systems used by some of the builders, the building methods remain conventional and costly. Investment in research and experimentation are critical in the building industry.
* Participation of homeowners in some aspects of home design and construction is necessary for developing appropriate forms of housing units as well as for giving the homeowners an opportunity to personalize their homes. The sweat equity in the construction process would reduce costs and improve livability.
* While family living is a key reason for owning a home, the demographic trends suggest newer forms of households or families, like single parents, married couples without children, unmarried couples living together, elderly couples, the single elderly, the disabled and so on. The demographic trends also suggest a change in life style from being home-centered to work-centered. Designs of homes and neighborhoods as well as financing techniques need to respond to these changing trends.
 
BHARAT M. GAMI
 Architect and Planner Assistant Professor
 
School of Architecture
 New Jersey Institute of Technology
 
Newark

HEADLINE: David's Island Impasse Linked to Public Access

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
THE failure of the developers of David's Island in New Rochelle to grant meaningful public access to the exclusive residential community they planned was a major factor in the decision by state officials last week to reject the project.
That impression was underlined by Gail S. Shaffer, New York's Secretary of State, both in an interview and in a 17-page letter she sent to Gordon Marshall, a partner of Xanadu Properties Associates, the developers. The letter was sent after Mr. Marshall sought to nullify her planned rejection by withdrawing Xanadu's pending application a day before the state planned to announce its decision.
 
Plan Is to Be 'Revised and Resubmitted'
Mr. Marshall, in a brief notice released on Monday, said the application would be ''revised and resubmitted as soon as possible'' with ''additional information.'' He provided no details, but an examination of the objections raised by the state indicated that it would be no small matter to provide the changes necessary for certification. 
The proposal includes 1,750 condominiums in four 31-story apartment towers, an 800-slip marina for island residents and a 29,300-square-foot helicopter pad extending into Long Island Sound. In addition there would be a 3,465-foot-long private bridge - 10 feet longer than the Brooklyn Bridge - that would span New Rochelle Harbor, part of Glen Island and two navigational channels.
This was a revision of Xanadu's original offering, which included one 50-story and two 35-story residential towers. The first version also included a crescent-shaped beach on the island's eastern shore for island residents but no beach access for nonresidents. Since then, as the official state report puts it, ''The applicant has offered a tiny public esplanade adjacent to parking garages and the island's sewage-treatment plant.''
 
A Search for Meaningful Concessions
The withdrawal of the application, just before it was to have been turned down, was the second such action by Mr. Marshall in three years. In August 1987, also facing rejection by Albany, he pulled back the original plan to make changes. But these changes were called ''minimal'' by Ms. Shaffer.
The project, which was approved by New Rochelle in April and by the city's Office of Development in June, would provide an estimated $28 million in property taxes each year, half to the school district and the other half divided almost evenly between the city and the county, according to the plan's sponsors.
This has encouraged the support of city officials and many residents, who have seen virtually no increase in the assessed value of property in New Rochelle over the last decade. During that period, the school budget doubled and the city budget rose by nearly 40 percent.
The developers have said the island's projected 3,700 residents would pay 30 percent of the city's tax bill. In addition, the sale of condominiums would generate $100 million in state sales taxes.
That first withdrawal of the project's application was followed by meetings between the developer and Ms. Shaffer's office ''but throughout the process there has been no willingness on the developer's part to make any meaningful concessions to public access and to other concerns we have raised,'' Ms. Shaffer said.
''In withdrawing it this time, he said our reasons for rejecting the application were 'vague,' '' Ms. Shaffer said. ''Since that's how he felt, I thought it was incumbent upon us to clarify to him what was wrong.'' The 17-page letter, she said, ''is what I would have signed if the process had gone forward.''
 
Protecting a 'Finite Resource'
It found many aspects of the plan inconsistent with the State Coastal Management Program, an eight-year-old effort initiated by the United States Congress to regulate use of the nation's coasts. The state's shoreline was described by Ms. Shaffer as a ''finite resource'' that her office was obliged to protect ''by balancing environmental preservation with economic development.''
Her department's ''principal concern,'' she wrote to Mr. Marshall, ''is that the excessive scale, intensity of development and height of the bridge and buildings proposed for David's Island completely precludes the beneficial use of coastal resources'' while diminishing open spaces, impairing scenic beauty and changing ecological systems.
''Cramming four 31-story towers and other multi-story buildings containing 1,750 residential units and an 800-slip marina with its attendant one-third-mile-long breakwater on a small publicly owned island in the already stressed Long Island Sound does not achieve these objectives,'' she said, referring to the need to maintain coastal resources. ''It makes no sense,'' she said.. The coastal waters and underwater lands surrounding the former offshore Army base on David's Island are publicly owned and are now accessible to the general public for recreational boating, fishing and other water-related activities. The Xanadu plan would remove them from public ownership, and a proposed breakwater would prevent further public access. Similarly, the 3,200-foot-long marina covering 40 acres of surface waters also would be reserved for the private use of the future residents.
 
'Public Must Have Access'
Ms. Shaffer's recommendation was simply that ''the general public must have access to all the waters, lands and facilities which the marina and breakwater would occupy.''
The proposed bridge, supported by 14 concrete piers, crosses two navigational channels. At the smaller one, closer to shore, ships would have a clearance of 14 feet vertically and 160 feet between the piers; at the wider channel, those figures would become 65 feet and 250 feet.
The bridge would introduce ''a large visual element,'' the letter to Mr. Marshall stated. Both the bridge and the high-rise apartment towers ''would not be compatible with the scale of existing development in New Rochelle Harbor,'' while traffic generated by the development would similarly ''adversely affect'' the character of the harbor, it said.
Ms. Shaffer was asked if guarding coastal resources meant rejection of all development likely to represent major change. She said it meant establishing a ''framework'' for proposed development and a balanced approach to preservation and development. ''We're not saying no development,'' she said. ''We're saying appropriate development.''
Mr. Marshall declined to comment and city officials were unwilling to speak for publication until they could meet with Ms. Shaffer. But one official said: ''We never heard her object to the bridge before. The height of the buildings, public access, yes. But the bridge, no. We'll have to talk to her about it.''
 
Ferry Service Suggested
Her letter to Mr. Marshall suggested that ''a ferry service should provide access to David's Island.'' But the developers have said that effective use of the island, in terms of the Xanadu plan, could not be achieved through use of a ferry.
This prompted Ms. Shaffer to comment on the exclusivity sought by the developer as a major selling point.
Throughout most of the review of this project, she wrote, ''the applicant has maintained that public access to the island would not be provided because the provision of such access would eliminate the exclusivity of the residential development, and thereby reduce its marketability.''
In the interview she said she had an obligation to ''uphold the public trust.''
''This is a resource for all,'' she said, ''not just for the privileged few, particularly if it is land already in the public domain.'' She drew attention to the changes in access to a public beach on the island.
 
78 Acres From Public Domain
''He proposes taking 78 acres of land out of the public domain and using three-tenths of an acre for a public beach, near the sewage-treatment plant, while restricting its use from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M., and running them over on privately operated jitneys.''
''That's not meaningful access,'' she said. ''Certainly on this issue we are miles apart on our concept of public access.''
Other objections listed by Ms. Shaffer included the helicopter pad, which she said should be relocated on the island rather than extending into the water, and the location of one of the apartment towers, which she said was too close to the water and therefore an intrusion.

HEADLINE: Northeast Notebook: South Portland, Me.;
City to State: Buy It Again

BYLINE: By Lyn Riddle

 BODY:
This city's government wants the state to buy 13.9 acres of oceanfront land with an asking price of $6 million. The catch is that the state recently handed over its title to a developer.
The scenic site, adjacent to a city-owned lighthouse, is the last big tract of mostly undeveloped property along Portland Harbor. The city wants it for a park. But many residents question whether the state should pay such a high price for property it once owned. 
''I'm so mad I could spit,'' wrote Bill Williamson, a columnist for The Portland Press Herald. Mr. Williamson exhorted the state to refuse to pay any more than the developer had invested and accused the state of lacking foresight.
Once the site of a Federal shipbuilding center, the land was given to the state-run Greater Portland Public Development Corporation after World War II. In 1970, the agency, which was charged with stimulating the peacetime economy through development of such parcels, leased the land and a factory on it to General Electric, which wanted to make parts for nuclear power plants there. The company was to pay $3,750 a month for 20 years and at the end of the lease, own the land.
But in 1983, General Electric closed the plant and sold its lease to Al Glickman, a Cape Elizabeth developer, for $2 million. Mr. Glickman gained title in April.
Two years ago, a Boston developer, McCourt Company, built 175 condominiums on adjacent property and took an option on the 13.9 acres. When the Maine real-estate market sputtered last year, the company let its option lapse and Mr. Glickman asked the city if it wanted the land, said City Manager Jerre Bryant.
The city has asked the Land For Maine's Future Board to buy the parcel. The board was established in 1987 to buy land to protect it from development. The board is working on an appraisal of the property and will consider the purchase along with 103 others.
''There is some irony in it but the history of Maine is replete with such transactions,'' said Richard Silkman, the director of the State Planning Office and the chairman of the land board. Jewell Island, for example, 160 acres off the coast of Portland, was sold for $10,240 in the 60's. In 1972, the state bought it for $200,000 and made it a state park.
Because half of Maine is owned by several large paper companies and families that had always allowed public access, many residents believed it unnecessary for the state to own land.
But as development of the land along the coast and surrounding lakes has grown, more residents are encouraging public ownership.

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse; New England;
IN NEW ENGLAND, HARDEST RECESSION IN U.S. TAKES HOLD

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass.

 BODY:
After a decade of spectacular growth built on the pillars of high-technology industries, military contractors and financial services, New England has plunged into recession, the worst of any region in the country.
In an economy that has had the highest per capita income and housing prices in the country, unemployment is rising rapidly in all six states in the area, real estate prices are falling and the growth of wages is slowing.
Five states - Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont - suffered job losses in the last year, the only states to do so, said Sara Johnson, a regional specialist with DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting organization in Lexington, Mass. The other state, Connecticut, had a job growth rate of only 0.1 percent, giving it the seventh-worst record after the other New England states and Michigan.
 
An Important Measure
Job growth is important, Ms. Johnson said, because economists often use that as the best measure of a state's economic performance. It is particularly important because the Federal Government does not calculate output by state, as it does for the nation as a whole with the gross national product. 
''We're suffering a big hangover from the party we threw in the 1980's,'' said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist for the Shawmut National Bank in Boston. ''I call it life in the slow lane.''
Ten years ago, for instance, Pauline Anton eagerly quit her job to take a new position with Wang Laboratories Inc., then emerging in the fast lane as the world's leading maker of word processors and the force behind the revival of Lowell, an old mill town.
''It was a career move, I was looking for security,'' Mrs. Anton said of her decision to leave her job at a smaller electronics company. But facing increased competition and poor business decisions in the last two years, Wang has cut its work force to 21,000 from 31,600, and Mrs. Anton was registering recently to collect unemployment benefits in this city where the first American industrial revolution blossomed in the 19th century.
 
Foreclosures Are Doubling
The situation has become so bad that personal and business bankruptcies in the first six months of this year are about double the level in the first half of 1989 in each New England state, according to the United States Justice Department. Real estate foreclosures in Massachusetts jumped to 3,497 in the first half of this year, against 1,441 in same period in 1989, according to Banker and Tradesman, a weekly trade publication in Boston.
The Land Court in Boston is where many such cases are filed, and The Boston Globe reported its figures as showing 254 residential and commercial foreclosures in 1985 during the boom. The number more than doubled in 1988, to 546, and in 1989 the number more than doubled again, to greater than 1,200.
Throughout New England, states and local communities have begun slashing services as tax revenue has sharply fallen. In Laconia, N.H., for instance, the City Council has eliminated kindergarten, achievement tests and sports and all other extracurricular activities like band and chorus.
 
The Outlook
How Long Will Downturn Last?
The major question is: What kind of a downturn is New England facing? It could be just a normal cyclical correction after one of the greatest periods of regional growth in modern American history.
Or is it a long-term structural contraction, as the industries on which New England's prosperity was built undergo permanent decline? These include high-technology companies like Wang, many of which made the now out-of-fashion minicomputers or word processors; military contractors imperiled by the winding down of the cold war, and financial service companies, which have suffered since the stock market crash of 1987.
Unlike those who expect the problems to last a long time, the optimists say they believe that the worst will happen this year or next year as wages and real estate prices continue to fall, and that then a gradual rebound will occur.
''The down cycle was inevitable after we hit the wall'' with an unemployment rate below 3 percent and wages rising almost 10 percent a year, said Karl E. Case, a professor of economics at Wellesley College. ''We priced ourselves out of the market so businesses just didn't want to invest here. This had nothing to do with high technology or defense.''
At the height of the boom years, in 1987, for example, Boston became the highest-priced housing market in the country. Today, the city has dropped to being the fifth-costliest housing market, with the median price of an existing single-family house at $182,300, according to the National Association of Realtors. But that is still almost double the national median of $95,900.
But other economists see deeper problems. ''This is not just cyclical; it's also structural,'' said Barry Bluestone, a professor of political economy at the University of Massachusetts at Boston.
In his view, the pillars on which the New England economy has been built, like the high-technology and military businesses, are in trouble and may have to shrink. ''There will be a period of painful readjustment,'' he said.
Diane Swonk, an economist with the First National Bank of Chicago who wrote a recent study called ''Regional Winners and Losers,'' predicts that ''New England will be at the bottom of all the regions for growth in the 1990's.''
 
The Advantages
Competitive Edge Will Not Go Away
Most economists agree, however, that even with much slower growth, New England will remain one of the country's most affluent regions. The Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis projects that Connecticut, which ranks first among all states in per capita income, with $18,500 a year, will still be No. 1 in the year 2000. Similarly, Massachusetts, which is fourth, is expected to remain in that position, while New Hampshire, which is seventh, is expected to keep that ranking. The worst drop is expected to occur in Maine, falling to 30th from 28th.
One reason for hope that the economy will rebound, experts say, is that New England will retain its main competitive advantage: the large number of universities that produced the founders of companies like Wang and the Digital Equipment Corporation, the biggest employer in both Massachusetts and New Hampshire. ''Universities are our natural resource, and we were able to mine them when the information age came in the 80's,'' Mr. Bluestone said.
New England has the highest percentage of employees in professional, technical and managerial jobs of any of the eight regions counted by the Commerce Department, said Andrew M. Sum, the director of the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University in Boston.
The economists also stress that the growth of the 1980's in New England was extraordinary, transforming an area where the old economy based on textiles, shoes and leather had been in decline since the 1920's. ''There was a miracle,'' Mr. Sum said.
Each New England state is slightly different, but the six have been tied together by history and geography. In the past decade, Massachusetts - and Boston in particular - were the engine for the region's prosperity, with economic growth radiating north into New Hampshire and Maine, and south into Rhode Island and parts of Connecticut. And it was the ''Massachusetts miracle'' that propelled the state's Governor, Michael S. Dukakis, into the limelight and onto the Democratic ticket as the party's 1988 Presidential nominee.
Mr. Sum noted that in Massachusetts unemployment dropped from a high of more than 12 percent in the mid-1970's to 2.7 percent in 1988, and was consistently the lowest in any major industrial states throughout the decade.
Moreover, per capita income in Massachusetts, which was 4 percent above the national average in 1979, rose to 26 percent more than the national average in 1989, Mr. Sum said.
''It's because the miracle was real that the downturn now is so painful,'' he said.
The seriousness of the regional recession is illustrated by the turnaround in the job situation. Unemployment in Massachusetts, after dropping to 2.7 percent in May 1988, has been steadily climbing, reaching 5.8 percent in June, as against the national average of 5.2 percent, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. This marks the first time in more than a decade that Massachusetts had been above the national average.
 
One City
Lowell Is Mirror For Whole Region
The unraveling of the miracle is underscored by the plight of Lowell, a city of 100,000 people 25 miles northwest of Boston. Lowell was named for Francis Cabot Lowell, a Boston merchant who toured British textile mills in the early 19th century and memorized their design for water-powered machinery that was creating the industrial revolution. Lowell died soon after, but in the 1820's a group of friends acquired this site on a falls in the Merrimack River, dug canals to bring water power around their projected city and built new mills, copying Mr. Lowell's purloined plans.
Lowell was an instant success, and by 1840, it was the largest manufacturing center in America. But as electricity replaced water power and the country sprawled west and south, Lowell began a long decline. Only in the late 1970's, through a combination of smart civic leadership, Federal grants and an infusion of high-technology companies, were Lowell and its old red brick mills rejuvenated. For many, Lowell's rebirth came to symbolize the Massachusetts miracle.
But, like most other computer manufacturers in Massachusetts that made mid-sized machines, Wang misjudged the advent of the smaller personal computer and the work station, which undercut the companies' market.
Wang's ills have spread through Lowell like a virus. In one recent week the city's main department store, a branch of Jordan Marsh, was shuttered, and the five-year-old Lowell Hilton, the centerpiece of a renewed downtown, underwent foreclosure. The hotel had been built beside a new training center for Wang employees and had counted on its business, but was suffering from an occupancy rate of 50 percent, said the Hilton's manager, Stephen E. McCarthy.
Wang's problems have also spread to the many small subcontractors that sprang up here, like Omni Industries Inc., which assembled boards for Wang's word processsors. From 156 employees in 1985, Omni has shriveled to only 9 workers today, said William S. Taupier, its founder.
Mr. Taupier, who also owns a real estate agency in Lowell, said housing prices there are down by 25 percent since they peaked in 1986, and have plummeted 12 percent in just the past year.
In New Hampshire, which was the second fastest-growing state in population east of the Mississippi in the 1980's after Florida, the real estate market is so soft that Nece Caratelli, a health food store manager in the upper-middle-class town of Hampton Falls, has not had one person come to look at her house in the two years it has been for sale.
In Vermont, Walter Gray, a 58-year-old inventory manager, was laid off in December by the General Electric Armament Systems plant in Burlington, which makes high-speed machine guns for aircraft, as it has reduced its work force to 1,000 employees from 2,000 last year. Mr. Gray has not found another job, and like many of the factory's former employees is preparing to move from Vermont.
In Connecticut, the vacancy rate for office buildings in the Hartford area has climbed from 13.4 percent in the second quarter of 1988 to 20.6 percent in the same period for 1989 and now to 25 percent this year, according to the real estate company Coldwell Banker. The current national average is 19.7 percent.
Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with the stock brokerage firm of Tucker Anthony Inc. in Portland, Me., points to other indicators of a regional slowdown. The help-wanted index, for instance, a survey of help-wanted advertisements in newspapers in Hartford, Providence and Boston, published by the Conference Board in New York, has fallen from its high reading of 186 in the second quarter of 1987 to 80 in April.
 
The Future
Region Adds Up Pluses and Minuses
There is more bad news to come. Because New England, particularly Massachusetts and Connecticut, benefited disproportionately from the military buildup in the Reagan years, the region will be harder hit than much of the nation as the Pentagon's budget is cut in the next few years, said Yolanda K. Henderson, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston.
In a study published in June by the Federal Reserve, Ms. Henderson estimated that New England could lose $4.1 billion to $9.6 billion in military funds by 1995, roughly double the national average, and from 57,000 to 134,000 jobs.
The recession, which has led to sharp declines in state tax receipts and caused havoc with state budgets, has resulted in tax increases or budget cuts or both in each state. For example, the largest tax increase in the history of Massachusetts was signed into law last week in an effort to raise more than $1 billion to pay for a deficit in the fiscal year that ended on June 30 and to balance the budget for the current year.
The developments have taken a toll on New England's politicians, with the three Democratic Governors - Mr. Dukakis, William A. O'Neill of Connecticut and Madeleine Kunin of Vermont - deciding not to run again. And while the three Republican Governors in the region are running again, two of them, William DiPrete of Rhode Island and John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, appear to be in trouble, and Judd Greg of New Hampshire faces an unexpectedly tough campaign.
But despite this abundance of difficulties, most economists believe that New England is far from being in as bad shape as Texas was in the late 1980's when the price of oil declined. They estimate that after the regional economy works off some of the high costs of labor and housing, it will resume a period of slower growth sometime in the next few years.
''The real question is how long it will take us to work off the excesses of the 80's,'' said Frederick Breimyer, president of the New England Economic Project, a nonprofit organization that does regional economic analyses.
New England still has several potential advantages, Mr. Breimyer and other economists say. For one thing, it has an older and slower-growing population than most other regions and attracted few new residents even in the boom years, a result partly of its high housing costs and of its climate. But this slowly growing population also means that any improvement in the economy will reduce unemployment faster than in regions with greater population growth.
But there remains the critical question of what will happen after New England returns to a normal slower pattern of development in the next few years, as Mr. Perna put it.
Can New England, drawing on its universities and high-technology resources, develop new industries or revitalize its faltering electronics companies so that it can continue having one of the highest rates of productivity growth?
There are some candidates for new industries: computer software and biotechnology are often mentioned. But Mr. Bluestone is dubious. ''They won't be the white knight,'' he said. They employ too few people and there is too much competition from parts of the country that missed out on the computer manufacturing boom in the 1980's.
More important to Mr. Bluestone is how ''the current pillars are restructured,'' meaning how well the big companies like Digital can develop new products to replace its minicomputers or Pratt and Whitney in Hartford can make the transition from manufacturing military jet engines to engines for civilian airliners.
The evidence on this question so far is mixed.
Still, a number of the economists are optimistic. ''My gut feeling is, if the American economy is going to make it, it will be in technology,'' said Professor Case of Wellesley College. ''And technology is what we do best.''

HEADLINE: Iran's Students Chafe as Islam Puts Imprint on Their Futures

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran

 BODY:
Along Enghelab Street, the tree-lined boulevard that is the Iranian equivalent of Harvard Square, the students who are the future of this country say they cannot predict where the Islamic revolution in Iran will lead them.
''Yes, the revolution has done some good things, but maybe we will need a second revolution, especially in the way we are educated,'' said Leila, a 21-year-old science student at Teheran University, perhaps the most important and prestigious university in Iran.
As she hurried between classes, her black head scarf fluttering in a steamy breeze, Leila asked an American visitor whether college students in his country were forced to wear special restrictive clothing, or were plagued by a shortage of professors, or were barred from even the most innocuous classroom conversation with a student of the opposite sex. Her questions were clearly rhetorical. 
 
A Call for Freedom
''Universities must have freedom,'' said Leila's friend, who gave her name as Maryam. ''This university and this nation must have more freedom.''
As much as any institution in the country, Iran's universities and colleges have been restructured - revolutionized, the Government prefers to say - in the 11 years since the fall of the Shah and the declaration of Islamic law.
The Western-style teaching methods used during the Shah's reign have been abandoned, replaced by the sort of structured tutorials favored by the Islamic clerics who now have an important say in the educational system. As a rule, students say, they must remain silent in class and cannot challenge the arguments of a professor.
Applicants to Iranian universities are now admitted largely on the basis of their knowledge of Islam, and rigorous courses on the history and teachings of Islam are compulsory for all students.
The changes wrought by the Islamic Revolution have been particularly severe for college women, who must now adhere to a strict Islamic dress code that requires them to cover their hair, arms and feet at all times, and who face expulsion if they are caught fraternizing with men, even outside class.
In encounters along Enghelab Street and at a hamburger restaurant near campus called the Iran Mac - the restaurant incorporates a golden arches logo - few students declined to be interviewed by an American reporter.
Although Teheran University has often been used by the Government as the staging point for major anti-American demonstrations, students insisted that they had never stopped liking Americans and that they were delighted at the rare opportunity to speak to one. ''We love American people, although we do not love the American Government,'' is a common refrain.
Despite their willingness to answer questions, most of the students asked that their full names not be used, to prevent trouble with university administrators who, in one undergraduate's words, ''may feel differently about you than we do.''
 
'Better Form of Education'
Iranian students are clearly torn over the changes in the educational system brought about by the 1979 revolution. A number of students, especially those with a strong religious upbringing, said they appreciated the way Islam now permeates their studies.
''What we have now is a better form of education,'' declared Mohammed, a literature major in his early 20's who said he enjoyed the university's strict religious instruction and the opportunity to study with some of Iran's most distinguished Islamic clerics.
''If there are still many troubles with this system, it is because of the long war with Iraq, which robbed us of many resources,'' he said. ''With time, I think the universities can overcome these problems.''
Unlike many of his friends, Mohammed said he preferred the restrictions placed on the life style of students - the prohibition on social contact between men and women, for instance -saying the rules allowed him to focus on his studies.
 
A Shortage of Teachers
But Mohammed expressed the frustration of so many Iranian college students: that Iran's best academics left during the revolution and did not return and that there are now far too few qualified professors.
A 24-year-old theater student compared the university to a gardener who ''has picked out the best flowers - us, the students - but who will not water them.'' She added, ''There are so few teachers that it seems we must teach ourselves.''
Students complain, too, that the talents of their best teachers are diluted by an admissions policy that allows entrance to many students who are, at best, marginally qualified.
By most standards, the universities in Iran are as selective as any in the world, admitting only a tiny fraction of the applicants, after rigorous examinations.
The system grew more selective after the revolution, when Iranian students suddenly found themselves barred from entrance to many colleges and universities overseas, particularly in the United States. In a number of disciplines, students said, fewer than 1 in 10 applicants were offered admission to Teheran University last year.
But for some who apply, there are special privileges in the admissions process. At Government decree, more than a third of the places in the student body are reserved for handicapped veterans of the Iran-Iraq war, family members of the war dead and others who somehow sacrificed for the Islamic revolution.
Many students say the quota is closer to 40 percent, and they complained that the system of preferences had flooded the schools with students who are not prepared for the rigors of a university.
''The system we have now causes many problems,'' said 22-year-old Reza, who was a soldier in the front lines during the Iran-Iraq war but who said he gained entrance to Teheran University under the regular admissions process. ''The teachers cannot teach properly because they must do so much remedial work. We all went to war with Iraq to defend our country, but it does not make sense now to use this same heroism to harm the educational system.''
 
A Poor Outlook for Jobs
Students say that their worries extend far beyond their studies and that they fear a university degree will not insulate them from new troubles when they try to start a career.
The Iranian economy is in disarray, a result of the eight-year war with Iraq and of the sharp drop in recent years in the price of oil, Iran's main export. With rampant inflation and an unemployment rate of more than 25 percent, the jobs open even to the nation's best-trained university graduates may simply not offer a paycheck large enough to cover basic living costs.
Sara, a 23-year-old history student, quietly sipped a cola at the Iran Mac as she speculated on her future.
''I am not from a rich family, and I think I will have to work two jobs to have enough money to buy food and to pay rent for a very small apartment,'' she said, her friends nodding in agreement at what they say is their common plight.
''I love Iran,'' she said solemnly. ''I agreed with many of the ideals of the revolution. But Iran has so many problems that it is now like a third world country. Many of my friends and I think we will have to leave our country just so we can survive.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
C.I.A. Accused of Overestimating Soviet Economy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency, which has prided itself on its knowledge of the inner workings of the Soviet Union, has come under criticism from some lawmakers and economists who say it greatly overestimated the strength of the Soviet economy.
At issue is whether the C.I.A. botched its measurements of Soviet economic growth and industrial production, especially over the last decade, and in so doing led American leaders astray in their strategies.
Critics say the United States military build-up, especially during the Reagan Administration, was rationalized in part by C.I.A. estimates that the Soviet economy was far more powerful than it actually was. The social and economic chaos unleashed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's internal reforms, they say, demonstrates that the system was shakier than the intelligence agency said it was.
C.I.A. officials are clearly nettled by the charges of inaccuracy. ''I just think that is flat-out untrue,'' said a senior C.I.A. official when asked about complaints that measures of the Soviet economy are wrong. 
''We have done extraordinarily good work over the whole decade,'' said the official, interviewed in April. ''If there is anyone in town who can beat us on the basic factors affecting Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union, economically, linguistically, culturally, I don't know who they are.''
 
Assessments Were Gloomy
In fact, the agency's public assessments of the Soviet economy since 1980 have been uniformly gloomy, and its forecasts of political and social fallout from those economic problems appear to have been largely on the mark.
Yet outside experts have persisted in the criticism, in part because they believe that the C.I.A.'s underlying estimates of the size of the economy have been far too rosy, even if the agency's forecasts have been correct.
In an April conference sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative Washington research center, a Soviet economist who is a member of the Council of People's Deputies, Vladimir Tikhonov, said Soviet living standards were ''significantly worse than it seems to our American colleagues'' at the C.I.A.
For its part, the agency says it is wrong to rely solely on gross national product, which reflects neither the scope nor the subtleties of the Soviet economy. A large G.N.P. is not incompatible with poor living conditions, for example, if most of a country's production goes to the military and heavy industry rather than consumer goods, as is the case in the Soviet Union.
The criticism of the C.I.A has been popular among political conservatives who have maintained that the Soviet military takes up a larger portion of a much smaller economy. But the debate acquired a distinct partisan cast last Monday, when Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said the C.I.A. ''may have hugely overestimated the size and the growth of the Soviet economy'' and, as a result, its military threat.
 
'Much Less Impressive Economy'
At a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on the issue, Mr. Moynihan said ''we are up against what has clearly turned out to be a much less impressive economy,'' calling it ''nothing like what they expected it to be, and perhaps we depicted it as being.''
In an opinion-page article in The Washington Post this month, Senator Moynihan suggested that the ''persistently distorted'' view of the Soviet threat may have led the Reagan Administration to spend the nation's fortune in the 1980's to defend against an overrated adversary.
At Senator Moynihan's hearing, a longtime critic of the C.I.A. who is employed by the Defense Intelligence Agency, William Lee, contended that the agency's economists ''considerably overstate'' the Soviet Union's total economic output and at the same time ''greatly understate'' its military spending.
Even the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Michael Jay Boskin, a Stanford University economist, told Senator Moynihan that he believed that the Soviet Union's total annual production of goods and services - its gross national product - was roughly a third less than the C.I.A. estimates. #51 Percent or 35 Percent?
The agency estimates that in 1989 Soviet G.N.P. was roughly 51 percent of the United States G.N.P. of $4.2 trillion. Mr. Boskin and many others place the Soviet Union much lower, at about 35 percent, and one prominent Soviet economist at the American Enterprise Institute seminar, Viktor Belkin, claimed it was less than 28 percent.
To support their lower estimate, the critics cite shockingly poor living conditions in the Soviet Union, new figures on waste and spoilage in industry and farming and new proof of deliberately inflated figures from some Soviet industries, like cotton farming.
Some critics question whether the caliber of the C.I.A.'s economists, who work at lower Government salaries, matches the caliber of those in the private sector. Other suggest that the agency is simply being stubborn, refusing to acknowledge error.
Yet all the parties are debating a figure which they agree is impossible to verify. Most Soviet economic data were state secrets until recently, and economists say even data that are public are unreliable.
 
Outside Reviews Conducted
During the Ford and Reagan Administrations, outside reviews of the C.I.A.'s Soviet economic estimates were conducted by teams of experts assembled by the Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, a monitoring agency of the White House. Both reviews concluded that the agency's methodology was sound and that its conclusions appeared reasonable.
A Bush Administration official who follows the agency's Soviet forecasts conceded that the estimates of Soviet G.N.P. could be off-target, but not by the amounts critics claim. Privately, however, Administration officials argue that the precise G.N.P. figure is unimportant compared with the accuracy of forecasts about the direction and effects of Soviet economic trends.
The C.I.A.'s own public reports to Congress seem to bolster that claim. In 1980, the agency's economists outlined an economy they said was ''losing its momentum while military programs continue to be pursued with vigor and determination.''
The agency added that major changes in Soviet economic priorities were unlikely under Leonid I. Brezhnev, and that it could take ''several years'' after his departure ''before a new leadership has acquired enough power to make hard choices among competing demands.''
 
Assessment in 1982
When Yuri V. Andropov took over in 1982 after Mr. Brezhnev's death, the C.I.A. said Soviet economic performance was ''deteriorating,'' even as its G.N.P. continued to grow. An economic collapse was ''a very remote possibility indeed,'' the agency said then, but Eastern Europe had ''severe economic problems'' of its own.
In a closed hearing in 1984, Robert M. Gates, now the deputy national security adviser to President Bush, said production had picked up slightly under Mr. Andropov's successor, Konstantin U. Chernenko. But he added that the Soviet Union continued to fall further behind the United States in technology and that its economic state in general was worsening.
In 1986, the C.I.A. said that Mr. Chernenko's successor, Mr. Gorbachev, had had a good year, but that he still had ''no viable, integrated plan for modernization'' of the beleaguered economy, and suggested that he ''may decide to put more teeth into his calls for radical reform.'' The agency predicted - incorrectly, it turned out - that the Soviet economy would grow in the next few years by 2 to 3 percent annually, a figure that has proved too optimistic.
But even that pace, the agency said, would not be enough to remedy the Soviet Union's economic woes. Instead, experts wrote, it would lead to ''more severe battles over resource allocation,'' greater reliance on foreign economic ties and a push for further economic reforms.

HEADLINE: Indian Gaming Spreads, Upsetting Some States

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
To the irritation of some state governments, a booming gambling industry operated by Indian tribes is beginning to spread off the reservations.
A growing number of tribes, taking advantage of a law passed more than half a century ago allowing them to acquire land outside their reservations and place it under tribal jurisdiction, are buying or looking for land near urban centers to open casinos and high-stakes bingo parlors.
The Federal Government, which acts as a trustee for the tribes, two years ago granted them the right to operate such gambling operations as a means of raising money for economic development that benefits all members of the tribe. More than 100 legal gaming operations, most on reservations, are already bringing in nearly $500 million a year. 
But a number of governors have expressed concern about the establishment of off-reservation gaming businesses, which are not subject to state law or supervision. The governors say they are worried about their lack of control as well as unfair competition with charitable or state-run gambling activities that are constrained by state or local regulations.
 
Regulations Proposed
Last Wednesday, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. proposed new Federal guidelines governing the acquisition of off-reservation land for gambling operations. They would require the tribes to explore economic alternatives to gambling for use of the land and would also require that a tribe acquire land for gambling only in a state where it has a reservation.
Earlier this year, Mr. Lujan announced the formation of an Indian Gaming Commission to regulate and oversee Indian gambling operations around the country. The creation of the commission reflects ''a very strong concern that we make sure these games do not fall under the influence of an outside criminal element,'' said Stephen A. Gleason, staff assistant to Eddie Brown, the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs. A function of the commission will be to oversee an annual audit of all Indian gambling operations.
After Mr. Lujan announced his guidelines, Gov. George Sinner of North Dakota said he was still opposed to off-reservation gaming operations. ''I don't think that we want islands of gambling or anything else outside the reservations,'' he said.
 
Opposition in Iowa
Paula Dierenfeld, administrative counsel to Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, said in a telephone interview that the state is against a plan by the Mesquakie tribe, which has a reservation in Iowa, from setting up a gaming business outside of the reservation.
''His philosophy at this point is that we have enough gambling opportunities in the state,'' Ms. Dierenfeld said.
Not all states are opposed to off-reservation gambling. Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, for instance, has approved a proposal by the Forest County Potawotomi tribe to establish gaming operations just outside Milwaukee, 200 miles from its reservation. But Governor Thompson's legal counsel, Raymond P. Taffora, said by telephone that the Governor ''is continually concerned about the proliferation of gambling and he is on the record as opposing Atlantic City-Las Vegas type of casino gambling.'' $400 Million From Bingo Indian gaming operations are already big business. According to the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs, bingo alone is expected to bring the tribes more than $400 million this year.
Of the more than 100 legal operations, only two bingo parlors are operating off reservation. Applications for two casinos have been filed, and Mr. Gleason said the Interior Department expects many more tribes to open off-reservation casinos soon.
The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 gave the tribes the right to acquire land and take it into trust, meaning it would be subject to tribal rather than state or local jurisdiction. The passage of the Indian Game Regulatory Act of 1988 provided an incentive to the tribes to acquire lands near population centers to set up their gaming centers.
Indian leaders say that gambling provides a much needed stimulous to tribal economies that are often badly depressed.
The Sycuan Band of the Mission Indian tribe, for example, is expanding its bingo operation on its reservation east of San Diego. Jim Trant, business manager of the band, said by telephone that proceeds from its gambling operations have been used to build a profit-making health clinic and ambulance service, which serve not only Indians but also members of nearby communities. The gambling profits have also been used to build housing for the band and a church, and to open a 24-hour fire-protection service, he said.

HEADLINE: 30 Million Americans Can't Joke Poverty Away

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 6 front-page report that the Bush Administration has abandoned its intentions to develop new programs to combat poverty is a sobering reminder of our less kind and less gentle national commitment. A White House official you quote summed up interagency task force conclusions with the not-so-funny flippancy: ''Keep playing with the same toys. But let's paint them a little shinier.'' It is enough to make one weep with shame for our country. 
Twenty-seven years ago, the President challenged his economic advisers: ''It's intolerable that in our rich country there should be over 30 million Americans living below a very low poverty line. I want to know who these poor people are, why they are poor, and what we must do to get them out of poverty, not just to relieve their poverty.'' John F. Kennedy's challenge became Lyndon B. Johnson's, and a ''war on poverty'' began. Millions were helped out of poverty, but not enough. The ''war'' failed to keep up with new challenges.
Today, tragically, there are again more than 30 million Americans below the poverty line - with disproportionate numbers of children and minorities among them. It is incumbent upon today's President to ask the questions asked by Kennedy. The answers will be somewhat different, but the questions are the same: Who are the poor? Why are they poor? What can we do to get them out of poverty? As one who tried to answer such questions in the 60's, I know there are no easy or sure answers. But it is intolerable to be told that there are no answers. Whatever happened to the dramatic call for a new war on poverty issued by Jack Kemp when he was sworn in as Housing and Urban Development Secretary?
I urge President Bush to refuse to take ''no'' for an answer. If his aides cannot make intelligent proposals for wiping out illiteracy, bringing better health care to the poor, improving education and training for the underclass and for the whole range of identifiable obstacles to escaping from poverty, let him get more imaginative aides.
 
HYMAN BOOKBINDER
Washington, July 9, 1990
 The writer served as executive officer of the President's task force on poverty in 1964.

HEADLINE: 30 Million Americans Can't Joke Poverty Away;
The Fun of Being Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Things I find fun to think about:
My kids when they are agreeable; my cats when they are off the dining-room table; the Mets when they are on a streak.
Things I do not find fun to think about:
Women, often with children, coming into my court with no money to pay the rent and facing the loss of their homes; men, women and children begging for money in the subways and showing clear signs of great physical and mental stress; citizens living on the streets, and often falling there and dying, especially when it is cold and wet. 
But your July 6 front-page report on the White House's decision not to expand antipoverty programs quotes an Administration official as saying, ''It was fun to think about these things.'' The reference is to efforts by members of the Domestic Policy Council to come up with plans to combat poverty. The Administration decided the ''cash wasn't there'' and concluded that nothing would be done.
This kind of ''fun'' thinking is, to me, characteristic of the callous and often cruel approach that our Government has taken toward the need of the 32 million or more people who suffer and barely survive in America today.
 
ALICE SCHLESINGER
New York, July 7, 1990
 The writer is a judge of the Civil Court of New York City.

HEADLINE: Florio Faces Growing Anti-Tax Storm in New Jersey

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 21

 BODY:
Barely six months after taking office, Gov. Jim Florio is confronted with a growing tax revolt that is fast turning into a general wave of discontent threatening his dominance of the machinery of government in New Jersey.
A central source of anger is a feeling that the Governor lied when he told voters in his campaign that no new taxes were likely and then promptly rammed through the biggest increase in the state's history - $2.8 billion. That sum, an economics consulting concern concluded in a study released on Thursday, ''is the largest single tax increase in the history of the finances of the 50 states, and will become a national test case on both political and economic grounds.''
One goal of the developing protest is to wrest control of the legislative process from the Governor and Legislature by establishing a system for recalling officeholders and overturning legislation by referendum.
 
Protest Stuns Some
For a decade, Republicans have urged an initiative like those in 23 other states, including California, where voters recently approved a tax increase. 
No one can say whether that goal will be achieved, but among politicians and academics who follow government, even skeptics admit they are stunned by the scope of the protest and the depth of its anger. Members of the Florio administration concede that those who seem the angriest are the very people the Governor says he is trying to help the most with his ambitious plans to change the way New Jersey taxes residents and spends money: the frustrated, homeowning, tax-battered middle class.
Yet the administration's response so far has been to largely ignore the protest, maintaining that it will peter out as the benefits of Mr. Florio's tax revisions, which now exist only on the charts of his number-crunchers, turn into things like property-tax rebate checks, lower auto insurance rates and a school financing formula that will give more money to 85 percent of the state's schoolchildren and less to only 15 percent in the wealthier districts. But protest leaders say that it is too little too late, that Mr. Florio is not to be trusted, and that no less than fundamental change of the system to give more power to the people will satisfy them.
Few outside the protest agree, but there is concern even among Florio supporters.
''This thing does have enormous momentum,'' said a leading Democratic strategist with ties to the Governor and who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''And I think that one of the things that those of us in the party and in his administration must do is think about a game plan - and unfortunately I have to say I'm not sure there is one at this point.''The Governor's popularity has plummeted in polls after a landslide victory in November.
There is anger over taxes, but there is a more amorphous discontent as well: a feeling that the dream is dying in New Jersey and no one is doing anything about it.
''I tell people that my name is Pat and I'm mad as hell and I'm going to do something about it,'' said Pat Ralston, a Belmont grandmother who helped begin the rebellion with a furious phone call to a Trenton radio talk show a month ago.
She quickly linked up with another irate caller, John Budzash, a 39-year-old mail carrier from Howell. They formed a fledgling protest group they called Hands Across New Jersey, held a rally on July 1 in Trenton that drew 6,000 to 8,000 supporters, and began circulating petitions they say drew 350,000 signatures before they stopped counting a week ago to concentrate solely on circulating and collecting new petitions.
 
Democrat Would Allow Recall
With growing support, they say their goal is a million signatures by Aug. 1. Mr. Budzash promises that ''we're going to hand them right to the Governor.''
The petitions have no weight other than popular pressure - the group's goal is to obtain binding referendums and a recall mechanism - but some Democrats admit that they are beginning to worry and that there is some evidence that the Governor's support in the party could wane if pressures increase.
One Democratic legislator, Assemblyman Thomas P. Foy of Burlington County, declared this week that he supported a provision to allow recall of legislators by popular vote.
His declaration came on a New Jersey talk radio station in Trenton that has become the clearinghouse for complaints and information about the protest movement. The Trentonian, a daily Trenton newspaper, has also become something of an ally of the protest, printing telephone numbers of organizers and running banner accounts of such legislative peccadillos as Assembly Speaker Joseph V. Doria Jr.'s ''personal gift'' of gold badges to Assembly members - a $7,250 gift that Mr. Doria billed to the taxpayers, repaying the money with campaign funds five months later only after the purchase was made public.
 
Toilet Paper a Tax Symbol
Although not of great consequence as legislative expenditures go in a state with a $12 billion budget, the matter rankled many - as did relatively minor aspects of the tax increase.
Protesters at the July 1 rally in Trenton, for example, draped the grounds with toilet tissue as a symbol of their anger not only at the increase in the state sales tax to 7 cents from 6 cents, but also at the broadening of the new tax to apply to paper products and detergent.
But the tax increase was by no means irksome only to household shoppers. Polyconomics, Inc., an economics consulting concern in Morristown that advises 120 corporate clients around the world on economic trends, released a study on Thursday maintaining that New Jersey residents, with the increases, ''will now pay the highest combination of state and local taxes in the nation,'' an average of $8.64 out of every $100.
Moreover, the report warned that increases in state and local taxes around the country threatened to tip the national economy into recession.
 
General Feeling of Discontent
David Goldman, the economist who wrote the study, predicted that with no offsetting relief from Washington, the increase would throw the state into ''a severe regional recession with growth 3 percent below what it otherwise would be.'' State tax receipts, because of the downturn, could actually decline by 5 percent to 10 percent, office relocation could stagnate and middle-range property values could decline as a result, he said.
But what is really intensifying the protest is not taxes alone, but a general feeling of discontent and anger.
''There are really so many things that made me mad,'' said Mr. Budzash, the co-founder of the revolt, which in a very real way is not simply a tax protest but a protest against government itself - its perceived excess, unresponsiveness and even arrogance.
''I was really incensed that my mother all of a sudden had to take a $3 salary cut, from $9 to $6, and she's 65 and ready to retire and her retirement benefits are based on her last salary scale,'' said Mr. Budzash, adding that her mother's employer had been in financial difficulty. ''I know other people who have to take salary cuts and with the economy in the state as bad as it is and our so-called deficit and fiscal problems, the Assembly gets a raise.''
 
Florio 'the Lightning Rod'
The raise was actually voted in the administration of Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who left a $1 billion to $2 billion deficit.
Supporters of Mr. Florio say the economic downturn started in New Jersey well before he took office, auto insurance rates have been crazy for years, and it was the courts, not Mr. Florio, that ordered the state to put more money in its poorer schools.
But politically, that does not matter. It is Mr. Florio who will take the heat. ''He's becoming the lightning rod for everything,'' said Janice Ballou, director of the New Jersey poll conducted jointly by The Star-Ledger of Newark and the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. The poll recently found that only 23 percent of state residents gave the Governor a favorable job rating.
''As soon as you get a negative image, everything is clouded by that perception,'' she said.
 
New Jerseyans Less Happy
Governor Florio exists in a world that in large measure he did not create. And it is an increasingly restive world. People were unhappy before he moved into the Governor's office. The Eagleton Institute found in other surveys that New Jerseyans are - suddenly - not as happy with where they live.
In 1984, 80 percent of residents said New Jersey was a good to excellent place to live; about the same percentage said the same thing as late as 1988. But this month, that figure dropped to 59 percent.
The state is crowded, housing expensive, freeways jammed, taxes soaring and discontent rising, residents told pollers.
 
Property Taxes Outpace Rebate
''My taxes were $2,000 and then they were $2,519 and now they are $4,003,'' said Mr. Budzash, of Howell. ''But I get a $50 veterans discount. Whoopee. I get the $500 property tax rebate, but my taxes are up a thousand. The guy across the street really got it; he went from $3,000 to $6,000.''
Mr. Budzash continued, ''The people Florio claims he's helping, he's hurting what he says is the middle class. I'm on the low end of it, about $30,000.''
But those on the high end also complain that the combined income for a couple might be $70,000, but that means day-care bills of $5,000 to $10,000 a year, two cars, with two car payments and $2,000 in auto insurance, parking and all the rest.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 Congress is considering ways to assess foreign ownership and its impact on the economy, mirroring concern about the rise in foreign investment in the United States in the last decade. [D1.]
 
American companies are rushing to issue new shares with an eagerness not seen since before the October 1987 stock market crash. The market's climb to new highs and a more conservative approach to finances have spurred equity offerings. [Page D1.] 
 
Nonmilitary uses for the jobs, skills and technology long supported by the Pentagon are being sought. But military contractors have not had much success in their past attempts to convert to civilian production. [D1.] The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee will urge that production of the B-2 bomber be ended. [A11.]
 
New England's economy is in the worst shape of any region's after a decade of growth built on technology. Unemployment is rising rapidly and real estate prices are falling. [A1.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
The trade talks that begin today in Geneva will take up agricultural subsidies, one of the main issues facing the nations in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. A compromise proposal was drafted by a Dutch civil servant who was not widely known until the Houston economic summit meeting earlier this month. [D1.]
 
Many companies are turning to consultants in East Germany to help evaluate the potential of the unified German market and find joint-venture partners. [D1.]
 
The victims of the Bhopal gas leak are finally receiving relief payments, nearly six years after the deadly industrial accident. But the distribution of assistance is so uneven that more than 400,000 people have still received nothing. [A2.]
 
Paribas, the venerable French financial house, is planning to move more deeply into the American markets. [D3.]
 
Iran's economy was dealt a devasting blow by the earthquake in June, just when it seemed incapable of withstanding more difficulty. [D3.]
 
THE MEDIA BUSINESS
 
A revolution in the craft of type design has transformed the look of everything from billboards to business letters and packaging to magazines. With personal computers and laser printers, hundreds of designers have invented scores of new typefaces and revived unused classics. [D1.]
 
A new magazine, Eating Well, will be aimed at people with a sophisticated taste in food and a serious interest in health. [D6.]
 
Brandon Tartikoff wants NBC to alter the entire concept of a television network. As head of a new entity, the NBC Entertainment Group, he hopes to create an organization that resembles a large Hollywood studio. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
 
A growing number of editors are having their names appear on their books' spines. They will acquire and edit their own books while the publishing companies manufacture and market them. [D6.]
 
Two ad agencies in Los Angeles have adopted sharply different strategies for expanding in the fiercely competitive market where too many agencies are chasing too few clients. Advertising. [D7.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS

HEADLINE: East German Consultants Forging Links With West

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN

 BODY:
The words management, marketing and consultant were not in the East German dictionary during four decades of Communism. Now, from lexicographic oblivion, Heino Ackert and Michael Jarowinsky have emerged as two of East Germany's first private management and marketing consultants.
Their rise comes as many companies are turning to consultants for help in evaluating the potential of the unified German market and in finding joint-venture partners. And a number of West German and American consulting groups are rushing to build networks of contacts and a base of information on East Germany. 
Price Waterhouse G.m.b.H., for example, is looking for office space in East Berlin and says it is active in East Germany; McKinsey & Company is running its East German operations from its office in West Berlin; Roland Berger, a consulting company that is a subsidiary of Deutsche Bank A.G., said it was very active in East Germany, and so is Deutsche Gesellschaft fur Mittelstandsberatung, another Deutsche Bank unit.
 
Formidable Competition
Mr. Jarowinsky, a 36-year-old marketing expert who was born and raised in East Berlin, acknowledged that the competition is formidable. His company, Marketing Services Berlin G.m.b.H., operates in cooperation with Dr. Ackert & Partner Management Consulting G.m.b.H., the first East German company to join the American Chamber of Commerce in Germany.
''Even for the Western consultants, it's tough,'' Mr. Jarowinsky said. ''The market here was far away behind the Iron Curtain. To outsiders, it was a black box.''
Before Communism's demise, both men worked for Iberma Ltd., a management consulting company partly owned by the East German Government, which had occasional need for capitalist techniques even though it banned them from reference books.
''We operated in both systems and have the advantage of detailed knowledge about East German companies and their ties throughout the East bloc,'' said Mr. Jarowinsky. ''We also have the contacts and the language skills needed to operate in Eastern Europe or Western Europe.''
 
American Clients Preferred
Both men said they hoped to work for private clients, preferably highly specialized, medium-sized companies from the United States. A company from Alaska that specializes in environmental decontamination - a service much in demand in highly polluted East Germany - is one of their first American clients. They would not give the company's name.
Working together, the two companies offer a wide range of services, Mr. Jarowinsky said. ''We want to be primarily a specialized marketing service offering advice on marketing strategy, financing, legal advising and contacts to companies and individuals.''
To help bridge the gap between foreign companies, the two consultants are working in cooperation with a number of foreign specialists, including Fulbright & Jaworski, the Washington law firm, and Hudig-Langeveldt G.m.b.H., the largest industrial insurance brokerage group in Europe.
Both men are confident of their abilities, in large part because of the experience they gained working abroad.
''We advised the state-owned companies on foreign trade and acquisitions,'' said the 36-year-old Mr. Ackert, who was licensed as a private lawyer in March, specializing in foreign trade law. ''My last deal before I left to set up my own business in February was the purchase of Royal Zenith in the United States by Kombinat Polygraph.''
 
East German Acquisition
That $35 million purchase on Jan. 10 was the first time an East German company had acquired a concern in the United States. Royal Zenith Inc., a trading and marketing company for the printing industry, is based in Great Neck, L.I. It was the United States distributor for Polygraph's Planeta unit, which makes sheet-fed printing presses that are rated among the finest in the world.
''That acquisition made a good bridge,'' said Mr. Ackert, who was deputy head of Iberma until the end of last year. ''It was the biggest and most interesting project I worked on, and it gave me excellent contacts in the United States. And the time was right to leave the company where I was working. They have a lot of good people, but the top managers have no experience and the firm is just sitting there now, being passive at a time when the situation calls for positive action.''
Neither man is apologetic about his membership in the Communist Party. ''Everyone bears a piece of the responsibility for what happened here in the D.D.R.,'' said Mr. Ackert. ''Sometimes, from the way people talk, you get the feeling that there were 16 million resistance fighters chasing 16 million guilty people. I joined the party in the early 70's. People forget now that when Honecker came to power there was a new, optimistic outlook. We thought he would improve things. And it did go better for a while.''
 
Unused Skills and Knowledge
The severe economic downturn that helped speed Erich Honecker's fall as head of state was particularly frustrating since both men had skills and knowledge that went unused.
''We were always present in the marketplace,'' Mr. Jarowinsky said. ''We traveled to East Germany's foreign trade offices in Europe and elsewhere. But we didn't dare do anything. We weren't allowed to do anything. Now we can work, make money and do something for the people here by creating jobs and opportunities.''
Another freedom they enjoy is charging what the market will bear. Their former employer billed customers 28 East German marks an hour, about $4.60 at the time. The going rate now is between $100 and $200 an hour, Mr. Ackert said, ''Depending, or course, on the client and the job.''
