HEADLINE: Balance Sheets in 90's: Less Debt

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
As the stock market climbs to record highs, American corporations are rushing to issue equity with an eagerness not seen since before the October 1987 stock market crash.
Common stock offerings rebounded in the first half of 1990 after a two-year slump. Wall Street bankers say this may signal a fundamental shift in corporate balance sheets away from debt and to equity. They say the shift reflects a desire by corporations to adopt a more conservative financial structure in the face of concerns about an uncertain economy and recent bankruptcies.
''Debt is not king anymore and equity is becoming the favored way to fund,'' said John Trygg, head of investor relations at U S West, the Denver-based regional telephone company that recently issued about $331 million in new stock. ''The upfront premise is that the world is changing as far as finance is concerned.'' 
 
Shift Away From Leverage
Indeed, the leveraging of corporate balance sheets that took place in the 1980's is being replaced in the early 1990's by ''deleveraging'' as companies are replacing debt with equity. In addition the growing appetite for equity stocks among large institutional investors, with millions of new dollars to invest daily, is expected to feed this trend.
The change may also make American corporations more competitive globally. With less debt on their balance sheets, companies have the capacity to borrow and expand when times are good and are less vulnerable to downturns when times are bad.
Corporations overseas, particularly in Japan and Germany, tend to be even more debt-heavy than those in America, but have stable and deep pockets that their counterparts in America do not because many are partially owned by large banks.
To be sure, part of this recent trend toward equity is cyclical. Corporations issue stock when the market is high to get as much as possible for every share floated. During market peaks in 1983 and 1987, companies flooded the market with stock. In the first half of 1987, for instance, 515 companies issued $25 billion in equity, including both intitial public offerings and secondary offerings, according to the Securities Data Company, a research firm.
Stock offerings fell sharply after the October 1987 crash and hit bottom in the first half of 1989, when only 187 companies raised $8.9 billion. In the first half of this year, 240 companies issued equity of $12.8 billion.
But unlike the halcyon days of the 1980's, the current rise in equity issues has not been accompanied by an increase in corporate debt offerings. Debt and equity offerings marched in lock step in the 1980's, with both forms of capital-raising breaking records. At the time much of the debt was used to retire equity when corporations were taken over through raids, mergers and leveraged buyouts. Between 1984 and 1989, for instance, corporations retired about $494 billion in equity, a record amount, according to the Federal Reserve Board.
Now, the reverse is true. In the first half of this year, only $57.3 billion in corporate debt was raised, the lowest since the second half of 1985, with much of it going to debt retirement.
 
Psychology of Fear
For issuers, what lies behind these numbers is a psychology of fear. Corporations are troubled by the collapse of the ''junk bond'' market, the specter of Donald J. Trump's problems, the bankruptcy of many celebrated buyout companies and an economy that could be headed for rough times.
''Debt is becoming a four-letter word,'' said Richard L. Kauffman, director of equity capital markets at the First Boston Corporation.
''People are looking at Donald Trump and all the companies being worked out,'' said Richard L. Franyo, a managing director at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., a Baltimore investment bank. ''Companies say, 'There's plenty of risk outside my doorstep: Do I want to have that risk on my balance sheet?' ''
And Sorrell M. Mathes, head of equity origination at Merrill Lynch, said: ''Corporate managers are nervous. The economy refuses to go into a recession, but keeps driving along the edge.''
 
Concern About Banking System
Compounding these concerns are worries about the banking system, particularly in the wake of the savings and loan crisis. And with Federal regulators clamping down on loans classified as ''highly leveraged transactions,'' banks are lending less to risky corporate ventures.
Moreover, corporations are more inclined to issue equity now that the threat of hostile takeovers is all but gone. They once feared that with more shares outstanding, the chances of falling into unfriendly hands was higher. And many companies loaded on debt as a takeover defense, using up excess debt capacity before a raider did it for them.
''To remain independent, a lot of companies felt pressure to have balance sheets more leveraged than they were comfortable with,'' said Mr. Kauffman of First Boston.
Corporations, as always, have many reasons for raising equity, not all related to deleveraging. U S West, for instance, felt stock was the safest way to finance untried new telecommunications ventures overseas, including in Eastern Europe. The company did not want to be saddled with debt payments that continued if the ventures did not. At the Reader's Digest Association, a $420 million initial public offering last February provided liquidity to foundations and charitable organizations, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Lincoln Center, which had been given non-voting stock by the trust of the association's founding family.
But for others, equity has become a way to separate themselves from the reality of heavy monthly debt payments as well as the stigma of debt of many investors' eyes. Some offerings are ''reverse'' leveraged buyouts, as companies that once borrowed heavily to go private now pay down high-cost debt with equity in partial spinoffs to the public.
''We did have a heavy debt load,'' said Phillip Bode, head of investor relations for Sante Fe Energy Resources. The energy company issued $170 million in equity last March in a partial spinoff from the Sante Fe Pacific Corporation, its parent company, which still owns 81 percent of the company. ''Wall Street and the business community almost mandated that we get the debt load down,'' Mr. Bode said. ''And oil equities were in favor, so it was a good time.''
 
Choices Becoming Limited
In addition, stock offerings are often the only option that the original investors in a leveraged buyout have to recoup their investments now that the junk bond market is flattened and well-heeled financial buyers are not acquiring many companies.
For still others, deleveraging is simply a way to cut debt payments. Investment bankers classify as deleveraging deals those offered by the Storage Technology Corporation, a Colorado data storage maker that raised $115 million last March to pay down debt; Maxus Energy, an energy company that raised $94.5 million last May to repurchase covertible shares, and Safeway Stores Inc., a Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company buyout, that issued $90 million in April to repay debt.
Investors, who have traditionally bid up stocks of leveraged companies are also changing their tune. ''There's been a real change in investor psychology, and corporations are responding to it,'' said Frederic M. Seegal, co-head of corporate finance at Salomon Brothers. ''In the past, people focused on the upside of leverage. Now they are thinking about the downside.''
 
'Bias Against Equity'
A debt-laden company has a greater upside than a similar-size company with more equity because there are fewer shares outstanding over which the earnings are spread. Thus, the leveraged company records higher earnings per share, a big factor in determining stock prices. ''Investors normally have a bias against equity,'' Mr. Seegal said. ''But a too-leveraged company may not survive the difficult economy of the next three to five years.''
One sign of this changing attitude was Safeway. When the stock was first announced in February, it was to be priced at $13 to $16 a share. But investors, concerned the company was too debt heavy, were unwilling to pay that price, forcing Safeway to lower its offering to $11.25 a share.
How long caution will be demanded by investors is unclear, particularly if the bull market stalls and the economy falters. Kenneth Lipper, an investment banker who heads his own firm, said: ''You can't add equity without it impacting your return on equity. And if you don't have rapid growth, which we may not have, and the market drops, these stocks could get into some real problems.'' In this situation, stocks could plummet.
 
Economic Benefit Seen
Some say that deleveraging is good for the economy. Jeffrey Schaefer, senior vice president at the Securities Industry Association, said the economy should ''be subject to less shocks.''
''The more equity companies have,'' he said, ''the safer they are relative to volatility in the economy and their earnings.''
Mr. Kauffman of First Boston points out that more equity gives companies the flexibility to invest in things like research and growth. The question is whether they will actually do this. Once the discipline of debt and the threat of takeover are gone, corporate managers could be less inclined to cut fat and curtail perks. ''Leverage imposes a discipline,'' Mr. Kauffman said, ''and with more equity companies could simply go back to the good old days.''

HEADLINE: Sudden Fame for a Compromise on Trade

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 21

 BODY:
A Dutch civil servant with a dry sense of humor and an endless supply of patience was in bed with the flu in Geneva when leaders of the world's seven major industrial powers found themselves struggling to pronounce his name at the Houston summit meeting earlier this month.
Not the sort of man interested in even a Warholian 15 minutes of fame, Aart de Zeeuw shrugged off the repeated mangling of his surname. But what did make him feel better was the unlikely interest stirred in Houston by an eight-page document he had prepared on freeing world trade in agricultural products.
''I was surprised,'' Mr. de Zeeuw (pronounced ''duh-ZAY-ow'') said in an interview squeezed between meetings at the headquarters of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade here. ''I didn't realize the paper would be so central to the summit. The entire subject is very detailed and complicated, but they spent five or six hours discussing it.'' 
The fact that they did so, though, reflected their alarm that a bitter dispute over farming subsidies and supports is threatening to ruin four years of trade liberalization negotiations. And with the United States and the 12-nation European Community moving toward confrontation, the seven turned to the ''de Zeeuw text'' as a possible peace formula.
Although they did not adopt the text, which calls for across-the-board reduction of farm supports, their final communique commended it ''as a means to intensify the negotiations.'' President Bush referred to Mr. de Zeeuw by name in a news conference, while Britain's Prime Minister Thatcher told Parliament that the report by ''a Dutchman called de Zeeuw'' would be the basis for future talks.
The first real test of the suddenly famous text will come Monday in Geneva when a 96-nation Trade Negotiations Committee begins to draft final agreements on agriculture and a range of other trade issues. Without rapid progress, there are doubts whether the December deadline for completion of what is known as the Uruguay Round of GATT-sponsored trade negotiations can be met.
Mr. de Zeeuw was made chairman of the agriculture negotiating group, because the Netherlands stands roughly midway between the free-trade stance of the United States and the more protectionist position of most Community countries. After traveling widely and listening intently, it was his job to present a compromise plan on July 2.
Yet Mr. de Zeeuw - both as drafter and ''referee,'' as he calls himself -has now assumed still greater importance because of the disproportionate weight that agriculture carries in the trade talks as a whole. ''We all know that we can expect no real result from the Uruguay Round without an agreement on agriculture,'' he said.
The Uruguay Round, the seventh in a series that began 30 years ago, aims to reduce trade restraints in 15 areas, ranging from textiles and tropical goods to services and intellectual property. At present, existing GATT agreements cover $1 trillion of a total annual world trade of around $3 trillion. If successful, the Uruguay Round will liberalize an additional $1 trillion worth of international sales.
Many governments, including that of the United States, have warned that they will not accept any package that excludes agriculture. Some developing countries have also indicated that unless they obtain concessions on agriculture they will not endorse draft accords in, say, services.
The clash between the United States and the European Community over agriculture dates back to the early 1960's, when the community -at the time, still a six-nation common market - began what became known as the Common Agricultural Policy. Justified as a way of insuring ''food security,'' it sought to protect millions of small farmers, mainly in France and West Germany, through a system of direct subsidies, import barriers and export incentives.
The United States, which failed to have agriculture included in previous GATT rounds, complains that this policy enables European countries to keep out cheaper foreign food products at the same time they are dumping their surpluses abroad at below-market prices. As a result, the United States claims to have lost $11 billion in agricultural exports in 1989 alone.
The United States itself plans to channel $8.5 billion in subsidies to its 2.2 million farmers this year, with other assistance hidden in Federal irrigation programs, low-interest credit and price supports. But Washington argues that the community's program of export subsidies has an immediate and disruptive impact on world trade. And it is these subsidies that it most wants reduced.
In contrast, while Washington often bows to pressure from the American farming lobby, the European policy is defended as the ''economic cement'' binding the community together. Europeans pay dearly to shield 11 million farmers, 7.5 percent of the work force, from market forces. In 1990, $45 billion in tax revenues will be channeled through the community as subsidies, while consumers will pay $54 billion extra for food because prices are fixed above market rates.
The debate is further complicated by bitter charges of protectionism against the United States, the European Community and Japan by the 13-nation Cairns group that represents leading agricultural exporters, including Australia, Canada, Argentina and Brazil. For them, the answer is a total liberalization of trade in farm products so that their cheaper exports can find markets.
 
Mr. de Zeeuw's Targets
In drafting his text, Mr. de Zeeuw identified four areas in which protectionism should be reduced: domestic supports, like subsidies; nontariff barriers, like quotas; export subsidies, and plant, animal and human health controls that serve to restrict trade. He did not suggest when and by how much the reductions should take place, although he asked governments to provide a list of all their farm supports by Oct. 1.
But, to the distress of the community, Mr. de Zeeuw did express his belief that priority should be given to reducing export subsidies, which happens to be the United States' view. ''Export subsidies are the most trade-distorting measures,'' the 66-year-old agricultural economist said. ''Therefore we have to do more here than in other areas.''
The community, though, favors ''aggregate measures of support,'' meaning that all farm supports should be looked at as a package. And it points to a recent report by the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development showing that total producer subsidies for each farmer were worth $8,000 in community countries and $20,000 in the United States.
Mr. de Zeeuw brushed off the suggestion that his recognition at Houston had increased his responsibilities. ''I don't decide these things,'' he insisted. ''Governments do. I'm just a mediator; I don't count. When my name was mentioned on television from Houston, my son called up and said, 'So that's what you've been doing all these years.' ''

HEADLINE: Proposals On Foreign Investors

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Mirroring concern about a sevenfold rise in foreign investment in United States companies in the last decade, Congress is considering a spate of bills that would help the Government assess the extent of foreign ownership and its impact on the economy.
Some of the 21 bills would require not only expanded reporting requirements by foreign investors, but much wider distribution of confidential data among units of the Government, including committees and subcommittees of Congress, in the case of a bill sponsored by Representative John Bryant, Democrat of Texas.
Another bill, by Representative Doug Walgren, Democrat of Pennsylvania, would require foreign companies seeking American takeover partners to report how they would handle technology crucial to the American industrial base and provide crucial supplies to customers.
In another indication of the ferment over the issue, the Federal Election Commission, the agency that seeks to insure fair elections, is considering barring foreign-owned companies from organizing political action committees to support political candidates. 
While the Bush Administration continues to welcome foreign investment, as have other administrations in the last four decades, Congress and some Federal agencies are questioning whether that longstanding policy should be modified.
 
Sovereignty Seen Threatened
Opinion surveys indicate that three-quarters of the American people fear that the United States's sovereignty is somehow threatened by foreign investment, which now totals $2 trillion, including $401 billion in direct investment. That includes such high-profile investments as a controlling stake in Rockefeller Center, bought by the Mitsubishi Bank and a Japanese real estate group; the Honda Motor Company's auto plant in Marysville, Ohio, and the Sony Corporation's purchase of CBS Records.
''What we're seeing,'' said Elliot L. Richardson, the former Attorney General and chairman of the Association of International Investment, a group that tries to promote foreign investment in the United States, ''is the political reflection of the loss by the United States of its position as the dominant force in the world.'' Promoting Competitiveness The Democrats introduced proposals last month to promote economic competitiveness, indicating that foreign investment is likely to be an issue in the November elections, and perhaps in the 1992 Presidential elections.
The possibility of a ban on political action committees at foreign-owned companies has followed sharp Senate criticism of the existing system. For years, American subsidiaries of foreign companies, like Royal Dutch/ Shell, British American Tobacco, American Hoechst and Ciba-Geigy, have been allowed to maintain such committees, which often make large political contributions.
Even in the waning days of the 101st Congress, some of the investment bills in the Congressional hopper stand good chances of passage. Most focus on giving the Government additional information about foreign investments or disseminating already existing information more widely within the bureaucracy.
 
Some Bills Cause Anxiety
Some of the bills cause anxiety in business groups, which worry that confidential information about companies' strategic plans may be disclosed to competitors. Backers say that confidentiality can be protected and that the data will help in evaluating the overall impact of foreign investment on the economy.
''A better understanding of the level of foreign ownership will help the Congress and President better craft economic policy,'' said Senator James J. Exon, a Nebraska Democrat and former businessman who is a joint sponsor of one bill that has aroused little controversy.
The bill, which is also sponsored by Representative Norman F. Lent, a New York Republican, would give the Bureau of Economic Analysis access to detailed data collected by the Census Bureau. Both agencies are part of the Commerce Department and both collect confidential data from companies. Under the new legislation, both would go to special lengths to preserve the confidentiality of the information.
While the Reagan Administration resisted similar proposals in the past, the Bush Administration supports the Exon-Lent bill in the interests of ''higher-quality statistics'' and a ''better understanding of the role that foreign investment plays in the American economy,'' said Michael R. Darby, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs. Both the Bryant and Walgren bills, which would greatly expand the Government's role in foreign investment, are opposed by the Administration.
The change in tone from the Reagan years may also reflect acknowledgement of the high political content of the investment issue and a desire to undercut more sweeping legislation.
The first foray of Congress into the area of foreign investment came two years ago when Congress authorized a review process in which the President can stop an investment that he deems a threat to national security. The provision, an amendment to 1988 trade legislation. was sponsored by Senator Exon and Representative James J. Florio, now the Democratic Governor of New Jersey.
This year, half of the foreign companies involved in takeovers are expected to seek formal approval by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, the inter-agency body that advises the President on matters of foreign investment.
The Treasury-led group, known as Cfius, has received 409 notifications by foreign companies seeking national security clearance before going forward with American takeovers, said William E. Barreda, Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.
While notification is voluntary, the law provides that a transaction may be dissolved at any time should a foreign investor fail to notify the Government, provide false and misleading information or omit material information. This is a powerful inducement to seek Government clearance.
Yet of all the transactions the committee on foreign investment has reviewed, only one has been overturned - the purchase of Mamco Manufacturing Inc. of Seattle by the China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation. Mamco supplies the Boeing Corporation with metal components for commercial aircraft.
Some of the new bills would mandate the transfer of more data to the foreign-investment committee. And legislation just approved by the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Economic Stabilizationwould require the committee, which operates under strict secrecy, to make annual reports on the cases it reviews.

HEADLINE: Peace Starts To Take Toll

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
With big weapons makers like the McDonnell Douglas Corporation laying off thousands of employees and with communities across the country bracing for further cuts in the arms budget, many companies, workers and Government officials are scrambling to find nonmilitary uses for jobs, skills and technology long supported by the Pentagon.
To some extent, their efforts are already too late. What Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio recently called ''the dark side of the peace dividend'' is already becoming reality for tens of thousands of workers. For them, the talk of what is usually called economic conversion or adjustment -the post-cold war version of beating swords into plowshares - is a nice theory not so easily translated into reality. 
The large military contractors have shown little desire or ability to push into alternative fields. In Southern California, for example, large contractors have shown no interest in a proposal by local politicians that they help to develop an electric rail-car industry that could serve the region's growing need for mass transit. The contractors' reticence largely reflects their unsuccessful attempts in the past to crack such markets.
Many companies have found that their engineers, marketing staffs and skilled workers have difficulty shifting from the mentality of supplying the Pentagon, which puts a premium on quality and adherence to a maze of bureaucratic requirements, to that of a commercial business, where minimizing costs, the ability to bring a product to market quickly and competitive pressures play a much greater role.
''Most companies have learned the lesson that pursuing an unfamiliar customer is very tricky,'' said Robert Paulson, who advises military contractors for the consulting firm McKinsey & Company.
Smaller companies, many with highly specialized skills and products, often face daunting obstacles in converting to civilian markets, including the high costs of buying new tools and finding non-Government customers.
For its part, the Government remains divided over what role, if any, it should take in retraining workers, encouraging companies to pursue nonmilitary products and services and helping communities attract a more diversified industrial base.
 
New Lines of Business
To the extent that contractors are pursuing new lines, they are ''sticking with the technical skills they have and seeing if they can find applications in a related market, like space or commercial aircraft or transportation,'' Mr. Paulson said, adding, ''They're not going to go into toasters.''
But fields like commercial aviation and space, long cited by proponents of conversion plans as natural businesses to absorb workers are also reducing employment.
Still, workers at some companies are pressing management to come up with ideas to keep production lines and laboratories open. At the Unisys Corporation's defense systems division in St. Paul, where 1,800 union workers recently lost their jobs, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers came up with a list of 140 proposals.
 
Rejected by Management
''We approached the company with the ideas, and they didn't want to hear anything about it,'' said Wipali Globa, the union's local president. A Unisys spokesman said the company was open to ideas but reserved the right to decide on a strategy.
Even when large companies come up with new ways to use old skills, the benefits are often limited. The Lockheed Corporation, which has seen its military aircraft business shrivel, said recently that it would go into maintenance and modification work on Boeing 747 commercial aircraft, a venture that could eventually employ more than 900 people in Southern California. But Lockheed is eliminating 7,000 jobs in the area.
Faced with a rapidly growing list of layoffs, legislators are pushing for action to protect or help workers. The State of Washington recently appropriated $200,000 for a program to help military contractors and communities dependent on them develop diversification plans. California, like other states, is helping subcontractors and suppliers explore diversification efforts.
 
Ideological Debate
But in Congress, an ideological debate over the Government's role in managing the shrinkage of the industry makes it unclear whether there will be any significant Federal role.
''The questions are, what is going to be the mix between Federal, state and local governments in terms of responsibility for adjustment, and what is going to be the mix between public-and private-sector responsibility,'' said Gordon Adams, of the Defense Budget Project, a research group.
Congressional aides said conversion legislation would make it politically more palatable for members of Congress to vote for Pentagon budget cuts that would endanger jobs in their home districts.
''In a very direct way, the Government was responsible for getting people involved in defense work, and in order to avert or reduce economic dislocation there is an obligation on the part of Government to make the transition as limited and painless as possible,'' said Representative Ted Weiss, a New York City Democrat who is co-sponsoring economic conversion legislation in the House.
 
'We Cannot Throw It Away'
Apart from the question of jobs, some Government officials and industry executives argue that a coherent national policy is needed to preserve technologies and skills critical to national security.
''We have an infrastructure in place - scientists, engineers, facilities - that we spent trillions of dollars building,'' said Robert B. Costello, the Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition during the Reagan Administration, who is now with the Hudson Institute, a research organization. ''We cannot throw it away.''
There are some examples of companies that have transformed themselves to prepare for lower Pentagon spending.
One is the Kavlico Corporation of Moorpark, Calif., a maker of sophisticated sensors used in many military aircraft. In the last few years, Kavlico successfully expanded and diversified its business by adapting its products for use in other industries and winning big orders from customers like the Ford Motor Company. As a result, Kavlico in the last four years has more than doubled its sales, to about $50 million annually, and grown to 600 employees, from 200.
 
Extensive Studies
Kavlico's scientists and engineers made extensive studies of the company's strengths and existing technologies. The company hired sales and marketing executives with commercial backgrounds, brought in some engineers from outside the military-aerospace field and invested in research and new equipment.
''We wanted to be less dependent on a single business,'' said Michael C. Gibson, Kavlico's president. ''You can make the transition to a more diversified mix, but it's not easy.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rise in Long-Term Rates Forecast

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The bond market is likely to have a difficult time adjusting to the Federal Reserve's new, seemingly more benign attitude about inflation, credit market analysts say.
As a consequence, unless compelling evidence of serious economic weakness emerges, the analysts said, long-term interest rates were likely to move higher even though pressures on short-term rates might recede.
There were sound reasons for Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, to make it plain to Congress last week that the Fed has shifted its priorities toward avoiding recession and shoring up a weakened banking system, the analysts added.
 
'Unspoken Tenet'
''It is an unspoken tenet of Federal Reserve activity that bank profitability is in the public interest,'' said Hung Q. Tran, an economist at the Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation. ''That is especially true when the margin of safety at one or more large institutions is seen as uncomfortably thin.'' 
Still, bond market participants have traditionally had difficulty with a Fed whose overriding consideration was anything but dampening inflation, since rising prices erode real returns on fixed-income securities.
''This new attention to sustaining the economic expansion and offsetting unintended restrictions in credit availability suggests that there is now less hope that the inflation premium in United States bond yields will be eliminated soon,'' said Richard Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
 
Standoff Is Seen
''Accordingly, bond investors are presented with a standoff: although a sluggish economy likely will not boost inflation, policy makers likely will not wring it out,'' he added. ''This scenario closes off the possibility that yields will dip significantly further.''
The analysts said there might be a good reason for the Fed to have chosen a tactical retreat in its fight against inflation. ''Tight monetary policy is not going to affect the price of prescription drugs or other services,'' said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''And more economically sensitive prices in manufacturing and other areas are showing signs of abating.''
Nevertheless, the market is almost certain to remain wary about inflation, and an important measure of price trends to be released tomorrow is not expected to make pleasant reading. Because of growing costs for health care and other services, analysts are projecting a second-quarter rise in the employment cost index of about 5.5 percent, duplicating its performance in the first three months of the year.
 
Inflation Viewed as Problem
''If the employment cost numbers are above 5 percent, it's kind of hard to see how inflation is coming down,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''From our point of view, we think there is a continuing inflation problem. But the Fed seems more inclined to ease policy.''
Mr. Greenspan will have another chance to amplify the Fed's intentions tomorrow, when he delivers his semiannual testimony on monetary policy and the economy to members of the House of Representatives. Last week Mr. Greenspan addressed senators on those issues.
Aside from those developments, the release on Friday of preliminary estimates of second-quarter economic growth is likely to be the highlight of the week. Forecasts from private analysts about the figures vary widely: the most optimistic are projecting economic growth in the quarter of as much as 2.5 percent, while the gloomiest show that growth limped ahead at an annual rate of 1 percent.
 
Revised Three-Year Figures
The task of analyzing the numbers will be made much more difficult because the Commerce Department will also release revised figures on the gross national product for the last three years. ''Days like that are a numerical mess for an economist,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Worries about inflation and the degree of vigilance being exercised by of Fed may dictate the overall direction of interest rates, but such concerns are not readily apparent in the $200 billion market for high-yield ''junk bonds.''
The high-yield market got long-awaited help last week when details of the $6.8 billion refinancing program for RJR Nabisco were released. As a result of that program, $4 billion to $5 billion of outstanding high-yield RJR securities will be retired this year, further diminishing the supply of bonds that are currently trading in the market.
 
Pool Will Be Refilled
In the first half of 1990, more than $7.5 billion worth of high-yield securities were retired, said Robert Long, director of high-yield research at the First Boston Corporation. That figure is more than twice the amount of securities that were retired in all of 1989. The pool of outstanding securities will be refilled somewhat by the Resolution Trust Corporation, which has a $3.7 billion portfolio of high-yield bonds that it intends to sell over time.
But over all, analysts said, the once-battered junk bond market is in good shape. ''I am very optimistic about the outlook for the next several months,'' said Martin Fridson, a managing director in charge of high-yield research at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The improved climate may encourage some underwriters to make public offerings of new high-yield securities over the next few months, Mr. Fridson and others said.
 
Private Placements Made
While no high-yield issuer has tapped the public market since February, $3.8 billion worth of high-yield securities carrying registration rights have been sold through the private placement market, Mr. Long said. Registration rights require the bonds to be registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission so that they can be traded publicly at a later date.
Despite the market's problems over the last year, demand for high-quality junk paper remains very strong. An example was provided last week, when the GTech Corporation, a provider of lottery systems for states and municipalities, privately placed $115 million worth of senior subordinated debentures through Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette. According to market participants, the issue was oversubscribed by a ratio of 6 to 1.
''If the deal is structured properly and is priced appropriately, I will be a buyer,'' said Mark Vaselkiv, a vice president of the T. Rowe Price High Yield fund. ''Right now it is really hard to find paper to buy in the secondary market.''

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: TELEVISION;
Tartikoff Show Goes On, But Its Script Is Changing

BYLINE: By Bill Carter

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
JUST before Brandon Tartikoff faced the press for the last time as NBC's chief programming executive, he strapped on a mobile microphone and headset, a la Madonna, and sang a two-minute rap number with the network's newest star, Will Smith - also known as the Fresh Prince.
No other television executive would have dared try the stunt, let alone bring it off, as Mr. Tartikoff did last week. But Mr. Tartikoff is a showman by every possible definition.
The Tartikoff show is going to continue at NBC, but not as before. And if NBC does not show Mr. Tartikoff something that he wants to see, the show might not run too long. 
What Mr. Tartikoff wants to see is that NBC is serious about expanding in directions that will alter the entire concept of a network.
Mr. Tartikoff has been president of NBC Entertainment for more than 10 years, longer than anyone else in the business. Last week, though, he announced that he was giving up day-to-day control of NBC's programming department and becoming chairman of a newly created entity, the NBC Entertainment Group.
Several NBC executives described the move not as the end of an era at the network, but rather as a shifting of priorities. The succession of Warren Littlefield, Mr. Tartikoff's chief programming lieutenant, as entertainment president assures a smooth transition, the NBC executives said.
But it will still be a transition, and that has inescapable implications for NBC. Mr. Tartikoff has been the most successful television executive in a generation, leading a department that climbed from laughingstock to television supremacy, pulling in up to $500 million a year in profits.
He has been closely associated with NBC's hits over the last decade, from ''Cheers'' and ''Hill Street Blues'' to ''Cosby'' and ''Golden Girls.''
But those shows have made their creators and studio owners far more money from syndication profits than Mr. Tartikoff or NBC earned from selling the commercial time in them. Now, Mr. Tartikoff said, with the economics of television in upheaval, it is possible for such hits to become ''loss leaders'' for a network while they continue to make their owners rich.
As he see it, there is a need for a a new form of television network, resembling a large Hollywood studio.
The word studio is much on Mr. Tartikoff's lips these days. The new opportunity he most wants is to run a movie studio that NBC's parent company, the General Electric Company, would buy for him.
The network put in a determined effort to keep Mr. Tartikoff, who said he had communicated for seven months his ''diminished interest'' in several aspects of the programming job. Mr. Tartikoff has frequently been wooed by studios, most recently this last March when he declined a feeler to take over the troubled Orion studio.
Mr. Tartikoff called a studio a ''big toy to play with.'' He does not necessarily expect G.E. to run out and buy him one. But, he said, ''I don't rule it out either.'' He has told associates that he would like to see NBC move to buy a studio by January, especially if the networks win a ruling in December from the Federal Communications Commission authorizing them to take some profits from programs sold into syndication.
As long as the networks are excluded from those profits, owning a studio makes less sense. But Mr. Tartikoff believes that such a move is necessary - both for NBC and his own personal growth.
A small studio, he said, could provide the network with the packaging, experience and distribution to make middle-budget movies, those costing $12 million to $14 million.
But, he added, he can see NBC moving to a higher level by taking advantage of its assets, including its large news and sports staffs and the production abilities of its local stations.
Even if the studio does not work out right away, Mr. Tartikoff sees other ''sparkling opportunities.'' He has ideas for working inside NBC in a separate production unit, spinning out international co-productions and other creative programming deals.
The arrangement calls for Mr. Tartikoff to explore these areas, while maintaining ultimate authority over his previous empire, the NBC programming division.
But Mr. Littlefield says he will be running NBC Entertainment, using Mr. Tartikoff as a consultant.
Mr. Littlefield participated in developing virtually every NBC show now on the air and is respected in Hollywood for his programming talent, if not his rap singing.
In an interview last week, Mr. Littlefield acknowledged, ''Brandon casts a very large shadow.''
So despite the carefully muted talk of the end of the Tartikoff era in network programming, the evidence is growing that the shadow has moved on to a position in front of a different set of spotlights.

HEADLINE: Noriega's Troops Now Form Police With U.S. Aid, Panamanians Say

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, July 22

 BODY:
Miguel Antonio Bernal, a respected Panamanian scholar and social critic, was eating dinner with friends recently in a restaurant when his companions noticed a man they recognized as their torturer during their detention under Manuel Antonio Noriega.
Mr. Bernal and his friends started clinking their glasses with silverware in a kind of protest, and shortly after that were arrested by Panamanian officers accompanied by United States military policemen and detained for several hours. The officers were former soldiers from General Noriega's army, who now serve as the Fuerza Publica, the national police force that has replaced the military.
The arrest of Mr. Bernal, who was recently named chairman of the department of public law at the University of Panama, has propelled an already intense debate over what role the former soldiers should have and how deeply the United States should be involved in shaping the new force. 
Coming on top of an economic restructuring plan that in some aspects resembles unpopular programs of past Governments, some Panamanians are complaining that with the overnight conversion of Noriega soldiers into policemen, their country is now facing ''Noriegism without Noriega.''
 
'Reviving the Old Army'
After the invasion by the United States on Dec. 20, with widespread looting following the routing of General Noriega's forces, ''the United States told us to create a police force, to do it now,'' said Alberto Conte, a 54-year-old leader of Civic Crusade, an association of business and professional groups that organized boisterous street demonstrations in 1987 that shook the Noriega Government.
''They called the Government and said, 'You guys have anyone who knows how to handle weapons?' '' Mr. Conte said in an interview in his advertising agency offices. '' 'Sure, they are behind bars,' was the answer. And now we have almost the same number of people, in fact the very same people as before. They are not creating anything, or filtering anything. They are reviving the old army.''
In recent days, the Panamanian Government has moved to calm fears about the police. Last week, it named three civilians, including a member of Civic Crusade, to oversee the new force at the sub-ministerial level.
Mr. Conte and others have said the United States has a duty to ''watch over the security of the invaded country,'' until a new police force can be created ''clean from the first officer down.''
The arrest of Mr. Bernal, who returned last month from three years of political exile, is only the most celebrated in a growing number of cases that have raised questions about the comportment of the new police. In another incident, Panamanian officers were charged with murder in May after the death of the 3-year-old granddaughter of General Noriega's former second-in-command. Prosecutors say the girl was abducted in an extortion plot.
Defenders of the police, including the United States Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, point to such arrests as evidence that the system is working. ''When those cases turn up,'' Mr. Hinton said, referring to police abuses, ''the will exists in the Government to do something about it.''
For the 40-year-old Mr. Bernal, an academic and sometime journalist, and many active in human rights here, these incidents illustrate the urgency of quickly reducing the American military presence.
''There must be no more arbitrary arrests,'' Mr. Bernal said in an interview in his office overlooking the university campus. ''They only act this way because they are backed up by the Americans.'' A judge later dismissed all charges against Mr. Bernal and his friends.
For some, the incident demonstrates the necessity of having the United States continue to share responsibility for public order in Panama seven months after the American invasion that destroyed an army known for its corruption.
 
U.S. Asked to Do More
Despite the presence of about 200 American military police officers, who accompany the Panamanian police on patrols, and Justice Department and civilian police experts who are helping train the new Panamanian force, these critics say the United States has not done enough to assure a smooth transition to Panamanian-maintained law and order with respect for civil rights.
Where Panamanians of virtually every stripe seem to agree, however, is in their deep skepticism and apprehension over the Government's decision, made in the immediate aftermath of the invasion and supported by the United States, to build the 12,000-member Fuerza Publica almost entirely from decommissioned soldiers from General Noriega's army.
For these Panamanians, the wholesale incorporation of soldiers into a new police force with a military-style command structure means trouble in spite of the Government's declared intention to demilitarize the society.
Roberto Eisenman, publisher and editor of La Prensa, a leading Panamanian newspaper, has been a persistent critic of the way the force was formed. Everything about the Fuerza Publica, ''including its very name,'' a La Prensa editorial said, must be opened to full national debate.
''Giving up the historical opportunity to come out of this a totally demarilitarized society is a criminal shame,'' Mr. Eisenman said in an interview.
 
Warning Against Criticism
Ricardo Arias Calderon, a former director of La Prensa, is now First Vice President and oversees the creation of the new police force. He caused a stir earlier this year when opponents of his plan to use General Noriega's soldiers said he warned them, ''We will not tolerate criticism.''
Mr. Eisenman and others have focused criticism on the hiring of Col. Eduardo Herrera Hassan to head the new police force.
Colonel Herrera was sent to Israel as Ambassador in 1985 after Mr. Noriega began to regard him as a serious potential rival. Many describe him as ''less corrupt'' than most of the former Panamanian Defense Force's senior officers, but the ambitious 23-year Panamanian Army veteran is still viewed as a soldier at heart who learned at the elbow of General Noriega.
Colonel Herrera has done nothing to allay concerns about his ambitions, bristling in interviews about suggestions for more civilian control and warning that the police, demoralized by their lack of automatic weapons to pursue heavily armed criminals, could eventually go on strike.
Mr. Eisenman said that ''the Government should find someone with a strong sense of civic duty who is a good administrator and knows how to handle money and then recruit university graduates'' as staff members.
 
New Recruiting Urged
''We have had thousands of people marching in the streets who have shown their devotion to the country who could have been recruited as policemen,'' he said. ''From everything I have heard, carefully looking at the question, it would be much easier to train these people to be police than to retrain the military.''
In an interview at police headquarters, Ebrahim Azbat, the senior adviser to Vice President Arias who was named as director of public security, sought to blunt the criticism and offer a reassuring assessment of the role of the former soldiers.
''It was a decision to make every Panamanian feel that he can be part of the new democracy,'' said Mr. Azbat, a boyish-faced 35-year-old lawyer.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wall St. Volatility Reflects Larger Economic Worries

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
A sharp fall in stock prices yesterday reflected growing worries over the health of the economy, especially the erosion of corporate profits, as well as a stock market that has grown increasingly fragile, some traders and analysts say.
The rapid plunge in prices, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 100 points in little more than an hour of trading, only to stabilize and end the day down by 56.44 points, or 1.9 percent, at 2,904.70, came after a series of disappointing earnings reports from companies as diverse as Texas Instruments, the electronics company, and McDonald's, the hamburger chain.
The selling extended to virtually all stocks, with six stocks falling in price for every one that rose. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell by 6.30, or 1.7 percent, to 355.31. [Page D1.] Growing Apprehension The profit disappointments came at a time of growing apprehension about the health of the financial system -many large bank stocks are trading at their lowest levels in two years - that had generally not hurt the stock market up to now. While share prices were not as expensive, measured against such indicators as earnings and interest rates, as they were in the summer of 1987, they were approaching that level, according to many analysts. 
''The market had reached overvalued levels, the economy is sluggish, and corporate profits, while they are not horrendous, are well below the levels of expectations that were built into prices,'' said Abby Joseph Cohen, the chief American strategist for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Research.
The Federal Reserve lowered interest rates slightly two weeks ago, providing some help for share prices, but worries that interest rates would not fall further, and might rise, have grown. Those fears intensified yesterday after rates in Japan rose overnight, and share prices declined in Tokyo, with the Nikkei 225-stock index off 1.6 percent. But in early trading today the Nikkei's losses were trimmed. At the close of the morning session, the average was down by 67.66 points, to 31,827.13, a decline of about two-tenths of a percent.
 
Rates Quickly Turn Down
Interest rates were up in early New York trading yesterday, but quickly turned down after stock prices cracked, as traders seeking safety bought Treasury securities.
The suddenness of the plunge stunned many traders, recalling the 190-point fall on Oct. 13, 1989. But while there were a pair of causes that touched off that slide - including the collapse of financing for a takeover of United Airlines and a Washington setback to efforts to lower capital gains taxes - there were no such ready explanations yesterday morning, although some pointed to the continued rise of oil prices and to the fact that McDonald's, a consumer growth stock and market leader up until now, reported poor earnings late Friday. The company fell $1.50 that day and another $3 today, closing at $33 a share.
The plunge may have been accelerated by the fact many brokers had built up inventories of shares in recent weeks as the Dow neared 3,000, a point at which it was hoped that buyers would come flooding in. Last week, the average traded over that level on three days, but never closed there. In addition, there had been a widespread expectation on Friday that prices would rise in late trading as the scheduled expiration of a stock index futures contract in Chicago touched off a wave of buying. Instead, the buying from that was minor and was overwhelmed by late selling from other areas.
Some analysts said the decline was exaggerated by changes in the securities industry in recent years. With commission rates on stock trades falling steadily, the big brokerage houses seem less willing to risk their own capital to buy stocks that institutions are selling. Without that buying support, the volatility of stock prices is increased.
With buyers returning in the afternoon, the day ended as only the third worst decline of the Dow in 1990, and there were indications that some buyers were betting that the market would bounce back quickly.
Robert Farrell, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that it appeared more retail customers at his firm were inclined ''to want to buy something'' rather than to ''panic and sell.''
 
Impact of 'Circuit Breakers'
The ''circuit breakers'' in effect at futures exchanges - most importantly the one at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which trades contracts on the Standard & Poor's 500 index - seem to have had a dual impact. They may first have accelerated the drop, but then stabilized the market.
The rule on the S.&P. provided that if the September futures contract fell 12 points - about 3.3 percent - there could be no trading below that level for 30 minutes. When prices began to near that amount just after 10:30 A.M., there appeared to be a ''magnet effect,'' in which they fell to the level. Prices in the stock market at first continued lower, but then rallied, helping the futures quotes recover.
In the afternoon, when the market again sagged, S.&P. futures prices fell even lower. There was no circuit breaker then, and there would not have been one unless prices fell 20 points, but the market nonetheless rallied.
 
Rules Proposed by Exchange
The New York Stock Exchange has proposed rules to halt stock trading for 30 minutes if the Dow falls 100 points in a day, but they are awaiting approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission and by other exchanges, and were not in effect.
The Big Board did, however, put into effect a ''side car'' rule in which some program trades related to index arbitrage were delayed for five minutes after the futures circuit breaker was set off. The immediate effect of that was to cause some program trades to be executed at a loss, some traders said.
In recent weeks, as the Dow rose while many stocks were weakening, traders had increasingly focused on two groups: computer stocks, which were market stars early in the year, and companies that were thought to have consistent growth in profits, whatever happened to the economy. It was in that context that disappointments in such companies as McDonald's and Texas Instruments may have demoralized money managers, and made them hesitate to buy when prices tumbled yesterday.
Volume yesterday, at 209 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, was heavier than usual, but by no means as heavy as in previous big drops. That fact served to reinforce the feelings of some traders that the markets have become more fragile, able to plunge with only limited selling pressure.
Reports from some brokerage houses yesterday said there was only limited selling of stocks by institutions. But there seems to have been more selling of stock index futures in an effort to hedge portfolios against further losses. That selling was then translated back to the stock market through index arbitrage, in which traders sold stocks while buying the futures contracts.
The Big Board asked that brokers refrain from some forms of index arbitrage after the large fall in the morning, but some of it continued, traders said.

LENGTH: 1045 words

HEADLINE: Iran's Leaders Achieve a Subtle Balance of Power

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran

 BODY:
The relationship between the two men who run Iran is sometimes likened to that of two talented but competitive dancing partners.
''One leads at one moment, one leads at another,'' a Western diplomat said. ''Let us please hope that they never want to lead at the same time.''
President Hashemi Rafsanjani and the nation's supreme spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, seem at first to be working together on an agenda to end Iran's isolation and somehow to revive its economy. 
In recent weeks, they have united on what is seen here as the most contentious foreign-policy question facing the country, agreeing that the Government should accept humanitarian aid from the United States and other nations that have had poor relations with Teheran to assist victims of the devastating earthquake in northern Iran in June.
 
Cooperation Not a Tradition
But in the murky, sometimes dangerous world of Iranian politics since the 1979 Islamic revolution, President Rafsanjani and Ayatollah Khamenei know that, in the end, cooperation has never been a strategy for survival in Iran.
In ways both subtle and overt, the two seem to be struggling for dominance in a nation still trying to find its way after the death last year of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's absolute leader for nearly a decade.
''I don't think anyone is predicting a real break between Rafsanjani and Khamenei - their policy differences are certainly not insurmountable,'' an Iranian scholar said. ''Watch them, though. They will each want to consolidate power at the other's expense.''
While Mr. Rafsanjani is the nation's chief of state, Ayatollah Khamenei wields political power beyond his title, which is supreme spiritual guide of the Islamic revolution. He controls the military and has considerable influence over the Government-controlled radio and television service.
There are rumblings, apparently from Rafsanjani supporters, that the role of spiritual leader may be eliminated over time. There are rumors, perhaps from Ayatollah Khamenei's camp, that Mr. Rafsanjani is losing the support of some of the nation's most important religious leaders because of his overtures to the West.
 
Both Were Khomeini Followers
Mr. Rafsanjani is a hojatolislam, a step below ayatollah in the hierarchy of Shiite Islam, and both he and Ayatollah Khamenei were Khomeini followers in the 1960's and 1970's, in the difficult years of resistance to the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.
Both were arrested, imprisoned and they say, tortured, by the Shah's notorious secret police, the Savak.
With the fall of the Shah and Ayatollah Khomeini's return to Iran from exile 11 years ago, his two trusted lieutenants took prominent posts in the revolutionary Government.
Ayatollah Khamenei, who was born in 1940, was elected President in 1981. Mr. Rafsanjani held a succession of jobs, including head of the military force known as the Revolutionary Guards, before rising to the powerful post of Speaker of Parliament.
Mr. Rafsanjani, 56, became known in Parliament as the consummate politician, a powerful orator and shrewd negotiator. ''He would do well in your Washington, D.C.,'' an Iranian supporter said.
 
Predictions Off the Mark
With the death of Ayatollah Khomeini in June 1989, many Western analysts predicted a long and possibly violent battle for succession.
But to a large extent, Mr. Rafsanjani and Ayatollah Khamenei, who are considered moderates in the world of Iranian politics, maneuvered quickly to prevent the rise of militant Islamic fundamentalists.
Ayatollah Khamenei threw his support behind Mr. Rafsanjani as the nation's new President, while he took for himself the late Ayatollah Khomeini's post of spiritual leader.
It originally appeared to some Westerners that Ayatollah Khamenei was preparing to remove himself from much of the day-to-day governance of the nation, leaving that job to Mr. Rafsanjani.
In a May 1989 speech, just a month before Ayatollah Khomeini's death, Ayatollah Khamenei said: ''A single person must be in charge of the nation. People must make demands of him, protest to him and hold him responsible.''
 
Powers Are Being Shared
To a degree that has surprised some Western diplomats and businessmen here, Government powers have been shared between President Rafsanjani and Ayatollah Khamenei.
There was surprise among diplomats when, shortly after Mr. Rafsanjani took office last year, Ayatollah Khamenei reorganized the Security Council to include well-known rivals of the President, including Ahmad Khomeini, the late Ayatollah's son.
The envoys say they were also startled when Ayatollah Khamenei moved to assert a degree of oversight over the Iranian broadcasting system, which is run by Mr. Rafsanjani's brother, Mohammed Hashemi.
Iranian businessmen say there may yet be a public clash between the two leaders over how to deal with the nation's long-running economic crisis -the spiraling inflation and business stagnation that are almost certainly the greatest threat to the survival of the Government.
Mr. Rafsanjani, from a family of bazaar merchants, is a champion of free enterprise. Although his economic views appear to have moderated with the years, Ayatollah Khamenei, from a family of religious scholars, has in the past strongly supported a planned economy and the nationalization of important Iranian industries.
 
Reports of Friction
But there are reports of friction between the two leaders, but these cannot be easily substantiated.
President Rafsanjani and Ayatollah Khamenei have shared years of sacrifice against what seemed extraordinary odds, and their mutual ties to the Ayatollah Khomeini and his vision for Iran are seen here as having created a camaraderie that should survive most challenges.
But Iran is a nation where an intelligent analyst will hesitate before making a prediction.
''Iran has always been full of duplicity and insecurity, and sometimes Rafsanjani and Khamenei must wonder about exactly what the other one is doing,'' said a European business executive whose company was active in Teheran long before the revolution.
''I don't think it will happen, but if there was a very significant break between these two men, I don't know what would happen to Iran.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 6, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 743 words

HEADLINE: Bush Presents Plan to Help Andean Nations Grow Non-Coca Crops

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
President Bush announced trade concessions, expanded agricultural development assistance and other measures to help Ecuador, Colombia, Bolivia and Peru, the main cocaine-producing countries of Latin America, to develop alternative exports.
The moves, announced after the visit here of President Rodrigo Borja of Ecuador, were received on Capitol Hill as a welcome gesture, but many analysts questioned the extent to which economic benefits would eventually flow to these countries.
The program responds to one of the main Latin American complaints: that American policy is too enforcement-oriented and is not designed to cope with the economic and social repercussions of its enforcement efforts.
 
Incentive to Peasants
''When you wipe out a peasant's coca field and leave him with no reasonable economic alternative, he's faced with some rather stark choices - emigration out of the region or joining a revolutionary movement,'' said Rensselaer W. Lee, head of Global Advisory Services of Alexandria, Va., a consulting firm working on narcotics issues. 
Mr. Lee said the President's measures ''will expand the range of economic opportunities of these countries, but unless there is a clear incentive to do so, growers will not switch out of coca in large numbers.''
Representative Sam M. Gibbons, the Florida Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee's trade subcommittee, called the program ''a step in the right direction'' and said, ''I will support it, and I hope that most members of Congress will too.''
The centerpiece is a decision, which will become effective by Presidential proclamation on Aug. 1, to abolish import duties on 67 products, from fresh strawberries to expensive bicycle frames, sold to the United States by the four countries.
United States imports of the designated products from the Andean nations amounted to $26.6 million last year. Lower duties could help stimulate sales by giving those countries an edge over competitors.
For example, Mexico, now the principal exporter of fresh strawberries to the United States, would still have to pay the 1.5 percent tariff on them.
 
Encouraging Alternative Crops
White House officials said the goal of another part of the program, expansion of agricultural assistance to the Andean region, was to encourage alternatives to narcotics production by working with countries in the region to identify products that have a potential for increased production and trade.
Mr. Lee, the narcotics consultant, said possible crops included oranges, avocados, tea, coffee, macadamia nuts and spices. But he noted that the cycle from planting to first harvest for all those crops was longer than the 18 to 24 months for coca.
Mr. Lee said 400 to 500 tons of refined cocaine was exported from Latin America annually, up from 250 tons in 1987. He placed at $9 billion to $10 billion what Latin American drug traffickers now earned from this trade.
The extension of duty-free access comes under the so-called Generalized System of Preferences, an already existing program of special trade privileges that the United States gives to 130 developing countries.
Mr. Bush has also announced his intention to seek early Congressional approval for a tariff preference system for the four countries, patterned after the Caribbean Basin Initiative, further broadening duty-free access.
 
Expansion of Existing Program
For the past half-dozen years, the United States has allowed most products made in Caribbean and Central American countries to enter duty-free. So-called sensitive products, such as textiles and footwear with important domestic production, are excluded from the preferences.
The proposed Andean preference zone would complement existing programs of economic assistance and drug control, the White House said.
On June 27 the Bush Administration announced as its ultimate goal a free-trade system in North, Central and South America. In other words, there would be no duties on any commercial exchanges within the hemisphere.
The United States recently negotiated such a zone with Canada and is moving towards similar negotiations with Mexico.
The Bush Administration has also said it is prepared to forgive a substantial portion of the $12 billion that Latin American countries owe the United States Government and to announce plans for creation of a $300 million fund to encourage Latin nations to open their economies to foreign investment.

HEADLINE: Rift Over Water On Indian Land Has Deep Roots

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOTEVILLA, Ariz.

 BODY:
From the edge of this Hopi Indian village on the rim of the Third Mesa, with hot white sky and parched high desert as far as the eye can see, the splash of cool water can be heard.
A steep climb down the cliff, two village girls with buckets are at play in a spring that bursts from deep within the sandstone. The spring is one of several that are at the heart of a bitter dispute over water rights here on the Hopi and Navajo reservations.
The struggle is a classic treaty dispute that involves a clash of cultures between the Indians - for whom the springs are a source of both irrigation and spiritual identity - and the Peabody Coal Company of St. Louis, which uses underground water to flush crushed coal through a pipeline to a power station in Nevada.
Company officials voice exasperation at the dispute, saying they have fulfilled their side of a longstanding mining contract with the Indians and have satisfied all conditions for its indefinite extension. ''We've played by the rules,'' said Edward Sullivan, the company's Western Division vice president for legal and public affairs. 
 
'Water Is Our Life'
In the past, the contract was renewed at five-year intervals with little attention. But one of the most prolonged droughts in memory has made water more precious. The Hopis say the pumping is depleting the underground springs that for hundreds of years have allowed them to live and farm around their arid mesas. In a broader sense, they say the pumping, contract or no contract, is draining away their culture. They want the coal company to find another source of water or another way to transport the coal.
''That water is our life; it is our blood; it is the blood of the Hopi,'' said Jerry Honawa, one of the 800 residents of this village 40 miles from the mine. Below him the village girls splashed water into tiny plots of corn, radishes, carrots, beans, onions and squash.
''If Peabody continues drawing the water from under us, the whole earth will dry up and we will not be able to do any farming,'' he said. ''And in essence, we will begin to dry up.''
As argued before the Department of the Interior by lawyers and hydrologists for both sides, the dispute involves questions of the mine's potential effect on the environment.
Peabody is seeking what is called a ''life of the mine'' permit to maintain operations at the 20-year-old Black Mesa-Kayenta Mine. The permit would allow it to indefinitely continue pumping 1.4 billion gallons of water a year from an underground lake, or aquifer, to flush crushed coal through the pipeline.
The 273-mile pipeline carries about five million tons of coal a year from the Black Mesa mine around the Grand Canyon to the Mohave Generating Station near Laughlin, Nev. From there, lines supply much of the power used in Los Angeles and Southern California.
A separate rail line transports seven million tons of coal a year from the adjoining Kayenta mine to the Navajo Generating Station near Page, Ariz.
The Indians are contesting the results of a five-year environmental study for the department's Office of Surface Mining, which concluded that the pumping caused ''no material damage'' to the water source, thousands of feet underground, or to the springs.
Opposing experts disagree over whether the springs are connected to the aquifer, or whether they are suffering solely from the drought.
On July 6, under intense lobbying by both sides, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. agreed to an indefinite delay in granting the permit sought by the mining company, to allow time for further study. His decision only intensified feelings. Indians Collect Millions ''They'll never be satisfied,'' Mr. Sullivan said of the Indians. He said Peabody had done everything asked for by both the tribes and the Government, including participating in the environmental study.
Last year, he said, annual company payments for mining rights totaled $10 million to the Hopis and $23 million to the Navajos. ''We are a business. We make economic decisions,'' Mr. Sullivan said. ''The Hopi tribe is not a business. They don't make economic decisions. Their chairman indicates that this is a moral issue. I disagree with him.''
Speaking of the question of environmental damage, Vernon Masayesva, the Hopi tribal chairman, framed the dispute in much the same terms. ''When they set the damage criteria, they set just economic criteria,'' he said. ''They didn't set cultural damage criteria. When we see this amount of water being pumped, it bothers our conscience.''
In Hotevilla, the village elders, some of whom say the springs were planted by their forefathers, tend to the community's conscience. Still practicing the ancient rituals in this unpaved settlement of low stone dwellings and sacred spirit houses, they have forbidden the introduction of electricity or piped water, in part to preserve the ''hard life'' that the Hopis say will keep them close to their creator.
It is important, the elders say, that their water come from pure underground springs, and that their food come from their own farms. For fuel, glistening black piles of Peabody coal lie beside the sloping dirt paths.
''It is our religious responsibility to take care of the earth for the Creator,'' Mr. Honawa said. ''He offered everything that is on this earth. We have to use it moderately and not get greedy. We have to intervene somewhere and be the spokesperson for the Creator.''
The tribal council, for whom the Peabody payments make up close to 80 percent of the operating budget, is not seeking to close the mine. But it is demanding that the company use water from another source, or replace the slurry with new technology using methanol or with a railway.
 
Specialist Studies Springs
In its campaign to moderate Peabody's use of water, the Hopi tribal council has hired Steve Blodgett, a reclamation specialist, who spends part of his time exploring the area's springs, seeps and washes for surface signs of damage to the underground lake. Although the mines are on land shared by the Navajos and Hopis, it is the Hopis, with their traditional settlements and allegiance to the underground springs, rather than the more nomadic Navajos, who have been leading the battle against Peabody.
''What it comes down to is a gray area,'' Mr. Blodgett said as he walked along the twisting ''water caves'' carved eons ago into Blue Canyon by currents that he said emerged from the aquifer. ''The reality is that in a system this large, with as few data as you have, the only conclusion you can come to is you don't know.''
The Environmental Protection Agency, in a response to the report by the Office of Surface Mining, also said insufficient data had been collected to conclude that no environmental damage was being done.
In such a case, Mr. Blodgett said, the Department of the Interior is required by law to err on the side of environmental protection.
''If they keep on pumping and the government is wrong, the Hopi and Navajo people living around here are going to have to leave,'' he said.
 
Generations of Mistrust
At the village of Moenkopi, whose name in the Hopi language means ''the place where the water flows,'' Lewis Numkena, a 63-year-old farmer, described the generations of bewilderment and mistrust that have contributed to the Hopis' concern about the Peabody mine:
''My father said: 'I've learned a lot of things.' The white man can talk to you to make you do things. He can trick you into doing things with all this sweet talk.'
''My father told me that in the future, the white man is going to be starting to come in and he's going to grab what he can. Before you know it, this place is going to be full of white men, and they'll push you aside and say, 'This is mine.' ''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steve Blodgett, a reclamation specialist, inspecting a ''water cave'' at Blue Canyon in Arizona. Mr. Blodgett was hired by the Hopi tribal council as part of its campaign to moderate a coal company's use of water. (Monty Roessel for The New York Times); Map: Hotevilla, Ariz.

HEADLINE: Health Chief Rules Out Big Growth in Programs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
The Secretary of Health and Human Services today denounced ''those who call for a radical revamping of our health-care system,'' but he said the Bush Administration was looking for new ways to protect some of the 31 million Americans who lack health insurance.
In a speech in Atlanta, the first of a series that he plans on the subject, the Secretary, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, laid out the basic elements of the Administration's health policy. ''In an era of Federal fiscal constraints,'' he said, ''government dollars will never supplant private insurance.''
Likewise, he rejected Congressional efforts to require employers to provide workers with a package of basic health insurance benefits. 
''By adding overly burdensome mandates on business, we could retard economic growth and constrict employment opportunities,'' Dr. Sullivan said in the speech to the Atlanta Business Roundtable. ''Without job creation -or worse, with job destruction - we could end up with more, rather than fewer, persons lacking health insurance. If one does not have a job, one does not have access to employer-sponsored health care.''
Dr. Sullivan left the door open to unspecified incremental changes, but he ruled out a major expansion of Federal health programs of the type proposed recently by a 15-member bipartisan commission headed by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia.
 
Talking to the People
Dr. Sullivan said he was beginning ''a conversation with the American people on what they want from our health-care system and what we're willing to pay.''
In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 31, President Bush said he was asking Dr. Sullivan to ''lead a Domestic Policy Council review of recommendations on the quality, accessibility and cost of our nation's health-care system.'' Mr. Bush, like some of his predecessors, said he was ''committed to bring the staggering costs of health care under control.''
Dr. Sullivan has asked the Under Secretary of Health and Human Services, Constance Horner, to supervise the review of the way Americans pay for care provided by doctors, hospitals and nursing homes.
He said that there was no place for ''nationalized medicine'' in the United States, and that Canada's experience with a national health plan was of little relevance to this country.
''At a time when most Americans are receiving the finest health care in the world, I find it remarkable to hear some people proposing that we scrap the system and make a radical reform to nationalized medicine,'' Dr. Sullivan said. ''They often point to Canada as a model. But the Canadian system has some very serious problems, including long waiting lists for critical medical procedures and de facto rationing. This, I contend, would never suit Americans.'' More Preventive Services? In March, Senator Rockefeller's group, the Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, recommended a program to provide health insurance and long-term care to all Americans who need such coverage. The panel did not specify how to pay the extra Federal cost of such care, estimated at $66 billion a year.
Last week the commission voted to recommend that the Federal Government help low-income elderly people pay Medicare charges, and it said Medicare should be expanded to pay for more preventive services.
In addition, the panel called for new Federal standards to eliminate abuses in the sale of commercial insurance supplementing Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled.
Dr. Sullivan said he accepted the premise that ''everyone should be able to obtain necessary health care.'' But he said, ''the present private-public health system should be the primary means by which we achieve this goal.''
Thus, he said, private health insurers should not be squeezed out of the market by expansion of Federal health programs. Rather, he said, ''more Americans should be able to obtain health insurance,'' and ''the nation's health care must remain essentially a free-market system.''
''Those who call for a radical revamping of our health-care system, suggesting nationalized medicine, are mistaken,'' Dr. Sullivan said. ''We need to build on our achievements by getting an even higher percentage of people covered by insurance, rather than replacing our system with something that Americans do not need and would not tolerate.''
