HEADLINE: What's Wrong With Legalizing Drugs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The call for drug legalization by Jann S. Wenner, publisher of Rolling Stone magazine (''Drug War: Another Vietnam,'' Op-Ed, June 23), shows dangerous ignorance about our nation's drug crisis.
Mr. Wenner asks alarmingly: ''Would legalization produce a flood of new addicts? With crack, which is abhorred by society at large, this question is simply irrelevant.'' Yet how can this be irrelevant if addicts are dying due to crack use while we choose to look the other way? ''Abhorred by society at large?'' The society to which Mr. Wenner refers is obviously not the one being oppressed by the drug pushers who control the streets and corrupt young minds before antidrug education programs can reach them - that is, if these communities are fortunate enough to have such programs. Many do not, but what child would pay attention to warnings by a Government that gave up the fight against drugs? Many people would wish the problem away by legalizing illicit drugs, thus abolishing the black market. Unfortunately, this vision is unrealistic and deadly. 
Mr. Wenner states, ''Legalization would eliminate the inner-city violence associated with competitive drug dealing.'' Under legalization, drugs will be cheaper and readily accessible, which will in turn increase use and the number of addicts. He concedes this, stating, ''If the legalization of drugs will result in a few more abusers, let us accept the consequences.'' Although illegal drug trafficking violence will be gone, a new crime source will be created from this influx of new addicts. Hyperactive reactions to such drugs as cocaine will spur criminal behavior.
In addition to escalating health costs under any scheme of legalization, what type of health care for addicts would we provide? Mr. Wenner offers, ''Most middle-class Americans have access to a social safety net.'' What about the poverty-stricken people in whose cities deaths from drug abuse exceed those in middle-class areas? Addicts who stay in treatment have a better chance of reducing their drug dependency, and under legal compulsion, they stay in the programs longer, reducing dependency and often becoming working members of society. Under legalization, with no legal compulsion, addicts will not pay much attention to warnings by clinicians, much less become involved in the long-range treatment vital to calming dependency.
 
Rep.) CHARLES B. RANGEL
Chairman, House Select Committee
on Narcotics Abuse and Control
 Washington, July 5, 1990

HEADLINE: New York City Needs Strategic Planning to Keep From Drifting

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The recently approved New York City budget contains many sensible compromises and unavoidable disappointments. But the failure to appropriate funds for the Office of Strategic Planning in the City Planning Department makes no sense at all.
For years, the members of the Civic Affairs Forum, 40 of the city's leading civic groups, urged creation of such an office. Finally, Mayor Edward I. Koch established it in 1988. Its demise betrays startling shortsightedness on the part of Mayor David N. Dinkins's administration. 
The City Planning Commission was created in 1938 to provide the long-range citywide view, but over the years, the city has been slow to uncover and respond to fundamental changes. These changes have been lost in the noise of crisis management, the detail of hands-on planning and the traps of mere project and program review. In examining the city's planning process and its results, the Civic Affairs Forum has found, again and again, cases where the city has been shortsighted or caught needlessly off guard.
Some examples:
* The failure to treat mass transit as the lifeline of the city's economy.
* The deterioration of the city's physical infrastructure.
* The multiple crisis of waste disposal: solid, liquid and air borne.
* The impact on the city's economy of major technological changes.
* The mismatch between education, training and employment.
* The unmet income, service and housing needs of the poor, which have contributed to the alarming rise in homelessness.
Too often, the city has failed to shape a future that only leadership can create - opportunities to be discovered through a long and broader view of issues and options. Opportunities that could be advanced through comprehensive planning for employment, housing, waterfront development and other areas. Even when changes and opportunities have finally been acknowledged, action has been limited, weak in resources, scattered and poorly coordinated.
The Office of Strategic Planning should be reinstated with these responsibilities:
* To spot opportunities, project trends - technological, demographic, social, economic, environmental -and describe their implications.
* To identify, in light of opportunities and trends, program areas that require special planning action.
* To coordinate development of plans and secure firm, long-term commitments to carry them out.
Strategic planning is not a luxury and not deferable. Without it, New York City will fall far short of its potential. At worst, it will be overwhelmed by market forces, outwitted by international, interregional and intermunicipal competition and be defenseless against the inertia of business as usual and the local politics of ''not in my backyard.'' We therefore strongly urge Mayor Dinkins to restore funds for the Office of Strategic Planning.
 
STANLEY TURKEL
Chairman, Civic Affairs Forum
 New York, July 3, 1990

HEADLINE: The S & L Horror Show: Act II

BYLINE: By Charles Schumer; Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, is a member of the House Banking Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As an outraged public reviews the first act of the savings and loan disaster - a horror show of swindling, administrative delusions and Congressional and regulatory bungling - the curtain is rising on yet another gruesome sight: the execution of the bailout itself.
Act II of the savings and loan fiasco actually began the moment the bailout law was passed in August 1989. The bill, known as the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act, or Firrea, was a complicated scheme of regulations and relief. The law was supposed to carefully direct tens of billions of dollars into sick thrifts under the close scrutiny of the Administration. But almost immediately, the Bush Administration, including the President himself, ignored the bailout in hopes it would take care of itself. 
A year of delay and inattention has taken a heavy toll. Several voices are calling out orders but no single hand is on the steering wheel. No one can guess the ultimate price tag for this confusion, but the $40 billion to $80 billion of new money that, last month, Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas Brady said he needed is only a down payment.
It is no exaggeration to say that the dollar costs of the bailout are rising by the minute. This is an emergency. While it is a cliche that there is enough blame to go around for the savings and loan ripoff, there are some things that, at this point, only the President can do. How can the damage be contained? Put the bailout on budget - now. When the cost of the bailout was placed off-budget, the American people lost. Interest payments on this money are going to cost taxpayers at least $300 billion over the next 40 years.
Almost more disheartening, putting the cleanup off-budget whetted the ambition of many Administration officials to sweep the thrift crisis under the rug. Some now want ''continuous authorization'' of bailout funds - a fine print way of guaranteeing that politicians will never again have to ask, publicly, for new money to cover mounting costs.
Delay and deception have already cost this country dearly; the President must move to restore credibility to the bailout process. An on-budget cleanup would save taxpayers billions of dollars and show the nation that from now on the bailout will be dealt with openly and expeditiously. Centralize authority. We are in a crisis that will cost more than all of World War II. Like a war, the thrift cleanup desperately needs a five-star general to lead it. Bureaucratic turf fights are diverting energy from the task and destroying the morale of many valuable public servants. The health of the economy is at stake.
The Resolution Trust Corporation, which must successfully and carefully dispose of tens of billions of dollars in seized assets, needs decisive, central leadership. I recommend to Mr. Bush that he make a very humble phone call to its chairman, L. William Seidman, and not only beg him to remain in his job but strengthen his authority.
The plain-speaking Mr. Seidman is being undermined and forced out by White House backbiting and press leaks, yet he is the only man with the experience, skill and integrity to prudently, but efficiently, run the monstrous R.T.C. Mr. Bush ought to realize - fast - that he cannot afford to lose him.
If Mr. Seidman cannot be persuaded to stay past the expiration of his term in October, a search for a replacement with the same superior qualifications cannot be delayed.
Implement clear guidelines for the speedy disposition of assets. For too long, the R.T.C. has lacked simple procedures to carry out some of its most fundamental transactions. We cannot afford a trial-by-error bail-out.
Bureaucrats in the bowels of the regulatory agencies, shell-shocked by the scandal, have been afraid to make even easy decisions without guidelines from above. As a result, thousands of those interested in buying R.T.C. properties and institutions cannot get facts or answers to simple questions, costing the taxpayers untold millions as the value of these assets declines daily.
For seven months, when the Bush Administration had 413 insolvent thrifts under its conservatorship, it made only 66 mostly small deals that were badly flawed. Rather than sell a thrift whole, and give the purchaser responsibility for managing the assets, the R.T.C. too often sold only the lucrative corporate shell. The Government is absorbing heavy losses.
The $169 billion estimate of how much the bailout will cost assumes no errors in management. A vastly strengthened R.T.C. leadership must quickly formulate strict and consistent rules for the disposal of the taxpayers' property.
George Bush might not have imagined the size of the savings and loan mess when he campaigned for President. But if the chaos continues to mushroom, he - and the voters -will have no one else to blame.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: Rinfret Attacks Cuomo Fiscal Policies

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
The Cuomo administration is ''burning the furniture for firewood'' by borrowing extensively, using one-time revenues to fill budget gaps and dipping into state reserve funds, Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor, said yesterday.
Issuing a comprehensive review of the state's borrowing, Mr. Rinfret, an economic forecaster, said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's fiscal policies had produced $18 billion in borrowing in the last eight years, or $1,056 for every state resident - more than any of 26 states have borrowed in their entire histories.
''Can anyone doubt our state finances are out of control?'' asked Mr. Rinfret. ''Can anyone doubt that we are mortgaging our future?'' 
''We are burning the furniture for firewood in Albany, putting unneeded burdens on ourselves and future generations, all to keep up the pretense that the Governor knows how to manage the state's affairs,'' he said.
Mr. Rinfret's six-page single-spaced document, released at news conferences in Manhattan and Albany, represented a major plank in his campaign platform, which seeks to emphasize the Democratic Governor's fiscal shortcomings and Mr. Rinfret's strength as an economist.
Last week, Mr. Rinfret issued his first campaign paper on state spending and taxes, which he said were the highest in the nation.
 
'An Orgy of Borrowing'
Much of the language of yesterday's document was couched in the lively, unbureacratic idioms that Mr. Rinfret, as a writer on economics, was known for before he entered the political arena two months ago.
He described the Cuomo fiscal policies in terms like ''raiders of the lost reserves,'' ''spending 21st-century money today,'' ''cadging and pilfering'' and ''an orgy of borrowing.''
Governor Cuomo's press secretary, Gary Fryer, said he could not respond in detail yesterday but described the Rinfret paper as ''warmed over Assembly Republican minority propaganda.''
In his analysis, Mr. Rinfret divided the state's borrowing into several categories: borrowing approved by the voters under the State Constitution, ''backdoor'' borrowing by authorities that does not require voter approval, rolling over short-term debt from year to year, tapping reserves of various state agencies, refinancing debt at higher interest rates, reducing pension fund payments and selling off capital assets.
His language was reminiscent of Democratic attacks on Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, a Republican, for his ''backdoor'' financing of the State University system, the Empire State Plaza in Albany and other capital projects.
 
'Whole Sordid Mess'
Mr. Rinfret spelled out year by year the ''whole sordid mess,'' starting in 1985 with what he called a $255 million ''windfall'' by having the state's Urban Development Corporation borrow money for new prison construction and refinancing existing prisons that had already been paid for.
A year later, he said, the state 'raided'' the State Insurance Fund for $325 million, the first of a series of withdrawals from that fund that now amount to $875 million, and the Battery Park City Authority for $69 million.
In 1987, ''like a confirmed kleptomaniac,'' the administration again borrowed from the insurance fund, $133 million from the tax reserve fund and $53 million from the State University bond reserve fund, Mr. Rinfret said.
In 1988, the state insurance fund was again tapped, along with $110 million from the Aggregate Trust Fund, a workers' compensation reserve, and $32 million from the State Dormitory Authority and other authorities. The state also raised $123 million by remortgaging the Empire State Plaza and also issued $460 million in short-term bonds that were supposed to be paid off within that year.
''As revenues continued to fall behind spending, Cuomo began breaking open every piggy bank in sight,'' Mr. Rinfret said of 1989. The State Insurance Fund, the Aggregate Trust Fund, the Hazardous Waste Remedial Fund, the Housing Finance Agency and the Court Facilities Fund were ''raided'' for a total of more than $356 million. The previous year's $460 million short-term borrowing was rolled over and $850 million added to it, he said.
 
Deferred Payments
Mr. Rinfret said the current year's ''one shot'' revenues include deferred payments to the State Employees Pension Fund and a formula change in the Teachers Retirement System; refinancing of State and City University debt, probably at higher interest rates; a $150 million Battery Park City Authority loan, with the proceeds going to New York City; the surrender of below-market-rate leases at the World Trade Center for $200 million, and a plan to sell the Cross-Westchester Expressway to the State Thruway Authority for $200 million. The nonrecurring revenues totaled $1.8 billion.
Mr. Rinfret brushed off the State Senate Republican majority's approval of these ''gimmicks'' by arguing that Mr. Cuomo was the state's chief executive.
''The present Governor has failed by every standard,'' Mr. Rinfret said. ''His 'compassion' has only been a cover for his inability to manage the state's affairs. If he spends us into bankruptcy, everyone - rich and poor - will suffer.''

HEADLINE: Faldo Uses Dedication To Reach Higher Levels

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ

DATELINE: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 23

 BODY:
Nick Faldo calls it ''the circle,'' a personal continuum that begins with dedication and leads to improvement, spawning renewed enthusiasm for his simple but all-consuming goal: to be the best golfer in the world.
In the four years since Faldo first closed this inspirational circle, it has become concentrically smaller and more rapid, particularly when a major championship is at its center. On Sunday, a glorious day at the Old Course, Faldo scored the fourth and best bull's-eye of his career by winning the 119th British Open by five shots.
''If you are constantly working on things, trying to get better, it's a great pressure release,'' Faldo explained today for journalists looking for an answer to the flawless consistency he exhibited for four rounds at St. Andrews. ''You see improvement, you stay focused on small goals, and you keep ticking along. It's all part of the circle.'' 
Faldo will still be on a rapid spin cycle in two weeks, when he arrives in Birmingham, Ala., to try to win the P.G.A. Championship at Shoal Creek Country Club. If he conquers the oppressive humidity likely there and the just-as-uncomfortable pressure of expectations, he will become the first player to win three major championships in one year since Ben Hogan won the Masters, the United States Open and the British Open in 1953.
 
Putt That Missed
But for a lipped-out 15-foot birdie putt on the 72d hole at the United States Open at Medinah in June that would have earned him a spot in a playoff with Hale Irwin and Mike Donald, Faldo might have been shooting at the ultimate bull's-eye at Shoal Creek: the modern Grand Slam.
''It's very difficult, but it's not impossible,'' Faldo said today of the Grand Slam. ''David Leadbetter said at the beginning of the year that I was capable of winning two majors a year, which I thought at the time was unbelievable.''
But Faldo has done just that, combining his victory at the Masters in April with his victory Sunday. And the key may be Leadbetter, a teacher whom Faldo went to in 1985 when he was a highly successful but, by his own standards, incomplete golfer. The previous year, Faldo had failed in the final rounds of the Masters, the British Open and the P.G.A. Championship, and he wanted a swing that would hold up in the majors.
 
Swing Is Upgraded
Leadbetter rated Faldo's swing, then very wristy, at ''about a 6'' on a scale of 10, and told him it would take two years to get results. The English golfer then showed the dedication that distinguishes him by agreeing to do whatever it took. And after two indifferent seasons, right on schedule, Faldo won the 1987 British Open at Muirfield and then the Masters in 1989.
Leadbetter now ranks Faldo's swing ''a 9 1/2, sometimes a 10,'' and says Faldo is the most knowledgeable practicioner of the golf swing he has ever worked with.
''He's like a building now,'' Leadbetter said recently. ''All I'm doing now is giving him a lick of paint or touching up a crack.''
As he proved at St. Andrews, Faldo possesses a swing that is extremely economical for a long-limbed man who stands 6 feet 3 inches tall. He maneuvered his wood and iron shots over and around the treacherous sands and gorse of the Old Course with so much control that he seemed immune to the ancient ground's often capricious bounces.
''It seems unbelievable that I went through all that searching so recently, it seems moons ago,'' Faldo said.
But Faldo, who turned 33 years old last Wednesday, still believes he has a lot of learning to do.
 
Age No Factor
''The way I've progressed in the last three years has nothing to do with age,'' he said. ''Really, I think I can compete at the top level for the rest of this decade.''
With his recent accomplishments, the temptations to break his inspirational circle will be great. Faldo's agent, John Simpson of International Management Group, said today that his client's British Open victory Sunday would eventually be worth $10 million in income. In a few weeks, Faldo is planning to start a golf-course-design company that will charge about $1 million per project, and his tournament appearance fees, already near $100,000 per event in Europe or Japan, will also increase.
To further concentrate on the four major championships, Faldo said, he will reduce his playing schedule from the 30 tournaments he will play this year to about 25 next year. A maximum of only 10 of those will be in the United States.
 
Avoiding a 'Burnout'
''Eventually I will cut back drastically,'' Faldo said. ''It's all part of our plan not to rush around. There will be no burnout because I won't get pushed when I don't want to go.''
In the meantime, the circle will continue.
''I don't like to think about whether I'm the best player in the game,'' Faldo said Sunday after his victory. ''It's so much of a week-to-week thing; it's better to simply be concerned with improving. But when it's over, I'd most like to be remembered as someone who could really play the game. I want people to say in years to come: 'Did you see Nick Faldo play in his heyday? I did, and it was quite something.' ''
And even if Faldo never wins another championship, those who saw him at St. Andrews in 1990 will be able to say just that.

HEADLINE: Mighty Fire Ants March Out of the South

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS

DATELINE: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.

 BODY:
IN the annals of entomological villainy, few insects are as despised, as feared and as meticulously investigated as the tiny imported fire ant, which attacks humans, animals, plants, other insects and even electrical devices.
Government and private researchers have spent hundreds of millions of dollars in unsuccessful efforts to eradicate the ferocious little arthropod, which is no larger than the ''G'' at the start of this sentence. Scientists are mapping its mitochondrial DNA and studying its most intimate chemical scents. Frustrated homeowners spend tens of millions more on the counterattack, with tactics ranging from pesticides to electric prods, even fighting fire ants with fire.
Yet true to its name, Solenopsis invicta, from the Latin for ''invincible,'' has marched through the South like General Sherman. From its initial pincer-hold in Mobile, Ala., where it arrived on a ship from South America half a century ago, invicta now infests 250 million acres in 11 Southern states. 
Researchers say it has just established a successful colony in Santa Barbara, Calif., its first foray into the country's richest agricultural state. Entomologists say invicta also seems to be undergoing a fundamental evolution in its social system, establishing giant colonies with multiple queens instead of the smaller and more manageable single-queen colonies that had been characteristic.
''It's just a matter of time before we have fire ant infestations in California and Arizona that we cannot control,'' said Dr. William P. MacKay, a specialist in ant ecology and systematics at the Fire Ant Laboratory at Texas A & M University here. ''It's going to go all the way up the West Coast, all the way to Washington State.'' Colonies have been found as far north as Virginia.
The ant's inexorable spread has occurred not only in spite of, but partly because of, nearly four decades of determined campaigns to eradicate it with chemical pesticides. Through it all, the fire ant has thrived because the pesticides destroyed its enemies and paved the way for far larger colonies than had previously existed. An airborne pesticide assault in the 1960's and 70's, designed to eradicate the ant from American soil, has been described by the Harvard biologist Edward O. Wilson as ''the Vietnam of entomology.'' A more modest attempt to control the ant with pesticide applications on the ground also failed.
The campaigns backfired, many entomologists say, because the efforts to kill invicta with the chemicals chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin and mirex were effective only in wiping out the ant's natural enemies, principally other ant species, and parasites, thus making it easier for the ant to spread.
The pesticides also killed birds and other non-target species. Mirex, in particular, left significant residues in human and animal tissues. Mirex was determined to be a possible human carcinogen in 1977, and the Government's aerial spraying was halted in 1978.
Today, in a reversal, most state and Federal agencies now discourage the use of pesticides against the ant. They urge the public to learn to live with the ant, which is more a nuisance than a health hazard, and they hold out hope that scientists will enlist beneficial organisms to attack the ants or develop new compounds to disrupt their reproduction.
But agriculture officials said there was again growing pressure from farmers and ranchers to explore the option of spraying. The cost of such a new program would be prohibitive, the officials said.
Adversity seems to have brought invicta new strength. Initially the species had a single queen ant in each colony, and each colony was fiercely territorial. As a result, researchers said, the average density of infestation was rarely greater than 20 or 30 mounds an acre.
But researchers have recently found that single-queen colonies are being driven out by ''supercolonies'' containing multiple queens and tens of millions of workers. Researchers do not know what is causing the change, but they note that the older single-queen colonies, which were a nuisance, are now viewed as the best defense against the newer, more powerful colonies, which are an economic disaster.
In Texas, where the multiple-queen colonies now outnumber single-queen colonies, densities of 450 mounds an acre have been reported. In a draft report prepared for the Texas Fire Ant Advisory Board, the state Department of Agriculture estimated that fire ants caused $47 million in crop losses and pest control expenses in the state last year.
No national loss figures are available. ''We don't see any hope at this point of eliminating the pest from the United States,'' said William A. Banks, a fire ant researcher at the United States Department of Agriculture's fire ant research service in Gainesville, Fla. ''The hope is that we can find better ways of coping, so that we can learn to live with it.''
 
If Bite's Bad, Sting's Worse
The prospect of peaceful co-existence with invicta is hard for many Southerners to accept, especially for those who know its sting, which is often mistakenly referred to as a bite. The ant does bite, but only to anchor itself while it stings. Unlike bees, which eviscerate themselves with each sting, the fire ant stings repeatedly with a gusto that belies its size.
The bite is sometimes felt as a minor irritation, but the sting is immediately sensed as a burning sensation, worse than a mosquito bite but not as painful as a bee sting. It is common for people to be stung many times, since the ants are highly aggressive and swarm onto an intruder in seconds. Some victims have reported suffering hundreds of stings.
A sting later results in redness and swelling and, because invicta injects bacteria along with its alkaloid venom, creates a small pustule on the skin. The pustule, typically the size of a pinhead, later causes itching, and sometimes the pustules leave small brown scars that last for months.
Fire ant stings are potentially fatal to people who are allergic to bee stings and other venoms. Ryan Wingard, a 2-year-old in Anderson, Tex., nearly died in May when he was stung by fire ants in his yard. His mother noticed that he was having trouble breathing, and soon Ryan's lips turned blue, his tongue swelled and red blotches appeared on his body. He was rushed to the hospital and treated for a severe allergic reaction. For Ryan and many others in the South, playing or picnicking in the grass is now just a memory.
''I went to Willie Nelson's Fourth of July picnic and watched people popping up like popcorn, slapping their legs,'' said Dr. Edward Vargo, an entomologist studying fire ants at the University of Texas's Balcones Research Center in Austin.
 
Indiscriminating Palate
Dr. Vargo noted that the multiple-queen colonies can be elaborate structures that comprise hundreds of mounds covering dozens of acres, allowing worker ants - sterile females - to forage with astonishing efficiency. ''Basically, anything that stands still for longer than 15 or 20 seconds is fire ant food,'' he said.
Food, to a fire ant, is a broad term. Its diet includes everything from insects to germinating crop seeds to the rubber expansion joints on highway bridges. The ants feed day or night, as long as the temperature is 70 to 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
The impact on the ecology is especially worrisome to researchers, who note that invicta drives out other ant and insect species, including native fire ants, which are less aggressive. Increasingly, landowners say the ants are driving off ground-nesting birds, lizards, rabbits and larger wildlife. The Small Animal Clinic in the College of Veterinary Medicine at Texas A & M has treated 28 fawns this year for severe fire ant stings.
Because invicta is omnivorous, it also has some benefits. Invicta attacks corn worms, boll weevils and other costly agricultural pests, and is actually welcomed on cotton and sugar cane fields. The fire ant has also shown a fondness for fleas. However, ''Using fire ants to control the flea population does seem a lot like trading a headache for an upset stomach,'' said Kathy Palma, a researcher at Texas A & M. Fire ants do not live by food alone, Dr. MacKay at Texas A & M reported. He has found that the ant is attracted to electrical fields, the stronger the better. It is common for the ants to swarm on electrical relay switches inside air-conditioning units, until their charred bodies cause a short circuit. Municipal officials throughout Texas say fire ants are the leading cause of traffic light failures. Telephone companies say the ants can knock out switching devices. Dr. MacKay said the ants have been found in aircraft altimeters, in computers, and even in the electronic gear in boats and submarines.
The ants are aquatic at times, stinging people in swimming pools and rivers. In flood conditions hundreds or thousands of workers will form a living raft to carry the queen and her larvae to safety. Some researchers suggest that such living rafts will help carry invicta west.
 
Fatal Mating Flight
More commonly, the ants hitchhike in shipments of grass sod, trees and other nursery stock. They also spread as the queens seek new homes after their mysterious nuptial flights. Only queens and males develop wings, and because fire ants do not mate in captivity, and because it is difficult to observe tiny insects frolicking 500 to 800 feet in the air, researchers surmise that the mating is airborne.
On the first sunny day after rain, Southerners can see hundreds of winged male fire ants emerge from the soil and ascend on a sexual kamikaze mission. They fly only once, rising to several hundred feet, where they compete to mate with a flying queen who has summoned them by some unknown chemical signal. Only one will succeed, and then all the males, perhaps exhausted, fall back to earth to their deaths.
''If they mate they die happy, and if they don't, they die anyway,'' said Dr. Daniel Clair, an urban pest management specialist with the Texas Department of Agriculture.
The fertilized queen sheds her wings, burrows and either starts a new colony or joins an existing one. She stores the sperm from her nuptial flight, and for the next five or six years produces offspring, often laying her own weight in eggs each day.
Chastened by the failure of pesticides, researchers are focusing on two areas: chemical growth regulators and biological controls.
Dr. Vargo and others are trying to isolate and synthesize the chemical signals, or pheromones, given off by invicta queens. Pheromones are chemicals that act on other individuals, unlike hormones, which act within an individual.
 
Wanted: an Enemy
Among the queen pheromones of particular interest to researchers are signals that cause workers to assassinate rival queens and signals that keep immature females from developing sexually. If such pheromones can be developed, they could disrupt communications in the colony and the ants would eventually die.
The most promising chemical control, said Ronald Mulder of the Texas Department of Agriculture, is fenoxycarb ethyl, essentially a ''birth control'' agent that destroys the ovaries of sexual female ants. It is sold commercially under the brand name Logic and is believed to be much more environmentally safe than pesticides. To the frustration of homeowners, Logic is also slower acting, taking three to six months after a springtime application to take effect.
Dr. MacKay said there was also promise in biological controls. He and other entomologists who have visited invicta's native home in South America found that the ant was much less of a problem there than in the United States.
He said invicta mounds in Brazil are shared by several types of parasitic ants, beetles, wasps and flies. If one of these or some other natural fire ant enemy can be identified as a control agent and brought to the United States, assuming it does not pose a threat worse than fire ants, it could help keep invicta in check.
How about South American anteaters? ''The ones that could do the job are four feet tall with claws that could take your arm off,'' said Mr. Banks of the United States Agriculture Department. ''If we imported enough anteaters to have an impact, in a few years we'd be looking for something to control the anteaters.''

HEADLINE: A Revolution as the Bolshoi Meets Capitalism

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF

 BODY:
''I'm the bandit who sold out the Bolshoi Theater,'' Vladimir Kokonin, the 52-year-old general director of Moscow's grand opera house, said in New York the other day. Just joking, of course, he added.
Mr. Kokonin - a musician despite his well-heeled, corporate mien -was defending a commercial agreement that he insists is essential to the future success of the Bolshoi's ballet and opera companies.
The Bolshoi Ballet, which closed in New York on Sunday and continues its United States tour with an opening tonight at Wolf Trap Farm Park in Vienna, Va., outside Washington, has already seen the results of Mr. Kokonin's attempt to restructure his organization and its touring. 
This summer, all dancers in the Bolshoi corps are being paid a per-diem allowance of $50, twice as much as in the past. Gone, presumably, are the days when Soviet dancers, saving their daily allowances to buy everything from gold chains to videocassette recorders and computers, ate only canned food from home or very little else. Shopping is still on the company's mind: the first container ship to depart with goods purchased by members of the Bolshoi reportedly carried 14 refrigerators.
 
'A New Atmosphere'
But under a newly negotiated arrangement, the Bolshoi company received, in addition to a higher daily allowance, breakfast every morning at the Ginger Man restaurant near Lincoln Center or two meals there on days off. Charles Dillingham, the president of the Entertainment Corporation, the Bolshoi Ballet's British-American producer, said his organization also provided a daily lunch to the Soviet dancers in the New York State Theater. He added that the company's two-week season there had played ''to over 90 percent capacity, with the last four days sold out.''
''It's a revolution for us,'' Mr. Kokonin said, speaking in Russian in an interview in his hotel over the weekend. ''For the first time, the artists are getting decent pay, by European standards at least. And you see the dancers acting and feeling differently. There is a new atmosphere.''
''The lowest-ranked dancer will get $1,500 in a 30-day period on this tour,'' he continued. '' As for the principals, they will average $1,000 per performance.''
Mr. Kokonin said that in the past, even a Bolshoi veteran like Maya Plisetskaya had to give back 80 percent of her touring fee to Goscontsert, the Soviet Government concert management agency. The Bolshoi Ballet itself could keep only 20 percent, with the rest going to the agency.
 
Three New Goals
Faced with economic change in the Soviet Union, a need to earn hard currency and a political freedom that allows artists to leave for the West, the Bolshoi Theater is trying to achieve three goals that Mr. Kokonin considers crucial to its operation.
One goal is a reform of management procedures to decrease the theater's dependence on state subsidy and allow greater incentives to the Bolshoi's artists: for example, more-competitive pay on tour.
A second objective is to change to the kind of contract system common in the West. The Bolshoi Ballet technically has no power to retain a dancer who leaves for the West, since it has no individual contracts with its dancers. The artists' job security is covered under general Soviet law. At the same time, the theater has needed the assent of the finance and cultural ministries to raise individual salaries, which would be negotiated directly with the dancers under a contract system. The contract arrangement would clarify the relationship between the dancers and management, allowing the latter to retire older artists who have had life tenure under the old system.
A third goal, Mr. Kokonin said, is to remove the influence of the Communist Party committee within the theater from administrative and artistic matters.
''If we do things the old way, the Bolshoi remains a conservative theater, and it will be a theater in crisis,'' he said, ''Things must change.''
 
Rising 'as a Professional'
Trained at the Moscow Conservatory, Mr. Kokonin became a clarinetist in the Bolshoi orchestra. Mikhail Chulaki, a composer who was the Bolshoi Theater's general director, encouraged him to join the Culture Ministry when its head, Yekaterina Furtseva, was ''interested in training young cadres,'' Mr. Kokonin said. Mr. Chulaki told him that if his heart were really with the Bolshoi Theater, he would serve it best by returning in 25 years. ''I did in 23,'' he said.
During the interview, he pointed to a book on a table and noted that he had been reading Talleyrand, but he did not note that that this historical figure in the French Revolution was notorious for changing his political complexion.
Mr. Kokonin said that although he was a member of the Communist Party, he did not rise in the cultural bureaucracy through a party training school but rather ''as a professional.'' His first stint at the ministry was followed by 11 years as artistic director of Goscontsert, followed by a high post with financial responsibilities at the Bolshoi, and then a couple of years at the head of the culture ministry's music department. He was named the Bolshoi's general director in 1988, with overall authority over both the ballet and opera troupes.
Turning to the role of the Communist Party in the theater's management, Mr. Kokonin said: ''As in every Soviet institution, and this is still largely true, the Bolshoi Theater has had two parallel structures: the party committee and an adminstration. The party structure decided who would go on tour or not. There were no limits on its power.''
Asked if his increased authority stems from the chaos of a transitional period, Mr. Kokonin replied immediately: ''No. This is perestroika, which is not a slogan and not just another campaign. It creates a difficult situation, but it gives us the right to work freely. We have a second chance through the restructuring of the economy. The conservatives want to take us back.''
''What I don't want is the aggressiveness that has marked so much of our lives, a repetition of the exclusions aginst Boris Pasternak and Mstislav Rostropovich, but now directed against Yuri Grigorovich. Our theater party secretary would like to banish him as ballet director. But his work is part of our history, and you can't tear out that page. It is part of a single Russian culture.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (88%); EUROPE (79%); CENTRAL EUROPE (57%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (93%); WASHINGTON, USA (77%); 

CITY: MOSCOW, RUSSIAN FEDERATION (88%); OLYMPIA, WA, USA (77%);

Markets
Stock prices fell sharply, with program trading contributing heavily to a big early selloff. [Page D1.] The drop in stock prices reflects growing worries about the economy, especially the erosion of corporate profits, as well as a market that has grown increasingly fragile. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [A1.]

The dollar fell sharply against most European currencies, hitting a two-and-a-half-year low against the German mark. [D17.]
Gold futures prices surged to their highest levels in two months as lower stock prices, a weaker dollar and signs of Middle Eastern buying revived the interest of investors. [D17.]
 
 
 
The Economy
A former aide to George Bush who helped buy an insolvent Oklahoma bank from Federal regulators invested $100,000 with an official who had been involved in the negotiations, according to public records and participants in the deal. [A1.] The Senate Ethics Committee was asked to open an inquiry into the conduct of Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum and his staff in their investigation of specific savings and loan deals. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Accor Is Gambling on U.S. Motels

BYLINE: By JACQUES NEHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 23

 BODY:
The $1.3 billion deal by the French hotel and restaurant company Accor S.A. to purchase Motel 6, the Dallas-based chain of economy motels, may be the boldest move yet by two executives already known for their boldness and management skills.
In fact, the pair, Paul Dubrule and Gerard Pelisson, Accor's co-chairmen, are often called the ''dynamic duo'' in the French press. Many industry analysts say they are among the best managers in France in their ability to capture new business with adroit marketing.
The way the two presented their proposal to their 12-member management team reflects their direct style and also their selling ability.
''They told us we could sit on our behinds and just wait for our profit-sharing dividends; that our jobs would become uninteresting and we would probably fall asleep,'' recalls an executive who attended the meeting. ''Or else, they told us, we could make a bold move by buying Motel 6, and provide ourselves a challenge well into the next century. But it was for us to decide, not them.'' 
Not surprising, the outcome of the meeting was the announcement July 13 of Accor's $22.50-a-depository-unit tender offer for Motel 6, which operates 536 motels in 42 states. Depository units trade like common stock but represent shares in a limited partnership.
If the acquisition goes through, as expected, Accor will become the world's biggest hotel owner and operator, ahead of the Marriott Corporation, in terms of rooms under direct management.
''We showed that it was now the time to move, to be the leader in this market not only in Europe, but in the United States,'' Mr. Dubrule said in an interview at Accor's 27th-floor office in Paris. He was alluding to Accor's success with the Formule 1 low-priced motel chain started in 1985 and which now has 142 motels, most of them in France.
The Motel 6 purchase is practically assured because Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company has agreed to sell its remaining 55 percent stake in the motel chain to Accor. Kohlberg, Kravis bought Motel 6 in its entirety in 1985 for $881 million.
Some dissident Motel 6 shareholders have filed suits seeking to block the sale, but an Accor spokesman said, ''We have absolutely no worry about the sale going through.''
Mr. Dubrule, who is 56 years old, and Mr. Pelisson, who is 58, started in business together in 1967, opening their first Novotel hotel, at the Lille airport in northern France. They now sit atop a diversified hotel, food service and leisure group company that reported 1989 sales of 19.9 billion francs, about $3.4 billion.
Accor - a name the men chose in 1983 partly because it sounds just like the French pronunciation of accord, or agreement - operates five major hotel chains: Sofitel, Novotel, Mercure, Ibis/Urbis and Formule 1. It also has several resort hotels. The company's main headquarters are in Evry, a suburb south of Paris.
Accor's American operations include two mid-priced Novotel motels, in New York and New Jersey, and six higher-priced Sofitel hotels, in Chicago, Minneapolis, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Miami and Houston.
The corporation's food operations consist of a variety of restaurants and catering services, including the caterer Lenotre, and a highly profitable restaurant voucher service called Ticket Restaurant, marketed to companies as an employee benefit. The vouchers, which are accepted at most restaurants in France, allow employees to buy lunches at greatly reduced cost.
In addition, Accor has minority stakes in a cruise ship company, seawater therapy health spas, several large French casinos and the Asterix amusement park near Paris.
 
Earnings Surge
Accor's net earnings rose 29 percent last year, to 606.1 million francs ($104.7 million). It was a performance that market analysts have come to expect.
Mr. Dubrule, who worked in the United States in the early 1960's, is described by people who work with him as Accor's leading voice in long-term strategy, employee relations and marketing. Mr. Pelisson, who has a degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and served as a top manager at IBM Europe, is respected as an expert with financial figures.
''These guys are pretty smart cookies,'' said Ricaldo Zavala, international director for Magnin S.A., a Paris stockbroker. ''We've seen 20 percent annual growth for the last 15 years, which is a pretty impressive track record.'' He added that Accor was the ''only company in France'' in which earnings could be expected to grow for the next decade.''
With Motel 6, Accor will have some 80,000 employees and will gain a major foothold in the United States, where it has been struggling without much success since 1979. In recent years it has sold off its fledgling Ibis hotels in Texas and Georgia, as well as the Seafood Broiler chain of 28 restaurants in California.
Last year, Accor lost 15 million francs on its remaining United States operations.
The Motel 6 addition will put 131,900 rooms under Accor's management, well ahead of the 109,600 rooms controlled by the Marriott chain. Though Holiday Inn is the world's largest chain, with 350,000 rooms, most of its hotels are franchise operations. Including franchised hotels, Accor will have around 160,000 rooms under its trademarks.
Many analysts said they favored the acquisition.
''This makes a tremendous amount of sense for Accor,'' said Burland B. East, a hotels analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards, in Los Angeles. ''The economy lodging business is essentially the only part of the domestic lodging industry that's profitable and growing.''
 
'The Best Lodging Company'
He called Motel 6 ''the best lodging company in the country,'' pointing to occupancy rates of 78 to 80 percent and gross margins of 45 to 50 percent, both significantly above its competitors. He also said Motel 6 management, led by Joseph McCarthy, its chairman, was ''the best in the industry.''
Mr. McCarthy and four top managers have agreed to stay on, according to Accor.
Motel 6, structured in the form of a limited partnership, anticipates revenues in 1990 of $475 million and operating income of more than $220 million.
But Lorna Statham, an analyst with Citicorp Investment Bank in London, questioned the wisdom of a United States acquisition for Accor. She noted that the company would be exposing itself to greater risk of a falling dollar.
''We're seeing a lot of profit warnings from French companies that have expanded into the U.S. in recent years and now are taking a hit,'' Ms. Statham said.
Mr. Pelisson said Accor was investing for the long haul, and even if the dollar fell further, it would likely bounce back eventually. ''If you can't bet long term on the United States, who are you going to bet on?'' he said.
Since the deal was announced, Accor's stock has lost 4.3 percent on the Paris Bourse, closing last week at 995 francs. The decline, analysts said, reflected fears that the company would be saddled with heavy debt, not only to acquire Motel 6 but also in assuming the American company's $980 million in long-term debt, due to rise to $1.4 billion by year-end.
Olivier de Surville, Accor's controller, said the company would try to refinance Motel 6's debt, especially because the company is paying 14 to 17 percent a year. ''This should result in a much better financial situation,'' Mr. de Surville said. To ease the burden, Accor will initially take only a 40 percent stake in a new company that will hold the Motel 6 equity, with the remaining 60 percent to be spread among a group of French and international banks. By exercising convertible debentures in the holding company two or three years from now, Accor will ultimately be able to take majority control.
Mr. Dubrule said Kohlberg, Kravis had started off negotiations asking $30 a share and Accor offering $17, ''but within two hours we arrived at $25 asked by K.K.R. and $20 offered by us.''
 
Expansion Plans
Accor plans to double the expansion rate for Motel 6 motels, which are placed along major highways, adding around 75 units a year, about half of which will be existing motels that will be acquired, renovated and reopened under the Motel 6 name.
With Motel 6, Accor will operate more than 775 economy motels by the end of the year. Executives envision linking the names of Motel 6 and Formule 1 to tap business from low-budget trans-Atlantic travelers.
Formule 1 now has 142 motels with 10,000 rooms and is expanding at the rate of one new motel a week. Accor plans 1,000 motels in the chain by the end of the decade, with a good number of them in Eastern Europe, which Mr. Pelisson considers ripe for the concept.
''There will be a lot of popular tourism in these countries, as well as growing internal movement such as by traveling salesmen for whom $25 is affordable,'' he said.
Formule 1 rooms are much more austere than even those of Motel 6, whose sparse, functional decor is aimed at business travelers on a budget and vacationers trying to save money. For 120 francs a night, Formule 1 lodgers sleep in prefabricated rooms of just 30 square feet each. There is one bathroom for every four rooms.
Even while advancing aggressively in the economy sector, Accor is also moving to reinforce its higher-priced hotel operations and expand into the tourism sector. In June Accor obtained a minority stake in Cie Internationale des Wagon-Lits & du Tourism, a French-Belgian holding company that operates the luxury Pullman hotel chain and a vast network of travel agencies. The company is currently angling for a strong say in management.

HEADLINE: G.M. Goal: Restore Saab's Luster

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TROLLHATTAN, Sweden

 BODY:
David J. Herman, the new chief executive of Saab Automobile A.B., faces more than the usual challenge in trying to turn a loss-ridden auto maker into one that can flourish in a crowded luxury car market.
The reason, as the native New Yorker and 17-year veteran of the General Motors Corporation acknowledges, is that not only must he improve Saab's performance to justify G.M.'s 50 percent stake, but he has to take on Sweden's social welfare state while trying. While that system has given workers a high standard of living and almost full employment, it has also delivered a 20 percent turnover and absenteeism.
''It's a paradox that these beautiful, healthy people should call in sick and not come to work,'' Mr. Herman said. ''But when they do come to work, they build high-quality'' products. ''So if you get that right, boy, you could really do something.'' 
To create an incentive for Swedes to work harder, the Social Democratic Government is slashing sky-high income tax rates while a debate rages about other steps to take. Mr. Herman, who joined Saab in January, has no intention of sitting on the sidelines.
He has no choice. At stake is not just the $600 million that General Motors paid to Saab-Scania A.B. for a 50 percent interest in Saab Automobile and the $100 million that G.M. injected into it. There is also G.M.'s future in luxury cars, a category in which the leading American car maker has been unsuccessful in Europe. A rejuvenated Saab could also help G.M. in the United States, where its Cadillac line, although on the rebound, lacks appeal to young, affluent professionals.
Mr. Herman's mission is to prove that G.M. was right in not seeking more of a sure thing: Jaguar P.L.C., the British car company that the Ford Motor Company bought last year after G.M., Jaguar's preferred partner, decided the price was too rich.
Some analysts think Ford's payment of $2.38 billion for Jaguar was far too high. Others say the Jaguar name is priceless. Saab has larger and more modern production capacity, they say, but its name does not carry the same cachet.
''Saab is a European name that has stood for high technology, performance and individuality,'' said Robert N. Murray, editor of Autocar and Motor, a British magazine for car enthusiasts. ''What Saab hasn't stood for is out-and-out luxury.''
Mr. Herman's financial strategy is to slash Saab's production costs, and his marketing strategy is to push Saab more firmly into the luxury car segment. There he hopes to compete against the likes of BMW and Mercedes-Benz by positioning Saabs as lower-priced alternatives.
Plans call for three models to be introduced by the mid-1990's. A replacement for the 900 line, which will sell for $17,000 to $25,000, is scheduled for late 1993. Next will be a top-of-the-line model, priced at $35,000 to $55,000, which will be positioned as a less expensive alternative to BMW's seven series. Then will come a replacement for the 9000, which will sell for $25,000 to $33,000, or just below the BMW five series.
 
Losses Continue This Year
The soft economies of Saab's three most important markets - the United States, Sweden and Britain -are not helping Mr. Herman and largely explain why Saab lost $163 million in the first four months of this year. Saab executives say they will be lucky if 1990 retail sales equal the 109,482 cars the company sold last year, when Saab lost $343.2 million on sales of $2.47 billion.
In 1989, Saab sold only 31,306 cars in the United States, its largest market, a sharp drop from the 47,414 sold in 1986, when total sales reached a record 127,180.
But Saab was so preoccupied in the fat years with meeting demand in the United States that it neglected to develop other markets, particularly in West Germany and France, which are now buoyant for other car makers.
 
Heritage in Aerospace
General Motors is striving to help Saab without destroying Saab's culture and brand uniqueness built on its heritage as an aerospace company. So G.M. sent only three executives to Saab: Mr. Herman; James P. Crumlish, the chief financial officer, and David West, head of long-term product planning.
Mr. West, a Briton, once designed cars for Aston Martin, the maker of hand-built, high-performance cars now owned by Ford. He combines that experience with 30 years at G.M. in Europe, where he last served as a product strategist.
Mr. Crumlish, an American, previously served as chief financial officer of G.M.'s Canadian joint venture with Suzuki, which makes small cars and utility vehicles that G.M. sells under the Geo name.
And Mr. Herman, who joined G.M. in 1973, has a record of improving worker productivity and lowering purchasing costs.
 
Earlier Battles
Mr. Herman, who is 44 years old, earned his ribbons in some tough battles. He had to deal with an economic depression in Chile, which caused the car market there to all but vanish, and with Government price controls in Colombia that made losses inevitable. He helped to develop Spain into an important manufacturing base for G.M. and persuaded Belgian assembly-line workers to accept 10-hour shifts. His last job was as executive director of parts and accessories at G.M. Europe. Along the way, he learned several languages and plans to add Swedish to his linguistic repertoire.
The responsibility for making sure G.M. does not steal Saab's soul weighs heavily on Mr. Herman. ''I'm ultimately making decisions about our future products,'' he said. ''If the team doesn't get that right, then we won't succeed. Believe me, that's something we remind ourselves of every single day.''
 
Bigger Engines Planned
While Saab's turbo-charged, four-cylinder engines deliver impressive power for their size, many German car buyers, for example, insist on bigger engines. G.M. Europe is developing a six-cylinder engine and hopes to provide Saab with a customized version in four years.
Engine aside, Saab's lineup is not in the same league as those of Mercedes and BMW. The 900, its biggest seller, has been continuously improved since its introduction in 1978, but it needs to be replaced. The bigger, more expensive 9000, which was introduced in 1984, suffers an uncommon detriment for a Saab: an undistinctive exterior. Moreover, Saab does not have anything that can compete with the likes of BMW's seven series of high-end luxury cars.
The hope is that this program will enable Saab to increase annual sales to 180,000 by the end of the decade. The ultimate goal is to increase sales to as much as 500,000, which would put Saab in the same league as Mercedes-Benz and BMW.
 
A More Urgent Task
Perhaps an even more urgent task is lowering production costs, which is vital if Saab is to break even by late 1991 as planned.
In June, Saab announced it was closing or selling four components plants in Sweden and Norway. That will reduce employment by more than 1,300, to at total of 16,000; save Saab about $35 million a year, and enable its engineers to focus on what really makes a Saab a Saab: a roomy interior, distinctive styling and the strong and efficient power train.
Sweden's Government has called on Saab to act responsibly and to try to find jobs for those laid off.
''The most caring thing a company can do for employees is survive and prosper,'' Mr. Crumlish said in an interview.
 
Production Shifts
The vast majority of 900-line production at a half-owned Finnish factory will be moved to a new plant at Malmo, in southern Sweden. In March, capacity-constrained G.M. Europe will begin assembling its new sports coupe, the Calibra, at the Finnish plant, whose other owner is Valmet of Finland. Saab's headquarters plant in Trollhattan, which is in southwestern Sweden, will continue to assemble the 9000.
That will leave Saab with a capacity to make 120,000 cars a year and it will be able to keep profits it would have had to share with Valmet.
In addition, Mr. Herman is enlisting G.M.'s clout to obtain better prices from outside suppliers for parts like steel, tires, batteries and windows. His goal is to reduce the component costs - now about $1 billion a year -by 20 percent within four years.
 
'Significantly Less Efficient'
High labor costs may prove the biggest challenge. A study by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that the average European luxury car maker uses 57 hours to weld, paint and assemble a car. ''Saab is significantly less efficient than the average,'' while Volvo, the leading Swedish car maker, is significantly better than average, said Daniel T. Jones, a professor of motor industry management at the University of Wales who was involved in the M.I.T. study.
Saab is slowly trying to pay more to workers with greater skills and a longer tenure, an unusual idea in a country that has long emphasized egalitarianism.
To get more workers to care, Saab is introducing career-development programs that get workers involved in decision-making.
''It seems like you have to get into a crisis before you change,'' Peter Moller, the 37-year-old production director, said. ''Now it's our turn.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Crown American Founder Moves Son to Key Post

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Frank J. Pasquerilla, who built a small masonry contracting business into a large real estate company, the Crown American Corporation, is relinquishing more responsibility to his 31-year-old son, Mark E. Pasquerilla.
The company said yesterday that Mark had been named president of the privately held company. Frank, 64, who has been president, chairman and chief executive, will continue as chairman and chief executive. 
''We have experienced tremendous growth in the last 10 years,'' Mark said, ''and now we must build for our future by enhancing efficiency and effectiveness.''
The 40-year-old company, which is still based in Johnstown, Pa., operates dozens of shopping malls, 21 hotels, 5 office buildings and a chain of 75 Hess's Department Stores. The company, which has assets of $1.3 billion, was recently among the bidders for the Bloomingdale's operations of the Campeau Corporation. A sale never did materialize.
Mark Pasquerilla has had little business experience outside the family company. ''I was in premed in college, but things take strange turns,'' he said yesterday. A graduate of the University of Notre Dame and a Fulbright Scholar, he received a master's degree from the London School of Economics. He joined the business in 1981 and was named executive vice president of operations in 1987.
His sister, Leah, 26, is special assistant to the chairman. Nicholas Pasquerilla, a brother of Frank, also works for the company as senior vice president for facilities planning.
Mark Pasquerilla said yesterday that he would be responsible for the company's overall financial performance, as well as matters of strategy and policy. The Hess's stores will continue to report to his father, who will also be responsible for corporate policies and goals, will plan and direct mergers and acquisitions and give guidance to his son and the board, the company said.
As for the prospects for the real estate business, Mark Pasquerilla said: ''I guess everybody is worred about the economy. It's rather soft right now, but we don't see signs of a recession.''

HEADLINE: Student Loan Fiscal Crisis

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
The Education Department said today that it would try to resolve a financial crisis at one of the nation's largest guarantors of student loans.
 
The Higher Education
Assistance Foundation, a nonprofit corporation based in Overland Park, Kan., guarantees nearly $10 billion in student loans. 
The foundation told the department that it faced serious financial problems.
Etta Fielek, a department spokeswoman, said Higher Education had asked Congress and the department to approve a federally assisted takeover by another guarantor, the Nebraska Student Loan Program. But Ms. Fielek said: ''There's a problem of scale.
There's concern on the part of the department that Nebraska would be too small an operation to consume something the magnitude of H.E.A.F.''
 
According to The Wall Street
Journal today, Higher Education expects a cash shortfall of $50 million to $100 million in the next 12 months.
 
Separately, the Student Loan
Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, does not expect problems at Higher Education to have any material effect on its earnings, a spokeswoman for Sallie Mae said. The foundation is a large guarantor of loans for Sallie Mae.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Decline in Hectic Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower yesterday, gyrating wildly most of the day, as credit market participants reacted to the huge swings in the stock market.
Before the stock market opened in New York, bond traders had pushed prices of some securities down by as much as 3/4 point, a slide that may have been a reaction to a slide on Japanese financial markets earlier.
But once stock prices started their deep initial slide after trading opened on the New York Stock Exchange, Treasury issues recovered rapidly. Later on, when stocks had recovered from their lows, traders began to sell securities again. 
''This was not your typical sleepy Monday,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the fixed-income and foreign-exchange markets. ''For the first time in quite a while, we had a classic flight-to-quality response in the bond market to what was going on in the stock market.''
 
Effect on Treasuries
The effect of the stock market slide was most readily reflected in the bidding for new three-month and six-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.49 percent, down sharply from the average rate of 7.62 percent at last week's sale. Six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.40 percent, compared with an average rate of 7.52 percent a week ago.
However, traders said the price decline that resumed once conditions seemed to stabilize in the stock market was indicative of the bond market's mood.
''Things look pretty negative for the credit markets,'' one bond trader said, ''the long end of the market, which for the past month or so has responded positively to comments by President Bush, Fed chairman Greenspan and now this slide in the stock market, wants to go down.''
 
Changes on Greenspan
To a significant part of the trading community, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, damaged his credibility as an inflation fighter last week when he indicated to Congress that the central bank had redirected its policy efforts to help shore up the banking system and the economy.
Mr. Greenspan returns to Capitol Hill today to provide members of the House of Representatives with his semiannual review of monetary policy and the economy.
''His image has suffered a little bit over the last week, and he may want to use the testimony as a way to reassert the Fed's longer-term commitment to fighting inflation,'' Mr. McCarthy said.
In late trading, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 1/8, down 7/32, to yield 8.55 percent, compared with 8.53 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the price of the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes dipped by 1/8 point, to a late offered price of 102 17/ 32, to yield 8.48 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 25/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.29 percent.
 
Impact on Other Markets
The steep slide in stock prices had a limited impact in other debt markets.
Traders in the market for high-yield ''junk bonds'' said that prices of most issues dipped by about 1/2 point, but that trading was quite light.
''Most market participants were sitting back, trying to find out why stock prices fell, and weren't finding any real reasons,'' said Kingman Penniman, a specialist in the high-yield market at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a research and credit-rating agency.
Traders in the seconday market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most actively quoted issues closed higher by 1/8 to 1/4 point after moving lower early in the day. Activity was light, the dealers said.

LENGTH: 456 words

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark, Declining to a 2 1/2-Year Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against most European currencies yesterday, hitting a two-and-a-half-year low against the West German mark.
It also fell against the yen, but not as sharply, reflecting the contined chronic weakness of the Japanese currency.
Traders said the big swings in the United States stock market yesterday played a role, as dollars were sold as the stock market declined -the Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 100 points at one time - and then purchased as stocks recovered. 
''It was all sparked by the stock market,'' said Liliana Nealon, vice president for foreign exchange sales at the Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. She said that the fall against the mark was so sharp yesterday that it was possible the dollar could rebound against the mark today. But if the stock market slide continues, she said, the dollar could fall further.
 
Focus on Rates
But some traders said that more important factors were the increasing prospects for lower United States interest rates, which makes the dollar a less attractive investment, and the sluggishness of the American economy.
Richard Witten, vice president of foreign exchange at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, said that the dollar was vulnerable now because the Federal Reserve's goal of avoiding a recession and a compromise to reduce the Federal budget deficit could lead to lower interest rates.
He argued that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, had indicated a possible rate lowering in his testiomy to Congress last week, but that it had taken several days for traders to digest his comments and act on them.
In New York yesterday, the dollar closed at 1.6220 marks, down from 1.6385 Friday and its lowest level since the beginning of 1988. The previous low this year was 1.6290 in May, also the lowest close in New York since Jan 4, 1988.
The dollar closed at 1.5850 on Jan. 4 and 1.6380 on Jan. 5, rising sharply as the United States and other central banks bought dollars in the market to keep the dollar from falling lower.
Against the Swiss franc, the dollar closed at 1.3815, down from 1.4043 on Friday, a new low for the year and the lowest since the beginning of 1988.
But against the yen, the dollar closed at 148.12, only down half a yen from 148.65 on Friday and still far above its low for this year of 143 yen.
The decline of the dollar against the yen was less sharp than against European currencies because the yen has been much weaker than other major currencies against the dollar all year. In addition, the talk of rising interest rates in Japan has clouded the outlook for the stock market there, reducing the attraction for foreign investors and decreasing the demand for yen.
